This expansion comes as part of the US company's aggressive growth in South-east Asia, with new locations set to open in Bangkok, Ho Chi Minh City, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, and Manila by the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore bank lending slips in September: MAS data
summary: Singapore bank lending dipped 0.1% in September to S$669.5 billion, reversing a 0.4% gain in August, due to a 0.2% decline in business lending. Construction loans, the largest business lending segment, fell for the first time in four months.

site_title: Marina View 'white' site, Kampong Java Road residential site and Tampines Ave 10 exec condo site released for sale under GLS
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) released two residential sites and one "white" site for sale under the second half 2018 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme, yielding approximately 2,000 residential units. The sites include a 11,643.3 sq m plot on Kampong Java Road, which can yield 435 units, and two other sites. The revised regulations will raise the minimum average unit size and lower the maximum units allowed in new developments, starting January 17, 2019.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit buying 23 Europe properties for 384 million euros
summary: Cromwell E-Reit is acquiring 23 properties across Europe for approximately 384.4 million euros, enhancing its portfolio with increased geographical diversity and freehold and perpetual leasehold assets. The manager plans to raise 224.1 million euros through an underwritten and renounceable rights issue to partially fund the acquisition, issuing 600.83 million new units at 0.373 euros per unit.

site_title: China factory activity slows in October amid trade war woes
summary: Chinese factory activity slowed in October with a Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 50.2, down from 50.8 in September. This is the second consecutive month of decline, adding to economic woes amid the US-China trade war and a weakening yuan. The slowdown is a concern for policymakers, who are already under pressure to maintain economic momentum.

site_title: Bank of Japan lowers inflation forecasts again
summary: The Bank of Japan lowered its inflation forecast for the fiscal year ending March 2019 to 0.9% from 1.1%, marking the latest revision to its target. Despite years of monetary easing, the bank has made little progress towards its 2.0% goal, having earlier dropped a 2020 target. The central bank left its easing program in place, as expected.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) released three residential sites for sale under the GLS Programme, potentially yielding 2,000 units. Business sentiment in Singapore worsened in Q4, mainly due to global trade tensions and property cooling measures. ExxonMobil is investing $10 million in the Singapore Energy Centre. Hyflux seeks more time to present its restructuring plan to creditors. Cromwell E-Reit acquired 23 European properties for $604.98 million. Singapore shares rose 1.8% to 3,018.80, while KKR invested $200 million in PropertyGuru.

images.alt_text: THE Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and the Housing & Development Board (HDB) have released two residential sites and one "white" site for sale under the second half 2018 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme, which could in all yield about 2,000 residential units.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: All Things Volkswagen
summary: Volkswagen's Chasing Cars podcast discussed various car-related topics, including reviews of the MG ZS Hybrid+, BMW's adrenaline tourism venture, and the road to electric vehicles. The podcast also highlighted emerging trends in the automotive industry. Meanwhile, in other news, OCBC Bank announced the appointment of Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing Helen Wong.

site_title: Yellen says she's concerned about Trump undermining trust in Federal Reserve
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed concern that President Donald Trump's criticism of the Fed may undermine public confidence in the central bank. Yellen supports more interest-rate increases to stabilize the economy and labor market, stating that at least two more rate hikes may be necessary. She expressed confidence in her successor, Jerome Powell, and noted that nothing is set in stone, but her current assessment suggests more rate increases are necessary.

site_title: FBI looking into bid to smear Russia probe chief Mueller
summary: The FBI is investigating an alleged scheme to pay women to accuse Robert Mueller, the head of the Russia collusion probe, of sexual harassment in an effort to discredit him. A woman who claims to have worked for Mueller decades ago reported being offered $20,000 to make false claims about him. Mueller's office referred the matter to the FBI, which is now looking into the allegations.

site_title: China battles 'unfair' trader image with import expo
summary: China is hosting a Shanghai import fair, opening next week, to counter charges that its markets aren't open. The event aims to attract foreign goods worth billions of dollars. However, the US is snubbing the gathering, and foreign business figures see it as a diversion to delay lifting barriers protecting China's markets. The move comes as China's trade war with the US escalates, with the country's GDP growth expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: 11 dead in Italy storms as wild weather sweeps Europe
summary: Wild storms in Europe have resulted in 11 deaths in Italy, with thousands left stranded and without power. The storms, which also affected France and other parts of the continent, caused widespread flooding and destroyed trees. Motorists were trapped in their cars and tourists were stuck in hotels due to thick snow in mountain regions. The severe weather has left a significant impact on European communities, highlighting the risks associated with extreme weather events.

site_title: Some 1,500 protest Trump, mourn US synagogue dead
summary: Around 1,500 people in Pittsburgh protested against US President Donald Trump and mourned 11 Jewish worshipers killed in a synagogue, demonstrating peacefully in song. The crowd marched through Squirrel Hill, a diverse neighborhood with a strong Jewish community, holding signs that read "President Hate, Leave Our State!" and "Trump's Lies Kill." The event came after a deadly attack at the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh.

site_title: US indicts 10 Chinese over scheme to steal aerospace tech
summary: The US has indicted 10 Chinese individuals, including two intelligence officers, for a five-year scheme to steal aerospace technology from US and French firms through hacking. The scheme, engineered by China's Ministry of State Security, targeted a turbofan engine used in commercial airliners. The indictments follow the extradition of a senior Chinese intelligence official from Belgium to stand trial in the US for running the alleged state-sponsored effort.

site_title: CDLHT posts 4.8% fall in Q3 DPS to 2.18 S cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) reported a 4.8% decline in third-quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.18 Singapore cents, due to the absence of contributions from divested properties and lower net property income (NPI) from its Singapore portfolio. Despite this, RevPAR for Singapore hotels rose 1.3% year-on-year, driven by a stronger Chinese outbound leisure travel season and events. CDLHT's CEO noted the company is in a transitionary period, focusing on asset enhancement opportunities to maximize long-term potential.

site_title: New generation of Latin American tech 'unicorns' making mark
summary: A new generation of Latin American tech startups, dubbed "unicorns," is emerging, defying economic struggles to achieve significant success. Companies like Nubank, 99, and Rappi are revolutionizing industries such as finance, transportation, and logistics, with valuations exceeding $1 billion. These young digital companies are not only thriving in the face of adversity but also creating jobs and improving services for millions of people across Latin America.

images.alt_text: Nubank is the online bank with the greatest number of clients outside of Asia. Fellow Brazilian startup 99 is a platform that connects 300,000 taxi drivers and chauffeurs to provide a competitive service in which passengers pay less while drivers earn more.

site_title: India deploys huge security for inauguration of world's biggest statue
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated the world's largest statue, the Statue of Unity, in Sardar Sarovar Dam, Gujarat, amidst heavy security and anticipation of protests by local communities displaced by the project. Over 5,000 police personnel were deployed to maintain order, with Air Force jets and helicopters set to shower flowers on the statue during the inauguration. Protests were called by local activists and community groups demanding compensation for land taken for the statue, which cost 29.9 billion rupees. The statue, a tribute to Indian independence hero Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, has sparked controversy over its construction and impact on local communities.

site_title: AIMS Fund Management advises unitholders to hold off action on winding up bid
summary: AIMS Property Securities Fund's responsible entity, AIMS Fund Management, advises unitholders to hold off on voting to wind up the fund following a notice of meeting from boutique firm Samuel Terry Asset Management. This is the second attempt to wind up the fund in less than two years, with Samuel Terry pairing up with Sandon Capital Investments to call for a vote on December 10. The two firms together hold approximately 18.6% of the fund's voting shares, prompting AIMS Fund Management to seek advice on the notice's validity.

site_title: Pacific trade pact shunned by Trump cleared for launch
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has cleared its final hurdle and can enter into force on December 30, 2018, despite US withdrawal. Australia, Japan, and Canada have ratified the 11-country pact, with five remaining members set to follow. The deal aims to lower tariffs, introduce new labour standards, and counter China's approach to commerce. Critics argue the US-less TPP will struggle to exert leverage on China, while proponents see it as a game-changer for rapidly growing economies. The pact's impact will be felt globally, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Centurion completes 280-bed student housing in Adelaide
summary: Centurion Corporation has completed its 280-bed student housing, dwell East End Adelaide, in Adelaide, Australia, at a cost of A$45.5 million. This is the group's 18th purpose-build student accommodation globally, with 5,754 beds across Australia, Singapore, the UK, and the US. The property is now open for registration and will be available for rent from January 2019. It is Centurion's second asset in Australia, following its acquisition of RMIT Village in 2014.

site_title: Programme matches DBS, its clients with startups to solve issues
summary: DBS Bank launched Startup Xchange, a programme matching the bank and its clients with startups to solve business problems using frontier technologies such as artificial intelligence, data science, and the Internet of Things. The programme aims to help businesses stay relevant in the long run.

site_title: Eurozone growth slows as mood sours
summary: The eurozone economy experienced slower-than-expected growth in the third quarter, with a 0.2% increase, the lowest in four years. This slowdown may worsen in the final quarter, raising concerns for the European Central Bank. The data also highlights growing concerns about Italy's economic health, with signs of distress in the country. This may impact the ECB's plans to end its asset-purchasing program in December, which was introduced in 2015 to boost inflation and economic growth.

site_title: UK to extend scheme to assist first-time property buyers until 2023
summary: The UK government has announced plans to extend its Help to Buy scheme for first-time property buyers until 2023, aiming to increase home ownership for younger voters. The interest-free loans will focus on debut home buyers, with some tweaks to the original policy. This move reflects the government's priority on housing for first-time buyers, while landlords remain a target for policy changes.

site_title: US dollar gets boost from trade war worries
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-and-a-half-month high against other currencies, driven by concerns over the escalating Sino-US trade war. Investors bought into the dollar after Bloomberg reported that the US was preparing to announce tariffs on all remaining Chinese imports by early December. The euro slipped as traders prepared for data releases, including eurozone GDP and German inflation, while the Japanese yen fell 0.4% to 112.855 against the US dollar.

site_title: Elias Green condo up for en bloc sale with S$780m reserve price
summary: The Elias Green condominium in Pasir Ris, Singapore, is up for en bloc sale with a reserve price of S$780 million. The site has a gross floor area of 723,627 sq ft and a plot ratio of 1.4, translating to S$1,078 psf ppr.

images.alt_text: Tender for the 516,877 square-foot development with 419 units closes on Jan 11, 2019. The owners of the development could each walk away with proceeds ranging from S$1.7 million to just below S$2 million.

site_title: IndoAgri Q3 profit plunges 91.3% to 8.74b rupiah on weak commodity prices
summary: Indofood Agri Resources (IndoAgri) reported a 91.3% decline in its Q3 profit to 8.74 billion rupiah due to weak commodity prices and increased CPO stock in its plantation division. Revenue was flat at 3.71 trillion rupiah, with the Edible Oils and Fats division showing a stronger performance. The decline was attributed to poor sales and profit in the plantation division.

site_title: Singapore most active in PE, VC activity in region in Q2: EY report
summary: Singapore witnessed the most private equity and venture capital activity in South-east Asia during Q2 2018, with 36 deals totaling over $1.3 billion. Singapore-based deals accounted for more than half of the aggregated value, with 20 deals worth $739 million.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: UOB enhances robo-advisory platform for corporate clients
summary: UOB Asset Management has enhanced its robo-advisory platform, UOBAM Invest, to allow corporate investors to customise their portfolios digitally to meet specific investment goals. This move makes United Overseas Bank the first Singapore bank to offer a robo-advisory platform for corporates, with its two local counterparts, DBS Bank and OCBC Bank, offering similar services only for retail investors.

site_title: ISR Capital gets approval for acquisition of mining asset
summary: ISR Capital has received shareholder approval to acquire a 60% stake in Tantalum Holding for S$3 million, marking progress in its long-drawn-out proposal since June 2018. Tantalum Holding owns a rare-earth mining concession in Madagascar, with ISR Capital's acquisition set to expand its rare-earth mining asset portfolio.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published by BT on October 30, 2018. The puzzle featured clues related to various topics, including a low-profile property trust and US jobless claims. Meanwhile, global news included the Asean agreement on Myanmar's election, China's push for openness in South-east Asia, and the surge of Chinese property shares. Additionally, Reliance Jio's India IPO was delayed, and China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions. These news stories were published on July 11, 2025.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust's DPU up 1.7%
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 1.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.41 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, driven by growth from its Rock Square mall in Guangzhou and multi-tenanted malls. The trust's distributable income jumped 10.5% to S$23.6 million, underpinned by strong mall performance.

images.alt_text: CEO Tan Tze Wooi says the company's strong financial position will open doors to acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Budget aims for bipartisan support for soft Brexit
summary: British Chancellor Philip Hammond presented a £103 billion budget aimed at securing bipartisan support for a Brexit deal, including higher state spending and lower taxes for 32 million workers. The move is seen as a gamble to persuade Parliament to agree to the proposed Brexit deal.

site_title: Scrabble's world champ masters the tiles - in two languages
summary: Nigel Richards, considered the world's best Scrabble player, won the World Scrabble Championships in London, using obscure words like "groutier" and "zonular" to clinch the title. Richards, known for his photographic memory and rare mathematical skills, has been described as the best player "of all time."

site_title: Asian markets see-saw on unclear outlook
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed session, with the Straits Times Index falling 15.09 points (0.5%) to 2,966.45, as investors reacted to the US-China trade spat. A Bloomberg report suggested the US would impose tariffs on all Chinese imports if November talks with President Xi Jinping fail, but US President Donald Trump later contradicted the report, sparking a reversal in early losses. Chinese regulators introduced measures to stabilize markets, including encouraging share buybacks and mergers, which helped the Shanghai Composite close 1% higher.

site_title: Budapest's underwater wonderland draws divers from far and wide
summary: Divers from around the world flock to Budapest to experience the city's unique underwater wonderland, featuring spectacular underwater caves beneath its pavements. For Laura Tuominen, this is the ultimate diving experience, offering a glimpse into a hidden world teeming with life. The caves, while not as well-known as coral reefs, provide a unique opportunity for divers to explore an underwater labyrinth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MindChamps PreSchool has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a preschool centre in Sydney, Australia, for A$2.97 million. The assets include the authorisation to provide childcare and education services, intellectual property rights, and plant and equipment. This acquisition will expand MindChamps PreSchool's presence in Australia.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex may stay - even with en bloc
summary: The Golden Mile Complex in Singapore may be spared from demolition despite being offered for sale at its reserve price of S$800 million. An outline application has been submitted to retain the existing 16-storey building and add a new block, pending authorities' approval. This development could save the iconic step-terraced building from being torn down, although an en bloc buyer would still be required to purchase the entire complex.

images.alt_text: Golden Mile Complex was completed in 1973, at a cost of S$18 million, designed in the Brutalist style. Its previous collective sale attempt was in 2010.

site_title: India's finance minister blames RBI for huge bad debts
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley blamed the Reserve Bank of India for failing to curb a lending spree between 2008-2014, resulting in banks with huge bad debts. This comes amid a row between the government and RBI, with RBI Deputy Governor Viral Acharya warning that undermining central bank independence could be catastrophic. The issue is relevant ahead of India's general election due by May 2019.

images.alt_text: Mr Jaitley says RBI's lax policies have contributed to banks' current woes.

site_title: China tells speculators not to hope for relaxed curbs on property purchases
summary: China's government warned property speculators not to expect relaxed curbs on property purchases, citing the need to maintain control over prices despite a slowing economy. Authorities have introduced measures to rein in prices since 2016, including restricting multiple home purchases and raising mortgage lending standards. The government stated it will not loosen curbs to spur investment, despite economic concerns. This move aims to maintain control over the property market and prevent price bubbles.

site_title: Venture Corp drops more than 4% on Tuesday
summary: Venture Corp, an electronics manufacturing services provider, saw its shares drop 4.44% on Tuesday, reaching a year-low of S$14.65 after a "torrid day of trading". The decline was largely due to a significant drop of 68 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Electrionic manufacturing services provider Venture Corporation's counter sank 4.44 per cent on Tuesday, capping a torrid day of trading for the contract manufacturing services provider.

site_title: ING to sell Italian real estate lease portfolio to Goldman-document
summary: ING plans to sell its remaining Italian real estate leasing portfolio to Goldman Sachs, with the deal expected to be signed by early December and closed in the first quarter of next year. The portfolio, comprising both performing and non-performing contracts, will result in 31 job losses in Italy.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q3 net down 9.4% on higher admin, staff costs
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 9.4% decline in net profit to S$17.8 million for the third quarter ended Sept 30, primarily due to increased administrative expenses and staff costs from opening more stores. Revenue rose 8% to S$227.9 million, driven by new store openings.

site_title: Indonesia summons Lippo's James Riady to assist in Meikarta bribery probe
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency has summoned Lippo Group deputy chairman James Riady as a witness in a bribery probe involving a $21 billion construction project. The probe, which has already resulted in the arrests of nine people, is part of Indonesia's efforts to crack down on widespread bribery in the country. Riady's summons follows a series of high-profile arrests and raises questions about the influence of powerful executives in the country's economy. The investigation is ongoing, but the summons suggests Indonesia is taking a strong stance against corruption.

images.alt_text: The summons of Mr Riady follows the arrests this month of nine people in connection with the investigation.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro's share price dropped 6% on Oct 10 following reports that Go-Jek, Indonesia's ride-hailing company, will enter the Singapore market independently, rather than partnering with ComfortDelGro. However, analysts believe the impact on ComfortDelGro's taxi business will be less severe than during the Uber/Grab rivalry.

site_title: Creative Technology posts Q1 net loss of US$6.1m
summary: Creative Technology posted a Q1 net loss of US$6.1 million, reversing from a profit of US$22.8 million in the same period last year, due to sales that fell 18% to US$13.2 million. The decline was attributed to uncertain market conditions affecting product sales. The company warned that H2 revenue may be below target and operating loss will be similar to H1.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler's net cash guidance cut overshadows special dividend pledge
summary: Fiat Chrysler reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings, but a lowered net cash forecast and a charge related to US diesel talks weighed on shares. The company confirmed its operating guidance for the full year and promised to pay 2 billion euros in special dividends. Despite a brief recovery, shares fell 2.2% after the earnings release.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings and promised to pay 2 billion euros (S$4.72 billion) in special dividends, but a lowered net cash forecast and a charge related to US diesel talks weighed on shares.

site_title: Trump says he plans to scrap birthright citizenship
summary: President Donald Trump announced plans to scrap a constitutional guarantee to citizenship for anyone born on US soil, bolstering his anti-immigration platform ahead of midterm elections. The move follows the deployment of over 5,000 troops to the Mexican border. The proposal is likely to be highly controversial, given questions over whether a president can meddle with the constitution. Trump's announcement comes as the country prepares for the midterm elections, which will take place a week later.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said he will scrap a constitutional guarantee to citizenship for anyone born on US soil in a headline-grabbing move bolstering his anti-immigration platform a week before midterm elections.

site_title: Hawking's signed thesis, wheelchair auctioned in London
summary: A copy of Stephen Hawking's signed doctorate thesis was unveiled at a Christie's auction in London, highlighting his personal items, including a signed wheelchair and a script from "The Simpsons." The collection showcases Hawking's brilliance, determination, and sense of humor, reflecting his lifetime work to unlock the universe's secrets. The auction features 22 lots, offering a glimpse into Hawking's life and legacy.

images.alt_text: A copy of Stephen Hawking's doctorate thesis signed in a shaky hand was unveiled Tuesday as the highlight of a new auction of the British physicist's personal items in London.

site_title: Thousands take to the streets to back ousted Sri Lankan PM
summary: Thousands of supporters of ousted Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe took to the streets in Colombo, blocking roads and confronting the country's newly appointed leader, Mahinda Rajapakse. Wickremesinghe condemned President Maithripala Sirisena for dismissing him and appointing Rajapakse, who is accused of human rights violations and corruption. The confrontation marks a significant showdown between the two factions, with Wickremesinghe's supporters demanding his reinstatement and Sirisena's administration facing widespread criticism. The situation remains tense, with no clear resolution in sight.

images.alt_text: Ousted prime minister Ranil Wickremesinghe arriving at the protest against his removal, near the Prime Minister's official residence in Colombo, on Oct 30.

site_title: Homeownership rate in the US rises as buyer competition cools
summary: The US homeownership rate increased to 64.4% in the third quarter, up from 63.9% in the previous year, according to a Census Bureau report. Buyer competition is cooling, allowing more time for buyers to find deals without bidding wars, and recent mortgage rate increases have also reduced demand. Experts attribute the rise in homeownership to the large population of Americans under 45, who are increasingly making their first purchase.

images.alt_text: The homeownership rate in the US increased in the third quarter, a sign that first-time buyers may be seeing the cooldown in housing as a buying opportunity.

site_title: US consumer confidence hits 18-year high on jobs, income views
summary: US consumer confidence reached an 18-year high in October, driven by optimism over jobs and the economy. The Conference Board reported a significant increase in shares saying current business conditions are good and jobs are plentiful. This boost in confidence is expected to support continued gains in consumer spending, which accelerated in the third quarter to its best pace since 2014. The solid job market is also helping to support household confidence ahead of the US midterm elections.

images.alt_text: US consumer confidence rose in October to an 18-year high amid optimism about jobs and the economy, according to figures Tuesday from the New York-based Conference Board.

site_title: Sakae's handling of sugar deal far from sweet
summary: Sakae Holdings' annual general meeting was described as "disappointing" by a shareholder, citing concerns over the company's sugar deal. The deal involved a multi-million-dollar impairment loss due to an unnamed client failing to pay for 9,343 tonnes of sugar worth US$4.3 million. The company's handling of the situation has raised questions about its business practices.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Starhill Global Reit Q1 DPU falls 4.2%
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 4.2% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.15 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended Sept 30, primarily due to lower net property income. This was attributed to lower contributions from the retail portfolio in Singapore and the depreciation of the Australian dollar. Net property income decreased 2.3% to S$40.4 million.

site_title: Ixom deal could lift Keppel Infrastructure Trust's DPU
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust is considering buying Australian chemicals business Ixom, which could boost its distribution per unit (DPU). The deal, potentially worth over A$1 billion, may raise concerns about the company's debt. Analysts weigh the potential benefits against the financial risks, with the trust's DPU growth being a key consideration.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Rock band Kiss promises 'unapologetic' final tour
summary: Kiss, a rock band known for their over-the-top performances, is launching a farewell concert tour in January 2019. The band, which has had a 45-year career, wants to deliver their signature shows while they can still do so. The tour will mark the end of an era for the band, which rose to fame in the 1970s with hits like "Rock and Roll All Nite." The farewell tour is a way for the band to say goodbye to their fans while still delivering the high-energy performances they are known for.

site_title: Far East H-Trust Q3 DPS higher on improved outlook
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's (Far East H-Trust) third quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) rose to 1.05 Singapore cents from 1.03 cents in the year-ago period, driven by improvements in the tourism sector and the addition of Oasia Hotel Downtown to its portfolio.

images.alt_text: An exterior shot of Oasia Hotel Downtown (right). The trust says there is "an uptick in overall market demand for rooms on the broader front". For its 9 hotels, revenue per available room grew 6.6%.

site_title: China's growth potential remains unmatched despite risks: GIC
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, believes China's growth potential remains unmatched despite various risks. GIC CEO Lim Chow Kiat stated that being an early and steady investor in China has financially benefited the fund, while also providing valuable lessons and building strong partnerships. Despite challenges, GIC remains committed to China, marking the 20th anniversary of its first China office.

images.alt_text: "By being an early and steady investor in China, we have benefitted financially, learned valuable lessons and built many strong partnerships," says Mr Lim.
Angela Tan

site_title: UK, Norway agree right to remain for their citizens after Brexit
summary: The UK and Norway have agreed that British citizens living in Norway and Norwegian citizens living in Britain will retain the right to remain residents, even in a no-deal Brexit scenario. The agreement, announced by UK Prime Minister May and Norwegian Prime Minister Erna Solberg, aims to provide comprehensive citizens' rights for affected individuals. The UK and Norway are working towards a deal to mirror any Brexit agreement reached with the EU.

site_title: MeGroup's public offer 1.3 times subscribed at the close of IPO
summary: MeGroup, a Malaysian car dealership and automotive parts maker, announced its initial public offering (IPO) received 90 valid applications for its 1.5 million shares, exceeding the 1.3 times subscription rate. The IPO, priced at S$0.23 per share, aims to raise S$2.4 million, with 16.5 million new shares to be issued.

site_title: Lawsuit against Noble Group subsidiary withdrawn
summary: Noble Group's subsidiary PT Pinang Coal Indonesia has had a lawsuit against PT Alhasanie withdrawn. The lawsuit, filed for damages exceeding US$20 million, concerned a breach of a Technical Services and Management Consulting Agreement from 2015. PT Pinang Coal Indonesia had previously submitted its own claim to Singapore arbitration, which is the agreed-upon forum for dispute resolution.

site_title: Manulife seeks dismissal of court case after insurance rule change
summary: Canadian insurer Manulife Financial Corp is seeking to dismiss a court case brought by hedge fund Mosten Investment LP over a Saskatchewan rule change limiting investor contributions to certain life insurance policies. The hedge fund claimed the right to put unlimited funds into an old universal life insurance policy, which pays out 4.5% a year on excess funds. Manulife's shares have fallen 14% since the research firm took a short position on the stock, citing the court case, which could be financially damaging to the company if lost.

site_title: Fragrance Group completes sale of Australian property for A$140m
summary: Fragrance Group's wholly-owned subsidiary sold its Melbourne property for A$140 million, satisfying the total consideration in cash upon completion on October 26. The sale was concluded due to slow unit take-up and higher construction costs in Melbourne. This marks a significant transaction for the company, demonstrating its ability to adapt to market conditions and make strategic decisions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain; foreigners sell for 9th session
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose on Tuesday, ending a five-session losing streak, but gains were limited by global uncertainties. Foreigners sold Kospi shares for the ninth consecutive day, netting 2.11 trillion won in losses over the past nine sessions. Authorities vowed to stabilize the markets and closely monitor global money flows.

site_title: ST Engineering's marine arm secures S$431m worth of contracts in Q3
summary: ST Engineering's marine arm secured S$431 million worth of contracts in the third quarter, including options for shipbuilding and repair services in Singapore and the US. The contracts include a US$244 million deal with the Naval Sea Systems Command for two Auxiliary Personnel Lighter Small APL Class Berthing Barges and a US$30 million new build contract for an Articulated Tug Barge. Deliveries are expected in 2020 and 2019, respectively.

site_title: Japfa Q3 net profit jumps on stronger performance across most business segments
summary: Japfa, an agri-food company, reported a net profit of US$14.3 million for the third quarter, up from US$3 million a year ago, driven by stronger performance across most business segments. Revenue rose 7.8% to US$877.4 million, despite weakening currencies in major subsidiaries. Earnings per share increased to 0.77 US cents from 0.17 cents a year ago.

site_title: US: Stocks struggle at the open
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Tuesday, with losses in high-growth names like Amazon and Netflix affecting the Nasdaq. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.16% to 24,482.04, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened flat.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened mixed on Tuesday, with losses in high-growth names including Amazon and Netflix keeping the Nasdaq under pressure, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial index opened flat.

site_title: Mastercard wins new partnerships without big boost to incentives
summary: Mastercard has secured new partnerships with banks and merchants without significantly increasing incentives, helping the company post a profit that exceeded estimates in the third quarter. The company offered $1.73 billion in rebates, an 18% increase from the previous year, but still below the estimated $1.84 billion. Fees from cross-border transactions rose 16% to $1.34 billion, despite a warning that fewer consumers are using credit cards to buy cryptocurrency.

images.alt_text: Mastercard Inc is winning new deals with banks and merchants even without sweetening its incentives as much as analysts expected, helping the world's second-largest payments network post profit that topped estimates in the third quarter.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit Q1 DPU dips 4.2%
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 4.2% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.15 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended Sept 30, mainly due to lower net property income. The decline was attributed to lower contributions from the retail portfolio in Singapore and the depreciation of the Australian dollar. Gross revenue and income available for distribution also fell 1.8% and 1.9% respectively.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust Q3 DPU up 1.7%
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 1.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.41 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by growth from its Rock Square mall in Guangzhou and multi-tenanted malls. The trust posted a 10.5% jump in distributable income to S$23.6 million, with a 2.2% increase in net property income. The annualized distribution yield was 7%. CRCT's active asset management strategy is progressing well, with 97.7% portfolio occupancy and 12.1% rental reversion for the quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend slump, end nearly 18-month low
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index closed at its lowest in nearly 18 months, ending the day 0.9% down at 24,585.53 points. The slump came despite China's securities regulator promising support for mainland markets. The CSI300 index rose 1.1% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 1% on Tuesday, contrasting the Hong Kong market's decline. The downturn was attributed to tepid investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's main Hang Seng index closed at its lowest in nearly 18 months on Tuesday after a choppy day for regional markets, as tepid investor sentiment outweighed promises of support for mainland markets by China's securities regulator.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.21 points to 1,685.94 on Tuesday, driven by a gain of two billion lots worth RM1.6 billion. The market saw a higher number of gainers (420) compared to losers (358).

site_title: Indonesian divers, "pinger locators", hunt for doomed plane's cockpit recorders
summary: Indonesian divers searched for the cockpit recorders of a crashed Lion Air 737 MAX 8, which killed 189 people, 13 minutes after take-off from Jakarta. The Boeing plane, one of the world's fastest-growing aviation markets, had a patchy safety record. The crash is expected to be Indonesia's second-worst air disaster. The "pinger locators" were trying to locate the recorders, while ground staff lost contact with the flight 13 minutes into its journey to Pangkal Pinang.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Navy Seals prepare to dive on the recovery mission for the crashed Lion Air flight JT-610 plane at Tanjung Pakis Sea, West Java, Indonesia 30 October 2018

site_title: Singapore most active in private equity, venture capital activity in region in Q2: EY report
summary: Private equity and venture capital activity in South-east Asia remained robust in Q2 2018, with $1.3 billion invested in 36 deals. Singapore accounted for over half of the aggregated deal value, with 20 deals worth $739 million. Top deals included the privatisation of Tat Hong Holdings and the close of Carousell's Series C round. Investment in small and mid-cap deals increased 87% year on year, driven by consumer products and technology sectors.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Second Chance Properties reports higher profit for Q4
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a 97% increase in net profit for the fourth quarter, reaching S$1.64 million, driven by lower expenses and a gain on fair valuation of properties. Revenue fell 13% year-over-year to S$8.98 million, while earnings per share rose to 0.22 cents. The company attributed the improvement to cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.5% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 15.09 points to 2,966.45. About 1.93 billion shares worth S$985 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 266 to 132, with all but eight index stocks closing lower. The most actively traded stock was Genting Singapore, which fell 1.7%.

site_title: Razer Phone 2 to launch Nov 3 exclusively on Singtel with quadruple data bundle
summary: The Razer Phone 2 will launch exclusively on Singtel on November 3, offering a promotional bundle that quadruples customers' monthly data allowance. The phone will be priced between S$98 and S$918, and customers who purchase the phone will receive free six months of Singtel's DATA X 4 data bundle and free Hearthstone card packs. Additionally, the first 100 customers will receive a limited edition #TEAMRAZER Gaming Pack.

site_title: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharma Q3 net profit up 7%
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group Corp reported a 7% year-on-year increase in net profit to 87.4 million yuan (S$17.4 million) for the third quarter, driven by a 21% rise in revenue to 1.58 billion yuan.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Australia shares turn higher as China bounces; NZ inches up
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.3% to 5,805.100, driven by China's attempt to stabilize its markets and boost liquidity. China's securities regulator encouraged share buybacks and mergers, while US President Donald Trump predicted a "great" deal with China, sparking a rally in metals and mining stocks. Australia's largest trading partner, China, also influenced the Australian dollar, which gained 0.5%. Financial stocks also benefited, with National Australia Bank and Commonwealth Bank rising 0.6% and 2.3% respectively.

site_title: Drugmakers tout new medicines as eye disease battle intensifies
summary: Switzerland's Roche and Novartis, along with other drugmakers, are releasing new treatments for age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a leading cause of blindness in older people. Roche's experimental treatment faricimab showed long-lasting effectiveness, while Novartis' RTH258 is being promoted for its ability to control fluid in the retina. Patent expiries in 2020 and potential pricing reforms under the Trump administration are expected to disrupt the market, potentially leading to cheaper alternatives from biosimilars.

site_title: In Japanese film 'Sea', guilt leads to revenge after sexual assault
summary: A Japanese film "Sea" by director Kensei Takahashi explores the theme of guilt and revenge after a young man fails to stop the rape of a school girl. The film, released at the Tokyo International Film Festival, follows Hiroshi, a shy high school student who witnesses the crime but is powerless to stop it. The story delves into themes of abandonment, indifference, and redemption, highlighting the importance of speaking out against sexual assault. Takahashi's film is his university graduation project, and he hopes it will lead to a main competition section in the festival.

images.alt_text: A young man suffers years of anguish after failing to stop the rape of a school girl in "Sea", a gritty film of revenge and redemption by new Japanese director Kensei Takahashi (R).

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as BP, Volkswagen beat expectations
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, their second day of gains, as BP and Volkswagen beat earnings expectations. The oil and autos sectors led gains, with BP jumping 4.3% and Volkswagen rising 4.6%. However, risk appetite remained cautious, with US stocks falling after a report of planned tariffs on all Chinese imports. Despite this, investors remained optimistic, with Asian markets showing slight gains, ahead of US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: The leading euro zone stocks index was up 0.4 per cent by 0829 GMT, while Germany's DAX rose 0.3 per cent and Britain's FTSE 100 climbed 0.4 per cent.

site_title: A tale of two islands: Brexit blues hit Caribbean cousins
summary: A Caribbean island, Anguilla, may face border changes due to Brexit, which could impact its free movement of goods and people with neighboring island Saint Martin. The island's economy relies heavily on services, including offshore finance and tourism, which could be disrupted by potential visa restrictions. Anguillians consider Saint Martin as their "downtown" and have close family ties, with around 300,000 people moving between the islands in 2016. The island's government plans to negotiate post-Brexit replacement aid with London, but there are concerns about the potential separation of families.

images.alt_text: The tiny Caribbean island of Anguilla lives in harmony with neighbouring Saint Martin but the borders could soon be going up in this sun-soaked paradise due to Brexit.

site_title: Apple Watch supplier under fire over China student labour
summary: Apple is investigating a factory in southwest China after a labour rights group said the tech giant's supplier forced student workers to assemble Apple Watches. The factory in Chongqing municipality allegedly compelled students to work night shifts to obtain vocational degrees. An investigation by Hong Kong-based NGO SACOM found that all 28 students interviewed had not voluntarily applied to work at the plant. The investigation raises concerns about Apple's supply chain practices and the exploitation of student workers in China.

images.alt_text: Apple is investigating a factory in southwest China after a labour rights group said the tech giant's supplier forced student workers to work "like robots" to assemble its popular Apple Watch.

site_title: Bus and train fares to rise by 6 cents per trip from Dec 29
summary: Bus and train fares in Singapore will rise by 6 cents per trip from December 29, with single-trip train fares and adult cash bus fares increasing by 10 cents. However, student and senior citizen card fares will only rise by 1 cent, while their cash fares remain unchanged. The fare increases are part of the latest annual revision approved by the Public Transport Council (PTC).

images.alt_text: Bus and train fares will rise by six cents per trip from Dec 29, as the latest annual revision approved by the Public Transport Council (PTC) kicks in.

site_title: Australia spy chief says 5G risks high, in nod to China firms' exclusion
summary: Australia's spy chief, Mike Burgess, says the country must restrict foreign firms with government ties from its 5G mobile communications network due to national security concerns. This comes after China's Huawei was banned from Australia's 5G network, straining bilateral relations. Burgess stated that a potential threat in the 5G network would be a threat to the whole network, and that different rules are required for 5G networks compared to 4G networks. Western intelligence agencies have raised concerns about Huawei's ties to the Chinese government.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q3 net profit dips 9.4% on higher staff, administrative costs
summary: Sheng Siong Group's third-quarter net profit declined 9.4% to S$17.8 million, primarily due to increased staff and administrative costs. Revenue rose 8% to S$227.9 million, driven by new store openings. Earnings per share dropped to 1.19 Singapore cents, down from 1.31 cents last year. The company attributed the decline to the higher operational costs associated with expanding its store network.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article discusses various news stories from around the world. Venture Corp's stock slid over 4% to S$14.65, a 50% drop from its peak in April. Vietnam was surprised by the US's announcement of tariffs, while the Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs. In other news, a Malaysian agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The article also covers other global news, including a UK economy shrinkage and a Thai court's potential decision on a PM's ethics case.

images.alt_text: Its counter shed 68 Singapore cents to S$14.65, its lowest level in the year to date.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise on bargain-hunting after falls
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.45% on Tuesday after investors bought on dips following recent declines, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 21,457.29. The recovery was driven by bargain-hunting after US President Donald Trump's administration planned more tariffs on China if talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping were unsuccessful. A weak yen and recoveries in Chinese shares also contributed to the market's improvement, with Sony and Nintendo among the top gainers.

site_title: Malaysia fiscal deficit may surprise market: BAML
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAML) analysts predict Malaysia's fiscal deficit may surprise the market, reaching 3.5% in 2019, up from 2.8% in 2018. The country's balance of payments picture is peaking, with fiscal risks underpriced. A large fiscal deterioration could lead to a negative watch from ratings agencies, putting pressure on Malaysian ringgit bonds. A credible medium-term fiscal consolidation plan is expected to be crucial in mitigating this risk.

site_title: UK turns the screws on landlords, doubles down on help to buy
summary: The UK government has announced plans to extend its Help to Buy policy until 2023, focusing on first-time buyers, and remove lettings relief for rental investors. The measures aim to boost home ownership among younger voters. Other key changes include scrapping stamp duty for shared ownership homes, providing more funding for housing infrastructure, and cutting property taxes for businesses with lower-value stores. The government also plans to introduce a 1% stamp duty surcharge for non-residents buying homes in England and Northern Ireland.

site_title: Asia airports present investment opportunities: DBS
summary: Asia's airport market presents investment opportunities due to rising passenger numbers and congested facilities. Airports in Thailand, Malaysia, and Beijing are highlighted as promising plays with a 'buy' rating. The Asia Pacific is expected to see a 20-year compound annual growth rate of 5.1% in air passenger traffic, reaching 3.5 billion passengers in 2036. However, 12 of Asia's top 20 airports were already operating at or above capacity in 2017, requiring $516 billion in investment over the next two decades.

site_title: Elias Green condo up for en bloc sale with S$780m reserve price
summary: The 419-unit Elias Green condominium in Pasir Ris is up for en bloc sale with a S$780 million reserve price. The owners of the 516,877 sq ft development can potentially receive between S$1.7 million to S$2 million each if the site is sold. The public tender was launched on October 29, allowing owners to bid on the site.

images.alt_text: Elias Green condominium has launched its collective sale tender at a reserve price of S$780 million.

site_title: China's hunger for safe food attracts Tencent-backer Hillhouse
summary: Hillhouse Capital Group, backed by Tencent Holdings, is investing up to $100 million in emerging consumer brands to expand globally in China, driven by the country's increasing demand for safe foods following tainted-food scandals. The first investment is in Little Freddie, an organic baby food and snack maker, and the partnership aims to help brands grow through better exposure, distribution, and marketing. Hillhouse has expertise in Asian consumers and retail, and its connections with Chinese technology and e-commerce companies will aid in tapping the Chinese market.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.79 points to 1,685.52. Volume was 28.44 million lots worth RM13.97 million. Losers beat gainers 88 to 40.

site_title: Can eating organic food lower your cancer risk?
summary: A French study of 70,000 adults found that frequent organic food consumers had a 25% lower risk of cancer overall, with significant reductions in lymphomas and postmenopausal breast cancers. The study, funded by public and government funds, suggests an organic-based diet could contribute to reducing cancer risk, but experts caution that more research is needed to validate the findings. Nutrition experts emphasize the importance of eating a variety of fruits and vegetables, regardless of whether they are organic or conventionally grown, to prevent cancer.

images.alt_text: People who buy organic food are usually convinced it is better for their health, and they are willing to pay dearly for it. But until now, evidence of the benefits of eating organic has been lacking.

site_title: Higher fuel costs clip Lufthansa's wings in third quarter
summary: Lufthansa reported a 10% drop in net profit in the third quarter, to 1.07 billion euros, due to higher fuel costs and integration costs related to Air Berlin's bankruptcy. Despite this, the company still beat analyst forecasts and reported a 1.5% revenue growth. Operating profit adjusted for one-off items fell 10.8% to 1.35 billion euros. Lufthansa confirmed its full-year objective for an adjusted operating profit "slightly lower" than in 2017.

images.alt_text: German airline giant Lufthansa reported falling profits in the third quarter, hit by higher fuel costs and the pricey integration of defunct competitor Air Berlin.

site_title: MindChamps to acquire Sydney preschool for A$2.97m
summary: MindChamps PreSchool, a mainboard-listed company, has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a preschool centre in Warriewood, Sydney, Australia for A$2.97 million. The acquisition is expected to have a positive impact on MindChamps' earnings per share for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2018. This is the company's 10th childcare centre in Sydney and New South Wales, expanding its operations.

site_title: Thai Sept factory output falls 2.6%, first decline in 17 months
summary: Thai manufacturing production index contracted 2.6% in September, marking the first decline in 17 months, according to the Industry Ministry. This decline was led by lower production of cars and rubber. Capacity utilisation was at 66.35% in September, down from August's revised 66.34%. The drop in production index was lower than the 0.5% drop predicted by a Reuters poll.

images.alt_text: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) in September contracted for the first time in 17 months, down 2.6 per cent from a year earlier, led by lower production of cars and rubber, the Industry Ministry said on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore office landlords get upper hand as rentals jump
summary: Singapore office landlords are gaining the upper hand in rental negotiations, with leasing rates in the city-state's prime business districts rising at the steepest pace in over four years. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's central area rent index rose 3% in the third quarter, with Grade A office rents expected to increase 11% this year and 9% in 2019. This trend is driven by accelerating demand and dwindling supply, with rents forecast to remain firm until at least 2022.

site_title: Gold down as dollar gains on US-China trade war fears
summary: Gold prices fell on Tuesday as the US dollar strengthened due to concerns over the Sino-US trade war and slowing global economic growth. The dollar gained value after reports that the US may impose tariffs on all remaining Chinese imports by early December. A stronger dollar makes gold more expensive for holders of other currencies, leading investors to shun riskier assets and buy the greenback.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged down on Tuesday as the US dollar firmed on renewed fears of an intensification in the Sino-US trade war and worries over slowing global economic growth.

site_title: Australia must assess security threats in 5G network: spy chief
summary: Australia must assess security threats in its 5G network due to critical infrastructure, said Mike Burgess, director-general of the Australian Signals Directorate. The country has restricted some firms from providing equipment for the network, including China's Huawei, amid concerns of espionage. The move is part of Australia's expanded national security rules, which also prevented Huawei from participating in the domestic broadband network. Western intelligence agencies have long raised concerns about Huawei's ties to the Chinese government, leading to similar restrictions in the US.

images.alt_text: Australia must restrict some firms from providing equipment for its 5G mobile communications network because it is such critical infrastructure, the head of the domestic intelligence agency said, helping to explain why China's Huawei was banned.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 2,971.63, down 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday at 2,971.63, down 0.3% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index (STI) saw 1.50 billion shares worth S$487 million change hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 207 to 110. Key stocks like Ezion Holdings, Genting Singapore, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding were among the most actively traded, while DBS and UOB shares declined, while OCBC Bank shares rose.

site_title: Apple Watch supplier under fire over China student labour
summary: Apple is investigating a factory in southwest China, operated by Quanta Computer, after a labor rights group reported that student workers were forced to assemble Apple Watches under the guise of "internships". The students, who were compelled to work to get their vocational degrees, reported working long hours, including night shifts, and having their graduation certificates withheld if they refused. The group, Students and Scholars Against Corporate Misbehaviour, claims the practice is widespread in China and violates labor law provisions. Apple has sold tens of millions of Apple Watches since its launch three years ago.

images.alt_text: Apple is investigating a factory in southwest China after a labour rights group said the tech giant's supplier forced student workers to work "like robots" to assemble its popular Apple Watch.

site_title: DBS matches bank and its customers with startups to solve business pain points
summary: DBS Bank launched Startup Xchange, a program matching the bank with startups and its clients to solve business problems using frontier technologies like AI, data science, and the Internet of Things. Since its pilot, 21 startups have been matched with DBS, resulting in 10 successful solutions and 10 more expected over the next 12 months. The program co-creates solutions with startups and DBS' clients, allowing startups to showcase their work and gain funding. DBS aims to support the startup ecosystem with a $10 million investment over five years.

images.alt_text: Since the launch of Jim, Southeast Asia's first virtual recruiter in April this year, CEO and co-founder of impress.ai Sudhanshu Ahuja (second from the left) and his team have raised USD 1.2 million in funding from investors. They have also increased their monthly revenue by five-fold. Sud is pictured here with the DBS Innovation Group team.

site_title: Regional airlines could benefit from deadly Lion Air crash, say Nomura analysts
summary: Regional airlines, including AirAsia and Garuda, may benefit from the Lion Air crash, which killed all 189 passengers, as travelers opt for higher airfares to avoid the carrier. Competitors like Singapore Airlines and Thai Airways could also see a temporary increase in yields. However, analysts warn that passenger growth, especially in Indonesia, may slow over the next three to six months due to the crash. Garuda and Indonesia AirAsia are expected to remain loss-making this year, according to Nomura analysts.

site_title: Cypriot farmers fear no-deal Brexit may hit livelihoods
summary: Cypriot farmers fear that a no-deal Brexit may lead to the loss of EU subsidies and the imposition of crippling tariffs, potentially crippling their livelihoods. Farmers working on British military bases, which are part of Britain's sovereign territory, are uncertain about their future after Brexit. The European Commission flags a 15.2% tariff for olive imports from non-EU countries, while the UK parliamentary committee warns that customs barriers will lapse after Brexit, requiring Cyprus to apply controls on goods crossing between the bases and the Republic of Cyprus.

images.alt_text: Olive farmer Andreas Fotiou steered carefully along a dusty lane in southwest Cyprus, en route from his village to nearby groves -- locations that could have clashing trade regimes, post-Brexit.

site_title: UOBAM rolls out first-in-market customised digital investment portfolios for corporate investors
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) launched the first-in-market customised digital investment portfolios for corporate investors, offering enhanced UOBAM Invest, a digital advisory service. Corporate investors can create a customised portfolio based on their specific goals, risk profile, and investment horizon through the online portal. The portfolios are generated by an optimisation algorithm and can be monitored and rebalanced quarterly by UOBAM. The minimum investment requirement is S$500,000, with a waived advisory fee until the end of the year.

site_title: China spurs share buybacks as latest tool to rescue market
summary: China has revised its law to allow companies to repurchase shares with approval from at least two-thirds of the board, and the nation's securities regulator has encouraged the practice. The move aims to protect shareholders' interests and fund convertible bond exchanges. Several companies, including Xinhu Zhongbao Co and Meisheng Cultural & Creative Corp, have already announced share buybacks, with some stocks experiencing significant price fluctuations. The new measure is the latest attempt by China to rescue its struggling stock market, which has been the worst performer in the world this year.

images.alt_text: Add share buybacks to the long list of measures that China has announced to stem a rout in its stock market, the worst performing in the world this year.

site_title: JTC launches Jalan Lam Huat site in Kranji for tender
summary: JTC has launched a 0.77-hectare industrial site in Kranji, Singapore, for tender under the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. The site, zoned B2 for heavy industries, has a 20-year lease and a gross plot ratio of 2.5 ha. This is the fourth of six Confirmed List sites for the second half of 2018. The tender will close on Dec 26, after a previous bid was rejected due to a low price.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure says it is preferred bidder for Blackstone's Ixom
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust has been selected as the preferred bidder for Blackstone's sale of Australian chemical firm Ixom Holdco. The business trust will complete due diligence and negotiate the share sale agreement, with the potential deal valued at approximately A$1 billion (S$980 million). Blackstone purchased Ixom from Orica in 2015 for A$750 million. The sale will add to Keppel's portfolio, which includes piped town gas and waste-to-energy plants.

site_title: Thousands of US troops head for southern border
summary: The US is deploying 5,200 active-duty troops to the southern border to bolster security and prevent a Central American migrant caravan from crossing the US-Mexico border. The move comes amid growing concerns over border security and immigration, with President Trump claiming the caravan poses a threat to national security. The deployment marks a significant increase in military presence along the border, with officials tracking over 3,500 migrants in southern Mexico. Trump plans to build tent cities for migrants seeking asylum, and the deployment has been criticized as a political move to fuel anti-immigrant rhetoric ahead of the midterms.

site_title: AddValue Technologies requests trading halt pending announcement
summary: AddValue Technologies, a communications technology firm, has requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The company had previously announced a collaboration agreement with Network Innovations to develop market opportunities for its iFleetONE-VMS, a maritime satellite communications terminal. The package helps commercial fishing vessels meet regulatory requirements. AddValue's business has been valued at S$123 million as of May 2017. The counter last traded at S$0.025, down 3.85% on Tuesday.

site_title: US agriculture chief says no plan to extend farm aid to offset tariffs
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue announced that the US Department of Agriculture will not extend a $12 billion aid package for farmers into 2019, citing the resilience of farmers in making market decisions. The aid was authorized in July to mitigate losses due to tariffs on US exports, particularly with China. Perdue stated that farmers will make their best business decisions without the expectation of aid, and the second tranche of aid is still being discussed.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Agriculture is not planning to extend an up to US$12 billion aid package for farmers into 2019, Secretary Sonny Perdue said on Monday, to mitigate farmer losses due to the imposition of tariffs on American exports.

site_title: More body parts found from crashed Lion Air plane
summary: Indonesian search teams recovered more remains from the wreckage of Lion Air Flight 610, which crashed into the Java Sea with 189 people on board. The Boeing-737 MAX suffered an instrument malfunction before plummeting into the water 13 minutes after takeoff. Dozens of divers are participating in the recovery effort, finding body parts, shoes, and personal items. The search for the main wreckage continues, with authorities ruling out finding survivors due to the severity of the impact. The incident raises questions about the safety of the Boeing-737 MAX, which was recently introduced into service.

images.alt_text: Indonesian search teams on Tuesday recovered more remains at the site of a crashed Lion Air jet that plunged into the sea with 189 people aboard, as a report said it had suffered an instrument malfunction the day before.

site_title: China regulator to propose 50% cut to car purchase tax
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission is proposing a 50% cut to car purchase tax, from 10% to 5%, to revive the country's flagging automotive market. The move is expected to stimulate car sales, which have been declining due to an ongoing trade war with the US. Carmakers such as Great Wall Motor, Geely Automobile, and Volkswagen AG surged in response to the news. The tax cut is seen as a key effort by China to support its $12 trillion economy, which has slowed this year amid trade friction.

images.alt_text: China is considering a tax cut to revive its flagging automotive market, according to people familiar with the matter, lending support to a key industry that's been damaged by an ongoing trade war with the US.

site_title: Sembcorp, EMA renew S$10m partnership to drive R&D, capabilities development in Singapore energy market
summary: Sembcorp Industries and the Energy Market Authority (EMA) have renewed a S$10 million partnership to drive research and development (R&D) and capabilities development in Singapore's energy market. The partnership aims to translate and commercialize R&D solutions in strategic areas, with potential trials at Sembcorp's facilities. The agreement reaffirms a joint commitment of over S$20 million, with grants awarded to three R&D projects. The partnership also includes initiatives to attract young people to explore careers in the energy sector through the Sembcorp-EMA Energy Challenge.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks skid in first few minutes
summary: Hong Kong and mainland stocks fell in the opening minutes of trade on October 30, 2018, tracking losses on Wall Street due to a report that the US plans to impose tariffs on all China imports as early as next month. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.28%, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.14%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Rohingya refugees sit on a makeshift boat as they are interrogated by the Border Guard Bangladesh after crossing the Bangladesh-Myanmar border, at Shah Porir Dwip near Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh November 9, 2017. REUTERS/Navesh Chitrakar/File Photo##########llfacebook8##########

site_title: Islamic banking faces growth challenge in Asean, but regulatory efforts can spur its development: Moody's
summary: Islamic banking faces growth challenges in Asean, but regulatory efforts can spur its development, according to Moody's. The sector has a solid foundation in the region, driven by robust economic environments and a significant Muslim population. However, government commitment is needed to develop the sector, as low public awareness and lack of incentives for banks to invest in Syariah-compliant services hinder growth. Countries like Malaysia and Indonesia are stepping up regulatory efforts, aiming to increase Islamic banking assets to 40% and 15% of total banking assets, respectively.

site_title: From streaming TV to Gmail, it's all about the cloud
summary: The cloud has become an essential part of digital lives, with servers handling programs and data remotely, accessible from devices worldwide. Cloud computing is being adopted by tech giants like Amazon, Google, Microsoft, and IBM, with IBM investing $34 billion in Red Hat, a pioneer of open-source cloud technology. The trend is expected to continue, with the public cloud services market projected to grow to $338 billion by 2022, driven by businesses' need for flexible and cost-effective computing solutions.

site_title: UK targets waste packaging with tax non on-recyclable plastics
summary: The UK is planning a tax on non-recyclable plastic packaging with less than 30% recycled material, targeting single-use plastics polluting the environment. Chancellor Philip Hammond announced the plan in the 2018 Budget, with a levy also being considered for single-use plastic cups. The move aims to reduce plastic waste, with only 14% of global plastic recycled, and is part of the UK's efforts to eliminate "avoidable" plastic waste by 2042.

images.alt_text: The UK is planning a tax on the import and manufacturing of non-recyclable plastic packaging in response to growing concern about waste materials polluting the environment.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.4% to 2,970.75
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.4% to 2,970.75 on Tuesday, with 42.4 million shares changing hands. The decline followed a similar trend in Tokyo and US stocks, amid fears of a fresh escalation in the US-China trade row. Losers outnumbered gainers 85 to 43, with DBS Holdings and UOB leading the decline. The drop was attributed to global market volatility, with investors cautious about the impact of trade tensions on earnings growth.

site_title: More grants to help Singapore businesses lift energy efficiency
summary: Singapore's businesses are receiving extra support to boost energy efficiency. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing unveiled new and increased grants for energy efficiency projects, with the goal of reducing carbon emissions. The Energy Market Authority and Economic Development Board are co-funding projects that can reduce at least 500,000 tonnes of carbon emissions annually, with the National Environment Agency offering 50% co-funding for small to medium enterprises. The enhanced grants are available starting January 1, 2019, for companies seeking to implement energy-efficient technologies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall St drops
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday following a drop on Wall Street, amid fears of a US-China trade escalation. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.48% to 21,048.62, while the Topix index lost 0.27% to 1,585.22. This marks the third straight session of decline. The market reaction is attributed to concerns over the US-China trade tensions and their impact on global markets.

site_title: Airbus 2018 delivery goal questioned by analysts ahead of results
summary: Airbus may struggle to meet its 2018 target of 800 jet deliveries, following production setbacks and engine delays. Analysts warn that the company needs to repeat the record delivery pattern of 2017 in the final quarter to meet the goal. Airbus has delivered 503 aircraft in the first nine months, leaving 37% of the target to be achieved in three months, a challenging task. The company faces issues with its best-selling A320neo and A321neo models, and engine delays have impacted deliveries.

images.alt_text: Airbus will have to equal a record final quarter for deliveries if the European planemaker is going to meet its overall 2018 targets following a series of production setbacks.

site_title: EMA in energy storage tie-up with PSA, Sembcorp Industries
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has partnered with PSA International and Sembcorp Industries to deploy Energy Storage Systems (ESS) on a commercial scale. ESS will help mitigate the intermittency of renewable energy sources and enhance energy resilience. The partnership aims to pilot use cases, design business models, and secure regulatory approvals for ESS deployment in Singapore. The EMA seeks to harness solar energy more effectively and maintain a stable energy supply, with potential applications in managing peak demand and optimizing energy needs.

site_title: Trumps accused of fraud over sham investment schemes
summary: A lawsuit filed in a Manhattan federal court accuses President Donald Trump and his company of promoting sham business opportunities, including the telecommunications marketing firm ACN, to thousands of investors, resulting in significant financial losses. The plaintiffs, described as "working-class Americans," claim they invested hundreds or thousands of dollars in ACN after watching promotional videos featuring Trump, with no promised profits. Trump received secret payments worth millions from ACN between 2005 and 2015, despite denying any promotion of the company for financial gain.

images.alt_text: A lawsuit filed Monday accuses President Donald Trump, his three eldest children and his eponymous company of seeking to entice people to invest in sham business opportunities.

site_title: EU draft plan on money laundering urges ECB review of recent bank scandals
summary: The European Union is discussing a draft plan to combat money laundering at banks, which would grant clearer powers to supervisors and review recent high-profile cases. The plan, set to be adopted in early December, mandates the European Central Bank and Commission to conduct a review by mid-2019, with the possibility of strengthening the EU's legal framework. This move comes in response to recent scandals at EU banks.

images.alt_text: European Union states are discussing an action plan to counter money laundering at banks that would involve clearer powers for supervisors and a review of a series of recent high-profile cases, a draft document seen by Reuters showed.

site_title: Singapore wants to repeat its water success story with energy: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore aims to replicate its successful water management model by investing in energy infrastructure, green energy, and innovative solutions. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing announced new projects, including a 100-fold increase in solar production capacity by 2030. The government plans to support energy storage systems and expand solar generation through initiatives like SolarRoof and SolarLand. This effort aims to enhance energy resilience and provide cleaner, more affordable, and reliable energy to the public.

images.alt_text: Singapore is looking to replicate its water success story in the realm of energy, by investing in infrastructure, tapping green energy and acting as a test-bed for innovative solutions here and abroad.

site_title: Singapore dollar 'too strong' relative to external and domestic factors: DBS Group Research
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its Singapore dollar forecast, citing the currency as "too strong" relative to external and domestic factors. Analysts now predict the USD/SGD will rise to 1.40 by the end of this year and stay above that level into 2019. The strong US dollar and weakening Asian currencies, including the Thai baht and South Korean won, are driving the shift. Domestic factors, such as low inflation, also support the downgrade, with CPI inflation within forecast range and no signs of core inflation exceeding 1-2%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Far East H-Trust, Cityneon, Sakae, DISA
summary: Noble Group issued a profit guidance, warning of a potential total net loss of $90-115 million in the third quarter. Far East Hospitality Trust reported improved distribution per stapled security due to tourism sector improvements. Cityneon Holdings is considering delisting and taking the company private after a significant stake purchase. Sakae Holdings lost $4.3 million on a sugar trading deal with a mysterious customer. DISA Limited announced that Samsung's Galaxy Tab A 8.0 model now features its Smart Lock protection.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam speaks to the media during a break in a "Virtual Tour to the Greater Bay Area for Foreign Business” held at China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Hong Kong with the HKSAR Government and the Guangdong Provincial Government meeting with foreign business leaders in person and virtually, in Hong Kong on November 26, 2021. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)##########HK8##########

site_title: Lornie Highway experiences slow traffic on first work day
summary: The new Lornie Highway, formerly known as Bukit Brown Road, experienced slow traffic on its first working day, with drivers reporting heavy traffic and uncertainty about the new road's exits. Analysts Mahindra Jith and Christine Lim experienced delays of over an hour and 15 minutes, respectively. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) attributed the slow traffic to the initial uncertainty among drivers and expected peak traffic during morning and evening hours. The LTA plans to monitor traffic conditions and provide traffic signs to aid navigation, with the full completion of the highway expected in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Nasa spacecraft breaks record for coming closest to Sun
summary: NASA's Parker Solar Probe broke the record for the closest human-made object to the Sun, passing 26.55 million miles from the Sun's surface on October 29, 2018. The spacecraft, launched in August, aims to protect Earth by studying solar storms. Its closest approach to the Sun is scheduled for October 31, with a final approach in 2024. The probe's speed relative to the Sun is expected to break a record on October 29, reaching 153,454 miles per hour.

site_title: Myanmar garment workers demand sacked colleagues get jobs back
summary: Dozens of striking Myanmar garment workers from a Chinese-owned factory, Fu Yuen Ltd, marched to the government compound in Yangon, demanding the reinstatement of 30 sacked colleagues. The workers, led by labor activists, met with Chief Minister Phyo Min Thein, agreeing to disperse in return for a second meeting. The protesters, who have been demonstrating since August, are seeking to protect workers' rights and dignity, and are unwilling to accept compensation.
