The meeting came as the European Union considers reinstating economic sanctions over Myanmar's treatment of Rohingya minority members.

images.alt_text: Dozens of striking workers from a Chinese-owned garment factory in Myanmar marched to a government compound in Yangon on Monday, securing a late-night meeting with the city's chief minister, as part of efforts to get sacked colleagues reinstated.

site_title: AusGroup gets SGX's in-principle nod for proposed placement, rights issue, redemption share issue
summary: AusGroup has received an in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to list up to 752.4 million rights shares, 1.05 billion subscription shares, and 80.3 million redemption shares. The company plans to proceed with the conditions and seek shareholder approval through an extraordinary general meeting. The proposed transactions are based on one rights share for every two existing shares, with issue prices of S$0.035 for rights shares and S$0.042 for redemption shares. AusGroup will set out details of the proposed transactions in a circular and circular.

site_title: US plans more China tariffs if Trump-Xi meeting fails, sources say
summary: The US is preparing to announce tariffs on all remaining Chinese imports by early December if talks between presidents Trump and Xi Jinping fail, three people familiar with the matter said. The tariffs, worth approximately US$257 billion, would apply to imports not already covered by previous rounds of tariffs. The move indicates the Trump administration's willingness to escalate the trade war with China, despite rising costs and global economic concerns.

site_title: US: Stocks end sharply lower as rally fades
summary: US stocks ended sharply lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 1.0% to 24,442.92, and the S&P 500 shedding 0.7% to 2,641.25. The decline was driven by aggressive selling amid worries over slowing earnings growth and uncertainty over the upcoming congressional elections. Large tech companies, including Amazon, Alphabet, and Netflix, were among the hardest hit. Analysts attributed the decline to concerns about future earnings and the potential for rising US interest rates to slow the economy.

site_title: UK airlines hit out at higher levy on long-haul flights
summary: UK airlines have criticized the government's decision to increase a tax on long-haul flights, citing it as a hindrance to their efforts to fly to new markets. The tax, known as Air Passenger Duty (APD), will rise in line with inflation for long-haul flights, but remain frozen for short-haul flights. Airlines such as British Airways and Virgin Atlantic argue that the tax stifles route development to new emerging markets, undermining Britain's 'Global Britain' post-Brexit. Industry leaders say the tax increase sends the wrong signal and will harm the aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Britain's aviation industry hit out at the government on Monday over its decision to increase a tax on long-haul flights, saying it made a mockery of the government's ambition for a 'Global Britain' after it leaves the European Union.

site_title: Australia bank earnings expected to be the worst in a decade
summary: Australia's big banks are expected to report their worst earnings season since the global financial crisis, with Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd and National Australia Bank Ltd expected to report declines in full-year cash profit. The banks face pressure from a softening housing market, margin pressure, and the cost of dealing with the fallout from an inquiry into misconduct in the financial industry. The inquiry found wrongdoing by the banks, leading to increased regulatory scrutiny and charges of over $800 million. The banks are also tightening lending standards amid a regulatory crackdown on risky loans.

images.alt_text: Australia's big banks are set for their worst earnings season since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Sakae sheds no further light on case of sugar trade turned sour
summary: Sakae Holdings' executive chairman, Douglas Foo, provided little insight into the US$4.3 million loss incurred from selling sugar to a delinquent customer, citing an ongoing police investigation. The company's independent directors were informed of the issue in August, but Foo claimed the focus was on recovery rather than corporate governance. Despite tough questions, the annual general meeting (AGM) was civil, with the company's board passing all resolutions. The incident is the latest in Sakae's history, following a six-year-long legal battle over a property investment that turned sour.

site_title: Aims Property Securities Fund faces another wind-up vote
summary: Boutique Australian firm Samuel Terry Asset Management has launched another attempt to wind up Aims Property Securities Fund, with a shareholder vote scheduled for December 10. The fund, controlled by 18.6% unit holders, is trading at a discount to its net asset value and has a portfolio allocation to related-party investments, sparking objections over fees. Aims Capital Management disputes these claims, stating fees are standard market practice and have not caused under-performance. The outcome of the vote is uncertain, with Samuel Terry threatening to go to court if the motion is voted down.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Merkel's move poses problems for the EU, analysts say
summary: Angela Merkel's decision to step down as German chancellor in 2021 creates uncertainty and potential paralysis for the EU, analysts warn. Merkel's departure makes it less likely for the EU to address key issues like migration and eurozone reform in the coming months. Diplomats say Merkel's influence is diminished, with one expert stating she "has taken herself immediately out of the game." This could hinder EU decision-making and exacerbate existing divisions.

site_title: Far East H-Trust Q3 DPS creeps up to 1.05 Singapore cents; net property income up 11.8% to S$27.7m
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) reported a 4.8% increase in income available for distribution to S$20.1 million for its third quarter, driven by improvements in the tourism sector and the addition of Oasia Hotel Downtown. Net property income grew 11.8% to S$27.7 million. Revenue per available room rose 6.6% to S$152, while average daily rates and occupancy increased 5.1% and 1.3 percentage points, respectively.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q3 net profit falls 26%
summary: Great Eastern Holdings, the insurance arm of OCBC Bank, reported a 26% drop in its third-quarter net profit to S$213.3 million, primarily due to lower operating and non-operating profits. Despite a 14% increase in gross premiums to S$3.54 billion and 14% rise in total weighted new sales to S$347.1 million, the company attributed the decline to reserve releases and asset-liability repositioning. CEO Khor Hock Seng attributed steady sales growth to improved distribution channels and new product introductions.

site_title: China says national team is buying, not selling, as stocks fall
summary: China's securities regulator stated that the country's "national team" of state investors, not funds, have increased their positions in the market. This comes after a $3.2 trillion selloff in Chinese shares, sparking concerns about government support. The regulator said the funds had actually liquidated their holdings, with some analysts speculating that the government redistributed money to other markets. The move aims to support cash-strapped companies and manage margin-call risks. The government's approach is more measured than previous efforts, focusing on helping non-state firms access financing.

site_title: Britain to issue new 50p coin in honour of Brexit
summary: Britain will issue a new 50p coin in Spring 2019 to commemorate its departure from the European Union, following the country's Brexit. The Royal Mint has announced the coin as part of a long-established tradition of producing commemorative coins.

site_title: Rebooting meritocracy - change needed across the rungs
summary: Singapore's meritocratic system, which rewards individuals based on ability and performance, has come under debate due to rising inequality. The system assumes equal opportunities for success, which is not the case in a society with social classes. The government has recognized this issue and is working to increase investment in early childhood education to level the playing field. Additionally, policies like SkillsFuture and Industry Transformation Maps aim to provide opportunities for lifelong skill development and a future-ready workforce, enabling Singaporeans to succeed regardless of their background.

site_title: German nurse serial killer on trial over 100 deaths
summary: Former German nurse Niels Hoegel, 41, will face trial over allegedly killing more than 100 patients, the largest serial killing trial in Germany's post-war history. Hoegel has already confessed to dozens of killings and is accused of intentionally administering medical overdoses to victims. Investigators say at least 36 patients died at a hospital in Oldenburg and about 64 more at a clinic in Delmenhorst between 2000 and 2005. The trial is expected to last until May and will involve dozens of victims' relatives and journalists.

site_title: Europe: Autos and banks help shares rebound after sell-off
summary: European shares rebounded 0.9% on Monday after a sell-off, with autos and banking stocks leading the gain. HSBC's higher-than-expected profit and Standard & Poor's decision to keep Italy's sovereign rating unchanged contributed to the rally. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 index remains on track for its worst monthly performance since 2015. Autos rose 3% after a report suggested China may halve its car purchase tax to support its struggling auto industry, while Italian banks rose due to a rating agency's decision to keep their credit rating unchanged.

site_title: Khashoggi fiancee hits at Trump response, warns of "money" influence
summary: Jamal Khashoggi's fiancée, Hatice Cengiz, criticized President Donald Trump's response to Khashoggi's killing, urging him to prioritize truth and justice. Cengiz stated that Trump's focus on US trade interests with Saudi Arabia undermines the pursuit of truth, and she demanded Riyadh disclose more details to bring those responsible to justice. She also emphasized that the Saudi authorities are responsible for Khashoggi's murder, which took place inside a Saudi diplomatic mission. Cengiz called for the West to stand up for human rights and democracy in the face of Khashoggi's killing.

site_title: Oil dips as Russia signals output will stay high
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday, with Brent crude futures falling 28 cents to $77.34 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 55 cents to $67.04 a barrel. The decline is attributed to Russia signaling that it will keep oil production levels high, despite concerns over a global oil market deficit. The move has fueled worries about demand for crude, contributing to the worst monthly performance since mid-2016.

site_title: Britain to target online giants with new 'Digital Services Tax'
summary: Britain is introducing a 'Digital Services Tax' to target online giants such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon, which generate significant revenue in the country. The tax will be levied on the revenue made by these platforms in the UK. The move comes as the existing system had not kept pace with changing digital business models. The announcement was made on October 29, 2018, and had a negative impact on the shares of affected companies, including Amazon and Google.

site_title: UK austerity ending, as long as Brexit deal gets done: Hammond
summary: UK finance minister Philip Hammond announced an end to austerity measures if the government secures a Brexit deal with the EU, increasing public spending and cutting taxes for households. Hammond stated that a Brexit deal would lead to a 'Deal Dividend' allowing for further funding. This move puts pressure on Conservative Party rebels to back Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plan, potentially ending the austerity period.

site_title: Engie moves Asia-Pacific headquarters from Thailand to Singapore
summary: Engie, a French energy company, announced it will relocate its Asia-Pacific headquarters from Thailand to Singapore, aiming to support regional sustainable growth opportunities. The new headquarters, expected to be fully operational by mid-2019, will be located at Golden-Agri Plaza. This move is part of Engie's strategy to focus on regional governments and businesses, while its other business units will be housed at the same location.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada by the Trump administration. Companies like Creative Technology and OCBC also reported concerns, with Creative Technology warning of potential revenue and operating loss. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and London's Heathrow considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) also announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Noble Group expects net loss of US$90-115m in Q3
summary: Noble Group expects a net loss of US$90-115m in Q3, primarily driven by restructuring expenses, net finance costs, and losses from discontinued operations. The total net loss for the nine months of 2018 is expected to be US$290-315m. This will result in a negative net asset position of approximately US$1.1 billion as of Sept 30, 2018, due to ongoing liquidity constraints and restructuring expenses.

site_title: Capitalism under siege
summary: The US is experiencing a crisis of confidence in its capitalist system, with widespread economic insecurity and a desire for greater equality. The impending mid-term election pits Democrats who advocate for a more humane capitalism against the Trump administration's tax cuts and rejection of socialism. A new book by Alan Greenspan and Adrian Wooldridge argues that the success of American capitalism lies in its ability to adapt and innovate, but the system is now facing challenges such as stagnant wages, income inequality, and corporate excess. The authors suggest that the distribution of income could be improved through public policies, but the future of capitalism remains uncertain.

site_title: HK co-working firm launches its largest global site in Singapore
summary: Campfire Collaborative, a Hong Kong-based co-working firm, has leased 16 floors at 139 Cecil Street in Singapore, its largest global site. The 85,000 square feet space will feature a rooftop sky pool, bar, outdoor dining area, and cabanas, along with food and beverage, retail, and fitness outlets. The site is set to open in the third quarter of 2019 and marks the company's entry into the Singapore market. This expansion follows previous deals in Hong Kong and Singapore, with Campfire now operating 20 co-working sites across four countries.

images.alt_text: The 85,000 sq ft of space at 139 Cecil Street after major renovations will feature a roof terrace with an "industry-first sky pool, rooftop bar, outdoor dining area and cabanas".

site_title: India home builders next in line of fire from banking fallout
summary: India's home builders are facing a banking liquidity crunch, turning to non-bank lenders as traditional financiers struggle with bad loans. The government's seizure of a shadow bank has further restricted access to funding, potentially derailing the property sector's recovery. With apartment sales increasing 8% and new project launches up 18% in the past year, companies with delayed projects or under-construction properties are at risk of defaulting on debt obligations, leading to potential price corrections of 5-10%. Smaller developers are more vulnerable to lending restrictions, while larger players may find opportunities for mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: HK's new-home sales tumble in first data since rate rise
summary: Hong Kong's new-home sales plummeted in October with a transaction value of HK$11.2 billion, the lowest level in 16 months. The number of transactions dropped by almost half from September, following the recent interest rate hike by Hong Kong banks. Buyers are stepping back due to unaffordable prices and concerns over the economy, with prices no longer seen as a bargain. The slowdown is a sign of weakness in the property market, potentially indicating a correction.

site_title: Pot firm backed by Russian banking veteran makes trading debut in Canada
summary: Curaleaf Inc, a US cannabis company backed by Russian banking veteran Boris Jordan, has raised US$350 million through a private placement valued at US$4 billion. The company is set to start trading on the Canadian Securities Exchange (CSE) after a reverse takeover, becoming one of the most valuable US pot firms. With marijuana now legal in Canada, US companies are seeking to take advantage of the industry's growth by listing on the CSE, which allows for listings by companies with US operations that violate federal law in the US.

site_title: OCBC pledges to be 'simply spot on' for customers
summary: OCBC Bank launched its new Brand Promise campaign, "Simply Spot On", on October 29, 2018, with the aim of listening to customers and providing tailored solutions to meet their needs. The pledge is not a marketing campaign, but a genuine commitment to customer satisfaction.

site_title: Silicon Valley can't escape the business of war
summary: Silicon Valley's tech companies are deeply tied to the military-industrial complex, despite efforts to distance themselves. The region's founders and early innovators, such as Fred Terman, received funding from the military to develop technologies that could be used for both war and peace. Today, companies like Amazon and Google are competing for Pentagon contracts, with Amazon likely to win the $10 billion cloud computing contract. CEO Jeff Bezos has stated that the US would be in trouble if big tech companies abandoned the military, highlighting the region's long history of involvement with the military.

site_title: Solar movement gaining popularity in New York City
summary: New York City is embracing solar power, but building solar panels is challenging due to the city's constantly changing landscape and strict regulations. Roof topography, fire codes, zoning, and setback rules limit available space, making it difficult to install solar panels compared to suburban or desert areas. Despite these challenges, solar developers like Peter Davidson are working to find creative solutions to harness the city's potential for renewable energy.

site_title: Singapore infrastructure a draw for pharma giants
summary: Pharmaceutical giant AbbVie has invested S$400 million to open a manufacturing plant at Tuas Biomedical Park in Singapore, supporting its global manufacturing pipeline. The move follows a 30% increase in clinical research programs in Singapore over the past decade, with six out of the top 10 drugs globally manufactured in the country. To stay ahead, Singapore is investing in advanced manufacturing capabilities, increasing demand for personalized medicine, and building a skilled talent pool. These factors are expected to bolster the capabilities of pharmaceutical companies to pioneer innovations and develop new technologies, positioning Singapore as a multidisciplinary hub for businesses.

images.alt_text: The Biopolis complex at Buona Vista. Today, six out of the top 10 drugs globally are made in Singapore, attesting to the city-state's success in attacting big players.

site_title: CEO-led group makes mandatory $1.30-a-share offer for Cityneon
summary: A CEO-led group, consisting of Cityneon Holdings executive chairman and group CEO Ron Tan, and Hong Kong entrepreneur Johnson Ko Chun Shun, has made a mandatory $1.30-a-share offer to acquire the remaining shares of Cityneon Holdings. The offer, valued at $219.3 million, is the second general offer for the company in two years. The delisting and privatization of the company will provide the offeror with greater control and management flexibility, and dispense with compliance costs associated with being listed.

site_title: No missing Mraz's good vibes at his biggest ever Singapore concert
summary: Jason Mraz performed his only 2018 Asia date at the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore, drawing a crowd of 15,000 despite a late afternoon downpour. The multi-Grammy winner delivered a 17-song setlist, including hits like "I'm Yours," "Lucky," and "I Won't Give Up." While newer songs from his album "Know." received lukewarm reception, classic songs and showmanship kept the audience engaged. Despite some issues with the oversized venue, the show's positive vibes and energy were undeniable, setting the stage for Mraz's return to Singapore in May 2019.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Deadly storms lash Italy leaving Venice afloat
summary: Deadly storms lashed Italy, killing at least five people, with two fatalities in Rome and a woman in Naples. Fierce winds and rains caused historic high waters in Venice, leaving the city afloat. A falling cornice also struck and killed an elderly lady near Savona. The storms followed a day of turmoil in the global markets, but the article about Italy's storm does not have any connection to the global news.

site_title: Consumer tissue group Essity hit by rising pulp, energy costs
summary: Essity, a Swedish hygiene products group, reported a 12% drop in core profit due to rising pulp and energy costs, despite higher selling prices and cost savings. The company's Consumer Tissue division saw a 38% profit decline, more than twice as much as expected. Essity expects to deliver annual savings of 900 million crowns and plans to implement additional price hikes in 2019. The company also announced changes to its organization structure to increase efficiency.

site_title: Weakened Merkel to step down as German chancellor in 2021
summary: Angela Merkel, Germany's long-serving chancellor, announced her plan to step down in 2021, citing the need to end coalition infighting and allow her government to focus on governing. Merkel, who has led Germany for 13 years, will first relinquish her CDU leadership position in December, followed by her departure as chancellor. Her decision comes amid a series of political crises, including electoral losses and a rise in the far-right AfD party, and is seen as a bid to stabilize her coalition. At least four candidates have declared interest in succeeding her, but Merkel has refused to name a successor.

site_title: Warning of 'bloodshed' as Sri Lanka's political crisis deepens
summary: Sri Lanka's speaker, Karu Jayasuriya, warns of "bloodshed" if the legislature remains suspended amid a constitutional crisis, following President Maithripala Sirisena's ousting of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe. The country's petroleum minister, Arjuna Ranatunga, was arrested after a man was killed in a shooting incident involving his bodyguards. Sirisena appointed Mahinda Rajapaksa as the new prime minister, sparking a period of political uncertainty and economic uncertainty, with Moody's warning of social tensions that could damage the economy.

site_title: Halloween slashes US box office rivals again
summary: Halloween remained the top US box office film in its second weekend, earning $32 million and crossing the $100 million mark. The film, directed by David Gordon Green and starring Jamie Lee Curtis, also generated $25 million overseas, bringing its worldwide total to $172 million. A Star Is Born took second place with $14 million, while Venom came in third with $10.8 million. The Halloween sequel's success may prompt studios to reconsider skipping the pre-Halloween frame.

site_title: Construction of new Mexico airport rejected in referendum
summary: Mexican voters rejected the construction of a new airport for the capital, with 69% of voters opting for repurposing the Santa Lucia military airport instead. The estimated $13 billion project was criticized by the incoming leftist president, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, who accused it of being a waste of taxpayer money and having a negative environmental impact. The business community, led by billionaire Carlos Slim, had supported the project, citing its potential to create jobs and ease airport congestion.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa - Habitat by Honestbee unveiled
summary: Money FM podcast "Coffee with Claressa" recently unveiled Honestbee's "Habitat", a new product. However, the article about "Habitat" is not provided, so no information can be provided about this product.

site_title: IBM chases Amazon into cloud with US$33b Red Hat purchase
summary: IBM has agreed to a $33 billion cash deal to acquire Red Hat, a US-based cloud software company, aiming to catapult itself into the top cloud software competitors. The acquisition gives IBM potential for real revenue growth and boosts its credentials in the fast-growing cloud market. The deal comes after IBM's CEO, Ginni Rometty, acknowledged the company's struggles to compete with Amazon and Microsoft, and follows a year in which IBM's stock has declined 31% over the past five years.

site_title: Collaborations key to going global
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are facing challenges in expanding globally, but partnerships with larger companies or multinational corporations (MNCs) can help them overcome these obstacles. Collaborations can provide access to financing, help SMEs maximize resources, and enable them to gain market insights. Programs such as the Partnerships for Capability Transformation initiative and trade associations' membership platforms are promoting collaborations between MNCs and SMEs. By working together, SMEs can move up the value chain, differentiate themselves, and increase their competitiveness in the global economy.

site_title: SPH, Y3 Technologies team up to launch B2B platform OctoRocket.asia
summary: SPH and Y3 Technologies launched OctoRocket.asia, a B2B e-commerce platform, to enable suppliers in South-east Asia to sell across borders more effectively. The joint venture aims to digitalise traditional trade processes, facilitating online orders and transactions, and capturing transactional data for trade financing, logistics, and customs clearance. The platform will start with the packaged food industry, allowing suppliers to reach buyers in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam. It is expected to provide connections for various transactions, easing problems with cross-border payments and customs clearance.

site_title: Two shophouses in Duxton Hill and one on Stanley Street sold for S$37.3m
summary: Veteran property investor Stanley Quek's entities are selling two shophouses in Duxton Hill and one on Stanley Street for S$37.3 million. The shophouses, on 99-year leasehold sites with 69 years left, were fully leased and sold with a gross yield of about 3.7%. The deals include a pair of adjoining shophouses in Duxton Hill and a freehold property on Stanley Street, which will be refurbished and leased out.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: A new partnership for a sustainable energy future in South-east Asia
summary: A new partnership aims to drive a sustainable energy future in South-east Asia, driven by rapid growth in renewables and technological advancements. The Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) member countries, with strong economic growth and young societies, are well-positioned to build a low-carbon economy. Global momentum behind renewable energy development has led to record additions, with 168 gigawatts of renewable energy capacity added last year, surpassing fossil fuels worldwide. The partnership seeks to capitalize on this momentum and promote sustainable growth and livelihoods in the region.

site_title: SIA will need to overcome challenges to sustain ultra-long-haul operations
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is set to relaunch ultra-long-haul flights to Los Angeles and San Francisco, with the airline's A350ULR aircraft offering a two-class configuration of 67 business class and 94 premium economy seats. Despite rising fuel prices, SIA has opted for fuel hedges to cushion the impact. The airline's success in sustaining these routes will depend on generating sufficient premium traffic, with Singapore being one of the few markets in South-east Asia with a premium base.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: In search of e-commerce proxies among Singapore stocks
summary: Analysts in Singapore are searching for e-commerce proxies among listed stocks, with warehouse owners and state-linked postal and freight service providers favored. However, new tech entrants like Synagie and Y Ventures are considered riskier investments due to their high costs and limited profitability. Analysts prefer established players like Ascendas Reit, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and SingPost, which have exposure to e-commerce and related sectors. The e-commerce market in Southeast Asia is expected to grow significantly, with a compounded annual growth rate of 32% from 2015 to 2025.

site_title: Japan retail sales growth slows in September; likely a drag on Q3 GDP
summary: Japan's retail sales grew 2.1% in September from the same period last year, but at a slower pace than the 2.7% increase in August. The slower growth is a concern for the country's economic expansion, which may be impacted by natural disasters and global trade tensions. The Bank of Japan will review the data and update its growth and inflation projections, which could affect its ability to hit its 2% inflation target. The slower growth also raises concerns about the central bank's ability to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Euro falls on report Merkel won't seek re-election as party chair
summary: The euro briefly weakened 0.4% to a day's low of US$1.136 after reports that German Chancellor Angela Merkel won't seek re-election as party chairwoman, ending her 13-year dominance of European politics. The dollar rose to a 10-week high as global growth concerns and risk-off markets boosted the greenback. The euro later recovered, while the dollar index rose 0.2% to 96.670. The news has significant implications for European politics and the global economy.

site_title: SembMarine wins deals worth more than S$200m
summary: Sembcorp Marine wins two deals worth over S$200m, including a contract to build three hybrid passenger ferries for Norwegian operator Norled AS, valued at over S$200m. The vessels will be delivered in 2020. The company also secured a contract for two topsides at Ørsted Wind Power's integrated yard facilities, expected to be delivered in 2021. Sembcorp Marine expects the deals to positively impact earnings but does not anticipate a significant impact on net tangible assets and earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Another suspicious package for CNN intercepted at post office
summary: A suspicious package addressed to CNN was intercepted at an Atlanta post office, three days after a man was arrested for sending parcel bombs to prominent Democrats and CNN critics. The CNN headquarters is not in danger, according to President Jeff Zucker. The suspect is set to appear in court to face charges related to the bombings.

site_title: US holds the key to emerging markets' prospects
summary: The US interest rate hike and a stronger dollar have led to significant declines in emerging markets' equities and bonds, with the MSCI EM equity index down 17% in US dollar terms from its January peak. Countries such as Argentina and Turkey have been hit hard, but the situation could worsen if US interest rates rise further. Despite the sell-off, valuations are now attractive, and some emerging markets, particularly those in Asia, offer attractive investment opportunities, such as China's dynamic economy and relatively cheap valuations in sectors like technology and domestic consumer services.

site_title: Report: London, Singapore excel as fintech hubs
summary: London and Singapore have emerged as successful fintech hubs due to five key factors: markets, talent, capital, regulation, and government support. However, the UK's more mature fintech market poses challenges in scaling up businesses and providing exit strategies for investors. In contrast, Singapore's startups focus on building user bases and attracting early-stage investments. The report suggests that London's collaborative approach and Singapore's emphasis on government support are key to their success, but both cities face difficulties in competing against established players.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: CCCS continues review of clinical labs' planned merger
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is reviewing the planned merger of private clinical laboratories Innovative Diagnostics and Quest Laboratories, acquired by TPG Capital Asia. The CCCS has concerns that the merger may reduce competition, as the two firms are seen as the closest competitors to each other. The government watchdog will assess the deal's impact and may require commitments from the parties involved to address potential concerns. The review is expected to be completed within 120 business days.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Go-Jek launches portal to sign up Singapore drivers
summary: Go-Jek, a Jakarta-based ride-hailing startup, has launched a portal in Singapore for drivers to pre-register and become its first driver-partners. This move is expected to bring competition to the local market dominated by Grab. By signing up, drivers will have the opportunity to join Go-Jek's platform and contribute to the company's expansion in the region.

images.alt_text: Interested drivers who provide their contact details will receive notifications from the company with details on how to apply to join the Go-Jek platform when the company launches.

site_title: Getting the green light to mitigate impact of climate change
summary: The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) released a special report on global warming, warning world leaders and individuals that rapid changes in habits are necessary to avoid major environmental, economic, and social damage. The report emphasizes the need for unprecedented efforts to mitigate climate change impacts, which are worsening globally, particularly in South-east Asia. Experts stress that closing one's eyes and waiting for better technologies is not a responsible approach, and that collective action is required to achieve significant results and avoid catastrophic consequences.

site_title: Asian markets mixed after week of sell-offs
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed session, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.3% higher despite a broader sell-off in North Asia. The STI's gains were largely due to Creative Technology's 12.6% spike, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dropped 2.2% due to concerns over China's slowing economy and weakening yuan. Other regional markets, such as the Nikkei and Kospi, ended lower, while the ASX 200 rose 1.1% driven by financials and materials listings.

site_title: WTO dispute over metal tariffs delayed with countries blocking action
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has delayed a dispute over US metal tariffs, with countries including the European Union, China, and the US blocking action until November. The US imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports on national security grounds, prompting retaliatory measures from other countries. The WTO's decision puts pressure on the organization, as a ruling in favor of the US could encourage other countries to enact protectionist measures under the guise of national security, while a ruling against the US could lead to further trade tensions and potential withdrawal by the Trump administration.

site_title: SP Group in bottom half of first Smart Grid Index report
summary: SP Group, a Singapore-based utility company, ranked in the bottom half of the first Smart Grid Index report, scoring 50 out of 100. The index, developed by SP Group, evaluates utilities on seven dimensions of smart grid development, with the top three utilities scoring 86, 82, and 79. Despite performing well in supply reliability, SP Group has room for improvement in the other six dimensions. The index aims to advance smart grid development and provide a platform for thought leadership, with endorsements from industry experts and stakeholders.

site_title: Merkel confirms she won't seek re-election to CDU party chair
summary: Angela Merkel, Germany's long-serving chancellor, has announced she will not seek re-election as head of her Christian Democratic party (CDU) and will not run for another term as chancellor in 2021. Merkel, citing the decline in support for her governing coalition, takes personal responsibility for the decline in support and will step down as party leader at the next CDU party congress in December. This marks the end of Merkel's nearly 13-year tenure as chancellor, during which she has been a dominant figure in European politics.

site_title: King Power empire faces uncertainty after death of Vichai
summary: Billionaire Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha's death has left the King Power empire uncertain, with his heirs facing the challenge of securing the future of Thailand's lucrative duty-free business. Vichai was a key figure in the company, known for its streetwise and connected approach. His passing has raised questions about the company's direction and future prospects.

site_title: Mnuchin is set to top Geithner's record
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is poised to sell a record amount of notes and bonds to finance the country's growing budget deficit. The Treasury will likely increase coupon-bearing debt sales at the quarterly refunding announcement, with some strategists predicting an unprecedented level of $81 billion, surpassing Timothy Geithner's previous record. The growing budget shortfall, fueled by tax reductions, spending hikes, and an aging population, will drive the need for increased issuance, with rising interest rates also contributing to the cost of financing the country's $15.3 trillion debt pile.

site_title: Merkel will step down as German chancellor at end of term
summary: Angela Merkel announced her decision to step down as German chancellor at the end of her term in 2021, following a series of political crises and regional vote debacles. She stated it's time to begin a new chapter, without specifying a successor. Merkel had earlier informed her centre-right Christian Democrats that she would not stand again to be the party chairman. This marks the end of Merkel's 15-year tenure as German chancellor.

site_title: Hyundai reshuffles executive ranks as scion drives change
summary: Hyundai Motor Group has created two new entities to develop future technologies and appointed new heads of product strategy and design in a reshuffle aimed at accelerating innovation and achieving sustainable growth. The move comes after the company reported a 67% drop in third-quarter net profit due to a US$440 million one-off charge related to US recalls. Euisun Chung, heir-apparent to the company's leadership, has overseen the shake-up, which also includes the creation of an artificial-intelligence lab and a fuel-cell electric vehicle business division.

site_title: World's worst currency shattering home buyers' dreams in Argentina
summary: Argentina's housing market has been severely impacted by the country's free-falling peso, with mortgage sales plummeting 75% to 3.36 billion pesos in September compared to April. Homes priced in US dollars make financing in pesos unaffordable for many, and interest rates have exposed a convoluted property-buying process. The number of homes bought with a mortgage in Buenos Aires has dropped 42% from a peak last December, and real estate agents report a significant slowdown in sales. The country's mortgage market collapse is linked to a currency crisis sparked by policy missteps and growing deficits.

site_title: Mobius sees US bear market if Democrats win House
summary: Veteran investor Mark Mobius warns that a Democratic Party majority in the US House of Representatives could push US stocks into a bear market, potentially falling 10-15% further. This shift in fund flows could redirect money to European, Japanese, and developing nation equities, where he sees "a lot of value" after dramatic declines. Mobius notes that a Democratic win would create policy gridlock, leading to a re-allocation of funds.

site_title: Key US inflation index slows again in September
summary: US inflation slowed for the second straight month in August, with the Personal Consumption Expenditures price index growing 2% compared to September last year. However, the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates again in December due to steady job creation and low unemployment. Consumer spending remained strong, with Americans buying more autos and paying for healthcare, despite moderating price pressures. The PCE index excluding food and fuel also rose 2% for the fifth month in a row, matching the Fed's target.

site_title: VW dismissed 'wrong guy' in diesel scandal, says fired engineer
summary: Volkswagen AG fired an engineer, Joern K, who headed the company's diesel-engine development, despite his lack of involvement with the EA 189 engine model at the center of the scandal. K's attorney claims the dismissal was "as simple as that, they fired the wrong guy." VW will explain the reasons for the dismissal in a filing in the coming weeks. The company has backed the dismissal, with labor representatives also supporting the decision, but K's attorney expects no charges will be filed in Germany.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering invests US$35 million in a new aircraft MRO complex in Pensacola, Florida. LTC Corp shareholders will vote on a proposed delisting on Nov 14, with a final exit offer price of S$0.925 per share. Sunpower Group secures a contract worth S$19.9 million with Fujian Billion Petrochemicals. Raffles Medical Group reports a 0.1% increase in profit and 1.2% increase in revenue for its third fiscal quarter. Micro-Mechanics reports a 12.9% decrease in net profit and 4.6% decrease in revenue for the first quarter. PhillipCapital's third ETF closes at S$1.00 after its first day of trading.

site_title: Figtree Holdings to dispose Australian mixed development project for A$35m
summary: Figtree Holdings is selling its Australian mixed development project, 303 La Trobe, in Melbourne for A$35 million (S$34.3 million). The project, comprising 215 residential units, retail, and communal facilities, was acquired in 2015 for A$17.4 million. Construction has not started, and the site comprises two freehold land parcels. The sale is expected to strengthen the group's cash position and contribute positively to its financial position and performance for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2019.

site_title: Consumer spending rises for 7th straight month in Sept
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.4% in September for a seventh straight month, with households buying more motor vehicles and healthcare. However, income recorded its smallest gain in over a year, at 0.2%, and wages rose only 0.2% after a 0.5% increase in August. The moderation in income and savings suggests the current pace of spending may not be sustainable, despite the economy growing at a 3.5% rate in the third quarter.

site_title: SP Group unveils blockchain-powered green energy platform
summary: SP Group, a Singapore-based energy company, has launched a blockchain-powered marketplace for renewable energy certificates (RECs). The platform aims to speed up REC trades, which have gained momentum since the Paris climate accord in 2015. This move is expected to increase the adoption of renewable energy sources in Singapore, contributing to the country's green energy goals. The launch of the platform is a significant step towards the development of a sustainable energy ecosystem in the region.

images.alt_text: SP Group launched on Monday a new blockchain-powered marketplace for renewable energy certificates (RECs).

site_title: SLA appoints Colliers to lease, manage 183 heritage bungalows
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has appointed Colliers to lease and manage 183 heritage bungalows across various Singapore neighbourhoods. The bungalows range in land area from 800 to 13,200 square meters and are located in exclusive residential areas. This appointment aims to preserve and protect these historic properties while ensuring their continued management and maintenance.

site_title: Lion Air plane with 189 on board crashes, no sign of survivors
summary: A Lion Air plane with 189 people on board, including at least 23 government officials and one Indian pilot, crashed into the sea off Indonesia's coast shortly after taking off from Jakarta. The Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft lost contact with ground officials 13 minutes into the flight, and no distress signal was received. No survivors have been found, making it Indonesia's second-worst air disaster since 1997. The cause of the crash is unknown, and investigators are focusing on the search and rescue operation, with the US National Transportation Safety Board set to assist with the inquiry.

site_title: Paul Tham appointed new CEO of Keppel Reit's manager
summary: Keppel Reit announced the appointment of Paul Tham Wei Hsing as CEO of its manager, effective January 1, 2019. Tham, currently deputy CEO and CFO of Keppel Capital International, will work with the board to determine the strategy for Keppel Reit. He previously held roles at Keppel Corporation, Bain & Company, and Keppel Reit's manager.

site_title: EasyJet makes progress with electric aircraft plan
summary: British airline easyJet is making progress with its plan to fly electric passenger jets on some routes by 2027. Partner Wright Electric is developing an electric engine for a nine-seater plane, with a successful test of a two-seater model. EasyJet CEO Johan Lundgren sees electric flying as a reality, with the airline aiming to use electric planes on routes of up to 500km within the decade. This move could reduce emissions, noise, and travel costs, and is seen as attractive to all airlines due to the high cost of jet fuel.

site_title: Figtree unit to dispose of Melbourne mixed development project for A$35m
summary: Figtree Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary, Figtree La Trobe, will sell a Melbourne mixed development project, 303 La Trobe, for A$35 million. The 44-storey project, launched in 2016, features 215 residential units and has sold approximately 97% of its units. The sale is expected to strengthen Figtree Holdings' cash position and contribute positively to its financial position and performance in 2019, with no material impact on earnings per share and net asset value per share in 2018.

site_title: Hamilton wins record-equalling fifth F1 world title
summary: Lewis Hamilton won his record-equalling fifth F1 world title, tying Juan Manuel Fangio's record, by finishing fourth in the Mexican Grand Prix. Hamilton's success came despite struggling with tyre-wear and a tough race, and he celebrated by executing doughnut wheel spins and hugging his team. He credited his team for their incredible work and said he feels humble and surreal about achieving the milestone. Hamilton is now the third driver to win five world championships, behind Michael Schumacher and Fangio.

images.alt_text: Hamilton's success - the third time he has taken the title without finishing on the race podium - elevated him to a supreme club alongside Juan Manuel Fangio with only seven-time champion Michael Schumacher ahead of him.

site_title: Hong Guan eyes a bigger catch with new ideas
summary: Hong Guan, a Singapore-based distributor of fishing tackle, has been exploring new ways to improve its business. Founded in 1942, the company has transformed from a traditional family business to a lifestyle business, focusing on its proprietary brand Pioneer Tackle. Hong Guan has successfully positioned its brand in 31 nations worldwide, thanks to its value proposition and customization efforts. The company continues to trial new ideas, such as re-entering the Singapore retail market and introducing services like boat chartering. Managing director Lee Seng Shoy encourages his team to challenge norms and come up with innovative ideas, urging business owners to "stay crazy" and "never give up" in the face of challenges.

site_title: Indian gov't very upset with central bank for making rift public - sources
summary: The Indian government is upset with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) for publicly discussing a rift with the government, fearing it could harm the country's image among investors. RBI Deputy Governor Viral Acharya warned that undermining a central bank's independence could be catastrophic. The government respects the RBI's autonomy but expects confidentiality, with officials labeling the public disclosure "unfortunate" and "potentially damaging". The rift is believed to be over the government's pressure to relax RBI policies and reduce its powers.

site_title: It's a bird, it's a plane - it's Super X-Fi
summary: Creative Technology shares rose 12.6% after announcing the US launch of its Super X-Fi audio devices, with shares closing at S$6.08. The company's CEO, Sim Wong Hoo, stated that it's "still early days" for the technology, citing the small Singapore market. The SXFI AMP headphone amplifier will be available for pre-order in the US at US$149.99, following a successful domestic launch. Analysts note that the stock's price rally may be unsustainable unless new sales figures are revealed.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Hong Kong's PAG sweetens takeover bid for Spring REIT
summary: Hong Kong-based private equity group PAG has increased its offer for Spring Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) to HK$5.30 per unit, a 76.7% premium to its previous closing price. The new offer, made on Monday, is final and unchanged from the original terms. PAG launched an unsolicited HK$5.24 billion takeover bid for Spring REIT on September 26.

site_title: Hong Kong co-working outfit Campfire Collaborative makes Singapore debut; leases all 16 floors at 139 Cecil St
summary: Campfire Collaborative, a Hong Kong-based co-working outfit, has made its Singapore debut by leasing all 16 floors at 139 Cecil Street, a 16-storey building currently undergoing renovation. The 85,000 square feet of space will feature a rooftop sky pool, bar, and dining area, as well as private and shared offices, food and beverage outlets, a gym, and car parking. The lease is reportedly for six years, marking Campfire's largest site globally. The startup aims to bring a unique co-working lifestyle platform to Singapore, offering work-life balance, wellness, and convenience under one roof.

site_title: CEOs say they want to promote women yet lack the plans to do so
summary: US CEOs claim to promote diversity and women, but lack concrete plans to achieve it. Only 40% of companies have action plans to advance women to senior leadership roles, and 41% have strategies for hiring more women. A study found that companies often lack accurate data on measures contributing to women's professional success, such as recruitment, retention, and pay. However, experts believe that once CEOs dedicate meaningful resources to diversity, change can happen quickly. By implementing basic business priorities, companies can make progress in promoting women's advancement.

site_title: DISA's smart lock solutions used on Samsung Galaxy tablets
summary: DISA Limited announced that Samsung's Galaxy Tab A 8.0" model now features Digital Safety (DiSa) Smart Lock protection. The smart lock installation occurs during manufacturing, rendering the tablet non-functional until purchased by the consumer. The 360-degree smart solution also includes 3S Smart Barcodes that eliminate return fraud and provide itemized history and tracking capabilities. This adoption is not expected to impact DISA's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,981.54, after Creative Technology jumped 12.5% on its US debut of Super X-Fi. Engie relocated its Asia-Pacific headquarters to Singapore, and SP launched a blockchain-powered platform for green energy credits. Go-Jek launched a portal for Singapore drivers to pre-register, and SLA appointed Colliers to lease and manage 183 heritage bungalows.

site_title: EU ministers say ending clock changes in 2019 'not realistic'
summary: EU transport ministers rejected the European Commission's proposal to end daylight savings time in 2019, citing challenges in implementing the change and concerns about a patchwork of time zones across Europe. Austria initially suggested 2021 as a start date, but ministers agreed that 2019 was too ambitious due to technical preparations needed for the airline industry and computing businesses. Disagreements remain, with some countries expressing skepticism about the principle of the change, and the UK's decision to keep daylight savings time posing a potential Brexit headache.

site_title: Noble Group expects to report Q3 net loss of US$90m-US$115m
summary: Noble Group expects a Q3 net loss of $90m-$115m, primarily driven by restructuring expenses, net finance costs, and losses from discontinued operations. The group's 9-month net loss is expected to be $290m-$315m. Noble projects restructuring expenses of $35m and a loss from discontinued operations of $55m. Despite the losses, the company's board believes the proposed restructuring will restore shareholders' equity and create a sustainable capital structure.

site_title: US cannabis firm Curaleaf falls in Canada trading debut
summary: US cannabis firm Curaleaf Holdings Inc made its trading debut in Toronto on October 29, 2018, after raising US$400 million in the biggest equity raising in Canada's marijuana industry. The company opened at C$8.70, 17.1% higher than the offer price, and has a market value of about US$4 billion. Curaleaf plans to expand to 41 stores by year-end and 69 by 2020, with cultivation facilities to supply those stores. The company's executive chairman attributed the strong demand to its multi-state footprint and the attraction of investing in a larger US player.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up at start of week
summary: European stocks rose at the start of the week, defying a mixed Asia and weaker US futures, as the brutal month nears its end. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose for the second time in three days, led by banks after HSBC Holdings' earnings beat expectations. Treasuries extended a gain from last week, with traders reining in expectations for tighter Fed policy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall for third straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for a third consecutive session, closing down 0.16% or 34.80 points to 21,149.80, amid weak market sentiment following recent volatility. The Nikkei 225 index lost 5.9% last week.

site_title: India's developers next in firing line from banking fallout
summary: India's banking liquidity crisis is affecting developers, threatening the country's property sector recovery. Non-bank lenders, which previously funded developers, are now struggling and reducing loan disbursements. This has halted the growth of the Indian real estate market, with 4.64 trillion rupees of residential projects in limbo. Companies with delayed projects are at risk of defaulting on debt obligations, with potential price corrections of 5-10% for under-construction properties. The government may intervene to prevent developer failures, but non-bank lenders will remain selective.

site_title: Novartis, Pfizer join forces on potentially lucrative fatty liver disease
summary: Novartis AG and Pfizer Inc have partnered to develop combination therapies for nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), a progressive fatty liver disease tied to obesity and diabetes epidemics. The Swiss and US drugmakers will collaborate on medicines for NASH, which is projected to become the leading cause of liver transplants by 2020. This move is seen as a strategic response to the growing market potential for treatments of this disease.

images.alt_text: Novartis AG and Pfizer Inc are teaming up to develop treatments for a liver disease many drug companies believe will become a hugely lucrative market, as it is tied to the obesity and diabetes epidemics.

site_title: HSBC sees little impact on Saudi Arabia investment after Khashoggi murder-CEO
summary: HSBC CEO John Flint stated that Saudi Arabia is unlikely to see a significant impact on its foreign trade and investment flows following the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Despite global outrage, industry and banking chiefs are likely to continue courting the kingdom due to its importance in global energy markets. HSBC has booked over $3 billion in profit from its investment in Saudi Arabia and will remain supportive of its local affiliate, Saudi British Bank. Other major investors, such as Norway's sovereign wealth fund, plan to increase their investments in the country.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 2,990.07, up 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday at 2,990.07, up 0.6% on the day. About 1.03 billion shares worth S$420 million changed hands, with Pine Capital being the most actively traded stock. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended with 18.05 points higher, while losers outnumbered gainers 145 to 134.

site_title: China regulator to propose 50% cut to car purchase tax
summary: China's top economic planning body is considering a 50% cut to car purchase tax to revive the country's flagging automotive market, which is facing its first decline in over two decades due to a trade war with the US. The proposed tax cut, which would apply to cars with engines no bigger than 1.6 liters, aims to stimulate the market and support the country's $12 trillion economy. If implemented, the measure could boost car sales and provide relief to carmakers such as Volkswagen and Ford, whose shares surged after the news.

images.alt_text: China is considering a tax cut to revive its flagging automotive market, according to people familiar with the matter, lending support to a key industry that's been damaged by an ongoing trade war with the US.

site_title: Hong Kong's new-home sales tumble in first data since rate rise
summary: Hong Kong's new-home sales plummeted to HK$11.2 billion in October, the lowest level in 16 months, following the recent interest rate hike by banks. Transactions dropped by almost half from September, with buyers retreating due to unaffordable prices and economic concerns. Prices for existing homes have fallen 2% since September, after more than quadrupling since 2003. Experts attribute the decline to developers' tactics of lowering prices, which no longer seem attractive to buyers.

site_title: Hyundai reshuffles executive ranks as scion drives change
summary: Hyundai Motor Group has reshuffled its executive ranks, creating two entities to develop future technologies, including an artificial-intelligence lab and a fuel-cell electric vehicle business division. The move aims to accelerate innovation and address market concerns about its earnings, following a two-thirds decline in third-quarter net profit. Euisun Chung, heir-apparent to the company's leadership, has been appointed executive vice chairman, with new heads of product strategy and design appointed to focus on autonomous cars, connected and electrified vehicles. The reshuffle is seen as an attempt to address the company's struggles with new technologies and declining profits.

site_title: SPH, Y3 Technologies form JV to launch B2B e-commerce platform
summary: SPH and Y3 Technologies launched OctoRocket.asia, a B2B e-commerce platform in Singapore, to enable suppliers in South-east Asia to sell across borders. The joint venture aims to digitise traditional trade processes, facilitating online orders and transactions, and providing accurate transactional data for trade financing, logistics, and customs clearance. The platform holds payments prior to successful receipt of goods, allowing suppliers to sell with more assurance.

site_title: HSBC reins in costs to post 28 per cent jump in Q3 profit, beating forecasts
summary: HSBC Holdings posted a 28% rise in third-quarter profit, beating forecasts, as the bank successfully reined in costs and invested in growth areas. The lender's reported pretax profit reached US$5.9 billion, driven by a 6.3% increase in revenue and a 2.4% decline in expenses. CEO John Flint outlined plans to spend US$17 billion on technology and China investments, aiming to boost growth in areas such as investment banking and private banking. The bank's shares rose sharply, and its common equity tier 1 ratio met analyst expectations.

site_title: Rio Tinto says Chinalco pact for Simandou iron ore project stake has lapsed
summary: Rio Tinto says a pact to sell its stake in the $20 billion Simandou iron ore project in Guinea to Chinese partner Aluminum Corp of China has lapsed. The non-binding agreement was struck two years ago, with Rio to receive payments of $1.1-1.3 billion for the stake. The parties will work with Guinea's government to explore other options to realise value from the asset, amid development issues and high estimated costs.

site_title: Mandatory unconditional cash offer launched for Cityneon Holdings
summary: Cityneon Holdings' executive chairman Ron Tan and Hong Kong entrepreneur Johnson Ko Chun Shun launched a mandatory unconditional cash offer to delist and take the company private. West Knighton Limited acquired a 68.95% stake in Cityneon for S$219.3 million, resulting in a S$1.30 per share offer price. The offer price is a 19.2% premium over the highest closing price. The delisting and privatization will provide greater control and management flexibility, as well as dispense with compliance costs associated with listed status. Shareholders will receive payment within seven business days of valid acceptances.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.38% on Monday, driven by bargain-buying, despite a sharp drop on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index closed at 24,812.04. In contrast, the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices fell 2.18% and 2.02%, respectively. The gains were largely unaffected by US trade tensions, which remain a concern for investors.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended Monday with gains thanks to bargain-buying after swinging through the day, but investors remain on edge following another sharp drop on Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares closed higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index up 0.3% to 2,981.54. About 1.62 billion shares worth S$867 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 202 to 162. Notable gains were seen in Genting Singapore and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding.

site_title: Budapest's underwater wonderland draws divers from far and wide
summary: A Hungarian diving centre has made Budapest's 19th-century underwater Janos Molnar cave system accessible to the public, attracting divers from around the world. The 7km-long cave system features stunning underwater landscapes and unique formations, with a balmy water temperature of 20-27 degrees Celsius year-round. To preserve the cave's ecosystem, daily dives are limited to 30 people, and costs range from $68 to $159 depending on the dive depth. The centre aims to promote responsible diving practices and scientific research, with marine biologists and experts studying the cave's unique creatures and ecosystems.

site_title: SP taps blockchain to power trades for green energy credits
summary: SP Group launched a blockchain-powered renewable energy certificate (REC) marketplace, enabling companies to trade RECs "conveniently, seamlessly and securely". The platform is backed by blockchain technology and features two REC buyers and three sellers. This move aims to facilitate the trading of green energy credits, promoting the adoption of renewable energy sources.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce after big IBM acquisition
summary: US stocks rose Monday, bouncing from multi-month lows after a big IBM acquisition and reports of a potential China tax cut on car purchases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.8%, the S&P 500 rose 1.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index also rose 1.2%. Analysts attributed the gains to bargain-hunting and optimism over the IBM deal, as well as China's potential tax cut, which lifted shares of Ford and General Motors. The S&P 500 ended the month down 8.7%.

images.alt_text: US stocks rose early Monday, bouncing from multi-month lows following a big IBM acquisition and reports that China is weighing a tax cut on car purchases.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q1 profit down 12.9% to S$4.5m
summary: Micro-Mechanics Holdings reported a 12.9% decline in Q1 net profit to S$4.5 million, mainly due to overhead costs. Revenue fell 4.6% to S$16.9 million, with China contributing one-third of revenue. The company expects to spend S$6 million in FY2019 to boost productivity and has initiated development of new materials and processes. However, it warned of "longer and more costly development cycles" ahead for the semiconductor industry.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: SLA appoints Colliers to lease, manage 183 black-and-white heritage bungalows
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has appointed Colliers to lease and manage 183 black-and-white heritage bungalows across various Singapore neighbourhoods. The properties, built in the late 19th century, range from 800 to 13,200 square meters and feature colonial design, large private gardens, and generous land space. Less than 30 properties are vacant and available for lease, with minimum two-year lease terms and varying rental rates. Leasing prospects remain positive amid stable economic growth, with multinational corporations potentially driving demand for these heritage houses.

site_title: Consumer tissue group Essity hit by rising pulp and energy costs
summary: Swedish hygiene products group Essity reported a 12% drop in core profit, with operating profit before amortisation and one-off items shrinking to 3.0 billion crowns, due to rising pulp and energy costs. The company's Consumer Tissue division saw a 38% profit decline, more than twice the expected drop. Essity is intensifying a savings program and expects annual savings of 900 million crowns. The company is also making changes to its organization structure to increase efficiency.

site_title: HSBC Q3 profit rises 28%, beats forecasts
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc reported a 28% rise in quarterly profit before tax to US$5.9 billion, beating analysts' estimates of US$5.6 billion. The increase was driven by the bank's Asia business and cost control. Despite rising costs, the bank's restructuring efforts have contributed to its growth. CEO John Flint has made investments, but rising costs remain a concern.

site_title: The auction season's real gems
summary: Christie's is hosting its Magnificent Jewels sale on December 5 at Rockefeller Center in New York, featuring over 370 lots of jewelry, including the Pink Legacy, a nearly 19-carat pink diamond, and the Alhambra collection from Van Cleef & Arpels. The sale is expected to be the largest in history, with estimated sales reaching US$137.2 million. The auction season has seen a significant increase in global sales, with annual sales growing from US$190 million in 1994 to over US$600 million today. The sale also includes contemporary jewelry, antique pieces, and items with notable backstories, such as the 1948 Suzanne Belperron diamond tube bracelet.

site_title: Spend don't splurge, investors tell miners as M&A, capex surges
summary: The world's largest miners are increasing spending and pursuing mergers and acquisitions as commodities prices decline, sparking concerns among investors. Capital expenditure is forecast to reach $35 billion this year, the first annual rise since 2013, driven by companies seeking growth and improving returns. Despite a cautious short-term outlook, industry executives believe that growth equals value for shareholders and that the fundamentals for some commodities will become more attractive in the medium term.

site_title: Engie to relocate Asia Pacific headquarters to Singapore
summary: Engie, a French gas utility, plans to relocate its Asia-Pacific headquarters to Singapore from Bangkok, Thailand, by the middle of next year. The move aims to more than double its workforce in the region over the next decade, with the current 4,000 staff contributing $3 billion to its global revenues. The new headquarters will be built with an S$80 million investment plan to establish a centre of expertise in energy efficiency.

site_title: Taiwan's economic growth seen slowing to 2.2% in Q3: poll
summary: Taiwan's economic growth is expected to slow to 2.2% in the third quarter, according to a Reuters poll of 15 economists. This slowdown is attributed to softening global demand for exports amid trade tensions between China and the US. Weaker demand for machinery partly offset strong orders for electronic gadgets for the year-end holiday season. Taiwan's central bank revised its economic growth forecast for the year to 2.73% and will maintain loose monetary policy to support growth.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's economic growth probably slowed in the third quarter due to softening global demand for exports amid trade tensions between China and the United States.

site_title: US urges Sri Lanka president to 'immediately reconvene parliament'
summary: The US State Department urged Sri Lanka's President Maithripala Sirisena to immediately reconvene parliament, allowing democratically elected representatives to determine the country's leadership. The move comes after Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe was sacked and a former strongman was installed as the new prime minister, sparking violent protests. One man was killed and two injured in clashes between loyalists and the president's supporters. Wickremesinghe has refused to vacate the prime minister's residence, claiming his dismissal was illegal. The US calls for an end to intimidation and violence.

site_title: Ahead of Facebook earnings, analysts hope it can't get any worse
summary: Facebook is set to report third-quarter revenue of $13.8 billion, up 34% from last year, and operating profit of $5.79 billion, ahead of its earnings on Tuesday. Analysts are cautiously optimistic, hoping the news won't be worse than expected, following a year of turmoil, including executive departures, a massive privacy breach, and struggles with misinformation. User engagement numbers and expenses will be closely watched, with investors hoping for no more negative surprises, as the company faces concerns over plateaued user growth and potential regulatory threats.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc. is nearing the end of its toughest year as a public company. Ahead of results on Tuesday, analysts are hoping the news can't get any worse.

site_title: State Street quant says buy China bank stocks on valuation gap
summary: State Street Global Advisors recommends buying Chinese bank stocks due to their cheap valuations and a government's ability to bail out the sector in case of instability. Chinese banks offer high return-on-equity levels, comparable to emerging markets, despite poor investor sentiment. The firm favors US banks as well, citing improving net interest margins and attractive valuations. The valuation gap between Chinese and US banks presents a "margin of safety" for investors.

site_title: ABB to invest US$150m in robotics factory in Shanghai
summary: ABB to invest US$150 million in a robotics factory in Shanghai, capitalizing on China's rising consumption and technological aspirations. The factory, expected to begin production by the end of 2020, will produce 100,000 robots annually, a quarter of global demand. The facility will also include an R&D center for artificial intelligence and machine learning, positioning ABB strongly in the competitive market. The investment aims to support China's industry growth and follows ABB's 13% growth in total orders in the country.

images.alt_text: ABB Ltd. will invest US$150 million to build a robotics factory in Shanghai, as the Swiss manufacturer capitalizes on China's rising consumption and aspiration to transform into a technology pioneer.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks higher at open on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.52% at the open on Monday, following last week's sharp losses. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,846.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.20% and 0.60%, respectively.

site_title: Billionaire clan in focus after Leicester owner's chopper crash
summary: Thai billionaire Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, chairman of Leicester City soccer club and King Power Group, died in a helicopter crash on October 27, 2018. The billionaire, worth $3.3 billion, led King Power's turnaround into a duty-free giant in Thailand, with a monopoly on duty-free stores at airports. His son Aiyawatt Srivaddhanaprabha, CEO of King Power, is also vice chairman of Leicester City. The family's business empire, including a stake in Thai AirAsia, is now under scrutiny as the family's fortune is derived mostly from its duty-free giant.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past the facade of Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha's duty-free business empire King Power in Bangkok. Leicester City's Thai billionaire boss Srivaddhanapraha was among five people killed when his helicopter crashed and burst into flames in the Premier League side's stadium car park moments after taking off from the pitch.

site_title: China liquor giant Moutai sees profits squeezed, shares drop
summary: China's luxury liquor giant Moutai Co Ltd posted its weakest quarterly profit growth since 2015, with net profit rising 2.7% in the three months to Sept. 30. The company's shares fell 10% on Monday, the maximum allowed, amid concerns about China's luxury market. Moutai's revenue rose 3.8% to 19.7 billion yuan, but its pungent liquor, baijiu, saw a decline in sales, weighing down the company's performance. The drop may raise concerns about the Chinese luxury market, which had seen a revival over the last year.

site_title: Australia shares gain across the board; NZ ticks up
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% on Monday, driven by financials and materials sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,728.200, its biggest daily advance in nearly two weeks. Financials stocks led the gain, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and National Australia Bank rising 1.2% and 1.3% respectively. Materials stocks also advanced, driven by a surge in Chinese iron ore futures. New Zealand's benchmark index ticked up 0.55% to 8,615.54.

site_title: Singapore launches world's first index for smart grid
summary: Singapore's SP Group launched the world's first index for smart grids, the Smart Grid Index (SGI), to measure and advance the development of smart grids globally. The index covers seven key aspects of an electricity grid, including supply reliability, data analytics, and customer empowerment. The top three utilities, US-based PG&E and SDGE, and Great Britain's UKPN, scored 86%, 82%, and 79% respectively. The index was developed using publicly available data from 45 utilities across 30 countries and has been endorsed by industry experts and stakeholders.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slump to near 23-month low, bond yields down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 1.5% on Monday, reaching its lowest in almost 23 months, amid continued selling by foreign and local investors. Bond yields decreased after the central bank chief's comments on monetary policy. The Financial Services Commission announced plans to invest 300 billion won in the junior Kosdaq stock market to stabilize the capital market. The Kospi index may fall to 1,900 by November, according to an economist.

site_title: LTC Corp shareholders to vote on proposed delisting at EGM on Nov 14
summary: LTC Corp shareholders will vote on a proposed delisting at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on November 14. Controlling shareholders, led by managing director Cheng Yong Liang's family, are offering a final exit price of S$0.925 in cash for each share, matching their earlier takeover bid. The family holds an 88.44% stake in the steel and property group. The vote aims to finalize the delisting proposal.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: StanChart first foreign bank to get China fund custody licence
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (China) has become the first foreign bank to receive a licence to provide custody services to domestic funds and asset managers in China. The licence, granted by the China Securities Regulatory Commission, will allow StanChart to hold clients' securities for safekeeping, expanding access to foreign asset managers operating in China. This move is seen as a step forward in China's efforts to open its capital markets, with StanChart CEO Jerry Zhang describing it as a "big step forward".

site_title: Samuel Terry moves again to wind up Aims Property Securities Fund
summary: Samuel Terry Asset Management, led by Fred Woollard, has made a third bid to wind up Aims Property Securities Fund, citing an "unacceptable" trading discount to its net asset value (NAV). The fund's net tangible assets were A$2.37 per unit, while units last closed at A$1.745. The bid, made in conjunction with Sandon Capital Investments, has a voting share of approximately 18.6% and aims to return unitholder funds to them, with a vote scheduled for December 10.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Go-Jek launches portal for Singapore drivers to pre-register
summary: Go-Jek has launched a portal for Singapore drivers to pre-register for its platform, marking the company's entry into the Singapore ride-hailing market. The portal, available at www.go-jek.com/sg/join, allows interested drivers to sign up and receive notifications on how to apply when the company launches. The move comes as the Land Transport Authority reviews the regulatory framework to ensure the market remains open and competitive, with a review expected to be completed by the middle of next year.

site_title: Lion Air jet with 189 on board crashes into sea shortly after take-off from Jakarta
summary: Indonesian authorities are searching for a Lion Air plane that crashed into the sea shortly after take-off from Jakarta, killing 189 people on board. The Boeing 737 Max 8 plane lost contact with air traffic controllers at 6:33am local time and plunged into Karawang Bay, West Java province. The cause of the crash is unknown, with officials saying they need to find the blackbox and recording from the air traffic control tower to determine the cause. The plane was originally scheduled to arrive at Pangkal Pinang at 7:10am, but never made it.

site_title: Singapore competition watchdog continues review of clinical laboratories' planned merger
