The article touches on various other topics, including the US high-yield bond segment, blockchain technology, and the importance of proper screening for coronary artery disease.

site_title: Debenhams to close up to 50 stores, takes one-time charge of £512m
summary: Debenhams, a British department-store chain, is closing up to 50 stores due to struggles with e-commerce and real estate costs. The company took a one-time charge of £512m and faces a make-or-break Christmas season. Despite online sales growth of 12%, the retailer must adapt to the digital age. CEO Sergio Bucher, who joined from Amazon, has a challenging task ahead to steer the company towards recovery.

site_title: My Funny Valentine
summary: Joel Pommerat's play "The Reunification Of The Two Koreas" is a French production translated into English, set to premiere in Singapore in November before traveling to France. The play explores the complexities of love through various stories, including romantic love, familial love, and platonic love, rather than focusing on the reunification of the two Koreas. The production features a cast of nine Singapore actors and is directed by Jacques Vincey, who notes that the search for a perfect partner can be agonising and full of pitfalls, but ultimately drives us to find someone to share our lives with.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Industrial property sector outlook stable in Q4 and beyond
summary: The industrial property sector in Singapore remains stable in Q3, with industrial prices edging up 0.1% and rents slipping 0.1% for the 14th consecutive quarter. Occupancy rates climbed 0.4 percentage point to a six-quarter-high of 89.1%. Experts expect rents and prices to stay stable, despite the impact of the US-China trade war, with some predicting a potential two-tiered market where high-spec and business park space sees rent increases, while older space declines. New industrial supply is expected to come onstream in Q4 and 2019, with vacancy rates for factory spaces expected to improve over the next two years.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: AA Reit's Q2 DPU dips 2% to 2.5 Singapore cents
summary: AA Reit reported a Q2 DPU of 2.50 Singapore cents, down 2% from the same period last year. Gross revenue was S$29.4 million, down 0.3%, and net property income was 0.5% lower at S$19.3 million. The Reit manager distributed S$17.1 million to unitholders, unchanged from the first quarter. AA Reit increased portfolio occupancy to 93.6% and executed 14 new leases. Net asset value per unit remained unchanged at S$1.37, and the counter rose S$0.01 to S$1.35.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands Q3 earnings slide on weaker VIP segment
summary: Marina Bay Sands' Q3 earnings declined 5.2% to US$419 million due to a 24.9% drop in VIP segment revenue. Total casino revenue fell 8.7% to US$532 million, offset by growth in hotel and non-gaming businesses. The company attributed the decline to weaker VIP play, but noted that hotel occupancy and revenue per available room increased. Las Vegas Sands Corp, the parent company, reported a 6% rise in Ebita to US$1.28 billion and a 2.2% increase in net income to US$699 million.

images.alt_text: The slower casino business offset growth in MBS' hotel and non-gaming businesses. Net revenue fell 2.9 per cent to US$766 million, although room revenue rose 12.8 per cent to US$106 million, while food and beverage sales rose 15.2 per cent to US$53 million. Mall revenue rose 4.8 per cent to US$44 million.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust DPU up 5% at 2.92 Singapore cents for Q3
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 5% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.92 Singapore cents, driven by a 1.1% rise in net property income to S$122.7 million. Gross revenue rose 0.7% to S$170.5 million, despite lower occupancy and rental rates. The trust's portfolio occupancy reached 98.5%, above the market level of 92.7%. CMT also announced plans to acquire the remaining 70% interest in Westgate and expects to complete the acquisition on November 1.

site_title: Duo offices, hotel, retail space said to be going on the market
summary: M+S Pte Ltd, a joint-venture between Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional and Singapore's Temasek Holdlings, has appointed JLL to advise on the sale of the office, hotel, and retail components of the Duo mixed-development project along Beach Road. The combined asking price for these components is approximately S$2 billion. The office component alone has an indicative pricing of S$1.6 billion, while the 342-room Andaz hotel is on the market for S$500 million. The sale of the 660 apartments has already been completed, and the office space occupancy rate is around 85%.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: New home sales in US reach 2-year low while mortgage rates go up
summary: US new home sales fell to a near two-year low in September, dropping 5.5% to 553,000 units, according to the Commerce Department. This decline, combined with higher mortgage rates and prices, is raising concerns that a protracted housing weakness could affect the broader economy. Economists blame the sluggishness on unaffordable home loans and higher house prices, outstripping wage growth. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate has increased over 80 basis points this year to 4.85%.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q3 DPU falls 4.1% to 3.23 cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 4.1% drop in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.23 cents, attributed to the absence of a one-off divestment gain from 2016. Excluding this, DPU from recurring operations grew 2.7% year-over-year. Net property income and gross revenue rose 2.5% each, driven by contributions from a new nursing facility and higher rents from Singapore properties. The Reit remains committed to preserving earnings amid rising interest rates and market uncertainties.

site_title: WPP goes through rough patch
summary: WPP plc, the world's largest advertising company, has cut its sales outlook and revealed a big earnings miss, with shares slumping 18%. New CEO Mark Read has pledged "decisive action and radical thinking" to reorganize the company, which has been slow to adapt to industry changes and underinvested in key areas. The company now expects sales to fall this year and its profit margin to decline, with a £3 billion sale of Kantar data and market research unit planned to reduce debt.

site_title: Wealth-flaunting meme goes viral in China
summary: A viral meme in China, known as the Wealth Flaunting Challenge, has been viewed over 2.3 billion times, with users posting pictures of themselves rolling in their own wealth, such as cash, jewelry, and luxury items. The meme has sparked a range of parodies, including counter-posts that poke fun at China's nouveau riche and even government agencies have joined in, using the meme for propaganda. The online reaction has been mixed, with some dismissing the posts as a waste of time, while others see it as a fun way to express oneself.

site_title: The slow death of Sears is a crisis for struggling malls
summary: Sears' bankruptcy filing marks the latest decline of traditional anchors in US malls, with 77 stores set to close. 24% of shopping centers have at least one vacant anchor, and mall owners see an opportunity to release space to hipper tenants that pay higher rents. However, the process takes time and money, and the decline of malls is accelerating, with some predicting an "epic hollowing-out" of the retail landscape.

images.alt_text: Sears Holding Corp filed for Chapter 11 protection on Oct 15, saying it will close 77 of its namesake stores in the next few months. Already, 24 per cent of those shopping centres have at least one vacant anchor of at least 25,000 square feet, according to CoStar Group Inc.

site_title: Britain's Lloyds Bank downplays Brexit fears as profits rise
summary: Lloyds Bank reported a Q3 pre-tax profit of £1.8 billion, despite Brexit fears. Finance chief George Culmer downplayed concerns about a chaotic Brexit, citing hopes for a deal before the UK's departure in March 2019. The bank pledged to maintain credit flows into the economy regardless of the outcome.

site_title: Saudis trumpet US$56b worth of deals as investment conference ends amid partial boycott
summary: Saudi Arabia announced $56 billion in deals signed at its investment conference, despite a partial boycott by US and European officials over the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The conference drew hundreds of businessmen and government officials, with US companies accounting for most of the contracts. Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said the killing would not derail the kingdom's reform drive, and a senior European banker predicted investment patterns would return to normal in a couple of months.

site_title: AMD follows broad tech decline with poor sales forecast, chip woes
summary: AMD reported disappointing results and forecasts, with its stock slumping 25% in extended trading. The chipmaker's fourth-quarter revenue forecast of $1.45 billion fell short of analysts' average estimate. Despite a 12% sales increase in its computing and graphics business, the company cited struggles in its graphics-chip unit and warned of a potential two-quarter decline in revenue. CEO Lisa Su expressed confidence in the company's server business and its ability to win market share from Intel.

site_title: Tesla's profit blowout undoes much of Musk's damage to stock
summary: Tesla reported its third quarter of positive earnings, beating analysts' expectations with an adjusted net income of $2.90 per share and free cash flow of $881 million. The company's shares surged 11% to $319.39, reversing losses from the previous months. Tesla's production of Model 3 sedans exceeded expectations, with buyers quickly taking delivery, making it the top-selling sedan in the US. Despite still being far from profitability, the results have shifted investor sentiment, with analysts praising the company's sustainable profitability and outlook for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Wine And Dine In Hong Kong
summary: The China Construction Bank (Asia) Hong Kong Wine & Dine Festival is now in its 10th year, featuring 450 booths serving fine wines and food. The festival includes the "10-Michelin-starred Dinner", an eight-course banquet by five visiting master chefs and two renowned Hong Kong chefs. New zones include International Street Eats with dishes from Taiwan, Korea, and Latin America, and the Coffee Fiesta. The event is held from October 25 to 28 at Central Harbourfront Event Space & Tamar Park. Tickets can be purchased on discoverhongkong.com/eng/winedinefestival.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Sembcorp Marine in the red again with Q3 net loss of S$29.8m
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a Q3 net loss of S$29.8 million, its second consecutive loss, due to low business volumes and the sale of a semi-submersible rig at a loss. Revenue rose 60.2% to S$1.17 billion, driven by the rigs and floaters segment, but the repairs and upgrades division saw a 83.2% decline. The company expects low business volumes to continue and a narrowing operating loss for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Has America lost its entrepreneurial edge?
summary: A new study reveals that the US has lost its monopoly on entrepreneurship, with globalisation and foreign investment increasing. The US share of venture-capital investment declined from 95% in the 1990s to 50% between 2005 and 2017. Foreign venture-capital spending grew faster, with China emerging as a major challenger to Silicon Valley. The US needs to adapt to this shift by creating special visas for startup founders and protecting its position as a hub for high-tech entrepreneurs.

site_title: Halloween Spookfest
summary: Golden Village is hosting its 12th Horrorthon from Oct 26 to 31, featuring four indie horror films that have never been shown in Singapore, including Still/Born, Ruin Me, Terrified, and Living Space. A S$40 ticket grants access to two movies, popcorn, and a drink.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Growth engine for the world's carmakers becoming a liability
summary: China's auto market, the world's largest, is slowing due to a weakening economy and the rise of ride-hailing and car-sharing services. Sales have been flat or lower for the year, prompting major carmakers such as Volkswagen, Ford, and Renault to downgrade their growth forecasts. The trend is expected to shift consumer preferences, with shared autos accounting for 30% of passenger vehicles by 2025. Carmakers are adapting by expanding into new transport services and electrified vehicles, but traditional car ownership is declining.

site_title: Fortifying Fungi
summary: Red mushrooms, found only in China's Mount Wuyi, have unique characteristics. They grow only at certain altitudes, under high temperature and humidity, and have a short 15-day growth cycle. Picking is only possible at 3am when the caps are unopened, and they retain nutritional value and taste. The mushrooms can be enjoyed as a savory tea, braised with beancurd skin, or cooked in double-boiled chicken soup. Putien restaurant offers a limited supply of the red mushrooms for its seasonal menu until November 30.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: China's HNA Group seeks buyer for US$300m 'Dream Jet': sources
summary: China's HNA Group is selling its luxurious "Dream Jet", a 40-seat Boeing 787 with a "seven-star" hotel-style cabin, for at least $300 million. The jet, which has been used by top HNA officials and Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, is part of the company's efforts to sell assets worth over $20 billion amid pressure from Beijing. The sale price may be difficult due to the limited market for wide-body private jets and the high cost of custom interiors, which could reduce the sale price to two-thirds or half of the original price.

site_title: Alphabet Q3 sales expected to surge 23% despite regulatory headwinds
summary: Alphabet Inc, parent company of Google, is expected to report a 23% surge in third-quarter sales to over $27 billion, driven by digital-advertising and cloud growth. Net income is projected to rise to $10.45 a share. Regulatory headwinds, including antitrust fines and concerns over privacy and data-collection practices, may weigh on the company's stock. Analysts closely watch costs, hardware sales, and Google Cloud's expansion efforts, which still lag behind competitors Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Corp's Azure.

site_title: US state banking regulators sue government to stop fintech charters
summary: US state banking regulators, the Conference of State Bank Supervisors (CSBS), have sued the federal government to void the decision to award national bank charters to online lenders and payment companies, citing it as unconstitutional and a risk to consumers and taxpayers. The CSBS filed a complaint in the US District Court for the District of Columbia against the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) over its plan to issue bank charters to financial technology firms. The OCC has previously defended its authority to grant the charters.

site_title: US imposes North Korea-related sanctions on Singapore firms
summary: The US Treasury Department imposed sanctions on two Singapore-based entities and a man accused of money laundering through the US financial system to evade sanctions against North Korea. Tan Wee Beng, a director and shareholder of a commodities trading company, hid payments from North Korean contracts worth millions since 2011. Two vessels linked to Tan's company were also sanctioned for illicit economic activity connected to North Korea. The US Justice Department unsealed criminal charges against Tan, but details were not disclosed.

site_title: ECB sticks to plan to rein in stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reaffirmed its plan to cap bond buying by year-end and leave room for an interest-rate increase by late 2019, despite signs of a weakening euro-area economy. The bank will buy 15 billion euros of bonds per month through December, with a final decision contingent on new information. Interest rates are expected to remain at record lows "at least through the summer" of 2019. The decision aims to address mounting economic and market concerns, including slowing private-sector growth and trade tensions.

site_title: Triyards' units face new statutory demands, litigation claims involving US$15.9m
summary: Triyards Holdings faces new statutory demands and litigation claims totaling US$15.9 million, including US$14.6 million from Taiwanese lender CTBC Bank and US$800,000 from a supplier. The company is also facing a winding-up bid by Hong Leong Finance and is considering its options. Triyards Marine Services has received statutory demands and is involved in a winding-up application. The company will provide further updates on its website.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: WTO members hold talks to tackle challenges to its future
summary: Senior officials from 12 countries, including Canada, the European Union, Mexico, and Japan, gathered in Ottawa to discuss reforming the World Trade Organization (WTO) and addressing US grievances that threaten the body's future. The meeting aims to find solutions using a "bottom-up approach" and address issues such as boosting WTO judges and rewriting trade rules. The US and China, whose escalating tariff war has raised doubts about the WTO's future, were not invited. The goal is to demonstrate progress and put pressure on the US and China to find common ground.

site_title: Singapore's AUM industry up 19% to S$3.3 trillion in 2017
summary: Singapore's asset management industry (AUM) grew 19% to S$3.3 trillion in 2017, surpassing the 15% average growth rate of the previous five years. The growth was driven by higher valuations and inflows to Asian markets, with 800 respondents participating in the Monetary Authority of Singapore's annual Asset Management Survey. Alternative AUM, including private equity, saw significant growth, while venture capital AUM declined. Singapore-based asset managers saw S$220 billion in net inflows, with the Asia-Pacific region accounting for 67% of total AUM.

images.alt_text: Total assets managed by Singapore-based asset managers rose by 19 per cent to S$3.3 trillion at the end of 2017, compared to S$2.7 trillion in 2016, outpacing the 15 per cent average growth rate of the previous five years.

site_title: GL's Q1 net profit down 7% on lower revenue
summary: GL, formerly GuocoLeisure, reported a 7% drop in Q1 net profit to US$16.2 million, mainly due to lower hotel revenue. Revenue declined 2% to US$95.9 million, attributed to one-off gains in the previous year and the closure of a London hotel. The company maintained a cautious outlook due to weaker British economic growth and soft household spending. No dividend was recommended, and shares fell 0.68% to S$0.73.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover's Slovak plant to produce 100,000 cars a year by 2020
summary: Jaguar Land Rover plans to reach annual production of 100,000 cars at its Slovak plant by 2020, with the plant already producing the Discovery model. The plant, costing 1.4 billion euros, has a maximum capacity of 150,000 vehicles and was opened in September. CEO Alexander Wortberg stated the goal of 100,000 cars per year, surpassing the initial capacity.

site_title: Dinner Most Fowl at Faviken
summary: Chef Magnus Nilsson creates an unforgettable dining experience at Faviken Magasinet in Sweden, where a bird-only challenge sends him into creative overdrive. The restaurant, located in a remote wilderness area, features a menu that showcases seasonal local produce and focuses entirely on birds hunted on the estate. Artist Carsten Holler, a friend of Nilsson's, requests a bespoke menu featuring only birds, which sparks a discussion about the concept of "Brutalist Cuisine" – a culinary doctrine that emphasizes simplicity and purity. The dining experience, which includes a procession of 20 bird-related dishes, is orchestrated down to the tiniest detail, with each course served at a pre-determined time.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's stock market plunged, with the Straits Times Index retreating 19.24 points to 3,012.84, as one-third of index stocks touched 52-week lows. Grab partnered Mastercard to issue prepaid cards for unbanked users, while asset managers reported strong growth in 2017 with AUM reaching S$3.3 trillion. Edmund Koh was named UBS Asia Pacific president. Industrial space prices and rents remained stable in Q3, and DBS unveiled a chatbot for ordering meals through Facebook Messenger.

site_title: Opec mulls options to cut 2019 oil output to prevent oversupply
summary: Opec is considering reducing oil output in 2019 to prevent oversupply and stabilize prices, amid rising inventories and concerns over an economic slowdown. The Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee, which oversees the agreement between Opec and its allies, has prepared options to adjust production levels. A recent rise in oil inventories in the US, coupled with fears about demand, has prompted Opec to reassess its production strategy. The group aims to maintain a balance between supply and demand, which it fought to achieve by slashing production in 2017 and this year.

site_title: Twitter tops earnings estimates, lifting shares
summary: Twitter reported a US$789 million profit and 29% revenue growth in the third quarter, exceeding estimates. The company's shares rallied 13.6% in premarket trade despite a decline in user numbers. The strong earnings report overshadowed the drop in users, with the company's revenue reaching US$758 million.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher helped by strong Microsoft earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by strong earnings reports from Microsoft and Ford, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.62% to 24,736.54. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising 0.71% and 1.25% respectively to 2,674.88 and 7,197.49. The positive sentiment was attributed to the strong earnings reports, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: JustCo to open latest co-working space in Q4 2019
summary: JustCo, a Singapore-based co-working space, will open its latest space in the fourth quarter of 2019 in Fraser Property's China Square Central complex. The 2nd floor will feature state-of-the-art facilities, flexible leasing terms, and various meeting and entertainment areas. JustCo founder Kong Wan Sing aims to open 100 centres by 2020, with new openings planned in Bangkok, Jakarta, Seoul, Sydney, Melbourne, Taipei, Shanghai, and other Asian cities. This is the startup's first project in a Frasers-owned building.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine's losing streak continues with Q3 net loss
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a Q3 net loss of S$29.8 million, its second consecutive quarterly loss, despite a 60.2% year-over-year increase in revenue to S$1.17 billion. The loss was largely due to the sale of the West Rigel rig at a loss of S$34 million and a slump in overall business volume. The company expects business volume and activities to remain low in the coming quarters, with a continued trend of negative operating profit.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Alliance Mineral, JV partner announce 2 sales deals for Australia mine
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets and its joint-venture partner Tawana Resources have agreed to sell 20-30 dry metric tonnes of high-grade tantalum concentrate to HC Starck Tantalum and Niobium, and 400 wet metric tonnes of low-grade tantalum concentrate to Global Advanced Metals Greenbushes. The sales deals follow strong tantalum pricing in 2018, with premium concentrates from the Bald Hill mine commanding prices well above budgeted levels. The joint venture partners expect to secure long-term off-take for high-grade tantalum concentrate production.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Home Shopping Style
summary: Dream Interiors, a furniture store, has reopened its showrooms featuring chic and well-designed living spaces. The store, located at 1 Kallang Junction, Vanguard Campus, showcases its products in a real home setting, highlighting the quality of its furniture. The store's interior design was conceptualized by Italian architect Piero Lissoni, who is also the art director for Living Divani and Porro, of which Dream Interiors is the exclusive distributor. This unique approach allows customers to experience the products in a lifestyle setting, making it a standout in the furniture retail industry.

images.alt_text: Dream Interiors.
Dream Interiors.
Dream Interiors.
Marquis Studio.
Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: SpaceX seeks US$500m loan via Goldman Sachs
summary: SpaceX is seeking a $500 million loan through Goldman Sachs, with talks underway among potential investors. The loan would be part of the company's leveraged loan market, with Elon Musk's valuation of the company reaching $28 billion. This comes as SpaceX continues to launch and reuse rockets, reducing the cost of space travel. The company's valuation has climbed to become the third-most valuable venture-backed startup in the US.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk's rocket company SpaceX is seeking to borrow US$500 million in the leveraged loan market, according to three people familiar with the matter.

site_title: US pending home sales rise 0.5% in September
summary: US pending home sales rose 0.5% in September, according to the National Association of Realtors, exceeding economists' expectations. This marks a bright spot in the US housing market, which has seen annual pending home sales fall for nine consecutive months. Regionally, pending home contracts increased 4.5% in the West and 1.2% in the Midwest, while declining 1.4% in the South and 0.4% in the Northeast. Despite a 1.0% decrease from September 2017, pending home contracts are seen as a good indicator of future existing home sales.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with big losses, Shanghai bounces
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.01% to 24,994.46, following a Wall Street decline. Cathay Pacific fell after admitting a massive passenger data hack. In contrast, Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.50 points to 2,603.80, while Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.34% to 1,292.60. The losses in Hong Kong were largely due to the global market rout, with Asian markets following suit.

site_title: YuuZoo board replies to Sias, SGX queries ahead of morning meeting
summary: The YuuZoo Networks Group Corp board has suggested that trading of its shares, suspended by the Singapore Exchange in March, may resume "in the near future". In response to queries from the Securities Investors Association (Sias), the board stated it is committed to regaining confidence from SGX and the public. The company is conducting an independent review by Ernst & Young and plans to disclose its findings and scope once complete. The board is also recruiting new directors and strengthening its finance team to enhance governance and expertise.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Arthur Kiong
summary: Arthur Kiong, CEO of Far East Hospitality, has turned adversity into opportunity throughout his 30-year career in the hotel industry. Despite facing disasters like war and pestilence, Kiong has risen through the ranks, working for international hotel brands and eventually taking the helm at FEH. The company's upcoming Sentosa openings, including three new hotels, will further raise its profile. Kiong attributes his success to divine intervention and defines Singapore-style hospitality as "inspired hospitality," mirroring the country's story with four key facets: comfort without excess, aesthetics without ostentation, attentiveness without pretension, and relevance with elegance.

site_title: Saudi Arabia, in reversal, says Khashoggi's killing was 'premeditated'
summary: Saudi Arabia's public prosecutor stated that new evidence shows Jamal Khashoggi's killing was "premeditated," contradicting previous claims that it was an accident. The 15-man team that confronted Khashoggi in the Istanbul consulate killed him, according to Saudi officials. Initially, they said Khashoggi left the consulate alive, then hinted that he might have been killed by "rogue" agents. The shift in the kingdom's official story suggests a change in how the Saudi government will proceed with the investigation.

site_title: Chinese court dismisses legal claim against China Jishan: board
summary: A Chinese court has dismissed a legal claim by Shanghai Jintumu Real Estate against China Jishan Holdings' unit, Zhejiang Jishan Printing and Dyeing. The court ordered Jintumu Real Estate to pay 5.96 million yuan in costs and disbursements, while Jishan P&D must cover 220,900 yuan in costs. The decision allows either party to file an appeal within 15 days. The board of China Jishan Holdings and its legal advisers are reviewing the judgment.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US talk show host Megyn Kelly off air after blackface comment
summary: US talk show host Megyn Kelly was taken off the air after making comments about the use of blackface, sparking controversy. NBC aired reruns of her show amid speculation that the incident would end the program. Kelly parted ways with her agent and her show is reportedly ending after this season, with some sources suggesting it would be the final episode. The controversy led to Kelly's departure from NBC News.

site_title: Bangkok property investment sales down, residential segment 'fragile' in Q3: Report
summary: Bangkok's property sector saw a 59.7% drop in investment sales in Q3, with 10.3 billion baht (S$431.7 million) coming from domestic buyers. The residential market is "increasingly fragile" with weak demand in the central business district and non-CBD segments. Average take-up rates for new launches in the CBD were 31%, down from 58% last year, while average unit selling prices remained unchanged. Despite this, ET&Co expects interest from international investors and domestic investors to focus on hospitality options overseas, potentially driving land values to increase.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit lowest in over 1-1/2 years on global equities selloff
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted to their lowest level in over 1-1/2 years, falling 1.63% on Thursday, amid a global equities selloff triggered by US earnings and economic data. The Kospi index retreated 11% this month and 16% this year due to uncertainties including the US-China trade war and rising borrowing costs. Key players like Hyundai Motor, Samsung Electronics, and SK Hynix also suffered losses, while Celltrion bucked the trend with a 4.9% gain.

site_title: Asean firms confident in digital strategy, but tech adoption rates still low: Study
summary: A study of 1,325 senior IT managers in six Asean countries found that 94% of companies are confident in their digital transformation plans, despite relatively low technology adoption rates. Cloud services, cyber security, and Big Data analytics are widely adopted, while the Internet of Things is the least widely taken up. Automation adoption is expected to rise, with 48% of companies currently using it, and is seen as a shaping technology for the future of operations in the region. Policymakers and businesses are urged to work together to groom future talent and address budget and talent constraints.

site_title: Europe: Shares sink in sustained selloff
summary: European shares declined 0.7% on Thursday, following a heavy selloff in US and Asian markets, as investors expressed concerns over slowing earnings growth in a volatile political landscape. Weak results from major companies such as AB InBev and WPP contributed to the decline, with WPP's stock plummeting 22% after cutting its outlook. Meanwhile, peripheral euro-zone indices rose, with Spain and Italy up 0.3% each, while Sweden's ICA and Konecranes gained 10.6% and 8.3% respectively.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.6% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.6% lower on Thursday, retreating 19.24 points to 3,012.84 on the Straits Times Index. Losers outnumbered gainers 269 to 132, with key decliners including DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The most actively traded counter, Rex International, surged 17.8%. The rally in the previous five days was halted ahead of GDP data and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Questions mount over delay after Cathay Pacific admits huge data leak
summary: Cathay Pacific admitted to a huge data leak affecting 9.4 million customers, including passport numbers and credit card details, five months after discovering suspicious activity in March. The airline claimed no personal data was misused, but critics say its delayed response has fueled worries. Hong Kong politicians have slammed the carrier, demanding an explanation for the delay. Cathay has launched an investigation, alerted the police, and contacted affected passengers to provide solutions to protect themselves.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of possible revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to the first half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, was named OCBC's new CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth day ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green finance.

site_title: ECB sees growth risks still broadly balanced - Draghi
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained that risks to the euro area economy are broadly balanced, playing down concerns about growth slowing. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that protectionism, emerging market vulnerabilities, and financial market volatility remain prominent risks. The ECB's assessment is cautious, considering the global trade war, a potential hard Brexit, and industrial production decline, which may require policymakers to adjust their approach to wean the bloc off stimulus. The bank has exhausted much of its firepower, making interest rate discussions premature.

images.alt_text: "The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook can still be assessed as broadly balanced," ECB President Mario Draghi told a news conference.

site_title: Japan's Abe makes rare China visit as relations thaw
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe made a rare visit to China, the first by a Japanese premier since 2011, as relations between the two countries thawed after a six-year frost. Abe and Chinese President Xi Jinping discussed improving economic cooperation and potential deals, including joint investments in infrastructure in regional nations. The visit aims to repair relations, which soured in 2012 over a territorial row, and sets the stage for a potential reciprocal visit from Xi to Japan next year. The two leaders also plan to discuss North Korea and territorial frictions.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 2,997.21, down 1.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1.2% to 2,997.21 as of 1pm on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 34.87 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 274 to 84, with local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also declining. Genting Singapore was the most actively traded counter, falling 3.3%. The market was affected by negative sentiment from US trade uncertainty, despite a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: GuocoLand Q1 earnings fall 85% on revenue drop, lower share of JV profits
summary: GuocoLand's Q1 earnings plummeted 85% to S$26.2 million, primarily due to a 50% drop in revenue to S$168 million. The decline in revenue was attributed to a smaller stock of unsold private homes and fewer sales. The company's share of profit from associates and joint ventures also decreased. Despite this, the office market outlook remains positive. No dividend was recommended for the quarter, and GuocoLand's share price fell 1.08% to S$1.83.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Ascendas Reit Q2 DPU falls 4.2%, gross revenue up 1.1%
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 4.2% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.887 Singapore cents for Q2, mainly due to lower contributions from Singapore assets and higher interest expenses. The company raised S$450 million in equity for a UK portfolio acquisition and a built-to-suit development in Singapore. Total available for distribution decreased 3.1% to S$115 million, and net property income shrank 1% to S$158.9 million.

site_title: Bomb sent to Robert De Niro, latest in wave of explosives sent to Trump critics
summary: An explosive was sent to Robert De Niro's production company in New York, the latest in a wave of similar devices sent to prominent Democrats targeted by President Donald Trump. The device, resembling a pipe bomb, was similar to those sent to former President Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, and others. Authorities believe it may be from the same sender as previous packages. This incident is part of a growing trend of threats and violence against Trump critics, raising concerns about the impact of inflammatory rhetoric.

images.alt_text: Law enforcement officials gather near the scene of where another package bomb was found early Thursday morning at Robert De Niro's Tribeca Grill restaurant, October 25, 2018 in New York City.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.45 points to 1,686.59. The decline was attributed to a 2.2 billion lots volume worth RM2.3 billion, with 768 losers beating 173 gainers.

images.alt_text: An employee opens the door of a Nissan Ariya EV car at Nissan Gallery in Yokohama, Japan November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Androniki Christodoulou##########KELNISSAN30##########

site_title: Yogyakarta, Bandung join list of BLOCK71 locations
summary: Two Indonesian cities, Yogyakarta and Bandung, have been added to the BLOCK71 initiative, a startup hub established by NUS Enterprise, in partnership with Salim Group. The new locations will provide collaboration opportunities, access to mentors, funding, and new markets for startups. Preliminary operations began in October and the first group of startups will move in next month. Other international locations include Singapore, San Francisco, and Suzhou. The initiative aims to encourage entrepreneurship and expand the BLOCK71 ecosystem in Indonesia and beyond.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: UBS surprises with 32% rise in Q3 profit as investment bank shines
summary: UBS reported a 32% rise in Q3 profit, driven by a strong performance from its investment bank. The bank aims to grow wealth management profits at the upper end of a 10-15% target over 2019-2021, seeking a 2-4% annual growth rate. This comes as geopolitical tensions impact its core business, managing wealth for the world's wealthy.

site_title: Jack Ma back on top of Forbes China Rich List as stock rout upsets billionaire ranks
summary: Jack Ma has returned to the top of Forbes China Rich List, surpassing China Evergrande's Hui Ka Yan with a net worth of US$34.6 billion, down US$4 billion from last year. The list saw 93 billionaires drop out of the ranks, with 229 experiencing a decline in their net worth, and nearly a third losing 20% or more. Despite the decline, e-commerce giant Alibaba's net worth remained stable, and tech newcomers like Pinduoduo's Colin Huang made their debut on the list.

site_title: Industry veteran Edmund Koh named first Singaporean president of UBS Asia Pacific
summary: UBS has appointed Edmund Koh as the first Singaporean president of UBS Asia Pacific, effective January 1, 2019. Koh, a 30-year industry veteran, previously served as head of wealth management for Asia Pacific and country head of Singapore. He succeeds Kathy Shih, who retires after over three decades at the bank. Koh also joins the group executive board, replacing Markus Ronner, who takes on head of group compliance and regulatory affairs. The appointment was welcomed by UBS Group CEO Sergio Ermotti, who praised Shih's contributions to the bank's success in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: SP Group to double new electric vehicle charging points to 1,000; inks deal with HDT
summary: SP Group plans to install 1,000 new electric vehicle charging points by 2020, doubling its initial target. The charging points will include 250 high-powered direct current chargers (50kw) that can charge a car in 30 minutes and "extra-high-powered chargers" (up to 350kw) that can charge a car in 10 minutes. The company aims to extend its services to buses and trucks, and plans to partner with HDT for the installation of these charging points.

site_title: Aussie shares end at more than 1-year low after Wall St selloff; NZ down
summary: Australian shares ended at a one-year low, falling 2.8% to 5664.1 on the S&P/ASX 200 index, following Wall Street's largest daily decline since 2011. The Australian metals and mining index also dropped 3.5% to a one-month low. The decline was attributed to a bearish tone set by the US market.

images.alt_text:
sydream - Dreamcore's 10,000 square feet showroom - called Dream Centre - houses expanded operations of the company, and is a new retail and service experience for customers.

credit: Dreamcore##########sydream##########Dreamcore

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.34 points to 1,678.70 at 9am on Thursday, with volume at 51.25 million lots worth R22.58 million. Losers outpaced gainers 286 to 17.

site_title: Blackpool beer theft: David Schwimmer provides solid alibi
summary: Actor David Schwimmer was questioned by police in Blackpool, UK, after a Facebook post showed a man resembling him allegedly stealing a crate of beer. Schwimmer, known for his role in the TV show "Friends," provided a solid alibi, claiming he was in a different location at the time of the incident. The police's Facebook post sparked a wave of amusement and confusion among fans, with many jokingly identifying Schwimmer as the culprit. The police eventually cleared Schwimmer's name, and the incident has been largely dismissed as a lighthearted misunderstanding.

site_title: Uber's Lion City Rentals rebrands to also attract casual drivers
summary: Lion City Rentals, Uber's car rental subsidiary, is rebranding to serve casual drivers in addition to its private-hire leasing business. The company aims to "address a broader audience" and become the preferred car rental company in Singapore. General Manager Pascal Ly stated that casual drivers could include individuals looking for short-term rentals or those needing to transport bulky items. The rebranding is part of LCR's ongoing brand refresh, with the goal of expanding its customer base.

site_title: Credit Counselling Singapore to extend help to owners of failed or failing small firms
summary: Credit Counselling Singapore (CCS) is launching a pilot Enterprise Credit Counselling Programme to help owners of failing or failed small enterprises manage their debts and avoid bankruptcy. The programme will provide credit counselling, facilitate a comprehensive repayment proposal, and act as a facilitator for creditors. To qualify, owners must have terminated their businesses or be on the verge of doing so, with business assets not exceeding $1 million and total business debts of not more than $500,000. The move aims to help entrepreneurs minimize the impact of business failure and avoid bankruptcy.

site_title: DBS unveils chatbot for ordering, paying for meals through Facebook Messenger
summary: DBS Bank launched Foodster, a chatbot that allows customers to order meals through Facebook Messenger and pay with DBS payment channels. The solution, developed by Every Botty, uses artificial intelligence to become "smarter" with each transaction and offers personalized customer loyalty programs. Seven food and beverage merchants in Marina Bay have already adopted the platform, with daily sales growth of up to 20%. DBS aims to help businesses engage customers on Facebook Messenger, leveraging the platform's 77% user base in Singapore.

images.alt_text: A customer picking up her Kopi Ong order with a digital collection slip at a designated Foodster pickup counter.

site_title: One-third of Singapore index stocks touch 52-week lows as STI sinks below 3,000 level
summary: The Singapore stock market plummeted 1.08% on Thursday, with 11 blue-chip stocks reaching 52-week lows, taking the Straits Times Index (STI) below 3,000. The STI closed at 2,999.33. Key losers included Jardine Matheson, Jardine C&C, and Genting Singapore. The decline followed a US equity rout overnight and a Nasdaq entering correction territory.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes down 3.7% as global markets plunge
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted 3.7% on Thursday, its worst close in nearly seven months, amid a global market downturn. The decline followed a punishing session on Wall Street, where major US indices erased their 2018 gains. Investors are worried about higher US interest rates, the impact of the Jamal Khashoggi murder, and the ongoing budget dispute between Italy and Brussels. The yen surged against the dollar, negatively affecting Japanese exporters, while shares of major firms like Toyota and Sony plummeted.

site_title: Major shareholders of MMP Resources in talks with Lloyds Energy to sell shares
summary: Major shareholders of MMP Resources are in talks with Lloyds Energy to sell shares. The talks have resulted in a non-binding term sheet, with negotiations ongoing to finalize the definitive agreements. If successful, the sale could lead to Lloyds Energy acquiring more than 30% of MMP Resources' shares, triggering a mandatory general offer under Singapore's takeover code. The board advises shareholders to exercise caution, as there is no certainty that a definitive agreement will be reached.

site_title: LNG tankers stranded off Singapore, Malaysia as demand outlook weakens
summary: A fleet of six LNG tankers carrying over a million cubic meters of LNG has been stranded in Singapore and Malaysian waters for up to two weeks due to weaker-than-expected demand in Asia during the northern hemisphere winter season. The tankers, worth over $200 million, were purchased ahead of the winter season but now face storage costs that could eat into any potential profit. Weaker-than-expected demand is attributed to a relatively mild winter forecast and nuclear power plants restarting in Japan, which is the world's top LNG importer.

site_title: Singapore's asset management industry clocks strong growth; AUM up 19% to S$3.3 trillion in 2017
summary: Singapore's asset management industry experienced strong growth in 2017, with assets under management (AUM) increasing 19% to S$3.3 trillion, outpacing the 15% average growth rate of the previous five years. The growth was broad-based across traditional and alternative assets, driven by higher valuations and inflows to Asian markets. Singapore-based asset managers continued to view the city-state as a conducive place for portfolio management, with a net increase of 55 registered and licensed fund managers in 2017.

site_title: Prices, rents of Singapore industrial space relatively stable in Q3: JTC
summary: Prices and rentals of industrial space in Singapore remained relatively stable in the third quarter of 2018, with prices increasing 0.1% and rents decreasing 0.1% compared to the previous quarter. Occupancy rates rose 0.4 percentage points to 89.1%, while transaction volumes increased 2% but decreased 4% year-over-year. JTC expects another 1.8 million square meters of industrial space to come online in 2019, potentially stabilizing prices and rentals.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Marina Bay Sands earnings for Q3 slump on weaker VIP segment
summary: Marina Bay Sands' third-quarter earnings dropped 5.2% to US$419 million, mainly due to a 24.9% decline in VIP play, which accounts for a significant portion of the casino's revenue. The company's hotel and non-gaming businesses saw growth, with room revenue rising 12.8% and food and beverage sales increasing 15.2%. Las Vegas Sands Corp, the parent company, reported a 6% increase in ebitda and a 2.2% rise in net income, despite missing revenue and earnings forecasts.

site_title: Research institutes should draw up sectoral R&D plans: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for research institutes to develop sectoral R&D plans to translate research into commercial products. He stressed the importance of connecting research institutes with industry players to foster innovation and stay ahead in the global economy. This is one of eight critical economic strategies outlined by Chan, which include connectivity, rules, Industry 4.0, talent, and agile regulations.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Why Dyson picked Singapore to build its electric car
summary: James Dyson, the billionaire inventor, has chosen Singapore to build an electric car plant due to the country's strong supply chains, access to markets, and availability of expertise, despite the high costs. Singapore offers generous incentive schemes, including tax breaks and grants, and has a free trade agreement with China that could benefit electric vehicles. The decision may also be influenced by Dyson's existing presence in Singapore, with 1,100 employees, and its ability to source components from neighboring countries.

site_title: Co-working startup JustCo leasing 2nd floor of Fraser Property's China Square Central
summary: JustCo, a Singapore-based co-working startup, is leasing the entire second floor of Fraser Property's China Square Central complex. The move is part of its expansion plans, with the new space expected to open in the fourth quarter of 2019. This will be JustCo's 14th co-working centre in Singapore, adding to its existing portfolio of 13 centres.

site_title: Cathay Pacific shares hit 9-yr low after data leak affects 9.4m passengers
summary: Cathay Pacific shares plummeted to a 9-year low after a data leak affecting 9.4 million passengers was discovered. The breach included passport numbers, identity card numbers, and credit card information. The airline initially detected suspicious activity in March 2018 and confirmed the hack in early May. Cathay Pacific's shares dropped over 6% on the news.

site_title: Saudi crown prince deplores 'repulsive' Khashoggi murder in first comments
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman denounced the "repulsive" murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, vowing justice will prevail. In his first public comments, he pledged there would be "no rupture" in ties with Turkey, despite international censure. The prince denied involvement in Khashoggi's murder, but acknowledged those responsible would be held accountable. The US and other countries have revoked visas of Saudis linked to the killing, and Turkey is holding its own investigation, with President Erdogan calling for 18 Saudis to be tried in Turkey.

site_title: Grab deal to give Mastercards to millions without bank accounts
summary: Singapore-based Grab has partnered with Mastercard to issue prepaid cards to millions of unbanked consumers in Southeast Asia. The partnership aims to expand digital payments across the region, leveraging Grab's 110 million users and Mastercard's 3 million merchant outlets. This move is expected to help Grab's unbanked users transact online, while also advancing Mastercard's reach in Southeast Asia. The partnership aligns with Mastercard's goal of expanding digital payments across all consumers and merchants.

site_title: South Korea's SK Hynix posts record Q3 profit as chip outlook dims
summary: South Korea's SK Hynix Inc posted a record third-quarter operating profit of 6.5 trillion won (S$7.9 billion), beating analyst expectations by 73%. The company's sales rose 41% to a record high of 11.4 trillion won, driven by seasonal sales boosts for mobile devices and strong server demand. Despite softer chip prices, SK Hynix expects Chinese consumers' growing demand for high-density chips to offset negative impacts, but warns of uncertainty around the slowdown in the DRAM market due to global trade conflicts.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI sinks 1.38% as US market, Nasdaq correction trigger bloodbath in Asia
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 1.38% due to a US market correction, with the Dow and S&P 500 indices erasing their 2018 gains and the Nasdaq entering correction territory. The STI fell below the 3,000 key psychological support level, with 11 of its 30 stocks reaching 52-week lows. Market analysts expect the October rout to deepen, citing concerns over US corporate profits, economic growth, and monetary conditions.

site_title: Addvalue, Network Innovations to market maritime communications products to US fisheries
summary: Addvalue Technologies has partnered with Network Innovations to market its iFleetONE-VMS, a maritime satellite communications terminal and Vessel Monitoring System, to US fisheries. The terminal has been type-approved by the US National Marine Fisheries Service Office of Law Enforcement and will be exclusively marketed to US fisheries. An initial order of 50 units is expected, with NI providing airtime plans and support. The partnership aims to help commercial fishing vessels comply with regulatory requirements for secure satellite reporting of GPS positioning.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars keep their nerve as global equities sink
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remained stable despite a global market downturn, with the Aussie up 0.26% at US$0.7076 and the kiwi steady at US$0.6523. This stability is unusual given the currencies' correlation to global growth prospects. The Aussie's stability is attributed to recent buyers attracted to levels near US$0.7000, Chinese efforts to boost demand for iron ore, and lower US Treasury yields.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive at open on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 1.91% in the opening minutes of trade on Thursday, mirroring a collapse across Asia and a decline on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 24,766.72, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 2.40% and 2.99% respectively. The decline was attributed to growing investor concerns over the global outlook.

site_title: South Korea Q3 GDP growth misses forecasts, construction spending plunges
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.6% in the third quarter, missing forecasts, due to a plunge in domestic investment and declining construction spending. The decline in construction investment was the largest since the 1997-1998 Asian financial crisis. Private consumption improved slightly, supporting overall growth, but analysts cite turbulent global markets, uncertain trade prospects, and government policies as uncertain factors. The economy is expected to meet the central bank's full-year projections at 2.7%, down from 2.9%.

site_title: Asia: Shares slump as Wall St erases all of 2018 gains
summary: Asian shares plummeted as the Dow Jones Industrial Average erased all 2018 gains due to a rout in tech stocks, with the Nasdaq declining 12.4% from its record high. The tech sector was hit hard after chipmakers' disappointing forecasts, while weak US housing data, trade war fears, and concerns over a slowing global economy contributed to the sell-off. The sell-off also led to a surge in safe-haven assets like sovereign bonds and the US dollar, with yields in 10-year Treasuries falling to 3.11%.

site_title: China will never give up an inch of territory, defence minister says
summary: China's Defence Minister Wei Fenghe stated that the country will not give up any territory, including Taiwan and the South China Sea. The remarks come amid strained relations with the US, which has imposed sanctions on China's military and supported Taiwan's independence. China views Taiwan as a core interest and opposes displays of strength in the South China Sea. The US and China have been engaging in a trade war and military posturing, with the US withdrawing from a Cold War-era treaty that eliminated nuclear missiles from Europe.

images.alt_text: Chinese Defence Minister Wei Fenghe (centre) made the remarks at the opening of the Xiangshan Forum in Beijing, which China styles as its answer to the annual Shangri-La Dialogue security forum in the wealthy city-state of Singapore.

site_title: Australia: Stock market sinks, wiping out 2018 gains
summary: Australia's leading share index, the ASX 200, plummeted by over 2% at the open, erasing most of this year's gains. The decline was attributed to a global sell-off, fueled by concerns over US corporate earnings, President Trump's trade policies, and geopolitical tensions. Local traders picked up on these sentiments, with resource and consumer-focused companies leading the sell-off. Investor confidence has hit lower levels, with no new positive news, resulting in a continued downside trend.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q3 DPU falls 4.1% to 3.23 S cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 4.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.23 Singapore cents for its third fiscal quarter, mainly due to the absence of a one-off divestment gain from Japan properties in the same period last year. Excluding the gain, DPU from recurring operations grew 2.7% year-over-year, driven by a 2.5% increase in net property income and gross revenue. The Reit remains committed to preserving its earnings resiliency in a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Najib, ex-treasury chief charged with criminal breach of trust involving RM6.6b
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and his top treasury official, Irwan Serigar Abdullah, have been charged with six counts each of criminal breach of trust involving RM6.6 billion in government funds. The charges follow a widening crackdown on corruption. Najib and Irwan pleaded not guilty to all the charges, marking the latest development in the ongoing case. The charges stem from alleged misuse of government funds during Najib's tenure as prime minister.

images.alt_text: Former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak and his top treasury official were on Thursday charged with six counts each of criminal breach of trust involving government funds of RM6.6 billion (S$2.18 billion).

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust DPU up 5% at 2.92 S cents for Q3
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 5% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.92 Singapore cents, driven by a 1.1% rise in net property income. Gross revenue rose 0.7% to S$170.5 million, while portfolio occupancy reached 98.5%. The trust plans to launch a private placement to fund the consolidation of its Westgate mall stake, with net proceeds expected to be used to partially finance the acquisition.

site_title: Singapore shares open sharply lower on Thursday; STI down 1.4% to 2,991.12
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 1.4% to 2,991.12 on Thursday, following a global market rout. The decline was triggered by a tech stocks rout on Wall Street, which wiped out all gains for the year. Losers outnumbered gainers 146 to 26, with 62.4 million shares changing hands. The drop was part of a worldwide sell-off, with Asian shares also declining sharply.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CMT, Parkway Life Reit, AA Reit, MMP Resources, Tuan Sing, M1
summary: Stocks to watch on October 25, 2018, include CMT, Parkway Life Reit, and MMP Resources. CMT posted a 5% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit to 2.92 Singapore cents. Parkway Life Reit reported a 4.1% decrease in DPU to 3.23 cents, while MMP Resources' substantial shareholders entered into a non-binding term sheet with Lloyds Energy for a possible sale. Other notable developments include AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit's 2% decline in DPU and Tuan Sing's 35% fall in net profit.

site_title: Ford earnings drop on weak China sales
summary: Ford reported a 37% drop in third-quarter profits to $991 million, despite strong truck sales in North America. Weak China sales and higher commodity costs, including US trade tariffs, contributed to the decline. The company's Asia Pacific division suffered an operating loss of $208 million. Revenues rose 3.3% to $37.6 billion. Ford shares jumped 5.5% in after-hours trading.

site_title: US oil prices up after sharp drop in fuel stocks
summary: US oil prices rose after a sharp drop in fuel stocks, rebounding from a 5% slump on Tuesday. The drawdown in US petrol and diesel inventories signaled a seasonal increase in refining demand. Despite concerns about worldwide demand and global economic weakness, looming US sanctions on Iran supported prices.

site_title: Top Democrats accuse Trump of condoning violence, dividing US
summary: Top Democrats, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, accused President Donald Trump of condoning violence and dividing Americans. They pointed to his statements supporting rally attendees who engage in violence with protesters and branding the press as enemies of the people. Trump said acts of political violence "have no place in the United States," but his words were deemed hollow by Pelosi and Schumer, who urged him to reverse his statements. The criticism came less than two weeks before crucial midterm elections.

site_title: Tesla reports 'historic' profitable quarter
summary: Tesla reported a "historic" profitable quarter, with net income reaching $311.5 million and revenue more than doubling to $6.8 billion in the third quarter. The company's mass-market Model 3 was the best-selling car in the US in terms of revenue and the fifth best-selling car in terms of volume. Tesla's gross margin on Model 3 vehicles increased to over 20%, and the company has improved efficiency, aiming to be profitable again in the current quarter despite using cash to pay off notes.

site_title: Boeing lands on Airbus turf, with first European factory in UK
summary: Boeing has opened its first European factory in Sheffield, England, marking a significant presence in the UK. The 40 million-pound facility will produce system-control components for Boeing's 737 and 767 jets, employing 52 people. The move comes as the UK prepares to leave the EU, potentially offering opportunities for Boeing in the UK market. Boeing has also been selected for exclusive talks to supply the UK Ministry of Defence with a new generation of surveillance aircraft.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei plunges 3% after US selloff
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index plummeted 3.19% or 706.12 points to 21,386.06 after a punishing US stock session that erased all 2018 gains. The broader Topix index also fell 2.62%. The US selloff followed Trump's latest trade threats, which traders are largely ignoring. Despite this, other markets, such as Singapore's STI, rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Broadcom faces EU antitrust scrutiny in dominance probe
summary: Broadcom faces EU antitrust scrutiny over potential market dominance, with the European Commission investigating whether the company uses its power to pressure customers to buy its semiconductors and harm rivals in the cable and satellite industry. The inquiry is preliminary, and the US Federal Trade Commission is also examining Broadcom's practices.

site_title: A standout track record
summary: Manulife Malaysia CEO Mark O'Dell has won the Outstanding Leaders in Asia Award at the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES Awards). Since joining the company in 2008, O'Dell has driven strong growth in Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, spearheading initiatives such as the acquisition of MAAKL Mutual Berhad and the activation of an exclusive bank partnership. Under his leadership, Manulife Malaysia has also strengthened its brand presence and community involvement, including a partnership with a non-profit crowdfunding platform and various health and community-related initiatives, earning it the CSR Malaysia Award 2018.

site_title: US: Stocks plunge, sending Dow into the red for 2018
summary: US stocks plummeted, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.4% to close at 24,583.42, wiping out all 2018 gains. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index plummeted 4.4% and the S&P 500 sank 3.1% due to mixed corporate earnings, trade conflicts, and rising costs. Technology shares were especially hard hit, with Amazon, Facebook, Alphabet, and Netflix declining by 5.9%, 5.4%, 4.8%, and 9.4%, respectively.

site_title: Total CEO steps into eye of Saudi storm as other bosses stay away
summary: Total CEO Patrick Pouyanne attended an investment conference in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, despite other CEOs pulling out due to the Jamal Khashoggi killing. Pouyanne signed memorandums of understanding with Saudi Aramco for joint investments worth $5 billion in petrochemicals and fuel retail stations. His presence was seen as a bold stance to support Saudi economic reforms, which are in the interest of Western companies and regional stability.

site_title: Australia's AMP sells insurance businesses for A$3.3b
summary: Australia's AMP sold its insurance businesses to Resolution Life for A$3.3 billion as part of its restructuring following a misconduct scandal. The move aims to simplify the company, strengthen its balance sheet, and provide strategic flexibility. AMP also plans to divest New Zealand wealth management businesses via an initial public offering (IPO).

site_title: AA Reit DPU dips 2% for Q2 at 2.50 S cents
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) reported a 2% drop in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.50 Singapore cents, down from 2.55 cents last year. Gross revenue fell 0.3% to S$29.4 million, while net property income decreased 0.5%. The Reit manager distributed S$17.1 million to unitholders, unchanged from the first quarter. AA Reit increased portfolio occupancy to 93.6% and executed 14 new leases, with projects underway to redevelop two properties. Net asset value per unit remained unchanged at S$1.37.

site_title: Europe: Sixth straight day of losses for stocks as banks, autos, tech, fall
summary: European stocks fell for a sixth consecutive day, with the Stoxx 600 dropping 0.2% to a 22-month low, as weak results from chipmaker STMicro and Deutsche Bank weighed on the market. The tech sector slid 1.9%, while banks and autos stocks also declined. However, luxury stocks such as Kering, which reported strong results from Gucci, bucked the trend and rose. The decline was attributed to interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve and concerns over the mid-term elections in the US.

images.alt_text: Small toy figures are seen in front of a displayed South Africa flag and words "Omicron SARS-CoV-2" in this illustration taken, November 27, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration##########keloil29##########

site_title: K-Pop bands ride high on music charts but flop in stock market
summary: K-pop bands have achieved significant success on music charts, with BTS topping the US Billboard charts and embarking on a world tour. However, the financial performance of talent agencies behind these groups has been disappointing. Shares of JYP Entertainment Corp, representing the agency behind girl group "Twice," plummeted 20% in Seoul after an analyst downgraded earnings estimates, sparking a sell-off in the sector. This marks a significant downturn in the K-pop industry, which was previously a top performer in Asia's stock market.

site_title: Air traffic to double by 2037: IATA
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) forecasts that air travel will double to 8.2 billion passengers per year by 2037, with Asia and the Pacific leading the growth. The current 4.1 billion passengers are expected to expand by 3.5% annually. However, protectionist measures could curb the surge, according to IATA.

images.alt_text: The number of people travelling by air should double to 8.2 billion a year by 2037, with Asia and the Pacific leading the way, sector federation IATA forecast on Wednesday.

site_title: France says ready to back sanctions against Khashoggi killers
summary: France is prepared to support international sanctions against those responsible for the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, President Emmanuel Macron informed King Salman. Macron expressed his "profound indignation" at the crime and demanded transparency. France will not hesitate to take action, including sanctions, to defend freedom of expression and the press. Saudi Arabia has admitted to the killing, but Western countries, including the US and Britain, have demanded a thorough investigation.

images.alt_text: France is ready to back "international sanctions" against those responsible for the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, the Elysee Palace said after President Emmanuel Macron spoke by telephone to King Salman Wednesday.

site_title: Making dreams come true
summary: IRPC Public Company Limited has been recognized as a top community care company in Asia for its commitment to corporate citizenship. The company has a dedicated sustainability department and engages in various CSR projects, including educational development, environmental conservation, and healthcare services. In 2017, IRPC provided 1,859 employees with 17,447 hours of community service, and its CSR activities have benefited over 11,000 patients and 5,000 students. The company's efforts have helped people realize their dreams of an illness-free life and higher education, and have contributed to the well-being of society at large.

site_title: Microsoft quarterly profit soars on cloud services
summary: Microsoft reported a 34% increase in net income to $8.8 billion and a 19% increase in revenue to $29.1 billion for the first quarter of its fiscal year. The company's cloud services, including Azure, LinkedIn, and Office, drove the growth, with revenue increases of 76%, 33%, and 47% respectively. Microsoft's shares rose 4.75% to $107.18, and the company returned $6.1 billion to shareholders. CEO Satya Nadella attributed the results to innovation and customer trust in powering digital transformation.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Dr Jovina Ang, Why getting personal matters for leaders
summary: NUS' Dr Jovina Ang discusses her book "Leadership Communication - Connect, Engage, Inspire" on Money FM podcast "Influence". She emphasizes that getting personal matters for leaders, as it fosters authenticity and trust with employees and stakeholders. Dr Ang highlights the importance of leaders being vulnerable and genuine in their communication to inspire and engage others. This approach can lead to increased employee motivation, improved retention, and enhanced organizational performance, ultimately contributing to Singapore's global competitiveness.

site_title: Global Invacom in reverse takeover of biometric solutions firm Tactilis
summary: Global Invacom Group has agreed to acquire Tactilis, a Malaysian biometric solutions firm, in a deal valued at US$200 million. The acquisition is expected to result in a reverse takeover. Tactilis makes proprietary biometric system-on-card solutions. The deal was made on a "willing-buyer and willing-seller basis."

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to pay Q2 DPU of 1.98¢
summary: Ascendas India Trust will pay a Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.98 Singapore cents, a 32% year-on-year increase. Net property income rose 4% to S$32.9 million, driven by new acquisitions and higher interest income. However, total property income dipped 2% to S$44.9 million due to a stronger Singdollar. The trust's gearing stands at 32% and its growth pipeline is bolstered by a proposed acquisition of two buildings in Hyderabad. The trust's DPU for the six months is 3.58 Singapore cents, up from 2.81 cents.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US firms face tariff-fueled price hikes, widespread labour shortages: Federal Reserve
summary: The Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey revealed US firms face price hikes due to tariffs, while widespread labour shortages delay projects and pressure companies to raise wages or benefits. Despite a "modest to moderate" growth in the US economy, President Trump's aggressive tariff strategy may add fuel to inflation. The Fed is closely monitoring price pressures to gauge interest rate hikes, with potential increases in December. Companies are struggling to pass on cost increases to customers, and some are turning to robots to boost production.

images.alt_text: US firms nationwide complain trade disputes with China and others are boosting the prices of key inputs, while they continue to face widespread labor shortages, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday.

site_title: Texas Instruments tumbles as weak chip demand saps forecast
summary: Texas Instruments reported a third-quarter revenue miss, with shares tumbling 7.2% in extended trading. The chipmaker attributed the disappointing forecast to weak demand amid a brewing trade war between the US and China, with analysts noting that customers are bracing for weaker demand due to tariffs. Texas Instruments forecast fourth-quarter profit of $1.14-$1.34 per share and revenue of $3.6-$3.9 billion, below analysts' estimates. The company's financial outlook is seen as a broader economic barometer, with the lackluster projections indicating a potential slowdown in the semiconductor industry.

site_title: US$1.6 billion US lottery jackpot goes to one ticket
summary: A single US$1.6 billion Mega Millions lottery ticket, sold in South Carolina, matched all six numbers, beating the odds of 1 in 303 million to win the record-setting jackpot. The winning ticket's owner has the option to take the cash prize of US$904 million or the full jackpot over 29 years. Experts warn that the winner will face financial headaches and recommend creating a trust and hiring a team of lawyers, financial advisers, and security to manage the newfound wealth.

site_title: Fuelled by respect
summary: Pilipinas Shell, a Philippines-focused integrated oil company, has won the Community Care Company of the Year award from the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards. CEO Shanggari Balakrishnan praised the company's innovative and inspirational community and sustainability work, noting that it exceeded the judging criteria. Pilipinas Shell's outreach campaigns engage the public and generate positive brand communication, making it a living embodiment of the award category.

site_title: China-Japan relationship thaws, but elephants remain in the room
summary: China and Japan have begun to thaw their historically strained relationship, with a 40th-anniversary peace treaty celebration in Beijing this week. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's visit aims to strengthen economic ties and revive a dormant currency swap framework. Despite territorial disputes, including a 2012 incident over disputed islands, the two sides have agreed to more military exchanges and a hotline to avoid clashes. The visit marks a warming of ties, with China's President Xi Jinping seeing Japan as a way to mitigate US trade tensions. However, historical barriers remain, and territorial disputes continue to pose a challenge to improved relations.

site_title: Leadership bar none
summary: Six Asian leaders have been recognized as Outstanding Leaders in Asia by the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards. Rahul Hora, president of AXA Philippines, is known for his inclusive leadership style, while Dr. Chairat Panthuraamphorn, managing director of the Samitivej and Bangkok Nursing Home Group, strives for a "Man of Value" approach. Other notable leaders include Merrill Christopher Pereyra, who brought a winning strategy to QSR Brands, Parveen Kathuria, who emphasizes the importance of a clear vision, and Chadatip Chutrakul, CEO of Siam Piwat Group, who encourages innovative thinking. These leaders were recognized for their sound leadership, business acumen, and commitment to empowering employees and customers.

site_title: Marine fuel price spreads widen ahead of 2020 cap on sulphur content
summary: The price spread between high-sulphur heavy fuel oil (HSFO) and marine gas oil (MGO) has widened significantly, with an average price differential of US$219.26 a tonne as of October 23, 2018. This is a result of the impending 2020 global cap on sulphur content in marine fuels, which will require refiners to invest in new blends. Industry analysts predict that about three million barrels per day of HSFO will need to be replaced, and the transition period may lead to price volatility across marine fuel types and blends.

site_title: Eurozone business growth hits the brakes
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed significantly in October, dragged down by waning orders and decreased confidence, according to a survey. The slowdown is attributed to the escalating US-China trade war, a spiraling debt dispute in Italy, and deadlocked Brexit negotiations. The European Central Bank is expected to end its bond-buying program in less than three months, despite concerns about the economic slowdown. The eurozone's growth outlook for 2019 has dimmed, and policymakers are expected to stress caution amid the uncertainty.

site_title: Success across all sectors
summary: ACES' Top Companies In Asia recognized leadership and engagement as key factors in success. Meinhardt Group International excelled in the construction industry through innovative engineering solutions and customer needs. PT Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (Persero) bridged private and government sectors with innovative financing products and services. Honeywell forged ahead with connectivity and competitiveness, while Thoresen Thai Agencies Public Company Limited (TTA) achieved growth through diversified investments and strategic investments with social conscience.

images.alt_text: Meinhardt Group International is the largest Global Engineering & PM Company in Singapore.
Honeywell Asean reached out to 6,000 students in 2017 on fire safety and burn prevention.
PT Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (Persero) is a non-bank financial institution.
Thoresen Thai Agencies Public Company Limited is an industry champion because of it maintains agility across a full portfolio of investments.

site_title: Top economist Andrew Rose to become NUS Business School dean
summary: NUS Business School has appointed Andrew Rose, a renowned economist, as its incoming dean, succeeding Bernard Yeung on June 1, 2019. Rose, a professor at the University of California, Berkeley's Haas School of Business, has collaborated with prominent economists and worked with various international organizations. NUS president Tan Eng Chye welcomed Rose, praising his leadership skills and expertise in international trade, finance, and macroeconomics, stating that he will lead the school with wisdom and purpose.

site_title: Ford hires new China chief to tackle daunting turnaround task
summary: Ford has hired Anning Chen, a former Ford engineer and chairman of Chery Jaguar Land Rover in China, to lead its China operations starting November 1. Chen, fluent in Chinese, aims to fix Ford's deep sales slump in the world's largest car market.
