Sales have fallen 43% in September and 30% in the first nine months of the year, with the company blaming an ageing model line-up. The new appointment comes as Ford restructures operations worldwide and seeks to mend relationships with Chinese joint venture partners.

images.alt_text: Anning Chen will take the helm from Nov 1.

site_title: Amazon pitches facial recognition tech at agency handling migrants
summary: Amazon has pitched its facial recognition technology, Rekognition, to US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), despite protests from employees and civil liberties groups, citing racial bias concerns. The technology, which can identify people from surveillance footage, was presented at a "boot camp" attended by other tech companies. ICE has no current contract with Amazon, but the agency regularly meets with vendors to learn about their tools. Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos has stated the company will continue to support the US Defence Department, drawing a contrast with Google.

site_title: A bountiful venture
summary: Bounty Agro Ventures, Inc (BAVI), the Philippines' No 1 poultry integrator, has achieved success with its rotisserie chicken chain. Incorporated in 1997, BAVI has expanded nationwide, with a nationwide business network and hundreds of contract farms, hatcheries, and processing plants. Under President Ronald R Mascarinas' leadership, the company diversified operations, launched retail stores, and introduced antibiotic-free chicken, becoming the largest rotisserie chicken chain with over 1,000 stores. Mascarinas attributes the company's success to the trinity of "Vision, People, and Training," and BAVI's corporate social responsibilities focus on socio-cultural and health aspects.

images.alt_text: Bounty Agro Ventures Inc has seen its fair share of challenges. After the Asian Free Trade Agreement, which facilitated an open market which led to cheaper imports, BAVI faced thin margins and fierce competition. But under the able leadership of Mr Mascarinas (left), bold measures were taken to diversify its operations, with BAVI launching its own retail operation and developing a complementary range of cooked chicken and dressed chicken products.

site_title: For Sakae, it's once bitten, still not shy
summary: Sakae Holdings, a Japanese-themed restaurant chain, has fallen victim to a second scam, losing US$4.3 million, after a 5-year dispute with its former director. The company had previously emerged from a lengthy court battle over a property investment gone awry. The latest incident involves a missing sugar transaction, which was initially successful but later found to be "highly questionable" by an independent review. The company's management has denied criminal misconduct, but questions remain about its internal processes and due diligence.

images.alt_text: Dennis Chan

site_title: Deutsche Bank stumbles on path to profit as revenue recedes
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a steep fall in Q3 profit, with net profit decreasing 65% to 229 million euros, despite CEO Christian Sewing's claim that the bank is on track to return to profit this year. Revenue fell 9% to 6.175 billion euros, with weakness in key trading businesses. The bank expects 2018 revenue to be slightly lower than 2017 due to restructuring. Despite this, Sewing said the bank has its costs under control and sufficient capital to grow.

site_title: Bangkok goes all out for art
summary: The inaugural Bangkok Art Biennale opened with 200 works by 75 artists from 33 countries across 20 locations in Bangkok, transforming shopping centers, government buildings, and temples into exhibition spaces. The event aims to establish Bangkok as a key art hub in Asia. Meanwhile, other features include a dining experience at Faviken in Sweden, showcasing sustainable cuisine, and fashion advice from three industry insiders. The Bangkok Art Biennale runs until November 2018, offering a unique cultural experience to visitors.

site_title: Barclays beats Q3 profit forecasts despite investment bank costs
summary: Barclays reported a profit before tax of £1.6 billion in Q3, beating analyst forecasts and excluding litigation and conduct costs. The bank's investment bank revenue rose, but costs increased. CEO Jes Staley attributed the results to the bank's strategy, despite macroeconomic uncertainty and Brexit concerns. Barclays' shares rose 0.7% after the announcement, outperforming the STOXX European banks index. The bank also announced plans to redeem $2.65 billion of preference shares to reduce annual funding costs.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q3 DPU up 0.3% to 2.491 cents
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 0.3% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.491 cents, driven by higher contributions from Southgate Complex and Park Mall. However, gross revenue and net property income fell 2.5% and 11.4% respectively due to lower office revenue and higher maintenance charges. Despite this, the Reit's Singapore office portfolio maintained a committed occupancy of 99.6% and retail portfolio saw a 5.5% rise in footfall at Suntec City mall.

site_title: Why Brazil's reputation is on the ballot this week
summary: Brazil is set to hold a presidential election on Sunday, with right-wing candidate Jair Bolsonaro leading the polls. Bolsonaro's platform includes nostalgia for the country's former military dictatorship and controversial policies, raising concerns about Brazil's reputation as a modern democracy. The election's outcome will have a significant impact on the country's international standing, economy, and social stability, with many fearing a nosedive in reputation if Bolsonaro wins. The country is at a crossroads, having experienced a golden decade of growth but now facing economic and political troubles, including corruption and a Zika health crisis.

site_title: UK firms out of time to cope with no-deal Brexit: audit
summary: UK businesses have run out of time to prepare for a no-deal Brexit, according to a government audit. The National Audit Office found that uncertainty over Brexit negotiations has delayed preparations, and many businesses will need to make customs declarations for the first time. The audit estimated that 145,000 to 250,000 traders will need to make these declarations, and 11 out of 12 government projects to upgrade border systems are at risk of not being delivered on time. The UK's preparation for a no-deal Brexit has been deemed inadequate.

site_title: Daimler and Geely form ride-hailing joint venture in China
summary: Daimler and Geely Group have formed a 50:50 ride-hailing joint venture in China, led by Didi Chuxing, with plans to offer premium mobility services using Mercedes-Benz vehicles. The venture will provide services in several Chinese cities and is expected to use Mercedes-Benz S-Class, E-Class, and V-Class vehicles. Financial terms and investment plans were not disclosed. This partnership comes amid growing competition in the ride-hailing market, with significant growth potential in China, the world's largest car market.

site_title: Costs rise faster than revenue for M1 in Q3
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, reported a 5.5% decline in net profit to S$34.5 million for the third quarter, despite a 10.1% growth in operating revenue to S$274.6 million. Quarterly expenses rose 13.8% to S$230.5 million, mainly due to higher acquisition costs for post-paid customers. Mobile telecommunications revenue edged down, while fibre broadband saw a 4.4% increase in gross revenue. No dividend was recommended for the quarter, and the company's share price closed flat at S$2.10.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Driverless hover-taxis to take off in Singapore
summary: Singapore will host test flights of driverless hover-taxis by German firm Volocopter in the second half of 2024, with the goal of reducing traffic congestion. The electric air taxis can carry two people for 30 kilometers and are designed for inner-city missions. Volocopter plans to set up a product design and engineering center in Singapore to support expansion plans, which include rolling out fixed routes in cities. The hover-taxis will complement helicopter-hailing services, aiming to provide an alternative to traffic jams in Asia's major cities.

site_title: Tesla brings forward earnings report
summary: Tesla is set to release its earnings report, with Wall Street expecting the company to turn a profit for the first time in months. The stock surged 13% on Tuesday due to speculation that CEO Elon Musk is sharing good news. Musk has stated that Tesla will post profit and positive cash flow every quarter, and some analysts, including Citron Research's Andrew Left, are now bullish on the company's prospects. Tesla delivered 83,500 vehicles in the third quarter and is expected to show a profit, with some analysts predicting the company's third consecutive quarterly profit.

site_title: Billionaire family behind Tetra Pak revealed as mystery IFF shareholders
summary: Billionaire siblings Kirsten, Finn, and Jorn Rausing, who control the Tetra Laval food carton business, have become IFF's top shareholder, owning nearly 20% of the company through a Liechtenstein shell fund called the Haldor Foundation. The foundation's US$2.54 billion stake in IFF has driven up the company's share price by nearly 7% over two years. The Rausing siblings' investments are not connected to their Tetra Laval business, and they are seeking "fairly safe stocks" in the consumer products industry.

site_title: FCT posts 3.6% drop in Q4 DPU to 2.862 Singapore cents
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 3.6% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.862 Singapore cents for its Q4 2018, due to a 4.9% decline in net property income to S$32.88 million. Gross revenue rose 0.5% to S$48.51 million. Rising property expenses and non-property expenses, mainly due to higher borrowing costs, contributed to the decline. Despite this, FCT's portfolio occupancy remained stable at 94.7%. The trust expects stable performance from its suburban malls and will focus on continuous improvement and acquisition strategies.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yanlord Land Group's subsidiary has acquired a 30% stake in a Suzhou housing project for 450 million yuan (S$89.4 million). The deal is expected to have no material impact on the group's financials. Meanwhile, OUE's Brian Riady has become the group's new hospitality division CEO. The OKP Holdings case involving the fatal Pan Island Expressway viaduct collapse has been adjourned to November 13.

site_title: Industry 4.0: Are businesses stepping up to be future-ready?
summary: Industry 4.0 adoption in Asia remains uneven, despite government support and investments in technology and workforce training. Key industry players have adopted Industry 4.0, achieving productivity improvements of up to 15%. However, business leaders remain cautious, prioritizing business cases and strategic planning. To succeed, organizations must transform processes, not just apply technologies, and invest in worker 4.0 training and education. The adoption rate will grow as proven use cases emerge, driven by top-down implementation and overcoming resistance. Governments and corporations must collaborate to develop industry 4.0-related talents and skills.

site_title: A banker's woe: Chinese wealth may get harder to snag for global bankers
summary: A Singapore-based UBS wealth management banker was denied exit from China, sparking concerns for global private banks seeking to tap China's trillions of dollars in offshore wealth. The move, amid Beijing's growing curbs on overseas investments and outflows, has prompted banks to reconsider travel to China and may lead to clients and their offshore advisers becoming more cautious in making new investments. The incident highlights the challenges faced by foreign private banks in the wealth management business in China, where regulations and restrictions on business ownership and products have deterred most banks from having an onshore presence.

site_title: The next big things
summary: Two Brunei-based startups, Network Integrity Assurance Technologies Sdn Bhd (NiAT) and Mixmediaworx, have received recognition from the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES) for their innovative products and services. NiAT, a satellite communications service provider, has successfully bridged the gap in accessing remote and rural telecommunications, while Mixmediaworx, a full-service creative agency, has managed to thrive in the small Bruneian market by conducting frequent market surveys and maintaining strong client relations. Both startups have demonstrated scalability and profitability, with NiAT being profit-making in its last three years.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals drop to six-month low
summary: UK mortgage approvals fell to a six-month low of 38,505 in September, down 6.7% from the previous year, following the Bank of England's interest rate rise in August. This marks the lowest number of mortgages approved since March. Demand to refinance home loans also decreased, indicating a potential slowdown in the housing market.

site_title: Temasek upsizes retail bond offer to meet demand
summary: Temasek Holdings has upsized its S$400 million retail bond offer by S$100 million following strong demand, with the additional allocation going to the public tranche. About 70% of bonds in the public offer went to applicants who applied for S$30,000 or less. The company's T2023-S$ Temasek Bond will begin trading on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard on Friday, with retail investors able to check their allocations by logging into their CDP accounts.

site_title: Changing the perception of convenience with technology
summary: Singapore unveils a unified payment QR code, adopted by 27 payment schemes, to capitalize on a growing mobile payment appetite. Retail businesses, including the fuel industry, are encouraged to adopt digital transformation to meet customer demands. A survey found that drivers prioritize convenience and cost savings when using mobile apps for fuel purchases. As mobile payments become the norm, the payment process is expected to shift towards seamless transactions with minimal consumer intervention, revolutionizing the way consumers interact with merchants.

site_title: Recent collective sales face challenges galore
summary: Singapore's collective sales face challenges as owners struggle to lower initial reserve prices under revised guidelines. The Gilstead Mansion, a 24-unit development, has relaunched its tender at S$65 million, a S$3 million reduction from its initial guide price. The site's owners have secured an 80% mandate to lower the price, with a S$1,524.70 per sq ft per plot ratio, offering no development charge. The revised guidelines increase the average unit size for new private flats in the Stevens-Chancery area, potentially reducing the number of units that can be developed on the site.

images.alt_text: The 24-unit Gilstead Mansion in the Novena area has relaunched its tender at S$65 million, or S$3 million below the guide price they initially announced in June.

site_title: US FCC votes for opening more spectrum to connected devices
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) voted unanimously to open 1200 megahertz of spectrum in the 6 GHz band for unlicensed devices, such as Wi-Fi routers and baby monitors, making up to five times the current spectrum available. This move aims to accommodate the growing number of connected devices. The FCC also plans to study whether to tap another largely unused block of spectrum.

site_title: Made-in-Singapore electric cars a boon for manufacturing sector's future
summary: British technology giant Dyson has chosen Singapore as the location for its first electric car manufacturing facility, a significant endorsement of the country's growing reputation as a hub for high-tech manufacturing. The decision, made by Dyson CEO James Rowan, is based on Singapore's expertise in advanced manufacturing, global connectivity, and access to Chinese markets. The facility, expected to be completed by 2020 and producing its first model by 2021, is a win-win for both Singapore and Dyson, with the country's ongoing push towards environmentally-friendly transport systems set to receive a boost.

site_title: Dream sculpture by local artist unveiled at Sports Hub
summary: A symbolic art piece titled "Dream" was unveiled at the Singapore Sports Hub, commemorating women in sport and entertainment. Inspired by Billie Jean King's quote, the sculpture features a giant metallic tennis ball with a young girl leaping to hit it. Commissioned by the Sports Hub, Sport Singapore, and WTA, it aims to inspire the next generation to dream big. The piece will be displayed at the north entrance of the Indoor Stadium and is part of the Sports Hub's plans to celebrate Singapore's sports and arts heritage.

images.alt_text: Local artist Baet Yeok Kuan and former world No 1 tennis player Billie Jean King posing for photographs in front of Dream.

site_title: Shortlisting the creme de la creme
summary: The ACES Awards Jury Panel chairman Hemant K Batra commended the selection of exemplary business leaders and sustainability advocates in the Asian region. The jury, comprising global thought leaders, shortlisted 280 candidates for their excellence in corporate growth, governance, and sustainability. The panel acknowledged the challenging task of selecting the "crème de la crème" and praised the professional team of analysts and researchers for their assistance.

site_title: Changi Airport Group full-year net profit up 28% to S$849m
summary: Changi Airport Group's net profit rose 28.3% to S$849 million for the 2017-2018 financial year, driven by record highs in passengers, concession sales, and air freight throughput. The airport saw 63 million passengers, including the one billionth passenger, and 2.1 million tonnes of air freight. Concession sales reached S$2.5 billion, and Changi Airport was voted Skytrax's World's Best Airport for the sixth consecutive time. The airport's capacity is expected to increase by three million passengers per annum with the upcoming Jewel Changi Airport and T1 expansion.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Developing career technology
summary: Viventis Search Asia, an Asian human resource company, has been recognized as one of the most promising SMEs in the region. Established in 2001, the organization has shifted its focus from manpower recruitment to career creation, developing a strategy called "The Future of Career Creation." With a customer base of 1,445, Viventis has built its business into three core pillars: Talent Attraction, Talent Development, and Career Technology. The company aims to become a market leader in career creation by 2020 and has been named one of the most socially engaged staffing agencies in APAC by LinkedIn.

site_title: CITIC Envirotech Q3 net profit falls 55.4%
summary: CITIC Envirotech's third-quarter net profit fell 55.4% to S$21.9 million due to a lower gross profit margin for its civil works business. Revenue expanded 4.1% to S$238.2 million, driven by its membrane system segment. The company remains optimistic about its prospects despite China's increasingly progressive environmental policies. Net asset value per share slipped to 78.81 cents.

site_title: The green factor in success
summary: DSM Nutritional Products Pacific Asia, a leading nutrition corporation, has been recognized for its minimal negative impact on the environment, community, and society. As one of the top contenders for the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards, the company has implemented various eco-friendly practices, including renewable energy sources and sustainable products. DSM's products, such as recyclable carpets and sustainability-enhancing enzymes, are known for their environmental superiority. The company has also made significant contributions to humanitarian causes, including developing products for malnourished people in developing nations. DSM has received numerous awards for its sustainability efforts, including the Climate A list and the Humanitarian of the Year award.

site_title: TSMP leverages high-tech, but aims to be 'high touch'
summary: TSMP Law Corporation, a Singaporean law firm, is urging the government to create a platform for local law firms to adopt artificial intelligence (AI) technology, as it is not financially feasible for small and medium-sized firms to build their own capabilities. The firm, which positions itself as a "high-touch" firm, believes that AI can complement human expertise, but lacks the critical ability to understand psychology and provide personalized work. TSMP's strategy focuses on building strong client relationships and investing in human resources, allowing the firm to counter the disruption caused by technology.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: UK to remain BlackRock's EMEA HQ after Brexit: memo
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, will maintain its European regional headquarters in the UK after Brexit, relocating only a few roles to expanded offices in the Netherlands and France. The firm, which employs around 3,000 staff in the UK and manages $6.3 trillion worldwide, will retain three times as many staff in Britain as in all remaining EU countries.

site_title: Going beyond business, empowering communities
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES) recognized organisations that measure success beyond the bottom line, focusing on positive social impact. The initiative brings together winning leaders and companies to share insights and ideas on socially responsible business practices. This year's awards highlighted the positive contributions of companies across the region, promoting a "prosper thy neighbour" approach to business.

site_title: Helping companies grow in Vietnam
summary: DKSH Vietnam Co Ltd, an industry champion, is the leading market expansion services provider for companies seeking to grow in Vietnam. The company has 22 business locations, 4,500 employees, and invests in infrastructure and community development. DKSH Vietnam prioritizes sustainability, adhering to corporate governance, environmental regulations, and supporting local communities. Its extensive network and employee base enable it to effectively support businesses in Vietnam's growing market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers are bullish on Singtel, expecting its earnings to grow in Q1 2019 and 2020 forecasts due to Telkomsel's recovery and stable core business. A 12-month forward price-to-earnings ratio of 16x and 5.5% yield make Singtel attractive. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust is also recommended for its undervalued price, trading at 0.43x forward price-to-book ratio.

site_title: Saudis buy into Chinese mega oil refinery to lock in sales
summary: Saudi Arabia's Aramco is investing in a 400,000 barrel-a-day Chinese mega refinery on Zhoushan island, securing a long-term contract to supply 120,000 barrels a day. This deal is part of Aramco's strategy to invest in Asian refineries and boost its market share in the region. The acquisition marks a significant investment in China's oil and petrochemical industry, with Aramco planning to invest in a total 1 million to 1.5 million barrels a day of Chinese refining and petrochemical capacity.

site_title: A new way of doing business
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES) was held on October 11, 2018, at the Collyer Ballroom, Fairmont Singapore. The event celebrated socially conscious business practices in South-east Asia, with CEOs noting the shift towards human leaders and transparent business practices. Shanggari B, CEO of MORS Group, emphasized the need for corporations to adapt to changing consumer behavior and social media's impact on marketing. The event brought together corporate leaders for informal networking and recognized award winners at an after-party at Bar Rouge, Swissotel The Stamford.

site_title: Risk aversion, fragile sentiment prevail
summary: Asian markets finished mixed on Wednesday, with the Shanghai composite gaining 0.33% and Japan's Nikkei 225 rising 0.37%. However, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slipped 0.38% and South Korea's Kospi fell 0.4%. Risk aversion dominated the market, with US stocks finishing lower due to Caterpillar Inc.'s report on rising costs. Tech stocks were also affected, with chip companies falling after Texas Instruments gave disappointing guidance. Energy firms were impacted by crude oil prices tumbling 4% after Saudi energy minister commented on the country's ability to supply more oil.

site_title: Timing and opportunity: China's challenge to the US
summary: China, under the leadership of President Xi Jinping, is challenging the US for global supremacy. Following a decade of economic growth and a global financial crisis, China adopted a more assertive foreign policy in 2009. Xi Jinping, who had been preparing to succeed Hu Jintao, seized the opportunity to secure his position and launched the Belt and Road Initiative, a plan to link over 60 countries. China's growing economic and military power has led to a confrontation with the US, with the Trump administration responding with a trade war and counterproposals. Xi's decision to act quickly may have been motivated by the fear of being surpassed by China in the future.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q3 profit falls 35% to S$3.77m
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 35% drop in Q3 net profit to S$3.77 million, due to the absence of a one-off gain from last year. Revenue for the quarter fell 6% to S$94.6 million. The company aims to focus on its pipeline of projects and complete 18 Robinson before the end of the year to realise material developer's profit.

site_title: A talent magnet that empowers job-seekers
summary: Globe Telecom, a leading telecommunications provider in the Philippines, was named Best Workplace of the Year at the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards. With a staff force of 7,206, the company boasts a low attrition rate of 10.2%, significantly below the industry average. Established in 1935, Globe Telecom operates a large mobile, fixed line, and broadband network, and is listed on the Philippines Stock Exchange with a market capitalization of US$3.8 billion. The company's commitment to corporate social responsibility and employee satisfaction has earned it recognition as a highly sought-after employer.

site_title: Office landlords woo tenants with luxe amenities
summary: Commercial landlords in the US are offering luxury amenities such as pool tables, craft beer, and sleep pods to attract tenants in a sluggish market. The trend is driven by a desire to integrate work and life, and to provide a balance between the two. Landlords are also trying to compete with shared-office providers like WeWork, which are adding to the vacancy rate. The amenities are often provided at no extra cost to tenants, and can include nap rooms, table tennis, and coffee stations. Some landlords report increased occupancy rates and rents after implementing these luxury amenities.

site_title: For pharma, volatility and value are two sides of the same coin
summary: Singapore's pharmaceutical industry experienced double-digit growth for the four months to July, with July exports surging 109%. Despite the volatility, industry players predict a steady trajectory due to growing regional demand and strong regulatory support. The sector's volatility stems from base-effect blips, inventory stockpiling, and changes in drugmaker portfolios. To address this, the Economic Development Board (EDB) promotes a diversified manufacturing sector, focusing on industries with high automation and skilled workforces, such as biopharma. The industry's 3.7% share of the economy and S$16.9 billion in output in 2018 demonstrate its significance, with companies investing in new facilities and technology to boost production.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

For the four months to July, Singapore's export-oriented drug industry notched up double-digit yearly growth, while July exports surged a stunning 109 per cent - yet industry players are hard put to forecast a consistent trajectory.

site_title: Hitting the sweet spot
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES) recognized three winners in Asia: KDN Company Limited, Combiphar, and Triton Holding Public Company Limited. KDN, a Krispy Kreme franchise, achieved 1 billion baht in cumulative revenue within six years, while Combiphar, an Indonesian pharmaceutical company, championed a healthy tomorrow for its community through initiatives like COMBI HOPE. Triton Holding, a diversified investment holding company, focused on sustainable growth and performance through its long-term vision and investments. The companies demonstrated their commitment to sustainable business models, innovation, and employee development.

site_title: ECB reviews monetary policy framework as Governing Council meets
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is reviewing its monetary policy framework amid a decade of quantitative easing, which has significantly impacted interest rates. The bank is considering whether to revert to a system of controlling rates by keeping liquidity tight, or maintain a floor of minus 0.4% for holding banks' deposits overnight. The decision will have long-term implications for the credibility of monetary policy. ECB staff are reviewing the framework, with some officials arguing that large balance sheets and policy tools are more effective, while others suggest scaling back to avoid crimping money markets.

site_title: Beyond R&D: Capturing and commercialising IP
summary: Singapore aims to accelerate innovation growth through its Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 Plan, increasing the existing R&D tax deduction from 150% to 250% for staff costs and consumables incurred on qualifying R&D projects. To capture intellectual property (IP) arising from R&D, the government introduced the Intellectual Property Development Incentive (IDI), providing concessionary tax rates of 5% or 10% on qualifying IP income. The IDI aims to encourage the use of IP, such as copyrights and patents, and is expected to send a positive signal to large companies on where to place their R&D dollars.

site_title: Euro slides to two-month low on growth fears
summary: The euro slid to a two-month low, dipping below $1.14, after eurozone business growth slowed more than expected, with German private-sector growth and French manufacturing hitting record lows. The eurozone's Purchasing Managers Index showed a slower-than-expected decline, sparking concerns about the region's economic growth outlook. The European Central Bank's monetary policy meeting on Thursday is expected to address the deepening row between the EU and Italy over Rome's budget, adding to the euro's downward pressure.

site_title: Airline passenger numbers could double to 8.2 billion in 2037: IATA
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) forecasts airline passenger numbers to double to 8.2 billion by 2037, driven by strong demand in Asia, with a 3.5% compound annual growth rate. However, protectionism risks curtailing growth, with 60 million fewer passengers expected over the next 20 years.

site_title: First and foremost
summary: DatVietVAC, founded in 1994, is Vietnam's largest and only vertically integrated media entertainment technology group. It has the largest national market share and invests in new businesses to build a world-class digital economy. The company has three core business pillars: communications services, content provision, and media ownership. DatVietVAC is embracing digital transformation, aiming to triple its digital revenues within five years. CEO Dinh Ba Thanh, a winner of the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards, is a bridge builder and media revolutionary, actively involved in corporate social responsibility.

images.alt_text: Dinh Ba Thanh, is both a bridge builder and a media revolutionary. As a leader who has embraced the concept of sustainability and social awareness, DatVietVAC's CEO is actively involved in corporate social responsibility.

site_title: Vibrant Group unit will not pursue legal appeals, after fee waiver applications rejected
summary: Vibrant Group's Blackgold International Holdings subsidiary unit, Chongqing Heijin Industrial, will not pursue two Chinese court appeals after fee waiver applications were rejected. The unit was held liable for 197.8 million yuan in a debt lawsuit brought by China Minsheng Banking Corp. Vibrant's board stated that the company had no prior knowledge of the alleged contractual disputes over loan agreements. The company's share price fell 0.6% to S$0.167 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Don't let the weather disrupt your business
summary: The Asia-Pacific region is experiencing an increase in natural catastrophes, with economic losses from 2017 reaching US$31 billion, with many mega-cities highly exposed to natural perils. Parametric insurance is a solution to fill the protection gap, providing cover and convenience for businesses. It insures the probability of a pre-defined event occurring and pays out a fixed amount when such conditions are met, offering transparency and quick access to liquidity. Companies are reviewing their insurance cover to complement existing policies, with airlines and airports using parametric solutions to mitigate revenue losses and reputational damage.

images.alt_text: A satellite handout showing Hurricane Willa on Mexico's Pacific coast on Tuesday. The frequency, severity and economic losses from natural disasters have risen.

site_title: Building influence
summary: AP Thailand Private Company Limited, a leading Thai property developer, has been recognized as one of Asia's Most Influential Companies at the Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards. The company has consistently delivered record-breaking revenues, innovative designs, and a strong focus on sustainability. AP Thailand has pioneered "living innovation" through designs such as double-access bathrooms and sky kitchens, and has set a new benchmark in property development by using AI BIM in its total process. The company's mission is to provide the best quality of life to its residents, and has invested heavily in human resource development through its AP Academy.

images.alt_text: AP Thailand Private Company Limited's design innovations include double-access bathrooms, sky kitchens and "multiverse layouts" - which create unique living experiences. The company's mission statement is to provide the best quality of life to its residents.

site_title: Explosive devices found in mail sent to Hillary Clinton and Obama
summary: Two explosive devices were found in mail sent to former President Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, according to the Secret Service. The devices were similar to one found at billionaire George Soros' home. The packages were intercepted as potential explosive devices and were handled accordingly. A full scope investigation has been initiated to determine the source and identity of those responsible. The motive behind the attempted bombings remains unclear, with no claim of responsibility.

site_title: Tim Cook takes aim at companies that stockpile private data
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook criticized companies like Facebook and Google for collecting user data, likening their services to "surveillance." Cook emphasized the importance of privacy and called for federal laws in the US to protect it, citing the EU's General Data Protection Regulation. He contrasted Apple's approach, which collects as little data as possible, with competitors' business models based on harvesting personal information for advertising. Cook's comments come amid scrutiny over recent user data breaches at Facebook and Google, and as Apple begins to mend its relationship with the EU after a tax dispute.

site_title: EU lawmakers move to ban throw-away plastics
summary: EU lawmakers voted to ban throw-away plastics such as straws and place a 90% recycling obligation on plastic bottles by 2025. Single-use plastic products with alternatives will be banned by 2021, including polystyrene fast-food containers and oxo-degradable plastics. EU states must also cover the costs of waste management. The proposal is part of the EU's effort to clean up ocean litter, and the final rules still need approval from member states.

site_title: Why give only during Christmas?
summary: Singapore businesses can consider extending their corporate giving beyond the Christmas season by setting up systems and policies for regular or quarterly giving. Despite 50% of businesses in Singapore giving, only one in four do so regularly, and many rely on ad-hoc or seasonal giving. Integrating giving into core business functions can make it more practical and sustainable, as 64% of companies that give have done so. By doing so, businesses can foster a shift in mindset and create a competitive advantage.

site_title: Trump's move to block WTO judges forces it to establish reform plan
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has blocked appointments to the World Trade Organization's (WTO) judges, threatening to pull the US out of the organization, and forcing the WTO to develop a reform plan. The move has left the WTO's dispute settlement system at risk, with the appeal system set to cease functioning in December 2019 if no new judges are appointed. The WTO is scrambling to increase the number of judges and rewrite trade rules, including those on industrial subsidies, state-owned firms, and technology transfer.

site_title: US new-home sales tumble to lowest in almost two years
summary: US new-home sales plummeted to their lowest level in almost two years in September, with a 1.5% decline in the South region potentially attributed to Hurricane Florence. This marks the weakest pace since December 2016, amidst signs of a constrained market due to rising property prices, higher mortgage rates, and a scarcity of affordable listings. The data also shows a 90% confidence range in the sales change, highlighting volatility in the market.

site_title: Freeport third-quarter profit beats on higher copper sales
summary: Freeport-McMoRan Inc, the world's largest publicly listed copper miner, reported a beat on quarterly profit due to higher copper sales. The company's third-quarter copper sales rose to $1.04 billion, driven by an average price of $2.80 per pound. Revenue increased 13% to $4.91 billion, exceeding estimates. Freeport agreed to sell a majority stake in its Indonesian mine to the government for $3.85 billion. On an adjusted basis, the company's net income rose to $514 million, or 35 cents per share.

site_title: Singtel puts US$250m into funding round to grow African telco
summary: Singtel has invested US$250 million in Airtel Africa Ltd, valuing the telco at US$4.4 billion, to tap into Africa's growing mobile money market. The investment aims to reduce debt and grow business ahead of an initial public offering (IPO). Singtel holds a 39.5% stake in Airtel Africa, which has 91 million customers and a mobile wallet service with 11.8 million subscribers. The deal reflects confidence in Africa's long-term growth potential, with the African continent expected to be the world's second-fastest growing economic zone by 2020.

site_title: CNN bureau in NY evacuated over suspicious package
summary: A CNN bureau in New York's Time Warner Center was evacuated after a suspicious package similar to those sent to Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton was reported. Police investigated the scene, but couldn't confirm the package's contents. The evacuation occurred after a fire alarm was triggered, causing the lights to go off. The incident occurred amid heightened tensions between the US and CNN due to its aggressive coverage of the Trump administration.

site_title: Former coal plant to become US$4.6b oasis on Lake Ontario
summary: A former 177-acre coal power plant site in Mississauga, Canada, is being transformed into a mixed-use community worth up to C$6 billion, featuring 8,000 housing units, 825,000 sq ft of employment space, and a 1 km pier on Lake Ontario. The project, led by Lakeview Community Partners Ltd, aims to provide affordable housing and connect the waterfront land, following the province's efforts to combat climate change. Construction is expected to begin in 2020 and last beyond a decade, with the site also featuring a 64-acre conservation area.

site_title: Stephen Riady's son to lead OUE hospitality division
summary: Stephen Riady's son, Brian Riady, a 28-year-old Singapore resident, has become the CEO of OUE's hospitality division, succeeding his father as executive chairman and substantial shareholder. Brian, a former Credit Suisse analyst, previously led lifestyle and entertainment at Lippo Group, where his father is a key figure. The appointment was made in accordance with the company's limits of authority and took into account his qualifications and experience.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Cathay Pacific Airways says data of 9.4 million passengers accessed
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported that the data of approximately 9.4 million passengers, including 860,000 passport numbers, 245,000 Hong Kong identity card numbers, and 403 expired credit card numbers, was accessed without authorization. The breach occurred in March 2018 and was discovered in May, with the Hong Kong Police notified. There is no evidence that the accessed data has been misused. Cathay Pacific stated that the compromised data includes names, nationalities, dates of birth, and travel history.

site_title: UK's GBK burger chain files for bankruptcy protection
summary: UK's GBK burger chain files for bankruptcy protection, citing millions of pounds of losses due to weak consumer spending and high costs. The chain's parent, Famous Brands, initiated a company voluntary arrangement (CVA) to avoid insolvency and ensure its continued existence. Despite being acquired in 2016, GBK's contribution to group profitability has been slower than anticipated, with factors including increased property rates and oversupply of restaurants affecting its performance.

site_title: Europe hit by steel import surge from US tariffs -industry body
summary: Europe's steel imports surged by 10% in the third quarter of 2018 due to US tariffs, particularly from Turkey, which faces a 50% tariff. The US tariffs led to a 40% increase in US steel prices, allowing European producers to sell some steel to the US market. As a result, steel that would have gone to the US was redirected to Europe, with imports now making up 25% of the EU market. Eurofer expects EU apparent steel consumption to rise 2.2% this year and 1.1% in 2019.

images.alt_text: Steel imports into Europe have risen sharply as a result of US tariffs, particularly from Turkey, threatening European steelmakers as demand growth in the continent slows, European steel association Eurofer said on Wednesday.

site_title: Saudi crown prince may be behind Khashoggi killing - Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman bears ultimate responsibility for Jamal Khashoggi's killing, contradicting Riyadh's claim of a "rogue operation." Trump suggested that Prince Mohammed's involvement was more than just a possibility, saying "the prince is running things over there more so at this stage." Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan's adviser described Prince Mohammed as having "blood on his hands" over Khashoggi's death, and international pressure mounts on Saudi Arabia amid global outrage and a joint investigation into the killing.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince bore ultimate responsibility for the operation that led to Jamal Khashoggi's killing, and Turkish police were allowed to extend their probe at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare board warns of expected Q3 net loss
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare's board warned of an expected Q3 net loss due to operating costs and the deconsolidation of Wuxi New District Phoenix Hospital. The hospital's shares were ordered to be handed over to another company, but its properties remain under the group's ownership. The deconsolidation is a result of this matter, mainly affecting the group's financial results for the quarter ending Sept 30.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Sunpower Group announces engineering contract for Pakistani power project
summary: Sunpower Group has announced an engineering contract with Nishat Mills in Pakistan, with Shandong Yangguang Engineering Design Institute providing design and start-up services for a power plant. The project, expected to be completed by end-2019, does not have a disclosed dollar value.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: No more cash to give South African state workers' pay increases
summary: South Africa's government has approved an inflation-busting pay increase for public servants but failed to allocate additional funds, ordering state departments to find the money within existing budgets. The three-year pay deal, costing 30.2 billion rand, will be funded within the public-sector wage bill, which already accounts for 35% of government expenditure. Finance Minister Tito Mboweni stated that the wage bill should be capped at 30%, citing the need for negotiation with trade unions. This move aims to control real spending growth despite the government's 1% decrease in employment numbers since 2013.

site_title: CITIC Envirotech Q3 net profit falls 55.4%
summary: CITIC Envirotech's Q3 net profit dropped 55.4% to S$21.9 million due to a lower gross profit margin in its civil works business. Revenue grew 4.1% to S$238.2 million, driven by its membrane system segment. Earnings per share declined to 0.91 Singapore cent from 2.17 Singapore cents last year. The company remains optimistic about its prospects despite increasing environmental policies in China.

site_title: Yanlord Land paying 450m yuan for 30% stake in Suzhou residential project
summary: Yanlord Land Group has invested 450 million yuan (S$89.4 million) for a 30% stake in a Suzhou residential project in China, according to the company's announcement. The project has a gross floor area of 141,864 square meters and a maximum plot ratio of 2.5. The deal is seen as in line with Yanlord's strategic focus on the Suzhou real estate market, with "strong demand for high-quality residential developments". The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on Yanlord's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.56 points lower at 1,690.04 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 2.3 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion. The market saw 620 losers compared to 245 gainers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with small gains, adding 0.22% to 25,401.17, after a 3% drop the previous day. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.57% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.52%. Investors remain cautious due to geopolitical and trade tensions.

site_title: Temasek upsizes bond offer to S$500m; extra S$100m goes to retail investors
summary: Temasek Holdings has increased its bond offer to S$500 million, with an additional S$100 million allocated to retail investors due to strong demand for its first retail bonds. The company had initially offered S$400 million. About 70% of bonds in the public offer went to applicants who applied for S$30,000 or less, and the final public offer size of S$300 million was about five times subscribed. The T2023-S$ Temasek Bond will be issued on Thursday and begin trading on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard on Friday.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to pay higher Q2 DPU of 1.98 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas India Trust will pay a Q2 DPU of 1.98 Singapore cents, a 32% increase from the previous year. The trust's distributable income rose 46% to S$20.6 million, driven by higher interest income and lower expenses. Net property income increased 4% to S$32.9 million, but total property income slipped 2% due to the Singdollar's gains against the Indian rupee.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Changi Airport Group FY2018 net profit up 28.3%
summary: Changi Airport Group reported a 28.3% increase in net profit to S$849 million for FY2018, driven by strong performance from Changi Airport, which achieved record highs in passengers, concession sales, and air freight throughput. The airport saw a record 63 million passengers and 2.1 million tonnes of cargo, with concession sales reaching S$2.5 billion. Changi was voted Skytrax's World's Best Airport for the sixth consecutive time. The airport's capacity is expected to increase by three million passengers per annum with the upcoming Jewel Changi Airport and T1 expansion.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Boeing profits surge after tax settlement, raises earnings estimate
summary: Boeing reported a 30.6% surge in profits to $2.4 billion for the third quarter, driven by strong demand for commercial and defense aircraft. Revenues rose 3.8% to $25.1 billion, with the company upgrading its full-year revenue forecast by $1 billion. Despite a production slowdown in Washington state, Boeing's profit margins surged due to increased production of other planes. The company booked 171 net orders, including major defense contracts, but faced one-time costs of $691 million. Boeing's shares jumped 3.8% to $363.17, alleviating concerns about US-China trade conflicts.

site_title: Singapore Life's new service enables critical illness claim payouts within 24 hours
summary: Singapore Life has launched a new service allowing critical illness claim payouts within 24 hours. This is the first insurer in Singapore to offer such a service, where clients must have a valid critical illness supplementary benefit and submit forms and documents by 3pm daily. Claims will be paid out by 6pm the next business day via FAST transfer or couriered cheque. The new service aims to streamline the claims process and provide a fuss-free and timely payout for customers.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust Q2 DPU up 1.3%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust reported a 1.3% increase in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.27 Singapore cents, driven by higher contributions from VivoCity, Mapletree Business City I, and Bank of America Merrill Lynch HarbourFront. Gross revenue rose 2.5% to S$109.92 million and net property income (NPI) increased 2.2% to S$86.26 million. The DPU for the six months ended September 30 was 4.5 cents, with gross revenue and NPI also rising.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower, Shanghai bounces
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.38% on Wednesday, extending a previous day's drop of over 3%, despite a recovery in mainland Chinese markets. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.33%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.24%. Geopolitical tensions and worries about the impact on global trade weighed on investor sentiment, despite bargain-buying efforts.

site_title: Russia opposes US OneWeb satellite service, cites security concerns
summary: Russia's state security agency, the Federal Security Service (FSB), is opposing the US-based OneWeb satellite startup's deal to bring internet access to remote Russia due to security concerns. The FSB fears the project could be used to gather intelligence and damage national security. OneWeb is relinquishing its majority stake in the venture after Moscow expressed objections, citing the potential for a foreign internet service provider to gain a monopoly over rural areas. The FSB prefers a similar network to be set up in partnership with India, China, and non-aggressive countries.

site_title: MCT's Q2 DPU up 1.3% as gross revenue, net property income rise
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 1.3% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.27 Singapore cents, driven by higher contributions from VivoCity and Mapletree Business City I. Gross revenue rose 2.5% to S$109.92 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 2.2% to S$86.26 million. VivoCity's shopper traffic and tenant sales grew 5.8% and 2.8% year-over-year, respectively, with a new integrated concept by NTUC FairPrice expected to open in FY19/20.

images.alt_text: VivoCity's new B1 retail extension, which spans 3,000 sq m. Its shopper traffic and tenant sales in Q2 respectively clocked growth of 5.8% and 2.8% y-o-y.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics sues insurer for 16m yuan over fatal industrial fire
summary: Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics is suing the Taizhou branch of the People's Insurance Company of China for 16.14 million yuan (S$3.21 million) over a fatal industrial fire at a Chinese storage facility in 2016. The company filed the claim in the Jingjiang People's Court after talks with Chinese legal advisers. Hengyang will provide updates to shareholders as developments occur in the lawsuit.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: South African Airways gets 5 billion rand, told to restructure debt
summary: South African Airways received a 5 billion rand (S$483.7 million) allocation from the National Treasury to repay debt, but will need to restructure almost double that amount due to insufficient cash. The airline faces 14.2 billion rand in repayments by March, with creditors to be engaged in negotiations to refinance or extend maturity dates. This is part of a broader challenge for state-owned companies struggling to refinance debt due to weak balance sheets, poor governance, and liquidity challenges.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q3 net profit falls 35%
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 35% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to S$3.77 million due to the absence of an one-off gain in the previous year. Revenue for the quarter fell 6% to S$94.6 million. The property developer sold most of its completed units and will focus on its pipeline projects, aiming to complete 18 Robinson before year-end to realize a material developer's profit.

site_title: Asean stock markets highly diversified: SGX report
summary: A report from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) reveals that Asean stock markets are highly diversified, with Singapore's Catalist-listed companies generating most of their turnover from regional neighbors. The SGX notes that Singapore is the largest intra-Asean exporter and importer of financial and transport services. The report concludes that the Asean stock market is diversified, similar to its economy, with regional neighbors contributing significantly to the sector.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon trading at 3,050.07, up 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,050.07, up 0.6% on the day, with 162 gainers outnumbering 140 losers. The Straits Times Index reached 3,050.07 as 885.6 million shares worth S$447 million changed hands. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, despite US trade uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: LTA awards contracts for 60 electric buses worth S$50 million to 3 firms
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has awarded contracts worth S$50 million to three firms for the procurement of 60 electric buses. The buses will be delivered progressively from next year to 2020. This move aims to enhance the country's public transportation system with cleaner and more environmentally friendly vehicles.

site_title: NTUC Income's new insurance plan shields commuters from surge pricing on Grab when it rains
summary: NTUC Income launched Droplet, an insurance product that shields commuters from surge pricing on Grab when it rains. The product, available for Grab rides only, covers up to 60% of trip fare or cancellation fee if a ride is booked during rainy weather. Consumers can purchase the "rainsurance" for a maximum of S$9.60 per day, with premium prices dynamically pegged to rain forecasts. The product is part of NTUC Income's efforts to reimagine insurance and address technological disruption's impact on insurance.

site_title: Ford names new China head to tackle daunting turnaround task
summary: Ford has appointed Anning Chen, a 57-year-old former Ford engineer and chairman of Chery Jaguar Land Rover in China, as the new head of its China operations. Chen will take over on November 1, tasked with fixing Ford's sales slump in the world's largest car market. The move comes after the previous head, Jason Luo, resigned abruptly in January. Ford's vehicle sales in China fell 43% in September, with sales down 30% in the first nine months of the year, and Chen's appointment aims to give Ford a better understanding of the market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend losses on global uncertainties; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.40% to 2,097.58 on Wednesday due to global uncertainties, including US-China tensions and Middle East tensions. US President Trump warned of building up nuclear arsenal to pressure Russia and China, leading to a decline in shares of top biopharma firms Celltrion and Samsung BioLogics. The won gained, while bond yields edged up, amidst the uncertainty.

site_title: China just saved Asia stocks from entering bear-market territory
summary: China's strong performance in the stock market has prevented Asia from entering bear-market territory, with the regional benchmark rising 0.3% as of mid-day trading. Chinese stocks, including the Shanghai Composite Index, rallied after a day of swings, while US stock-index futures also turned higher. The rally comes as expectations for a meeting between US President Trump and China's Xi Jinping are being lowered, and amid concerns about a rolling bear market in US equities.

site_title: Deutsche Bank Q3 net profit down 65% but above expectations
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 65% decline in net profit to 229 million euros in Q3, beating analyst expectations of 149 million euros. The decline is attributed to restructuring under new leadership. Despite the decline, the bank's results were seen as a positive sign for investors, as they beat expectations. The bank's restructuring efforts are ongoing, with a focus on improving its financial performance and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound
summary: European stock markets rebounded on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.4% to 6,981.11 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index climbed 0.2% and the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.6%. The rebound followed a slump the previous session due to geopolitical risks, including US tensions with Russia and Saudi Arabia, and trade issues with China. Banking stocks were in focus, with Deutsche Bank's share price slumping 3.4% and Barclays rising 0.6%.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks ended flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.69 point to 3,032.08. Losers outnumbered gainers 203 to 166, with about 1.61 billion shares worth S$970.4 million traded. The most actively traded counter was Rex International, which fell 16.1% to close at 7.3 cents.

site_title: Saudi Arabia will not penalise banks that boycotted conference
summary: Saudi Arabia's central bank governor Ahmed al-Kholifey stated that foreign banks that boycotted the recent investment conference in Riyadh due to concerns over Jamal Khashoggi's killing will not be penalized. Banks can still apply for and obtain licenses to operate in the kingdom. The decision comes amid recent weakness in the Saudi riyal's peg to the dollar, but the governor reiterated the country's commitment to defend the peg.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman poses for a selfie during the Future Investment Conference in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. October 23, 2018. Saudi Arabia's central bank governor said the kingdom will not penalize foreign banks that boycotted an investment conference in Riyadh because of the fallout from the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound, end higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded, ending higher on Wednesday as bargain-hunters supported the market. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.37% to 22,091.18, while the Topix index edged up 0.08% to 1,652.07. This follows a rally in other Asian bourses.

site_title: M1 Q3 net profit falls 5.5% amid higher acquisition, retention costs
summary: M1's Q3 net profit fell 5.5% to S$34.5 million due to higher acquisition and retention costs, despite 10.1% growth in operating revenue to S$274.6 million. Handset sales increased 34.1% to S$84.5 million, while service revenue rose 1.9% to S$190.2 million. Higher operating expenses, including cost of sales and "other costs," also contributed to the decline in earnings.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US: Boeing props up Dow at open, but chipmakers pose headwind
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened flat on Wednesday, despite Boeing's profit forecast easing concerns about slowing corporate profits. However, chipmakers and other China-reliant companies raised concerns, putting pressure on the S&P and Nasdaq. The Dow fell 0.07%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.10%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.19%.

images.alt_text: Dow opened flat on Wednesday after Boeing's profit forecast eased worries of slowing corporate profits, but dim outlook from other China-reliant companies, including chipmakers, kept the pressure on the S&P and Nasdaq.

site_title: Who showed up at the Saudi investment summit
summary: Ken Moelis, founder of Moelis & Co, attended the Saudi investment summit despite many US finance executives skipping the event due to international outrage over Jamal Khashoggi's death. Moelis, who advises on the planned initial public offering of Saudi Aramco, emphasized the importance of relationships in business, even if they can't be accounted for on a balance sheet. Other notable attendees included CEOs from Total SA, Baker Hughes, and Schlumberger Ltd, while top executives from HSBC, Blackstone, and JPMorgan Chase opted not to participate.

site_title: Gilstead Mansion relaunches collective sale tender at S$65m
summary: Gilstead Mansion has relaunched its collective sale tender at S$65 million, S$3 million lower than its initial guide price, to attract potential buyers before new guidelines on maximum allowable units outside central areas take effect. The 24-unit development in the Novena area has a land area of 35,751 sq ft and an existing gross floor area of 42,632 sq ft, with a revised price of S$1,524.70 per plot ratio. The tender will close on Nov 22 at 2pm.

images.alt_text: Gilstead Mansion in District 11 which is now relaunched for tender for a S$65 million collective sale following July's cooling measures.

site_title: Heightened cancer risk in tall people down to number of cells: study
summary: Taller individuals have a higher risk of cancer due to having more cells, which increases the likelihood of abnormal cell growth. Researchers found that for every 10 centimeters in height, the risk of cancer increases by 10%. This "hard-wired" risk cannot be reduced by obvious means. The study, which examined populations across three continents, suggests that taller humans have more opportunities for cancerous cells to develop. However, the risk is relatively small for most people, and "unusually tall" individuals may benefit from additional screening.

site_title: Australian shares close lower, weighed by energy sector; NZ down
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% lower on Wednesday, their fourth consecutive session of losses, weighed down by a 5% decline in crude oil prices. The energy sector fell 2.1%, with Woodside Petroleum and Santos Ltd declining 1.3% and 2.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, gold stocks rose 2.9% on higher prices, while financial and healthcare shares recovered. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.4%.

site_title: German growth momentum evaporates as manufacturing orders shrink
summary: Germany's economy started the fourth quarter with a slowdown, as private-sector activity and factory orders contracted for the first time in four years. The composite Purchasing Managers' Index dropped to 52.7 in October, below all estimates, due to concerns over protectionism, financial-market volatility, and business confidence. Companies cut their profit forecasts, and the European Central Bank may face concerns about sustained weakness in Europe's powerhouse economy. Threats of a trade war and Brexit uncertainty weighed on German sentiment, pushing companies' expectations to the lowest level in four years.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 0.20 points lower at 1,697.40 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 46.89 million lots worth R21.56 million. Losers outpaced gainers 109 to 60.

site_title: Asia: Markets suffer fresh gains, energy firms tank
summary: Asian markets fell, extending a sell-off fueled by geopolitics and negative news, including China's growth concerns, Brexit talks, Italy's budget standoff, and the killing of Jamal Khashoggi. Energy firms took a hit, with oil prices plummeting after Saudi Arabia boosted output to maintain supplies. Investors fled riskier assets, seeking safety, and US stocks also fell, with the US equities' "Teflon persona" questioned. Despite an afternoon bounce, losses were reported in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Seoul, and Sydney, while Singapore edged higher.

site_title: Ex-Citigroup trader on trial for foreign exchange rigging
summary: A former Citigroup trader, Rohan Ramchandani, is on trial in New York for allegedly conspiring with two other traders to rig the foreign-exchange market. His former colleague, Carly Hosler, testified in his defense, describing him as "very professional" and "very smart," and saying he was a natural with the markets. However, Hosler claimed the allegations were "ludicrous" and that the traders were simply joking in a chatroom, rather than colluding to fix prices. Closing arguments are scheduled for Wednesday.

site_title: Philippines to re-open 'cesspool' Boracay after clean up
summary: The Philippines reopens its island resort Boracay after a six-month clean-up, aiming to restore its damaged environment. The island, once a "cesspool" due to overdevelopment, will have reduced hotels, a cap on visitors, and anti-beach party rules. The government hopes this will protect the island's turquoise waters and white sand beaches from the impact of 2 million tourists per year. The new rules, enforced by controlling hotel rooms and banning activities like fire eating and casino visits, are part of a "culture of sustainable tourism" in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: The Philippines re-opens its crown jewel resort island Boracay to holidaymakers on Friday, after a six-month clean up aimed at repairing the damage inflicted by years of unrestrained mass tourism.

site_title: Companies say they're ready to move supply chains from China
summary: Companies are preparing to relocate supply chains from China due to the escalating US-China trade war. US President Donald Trump imposed 10% tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports, with plans to raise it to 25% in January. Executives from companies such as Avery Dennison, Canadian National Railway, and Logitech International said they are ready to move supply chains to other regions, including Vietnam, Bangladesh, and Indonesia, to mitigate the impact of tariffs. Some companies, like Philips and Kuehne & Nagel, already have a presence in these regions and plan to expand their operations.

site_title: Players on edge for record US$1.6b jackpot in US Mega Millions drawing
summary: A record-breaking US$1.6 billion Mega Millions jackpot was drawn on Tuesday, with the winning numbers 5, 28, 62, 65, 70 and Mega Ball 5. Players have until October 29 to claim the prize, which can be taken as a lump sum of US$904 million or paid out over 29 years. The massive jackpot has sparked excitement across the US, but experts warn that the winner will face numerous headaches, including tax implications and public scrutiny.

site_title: Singapore Infrastructure Dispute-Management Protocol introduced to aid big infrastructure projects
summary: Singapore has introduced the Infrastructure Dispute-Management Protocol to aid in the management of disputes in big infrastructure projects. The protocol sets up a Dispute Board of neutral experts to quickly resolve issues as they arise, aiming to minimize time and cost overruns. The protocol was launched at the Asia-Singapore Infrastructure Roundtable and has attracted interest from parties worth S$500 million or more. It aims to improve bankability by standardizing terms, planning, and structuring projects to secure finance, and mitigating risks through mediation and other dispute resolution processes.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Euro edges up before EU decision on Italy budget
summary: The euro rose before a European Commission meeting on Italy's budget, which could lead to Brussels rejecting the plan and demanding changes. Investors are focused on potential European political turmoil amid the dispute and Britain's Brexit stalemate. The Commission's decision may impact the Italian economy and the eurozone's stability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on bargain hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.77% on Wednesday, rebounding from a sharp drop the previous day, as investors digested geopolitical concerns and digestion of revelations about Jamal Khashoggi's murder. The Nikkei 225 index gained 168.68 points to 22,179.46, while the Topix index rose 11.32 points to 1,662.04. Bargain hunters drove the rebound, with SoftBank and Nintendo leading gains.

site_title: Chinese chemicals maker Tongyi defaults on bonds: paper
summary: Chinese chemicals maker Tongyi Industrial Group has defaulted on 450 million yuan (S$89.6 million) of bonds, according to a statement by underwriter Western Securities. The default occurred on October 19, with Tongyi failing to make timely payments of principal and interest on the privately-issued bonds. Reuters was unable to reach Tongyi officials for comment.

site_title: US tech giants split over corporate tax to help homeless
summary: US tech giants are divided over a proposed ballot measure in San Francisco to tax the city's wealthiest companies to help address homelessness. The measure, Proposition C, would generate $250-300 million in annual taxes, funding housing and mental health services. Backers argue it's a necessary solution, while tech giants like Twitter, Uber, and Airbnb oppose it, citing concerns over increased costs and potential job losses. The measure will be decided by voters on November 6.

site_title: Decades of war shatter Afghanistan's glassblowing craft
summary: Afghanistan's centuries-old glassblowing craft, known as Herati glassware, is at risk of dying out due to decades of war, poverty, and cheap imports. The once-thriving industry has declined, with only a few days of operation a month, as demand for the distinctive colored glassware is low. Artisans like Ghulam Sakhi, who has been making glassware for generations, struggle to make ends meet, with prices starting at $6 per piece. Without government support or tourism, Sakhi fears he may be the last of Herat's glassblowers, leaving the craft to be lost forever.

images.alt_text: Hunched and shrivelled, Afghan glassblower Ghulam Sakhi deftly blows and twirls molten glass into delicate blue and green goblets and vases - a craft passed down for generations but now at risk of dying out.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singtel is investing US$250m in Airtel Africa, valuing the company at US$4.4 billion. Temasek is upsizing its bond offer to S$500m, with an additional S$100m allocated to retail investors. Global Invacom is acquiring Tactilis for US$200m. Gilstead Mansion has relaunched its collective sale tender at S$65m. LTA has awarded contracts for 60 electric buses worth S$50m to three firms. NTUC Income has launched a new insurance plan to shield commuters from surge pricing on Grab when it rains. Singapore shares ended flat on Wednesday with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.69 points.

images.alt_text: AIRTEL Africa will be valued at US$4.4 billion after the funding round, the proceeds of which will be used to reduce Airtel Africa's existing debt of around US$5 billion and grow its business ahead of an intended initial public offering, Singtel said.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.3% to 3,041.65
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,041.65, driven by gains from local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC, which rose 0.46%, 0.4%, and 0.76% respectively. The index edged out losses in the US and Tokyo markets, where stocks fell amid geopolitical concerns and mixed earnings.

site_title: Global Invacom to acquire Malaysia biometric solutions firm Tactilis for US$200m
summary: Global Invacom Group has agreed to acquire Malaysian biometric solutions firm Tactilis for US$200 million. Tactilis, valued on a "willing-buyer and willing-seller basis," offers a proprietary biometric system-on-card solution, the Tactilis Touch, capable of multi-factor identity authentication using fingerprints, face recognition, and iris recognition. The acquisition aims to expand Global Invacom's presence in the biometric solutions market.

site_title: Security scare briefly locks down US nuclear weapons facility
summary: Employees at the Pantex Plant in Amarillo, Texas, were briefly locked down due to a suspicious vehicle in a parking lot. The incident occurred at noon and was resolved after authorities searched the vehicle and found no prohibited items or explosives. The facility, operated by government contractors, is the US's primary nuclear weapons assembly and dismantlement site. The emergency response was deemed unnecessary and the facility is operating normally, according to the National Nuclear Security Administration.

site_title: Australia: Shares mostly flat as financials offset energy losses, NZ flat
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Wednesday, closing at 5,840.70, as energy stocks declined due to a 5% drop in oil prices. The decline in oil prices offset gains in the financial and healthcare sectors. Energy stocks, such as those in the S&P/ASX 200 index, were the main losers, while other sectors like finance and healthcare rose.

site_title: Bank Indonesia warns of slower Q3 growth rates
summary: Bank Indonesia maintained its benchmark interest rate at 5.75% as expected, citing efforts to narrow the current account gap and maintain foreign investor attractiveness. However, the central bank warned of slower Q3 growth rates, citing weaker-than-expected export growth and higher oil prices. Growth in the July-September period is expected to be "a little less than 5.1%," potentially pulling the full-year 2018 growth rate to the lower end of its 5.0-5.4% outlook.

site_title: When Sears flourished, so did workers; at Amazon, it's more complicated
summary: Amazon has stopped giving stock to hundreds of thousands of employees, despite lifting its minimum hourly wage to $15. This decision highlights how lower-paid employees across corporate America have been locked out of profit-sharing and stock grants, with shareholders' interests taking precedence. In contrast, Sears, a company that once provided a nest egg worth over $1 million to its retirees, has shifted its focus to shareholders. This trend reflects broader changes in how business is conducted in America, with profit-sharing and pensions becoming rare among rank-and-file employees.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Global Invacom, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Suntec Reit
summary: Singtel agreed to invest US$250 million in Airtel Africa, while Global Invacom acquired Tactilis for US$200 million. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's DPU decreased 3.6% in Q4, while Mapletree Industrial Trust's DPU rose 4.9% and Suntec Reit's DPU increased 0.3%. United Overseas Insurance's net profit rose due to investment gains, and OUE Lippo Healthcare raised S$150 million from a rights share issue.

site_title: Singtel to invest US$250m in Airtel Africa; funding round includes Temasek, Warburg Pincus, Softbank
summary: Singtel is investing US$250 million in Airtel Africa Ltd, valuing the company at US$4.4 billion. The funding will be used to reduce debt and grow the business ahead of an initial public offering. International investors, including Temasek Holdings, Warburg Pincus, and Softbank Group International, have contributed US$1.25 billion to Airtel Africa. The investment aims to tap the continent's mobile money and mobile wallet market.

site_title: Tesla shares surge as stock short-seller goes long
summary: Tesla shares surged 12.7% to $294.14 after Citron Research shifted from short-selling to going long, citing the company's potential to disrupt the automotive sector with its affordable Model 3. The note acknowledged previous warning signs but believes the Model 3 is a hit. Tesla's production acceleration and market dominance are seen as positives, despite the company's debt burden and lack of profitability. The move comes after CEO Elon Musk lashed out at short-sellers, and Tesla moves up its quarterly earnings release date, hinting at its efforts to share its progress towards profitability.

site_title: EU rejects Italy's budget in eurozone first
summary: The European Commission rejected Italy's 2019 budget, citing "openly and consciously" flouting pledges made by the Italian government. The Commission gave Italy three weeks to present a new plan to curb spending in line with EU rules. Italy's populist government has proposed a budget that would triple the deficit and approach the EU limit of 3.0%, aggravating the country's already high debt mountain. The Commission warned that failure to comply could lead to disciplinary action, including fines of 3.4 billion euros.

site_title: Australia manufacturing accelerates in October as services slow: survey
summary: Australian manufacturing expanded at a faster pace in October, driven by growth in employment, while services activity eased slightly, according to a survey. The manufacturing PMI rose to 54.3, while the services PMI dropped to 50.8. Despite this, both sectors reported strong job growth, and the outlook for the remainder of 2018 remains positive. The divergence in performance between manufacturing and services suggests a potential shift in the economy's trajectory, according to Commonwealth Bank chief economist Michael Blythe.

site_title: FCT posts 3.6% drop in Q4 DPU to 2.862 S cents on higher property expenses
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 3.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.862 Singapore cents for its Q4 2018, primarily due to higher property expenses. Net property income (NPI) fell 4.9% to S$32.88 million, while gross revenue eased 0.5% to S$48.51 million. Property expenses rose 14.4% to S$15.6 million, mainly due to higher property taxes and professional fees. Despite this, FCT expects suburban mall performance to remain stable.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: All Things Audi
