summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars: All Things Audi" discusses Audi's brand experience and the newly launched A8. Hosts Julian Kho and Claressa Monteiro share their impressions of the car, praising its exceptional performance and features. The conversation is part of Audi's Brand Experience 2018 event.

site_title: Trump's 'Space Force' to be built in stages by 2020
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed "Space Force" will initially be a step below the sixth branch of the military, with Vice President Mike Pence stating it won't be created before 2020. Pence plans to unify space security personnel under a single command and establish a Space Development Agency to focus on new technologies. The National Space Council recommends starting with a unified Space Command, with about 60,000 people working on space security across various branches. Congress must approve the plans, with the administration aiming to vote on an independent Space Force by 2020.

site_title: Interest rate trajectory: different endings
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to a range of 2% to 2.25% on September 26, marking its third rate hike this year and eighth since 2015. The Fed is forecast to raise rates again in December and three more times in 2019.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Khashoggi killing: Trump slams 'worst cover-up ever'
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Saudi Arabia for its handling of journalist Jamal Khashoggi's murder, calling it "one of the worst cover-ups in history." Trump stated that a Saudi operation to kill Khashoggi was poorly executed and had a bad cover-up. The Saudi government initially denied Khashoggi's death but later admitted that he was killed in its Istanbul consulate on October 2. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan demanded that 18 suspects be extradited to Istanbul for trial. Trump expressed support for Saudi Arabia as a US ally but emphasized the need to see facts before forming an opinion.

site_title: Trump says he's sending direct message to Fed chairman to lower US interest rates
summary: US President Donald Trump stated in an interview with the Wall Street Journal that he is sending a direct message to Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell to lower interest rates, despite acknowledging the Fed's independence. Trump expressed frustration with Powell's decisions, saying interest rates are being raised "too quickly" and that the Fed poses the biggest risk to the US economy. Trump has previously called Fed policies "crazy" and hinted at regret over nominating Powell, but it is unclear if he has the authority to remove the chairman.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump told the Wall Street Journal in an interview that he was intentionally sending a direct message to Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell that he wanted lower interest rates, even as he acknowledged that the US central bank is an independent entity.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE hits March low as jitters return; Ocado leads fallers
summary: British shares sank to their lowest since March, with the FTSE 100 closing down 1.24% at 7,000, amid a sell-off in Europe caused by weak results, geopolitical tensions, Brexit, and cooling markets. The FTSE 250 fell 2.2%, with Ocado losing 9.7% as investors turned to gold mining, tobacco, and utility companies for gains. Disappointing earnings from tech stocks and a slowdown in inflows at St. James's Place also contributed to the sell-off, with the financial sector and energy stocks among the biggest losers.

site_title: Starbucks opens first sign language store in US
summary: Starbucks has opened its first US sign language store in Washington, near Gallaudet University, catering to the deaf and hard-of-hearing community. The store, staffed by deaf or hard-of-hearing employees, uses sign language to communicate with customers and features a "sign of the week" and special merchandise. The initiative aims to bring diverse communities together, following Starbucks' response to the arrest of two black men in a Philadelphia store six months prior. The store offers a welcoming space for deaf individuals to socialize and interact with others.

images.alt_text: US coffee giant Starbucks opened its first "signing store" in the United States in northeast Washington near the campus of Gallaudet, the world's only university with an entire curriculum designed to accommodate the deaf and hard-of-hearing.

site_title: New initiative could save lives in ferry sector
summary: A new initiative has been proposed to improve ferry safety, calling for a dedicated body to oversee the sector and increase the number of safety experts. This comes after the author's personal experience with the dangers of small ferries in Indonesia nearly 40 years ago. The proposal aims to address the issues of gross overloading and dangerous conditions, potentially saving lives.

site_title: Oil slumps 5% as global equities tumble, Saudi supply assurances
summary: Oil prices plummeted 5% on Tuesday, reaching two-month lows, as global equities tumbled amid concerns over demand growth and US sanctions on Iran. Saudi Arabia assured that it could supply more crude quickly if needed, easing worries. Brent crude futures fell to $76.44 a barrel, while US crude ended at $66.43 a barrel. Analysts expect oil demand growth to slow due to higher prices and weaker economic growth, and some producers, such as Russia, have increased output to offset losses from Iran.

site_title: Prudential Singapore scraps retirement age for staff
summary: Prudential Singapore has removed its retirement age of 62, allowing 1,100 employees to extend their careers and decide when to retire. The company aims to enable employees to "fulfil their personal and financial aspirations". This policy change, effective October 1, 2018, marks a significant shift in the company's manpower policy, providing employees with more flexibility and autonomy in their career choices.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat amid geopolitical, economic concerns
summary: US stocks retreated on Tuesday, finishing 0.5% lower due to mixed earnings, geopolitical concerns over Saudi Arabia, and Italy's budget standoff with the EU. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5% to 25,191.43, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.6% to 2,740.69. Despite concerns of a global economic slowdown, investors showed willingness to step in on potential bargains, with some stocks rising after earnings releases.

site_title: 'Game changer' tuberculosis drug Bedaquiline cures 8 in 10 in trial
summary: A new treatment for drug-resistant tuberculosis, bedaquiline, has shown a 80% cure rate in a trial in Belarus. The trial involved treating patients with bedaquiline alongside other antibiotics. The results are being hailed as a "game changer" in the fight against the global killer of tuberculosis.

site_title: Suntec Reit DPU up 0.3% for Q3
summary: Suntec Reit posted a 0.3% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.491 Singapore cents, despite a 2.5% decline in gross revenue due to weaker Australian dollar and downtime from replacement leases. Net property income fell 11.4% to S$56.5 million, but joint venture income rose 4.1% to S$23.2 million. The Reit manager signed 268,000 sq ft of new leases, reducing expiring leases to 2.1% and 10.9% of net lettable area. Upgrading works at Suntec City office will commence in Q4 and be completed over three years.

site_title: UK optimistic an unloved Brexit deal will be negotiated by end-Nov
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May expressed optimism that a Brexit deal could be concluded by the end of November, despite lingering divisions within her Conservative Party. She stated that 95% of the deal had been agreed upon, with the key issue being the Northern Ireland-Irish border question. May urged her MPs to remain calm and support her, warning that a failure to unite could lead to an election and a high risk of a Labour government.

site_title: NTU partners HP to launch S$84m research laboratory
summary: NTU has launched an S$84 million research laboratory in partnership with HP, focusing on digital manufacturing technologies such as 3D printing, AI, and cybersecurity. The lab, which will employ 100 researchers and staff, aims to advance these technologies and develop educational curriculum on designing for additive manufacturing. This collaboration is part of the national push towards industry transformation and will also support multi-national companies expanding from Singapore into the region, according to the National Research Foundation Singapore. The lab is HP's first university laboratory collaboration in Asia.

site_title: Fixed-interest debt fortifies S-Reits against chill from rising rates
summary: Singapore-listed Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) appear to be well-positioned to withstand rising interest rates, thanks to their diversified funding sources, low gearing, and high proportion of fixed-rate loans. Analysts estimate that S-Reits can minimize the impact of rising rates, with some even benefiting from increased rental growth. In contrast, banks are expected to benefit from rising interest rates, with DBS Bank predicted to see a significant expansion in net interest margin.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: US revokes visas for Saudis involved in Khashoggi killing
summary: The US has revoked visas for nearly two dozen Saudi officials involved in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, the toughest action taken against its longtime ally. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo identified at least some of the individuals behind Khashoggi's death and stated that the US will continue to explore additional measures to hold those accountable. The move affects 21 Saudi suspects, including those from intelligence services, the royal court, and the foreign ministry, and may also lead to financial sanctions under the Magnitsky Act.

site_title: Hedge funds officially welcomed in from the shadows
summary: Global regulators have officially dropped the term "shadow banks" to describe hedge funds and alternative investments, replacing it with "non-bank financial intermediation". This change aims to emphasize the forward-looking aspects of financial regulation. The US$45 trillion sector has grown 7.6% since the financial crisis and will continue to be subject to rules aimed at enhancing its resilience, including global practices for responding to cyber attacks. The Financial Stability Board will focus on implementing existing rules rather than introducing new ones.

site_title: US existing home sales fall to slowest pace in September since 2015
summary: US existing home sales fell to their slowest pace in nearly three years in September, with a 6th consecutive monthly drop. Rising mortgage rates and prices kept potential buyers on the sidelines, with the average mortgage rate advancing nearly one percentage point this year. Existing home sales dropped 5.4% in the South, while Mid-west sales remained unchanged. The market shift reflects a cooling trend, with inventory ticking up yet remaining tight, and the decline in closings being the biggest since early 2016.

site_title: Citigroup asks private bankers to rethink China travel
summary: Citigroup and other international firms are advising their private bankers to reconsider travel to China due to the Chinese government's crackdown on riskier financial products and strong competition from homemade brands. UBS, which recently lifted its travel restrictions, is the first to do so, allowing all staff to travel freely in and out of the country. The decision comes as China's economy creates more billionaires, with the collective fortunes of China's ultra-rich growing 65% in 2017.

site_title: UOB, Shanghai Qilu to provide financing of up to 3b yuan to Shandong-based firms
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Shanghai Qilu Industrial, a state-owned company in Shandong, China, have agreed to provide up to $600 million in financing to Shandong-based companies. The financing will support the expansion of logistics, construction, infrastructure, and industrials sectors into South-east Asia. The pact was signed during the 20th Singapore-Shandong Business Council Meeting in Jinan, China, with the goal of deepening the capabilities of Shandong-based companies and facilitating their expansion through the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: US response to Khashoggi killing will be a tough balancing act for Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump is navigating a delicate response to the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, with concerns of a tough balancing act between criticizing the Saudi regime and maintaining US economic and military interests. A measured approach, similar to that of former President George HW Bush in dealing with the 1989 Tiananmen Square incident, may be necessary to avoid a major diplomatic confrontation. The Turkish government claims Khashoggi was murdered by Saudi agents, while Saudi officials dispute this, and the international outcry continues to grow.

site_title: London's housing market in prolonged slowdown
summary: The London housing market is experiencing a prolonged slowdown due to a combination of factors, including new taxes, stretched affordability, and Britain's impending exit from the EU. Despite official numbers showing prices only starting to fall this year, real estate agents report a 15% decline in central London compared to four years ago. Experts predict the market may fall another 7% in the next two years, with the cost of the average London residence being nearly 14 times the median full-time salary.

site_title: New Certis to provide integrated security services
summary: Singapore-based security firm Certis has launched a new integrated security services approach called Security+, which combines advanced security strategies with facilities management and customer service. The revamped business is powered by technology solutions, aiming to provide more efficient and lower-cost solutions to clients. The company has also opened a facility in Commonwealth Lane to develop and test technology solutions, utilizing data sensors and artificial-intelligence tools to manage the facility and assess pilot solutions. Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of building up Singapore's defences against global threats through technology and cooperation among the government, industry, and community.

site_title: Saudi Arabia signs deals worth US$50b at investment event despite boycott
summary: Saudi Arabia signed 25 deals worth $50 billion at an investment event, defying a boycott by Western politicians and global business chiefs. The deals were in the oil, gas, industries, and infrastructure sectors with companies such as Trafigura, Total, and Hyundai. Despite the boycott, the event showed Saudi Arabia's ability to attract investment, potentially easing pressure on policymakers. European Union lawmakers are set to push for targeted sanctions over the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

images.alt_text: European lawmakers are likely to push for "targeted sanctions" against the killers and also for an EU-wide ban on the export of arms to Saudi Arabia following the death of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

site_title: e-scooter sharing service bags US$6.4m in seed funding
summary: Beam, a Singapore-based transportation startup, secured US$6.4 million in seed funding to launch a shared mobility platform in Singapore and Asia, starting with e-scooters. The funding will be used to build infrastructure, purchase e-scooters, and develop the Ride Beam mobile app. Beam plans to debut its e-scooter sharing service in Singapore in the coming weeks and expand into Malaysia, Australia, and South Korea. The company aims to focus on the needs of local populations, limit e-scooter speeds for safety, and create an eco-friendly ecosystem.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported 13.8% year-on-year growth in Q2 2019 gross revenues and 14.6% year-on-year growth in net property income. The trust's portfolio occupancy increased to 97.6% and positive rental reversions averaged 1.3%. However, gearing increased to 38.1% due to loans for acquisitions and redevelopment. Analysts Best World and DBS Equity Research maintain a "buy" target, with Best World pricing in S$300 million worth of acquisitions and estimating a 40% jump in FY 2019 earnings.

site_title: Paul Volcker, at 91, sees 'hell of a mess in every direction'
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker, 91, expresses concern over the US economy, calling it a "hell of a mess in every direction." He attributes this to weak supervisory powers, which he believes are being eroded by the influence of wealthy individuals and lobbyists. Volcker, who wrote a memoir criticizing the current state of governance, argues that the country is developing into a plutocracy. He warns that the next financial crisis is looming, but emphasizes the need for stronger regulatory powers to prevent manipulation.

site_title: Dispute-handling protocol launched for big infrastructure projects
summary: Singapore has introduced a Dispute-Management Protocol for big infrastructure projects, aiming to minimize risks of time and cost overruns. The protocol sets up a Dispute Board of neutral experts to quickly resolve issues as they arise. The initiative has already attracted interest from parties involved in projects valued at S$500 million or more. The goal is to make mega infrastructure projects more bankable and secure the interests of all parties involved.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Jet Airways seeks loan moratorium to ease cash crunch
summary: Jet Airways, India's largest full-service carrier, has approached banks for a loan moratorium to ease a cash crunch. The airline has been unprofitable for nine of the past 11 years, struggling with low fares and intense competition. It has grounded about a dozen planes and is considering layoffs to reduce costs. The airline needs to raise funds to address a depreciating local currency, surging fuel prices, and a depreciating local currency. Banks have asked for a detailed action plan, and the airline has proposed selling shares and cutting costs.

site_title: US regulator orders halt to self-driving school bus test in Florida
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) ordered Transdev North America to halt its self-driving school bus test in Florida, citing "inappropriate" risk to the children being transported. The test, using a driverless shuttle in the Babcock Ranch community, was deemed "unlawful and in violation of the company's temporary importation authorization."

site_title: Private health group and Siemens unit open diagnostic-imaging centre
summary: A diagnostic-imaging centre was opened in Singapore by MWH Medical and a Siemens division under a training and equipment tie-up. The facility aims to provide healthcare staff with access to the latest tools from Siemens. This collaboration is part of a training and equipment tie-up, offering healthcare professionals in the region the opportunity to utilize advanced diagnostic imaging technologies.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Taming volatility of capital flows
summary: The IMF argues that countries should be able to benefit from international capital flows without risking excessive market volatility and crises. To achieve this, countries need to deepen their domestic financial markets, enhancing global surveillance, and establishing an enhanced global financial safety net. The current framework is insufficient, with regional arrangements and bilateral swap agreements lacking coordination and crisis testing. The IMF proposes a new standing liquidity facility to address liquidity crunches and prevent solvency problems from spreading. The goal is to tame the volatility of capital flows, allowing countries to invest and grow while minimizing the risk of financial crises.

images.alt_text: Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, speaking with Mr Tharman at the IMF and World Bank meetings in Bali earlier this month. A report by a G20-appointed group calls for an enhanced global financial safety net to ensure that countries are well protected against excessive capital-flow volatility.

site_title: Global Invacom suspends trading till acquisition talks are finalised
summary: Global Invacom Group, a Singapore-based satellite communications equipment provider, has suspended trading in its shares until acquisition talks are finalized. The company, listed on the Singapore Exchange and the London Stock Exchange's Alternative Investment Market, had initially called for a trading halt last Thursday. Global Invacom stated that negotiations and finalization of the terms of a definitive agreement have taken longer than expected, leading to the suspension of trading until talks are concluded.

site_title: Oil market can see past Khashoggi killing, but not Iran
summary: Saudi Arabia's killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and US sanctions on Iran have added uncertainty to the oil market. However, analysts believe these events are unlikely to have a significant impact on crude oil prices, as the market is driven by supply and demand fundamentals. Saudi Arabia may increase its oil production to meet demand, but it is unclear if this will be enough to offset the loss of Iranian barrels, which are expected to decrease significantly due to US sanctions. The market may experience a shortage if buyers avoid Iranian crude, but this is still uncertain.

site_title: Snapcrap app steps in to take on public poop
summary: A new mobile app called Snapcrap has launched in San Francisco, allowing users to share location-tagged pictures of public piles of poop with city works crews to help clean up the streets. The app uses GPS capabilities to pinpoint locations and sends alerts to municipal services. The creator, Sean Miller, designed the app to make reporting poop sightings simple and easy, addressing a growing concern about homelessness in the city. This initiative aims to reduce the number of calls to the city's public works line and improve sanitation.

site_title: It's snowing so much in Canada that crops can't get harvested
summary: Heavy snow in Canada has hindered crop harvesting, with farmers unable to access fields due to 2.5cm of snow on their land. This is particularly concerning for Canada, a top wheat supplier and canola exporter, as it could impact global market share. The US-China trade war and production issues in Russia and Australia have created an opening for Canada, but further harvest delays could impede sales. The global wheat market has seen a 7.3% increase in futures prices, but investors are cautious about the long-term impact of Canada's harvest delays.

site_title: It's been a tumultuous first 10 years for bitcoin
summary: Bitcoin, the world's first cryptocurrency, was born on October 31, 2008, amidst a global financial crisis. Over its first 10 years, it has become a central figure in a complex financial system, viewed warily by markets and investors. Launched by Satoshi Nakamoto, bitcoin initially conveyed a political vision, contrasting with its current role in facilitating financial transactions. As the cryptocurrency continues to evolve, its future and impact remain uncertain.

images.alt_text: Following its creation, bitcoin evolved for several years away from the public eye, grabbing the attention for the most part of geeks and criminals. After bitcoin surpassed US$1,000 for the first time in 2013, it began to attract the attention of financial institutions.

site_title: Bank Indonesia stands pat on rates, warns of slower Q3 growth
summary: Bank Indonesia kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.75% on Tuesday, marking a pause in its rate hikes since May. The central bank warned that third-quarter economic growth may not meet expectations, citing weaker-than-expected export growth and higher oil prices. The rupiah remained weak, and economists predict a potential rate hike in November to pre-empt the US Federal Reserve's anticipated December rate increase. The decision aims to maintain the attractiveness of assets for foreign investors and narrow the current account gap.

site_title: US judge affirms Monsanto weed-killer verdict, slashes damages
summary: A US judge has affirmed a verdict against Bayer's Monsanto unit, finding its glyphosate-based weed-killers responsible for a man's terminal cancer, but reduced punitive damages from $250 million to $39 million. The verdict was reached after a jury found the company's products, including RoundUp and Ranger Pro, caused the man's cancer. Bayer plans to file an appeal with the California Court of Appeal, despite the reduced damages. The verdict marks the first such decision against Monsanto, which faces over 8,000 similar lawsuits in the US.

site_title: The mid-terms are all about Trump
summary: US midterm elections, set for November, are expected to favor the Democrats, but polls can be wrong. Since the Civil War, the party in the White House has lost seats in the House of Representatives in 35 of 38 mid-term elections. The Democrats' chances of winning are boosted by President Trump's low popularity and the controversy surrounding his policies. However, recent polls show a shift in voter attitudes, with a booming economy and a "red wave" of Republican enthusiasm. The migrant caravan and Trump's response to it may also impact the election.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit launches rights issue to raise US$93.1m
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit launched a renounceable rights issue to raise US$93.1 million, with gross proceeds financing partially the proposed US$169.4 million acquisition of Westpark Portfolio. The 295-for-1,000 rights issue of 186.24 million new shares is being offered at US$0.50 apiece, a 30.1% discount to the Reit's closing price. The issue is expected to increase the Reit's market capitalization and improve trading liquidity.

site_title: SGX is clearly more than just a securities market
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expanding its global presence, setting up new offices and inking Memorandum of Understanding (MOUs with major cities. The exchange has seen significant growth in its derivatives business, with revenue rising 21% to S$97.7 million in its fiscal first quarter. Analysts praise SGX's co-operative model, which allows it to compete and collaborate with other exchanges. The exchange is also expected to benefit from market volatility, with its risk management and investment solutions in high demand.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Set of standard forms launched to aid startup founders and venture capitalists
summary: A set of standard-form documents, the Venture Capital Investment Model Agreements (VIMA), has been launched in Singapore to aid startup founders and venture capitalists. The VIMA comprises non-disclosure agreements, term sheets, and other contracts, designed to balance the interests of investors and startups. The initiative, led by the Singapore Academy of Law and the Singapore Venture Capital & Private Equity Association, aims to simplify and cost-effectively structure deals. The VIMA is targeted at early-stage funding rounds and will be available free of charge, with plans to expand the suite of documents in the future.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust resumes distribution reinvestment
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has resumed its distribution reinvestment plan (DRP), allowing unitholders to choose between receiving distributions in the form of units, cash, or a combination of both, without incurring transaction costs. This move aims to provide unitholders with more flexibility in managing their distributions.

site_title: Aston Martin pins hopes on 2019 Vantage as shares struggle
summary: Aston Martin's shares struggle after a disappointing initial public offering, with a £4.2 billion valuation that fell short of its target. However, the company's 2019 Vantage, a $150,000 coupe, has received positive reviews, with many considering it the best-looking sports car on the market. The Vantage's performance and handling have been praised, with a twin-turbocharged V8 engine and a responsive steering system. Despite the struggling shares, the Vantage is expected to be in high demand, with many considering it a "great car, bad stock."

site_title: Forecasts for investing? Unigestion prefers 'nowcasts'
summary: Unigestion's alternative risk premia (ARP) fund manager Joan Lee prefers "nowcasting" over forecasts for investing, stating that predicting future events has little to do with asset prices today. The approach focuses on the current market position. This approach is seen as a response to the challenges of forecasting, with Lee saying "what's important is where we are currently."

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Uber, Ola drivers strike in India, demanding higher fares
summary: Hundreds of Uber and Ola drivers in India went on strike in Delhi and Mumbai, demanding higher fares due to rising fuel costs. The drivers, who earn thin margins, claim fares have not kept pace with fuel price increases, forcing them to work long hours to make ends meet. The strike caused disruptions, with passengers waiting longer for rides and drivers being targeted by protesters. Both Uber and Ola have been criticized for not providing stable income to their drivers, leading to calls for increased fares.

images.alt_text: Indian drivers of cab aggregator services Uber and Ola taking part in a protest against their respective managements in Mumbai on Monday.

site_title: S Korea's Lotte seeks fresh start with revised 50t won investment plan
summary: SOUTH KOREA'S LOTTE GROUP RESETS 5-YEAR INVESTMENT PLAN. The company, whose chairman was released from jail this month, now aims to spend 50 trillion won (S$60.6 billion) through 2023, up from its initial US$35.20 billion plan. The revised plan includes 12 trillion won to be spent in 2019, mainly to expand chemical plants in South Korea, Indonesia, and the US. Lotte's investment plan follows other long-term spending pledges from major firms, including Samsung and Hyundai, as the liberal government calls on them to invest more in the local economy.

site_title: Is it time to strengthen antitrust laws?
summary: The US economy is experiencing a decline in competition, with large firms dominating markets and mergers and acquisitions leading to excessive consolidation. A 2016 report from President Obama's Council of Economic Advisers found that US corporate mergers and acquisitions totaled $2.5 trillion in 2015, while startup rates have dropped by nearly 50% since 1977. Critics argue that weak antitrust laws have allowed this consolidation to occur, but some experts suggest that market forces, such as investor pressure, can discipline large companies. The article concludes that the debate over strengthening antitrust laws is largely a political issue, rather than an economic one.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: United Global, a CATALIST-listed lubricant manufacturer, has signed a non-binding MOU with Repsol Lubricantes of Spain to explore the acquisition of an equity stake in United Oil Company. Repsol will conduct a feasibility study and discuss possible sale terms with United Global once completed. The study's outcome will determine whether to proceed with a definitive agreement.

site_title: Trump-sized window for Xi and Abe to thaw ties
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping for the first time in seven years, amid a "Donald Trump-sized" window of opportunity for a thaw in bilateral ties. The talks come as both countries navigate US-led tensions and Washington's undermining of the post-war economic and political order. Despite personal positivity between Abe and US President Trump, Tokyo has been alarmed by US sanctions, including those targeting key industries. The meeting aims to rebuild relations and explore shared agendas, such as building economic infrastructure in the Asia-Pacific, but distrust and competition remain a significant challenge.

site_title: Harley-Davidson expects up to US$48m in costs from tariffs in 2018
summary: Harley-Davidson expects up to $48 million in costs from tariffs in 2018, mainly from China and the European Union. The company spent more on raw materials in the third quarter, with tariffs expected to add $15-20 million in costs for steel and aluminium. This is attributed to tariffs imposed on these materials.

site_title: Former Fed chief Volcker worries about US 'plutocracy'
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker, 91, has written a memoir warning about the US's growing "plutocracy" due to hubris, distrust in government, and wealth concentration. Volcker expresses concern over the breakdown of governance and policymaking, citing polarization and the influence of wealthy individuals on politics. He believes that this has led to the decline of prudent budgeting and undermines the ability to address pressing issues such as infrastructure rebuilding. Volcker attributes President Trump's success to capitalizing on elite ignored issues and seizing on public fears.

site_title: Airbus confirms some deliveries rescheduled for non-engine snags
summary: Airbus has rescheduled some single-aisle aircraft deliveries due to non-engine snags, particularly with the new A321neo version involving cabin customization. The delays are attributed to the combination of aircraft waiting to be delivered, the new A321neo version, and increased production. Airbus has informed airline customers about the rescheduling, which is affecting deliveries at its Hamburg plant. The company is working to recover from previous engine supply delays.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure on new path to redemption
summary: Raffles Infrastructure, formerly China Fibretech, has undergone a significant transformation after a tumultuous period. The company has dropped its fabric processing business and renamed itself, venturing into infrastructure projects with China state-owned enterprises. It has signed agreements for infrastructure projects and invested in a Chinese construction company. The company's executive director, Eric Choo, aims to rebuild its reputation, but corporate governance experts note that more steps are needed to clear up lingering questions. The company has commenced a special audit to investigate compensation payments and is working on updating its website with investor-related information.

site_title: No place for 'dirty energy' in ADB's vision for tackling climate change
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has committed to a vision of tackling climate change by mainstreaming climate-smart policies and technologies into development planning. The bank aims to support 75% of all projects with climate change mitigation and adaptation efforts, increasing climate finance to $80 billion from 2019 to 2030. ADB has already approved over $2 billion for renewable energy and energy efficiency projects, deploying 1,557 megawatts of new renewable energy generation capacity and saving 738 gigawatt-hours of electricity per year. The bank also established a technology fund to promote innovative projects and will no longer support "dirty energy" projects.

site_title: Solar panel maker in S$585m sale, leaseback deal
summary: The Singapore unit of Norway-headquartered solar firm REC has entered into a proposed S$585 million sale-and-leaseback transaction on its Tuas South property with Australia-based Logos Property. The deal will not affect the facility's operations, which will continue to run as normal. The sale includes the real estate, while the manufacturing facility will remain under REC's control. The deal is expected to be completed by year-end and is viewed by market watchers as a form of financing for the solar panel manufacturing industry, which faces headwinds due to rising production capacity and growing protectionism.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Amazon lobbying spend hits record amid Pentagon competition
summary: Amazon spent a record $3.63 million in Q3 lobbying efforts to influence US policy makers, surpassing its previous quarterly record of $3.47 million. The spending comes as Amazon competes for a $10 billion cloud-computing contract with the Pentagon. Other tech giants, including Google, Facebook, and Twitter, also increased their lobbying expenditures, with Google spending $5.46 million and Facebook spending $2.82 million. The increased lobbying efforts come amid scrutiny over tech companies' size and market power, as well as allegations of political bias and antitrust concerns.

site_title: Saudi Arabia pledges US$3b to Pakistan amid balance of payment crisis
summary: Saudi Arabia pledged US$3 billion to Pakistan to address the country's balance of payment crisis. This includes US$3 billion on deferred payment for oil imports. The agreement was made during a visit by Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan to Riyadh, where he met with King Salman bin Abdulaziz. Khan also attended a Saudi Arabian investment conference, aiming to attract investors and secure funds for Pakistan.

site_title: Everbright, one of China's biggest funds, is getting ready to dump stocks
summary: China's state-backed Everbright Ltd, a major fund manager, is preparing to sell shares in up to 30 stocks due to concerns that global valuations have peaked. The company's CEO, Chen Shuang, cited geopolitical tensions, US stock market concerns, and a possible economic slowdown as reasons for the potential exits. This move comes amid a wave of pessimism in markets, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index nearing a bear market. Everbright has raised more funds overseas due to China's stricter regulations, and its CEO believes long-term growth should rely on fundamentals rather than policy stimulus.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open as weak industrials add to dour mood
summary: Wall Street plummeted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 278.95 points, or 1.10%, to 25,038.46, amid disappointing industrial earnings and concerns over Saudi Arabia's diplomatic isolation and the trade war. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 falling 34.85 points, or 1.26%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 140.08 points, or 1.88%. The market's decline was attributed to weak industrial bellwethers and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Two small towns in Germany seek to realise Trump's LNG dream
summary: Two small German ports, Stade and Brunsbuettel, are competing to build Germany's first liquefied natural gas import terminal, backed by US President Donald Trump's push to cut reliance on Russian gas. The winner is expected to receive hundreds of millions of euros in investment and federal approval. The project aims to shake up Europe's biggest gas market, with the government potentially announcing a winner next year.

site_title: Kaymer has his feet on the ground
summary: Former world No. 1 golfer Martin Kaymer believes he will return to the top of his game soon, having "got up there too quickly" in his career. Kaymer, 33, has been struggling since his swing change in 2015, but is now working on his game, practicing hard, and preparing for upcoming tournaments in the Middle East, South Africa, and Australia. He is taking a level-headed approach to his career, acknowledging that he may not be ready for the Ryder Cup in 2020, but is focused on getting back to his best form.

site_title: Saudi signs deals worth US$50b at investment event despite boycott
summary: Saudi Arabia signed 25 deals worth $50 billion at the Future Investment Initiative conference, defying a Western boycott following the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Deals were struck with firms such as Trafigura, Total, and Hyundai in the oil, gas, and industries sectors. Despite a pull-out of Western investors, Asian firms and Chinese and Japanese institutions participated, and Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund committed to investing $45 billion in the Vision Fund. The conference's success may minimize the long-term impact of the boycott on Saudi's economic prospects.

site_title: SHS unit racking up damages over delay in Bangladesh solar power project
summary: A Bangladesh solar power project has been delayed, leading SHS Holdings' subsidiary HDFC SinPower to default on agreements. The delay, attributed to land issues, regulatory approvals, and inclement weather, may result in up to $912,500 in liquidated damages. The board believes the power purchase agreement can only be terminated on or after April 19, one year after the planned commercial operations date. SHS Holdings will provide further updates on the project's developments.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Lloyds, Schroders team up to build "top three" wealth business
summary: Lloyds Banking Group and Schroders have formed a multi-billion pound wealth management deal, aiming to become a top three UK financial planning business within five years. The joint venture will combine Schroders' investment offering with Lloyds' 27 million-strong customer base and wide distribution network, boosting Schroders' ability to sell its products to Lloyds customers. The deal, worth around £80 billion, will be led by a management team from both parties, with Lloyds owning 50.1% and Schroders 49.9%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 24.87 points to 1,697.60. The market saw a high volume of 2 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with 727 losers surpassing 170 gainers.

site_title: Canadian PM says it would be hard to scrap big Saudi arms deal
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated it would be challenging to scrap a $13 billion arms deal with Saudi Arabia, citing a contract written in a way that would leave taxpayers with a large financial burden. Trudeau emphasized the need to discuss options while condemning the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and expressing frustration over the contract's terms. The government has offered to suspend export permits for armored vehicles if they were misused, but Trudeau ruled out canceling the deal entirely.

site_title: Asia markets sink amid uncertainties
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.52% on Tuesday, with real estate stocks like City Developments and CapitaLand losing 2.16% and 2.24% respectively. The market downturn was attributed to uncertainties in overseas markets, including US stocks' weakness due to geopolitical tensions and global growth concerns. Analysts expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to potentially tighten monetary policy in the coming months, despite a surprise dip in core inflation to 1.8%.

site_title: Hudson Square tower is the work of women in more ways than one
summary: Françoise Raynaud, a French architect, is leading the design of the 30-storey Greenwich West condominium in Hudson Square, New York. She joins a rare group of women to design a major building in the city, alongside Annabelle Selldorf and Zaha Hadid. Raynaud's firm, Loci Anima, aimed to create a building that relates to its surroundings, with a classic New York setback form and rounded corners. The building, which will feature retail space and luxury apartments, is expected to be completed by early 2020 and will have a mix of one- and two-bedroom units starting at $965,000.

site_title: Chew's Group cash offer to close on Nov 20
summary: Chew's Group, a Catalist-listed egg farmer, will close a cash offer on Nov 20 after Goldhill Trust acquired a 68.14% stake. The offeror, owned by Alex Tan Pei Hong and Amos Tan Theng Hong, plans to keep Chew's listed despite the acquisition. The company's shares rose to S$0.21 before the offer document was released. The cash offer price is S$0.2107 per share, and the offeror does not intend to extend the offer beyond the specified date.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Trail-blazing retired US Justice O'Connor says she has dementia
summary: US Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, a trailblazing figure in the legal profession, has announced she has been diagnosed with dementia, likely Alzheimer's disease. The 88-year-old retired justice, who served on the US Supreme Court from 1981 to 2006, has withdrawn from public life due to her diagnosis. O'Connor broke barriers for women in the legal profession and played a key role in shaping the court's ideological center, casting crucial votes on contentious issues.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with hefty losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 3% on Tuesday, wiping out previous gains due to geopolitical fears. The Hang Seng Index fell 3.08%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 2.26% and 1.92%, respectively. Global market uncertainty led to the losses, which followed a rally in previous days.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore: Prudential scraps retirement age for staff, allowing employees to decide when they want to retire. The Ministry of Law launches a new dispute management protocol for mega infrastructure projects, attracting interest from parties worth S$500 million. Certis launches a revamped business approach and new logo. Core inflation dips to 1.8% in September, lower than economists' expectations. NTU and HP open an S$84 million lab to develop digital manufacturing technologies. Ex-Uber executive scores funding to deploy e-scooters in Singapore.

site_title: Plastics have entered human food chain, study shows
summary: Researchers have found that bits of plastic have entered the human food chain, with 8 volunteers in a pilot study detecting 20 micro-particles per 10 grams of stool. The tiny specks, ranging in size from 50 to 500 micrometres, are believed to have been ingested via seafood, food wrapping, dust, or plastic bottles. The study's findings suggest that plastics are widespread in the human food chain, with potential implications for human health.

site_title: Australia stocks fall, domestic uncertainty adds to weak sentiment; NZ down
summary: Australian stocks fell 1.1% on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,843.1, marking the third consecutive session of losses. Global uncertainty, including concerns over the Italian budget, Brexit talks, and tensions with Saudi Arabia, contributed to the decline. Domestic issues, such as a disastrous by-election loss for Australia's ruling Liberal National government, also weighed on sentiment. The energy index fell 3.2% and financial stocks lost 1.2%, while healthcare stocks declined 1.9%.

site_title: Turkey demands to know who ordered "savage" Khashoggi killing
summary: Turkey's President Tayyip Erdogan stated that the person responsible for Jamal Khashoggi's killing must be brought to account. Erdogan rejected Saudi Arabia's claim that rogue operatives were responsible, saying Turkey will complete its investigation when all questions are answered and the identity of a local collaborator is revealed. Erdogan's comments come after Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was suspected of ordering the killing by some US lawmakers.

site_title: NTU, HP open S$84m lab to develop digital manufacturing technologies
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and HP have opened an S$84 million laboratory in Singapore to develop digital manufacturing technologies. The lab, which launched on October 23, 2018, will focus on areas such as 3D printing, artificial intelligence, and cybersecurity. It will employ 100 researchers and staff, marking HP's first university laboratory collaboration in Asia.

site_title: Standard contracts to make deal structuring easier for startups, venture capitalists
summary: Singapore's Academy of Law and Singapore Venture Capital & Private Equity Association launched standard form documents, Venture Capital Investment Model Agreements (VIMA), to simplify deal structuring for startups and venture capitalists. The VIMA, targeting early-stage funding rounds, include non-disclosure agreements, term sheets, and shareholder agreements, with explanatory notes and a glossary to clarify industry jargon. The initiative aims to make deal-making faster and more cost-efficient, with the VIMA governing Singapore law and resolving disputes in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Oculus' Brendan Iribe is latest founder to leave Facebook
summary: Facebook is losing another long-tenured founder, Brendan Iribe, who was the CEO of Oculus VR when Facebook acquired it in 2014. Iribe will step down as vice president of computer-tethered virtual reality, citing a desire to "recharge, reflect and be creative." This departure follows recent exits from Instagram and WhatsApp, marking a significant loss of talent from Facebook's acquired companies. Iribe's exact reason for leaving is not specified, but he will take a break from the company after over 20 years of service.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on October 23, 2018. The puzzle included clues for Across and Share, but no solutions were provided. Meanwhile, recent news includes the Asean agreement that Myanmar's election is not a priority, and Malaysia's stance on the matter. Additionally, US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, while China urged Southeast Asia to back openness as US tariffs loom. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector, and Ambani's Reliance Jio delayed India's IPO beyond this year. China also unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: EU executive rejects Italian 2019 draft budget
summary: The European Commission rejected Italy's 2019 draft budget due to a significant increase in the structural deficit, exceeding the EU's recommendation of a 0.6% of GDP cut. The Commission deemed the plan "unprecedented" and asked Italy to submit a revised budget within three weeks, threatening disciplinary action if no progress is made. Italy had acknowledged its budget plan was in violation of EU rules but insisted it would proceed with the original plan. The Commission warned that Italy's high debt-to-GDP ratio and excessive debt servicing costs pose risks to economic growth and stability.

site_title: Trek 2000 board warns of expected Q3 loss
summary: Trek 2000 International is expected to report losses for the three months and nine months to Sept 30, citing lower sales revenue and shrinking gross profit margin due to global economic uncertainty and a stronger greenback. The company's previous second-quarter net profit was US$77,000, down sharply from US$2.06 million the year before. The board advises shareholders and investors to exercise caution when dealing in the company's shares.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: McDonald's notches sales growth in key regions; profits dip
summary: McDonald's reported a 13.1% drop in third-quarter net income to $1.6 billion, despite comparable sales growth in key regions such as Britain, France, and Japan. Quarterly revenues fell 6.7% to $5.4 billion. The company's sales growth in these regions offset the decline in profit, which was partly due to the sale of businesses in China and Hong Kong in 2017.

site_title: Temasek's first retail bond just over 8 times subscribed
summary: Temasek Holdings' first retail bond, the T2023-S$ Temasek Bond, has been over 8 times subscribed with a total of S$1.68 billion in valid applications. The bond, offering up to S$200 million 2.7% guaranteed notes due 2023, was 7.19 times subscribed by institutional investors. The robust demand for the retail bond is seen as a signal that investors are seeking high-quality bonds from top-rated issuers, with DBS Bank's global head of fixed income expressing hopes for more retail bond offerings from quality issuers in the future.

site_title: UOI Q3 net profit up 10.6% as investment gains lift non-underwriting income
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) reported a 10.6% year-on-year increase in Q3 net profit to S$6.02 million, driven by non-underwriting income from investment gains. Core underwriting earnings declined 31.5% to S$1.46 million due to higher costs and lower gross premium. The company attributed the market's intense competition and escalating catastrophic losses to climate change. Despite the challenging market, UOI's non-underwriting income rose 34.7%.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Indonesia central bank stands pat on rates, sees slower Q3 growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.75% for the 7th consecutive month, citing efforts to narrow the current account gap and maintain foreign investor attractiveness. The decision, despite expectations of a pause, may signal a potential rate hike in November to pre-empt a US Federal Reserve rate increase. Economic growth is expected to slow in the third quarter, with growth forecasted at "a little less than 5.1%" due to weaker export growth and higher commodity prices.

site_title: Hedge funds officially welcomed in from the shadows
summary: Global regulators have officially dropped the term "shadow banks" to describe hedge funds and other alternative investments, replacing it with "non-bank financial intermediation." This change aims to emphasize the forward-looking aspects of financial stability efforts. The term "shadow banking" was used to describe the sector since the 2007-09 financial crisis, which grew to $45.2 trillion in 2016, representing 13% of total financial system assets. Regulators have introduced tougher rules, but the focus will shift to implementing existing regulations rather than introducing new ones.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to resume distribution reinvestment plan for Q2
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) will resume its distribution reinvestment plan (DRP) for its second quarter, allowing unitholders to choose between receiving distributions in cash or units. The DPU for Q2 increased to 3.01 Singapore cents, while income available for distribution grew 4.9% to S$56.7 million. Gross revenue dipped 0.4% and net property income decreased 0.1%, but contributions from development projects and a US data centre portfolio helped offset these declines.

site_title: Singapore shares slump 1.5% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 46.67 points, or 1.52%, to 3,031.39 on Tuesday, with 1.96 billion shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 294 to 111, led by Nico Steel, which closed 40% lower. DBS, OCBC, and UOB also ended in the red, with declines of 1.56%, 2.31%, and 1.58%, respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit lowest since March 2017 amid broader Asia selloff
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 2.57% on Tuesday, hitting their lowest in almost 20 months, amid intensifying Sino-U.S. trade frictions and geopolitical tensions. The benchmark KOSPI index closed at 2,106.10, driven by rising geopolitical risks following U.S. President Donald Trump's nuclear arsenal comment. The downturn was largely sentiment-driven, with investors fearing a prolonged trade war between the US and China. Global equities are expected to remain volatile during the Wall Street's earning season, but geopolitical concerns may ease ahead of the US midterm elections.

site_title: Singapore core inflation dips to 1.8% in September; lower than economists' expectations
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased to 1.8% in September, lower than economists' expectations of 1.9%. This moderation in retail inflation offset a pickup in services inflation. Headline inflation remained steady at 0.7% y-o-y, as lower retail inflation was offset by higher services inflation and smaller accommodation costs decline.

site_title: Prudential Singapore scraps retirement age for staff
summary: Prudential Singapore has removed its retirement age of 62, allowing 1,100 employees to continue working beyond 62 and decide when to retire. The policy change aims to empower employees to decide their own retirement, considering the increasing average lifespan of 83.1 years. The company will continue to support employees through re-skilling opportunities and flexible work schedules, and they will still receive a retirement payout if they choose to leave their jobs.

site_title: J&J makes US$2.1b offer to buy out Japan cosmetics firm Ci:z
summary: Johnson & Johnson has made a $2.83 billion offer to buy out Japanese cosmetics firm Ci:z Holdings Co Ltd, acquiring all outstanding shares for 230 billion yen in cash. The deal, valued at 5,900 yen per share, represents a 55% premium over Tuesday's closing price. The acquisition aims to strengthen J&J's international innovation pipeline, bolstering its skincare products portfolio with popular brands such as Dr.Ci:Labo and Genomer.

site_title: Certis launches revamped business, new Certis Commonwealth facility
summary: Certis, a security firm, has revamped its business approach and launched a new logo, adopting the Security+ approach that combines security, facilities management, and customer service. The company has already implemented this approach for several major clients in Singapore and has opened a new facility, Certis Commonwealth, to test and develop technology solutions. The facility features data sensors, a digital twin framework, and a central command centre to manage and optimize operations. The new approach aims to break down silos and provide better user experiences for customers.

site_title: BMW expands recall of vehicles at risk of fire to 1.6 million cars
summary: BMW is recalling approximately 1.6 million diesel cars worldwide due to a potential fire hazard caused by coolant leaks from the exhaust recirculation unit. The defect can lead to sparks and fires in extreme cases. The affected vehicles, produced between 2010 and 2017, will have their components replaced as necessary. The recall expands on an initial August announcement and follows a BMW investigation into the issue, which led to reports of 40 fires in South Korea this year and prompted the government to advise drivers to keep their vehicles off the road until checked.

site_title: Dairy Farm, Nets to enable WeChat Pay at Singapore's 7-Eleven, Guardian, Cold Storage and Giant stores from Nov 1
summary: Dairy Farm Singapore's over 600 stores will allow WeChat Pay from Nov 1, enabling Chinese visitors and China nationals to make payments. WeChat Pay users will scan a Nets QR code, and the foreign exchange charge will be determined at the point-of-sale. The rollout aims to increase convenience for Chinese visitors, with visitor arrivals from China rising 13% in 2017. This marks Dairy Farm's digital transformation journey, with cashless payments increasing by 6% at Cold Storage and 3% at Guardian since 2017.

site_title: Home-grown healthcare group partners Siemens unit for S'pore medical tech centre
summary: Singapore's MWH Medical has partnered with Siemens Healthineers to establish the Asia Reference Centre, a medical technology training facility. The centre, located in a 10,000 sq ft space, will focus on diagnostic imaging tools for stroke, cancer, and heart disease. Siemens will provide machines and training resources, while MWH Medical will host the facility. The partnership aims to enhance Singapore's reputation as a regional health centre for high-quality healthcare, according to MWH Medical's medical director.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Philippine officials still banking on investment growth, says Citi analyst
summary: Philippine officials remain optimistic about investment growth, citing tax reforms and other economic strengths. Citi analyst Nalin Chutchotitham notes that firms consider multiple factors beyond investment incentives when investing in the Philippines. The country's top sectors for investment include manufacturing, financial services, and real estate. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) is unlikely to raise interest rates due to inflation concerns, and energy prices are seen as a risk factor. The government believes new investors will not be affected by tax changes, and domestic demand growth potential is positive.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall to lowest levels in nearly two years
summary: European shares plummeted to nearly two-year lows on Tuesday, down 1.1% as earnings failed to alleviate concerns on Brexit, Italy's budget, and trade wars. The STOXX 600 index hit a 2016 low, while the German DAX also fell 1.4% to its lowest level since December 2016. The tech sector led the decline, with chipmaker AMS losing 17% after its earnings failed to impress investors. Geopolitical tensions and growing uncertainty weighed on markets, with analysts warning of a "risk off" sentiment.

site_title: Free admission to Cars @ Expo automotive show this weekend
summary: The Cars @ Expo automotive show will take place on October 27 and 28 at Singapore Expo Halls 4 and 5, featuring over 50 exhibitor booths and top car brands. Admission is free, and visitors can receive various prizes, including a S$50 Esso petrol voucher, a limited edition keychain, and a three-month Torque magazine subscription. The event is organized by Singapore Press Holdings and co-organized by sgCarMart.

site_title: Singapore welcomes the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement
summary: Singapore has welcomed the signing of the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), a bilateral agreement expected to benefit exporters of electronics, pharmaceuticals, and processed food products. The agreement, signed during the 12th Asia-Europe Meeting Summit in Brussels, will improve market access, increase government procurement opportunities, and eliminate tariffs on exports. The agreement is seen as a timely development given growing international trade tensions, with Singapore Business Federation CEO Ho Meng Kit calling it a "real game changer" for European companies operating in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

Calling it "a timely development given the growing international trade tensions", Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chief executive officer Ho Meng Kit said: "SBF is committed to support the successful implementation of the EUSFTA by promoting the new economic opportunities it offers to our companies, especially SMEs (small and medium enterprises)."

site_title: UOB, Shanghai Qilu to provide financing of up to 3b yuan to Shandong-based firms
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Shanghai Qilu Industrial have agreed to provide up to 3 billion yuan (S$600 million) in financing to Shandong-based companies, primarily in logistics, construction, and industrials. The pact aims to support expansion into South-east Asia, particularly under the Belt and Road Initiative. Shanghai Qilu, a state-owned conglomerate, will tap overseas investments and markets to enhance the capabilities of Shandong-based companies. The financing will help these companies seize business opportunities in the region.

site_title: Expired school meals spark probe of UK food giant in China
summary: UK-based food giant Compass Group Plc is under investigation in Shanghai over suspected expired meals provided to international schools. The Shanghai government has ordered three schools to suspend catering services, and the principal of Shanghai SMIC Private School has been removed for investigation. Compass Group has apologized and cooperated with the investigation, promising to improve its service. This incident is part of a growing trend of food and safety scares in China, with the government launching a food-safety inspection of all schools in the city.

site_title: Citigroup asks private bankers to rethink China travel
summary: Citigroup has asked its private bankers to reconsider travel to China, following UBS Group AG's removal of similar curbs. The move comes after a UBS wealth manager's departure from China was delayed due to a meeting with local officials. China's growing wealth has created opportunities for global banks, but also poses challenges due to cumbersome regulations and competition. Other firms, including Standard Chartered and JPMorgan Chase, have also restricted travel to China.

images.alt_text: Citigroup Inc. and some other international firms are asking their wealth managers to reconsider travel to China, as UBS Group AG removed similar curbs.

site_title: Embraer launches longer-range midsized private jets in turnaround push
summary: Embraer launches the Praetor 500 and Praetor 600, longer-range mid-sized private jets, as part of its turnaround strategy to revitalize its loss-making executive jet division. The aircraft feature revamped cabins and technology to reduce turbulence, targeting a competitive space with Bombardier's Challenger 350 and Gulfstream's G280. The launch comes ahead of Embraer's planned merger with Boeing, which may leave the company with only two remaining divisions: executive jets and defense.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index drops 2.67% amid global risk worries
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted 2.67% on Tuesday, falling 604.04 points to 22,010.78, amid global risk worries and ahead of corporate earnings reports. Geopolitical risks linked to the EU and Middle East, as well as the looming US congressional elections, contributed to the decline. The dollar weakened to 112.42 yen in Asian trade. Major Japanese companies, including Sony and SoftBank, also fell, while the Dow in New York dropped 0.5% to 25,317.61.

site_title: Amazon.com, Qualcomm to put Alexa assistant in more headphones
summary: Qualcomm and Amazon.com are partnering to integrate Amazon's Alexa voice assistant into wireless headphones, allowing any Bluetooth headphone maker to embed Alexa with a pre-made chip. This move aims to expand Alexa's presence beyond smart speakers and enable users to control the assistant by tapping a button on their headphones. The partnership is part of Qualcomm's effort to diversify away from mobile phone-related revenue and explore new markets.

site_title: Brexit deal or no deal, London's housing slump is here to stay
summary: The London housing market is experiencing a severe slump, with prices down 15% in central London compared to four years ago. The market's decline is attributed to a combination of factors, including new taxes, stretched affordability, and Britain's impending exit from the European Union. Brexit has reduced demand by up to 70% and the government's efforts to curb foreign buyers have further exacerbated the issue. Experts predict the market may fall another 7% in the next year and a half, with the affordability crisis showing no signs of improvement.

site_title: Foreign parents fight in vain for custody in Japan
summary: Foreign parents in Japan face significant challenges in securing custody of their children after divorce, with tough laws and patriarchal cultural norms favoring mothers in 80% of cases. Emmanuel, Stephane, Henrik, and James, who were all married to Japanese women, report being prevented from contact with their children despite court rulings in their favor. The country's restrictive laws and societal norms make it difficult for fathers to maintain a relationship with their children, leaving many feeling isolated and frustrated.

site_title: Saab launches US$665m rights issue to fund bulging order book
summary: Saab, a Swedish defence firm, has launched a US$918.6 million rights issue to bolster its financial muscles following big contract wins that have swelled its order backlog. The company needs a stronger balance sheet to develop large projects, invest in research and development, and compete for new contracts. Shareholders representing 58.9% of votes supported the rights issue, which will be used to fund bulging order book and invest in growth. Saab reported a 22% rise in order intake in the third quarter, with adjusted operating income down 22%.

site_title: Trump to cut Central America aid as migrant caravan rolls on
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the US will cut aid to Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador, three Central American countries, as a migrant caravan of over 7,000 people, mostly Hondurans, approaches the US border. The aid, which totals $615 million this year, aims to reduce the flow of migrants fleeing poverty and violence in the region. Trump has criticized the caravan, calling it a national emergency and accusing Mexico of failing to stop it. Mexico's government has vowed to continue calling for dialogue, while activists accuse the US of using the crisis to score political points.

site_title: Spain's Repsol to conduct feasibility study to explore stake purchase in United Global unit
summary: Spain's Repsol Lubricantes has signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Catalist-listed lubricant manufacturer United Global to explore a possible stake purchase in United Oil Company, a subsidiary of United Global. Repsol will conduct a feasibility study, and if successful, the company and Repsol will discuss and negotiate terms for a definitive agreement. The MOU remains in force for six months with the option to extend for another six months. United Global shares closed unchanged at S$0.42 following the announcement.

site_title: Snapcrap app steps in to take on public poop
summary: A new mobile app called Snapcrap has been launched in San Francisco to encourage users to report public piles of feces to city workers. The app, similar to Snapchat, allows users to share location-tagged photos of public poop, which are then reviewed by sanitation crews to identify areas that need cleaning. The goal is to increase community involvement in maintaining the city's cleanliness and reduce the burden on city workers.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading lower at 3,045.83, down 1.06% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed afternoon trading on Tuesday, falling 1.06% to 3,045.83, with the Straits Times Index down 32.23 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 220 to 90, with Nico Steel dipping 20% to 0.4 Singapore cents. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC also fell, with UOB down 1.19%, DBS down 1.03%, and OCBC down 1.76%.

site_title: Kirin's A$2b dairy arm attracts top China milk brand
summary: Kirin Holdings Co., a Japanese brewer, is selling its Australian dairy unit, Lion Dairy & Drinks Pty, for about A$2 billion. China's top milk producer, Inner Mongolia Yili Industrial Group Co., and Canadian rival Saputo Inc. have expressed interest in acquiring the business. The sale comes as Kirin narrows its business scope to improve profitability amid declining beer sales in Japan. Other beverage companies, including Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd., may also consider bids. Kirin has asked for first-round bids by late November.

site_title: Singapore launches new dispute management protocol for mega infrastructure projects
summary: Singapore has launched a new dispute management protocol for mega infrastructure projects, aiming to make them more bankable and minimize risks of time and cost overruns. The protocol, developed by a working group, provides for mediation, opinion, and determination methods and will be facilitated by the Singapore International Mediation Centre and the Singapore Mediation Centre. The initiative is seen as a key step to "crowd in private capital" and connect infrastructure firms with government officials to develop, finance, and execute infrastructure projects in the region, estimated to be worth S$500 million or more.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Explosive device found near George Soros' home
summary: A suspicious explosive device was found in a mailbox at George Soros' Westchester County home in Katonah, New York. The device was detonated by bomb squad technicians after being discovered by an employee. Soros was not home at the time. The FBI and ATF are investigating, with the case being referred to the federal authorities. This incident is the latest in a series of threats against Soros, a prominent philanthropist and political activist who has been targeted by right-wing groups.

site_title: Moscow cryptocurrency 'boutique' in legal grey area
summary: In Moscow, a cryptocurrency boutique called "DeeCrypto" operates in a legal grey area, offering physical portals to the virtual world of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. Founded by Denis Onatsik, the store aims to navigate Russia's uncertain regulatory landscape, where cryptocurrencies are neither fully authorized nor forbidden. With around 100 members, the store provides equipment for mining and investing in virtual currencies, despite the current market fluctuations and decreased viability of mining due to the global price collapse.

site_title: Amazon lobbying reaches company record amid Pentagon competition
summary: Amazon spent a record $3.63 million on federal lobbying in the third quarter, surpassing its previous quarterly record. The company is competing for a $10 billion cloud-computing contract with the Pentagon. Other tech giants, including Google, Facebook, and Twitter, also increased their lobbying efforts, with Google spending $5.46 million and Facebook spending $2.82 million. The lobbying surge comes amid antitrust scrutiny and allegations of political bias on their platforms.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc set its second consecutive quarterly record on spending to influence US policymakers in the third quarter as it competed for a US$10 billion cloud-computing contract with the Pentagon.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 1.00% or 226.22 points at 22,388.60. The broader Topix index also fell 0.88% or 14.93 points. The decline comes amid lingering worries over geopolitical risks ahead of the corporate earnings report season.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex invests in cryptocurrency exchange Binance to expand in Singapore
summary: Vertex Ventures, a venture capital arm of Temasek Holdings, has invested in Binance, a leading cryptocurrency exchange, to develop a fiat-to-cryptocurrency exchange in Singapore. The investment, a joint effort between Vertex Ventures China and Southeast Asia & India, aims to support fiat-to-crypto gateways and services across South-east Asia.

site_title: Bangkok is turning into a giant art gallery
summary: Bangkok is hosting the Bangkok Art Biennale, a three-month art exhibition featuring over 200 pieces from around 50 artists, including Yayoi Kusama and Choi Jeong Hwa. The event is taking place in 20 venues throughout the city, including malls and tourist attractions, aiming to boost tourism and attract new visitors. The exhibition's art director believes visual art can reveal the interpretation of Bangkok, highlighting the city's cultural side. The event comes as Bangkok faces a slump in Chinese arrivals, relying on tourism to drive growth.

site_title: Cryptocurrency bitcoin marks 10 years
summary: Bitcoin, the world's first cryptocurrency, marks its 10th anniversary. Created in October 2008 as a response to the global financial crisis, bitcoin's decentralized registry system, known as a blockchain, allows for peer-to-peer transactions without financial institutions. After a tumultuous childhood, bitcoin's price recovered in 2017 and surpassed $19,500 by the end of the year, reaching a total capitalization of over $300 billion. The concept of a digital currency has progressed, with over 2,000 rivals emerging, and bitcoin is now used primarily as a store of value or speculative instrument.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 0.97 points lower on Tuesday, closing at 1,721.50. Trading volume reached 18.63 million lots worth RM9.81 million, with no gainers or losers.

site_title: Asia: Markets resume downward spiral as geopolitical fears set in
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday, with Shanghai and Hong Kong experiencing sharp losses, following US President Donald Trump's warning of pulling out of a nuclear treaty with Russia and bolstering America's arsenal. Global financial markets are weighed down by geopolitical concerns, including tensions with Saudi Arabia, Italy's budget standoff with the EU, and a growing unease about the US midterm elections. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets, causing the US dollar to rally and the yen to climb against the greenback, as risk aversion permeates markets.

site_title: Hot stock: RHB initiates coverage on Best World with 'buy', S$1.97 target price
summary: RHB Research has initiated coverage on Best World with a "buy" call, targeting S$1.97. The stock rose 3.36% to S$1.54 following the announcement. RHB expects Best World's earnings to jump 21% CAGR over three years, driven by its successful penetration of the Chinese market and new business model. The brokerage believes the current 10x FY2019F P/E valuation is compelling, and the company's net cash of S$87 million allows it to maintain its dividend payout ratio. Key risks include regulatory changes and inventory management visibility.

site_title: Singapore shares open down on Tuesday; STI falls 0.8% to 3,054.86
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% on Tuesday to 3,054.86, with the Straits Times Index retreating 23.2 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 82 to 27, with Genting Singapore and UOB being the most actively traded counters. The decline follows a 5-day rally and amid geopolitical risks and corporate earnings report season.

site_title: World's longest sea bridge brings China closer to Hong Kong
summary: China has completed the world's longest sea bridge, a $15 billion, 55km link between Hong Kong and the mainland, reducing travel time to 30 minutes from three hours. The bridge is part of President Xi Jinping's plan to create the Greater Bay Area, a high-tech megalopolis to rival Silicon Valley. The project aims to integrate China's industrial might with Hong Kong and Macau's liberal, capitalist economies, and is expected to boost the region's trillion-dollar economy and become the world's fourth-largest exporter.

site_title: ECB to focus on bond-buying exit as threats mount
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi is set to continue exiting massive stimulus measures despite mounting threats to the eurozone economy, including Brexit, trade tensions, and rising oil prices. The ECB will maintain low interest rates and keep credit flowing, but will gradually end bond-buying, known as quantitative easing, in December. Analysts believe the risks to growth are "broadly balanced" and not severe enough to alter the ECB's path, with inflation forecasts remaining on track.

site_title: Facebook shuts accounts of marketing group in Brazil election
summary: Facebook has removed 68 pages and 43 accounts associated with a Brazilian marketing group, Raposo Fernandes Associados, for violating the social media network's policies. The group was the main online network for far-right presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro, and was accused of using fake accounts and clickbait to spread misinformation. Facebook's move is part of efforts to prevent bad actors from interfering with Brazil's elections. WhatsApp, another Facebook-owned service, has also faced scrutiny over the spread of fake news and conspiracy theories during the campaign.

site_title: Ex-Uber exec scores funding to bring e-scooters to Singapore
