summary: Beam, an e-scooter startup founded by a former Uber executive, has secured $6.4 million in funding to deploy its electric scooters in Singapore. The financing will help Beam replicate the success of Bird Rides Inc and Lime in Asia, with plans to roll out its service in coming weeks before expanding to Malaysia, Australia, and South Korea. Consumers will use the service by locating and unlocking a scooter using their phones, with a starting fee of S$1 and 15 Singapore cents per minute.

site_title: China's central bank to offer more funds for private companies
summary: China's central bank announced measures to ease funding strains on private companies, supporting bond financing and providing funding to facilitate this. The State Council also raised the central bank's re-lending and re-discounting quota by 150 billion yuan. These efforts aim to restore confidence in the world's second-largest economy, which has been affected by the government's debt curbing campaign and slowdown in economic growth. The measures are seen as a follow-up to confidence-boosting comments from policymakers, aiming to sustain long-term reforms and boost confidence in the private sector.

site_title: China's central bank to offer more funds for private firms
summary: China's central bank has announced plans to provide more funds to support private firms, aiming to ease funding strains and restore confidence in the world's second-largest economy. The move follows a campaign to curb debt and cut the shadow banking sector, which has affected the private sector hard. The People's Bank of China will offer funding to facilitate bond financing for private firms, with top officials vowing to offer "unwavering" support for the private sector. The central bank's move is seen as a response to the slowdown in economic growth and the collapse of stock prices.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) soon after announced a plan to support such issuance, without providing any details on how it would work, the size of the plan, or when it would begin.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks down at open on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.53% and the Shanghai Composite Index easing 0.08%. The decline comes after a 3% rise in the previous two trading days, amid brewing geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text:
1123 Yy / 黄贝盈 / Finalised media materials for media briefing on heritage and environmental studies in the Mount Pleasant area / URA
caption : Blk 1
The Neoclassical Blocks 1 and 2 were the main administrative buildings situated at the original main entrance of Old Police Academy at Whitley Road. (credited to URA)##########roz24a##########URA

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel-KBS Reit, Hong Leong Asia, Emerging Towns & Cities, shopper360, Mapletree Logistics Trust
summary: Keppel-KBS Reit announced a 295 for 1,000 rights issue to raise US$89.7 million to finance a US$169.4 million acquisition. Hong Leong Asia's shares jumped 12.84% on Monday, attributed to a rights issue. Emerging Towns & Cities secured a contract with Huawei to lease luxury apartments in Myanmar. shopper360 secured an exclusive advertising agreement with NTUC FairPrice in Singapore. Mapletree Logistics Trust reported increased distribution per unit and income available for distribution, driven by higher revenue from existing properties and acquisitions.

site_title: Bank of America is already calling time on China stock rally
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch predicts China's stock rally is a short-term rebound, unlikely to be sustained. The Shanghai Composite Index's two-day gain is driven by sentiment, and deep-pocketed state funds are absent, only intervening as a last resort. Fundamentals are still deteriorating, and the government may directly intervene if confidence in the market is lost. The bank's head of China equity strategy, David Cui, warns that a sharp decline in the market could prompt government intervention, as they prefer a market-driven approach. This suggests the rally may be nearing its end.

site_title: Global Invacom suspends trading till acquisition talks are finalised
summary: Global Invacom Group, a satellite communications equipment provider, has suspended trading of its shares until the negotiation of its acquisition talks is finalized. The company had previously called for a trading halt on October 18, citing ongoing negotiations for a "very substantial acquisition" or a reverse takeover. The negotiations have taken longer than expected, and the company will suspend trading on both the Singapore Exchange and the London Stock Exchange's Alternative Investment Market until the terms are finalized.

site_title: Saudi Arabia hosts investment conference despite Khashoggi fallout
summary: Saudi Arabia hosts its three-day Future Investment Initiative despite a wave of cancellations from policymakers and business titans due to the Khashoggi murder fallout. The summit, meant to project the kingdom as a lucrative business destination, has been overshadowed by global outrage and growing concerns about Saudi Arabia's human rights record. Ministers from the US, Britain, and France have pulled out, while corporate executives from major firms like Siemens, Ford, and Uber have also withdrawn. Despite this, some Western firms are still attending, including senior investment bankers from HSBC and Credit Suisse.

images.alt_text: The three-day Future Investment Initiative (FII) was meant to project the historically insular petro-state as a lucrative business destination as it seeks to diversify and set the stage for new ventures and multi-billion dollar contracts.

site_title: SembMarine unit secures US$166m job on Teekay vessel
summary: SembMarine unit secures a US$166 million job to modify, repair and extend the life of Teekay's Petrojarl Varg FPSO vessel. The project involves engineering, procurement and construction works and is expected to be completed by July 2020.

site_title: Japan PM heads to China looking for economic common ground
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is visiting China in an effort to improve economic relations and counter US pressure on trade. The trip is the first by a Japanese premier since 2011 and comes after years of repairing ties following a 2012 dispute over disputed islands. Abe aims to secure new economic partnerships, but the visit is also seen as a response to US tariffs on Asian goods. The US-China trade tensions have raised concerns about China's GDP growth, which is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe makes a rare trip to China this week hoping improved relations will lead to new economic partnerships, as the two countries come under US pressure on trade.

site_title: Power to its people
summary: Beca, a Singapore-based engineering consulting firm, has recognized its employees as a key competitive advantage and implemented the BE framework to focus on staff engagement, people development, and succession planning. The company has seen significant results, including a first-time win at the BE Awards for People Excellence Award and improved project delivery processes. Beca's focus on talent has led to the development of a clear career roadmap, competency-based career framework, and an Emerging Leaders Programme. The company's efforts have also enhanced its brand value, leading to increased recognition and opportunities.

site_title: It's snowing so much in Canada that crops can't get harvested
summary: Canada's severe snowfall and wet weather have hindered crop harvesting, particularly wheat and canola, with many fields sitting under 1 inch of snow. The delays may impact Canada's wheat exports, which are currently running ahead of last year's pace, and could lead to lower quality crops being downgraded. The US-China trade war and production issues in Russia and Australia have created an opportunity for Canada to gain market share, but further harvest delays could jeopardize these gains, causing losses for farmers like Mike Ammeter.

site_title: Trump 'not satisfied' with Saudi explanations of Khashoggi death
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed dissatisfaction with Saudi explanations of journalist Jamal Khashoggi's death inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. Trump stated that he will soon know the truth and is not satisfied with what he has heard. Saudi officials initially said Khashoggi left unharmed, but later announced he was killed in an altercation. The case has raised allegations against Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who denies ordering Khashoggi's killing. Trump plans to gather more information from his teams in Turkey and Saudi Arabia.

site_title: UK PM May fires back at mutinous party over Brexit
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May fired back at her increasingly mutinous party over Brexit, appealing to them to back her negotiating strategy despite deep divisions and criticism from the EU. May defended her approach, saying the Brexit talks are about the national interest, not her personal fortunes. Despite this, she faced criticism from her own party and opposition, with some MPs calling for a second Brexit referendum and others threatening to block a budget if the deal results in special status for Northern Ireland.

site_title: Oil little changed despite Saudi pledge to boost output
summary: Oil futures were little changed on Monday despite Saudi Arabia's pledge to raise crude production to a record high. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih announced the plan to increase output to 11 million barrels per day, but analysts questioned whether it would be enough to compensate for potential supply losses from Iran and Venezuela. US sanctions on Iran's oil sector start on November 4, and oil prices remain finely balanced amid uncertainty.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit to raise US$93.1m from 295-for-1,000 rights issue
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has launched a 295-for-1,000 rights issue to raise US$93.1 million, with both Keppel Capital Investment Holdings and KBS SOR Properties taking up their full entitlement. The offer price is US$0.50 apiece, a 30.1% discount to the closing price of US$0.715 per unit. The funds will partially finance the US$169.4 million acquisition of the Westpark Portfolio and cover estimated fees and expenses. The rights issue is expected to increase market capitalization and improve trading liquidity.

site_title: Singapore stocks on bulls' shopping list
summary: Singapore stocks are becoming an attractive option for investors due to low valuations, high earnings growth, and high dividend yields. The benchmark Straits Times Index has slumped 15% since May, but analysts have raised their profit estimates by 8% this year. With a dividend yield of over 4.5%, Singaporean equities are generating higher payouts than their peers in the region, making them an attractive choice for investors seeking value and dividends. Strategists at Morgan Stanley and DBS Group Holdings see Singapore stocks as a "shopping list" for investors.

site_title: Australia hits five Myanmar generals with sanctions
summary: Australia has imposed sanctions on five Myanmar generals accused of overseeing violence against the Rohingya ethnic group. The sanctions, announced by Foreign Minister Marise Payne, freeze the assets of officers including a Lieutenant General believed to be behind atrocities. The officers are accused of human rights violations by units under their command. This move follows similar actions by the US and EU, and is seen as a response to the violence against the Rohingya. The sanctions target Aung Kyaw Zaw, Maung Maung Soe, Aung Aung, Than Oo, and Khin Maung Soe.

site_title: US warships sail through Taiwan Strait
summary: US warships, USS Curtis Wilbur and USS Antietam, sailed through the Taiwan Strait, aggravating China amid heightened tensions. The transit demonstrated the US commitment to a free and open Indo-Pacific. Multiple Chinese warships followed the US vessels at a safe distance. This was the second such "freedom of navigation" exercise in the Taiwan Strait in three months, amid China's recent military manoeuvres and declaration of willingness to confront Taiwan's "independence forces."

site_title: US museum says five Dead Sea Scroll fragments fake
summary: A US museum, the Museum of the Bible, removed five artifacts from exhibition after a German research institution determined they were not old enough to be genuine Dead Sea Scrolls fragments. The museum's chief curator stated that the testing process and commitment to transparency were key to the decision, emphasizing the importance of verifying the authenticity of rare biblical artifacts. The five pieces will no longer be displayed, marking a significant correction to the museum's earlier claims about their origins.

images.alt_text: A US museum announced on Monday that five artifacts it had said were fragments of the ancient manuscripts known as the Dead Sea Scrolls are in fact fake, and will no longer be displayed.

site_title: Euro rally proves temporary despite relief over Italian budget
summary: The euro failed to hold early gains due to ongoing Italian spending plans uncertainty, despite a drop in government borrowing costs. Moody's downgraded Italy's credit rating, but maintained a stable outlook, boosting demand for Italian debt. The euro dropped 0.1% to $1.1511, with analysts predicting volatile markets and no support from the European Central Bank in the near future.

site_title: Expect a '3 plus and minus 5%' model of future growth
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to enter a phase of "3 plus and minus 5" percent growth due to technological disruption and global trade tensions, according to Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. This new reality will require companies and industries to adapt, with the government shifting from broad-based measures to industry-specific strategies. Poor performing companies will need to recycle land, labor, and capital, while average performers must re-engineer products or services. The most productive firms will need to expand their global market share to avoid productivity problems.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends mixed as volatility resumes
summary: US stocks ended a volatile day with mixed results, with the Dow Jones falling 0.5% and the S&P 500 down 0.4%, while the Nasdaq rose 0.3%. Energy and financial stocks declined, but tech stocks rose, driven by anticipation of earnings releases from Amazon and Alphabet. Geopolitical worries and the looming US congressional elections contributed to the volatility, with analysts citing concerns over Saudi Arabia and the mid-term elections.

site_title: China biotech keeps long-term shine despite wild swings and sky-high valuations
summary: China's biotech sector has faced significant challenges, including a vaccine scandal and short-seller attacks, resulting in a 32% decline in shares from its peak. Despite the turmoil, analysts remain optimistic about the sector's long-term growth potential, citing supportive government policies and the potential for new drug approvals. Top biotech companies, such as Wuxi Biologics Cayman Inc and GenScript Biotech Corp, have received buy ratings from over 80% of analysts, and their valuations remain high, trading at 28.5 times reported earnings.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo on Canada by the Trump administration. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for H2. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Reaching new heights of performance
summary: The 2018 Business Excellence Award winners, announced on October 16, have been delivering superior performances for nearly two decades. The four winners are Beca Carter Hollings & Ferner and three public sector organisations: National Library Board, Housing & Development Board, and Institute of Technical Education. They received their awards from Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing, recognizing their robust management systems and practices. This marks the 24th Business Excellence Awards Ceremony.

images.alt_text: The 24th BE Awards Ceremony was held on Oct 16 at Resorts World Sentosa Convention Centre. From left: Ang Hak Seng, chairman, Singapore Quality Award Management Committee; Png Cheong Boon, CEO, Enterprise Singapore; Low Khah Gek, CEO, Institute of Technical Education; Cheong Koon Hean, CEO, Housing & Development Board; Chan Chun Sing, Minister for Trade and Industry; Elaine Ng, CEO, National Library Board; Lee Ang Seng, MD, Beca Carter Hollings & Ferner (S.E.Asia); Cham Tao Soon, chairman, Singapore Quality Award Governing Council; Choy Sauw Kook, assistant CEO, Quality & Excellence Group, Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: Incoming Mexico FM vows foreign investment to entice migrants to stay home
summary: Incoming Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard vowed to stem Central America's migrant outflow by boosting investment in their home countries. Ebrard promised "substantial changes" to Mexico's migrant policy, including more work visas, investments in Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, and a new immigration policy. This comes amid US President Donald Trump's attacks on a caravan of migrants heading to the US border, with Trump threatening to cut off aid to the countries. Ebrard did not address the caravan directly, but his comments aim to counter Trump's rhetoric.

site_title: Global growth outlook dims amid concerns over trade war, tightening financial conditions
summary: Global growth outlook for 2019 has dimmed due to concerns over the US-China trade war and tightening financial conditions. Reuters polls of over 500 economists showed a downgrade to the outlook for 18 economies, with 23 unchanged. The US economy is expected to slow down by late next year, while emerging markets face pain ahead due to capital flow stoppages and trade tensions. Economists warn that a global trade war would inflict lasting damage on growth and cause permanent loss of output.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore has clinched a contract with Huawei Technologies to lease 147 luxury apartments in Myanmar for up to three years, generating US$7.7 million in rental income. Vibrant Group has received extensions of time to publish its financial reports, with new deadlines of October 31 and November 14. shopper360 secured an agreement with NTUC FairPrice to provide in-store advertising services at 68 hypermarkets and supermarkets in Singapore.

site_title: Housing a smart nation
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) of Singapore has won the Singapore Quality Award with Special Commendation for a second time, recognizing its efforts to deliver affordable and quality homes. Established in 1960, HDB has leveraged the Business Excellence framework to align its strategies and processes, introducing innovative designs and technologies such as smart homes, green communal spaces, and elderly-friendly homes. The organization aims to provide a sustainable and vibrant living environment for Singaporeans, with a focus on community interaction and resident needs.

site_title: Uber to appeal Singapore's competition watchdog decision on Grab deal
summary: Uber plans to appeal Singapore's competition watchdog decision on its merger with Grab, citing the regulator's ruling as "unsupported and incorrect". The CCCS fined Grab S$6.42 million and Uber S$6.58 million, stating the merger drove up prices and infringed competition laws. Uber disputes the allegations, arguing its deal respects the law and will be joined by Go-Jek, a new competitor. The company will appeal independently of Grab, which will not contest the decision.

site_title: Easier, safer access to e-govt services with SingPass Mobile
summary: Singapore has launched SingPass Mobile, a new mobile app that allows users to log into digital government services using 2-Factor Authentication (2FA) via fingerprint, facial recognition, or a six-digit passcode. The app aims to enhance security and convenience, with features such as malware detection and control over personal data. The launch is part of Singapore's vision for a National Digital Identity (NDI) system, which aims to provide seamless and secure transactions between citizens, businesses, and government agencies.

site_title: Australia's WorleyParsons to buy Jacobs energy, resources arm for US$3.3b
summary: WorleyParsons, an Australian engineering services firm, has agreed to buy Jacobs' energy, resources arm for US$3.3 billion, doubling its size. The deal will position WorleyParsons for growth in refining and petrochemical sectors, particularly in India, where massive new plants are being built. The acquisition will make WorleyParsons the world's largest provider of professional services in energy and resources, with a large footprint in Europe and North America. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2019 and will boost WorleyParsons' earnings per share by 50%.

site_title: Gilberto Benetton, co-founder of fashion brand, dies aged 77
summary: Gilberto Benetton, co-founder of the fashion brand Benetton, died at 77 after a brief illness at home in Treviso, Italy. He passed away three months after his younger brother Carlo's death. Benetton was a key figure in the company's diversification, serving as vice-president of Edizione and Autogrill. The company, founded by his three brothers and sister, has struggled with dwindling sales in recent years. Benetton's death marks the end of an era for the family's business empire, which generated 12.1 billion euros in annual revenue.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE erases gains in choppy trade on gambling, energy stocks
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index closed down 0.10% on Monday, erasing earlier gains, due to pressure from energy stocks and a report on a UK crackdown on offshore taxes affecting gambling companies. Energy stocks fell 12 points, with Wood Group down 2.8% and BP down 1.2%. Positive earnings from NMC Health lifted the healthcare provider, while UK mining companies were boosted by higher copper prices. Lloyds Banking Group also gained 0.5% after announcing a share buyback program.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa - Max Factor reinvention for the future
summary: Claressa shares insights on Max Factor's reinvention for the future in a recent Money FM podcast. Although the article is not directly related to the provided content, the key fact is that the article is about a podcast discussing Max Factor's reinvention.

site_title: As co-working rises, US owners copy hotel model to cut risk
summary: US co-working owners are adopting "management agreements" with flexible workspace providers, a new format that avoids fixed-lease payments, to mitigate risk and boost profits. This shift comes as the industry faces growing tenant demands for shorter contracts. Industry leaders, including WeWork, have turned to these partnerships to meet these demands, with fees ranging from 5-10% for shorter-term tenants. The move aims to reduce exposure to liability and provide a more stable income stream, but critics warn of potential asset-liability mismatches.

site_title: Pavilion Energy to double LNG fleet with BW charters
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-owned liquefied natural gas (LNG) company, has agreed to charter two new LNG carriers from BW Group, set to double its fleet capacity. The vessels, built in South Korea, will feature lower carbon engines and are scheduled for delivery between 2019 and 2020. The long-term charters are expected to strengthen Pavilion Energy's global LNG trading activities, particularly on long-haul voyages. This move comes amid a surge in global LNG demand, with Wood Mackenzie projecting a 150 million tonne increase in LNG output between 2015 and 2020.

site_title: An international leader among libraries
summary: The National Library Board (NLB) has been managing the International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions' (IFLA) Regional Office for Asia and Oceania for 13 years. NLB has raised the profile of libraries in the region, hosting international forums and winning awards, including the "Experience - Association Conference Organiser of the Year" category in 2014. This appointment highlights NLB's role in promoting libraries and information services in the Asia and Oceania region.

site_title: BuildTech showcases innovative tech for construction sector
summary: Singapore's BuildTech Asia exhibition showcased innovative technologies for the construction sector, attracting a record 10,000 visitors. Companies such as Kajima and Roboprint demonstrated robots that can lift heavy materials and paint building walls, respectively. The event aimed to drive the adoption of advanced construction methods, including Design for Manufacturing and Assembly (DfMA), and highlighted the importance of collaboration and leveraging expertise among firms. The Singapore Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) and Building and Construction Authority (BCA) will work together to reach out to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and provide them with specific programs and resources.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: KIT unit Basslink 'strongly rejects' Hydro Tasmania's allegations
summary: Basslink, a subsidiary of KEPPEL Infrastructure Trust, has rejected allegations by Hydro Tasmania that its facilities did not meet operational requirements. The dispute centers on the 2015 Basslink Interconnector outage, which was investigated by DNV GL. Basslink maintains its position that the analysis is flawed due to theoretical models and not actual testing. The company had advised Hydro Tasmania that its Asset Management Plan and Marine Disaster Recovery Plan were under review, prompting the dispute. Basslink's shares fell 1% on the news.

site_title: China brokers lead biggest rally since 2015 amid state support
summary: China's brokerages led a 9.8% surge in Shanghai, the largest rally since 2015, amid state support. The rebound follows President Xi Jinping's vow of support for non-state firms, measures to ease risks from stock-backed loans, and a plan to cut personal income taxes. Analysts say the collective message from top officials has eased concerns, and the government's moves will help reduce stock-pledge risks, stabilize the domestic equity market, and improve valuations for Chinese brokerages.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ Shipbldg SGD) and Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) are recommended as buy targets with price targets of S$1.82 and S$1.56, respectively. Yangzijiang's recent sell-off presents a buying opportunity due to its 10% return on equity and 4% yield, solid balance sheet, and upcoming Q3 2018 results expected to be healthy. FCOT's Q4 FY18 results were within expectations, and the company is optimistic about leasing momentum and potential to backfill vacancies in 2H FY19.

site_title: BP uses borrowed tech to drive billions in savings
summary: BP is leveraging borrowed technology to drive significant cost savings, particularly in the oil and gas industry. The company has adopted various innovative solutions, including wearable sensors to monitor workers' health, fibre-optic cables to detect problems in oil wells, and AI-powered algorithms to optimize production. By adapting tech from consumer industries, BP has reduced costs by billions of dollars, including a 30% cut in capital expenditure. The company's chief digital innovation officer, Morag Watson, and Blaine Toohey, a 26-member team, have been instrumental in driving this cultural shift, incorporating feedback and iterating on solutions to improve efficiency.

site_title: Striving to deliver better services
summary: The National Library Board (NLB) has used the Business Excellence framework to improve its services and deliver better results. Over 20 years, NLB has won all Business Excellence Awards, including Innovation Excellence, Singapore Quality, People, and Service Excellence Awards. The framework has helped NLB benchmark itself against other libraries worldwide and improve processes, leading to increased patron satisfaction. NLB has also introduced innovative services such as the NLB Mobile app and reservation lockers, and used technology to enhance its operations, including the AutoSorter and Mobile Bookdrop.

site_title: Eurozone banks hope for ECB lifeline as long-term loans start to mature
summary: Eurozone banks face a funding cliff edge as 722 billion euros of long-term ECB loans mature from 2020, prompting concerns about refinancing costs amid rising market rates. New regulatory standards may require replacement funds as early as next year. The ECB's potential lifeline is seen as crucial, but the timing and terms of the assistance are uncertain. Market volatility, driven by US policy, Brexit, and Italian politics, adds to the banks' woes, raising fears of a refinancing crisis. The ECB's response will be closely watched for its impact on the Eurozone's financial stability.

site_title: Warehouses see demand for storing collectors' cars
summary: US car collectors are increasingly seeking alternative storage solutions for their prized vehicles, driving the demand for specialized warehouses. Entrepreneurs and investors are building car garages with capacities of over 100 vehicles, with some projects costing upwards of $10 million. The trend is attributed to the growing popularity of car collecting among the wealthy, who prefer to keep their vehicles outside of their residences. With a waiting list of 85 people already lined up, Los Angeles media entrepreneur Matt Farah's 13,800 sq ft garage is set to open next summer, charging between $850 and $1,500 per month per parking space.

site_title: Silver workforce can play a part in Singapore's future
summary: Singapore's aging workforce faces threats from automation, with potential losses of $3.3 billion in GDP due to sickness absenteeism. A study across 15 countries found that countries with higher aging rates also have larger proportions of older workers at risk from automation. To counter this, governments and companies must devise strategies to encourage and accommodate older workers, valuing their experience and emotional intelligence. Investing in human workers, particularly older ones, can benefit companies with productivity gains, and harnessing their skills can contribute to the nation's future.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust posts higher Q2 DPU at 1.958 cents
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported higher Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.958 cents, up from 1.887 cents in the same period last year, driven by a 32.5% increase in income available for distribution to S$63.9 million. Gross revenue grew 13.8% to S$106.6 million, while net property income increased 14.6% to S$90.2 million. For the first half, DPU rose to 3.915 cents, with income available for distribution jumping 30.8% to S$124.8 million. The trust attributed its performance to its portfolio rejuvenation efforts and stable leasing activities.

site_title: Brexit in danger of meaning what it says
summary: The UK's Brexit process is at risk of not living up to its initial promise, with the EU's insistence on strict rules for the Northern Irish border threatening to derail the agreement. Despite the UK's desire to maintain free trade with the EU, the EU's stance on the border has led to a stalemate, with both sides refusing to budge. The UK's Prime Minister Theresa May's "Chequers Plan" was rejected by the EU, and with the transition period coming to an end, the UK is now considering declaring its intention to leave the EU as planned, potentially leading to a hard Brexit.

site_title: Saudi summit loses its swagger as elites question kingdom
summary: A Saudi investment summit has lost its luster after prominent business leaders withdrew due to the killing of government critic Jamal Khashoggi. The conference, meant to showcase the kingdom's economic reform efforts, was canceled after dozens of finance and business leaders pulled out. This marks a significant blow to Saudi Arabia's leadership, as the event was designed to attract top business titans and promote the country's economic growth. The summit's cancellation highlights the ongoing impact of Khashoggi's death on Saudi Arabia's international reputation.

site_title: US campaign against China is heating up on all fronts
summary: The US is intensifying its campaign against China, with multiple fronts heating up. The Trump administration has withdrawn from the Universal Postal Union, citing unfair rates that benefit China, and has imposed veto clauses in trade accords with Canada and Mexico. A show of force in the South China Sea is planned, and the US has strengthened its ties with Taiwan, which has emboldened those seeking independence. China has been calm but measured in its response, with President Xi Jinping needing to appear forceful to maintain his position. The US is also pushing for similar veto clauses in trade deals with Japan, the EU, and Britain.

site_title: Spearheading transformation in the semiconductor industry
summary: Feinmetall Singapore, a German-Singapore joint-venture, has established itself as a leading company in the semiconductor industry, achieving year-on-year growth of 29% over the past five years. The company's success can be attributed to its vision of changing traditional practices through automation, which has improved lead times and efficiency. Feinmetall Singapore introduced automated systems, such as Manufacturing Control Tower (MCT), and mobile apps to enhance customer convenience and employee productivity. The company also prioritized employee training and development, fostering a culture of collaboration and equality. With a focus on digital manufacturing, Feinmetall Singapore aims to participate in the Singapore Quality Award, further solidifying its position as a leading player in the industry.

site_title: Truck makers revving up for rollout of electric freight haulers
summary: Truck manufacturers are accelerating the rollout of electric and hydrogen-fuelled commercial trucks, driven by regulatory pressure to cut diesel pollution. Companies like Tesla, Toyota, and Hyundai have received orders from major fleet operators, but the market's potential is uncertain, particularly outside of China. The limited range of early electric and hydrogen trucks and lack of charging infrastructure threaten to limit sales to short-haul operations, with most manufacturers expecting to start with short-haul routes.

site_title: Bordeaux headed for 'great, classic' vintage
summary: Bordeaux is expected to have a "great, classic" vintage in 2018, following an unusually warm growing season and exceptionally dry summer and harvest. The region's wine-makers attribute the quality to the unique weather conditions, which included a wet period until June and a dry period after July. The 2018 vintage is expected to be comparable to previous high-quality vintages such as 2009, 2010, and 2016, with yields potentially reduced due to mildew in some areas.

images.alt_text: Winemaker Olivier Bernard, head of the Domaine de Chevalier, took part in the grape harvest of the La Croix de Guyenne vineyard parcel at the entrance of the Merignac airport near Bordeaux in south-western France in September.

site_title: A strategy to deal with disruption
summary: Maha Chemicals (Asia) leveraged the Business Excellence framework to drive innovation and digital transformation, aiming to enhance its competitive advantage and venture into new business segments. The company digitized customer engagement processes and developed mobile apps to simplify operations. Certified to Singapore Quality Class (SQC) since 2015, Maha's SQC certification has helped open doors to new business opportunities and boosted confidence among customers and stakeholders. The company continues to innovate and refine its approach, seeking to attain Singapore Quality Class Star and increase its global recognition.

site_title: Fright flick Halloween leads box office
summary: Universal's Halloween film opened with a US$77.5 million in estimated ticket sales, the second-best October opening behind Venom. The film, produced for US$10 million, tells the story of Laurie Strode's return 40 years after a bloody killing spree. A Star Is Born held the second spot, while Venom and Goosebumps 2: Haunted Halloween followed in third and fourth place, respectively.

site_title: US$12b earmarked for Asean enterprises on new platform
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced a new deal-making platform, MATCH, which has attracted 380 investors to invest up to US$12 billion in Asean enterprises in 2019 and beyond. The platform, part of the Singapore FinTech Festival, has generated over 17,000 matches between investors and 840 enterprises, with a focus on fintech, healthcare, and technology sectors. The investment is expected to support the development of promising Asean enterprises, with MAS committed to ensuring private capital is deployed effectively.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

On a new deal-making platform, 380 investors have indicated intentions to invest up to US$6.2 billion in Asean enterprises in 2019, with another US$6 billion earmarked over the following two years, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced on Monday.

site_title: Philips tumbles on lacklustre profit and health unit performance
summary: Philips' shares tumbled 9.9% after the company missed third-quarter profit estimates, with earnings of €568m falling short of €584m forecasts. The personal-health unit's growth rate of 4% was below analyst expectations of 5.3%. CEO Frans van Houten attributed the slower recovery to emerging-market currency weaknesses and trade tensions. The company reiterated its growth targets, but the disappointing results led to a 7.1% decline in shares to €32.23.

site_title: Keeping to the spirit of AGMs
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is working with the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) and the Singapore Institute of Directors (SID) to develop a guide on conducting shareholder meetings constructively. The exchange encourages "robust discussions" between shareholders and directors, following concerns about interactions and behavior at recent AGMs. The guide aims to promote a more constructive process for information sharing, question answering, and exercising shareholder rights. This effort is in response to recriminations and potential legal disputes arising from AGMs.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Harmony needed to achieve best results at AGMs
summary: Shareholders attending Annual General Meetings (AGMs) must understand their roles and observe respect, courtesy, and tolerance to maximize benefits. Rules of proper behavior apply to all parties, including shareholders, company officers, and directors. Shareholders should prepare questions, read the annual report, and avoid irrelevant topics. Company chairs must ensure order and decorum, allow equal opportunity for all to speak, and take firm control of meetings. A guide on proper conduct at AGMs is set to be released, including pointers from the Securities Investors Association (SIAS) and the Singapore Institute of Directors.

site_title: How Blackstone landed US$20b from Saudis
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has secured a US$20 billion investment in Blackstone Group LP's infrastructure fund, with concessions including lower management and incentive fees, as well as discounts based on revenue generated from other investors. In exchange, PIF will match other investors' deposits in the fund and have a limited board seat on the fund's advisory committee. The deal comes as tensions rise over the killing of a US-based journalist critical of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's regime, with some investors expressing concerns over the kingdom's influence on the fund's investment decisions.

site_title: Singapore-Bangladesh ties a study in complementarity for win-win gains
summary: Bangladesh and Singapore have strengthened their bilateral ties, with trade growing from $2.1 billion in 2013 to $2.8 billion in 2018. Singapore is a major source of foreign direct investment (FDI) for Bangladesh, with Singaporean companies investing in various sectors such as power generation, manufacturing, and IT. Bangladesh's growing economy, with an average annual growth rate of over 6%, and its young working-age population, make it an attractive destination for investors. The two countries have also established a partnership to facilitate investment in infrastructure projects, with Singaporean companies set to participate in Public-Private Partnership (PPP) projects.

site_title: China Evergrande seeks US$1.5b via tower financing
summary: China Evergrande Group is seeking US$1.5 billion via tower financing, offering its Hong Kong office tower as collateral. The move comes as the developer faces pressure due to China's slowing property sector and restricted ability to pay offshore debt. Evergrande plans to use the capital to pay back offshore debt and make dividend payments. This is an unusual move, as the tower has yet to be fully paid off, and the practice of securitizing a building with outstanding debt is rare among highly leveraged Chinese developers.

site_title: BASF, Nornickel join forces in electric vehicle battery push
summary: BASF and Nornickel, Russia's second-largest nickel producer, have signed a deal to supply nickel and cobalt to support growing demand for electric vehicle batteries. BASF will build a plant in Finland to produce battery materials, with the start-up planned for late 2020. The agreement aims to create local European battery cell manufacturing capacity, currently dominated by Chinese and South Korean firms.

site_title: Tokyo wants more price competition among telcos
summary: The Japanese government is urging the country's three major mobile phone carriers to cut prices by up to 40% to accelerate competition before e-commerce firm Rakuten launches its mobile service in October 2019. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that carriers NTT DoCoMo, KDDI, and SoftBank have the potential to reduce mobile charges. Rakuten aims to charge lower rates, potentially disrupting the market, but a 40% price drop could slow core consumer inflation. The government seeks to stimulate spending and boost overall consumption.

site_title: Raise CPF withdrawal age amid growing lifespans: study
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) system can be improved by raising the withdrawal age amid growing lifespans, according to the Melbourne Mercer Global Pension Index. The country scored a B grade, ranking 7th globally, with suggestions to open the fund to non-permanent residents and increase the age of withdrawal. This comes as Singapore's life expectancy increases, with the population aging and the number of centenarians rising 24 times since 1990. Experts suggest transparent communication and incorporating Singapore-specific considerations are key to implementing reforms.

site_title: Alibaba expands cloud business to UK with new data centres
summary: Alibaba's cloud computing arm has expanded to the UK with two operational data centres in London, driven by rapidly growing customer demand. The expansion, despite Brexit uncertainty, is part of Alibaba Cloud's efforts to challenge Amazon Web Services in Europe. The company, now the fourth-largest global cloud provider, has previously established a data centre in Frankfurt and is in talks with BT Group about a cloud services partnership. Alibaba's UK launch is seen as key to its success outside China, with prospects in the US uncertain due to President Trump's America First agenda.

site_title: Hong Kong's tech dreams are becoming a nightmare
summary: Hong Kong's plan to become a listing destination for tech companies has faced setbacks. In April, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange changed its rule to allow dual-class shares, but Xiaomi Corp's attempt to list was delayed due to Lei Jun's refusal to relinquish control. This move follows Alibaba Group's IPO in 2014, where Jack Ma retained control. The new rule has sparked concerns about the bourse's ability to attract top tech companies.

site_title: Russian oligarch files suit against Nordic banks
summary: Russian billionaire Boris Rotenberg has filed a lawsuit against Nordic banks, including Nordea Bank, Svenska Handelsbanken, Danske Bank, and OP Corporate Bank, alleging violations of service agreements due to US sanctions imposed in 2014. The lawsuit, filed at the Helsinki District Court, seeks to clarify the banks' compliance with US sanctions. Rotenberg, a Finnish citizen, was not sanctioned by Europe, but his brother Arkady was placed under US sanctions as part of President Vladimir Putin's inner circle. The banks have 30 days to respond to the lawsuit.

site_title: Weighing the likelihood of a US-China war
summary: US-China tensions have escalated, with some warning of a potential war, echoing predictions made by George Friedman in 1991 about a US-Japan rivalry. However, experts argue that the current disagreements between Washington and Beijing are driven by deeper structural changes in the international system, with the US facing challenges to its economic and military status from rising global power China. The US and China are now in a "Thucydides' Trap," where a rising power challenges the incumbent hegemon, increasing the risk of conflict. With nationalist leaders in power in both countries, the situation remains volatile, but also leaves room for a potential deal or compromise.

images.alt_text: For more than 20 years, American policymakers believed that engaging with a growing China was in the US' interest and would commit China to a peaceful rise. But things have now changed and the pro-containment camp now has the upper hand.

site_title: After taking Europe, Germany's Uber for buses targets Manhattan
summary: German startup Flixmobility, known for its bus service in Europe, plans to expand to New York City and other US cities in 2019. The company, which has disrupted traditional bus travel, aims to offer low fares and amenities like Wi-Fi and electrical outlets. Flix has seen success on the West Coast, with routes like Los Angeles to Las Vegas averaging 75% occupancy. The company's goal is to compete with Greyhound Lines and other regional bus companies, and to eventually become a dominant force in the US market.

site_title: PayPal backs emerging markets lender Tala
summary: PayPal has made a strategic investment in Tala, a financial technology startup that lends to underserved consumers in emerging markets. Tala will use the funding to further develop its product and broaden its reach, with a focus on lending to individuals in Kenya, Tanzania, the Philippines, and Mexico. The investment aligns with PayPal's mission to serve the unbanked and underserved, and reflects the growing trend of digital finance in emerging markets. Tala has lent over $500 million to customers and has over 300 employees worldwide.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after China rally, Italian budget relief
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by gains in global stocks due to hopes of economic stimulus in China and easing tensions over Italy's debt. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.19%, the S&P 500 gained 0.22%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.51%. The rally came ahead of a busy week of earnings and amid uncertainty over US-China trade relations.

site_title: Asia's slowing LNG demand growth to curb spot market buying
summary: Asia's demand growth for short-term liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargoes is expected to slow this winter, potentially capping prices that have risen due to increased imports by China. Forecasts predict a 0.8-9.8% increase in LNG demand in Asia from November to February, down from 11.9% last year. Japan's nuclear power plants, set to be online by winter, and China's securing of term supplies are contributing to the slower growth. This may lead to softer prices for Asian LNG buyers.

site_title: Cooling measures 'dampened developers' sentiment'
summary: The Real Estate Sentiment Index (RESI) in Singapore fell sharply to 4.0 in the third quarter from 6.6 in the second quarter, due to the imposition of tougher ABSD rules in July. Developers' sentiment towards the property market has been dampened, with the prime residential sector experiencing a significant decline in net balances. Survey respondents attributed the decline to the "unexpected and surprising" cooling measures and the "hefty" ABSD penalties, which have made land-banking decisions challenging and risky.

site_title: Are Singaporeans ready for AI?
summary: Singapore is preparing for the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on its workforce, with the government, educational institutions, and companies taking steps to reskill and redeploy workers into new roles. Despite a potential skills mismatch, Singaporeans are optimistic about AI's role in the workplace, with 78% expecting it to improve job satisfaction. New job opportunities will emerge in the "missing middle" space, where humans and machines collaborate, requiring skills in areas like data science, software engineering, and technology architecture. The key to success lies in educating individuals on how humans and machines can work together effectively.

site_title: Singapore to be investment broker for Asia's infrastructure
summary: Singapore plans to boost infrastructure investment in South-east Asia by structuring projects to make them more "bankable". The country's Infrastructure Asia agency aims to connect supply and demand for infrastructure projects, with the Asian Development Bank estimating $26 trillion in needed investments by 2030. Currently, only $880 billion is being spent annually. Singapore aims to play a key role in mobilizing capital and attracting investors, addressing concerns about over-reliance on China's funding in the region. The move is seen as a response to global trade tensions and a multilateral approach to economic growth.

site_title: 'No intention' of 1973-style oil embargo, says Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia has no intention of imposing a 1973-style oil embargo on Western consumers, energy minister Khalid al-Falih said, amid tensions over the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. However, he warned that oil prices could rise due to Iranian sanctions and potential declines in other oil-producing countries. Saudi Arabia plans to increase its oil output to 11 million barrels per day, but may use its limited spare capacities if other countries decline.

site_title: Euro zone banks see rising credit demand, easing standards in Q4
summary: Euro zone banks anticipate increased demand for housing loans, consumer credit, and enterprise loans in Q4, with easing of credit standards for housing loans and consumer credit. The European Central Bank's survey of euro zone banks found no change in credit standards for enterprise loans. This indicates a shift towards more lenient lending practices, which could boost economic growth.

site_title: Getting top marks
summary: ITE, a post-secondary institution, has transformed into a leader in career and skills education. Since its restructuring in 1992, ITE has focused on market-relevant and customer-focused education, employing its "Authentic Learning" approach. This approach involves simulated work environments, such as an Aerospace Hub and simulation labs, to prepare students for their chosen careers. ITE has also adopted the Business Excellence framework to support its forward-looking mission, aiming to equip students with skills to thrive in a fast-changing labor landscape.

site_title: Japan's financial system can withstand easing for now: BOJ
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) reported that Japan's financial system remains stable, with growth in bank lending supporting the economy. The central bank stated that lenders are coping with its record monetary easing program, but noted longer-term risks to the banking system. Banks' core profitability has decreased due to population shrinkage, competition, and low interest rates. The BOJ emphasized the need for banks to enhance risk management, particularly in areas like real estate lending and securities investment. The central bank's assessment suggests it may not adjust its policy, but is aware of potential risks.

site_title: Leveraging a culture of excellence
summary: CBM, a facilities management company, has leveraged its corporate culture of excellence to become a leading player in its sector. The company achieved various certifications, including Singapore Service Class and Singapore Quality Class, and has expanded internationally. CEO Roy Chiang attributes the success to continual improvements and customer feedback, which has boosted credibility with clients and supported its internationalization efforts. CBM aims to attain the Singapore Quality Award within the next two years, solidifying its position as a leader in facilities management.

images.alt_text: "Our corporate culture has always been to pursue continual improvements as the company continues to grow our market share and expand our range of services," says CBM CEO Roy Chiang.
CBM services clients from various industries, such as commercial, retail, residential, industrial, government and hospitality.

site_title: SGX-Tel Aviv pact may spice up IPO scene from H1 2019
summary: Singapore and Israel's stock exchanges have inked a pact to woo mid-market Israeli startups to tap Asian capital through dual listings. The Tel Aviv Stock Exchange (TASE) expects 30-50 companies to list on both exchanges within the next three years. The partnership aims to provide startups with a wider choice of investors and to capitalize on Singapore's gateway status to a diversified investor pool in Asia. High-tech companies in Israel, valued between $200 million and $500 million, are seen as ideal candidates for the dual-listing proposition.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: A path to sustainable growth
summary: Enterprise Singapore's Business Excellence (BE) initiative helps Singapore-based organizations improve their operations and achieve superior growth by conducting a comprehensive review, developing a strategic roadmap, and adopting a globally benchmarked framework aligned with international quality awards. Certified organizations can access best practice resources and leverage their certification to instill confidence in stakeholders. The certification process involves a 1,000-point assessment, with a minimum score of 400 required for Singapore Quality Class (SQC) certification and 550 for SQC STAR.

site_title: Carl Icahn rides cargo boom to US$1.34b sale of train-car maker
summary: Billionaire investor Carl Icahn sold American Railcar Industries Inc for $1.34 billion, quintupling his investment in the freight boom. The sale, to a subsidiary of hedge fund ITE Management LP, marks a retreat from Icahn's previous attempt to consolidate the rail-equipment industry. The deal is valued at $1.75 billion including debt and comes amid a surge in rail carloads driven by the US economy and a shortage of truck drivers.

images.alt_text: Billionaire investor Carl Icahn agreed to sell American Railcar Industries Inc for US$1.34 billion, quintupling his investment as a freight boom spurs a rebound in demand for rail equipment.

site_title: Saudi Ma'aden says hires Korea's Daelim to build 3.35b riyal ammonia plant
summary: Saudi Ma'aden has signed a contract with South Korea's Daelim Industrial to build a third ammonia plant in Ras al-Khair, Saudi Arabia, at a cost of 3.35 billion Saudi riyals. The 38-month project is part of a larger phosphate complex development estimated to cost 24 billion riyals.

site_title: Khashoggi killing 'a wake-up call': Qatar
summary: Qatar's foreign ministry says the killing of Jamal Khashoggi should be a "wake-up call" for the international community, with Qatar expressing faith in the Turkish investigation. The ministry's spokeswoman, Lolwah al-Khater, stated that Qatar's relations with Saudi Arabia have not changed dramatically, despite the diplomatic crisis between the two countries since 2017. Al-Khater called for a transparent investigation and backed a joint statement by the UK, France, and Germany, which urged Saudi Arabia to clarify Khashoggi's death.

site_title: NTUC FairPrice, shopper360 ink advertising agreement
summary: Shopper360, a Catalist-listed company, has secured an exclusive advertising agreement with NTUC FairPrice to provide in-store advertising services at 68 hypermarkets and supermarkets in Singapore. Under the agreement, ShopperPlus Singapore will secure media space and install advertising mediums for FMCG customers. This is shopper360's first such agreement in Singapore, with plans to leverage its existing relationships with FMCG clients in Malaysia to expand its presence in the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: US regulators require Linde, Praxair to divest holdings to allow massive merger
summary: US regulators approved the $80 billion merger between US Praxair Inc and German Linde AG, creating the world's largest industrial gas supplier. However, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) required Linde to divest nine business units, including Messer Group GmbH and Matheson Tri-Gas Inc, to address competition concerns. The merger will proceed provided Linde divests these units, which include numerous North American facilities.

site_title: US$12b earmarked for Asean enterprises via new matching platform
summary: A new matching platform, MATCH, has been launched by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to connect Asean enterprises with global private equity and venture capital. 380 investors have expressed interest in investing up to US$6.2 billion in Asean enterprises by 2020, with a focus on fintech, healthcare, and technology sectors. The platform has generated over 17,000 matches between investors and enterprises, highlighting the upward momentum in growth capital demand in Asean.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure unit inks preliminary pact for 6b yuan China rail project
summary: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings has signed a preliminary agreement with the Tourism Board of Dengfeng City and Chengdu Tianfu Railtech Valley Technology Co. to build 70 km of tourist railways in China for an estimated 6 billion yuan (S$1.19 billion). The project will be completed in four phases, with the first two phases spanning 2018-2020 and 2020-2022, and the last two phases spanning 2022-2024 and 2024-2026. The company will provide construction and management services, and the project is not expected to impact earnings for the year ended December 2018.

site_title: Craft beer brews up a storm as trademarks soar to a record
summary: Craft beer in the UK has seen a record 2,372 trademark registrations in 2017, a 20% increase from the previous year. This surge is driven by rising demand for limited-edition and small-batch beers, with big players like Anheuser-Busch InBev and Heineken acquiring local brands to join the craft-beer scene. The growth has led to increased competition, with disputes over brand overlap and intellectual property rights on the rise, according to law firm Reynolds Porter Chamberlain LLP.

images.alt_text: The number of trademarks registered for beer soared to a record 2,372 in 2017, an increase of 20% from the previous year. Protecting the value of the brands has become a priority.

site_title: Emerging Towns & Cities inks contract with Huawei to lease 147 apartments in Myanmar, expected rental income totals US$7.7m
summary: Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore has signed a contract with Huawei Technologies to lease 147 luxury apartments in Myanmar for three years, generating a total rental income of US$7.7 million. The apartments, part of the Golden City mixed-use development, will be leased for two years with an option to renew. The lease will commence on June 1, 2019, and expire on May 31, 2022, if the option is exercised.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Wanda Ferragamo, who built up a fashion giant, dies at 96
summary: Wanda Ferragamo, the matriarch of the global fashion empire Salvatore Ferragamo, has died at 96. She took over her husband's shoe business after his death in 1960 and expanded it into a global fashion powerhouse with the help of her six children. Under her leadership, the company grew from producing 6,500 pairs of shoes a year to over 10,000 pairs a day, with annual revenue of $1.6 billion. Ferragamo's children and grandchildren now hold key positions within the company, which has become a renowned luxury brand with a legacy of innovative designs and iconic clients.

site_title: Saudi metro is key part of French RATP's foreign growth drive
summary: French state-owned public transport firm RATP aims to double its foreign revenue by 2025 through contracts in the Middle East, Asia, and the Americas. The company has seen its foreign revenue grow from €110 million in 2007 to an expected €800 million in 2018. RATP has won major contracts in Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and Egypt, including a 12-year, €2 billion contract to operate a metro line in Riyadh. The company plans to hire 3,500 people in Saudi Arabia, including 100 female drivers, and will bid for other international public transport tenders.

images.alt_text: The French state-owned public transport firm operates in 14 economies and has seen its foreign revenue grow from 110 million euros in 2007 to an expected 800 million in 2018.

site_title: PayPal backs emerging markets lender Tala
summary: PayPal has invested in Tala, a financial technology startup that lends to underserved consumers in emerging markets. Tala, which has lent over $500 million, will use the funding to expand its product and reach. The companies share a commitment to serving the unbanked and underserved, with PayPal seeing Tala as a mission-aligned partner. This investment is part of PayPal's efforts to transform itself into a financial services company, following its acquisition of Xoom in 2015.

site_title: Imran Khan leaves for Saudi conference saying Pakistan "desperate" for loans
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan left for Saudi Arabia to attend an investment conference despite international boycotts over Jamal Khashoggi's death. Khan stated Pakistan is "desperate" for loans to shore up its economy, citing a looming balance of payment crisis. This is his second visit to Saudi Arabia in a month, as Islamabad seeks financial assistance to address its debt crisis. Finance Minister Asad Umar and Commerce Minister Abdul Razak Dawood accompany Khan, who has asked the IMF to open negotiations for a potential bailout.

site_title: MeGroup prices IPO at S$0.23 a share to raise S$2.4m
summary: MeGroup, a Malaysian car dealership and automotive parts maker, has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at S$0.23 per share, raising S$2.4m. The company's net profit for the year ended March 31 was RM8.9m (S$2.9m) on revenue of RM148.8m. MeGroup's market capitalization will be S$27.3m, 9.2 times its earnings for the 2018 fiscal year. The IPO will be listed on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange, with trading commencing on October 31.

images.alt_text: MeGroup wants to grow its dealership business by opening more outlets. It sells new automobiles under the Honda, Mazda and Peugeot brands.

site_title: Lufthansa is giving Boeing a shot at new wide-body deal
summary: Lufthansa is considering ordering 20 Boeing 787 Dreamliners as part of a deal potentially worth $10 billion, a move that could challenge Airbus's efforts to sell the German carrier A350 jets. The airline is also seeking to retire its aging A340 models in the deal. Lufthansa has requested proposals from both Boeing and Airbus, with a decision expected in the next few months. The airline's request for a way to get rid of its A340 models could be valued at around $5 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,078.06 on Monday, driven by gains in Genting Singapore, DBS, and OCBC Bank. The index saw 1.6 billion shares worth S$842.1 million trade, with 188 gainers beating 172 losers. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of the upcoming GDP data release.

site_title: Japan, India negotiating military logistics pact in tightening of ties
summary: Japan and India are negotiating a military logistics pact, known as the Acquisition and Cross Servicing Agreement (ACSA), which would allow access to each other's bases. The pact, which has been discussed since 2017, aims to strengthen security ties between the two countries and counterbalance China's growing influence in the region. The agreement would enable Japanese ships to access fuel and servicing at Indian naval bases, and Indian ships to use Japanese facilities for maintenance. The pact is seen as a significant development in bilateral relations between Japan and India, following similar agreements with the US.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) pension system ranked top in Asia, but improvement could be done. A new SingPass Mobile app simplifies and secures government transactions. Singapore aims to spur infrastructure investment in Asia through new agency. Emerging markets are more optimistic about global trade, contrary to developed countries. Uber has appealed a fine for violating Singapore's competition laws, while the Singapore shares closed 0.5% higher on Monday.

site_title: Asian markets rise on Chinese surge
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, driven by a surge in Chinese stocks following the government's pledge to boost the economy. China's Shanghai composite gained 4.3% to close at 3,270.27, while Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also rose. Singapore's Straits Times Index gained 0.5% to 3,078.06, while Australian shares fell 0.58% due to fresh political uncertainty. Analysts expressed caution, citing ongoing economic pressures and geopolitical tensions, but noted that tax cuts in China and robust corporate earnings could support global equity markets.

site_title: Singapore CPF scheme leads Asia in Global Pension Index
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) pension system has been ranked top in Asia, receiving a B grade in the Mercer's Global Pension Index. The scheme scored 70.4, with improvements in the sustainability sub-index and a C+ for adequacy, B for sustainability, and A for integrity. However, experts suggest that further improvements are needed, including raising the age for accessing savings and expanding the scheme to non-permanent residents. The index highlights a growing tension between adequacy and sustainability in pension systems worldwide.

site_title: Netflix selling US$2b of junk bonds to fund new shows
summary: Netflix is issuing a $2 billion junk bond offering to fund new programming, marking the company's first junk bond sale since 2017. The 10.5-year bonds will push Netflix's debt load above $10 billion for the first time. The company plans to use the funds to acquire and fund new content, despite expecting to burn about $3 billion in cash this year. The move comes as the company's market value has soared 70% this year to $140 billion, following impressive subscriber growth and revenue increases.

site_title: Innovative tech for the construction sector on show at BuildTech Asia 2018
summary: Singapore-based construction firm Kajima showcased its "Mighty Hand" robot, which lifts heavy elements like concrete and glass to assemble walls in Japan, at BuildTech Asia 2018. The exhibition featured innovative technologies from over 200 brands, including robots that paint high-rise building walls and smart solutions. The event aimed to drive the adoption of advanced construction methods, with the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) and Singapore Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) working together to reach out to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Malaysia shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 9.67 points lower on Monday, at 1,722.47, with 497 losers beating 315 gainers in volume. Total trading value was RM1.68 billion.

site_title: Chinese group plans asset-management scheme to aid companies
summary: China's Securities Association of China announced a 21 billion yuan (S$4.17 billion) asset-management scheme to support private companies. The scheme, initially funded by 11 brokerages, aims to attract investments from banks, insurers, and state-owned firms, with a target of 100 billion yuan. This move aims to boost market confidence amid recent regulatory measures.

site_title: Japan proposes LNG contract clause for resale of cargoes
summary: Japan's trade ministry proposes a model LNG contract clause to remove restrictions on resale of cargoes, following the country's anti-monopoly watchdog's ruling in June 2017 that new LNG contracts should not restrict resale. The proposed "model diversion clause" would allow buyers to resell spare cargoes, addressing concerns from Japanese LNG buyers who have been prevented by destination clauses. However, global LNG suppliers have been slow to revise their contracts, with no major changes reported. The move aims to liberalize Japan's LNG market, which is the world's biggest importer.

site_title: More than US$12b earmarked for Asean enterprises via new platform
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced a new deal-making platform, MATCH, which has attracted 380 investors indicating up to $6.2 billion in investments for Asean enterprises in 2019, with an additional $6 billion over the next two years. The majority of the investment is focused on fintech, healthcare, and information technology sectors. The platform aims to match Asean enterprises with global private equity and venture capital, supporting the development of promising Asean businesses.

site_title: Philips Q3 profit rises less than expected, cites currency headwinds
summary: Philips reported a 6.8% increase in core profit to 568 million euros in Q3, missing analyst estimates of 590 million euros. Sales rose 9% in China, with order intake up 11% from last year. The company attributed the underperformance to currency headwinds, despite improving margins and comparable sales growth of 4%.

images.alt_text: Dutch healthcare technology company Philips on Monday said its core profit in the third quarter rose 6.8 per cent to 568 million euros (S$1.18 billion), missing analyst estimates despite rising sales and improving margins.

site_title: Southeast Asia has an investment boom, thanks to the trade war
summary: Southeast Asia is experiencing a surge in foreign direct investment due to the intensifying US-China trade war. Vietnam, Thailand, and the Philippines saw significant increases in manufacturing inflows, with Vietnam's jumping 18% and Thailand's rising 53%. The region is becoming an attractive alternative for companies seeking to circumvent tariffs, with sectors such as consumer products and technology hardware showing interest. The trade war is seen as accelerating a trend, offering growth opportunities and mitigation from geopolitical risks, despite some regional countries experiencing unexpected economic fallout.

site_title: Fiat sells auto parts unit to Japan's Calsonic for 6.2b euros
summary: Fiat Chrysler is selling its Italian auto parts unit Magneti Marelli to Japan's Calsonic Kansei for 6.2 billion euros. The deal, expected to close in the first half of 2019, will create a top 10 global auto parts supplier with annual sales of 15.2 billion euros. The agreement will ensure Magneti Marelli's operations in Italy and employment levels remain stable. The merged company will provide a multi-year supply agreement with Fiat Chrysler, supporting growth at the unit.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on China stimulus expectations, won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.25% to 2,161.71 on Monday, driven by a strong Chinese market and expectations of stimulus. The won strengthened, up 0.33% against the dollar, while bond yields rose. The Bank of Korea's chief said he will consider a rate hike in November if the real economy shows big troubles. The Kospi is down 12.6% so far this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon trading at 3,074.22, up 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Monday, up 0.4% at 3,074.22, with 164 gainers and 147 losers. The most actively traded counters included Rex International and Genting Singapore, with Rex falling 3.09% and Genting rising 2.14%. DBS and Singtel were flat. The rally follows a 5-day run, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Norwegian billionaires head for showdown with supply creditors
summary: Norwegian billionaires Kjell Inge Rokke and John Fredriksen, who orchestrated a series of mergers in the struggling offshore supply industry, are heading for a final showdown with creditors. Solstad Offshore ASA, the resulting company, has announced debt negotiations and expects a "challenging" winter season. The market downturn has led to a significant decline in the company's value, with shares tumbling 27% and liabilities reaching 31.1 billion kroner. The two billionaires, who own 20% and 16% of Solstad, are strategically positioned to pressure banks and bondholders into accepting significant term changes.

images.alt_text: Billionaires Kjell Inge Rokke and John Fredriksen(above) used the oil-market downturn to force a series of mergers on Norway's struggling offshore supply industry. Now, they're heading for a final showdown with creditors.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open
summary: European stock markets rallied at the start of trading on Monday, with Milan up nearly 2.0% despite Moody's cutting Italy's credit rating due to high debt concerns. London's FTSE 100 index grew 0.4% to 7,081.06 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index jumped 1.0% to 11,665.68 points. The rally was largely driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: MeGroup prices IPO at S$0.23 per share to raise S$2.4m
summary: MeGroup, a Malaysian car dealership and automotive parts maker, has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at S$0.23 per share to raise S$2.4 million. The IPO will see 16.5 million new shares issued, resulting in a market capitalization of S$27.3 million. MeGroup made a net profit of RM8.9 million in 2018, driven by its dealership business, which accounted for 74.4% of revenue. The company aims to diversify its customer base and grow its dealership business, with plans to open more outlets.

site_title: Japan government wants lower mobile charges before Rakuten's entry next October
summary: Japan's government is urging the country's three dominant mobile phone network providers to lower mobile charges by up to 40% before e-commerce firm Rakuten Inc enters the market in October 2019. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga says this will help stimulate spending and boost overall consumption. Rakuten plans to charge less than the dominant carriers, with a spokesperson suggesting similar pricing to its current wireless offering. The government aims to ensure competition works and prices fall, but a 40% drop in mobile charges could slow core consumer inflation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks continue their rally, with the Shanghai Composite Index surging 4.09% to 2,654.88, its largest daily gain since March 2016. This follows tax cut plans and President Xi Jinping's efforts to support the country's markets. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 4.90%. The rally extends the market's performance at the end of last week.

site_title: China says will 'take care of' debt issues of 'Belt and Road' projects, respects Malaysia pull-out
summary: China's vice finance minister Zou Jiayi acknowledged debt issues with 'Belt and Road' projects, stating the government will strengthen macro-supervision on debt sustainability. China will optimize debt financing through foreign direct investment, public-private partnerships, and equity investment. The move comes after Malaysia stopped work on a $20 billion rail link due to debt concerns, a rare setback for the Belt and Road initiative. China respects Malaysia's decision-making and judgment, stressing the projects were inked on a commercial basis.

site_title: Vancouver elects Stewart new mayor as housing fury rages
summary: Vancouver has elected Kennedy Stewart as its new mayor, ending a decade without a change. Stewart won 28.7% of the vote, defeating Ken Sim, and has pledged to build 85,000 units of affordable housing in 10 years. The city faces a pressing issue of unaffordable housing, with the typical single-family house costing nearly 20 times median household income, making it the most unaffordable market in North America. Stewart aims to address this issue, succeeding Gregor Robertson, who stepped down earlier this year.

site_title: Retailer Casino's parent Rallye gets offer for 'Courir' sports arm
summary: Rallye, the parent company of French supermarket retailer Casino, has accepted a binding offer from private equity firm Equistone Partners Europe to sell its 'Courir' sports brand for 283 million euros (S$448 million). The deal, which could be completed by mid-2019, aims to reduce debts and sell off non-core assets. Rallye shares rose 3.8%, while Casino shares edged up 0.5% following the news.

site_title: Australia shares close lower amid fresh political uncertainty
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Monday, following a poor showing by the governing coalition in a weekend by-election that may hinder legislation passage. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5904.9. Most sectors declined, with financials and healthcare stocks losing 0.8% and 1.8% respectively. Mining stocks rose, led by BHP and Rio Tinto, driven by hopes for Chinese stimulus. The next election is not until May 2019, but the government's survival is uncertain.

site_title: UOB unveils financial support programme to help SMEs innovate, go global
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched a financial support programme to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) innovate and go global. The programme offers working capital loans, equipment financing, and cross-border cash management solutions. UOB will also expand its ecosystem of strategic partners to support SMEs in upgrading and scaling their technology capabilities.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.37% on Monday, driven by bargain-hunting as investors focused on companies expected to report positive results. Despite geopolitical worries, including US withdrawal from a nuclear treaty with Russia and tensions between the US and Saudi Arabia, shares of companies like Nippon Sharyo and Fanuc rose. The dollar strengthened against the yen, with Japanese firms seeing a positive impact from the currency's value.
