site_title: New Singapore agency to play investment broker in Asia infrastructure push: Indranee
summary: Singapore plans to create Infrastructure Asia, a new agency to help structure infrastructure projects to make them more "bankable" in South-east Asia. The agency aims to connect supply and demand, mobilizing capital to meet the estimated $26 trillion needed in infrastructure projects by 2030. Currently, only $880 billion is being spent annually. Singapore officials see themselves as a conduit for investment, countering China's dominance in the region and urging a multilateral approach to address global trade tensions and find solutions that benefit all.

site_title: Goldman Sachs changes Asia investment banking leadership: memo
summary: Goldman Sachs has named Todd Leland as its investment banking head for Asia Pacific excluding Japan, replacing Andrea Vella and Kate Richdale. Leland, an American veteran banker, will retain his role as co-president of the bank for Asia Pacific excluding Japan. The move comes as China's outbound M&A push slows amid the US-China trade war. Goldman's revenue in Asia rose 9% to $3.9 billion in the first nine months of 2018, but its share of group sales fell to 14%.

site_title: Saudi Arabia has "no intention" of 1973 oil embargo replay - TASS
summary: Saudi Arabia has no intention of repeating the 1973 oil embargo on Western consumers, Saudi energy minister Khalid al-Falih said amid the crisis over Jamal Khashoggi's killing. Al-Falih stated that Saudi Arabia will isolate oil from politics and instead use it as a responsible economic tool to stabilize global energy markets. He warned that higher oil prices could trigger a recession and urged caution, citing potential declines in other oil-producing countries and the impact of Iranian sanctions. Saudi Arabia plans to increase oil production to 11 million barrels per day.

images.alt_text: "There is no intention," Khalid al-Falih told Russia's TASS news agency when asked if there could be a repetition of the 1973-style oil embargo.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust's DPU rises to 1.958 Singapore cents for Q2 as revenue jumps 13.8%
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 32.5% increase in Q2 income available for distribution to S$63.9 million, driven by 13.8% growth in gross revenue to S$106.6 million. Distribution per unit rose to 1.958 Singapore cents, and H1 income available for distribution jumped 30.8% to S$124.8 million. Occupancy remained stable at 97.6%, with higher occupancies in Singapore, South Korea, China, and Vietnam. The trust's net asset value per unit increased to S$1.13, and its weighted average lease period (WALE) grew to 3.8 years.

site_title: Australia's sovereign fund beats target return, moves cash into private equity
summary: Australia's sovereign wealth fund, the Future Fund, has reported a 10.7% return on investment for the year to September, beating its target return of 4.1% by more than double. The fund shifted cash into private equity investments, reducing bonds and turbulent stock markets. Despite a cautious outlook, the fund's portfolio remains diversified and flexible, with private equity investments increasing to 14.8% of the portfolio. The fund now stands at A$148 billion, with equities making up 25.3% of the portfolio.

site_title: New Istanbul airport to only open fully at end of year: paper
summary: Istanbul's new airport will not open fully until the end of 2018, two months later than the initial planned opening date of October 29. The airport, with an initial capacity of 90 million passengers a year, will partially open on October 29, with Turkish Airlines operating domestic routes to Ankara, Izmir, and Antalya, and one international route to Baku, Azerbaijan. The delay is attributed to work conditions and living quarters at the airport, which were previously infested with bedbugs.

site_title: Japan banking system stable, divergence seen in profitability: BOJ
summary: Japan's banking system remains stable, but a growing divergence in profitability is seen between regional banks, which are struggling to match risks with profits. The Bank of Japan reported that core capital ratios for domestic banks have declined, with many increasing lending to middle-risk borrowers and property investment. The system lacks excess risk-taking, but policymakers may need to address the growing disparity between profitable and struggling regional banks.

images.alt_text: Japan's financial system remains stable as a whole but there is a growing divergence between regional banks that are profitable and those that are suffering, the Bank of Japan said on Monday.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB, CGS-CIMB, Phillip Securities maintain 'buy' on SGX
summary: Brokerages RHB, CGS-CIMB, and Phillip Securities maintain "buy" calls on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) following its stable first-quarter earnings. The bourse operator reported a 21% increase in derivatives revenue, with China A50 Index Futures being a key contributor. Analysts forecast continued volatility and rising interest rates to benefit derivatives turnover, driving the bourse's earnings. However, risks include regional competition and equity market weakness, with RHB warning of global economic fluctuations and geopolitical developments.

site_title: Indonesia's fiscal outlook benign but authorities hawkish: Citi
summary: Indonesia's fiscal deficit stands at 1.35% of GDP as of end-September, down from 2% in the previous year, according to Citi Research. The Ministry of Finance has lowered its projection for the FY 2018 fiscal deficit to 1.8-2% of GDP. Despite this, policymakers expect fuel prices to rise, potentially leading to inflation around 4% in 2019, contrary to Citi's base case scenario.

site_title: Pavilion Energy charters in low-carbon LNG carriers from BW Group
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-owned LNG player, has signed long-term charters with BW Group for two new liquefied natural gas carriers (LNGCs) to be built with lower carbon engines. The vessels, expected to be delivered between 2019 and 2020, will double Pavilion Energy's charter-in fleet. The newbuild LNGCs will reduce carbon dioxide emissions by approximately 22,300 tonnes per year, equivalent to 4,800 passenger cars. The charters are expected to run for more than 10 years and will bolster Pavilion Energy's capacity for long-haul trades between the Atlantic and Asia-Pacific regions.

site_title: Grab will pay S$6.42m anti-competition fine but Uber appealing Singapore watchdog's decision
summary: Uber is appealing a Singapore competition regulator's decision that its merger with Grab violated the city-state's competition laws. The regulator fined Grab S$6.42 million and Uber S$6.58 million, citing the merger led to a substantial lessening of competition and price increases. Uber disputes the regulator's decision, claiming the fine was "unsupported and incorrect" and that it respected the law. The appeal is made independently of Grab, and Grab will not appeal the regulator's decision. Uber also points to Go-Jek's impending entry into the market as a potential competitor.

site_title: US Gulf of Mexico oil and gas output returning to normal post storm
summary: US Gulf of Mexico oil and gas production is returning to near normal levels after Hurricane Michael, with oil output down 19% and natural gas production down less than 10%. Only one evacuated platform remains unoccupied, down from 89. Inspections and restoration of production can take several days after a storm passes. The hurricane made landfall on the Florida Panhandle, producing rough seas and high winds.

site_title: Grab to launch beta trial of GrabExpress in Singapore
summary: Grab launches a beta trial of GrabExpress in Singapore, a door-to-door delivery and courier service, to meet growing demand for instant parcel delivery. The service, initially limited to eastern Singapore, allows users to book deliveries via the Grab app, with prices starting from S$6 per delivery. The service supports parcels up to 5kg in weight and is covered by insurance, with the goal of eventually expanding to GrabCar and GrabTaxi drivers. The beta trial aims to provide income opportunities for delivery partners during off-peak hours.

images.alt_text: Grab will launch in Singapore on Tuesday a beta trial of GrabExpress, its on-demand door-to-door delivery and courier service, to serve the growing demand for instant delivery of parcels.

site_title: In Delhi, walk with Gandhi in the President's House
summary: The President's House in Delhi has opened its new museum, featuring a collection of treasures, including a moon rock and a chunk of Mount Everest. The museum, located in a classical palace built by the British, includes storerooms previously locked due to superstition. The collection showcases Indian history and culture, with items such as the Viceroy's House, which served as the residence of the British Viceroy of India. The museum offers a glimpse into the history of the President's House, a grand building with an Indian twist.

images.alt_text: With a moon rock, a chunk of Mount Everest and the chance to stroll with Gandhi, the President's House in Delhi is lifting the veil on its treasures in its new museum.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Monday; STI up 0.01% to 3,062.71
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 0.01% to 3,062.71. Trading volume was high, with 46.3 million shares changing hands. Key movers included Genting Singapore and Rex International, while UOB fell 0.36% and OCBC Bank rose 0.47%. The STI's flat opening was influenced by global market trends, including geopolitical worries and corporate earnings reports.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia surges 9.17% in early trading; firm says unusual activity due to rights issue
summary: Hong Leong Asia's share price surged 9.17% in early trading, with 1.4 million shares traded, amid unusual activity related to a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried the company for possible reasons behind the price and volume movements. The stock closed at 61.5 Singapore cents, up 12.84%, after the issue closed for acceptances and excess applications on October 19.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Oil edges up as looming Iran sanctions expected to tighten market
summary: Oil prices edged up as markets anticipated tightening due to US sanctions on Iran's crude exports, set to be implemented next month. Front-month Brent crude futures rose 13 cents to $79.91 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 12 cents to $69.24 a barrel. The expected sanctions are expected to reduce global oil supply and increase prices.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure inks preliminary pact for 6b yuan China rail project
summary: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings signed a framework agreement with the Tourism Board of Dengfeng City and Chengdu Tianfu Railtech Valley Technology Co. for a 6 billion yuan (S$1.19 billion) China rail project, involving 70 km of tourist railways in four phases. The project will be completed between 2018-2026, with the first two phases focusing on 15 km each and the last two phases on 20 km each. The company will provide construction and management services, and the project is expected to have minimal impact on earnings.

site_title: Me and my (porn) shadow: 'spycam' epidemic seizes South Korea
summary: South Korea is experiencing a "spycam" epidemic, with thousands of women forced to live with a pornographic shadow due to covert footage of sex, nudity, and urination posted online. The phenomenon has led to widespread sexism and social stigma, with tens of thousands of women marching for action. The government has enacted measures, including a taskforce to help victims and increased inspections, but critics say more needs to be done to educate people about gender equality and consent.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks extend rally at open on Monday
summary: Shanghai stocks extended their rally at the open on Monday, rising 0.59% to 2,565.64 on the Shanghai Composite Index. The Shenzhen Composite Index and Hang Seng Index also gained 0.93% and 0.79% respectively. The rally follows coordinated statements from China's top economic officials aiming to support markets.

site_title: China finds first cases of African Swine Fever in country's south
summary: China has reported its first cases of African Swine Fever in the southern region of Yunnan province, marking a significant shift in the country's outbreak. The highly contagious disease has already spread to 11 provinces and municipalities, resulting in the culling of an estimated 200,000 pigs. The latest outbreaks were reported on two small farms in Zhaotong, a city in Yunnan province, and are expected to impact the region's top pork consumers, leading to potential price increases ahead of the New Year holiday.

site_title: NUS-Redas property sentiment index falls sharply on cooling measures
summary: Singapore's NUS-Redas property sentiment index fell sharply to 4.0 in Q3 2018 due to cooling measures announced in July, including a buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) increase. The Current Sentiment Index dropped to 4.0 from 6.7 in Q2 2018, while the Future Sentiment Index fell to 4.2 from 6.4 in Q1 2018, indicating a decline in market sentiment.

site_title: UK bids adios to Spanish nurses 'betrayed' by Brexit
summary: The UK is facing a shortage of Spanish nurses due to Brexit, with 15% fewer Spanish staff in the NHS since 2016. Many Spanish health workers, like 34-year-old dentist Lara Garrido, have left the country due to job insecurity and Brexit uncertainty. Others, like 43-year-old nurse Joan Pons Laplana, have put down deeper roots but feel "betrayed" by the UK's decision to leave the EU. The NHS risks catastrophic consequences without these nurses, as demand for healthcare services continues to increase.

site_title: Bullish city of London stays confident as Brexit nears
summary: London's financial district remains confident despite Brexit nearing, with nearly 500,000 professionals working in the city. Despite initial fears of a brain drain, the city has seen a boost in international talent, with Chinese, Indian, and Japanese investors increasing their investments by nearly 50%. London's business-friendly regulatory and tax systems are also attracting foreign investors, with some predicting the city could become a "tax haven" outside the EU. The city's resilience and adaptability have allowed it to recover from past challenges, and it is expected to continue competing with New York and other global financial centers.

site_title: China stocks rally most since 2016 as state steps up support
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 3.1% to 2,629.90, its largest advance since May 2016, following top officials' support for the private sector. President Xi Jinping vowed "unwavering" support, while the country released a plan to cut personal income taxes and help manage share-pledge risks. The move is seen as a bid to stabilize the equity market and lift valuations. The yuan fell 0.1% to 6.9423 US dollars, while US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed openness to changing currency manipulation rules.

site_title: Australia startup Chargefox promises electric car charging in just 15 minutes
summary: Chargefox, a Sydney-based startup, plans to establish a national network of 21 ultra-rapid charging stations across major Australian freeways, reducing electric vehicle charging time to 15 minutes. The renewable-powered stations will deliver up to 400 kilometers of range and are funded by A$15 million from private investors and government. This initiative aims to improve Australia's electric vehicle infrastructure, addressing one of the major barriers to adoption. Chargefox competes with Fast Cities, which also plans to build a similar network of charging stations.

site_title: 'We failed them': Australia apologises to child sex abuse victims
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison issued a national apology to victims of child sex abuse, acknowledging the state's failure to stop decades of abuse in institutions. Morrison declared a new national credo, "We believe you," and apologized to survivors, parents, whistleblowers, and generations past and present. The apology comes after a five-year Royal Commission detailing over 15,000 survivors' claims. Lawmakers observed a moment of silence, and some institutions, including the Catholic Church, have already apologized for their failings.

site_title: E-government transactions easier, more secure with new app SingPass Mobile
summary: Singapore launches SingPass Mobile, an app allowing users to log in with fingerprint, facial recognition, or a passcode, eliminating password entry. The app provides an additional 2-factor authentication option, enhancing security and convenience. GovTech, the agency behind the app, aims to integrate digital services into a single, trusted National Digital Identity. The app will also offer enhanced security features, such as device security checks, to protect user data. Three to four of the most-used digital government services will be integrated into the app by the start of 2019.

site_title: China's tech hub warrants an upgrade from Beijing
summary: China's technology hub, Shenzhen, warrants an upgrade to a "directly administered municipality" to give it greater autonomy and influence in national policymaking groups. This move would boost the city's business clout, allowing it to advocate for local tech giants like Tencent, Huawei, and DJI at the national level. The designation would also align with President Xi Jinping's Greater Bay Area ambition, which aims to link Shenzhen to Hong Kong and other cities. A political step up would help China develop more technology at home, particularly in response to US President Donald Trump's attacks on the sector.

site_title: Singapore businesses welcome EUSFTA
summary: Singapore's business community has welcomed the signing of the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), citing benefits for exporters of electronics, pharmaceuticals, and processed food products. The agreement will improve market access, increase government procurement opportunities, and progressively eliminate tariffs on exports. SMEs, particularly those in the Asean region, are expected to benefit from the agreement, with enhanced market access for Asian food products made in Singapore. The agreements will be sent to the European Parliament for approval and are seen as building blocks towards an eventual EU-Asean FTA.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Bordeaux heading for 'great, classic' vintage after dry summer
summary: Bordeaux is expected to produce a "great, classic" vintage in 2018, following an unusually warm growing season and dry summer. The region's wine-makers attribute the favorable conditions to the region's susceptibility to weather swings. Despite some growers suffering from mildew due to wet spring weather, most were able to handle it and yields were not significantly reduced. The 2018 vintage is expected to be comparable to previous standout vintages, including 2009, 2010, and 2016, with wines to be released in early April and priced between April and June.

images.alt_text: Bordeaux wine-makers are heading for a "great, classic" vintage this year after an unusually warm growing season and exceptionally dry summer and harvest, according to Olivier Bernard, whose family owns Domaine de Chevalier in Pessac-Leognan south of the city.

site_title: SGX gives Vibrant Group more time to complete financial reporting
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted Vibrant Group extensions to publish its financial reports. The company now has until October 31 to announce its unaudited financial statements for the full year ended April 30, 2018, and until November 14 for the first quarter ended July 31, 2018. The extensions are subject to Vibrant convening its annual general meeting by December 31. The company had previously reported issues with its auditors due to additional procedures and accounting record discrepancies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oxley, KSH, SLB, Heeton, SembMarine, ST Engineering, Lion Asiapac, Libra, Raffles Infrastructure
summary: Stocks to watch: Oxley Holdings, KSH Holdings, SLB Development, Heeton Holdings, SembCorp Marine, ST Engineering, Lion Asiapac, Libra, Raffles Infrastructure. Companies announced delays in China development projects and secured new contracts, while others reported earnings and warned of losses due to exchange fluctuations and other factors.

site_title: Who's more optimistic about global trade? Surprisingly, it's emerging markets
summary: Business professionals in emerging markets are more optimistic about global trade than those in developed countries. A Bloomberg survey found 63% of emerging market respondents believe there will be more global trade in five years, compared to 36% in developed markets. Countries such as China, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand have the most optimistic views, with 66-80% of respondents expecting increased global trade. This contrasts with rising protectionist sentiment and US-China tensions, which have led to increased pessimism in developed markets.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma to open institute for tech entrepreneurs in Indonesia
summary: Jack Ma, executive chairman of Alibaba Group Holding, plans to open the Jack Ma Institute of Entrepreneurs in Indonesia, aiming to train 1,000 tech leaders annually over the next 10 years. The institute, which will be based in Indonesia, will provide training opportunities for young tech entrepreneurs. Ma, who is already an adviser to the Indonesian government on e-commerce, made the announcement during his visit to the country. The institute's launch date has not been confirmed, but it is expected to be a significant initiative for Indonesia's tech industry.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma, executive chairman of China's Alibaba Group Holding, said on Saturday he plans to open an institute to train thousands of tech entrepreneurs in Indonesia, where he is already an adviser to the government on e-commerce.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust unit Basslink 'strongly rejects' Hydro Tasmania disputes
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Australian subsidiary Basslink "strongly rejects" allegations by Hydro Tasmania that its facilities did not meet operational requirements, following a second notice of disputes. The disputes relate to the 2015 Basslink Interconnector outage, with all but one dispute based on reports from DNV GL consultants. Basslink maintains its position that the analysis is flawed, citing a lack of testing and theoretical modeling. The last dispute concerns Basslink's Asset Management Plan and Marine Disaster Recovery Plan, which are under review.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust announces clean-up DPS of 1.692 S cents
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) announced a clean-up distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.692 Singapore cents, in line with the merger of ESR-Reit and VIT. The distribution, to be paid on or around Nov 9, 2018, will be made to holders of its stapled securities as of Oct 8. VIT's stapled securities will be delisted on Oct 22.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, down 0.66% in the Nikkei 225 index and 0.72% in the Topix index, amid ongoing geopolitical concerns and ahead of corporate earnings reports. The move follows diplomatic fallout from the death of a Saudi journalist and US President Trump's recent threats.

images.alt_text: Paytm founder and CEO Vijay Shekhar Sharma breaks down while delivering a speech during his company's IPO listing ceremony at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) in Mumbai, India, November 18, 2021. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni##########pic##########

site_title: 'Crocodile hunter' Steve Irwin's family launch new show
summary: The family of late Australian conservationist Steve Irwin, including his wife Terri and children Bindi and Robert, are launching a new television show called "Crikey! It's the Irwins." The show will follow the family as they care for animals at their Australia Zoo in Queensland and embark on wildlife conservation expeditions. The series, which debuts on October 28 on Animal Planet, aims to continue Steve Irwin's conservation work and share his legacy with a new generation. The family will showcase their wildlife hospital work and take viewers on expeditions to various locations around the world.

site_title: May to say Brexit '95 per cent' settled as MP mutiny fears rise
summary: Prime Minister Theresa May will tell parliament that Brexit negotiations are "95% complete" as she faces opposition from within her own party. She will reject the EU's Northern Ireland border proposals, citing concerns over creating a customs border and breaking up the UK's integrity. Despite this, May will say agreements have been reached on issues such as security, transport, and services. The move is seen as an attempt to calm tensions and break an impasse in negotiations, but hardline Brexit MPs are reportedly planning a fresh bid to topple her leadership.

site_title: Bombardier sues Mitsubishi jet programme over trade secrets
summary: Bombardier Inc has filed a lawsuit against Mitsubishi Aircraft Corporation, AeroTEC, and several former employees, alleging they passed on trade secrets related to certification of airplanes in Canada and the US to help Mitsubishi's delayed regional jet project. Bombardier claims the employees sent confidential documents to personal email accounts prior to leaving Bombardier and joining the Mitsubishi project. Mitsubishi denies the claim, saying it believes the lawsuit is "groundless". The lawsuit seeks a preliminary injunction to prevent Mitsubishi from using the alleged stolen information, which Bombardier claims would accelerate the certification process and harm its business.

site_title: Unclaimed burial urns pile up in Japan amid fraying social ties
summary: Unclaimed burial urns are piling up in Japan, with thousands accumulating across the country due to fraying family ties and economic pressures. Many elderly individuals are living on welfare and have no family members to collect their remains, resulting in costly and time-consuming burials. Experts warn that the issue is likely to grow as Japan's population ages, with deaths projected to rise from 1.33 million to 1.67 million by 2040. To address the problem, cities like Yokosuka have started offering low-cost funeral services, aiming to alleviate the burden on families and local governments.

site_title: Former Schlumberger chief to acquire dominant shale pipe servicer Strike
summary: Former Schlumberger chairman Andrew Gould's company, Sentinel Energy Services Inc, is acquiring US pipeline services company Strike LLC for $854 million. The deal will take Strike public, with CEO Steve Pate remaining in the role. The acquisition is valued for its long-term growth potential in pipeline maintenance, with about 60% of Strike's revenue coming from servicing pipelines. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 2.28 points to 1,729.86. Trading volume reached 41.13 million lots worth RM21.88 million, with gainers beating losers 76 to 58.

site_title: Spanish Village goes en bloc again at same price
summary: Spanish Village, a 226-apartment development in District 10, Singapore, is going en bloc again with a guide price of S$882 million, the same price as its earlier attempt in July. The development sits on a 331,457 square foot site and is close to major roads and expressways. Despite recent property curbs, including higher additional buyer's stamp duty and tighter loan-to-value limits, the tender is still expected to close on Nov 20. Other recent en bloc attempts include Laguna Park and Faber Garden, both with reserve prices of over S$1 billion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Australia stares at hung parliament as by-election count goes to the wire
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison faces a hung parliament after a by-election in the Sydney constituency of Wentworth, where his Liberal party candidate trailed an independent rival by 1,600 votes with thousands still to be counted. The contest was seen as a test of Morrison's leadership, with the Liberals' poor showing partly attributed to voters' disillusionment with the party's handling of internal infighting. A general election is due by May next year, and Morrison's conservative coalition may need to rely on support from independent lawmakers to survive.

images.alt_text: The contest had gathered international attention after Mr Morrison's late attempt to garner support from Jewish voters.

site_title: Global growth outlook for 2019 dims for first time: poll
summary: The outlook for global growth in 2019 has dimmed for the first time, according to a Reuters poll of over 500 economists. The US-China trade war and tightening financial conditions are expected to trigger the next downturn, with 18 economies downgraded and only three upgraded. A majority of economists point to a further escalation of US-Sino trade tensions and tightening financial conditions as top triggers for the next global downturn. Global growth forecasts for 2019 were cut to 3.6%, the first time since polling began in 2017.

site_title: Dampener or source of growth?
summary: A sustained surge in oil prices poses significant risks to the global economy, particularly for countries heavily reliant on oil imports, such as India and Turkey. While some industries, like sustainable transport and renewable energy, may benefit from increased investment and adoption, others, like airlines and offshore marine industries, may face increased costs and reduced competitiveness. The oil price shock may also lead to economic recession, inflation, and increased anxiety about geopolitics.

images.alt_text: Mario Singh, CEO, Fullerton Markets.

site_title: Germany won't export arms to Saudi 'in current situation': Merkel
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that the country will not export arms to Saudi Arabia until the current situation is resolved. This comes after the dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi's violent death, which Merkel condemned in the strongest terms. Merkel stated that there is no basis for arms exports to Saudi Arabia at this time, contradicting previous approvals worth €416 million. Merkel will continue to consult with international partners to address the case.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said Sunday that Berlin would not export arms to Saudi Arabia for now in the wake of dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi's violent death.

site_title: Trump accuses Saudis of 'lies' over Khashoggi killing
summary: US President Donald Trump accused Saudi Arabia of lying about the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, calling their explanations "all over the place." Trump expressed confidence in Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's leadership despite shifting accounts from Riyadh. World powers, including Britain and France, demanded answers, while US lawmakers demanded a stronger stance against the Saudi royal family if it were proven to be responsible. Trump emphasized the importance of the US-Saudi relationship, but several Republicans called for a collective Western response if a link to Prince Mohammed is proved.

site_title: Peru judge postpones decision on jailing Keiko Fujimori
summary: A Peruvian judge postponed a decision on jailing opposition leader Keiko Fujimori, who faces 36 months of preventive detention on bribery charges related to millions of dollars in campaign bribes from Odebrecht. The judge adjourned the hearing after defense lawyers claimed the prosecution had failed to hand over requested documents. Fujimori called the decision a conspiracy and said she would not be intimidated. The case is part of a string of anti-corruption prosecutions against top politicians in Peru.

site_title: Beckham admits marriage is 'hard work'
summary: David Beckham, married to Victoria Beckham for nearly 20 years, has admitted that their marriage is "hard work" to maintain. As a UNICEF ambassador and owner of an American soccer team, Beckham attributes their success to being hardworking and setting a good example for their four children. Despite the constant media attention, Beckham has learned to ignore negative comments and prioritize protecting their children. He also expressed admiration for Prince Harry's Invictus Games, which aim to inspire recovery and rehabilitation through sport.

images.alt_text: David Beckham and ex-Spice Girl Victoria have been married for nearly 20 years and the football and fashion icon admits it has been "hard work" to make it a success.

site_title: At least 18 dead after train flips in Taiwan
summary: At least 18 people have died after an express train derailed and flipped over on a popular coastal tourist route in Taiwan, marking the island's worst rail accident in over 25 years. The Puyuma Express train derailed and five carriages flipped onto their side near Xinma station, with 366 people on board. 168 people were injured, and authorities have not confirmed if any passengers remain trapped alive. The cause of the accident is pending investigation, with President Tsai Ing-wen describing it as a "major tragedy."

images.alt_text: Images from the site showed the Puyuma Express train completely derailed and lying zig-zagged across the track in northeastern Yilan county.

site_title: Egypt denies alleged organ theft after British tourist's death
summary: Egypt's state information service denied allegations of organ theft after a British tourist, David Humphries, died suddenly in Hurghada, Egypt, on September 18. A second post-mortem in the UK found that Humphries' heart and other organs had been removed, sparking reports of organ theft. Egyptian authorities said samples were taken to establish the cause of death, citing a heart attack, and that the organs were removed for medical examination, not for sale. The daughter of the deceased also denied any involvement in her father's death.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Dr Wolfgang Baier, group CEO of Luxasia
summary: Luxasia's Group CEO Dr. Wolfgang Baier discusses the impact of e-commerce and digitalization on the company. He shares expansion plans in Australia and New Zealand, highlighting Luxasia's growth strategy amidst the digital shift.

site_title: Signs of turnaround for Brazil's crown jewel Petrobras
summary: Brazil's state-owned oil company Petrobras is experiencing a turnaround after recovering from over-leveraging and a corruption scandal. The company's profits have sharply increased due to rising oil prices, and its share price is rebounding. Petrobras plans to invest $60 billion over the next four years to boost production and infrastructure, with a focus on the pre-salt fields, which are expected to continue to drive growth. The company's debt, which stood at $73 billion in August, is being reduced through divestments and restructuring.

site_title: Hong Kong property billionaire Walter Kwok dies, family says
summary: Hong Kong property billionaire Walter Kwok, 68, died on October 20, 2018, after suffering a heart attack. The cause of death was not disclosed. Kwok was the former chairman of Sun Hung Kai Properties, a real estate developer founded by his father in 1963. He was kidnapped in 1997 and later ousted as chairman in 2008 due to a family dispute. Kwok's sons, Thomas and Raymond, were arrested in 2012 for bribery and misconduct, and Thomas was sentenced to five years in jail.

images.alt_text: Walter Kwok, the former chairman of Hong Kong real-estate developer Sun Hung Kai Properties, died on Saturday morning at the age of 68, according to statements from his family and the property company.

site_title: AI and machine learning spell radical changes for traders, asset management
summary: Artificial intelligence and machine learning are set to revolutionize the asset management industry, enabling traders to generate their own alpha and boosting fund managers' returns. According to Liquidnet CEO Seth Merrin, fund manager performance is the biggest problem in the industry, with massive amounts of money leaving active management for passive management and ETFs. Liquidnet is introducing an analysis tool called Discovery, which uses AI and machine learning to analyze market information and alert traders and fund managers to potential market events. The tool aims to help traders generate their own performance and improve fund managers' returns.

site_title: Older Americans delay - or defy - retirement for healthcare reasons
summary: Older Americans are continuing to work beyond traditional retirement age, with 8.3% of those aged 75 and over in the labor force in 2017, up from 5.3% in 2000. Many are forced to work due to financial insecurity, including those who lost savings during the 2008 financial crisis. Despite this, some older workers are choosing to continue working for health insurance benefits, financial stability, and personal fulfillment. Economists note that this trend is associated with increased life expectancy for those with advanced education, but also highlights the need for a public pension system to support retirees.

site_title: Saudi Arabia smothers online dissent
summary: Saudi Arabia has been using a "troll army" and Twitter insiders to silence critics both inside and outside the country, according to a New York Times investigation. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and his close advisers have mobilized hundreds of young men to harass critics on Twitter, including Jamal Khashoggi, a columnist for The Washington Post who was killed by Saudi agents. The operation, which includes the grooming of a Saudi employee to spy on Twitter users, aims to manipulate social media to spread the kingdom's version of reality and silence dissenting voices.

site_title: Markets expecting relief after Moody's refrains from downgrading Italy to junk
summary: Moody's Investors Service removed Italy's immediate threat of a downgrade to junk, citing concerns over the government's budget and structural reform. Italy's credit rank was cut to Baa3, its lowest investment-grade rating. This decision may lead to a rally in Italian government bonds, stocks, and debt from other European peripheral nations.

site_title: SembMarine secures US$166m contract for work on Teekay Offshore vessel
summary: SembCorp Marine has secured a US$166 million contract to modify, repair, and extend the life of Teekay Offshore's Petrojarl Varg FPSO ship. The project, expected to be completed by July 2020, includes engineering, fabrication, and installation of new equipment. The vessel will be operated by Alpha Petroleum Resources Limited and deployed at the Cheviot field in the North Sea. Sembmarine expects a positive contribution to its earnings from the contract, but notes it will have no material impact on the group's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year ending December 31, 2018.

site_title: Daimler's CEO Zetsche stumbles on his victory lap
summary: Daimler's CEO Dieter Zetsche faces a humbling end to his 12-year tenure after the company's earnings warning sent shares to their lowest since 2013. Investors are shocked by the significantly lower-than-expected earnings, with analysts calling it "disastrous" and a "falling star." Zetsche's turnaround efforts, which included a push into electric vehicles, have been overshadowed by the company's struggles with diesel emissions and the trade war with China. His departure next year will be marked by a significant share price decline, casting doubt on his legacy.

site_title: Singapore bucks global trend; draws more investments in H1
summary: Singapore defied the global trend of decreased foreign direct investments, recording $35 billion in foreign direct investments in the first half of 2018, a 18% increase from the same period in 2017. This drove FDIs in South-east Asia to $73 billion, up from $62 billion in 2017. The increase was attributed to multinational corporations investing in factories and offices in Singapore.

site_title: UBS warns staff over China travel after banker held in Beijing: source
summary: UBS has warned staff to reconsider travel plans to China after a banker was asked to delay her departure from Beijing to meet with local officials. The banker, based in Singapore, still has her passport but is being asked to remain in China. The bank has asked China wealth management staff to review their travel plans carefully, but other units remain unaffected. This comes as UBS is building up its presence in China, with plans to take majority ownership of its China joint venture under new rules. The meeting's purpose is unclear, adding to the uncertainty.

site_title: Banning foreign buyers seen not solving NZ's home shortage
summary: New Zealand has banned foreign buyers of existing homes, except for newly built apartments, in an attempt to address the country's housing shortage. The ban, effective Monday, aims to reduce prices and make homes more affordable for locals. However, critics argue that it won't solve the issue, citing a shortage of around 100,000 homes. The government has instead recommended increasing supply, speeding up the consenting process, and easing restrictions on first-time buyers as more effective measures. Foreign buyers, mostly from China, have been rushing to purchase properties before the ban takes effect.

site_title: Earnings season kicks off; close to 40 director acquisitions filed
summary: Earnings season has kicked off with almost 40 director acquisitions filed in Singapore, indicating increased investor confidence. The Straits Times Index declined 6.7% for the year, while regional benchmarks showed mixed moves. Share buybacks totaled $8.4 million, with 19 stocks participating. Director and substantial shareholder transactions included notable acquisitions by Allied Technologies, Oxley Holdings, and PropNex, with stakes ranging from 4.52% to 63.71%. These transactions suggest a shift in investor sentiment and increased focus on company performance.

site_title: Paradox of the twin-deficit US dollar
summary: The US dollar holds a unique position as the dominant reserve currency, despite having a current-account deficit and fiscal deficit. This "exorbitant privilege" allows it to accumulate global savings and is a result of its status as a reserve and settlement currency. However, this privilege is under threat as foreign central banks diversify their foreign reserves and consider alternative currencies like the renminbi. Triggers for the US dollar's potential dethronement could include increased trade protectionism, a devaluation, or an influx of loans denominated in the renminbi.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report shows that Middle East Gulf VLCC rates remained unchanged at WS 86 for Thailand and around WS 83.5/84 for China for 270,000mt. In unrelated news, Tesla launched in India, plans robotaxi expansion in California and Arizona, and FedEx partnered with QuikBot for robot deliveries. Additionally, Delta Air Lines offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, and Japan's carmakers reduced export prices to the US to offset tariff impacts.

site_title: 'Mixed bag' Q3 earnings expected on forex, trade concerns
summary: Singapore's Q3 corporate earnings are expected to be a "mixed bag" due to ongoing foreign exchange volatility and slowing global trade. Tech and telco stocks are likely to underperform, while consumer staples and defensive sectors such as real estate investment trusts (Reits) are expected to do better. Analysts predict a slowdown in corporate earnings momentum, with some sectors, such as coal producers, potentially surprising on the upside. The Singapore dollar's appreciation is also expected to impact the telco sector, while a strengthening dollar is expected to benefit companies with operating costs in the local currency.

site_title: UOB digitalises application process for all its consumer products
summary: UOB has digitalised its application process for all consumer banking products, allowing customers to open accounts and apply for loans, credit cards, and other services online in just 15 minutes. The bank uses the government's MyInfo digital identity service, reducing the need for physical documents and lengthy forms. This move is expected to save over 1,000 man-hours each month and increase online application rates to half of all consumer banking product applications within the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: AVIC International Maritime's controlling shareholder in talks for possible disposal
summary: AVIC International Maritime Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, announced that its controlling shareholder, AVIC International Holdings, is in preliminary discussions with potential investors for a possible disposal of its ship business. The potential transaction, if consummated, would include the disposal of AIHL's entire 73.78% stake in AVIC International Maritime. The discussions are ongoing, with no definitive agreements reached, and no certainty of a transaction occurring. The company advises shareholders to exercise extreme caution when dealing or trading in its shares.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: In Singapore, it's not margin calls brokerages worry about
summary: Singapore's brokerage industry does not foresee a significant increase in forced selling or contra losses due to the dwindling number of high rollers and increased caution among retail investors. Retail participation in the market has hit multi-year lows, with industry players attributing this to the decline of traditional speculative contra trading and the rise of passive investing through exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and financial advisers. The market's lack of retail interest is also evident in the quiet dealing rooms and decreased phone calls from clients, with some brokers reporting no trades for two to three days.

images.alt_text: In fact, margin calls are the furthest concern for stockbroking firms here today, as retail participation in the Singapore market stays muted, whether share prices are falling, rising, or going nowhere at all.

site_title: Mnuchin open to change in test to identify forex manipulators
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is open to changing the test used to identify foreign exchange-rate manipulators, potentially allowing President Trump to officially label China a manipulator. Mnuchin considers using a 1988 trade act with a broader definition of currency manipulation or changing the criteria for determining currency manipulation. This move could give Trump leverage to redefine trade terms with China, following his promise to do so as a candidate.

site_title: For BNP Paribas and women's tennis, it's a perfect match
summary: BNP Paribas, a French multinational bank, has announced its commitment to Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region through its sponsorship of the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals. The bank's new Singapore CEO, Joris Dierckx, said the sponsorship sends a clear signal of the bank's commitment to the region's growth. BNP Paribas has been the title sponsor of the WTA Finals in Singapore since 2014 and has also partnered with the bank to promote sustainable development and equality through the Sustainable Future Forum. The bank's Asia-Pacific revenues have grown to over $4.76 billion annually, and it employs around 2,200 staff in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Hong Kong property mogul Walter Kwok dies at age 68
summary: Walter Kwok, 68, a former chairman of Hong Kong real-estate developer Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd, has died peacefully at home on October 20, 2018, after suffering a heart attack in August. He was the oldest of three sons who inherited the fortune of their father, a grocery wholesaler. Kwok's family squabble led to his ouster as chairman in 2008, but he later settled his dispute amicably. He was also involved in a bribery case, with his brother Thomas sentenced to five years in jail in 2014.

site_title: FX options flag uncertainty before US midterm election
summary: US currency options are signaling increased uncertainty ahead of the midterm elections, with investors bracing for possible US dollar weakness. In contrast, bond market investors see the election as having limited impact on interest rates. Hedging activity has increased in the yen, Australian and New Zealand dollars, with implied volatility rising and one-month risk reversals showing bearish bets for a drop in the dollar against these currencies. A divided US Congress could lead to government gridlock, sparking market concerns.

site_title: New Delhi half-marathon tries radio waves to beat city's toxic smog
summary: The New Delhi half-marathon used ultra-high frequency (UHF) radio waves to clear the air for runners, an experimental technique aimed at improving the city's notorious air quality. Last year's race was cancelled due to toxic smog, and this year's event saw a 30% reduction in pollution, according to organizers. The technique, developed by a Bangalore-based company, was used to dispel particulate matter measuring 2.5 microns, which can lodge deep in the lungs. The event was deemed a success, with clear skies and no pollution-related incidents among the 35,000 runners.

site_title: Trump says 'full efforts' under way to stop migrant caravan
summary: President Donald Trump announced on Sunday that "full efforts" are being made to stop thousands of Honduran migrants from reaching the US-Mexico border. Trump tweeted that migrants must apply for asylum in Mexico first and that the US will turn them away if they fail to do so. He warned that if authorities do not stop the migrants, he will cut aid to the region, deploy the military, and close the border. Mexico has vowed to detain migrants without visas and process their asylum requests with the UN's help.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said on Sunday that "full efforts" were under way to halt the progress of thousands of Honduran migrants toward the United States.

site_title: US seeks to phase in shipping rules, sending refiners' shares sharply lower
summary: The US is seeking to phase in shipping rules aimed at reducing sulfur emissions, sending refiners' shares plummeting. The rules, set to take effect in 2020, would cut sulfur content by over 80%, increasing fuel costs and potentially passing them on to consumers. US refiners have invested billions to meet the new standards, but the administration's attempt to delay the implementation could undermine these efforts, risking alienation from an industry that supported Trump and stands to gain from the increased demand for cleaner-burning diesel fuel.

site_title: Bloomberg relay back for 6th year running
summary: The Bloomberg Square Mile Relay will take place on October 25 in Singapore, featuring over 150 teams from companies based in the city-state. The 1.6 km course around Marina Bay is the sixth consecutive year the event will be held. The relay aims to promote physical activity and team bonding among participants, while also encouraging a healthier lifestyle.

images.alt_text: Bloomberg's head of Asean, Maggie Ng, (centre with grey exercise pants) in action at last year's Square Mile Relay in Shanghai.

site_title: Theresa May in Brexit foxhole
summary: Theresa May's Brexit negotiations are stalled due to divisions within the UK government. The Brexit hedgehogs, who prioritize sovereignty and control, are blocking a deal, while the foxes, who are more willing to accept trade-offs, are doing the negotiating. The main reason for the impasse is the hedgehogs' insistence on a hard Brexit, which would leave the UK without full control of its laws and borders. The UK's constitutional integrity is also a concern, particularly for the DUP, which opposes the Irish backstop guarantee. The Prime Minister's efforts to woo Labour MPs and voters have been unsuccessful, and the clock is running out for a Brexit withdrawal agreement.

site_title: US earnings season kicks in; investors cautious on Asia
summary: US earnings season begins, with over 200 companies releasing results, focusing on tech, vehicle, and oil majors. Investors remain cautious on Asia due to volatile trading, with the European Union and Italy's budget dispute. Key data releases include Singapore's inflation numbers, South Korea's Q3 GDP, and China's September industrial profit figures. Analysts expect Singapore's inflation to rise, while South Korea's GDP is forecast to grow 2.7% y-o-y. The European Central Bank is expected to keep policy unchanged, but may discuss the Italian government budget.

site_title: Volatility to persist this week through earnings reports
summary: US stocks finished flat last week, despite significant daily swings, as volatility is expected to persist through earnings reports and the midterm elections. Strategists warn of problems in the eurozone and Saudi Arabia, which could exacerbate economic tensions. The trade war with China has intensified, with analysts recommending avoiding consumer-discretionary and industrial stocks. The semiconductor industry is another front in the economic war, with Chinese company Huawei battling a US inventor. Domestic-focused companies have fared better, but small-cap indices are deep into correction territory. The housing market has also experienced wobbles, with rising interest rates and elevated prices causing a levelling-off in many US housing markets.

site_title: Trump considering a 'major tax cut' for middle-income earners
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering a "major tax cut" for middle-income earners, potentially to be announced before the mid-term elections on November 6. The proposal, which would follow last year's landmark tax overhaul, aims to benefit middle-income people, not businesses. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the plan would need to balance financial issues with providing tax cuts to middle-income earners. A second round of tax cuts could face resistance from Republicans concerned about increasing the deficit, which has reached a six-year high.

site_title: Providing digital skills for the underprivileged
summary: Microsoft Singapore is providing digital skills to underserved communities, aiming to bridge the digital divide. Through partnerships with charities and coding academies, over 2,200 beneficiaries have received IT skills since 2006. The Microsoft-SPD Coding Quest programme, launched in June, helped participants set up online stores and secured employment and entrepreneurship opportunities. The initiative has shown encouraging results, including Joshua Tseng, a visually impaired student, being employed as a research and development intern, and Heather Wong, a wheelchair-bound student, building an online business.

images.alt_text: Microsoft-SPD Coding Quest mentor guiding a participant through basic HTML, Javascript and CSS coding at a training camp.

site_title: Space crew survives plunge to Earth after Russian rocket fails
summary: A Russian Soyuz rocket carrying two astronauts, US astronaut Nick Hague and cosmonaut Alexei Ovchinin, failed two minutes after liftoff from Kazakhstan, leading to a dramatic emergency landing. The crew safely parachuted down 31 miles to the surface, with no injuries reported. Rescue crews quickly reached them, and the astronauts were transported back to the Baikonur site for medical tests. The incident, the first serious launch problem in a manned Soyuz mission since 1983, has led to an investigation and the temporary suspension of all manned space launches.

site_title: BMW to buy control of China venture in 'new era' for foreign carmakers
summary: BMW will acquire a 75% stake in its Chinese joint venture, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd, for 3.6 billion euros, marking a significant shift in foreign carmakers' control in China as Beijing relaxes ownership rules. The deal is expected to spur BMW to shift more production to China, helping protect profits amid the trade war. The move is seen as a milestone for foreign carmakers, potentially encouraging rivals like Mercedes maker Daimler to follow suit.

images.alt_text: Germany's BMW will pay 3.6 billion euros (S$5.7 billion) to take control of its main joint venture in China, the first such move by a global carmaker as Beijing starts to relax ownership rules for the world's biggest auto market.

site_title: Rex to further develop Norway, Oman discoveries for 'greater rewards'
summary: Rex International, a CATALIST-listed oil and gas company, plans to develop its two discoveries, Rolvsnes off Norway and GA South off Oman, despite potential divestment of some working interests. The company aims to tap debt financing for its share of development costs, targeting a breakeven price of around US$30 per barrel. Rex expects to bring GA South onstream in the second half of 2019 and first oil from Rolvsnes in 2020, with a projected production of 7,000 and 3,500 barrels per day respectively.

images.alt_text: Mr Lidgren says the focus is now on raising the required funding for developing the resources found off Oman and Norway. He indicates that Rex is looking to lease and deploy a production jack-up for the field development in Block 50 in Oman.

site_title: Newsweek's former owner is charged in US$10m fraud
summary: Manhattan prosecutors have charged the former owner of Newsweek, Etienne Uzac, and William Anderson, former CEO of Christian Media, with a $10 million fraud and money-laundering conspiracy. The two companies allegedly misrepresented Newsweek's financial health and created fake financial statements to dupe lenders into investing millions. The indictment also names Oikos Networks, a computer company, for providing lower-quality computers. Top Newsweek editors and reporters were fired after investigating the companies' financial dealings, which also raised questions about connections to Olivet University.

site_title: Opec says oil market well supplied, wary of 2019 surplus
summary: Opec's Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo stated that the oil market is well supplied, with producers wary of creating a surplus next year. This comes despite oil prices reaching a 5-year high of $86.74 due to US sanctions on Iran. Barkindo cited non-fundamental factors influencing the market, beyond oil producers' control. Opec has no immediate plans to expand output, despite the rising prices.

images.alt_text: Opec sees the oil market as well supplied and is wary of creating a glut next year, the group's secretary-general said on Thursday, suggesting producers are in no rush to expand a June agreement that raises output.

site_title: China's Sept new home price gains slow on monthly basis
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.9% in September from a month earlier, a slower pace than August's 1.4% gain. Despite a slowing economy and tighter curbs, prices increased 7.9% from a year ago, the fastest year-on-year gain since August 2017. Solid growth in the sector could cushion the impact of a government crackdown, but also raises concerns of a bubble if prices climb aggressively.

site_title: Japan's FamilyMart to unload Uny, take US$1.9b stake in Don Quijote
summary: Japan's FamilyMart Uny Holdings Co is selling its entire stake in struggling general-merchandising unit Uny to discount retailer Don Quijote Holdings Co for US$1.9 billion. FamilyMart will take a 20% stake in Don Quijote in the deal. Don Quijote will also pay US$346 million for the remaining 60% stake in Uny, following a tender offer. The move allows FamilyMart to focus on its convenience stores, while Don Quijote gains scale and funding.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group in the pink of health
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has transformed from a struggling entity in 2013 to a profitable company with a market capitalization of over S$200 million. Under the leadership of CEO Dr. Beng Teck Liang, the group has successfully rebuilt its business through strategic investments and acquisitions, expanding into four markets, including obstetrics and gynaecology, pediatrics, oncology, and aesthetics. SMG aims to capitalize on Southeast Asia's growing middle class and has established a regional presence in Indonesia and Vietnam, with plans to expand into these markets further.

site_title: Toyota, SoftBank in first-ever alliance, target self-driving car services
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and SoftBank Group Corp have formed a joint venture, MONET, to develop self-driving car services. The partnership aims to create a platform for autonomous vehicles that can provide various services, such as mobile shops and hospitals. Toyota will initially focus on Japan and expand globally, with SoftBank owning 51% of the business. The joint venture is expected to roll out an autonomous driving service by the second half of the 2020s, using Toyota's "e-Palette" concept.

site_title: US aids recovery of 1639 Dutch painting taken by Hitler
summary: US prosecutors are helping the heirs of a Jewish art collector recover a 1639 Dutch painting taken by the Nazis during World War II. The painting, "A Scholar Sharpening His Quill" by Salomon Koninck, was seized from Adolphe Schloss's collection in Paris and ended up in Adolf Hitler's personal collection. After being sold at auction in 2017, the painting was seized by the FBI, and prosecutors are seeking a court ruling to return it to Schloss's heirs. The heirs have spent decades trying to recover the looted work.

site_title: The world can't get enough chocolate
summary: The global demand for chocolate has surged, with cocoa grindings rising 2.7% in Europe, 3.7% in Asia, and 2.5% in North America in the third quarter. The global chocolate confectionery market expanded 2.5% in the nine months through April, reversing a 2.2% drop the previous year. High demand for cocoa butter and cheap cocoa prices have driven processing profitability to its highest in over a decade, with benchmark cocoa futures rising 1.7% in London. Demand remains strong despite speculators betting on falling prices due to a large crop.

site_title: China should prepare 'more powerful' steps to support economy: state media
summary: China is preparing for more powerful policy measures, possibly including a large-scale stimulus package, to support its economy amid persistent trade frictions with the US. The People's Bank of China has already cut banks' reserve requirement ratios four times this year to ease credit conditions. Economists predict further RRR cuts, but China is concerned about introducing excessive leverage. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to take action.

site_title: Lion Asiapac warns of Q1 loss
summary: Lion Asiapac, a diversified investment holding company, has warned of a potential loss for the first quarter ended September 30, primarily due to an unrealized exchange loss from the depreciating Chinese yuan. The company's shares closed down 2% at S$0.49 on Friday, and further details will be released on October 31.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Sierra Leone axes plan to build Chinese-funded airport
summary: Sierra Leone's government has terminated a $400 million plan to build a new airport with Chinese funding, citing concerns over the additional burden on the country's external debt. The decision, made in June, was formalized in a letter to the project's manager, citing criticism from international financial institutions. The airport project, which had been criticized for its high cost and potential debt implications, was one of several Chinese infrastructure projects in Africa. The government's move is seen as a response to mounting concerns over Sierra Leone's debt burden.

site_title: German growth limited by trade disputes and labour shortages
summary: German economy growth is expected to slow due to trade disputes and labor shortages. The economy is projected to expand by 1.8% in 2018 and 2019, down from earlier forecasts. Rising imports and a large current account surplus will hold back growth, while protectionist tendencies and US trade disputes cloud the outlook. Labor shortages, particularly in skilled workers, are also a concern, with a planned immigration law aimed at addressing the issue. The government is urging swift implementation of a US-EU tariffs deal and reforming the World Trade Organization to safeguard the free trade order.

site_title: Saudi Arabia admits Khashoggi died in consulate, fires two senior officials
summary: Saudi Arabia has admitted that journalist Jamal Khashoggi died in the consulate, and two senior officials have been fired. A fight broke out between Khashoggi and people who met him, leading to his death. The investigation is ongoing, with 18 Saudi nationals arrested. The move comes after international outcry and strained relations between Saudi Arabia and the West. US President Donald Trump has said he may consider sanctions against Saudi Arabia, but has also emphasized the importance of the US-Saudi relationship.

site_title: Tennis: Wozniacki seeks repeat at wide-open WTA Finals in Singapore
summary: Caroline Wozniacki seeks to repeat as WTA Finals champion in Singapore, facing a wide-open field after a year of multiple Grand Slam winners. Serena Williams, recovering from childbirth, and Simona Halep, dealing with a back injury, will not participate. Wozniacki, who won the title last year, is confident and has momentum after recent victories, including a China Open title. The eight women will be divided into two pools, with play starting on Sunday, and the semi-finals and final taking place next weekend.

site_title: Top brewers raided by Indian watchdog in price-fixing probe: sources
summary: India's antitrust watchdog raided the offices of three top beer companies, including United Breweries, Carlsberg, and Anheuser-Busch InBev, as part of an investigation into price-fixing allegations. The raids, conducted by the Competition Commission of India, found evidence of price manipulation, including email exchanges. The investigation, which began last year, is ongoing, and executives at the brewers' Indian operations are being questioned. The regulator has the power to impose fines up to three times the profit made or 10% of annual revenue, whichever is higher.

site_title: India's richest brothers and how they grew US$41b apart
summary: India's richest brothers, Mukesh and Anil Ambani, have seen their fortunes diverge by about $40 billion over the past year. Mukesh, 61, has become Asia's richest man after his petrochemicals conglomerate Reliance Industries Ltd expanded its telecommunications business, driven by its 4G wireless network, Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd. Anil, two years younger, has faced legal and liquidity challenges, cutting his personal fortune by almost half to $1.5 billion. The brothers' diverging fortunes began 16 years ago when their rags-to-riches father, Dhirubhai Ambani, died without a will. Mukesh controls the flagship oil refining and petrochemicals business, while Anil controls the newer businesses, including power generation and financial services.

site_title: Marie Antoinette's jewels go on show before auction
summary: Marie Antoinette's 10 jewels, including the $1-2 million Pearl and diamond pendant, are on display in London before auctioning off at Sotheby's in Geneva on November 14. The collection, held by the House of Bourbon-Parma, features jewels belonging to Marie Antoinette, Charles X, and empress Marie Therese of Austria. The sale is expected to fetch $200,000-300,000 for the natural pearl and diamond necklace. Sotheby's senior director Andres White Correal describes Marie Antoinette as "the allure" and a symbol of the "sophistication of l'ancien regime."

site_title: Google to charge Android partners up to US$40 per device for apps: source
summary: Google will charge Android device manufacturers up to $40 per device for access to its apps, replacing a previous system deemed anti-competitive by the European Union. The fee, which can range from $2.50 to $40, applies to new smartphones and tablets launched in the European Economic Area and running Android. Device manufacturers can offset the charge by bundling Google's search and Chrome browser, allowing them to retain control over app choices for consumers. The move aims to give Google's rivals, such as Microsoft, more room to partner with hardware makers.

site_title: Trump administration wants phase-in of UN rules on maritime fuel
summary: The Trump administration is seeking a phase-in of UN rules on maritime fuel pollution limits, set to take effect in 2020, to mitigate potential price spikes in heating and trucking fuels. The rules limit ship fuels to 0.5% sulfur, compared to 3.5% now, unless equipped with scrubbers. A phase-in would delay full compliance until a later date, with the administration citing concerns about consumer impact. Analysts disagree on the feasibility of a phased implementation, with some arguing it's unnecessary given existing preparations by refineries and shippers.

site_title: Bells, bids and traffic jam as world's largest fish market reopens in Tokyo
summary: The world's largest fish market, the Toyosu market in Tokyo, reopened after a long delay, with its first tuna auction taking place on Thursday. The new facility, costing $5 billion, has been relocated to reclaimed land and is expected to become the core market of Tokyo and Japan. However, some traders, including a 45-year-old seller, expressed concerns about the location, citing a potential decline in customer base. The market's relocation was met with resistance from over 80% of Tsukiji fish traders, who oppose the move.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde warns trade, currency wars could be detrimental for growth
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned that trade and currency wars could be detrimental to global growth, hurting "innocent bystanders." She urged countries to de-escalate trade frictions and fix global trading rules. The US-China trade war has rattled financial markets, with investors worrying about global trade and investment. China's yuan has declined 8% against a basket of currencies, mainly driven by the dollar's strength. Lagarde encouraged China to continue moving toward a flexible currency system, supported by the IMF.

site_title: US: S&P falls on interest rate, trade concerns; P&G lifts Dow
summary: The US benchmark S&P 500 index fell on Friday due to concerns over rising interest rates and trade tensions, despite strong earnings from Procter & Gamble Co. The consumer staples sector led gains, but defensive sectors also rose as investors looked for caution. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose, while the Nasdaq Composite fell. Home sales declined in September, and investors are looking for stronger revenue growth to boost confidence.

site_title: Europe: Shares eke out weekly gains after choppy session
summary: European stocks ended a choppy session flat but managed a 0.7% weekly gain, despite mixed third-quarter earnings and a budget row between Italy's populist government and the EU. Italian bank stocks plummeted, while Chinese growth concerns weighed on tyre maker Michelin and French conglomerate Bouygues. The construction and materials sector fell 1.7% due to emerging market concerns and rising raw materials costs. Analysts downgraded European earnings forecasts, but some see 2019 growth estimates still too high.

site_title: MAS tightens policy again, cautions about trade risks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) tightened monetary policy for the second time this year, citing a 'relatively resilient' global growth and cautioning about trade risks. The MAS increased the slope of the Singapore dollar's policy band, keeping the width and mid-point unchanged. It expects the Singapore economy to expand steadily, with GDP growth forecast to come within the 2.5-3.5 per cent range in 2018 and moderate slightly in 2019, with core inflation expected to average 1.5-2.5 per cent. The MAS warned of potential risks from trade frictions between the US and China.

site_title: At least 59 killed as train hits crowd in northern India
summary: At least 59 people were killed when a high-speed train ran through a crowd gathered to watch a Dussehra festival celebration in northern India, making it the country's worst rail disaster this year. The accident occurred when the train, traveling at a high speed, plowed into the crowd, who were craning their necks and applauding a nearby effigy burning. Emergency officials are still trying to determine the extent of the disaster, and the death toll is expected to rise.

site_title: Fed's Kaplan sees 2-3 more rate hikes to hit 'neutral' level
summary: Dallas Federal Reserve President Robert Kaplan expects two to three additional interest rate hikes to reach a "neutral" level, where borrowing costs neither stimulate nor restrict economic growth. The neutral level is expected to be achieved by June 2019, putting US borrowing costs around 3%. Kaplan attributes the economy's growth to tax cuts and a strong consumer sector, which accounts for 70% of economic activity. Despite this, he does not expect a US recession anytime soon. The Fed's dual mandate is being met, with low unemployment and inflation near the 2% goal.

site_title: Swiss Re said to discuss investment in insurer Anbang with China
summary: Swiss Re has discussed an investment in embattled Chinese insurer Anbang Insurance Group Co with Chinese authorities. Swiss Re, along with Singapore's Temasek Holdings, is considered a potential investor to shore up Anbang, which has been seeking fresh funds since China temporarily seized the insurer earlier this year. Anbang's chairman was sentenced to prison for masterminding a multi-billion dollar fraud. The Chinese government aims to replace an industry security fund that injected billions of yuan into Anbang.

images.alt_text: Swiss Re AG has held discussions with Chinese authorities about an investment in embattled insurer Anbang Insurance Group Co, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: New stores and online growth help Ikea fend off rivals
summary: Ikea reported a 5% rise in annual sales, driven by strong online growth and new stores in India and other countries. The company opened 19 new outlets, taking the total to 422, and online sales jumped 31%. Ikea is investing in e-commerce, city-centre showrooms, and home delivery services to cope with mounting competition from online rivals like Amazon. The company aims to shift its business model, moving away from traditional self-serve stores and towards more service-oriented offerings.

images.alt_text: Ikea reported a 5 per cent rise in annual sales on Wednesday as strong online growth and new stores in India and several other countries helped the world's biggest furniture retailer cope with mounting competition.

site_title: Australia government braces for defeat in crucial by-election
summary: Australia's conservative coalition is bracing for defeat in a crucial by-election in the Sydney seat of Wentworth, which could leave Prime Minister Scott Morrison with a minority government. The by-election was triggered after former PM Malcolm Turnbull was ousted in August, and polls suggest the Liberal Party's Dave Sharma may lose to independent candidate Kerryn Phelps. A defeat would be embarrassing for Morrison, who has been under fire for infighting and leadership changes. If lost, it would effectively make Morrison a "lame duck" prime minister, ending his slim parliamentary majority.

site_title: Vietnam seeks to reduce reliance on Asian rice markets, raise exports to Africa, Americas
summary: Vietnam aims to reduce its reliance on Asian rice markets, targeting 50% of exports to be shipped to non-Asian markets by 2030. The country seeks to boost exports to Africa (25%) and the Americas (10%), focusing on high-quality and organic rice products. Vietnam, the world's third-largest rice exporter, aims to increase exports value by 26.9% in 2018, driven by a rise in rice exports revenue to $2.46 billion, up 21.3% from the previous year.

site_title: CDL to launch Whistler Grand in the west at average S$1,380 psf
summary: CDL's Whistler Grand condo, located at West Coast Vale, will launch at an average S$1,380 per square foot (psf) with prices starting from S$608,000 for one-bedders. The 716-unit development, comprising two 36-storey towers, is expected to complete in October 2021 and features over 60 recreational facilities. The location is near the Jurong Lake District and four MRT stations. CDL's head of property development expects good take-up due to its affordability and location.

site_title: 'You can run but you can't hide,' CEO says to Goldman analyst
summary: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc CEO Lourenco Goncalves publicly criticized Goldman Sachs analyst Matthew Korn after his company's shares fell 10% on Friday, with Goncalves saying "You can run, but you can't hide" to Korn. Goncalves accused Korn of misunderstanding the company's financials and vowed to "buy the stock back with two hands" to inflict maximum pain on critics. The CEO also threatened to attend the Goldman Sachs conference and bring a commodity expert to counter Korn's views, despite Cleveland-Cliffs' shares climbing 53% this year.

site_title: In the car business, the real investing comes after the selling
summary: Eurokars Group has invested S$70 million in its new aftersales building in Singapore, which spans 438,000 square feet. The facility, set to open on October 26, will cater to cars from five brands, including Porsche and Mini, and is designed to handle growing demand. The investment underscores the capital-intensive nature of the car business in Singapore, where companies like Eurokars, Inchcape, and Wearnes Automotive are expanding their facilities to meet increasing customer needs. The trend suggests that mega servicing facilities may become common, putting pressure on small, single-brand retailers to match the service levels of larger corporations.

site_title: Oil up but posts weekly loss on stock build, trade tensions
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday due to signs of surging demand in China, but were headed for a second weekly decline due to swelling US inventories and trade tensions. Brent crude futures rose 49 US cents to settle at $79.78 a barrel, while WTI crude futures rose 47 US cents to settle at $69.12 a barrel. Despite a record refinery throughput in China, US crude inventories climbed 6.5 million barrels, leading to a widening discount between WTI and Brent.

site_title: China's one-time richest woman becomes biggest loser in wealth rout
summary: Zhou Qunfei, China's once richest woman, has lost 66% of her fortune, or $6.6 billion, due to the US-China trade war. Her company, Lens Technology Co, has seen its shares slump 62% this year. This is the biggest drop in percentage terms among Chinese billionaires in 2018, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. The trade war has also affected other Chinese billionaires, with a combined loss of $86 billion. Chinese stocks have been particularly hard hit, responding more sluggishly to positive trade war news than US equities.

site_title: Italy cut to one step above junk by Moody's in wake of bond rout
