summary: Italy's credit rating was cut by Moody's to Baa3, one level above junk, due to concerns over the country's fiscal strength and stalled structural reform plans. The rating change follows a sell-off in local debt amid tensions over the country's budget and a debt-exchange operation. Italian bonds plunged, with the yield premium over German bonds reaching levels not seen since 2013.

site_title: Silicon Valley's dance with despots
summary: Tech giants, including Google and Uber, have faced backlash for their business ties with authoritarian regimes, particularly Saudi Arabia. The disappearance and alleged murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi has led to widespread criticism, with many pulling out of conferences and investments. Employees of these companies, including Google and Uber, are increasingly speaking out against their companies' dealings with despots, citing concerns over human rights and censorship. This shift in moral clarity has led some to question the ethics of tech companies' business practices, sparking a reevaluation of their role in the world.

site_title: Singapore, European Union sign landmark free trade, partnership agreements
summary: Singapore and the European Union have signed a landmark free trade agreement, known as the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA), aimed at promoting open trade and benefiting their people. The agreement, signed by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and European leaders, will simplify customs procedures, allow Singapore companies to bid for European government jobs, and exempt certain products from customs duties. The deal is seen as a symbol of the EU's commitment to free trade and a pathfinder for a wider FTA with Asean, with European leaders hailing it as a signal of their commitment to open trade.

site_title: US: Wall St gains at open on strong results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by strong results from major companies such as P&G and Honeywell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 41.64 points, or 0.16%, to 25,421.09, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Reits
summary: Realtors and investors are bracing for a potential slowdown in the Singapore property market with the upcoming Q3 condo launches. Condo prices above S$3,000 per square foot (psf) may face increased competition, posing a challenge to developers. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have jumped after five consecutive weeks of decline, while Manhattan rents have reached a record high. In other markets, UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, and WeWork has secured new tenants at its Singapore office. These trends signal a shift in the global real estate landscape.

site_title: PayPal gains after analysts say Venmo was earnings highlight
summary: PayPal Holdings surged 8% pre-market after beating Q3 estimates, boosting its 2018 forecast and providing 2019 guidance in line with targets. Analysts praised the company's progress in monetizing Venmo, with 24% of users participating in a "monetizable action" compared to 17% last quarter. The strong earnings report and guidance for 2019 have lifted investor sentiment, with many analysts expecting stable and compounding earnings growth driven by PayPal's online acceptance lead and operating leverage.

site_title: China Q3 GDP points to slower growth as trade war with US bites
summary: China's economy grew at its slowest quarterly pace since 2009 in the third quarter, expanding by 6.5% against 6.7% in the previous quarter, missing analysts' estimates. The trade war with the US and domestic restructuring are taking a toll on the world's second-largest economy. Growth slowed to 1.6% on a quarterly basis, and the yuan is under pressure, falling to its lowest point in 21 months. Analysts expect further easing of monetary and fiscal policy to stabilize growth, with some predicting a further slowdown to 1.4% in Q4.

site_title: Productivity hacks to help you go deep
summary: A book by Cal Newport, "Deep Work," suggests that individuals can boost productivity by setting aside time for "deep work" - tasks requiring high cognitive skills - and eliminating "shallow work" - low-value tasks that can be done while distracted. To achieve this, people can schedule specific times for deep thinking, minimize distractions like emails, and use productivity hacks such as delayed email sending and reading tools like Instapaper. By doing so, individuals can improve their mental state and accomplish important tasks more effectively.

site_title: It's a long way down for China stocks as slump burns investors
summary: China stocks have plummeted, wiping out over $3 trillion in value since January, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 28% from its year-high. The economic outlook is slowing due to a trade war with the US, and a weakening yuan is prompting capital outflows. Despite efforts by regulators to support the market, selling pressure continues, with over 60% of shares having a relative strength of less than 30.

site_title: Volunteer now to make a difference
summary: A Singaporean Rotarian reflects on the evolution of volunteerism in the city-state, from joining an organized movement like Rotary to contributing on a personal scale. With the rise of social media, individuals can now make a difference through smaller, more targeted efforts. Despite the disruption of volunteer-driven organizations, they remain relevant as vehicles for people to come together and give back to society, addressing pressing needs such as poverty, medical costs, and natural disasters. The author encourages readers to start volunteering, citing the potential for even small actions to make a difference.

site_title: World must help de-escalate mounting US-China trade conflict: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat urged the world to de-escalate the US-China trade conflict, warning that tensions could escalate into a more difficult issue. China has shown restraint, but trade tensions are already affecting the global economy, with the IMF cutting forecasts for global growth. Heng recommended studying WTO rule changes and speeding up regional free trade initiatives, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, to promote liberalization and mitigate the impact of the dispute.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corporation reported Q3 2018 core net profit below expectations, with the property business showing weakness. Earnings recovery is distant due to a slowdown in the key property business and O&M business struggles. In contrast, Soilbuild Business Space Reit is upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$0.65, driven by industrial rent bottoms and positive contributions from Australia. The reit's DPU outlook is expected to improve, offering attractive yields.

site_title: Advanced Holdings to pay S$15m for smaller stake in Agricore
summary: Advanced Holdings has agreed to pay S$15 million for a 12.25% minority stake in palm oil cultivator Agricore Global Pte Ltd, down from a 100% acquisition. The deal is part of a restructured acquisition, allowing the company to diversify into a new business area with growth potential. Advanced intends to fund the acquisition with bank borrowings and internal cash resources, exploring long-term collaboration and potential synergies with Agricore. The revised acquisition amount will be paid in two tranches, with the first S$7.5 million upon completion.

site_title: STI pares loss to end turbulent week 0.2% down
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore ended the week down 0.2% despite a late Friday rally, capping a turbulent week of trading amid rising US interest rates, global geopolitical tensions, and the US-China trade conflict. China's economy grew 6.5% year-on-year, the slowest rate since 2009, while private companies face liquidity concerns due to a weakened yuan. Asian stocks, including Tokyo and Malaysian indices, also fell, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.56% and Malaysian stocks closing 0.3% lower.

site_title: Derivatives drive SGX's Q1 net profit up 0.4%, higher interim dividend declared
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 0.4% increase in Q1 net profits to S$91.07 million, driven by strong derivatives market performance. Derivatives revenue rose 21% to S$97.7 million, contributing 47% of total revenue. The exchange also declared a higher interim dividend of 7.5 cents per share. CEO Loh Boon Chye expects the derivatives business to continue growing, with momentum expected to increase by at least double digits.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Getting high on bubbles
summary: A cannabis stock bubble has emerged, following the crypto bubble, with investors seeking easy gains. Companies like New Age Beverages and Canopy Growth are seeing rapid growth, with some stocks increasing by 400% in the past year. However, these companies have no proven profits and their business plans are often based on future revenue growth, making the current share prices unsustainable. Experts warn that the bubble is likely to burst, and investors should steer clear.

site_title: Tennis' elite 8 ready for Singapore showdown
summary: The world's top eight WTA players, minus injured No. 1 Simona Halep, will compete in the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global, a $7 million season-ending tournament. The players, including Angelique Kerber, Caroline Wozniacki, Naomi Osaka, and Petra Kvitova, will be divided into two groups of four and compete in a round-robin format, with the top two advancing to the semi-finals. The championship match will take place on the following Sunday. This is the fifth edition of the tournament, considered the "crown jewel" of the WTA tour.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: KS Energy sells unit, restructures debt
summary: KS Energy announced an internal reorganization, transferring 55.35% stake in KS Distribution to KS Resources for S$37.9 million, with the remaining 44.65% stake in KS Distribution to be sold to ACH Distribution for S$1.643 million. The company also issued S$30 million in bonds to OCBC to repay debt and finance debt repayments. The moves aim to strengthen KS Energy's financial position and dispose of its loss-making distribution business.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Rents for US homes drop for the first time since 2012: Zillow
summary: US rents dropped 0.2% in September, marking the first year-over-year decline since July 2012, according to Zillow. The median rent was $1,440, down from a 14% increase since September 2011. Strong job markets may have led to overbuilding, giving tenants, especially luxury apartment seekers, more negotiating power. Zillow senior economist Aaron Terrazas noted that while rents remain high, the decline eases pressure on higher-income renters to buy.

site_title: Oxley, KSH, SLB and Heeton say Gaobeidian sales launch to be delayed
summary: Oxley Holdings, KSH Holdings, SLB Development, and Heeton Holdings have delayed the sales launch of Phase 1 of their Gaobeidian development project in China due to the ongoing US-China trade war. The companies cited market sentiment improving after the initial expected date of November 2018. Construction on the project is on schedule, and the Urban Redevelopment Authority's revised guidelines on dwelling units will have minimal impact on the group's proposed developments.

site_title: New LSE boss in 438m-euro move to tighten hold on clearing business
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) has made a significant move to strengthen its hold on derivatives clearing, investing €438 million to increase its stake in clearing house LCH to over 80%. The new investment reflects the exchange's confidence in LCH's continued growth and comes as the UK prepares to leave the EU. The LSE has also applied for a licence in Amsterdam to operate its Turquoise pan-European share trading service, amid growing competition from rival Deutsche Boerse. The move is seen as a sign of the LSE's growing confidence in its position ahead of Brexit.

site_title: Kendall Court invests US$55m in Indonesian hospital expansion
summary: Singapore-based private equity firm Kendall Court has invested US$55 million in a 420-bed hospital expansion in Indonesia through preference shares in Mandaya Medical International. The hospital, Mandaya Royal Hospital Puri, will commence operations in end-2019 and is part of MMI's plans to build two more hospitals in major Indonesian cities, aiming to create a network of hospitals specializing in cardio-vascular, neuroscience, and cancer treatment.

site_title: Royal Caribbean out to woo millennials and Asians
summary: Royal Caribbean International has invested $120 million to refurbish the Mariner of the Seas, a 15-year-old ship, to attract millennials and Asian travelers. The revamped ship features new rides, water slides, and activities aimed at thrill-seekers, including a surf simulator and escape room. The company aims to change the perception of cruises as being for retirees and families, and is also exploring design-and-innovation competitions to understand the preferences of this demographic. With the growth of the Asian cruise market, Royal Caribbean plans to deploy larger vessels, including the 5,622-guest Spectrum of the Seas, set to launch in 2019.

site_title: Flurry of deals in SGD bond market
summary: A flurry of deals in the Singapore dollar (SGD) bond market occurred in the first 19 days of October, with Temasek Holdings, Metro, and Singapore Airlines issuing SGD 1.2 billion worth of bonds. The volume is a significant increase from the same period in October last year, with year-to-date issuances standing at SGD 18.2 billion. Fixed income bankers expect more deals in the last quarter of 2018, citing pent-up demand from investors and issuers. The SGD market is seen as more stable than the USD bond market, with volumes in the Asia excluding Japan G3 bond market down 13.7% year-to-date.

site_title: China's healthcare: from laggard to leader
summary: China's healthcare industry has made significant strides over the past decade, outpacing Western counterparts in medical skills, pharmaceuticals, and healthcare technology. Market demand, talent, and government support have driven the country's progress, with a growing middle class and aging population contributing to the increasing incidence of chronic diseases. China is now considered a leader in AI application in healthcare, telemedicine, and innovative pharmaceuticals, with tech giants like Tencent and Baidu capitalizing on the trend. While challenges remain, healthcare expenditure is expected to continue growing, with China potentially surpassing the US as a global healthcare leader in the next 10-20 years.

site_title: The US economy: 8 more years of expansion?
summary: The US economy is experiencing its second-longest expansion, with a 112-month recovery, surpassing the 120-month expansion that ended the dot-com bubble in 2001. Despite concerns over policy uncertainty and trade wars, the economy shows signs of continued growth, with low policy uncertainty, accommodative monetary policy, and stimulative longer-term fiscal measures. Research suggests that further growth could lead to an additional 8.8 years of expansion, with some experts arguing that expansions don't simply die of old age.

site_title: The benefits of fish oil: fact or fiction?
summary: Recent trials have shown that taking omega-3 supplements does not prevent heart attacks and death related to heart disease in healthy individuals or those at risk of diabetes. In fact, the current evidence from randomized controlled trials suggests that omega-3 PUFA supplementation in patients with or at risk of diabetes mellitus does not prevent heart attacks or stroke. However, for those with pre-existing heart disease, omega-3 PUFA supplementation may reduce heart-related death, primarily due to a reduction in sudden cardiac death from abnormal heart rhythms.

site_title: How to fly the best first-class seats, cheaper than economy
summary:
Airline industry experts say the "death of first class" is a myth, as airlines continue to offer luxurious suites with extravagant amenities. To experience these seats for less than the cost of economy, experts recommend using points savvy and leveraging powerful credit cards. Here are five hacks to get into the best cabins in the skies:

1. Emirates first-class suites: Book a round-trip ticket from Dubai to Europe for 85,000 miles each way, but be aware of high taxes and limited availability.
2. Singapore Airlines first-class suites: Use KrisFlyer miles to book a one-way ticket from Singapore to Sydney for 75,000 miles, but limited availability exists.
3. Air France la Première: Use Air France's Flying Blue miles to book a one-way ticket from Paris to the US for 200,000 miles, but high redemption rates apply.
4. Cathay Pacific First Class: Use AAdvantage miles to book a one-way ticket from Hong Kong to the US for 110,000 miles, or Alaska miles for 70,000 miles.
5. Etihad First-Class Apartment: Use Etihad Guest miles or AAdvantage miles to book a one-way award ticket from JFK to Abu Dhabi for 115,000 miles or 136,500 miles, respectively.

site_title: Watchdog warns about crypto money role in terror financing
summary: The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) warns that virtual currencies, such as cryptocurrencies, pose a significant threat to preventing terror financing due to their potential for anonymity. Governments are urged to take immediate action to regulate these digital assets and prevent their misuse. The FATF's report comes after a request from G20 finance ministers to investigate the use of cryptocurrencies in traditional finance. The international watchdog emphasizes the need for cooperation to combat money laundering, terror financing, and tax evasion through these new digital channels.

images.alt_text: An international finance watchdog warned Friday that virtual currencies have opened up new avenues for terror financing, and said governments needed to work together to meet the digital threat.

site_title: Indonesia corruption crackdown adds to strains on junk bonds
summary: Indonesia's corruption crackdown on major developer PT Lippo Karawaci has raised concerns among investors, adding to strains on the nation's junk bonds. Funding costs are rising ahead of a maturing debt wall, with Lippo Karawaci's dollar bonds losing 25% this year. The probe highlights Indonesia's poor corporate governance and the potential for broader implications. This comes as the rupiah tanks, contributing to a 6% decline in Indonesian dollar junk bonds compared to 2.8% for Asian peers.

images.alt_text: Labourers working on a building under the Meikarta project, developed by Lippo Group, in Bekasi Regency. The home of Lippo's deputy chairman James Riady was searched by anti-graft officials, the latest development in a bribery probe that has entangled one of Indonesia's leading business conglomerates.

site_title: CDL's Whistler Grand to soon launch at average S$1,380 psf
summary: CDL's Whistler Grand condo in Singapore will launch at an average price of S$1,380 per square foot (psf), with prices starting from S$608,000 for one-bedroom units. The 716-unit development, spanning 210,883 sq ft, will feature landscaping and over 60 recreational facilities. Located near the Jurong Lake District and four MRT stations, CDL's head of property development expects good take-up given its location and price, citing the upcoming Jurong Lake District masterplan as a factor.

site_title: Asia's wealthiest look to healthtech investing
summary: Asia's wealthiest individuals are investing heavily in healthtech, with UBS estimating the sector's value to exceed $100 billion. The bank's clients, including those in the Asia-Pacific, are backing companies using information technology to improve healthcare efficiency and reduce costs. This trend is driven by rising healthcare demand and costs, as well as a desire for positive social impact. UBS is launching a healthtech fund and expects to see further growth in the sector, with the potential to benefit society as a whole.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering's electronics arm secured S$435 million in contracts in the third quarter, primarily for mobility, satellite communications, and cybersecurity projects. The company announced the contracts without expecting a material impact on its financial performance. Asiatriavel.com Holdings appealed against the Singapore Tourism Board's decision to suspend its travel agent licenses, while Oceanus Group settled a dispute over its acquisition of a 60% stake in Oceanus Australia Abalone World. LTC Corporation's voluntary delisting was approved by the Singapore Exchange, pending shareholder approval.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.87 points to 1,732.14. Volume reached 2.3 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 579 to 252.

site_title: Pace of new home launches to remain steady despite cooling measures
summary: The pace of new home launches in Singapore is expected to remain steady despite the introduction of cooling measures. The market has adjusted to the new regulations, with buyers favoring projects with perceived strong value propositions. The top-selling projects have seen higher market share gains, while older launches may face challenges due to their less flexible pricing strategies. Despite higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) charges, demand remains strong, and prices have slowed down. The landed market was the key driver behind the price growth, while resale prices of properties at least 10 years old have shown resilience.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Qingjian Realty's Jade Scape, Singapore's first fully-smart, multi-generational residential development.
An artist's impression of Park Colonial condominium in the Bidadari Estate.

site_title: Oxley, KSH, SLB and Heeton say Gaobeidian sales launch to be delayed
summary: Oxley Holdings, KSH Holdings, SLB Development, and Heeton Holdings announced the delay of Gaobeidian sales launch due to the ongoing trade war between the US and China. The project's sales are now expected to start after November 2018 when market sentiment improves. Construction is on schedule, and the companies believe the revised guidelines on dwelling units will have minimal impact on their proposed developments.

site_title: Market keeps punishing stock bulls
summary: US stocks experience their fifth consecutive one-per-cent swing in seven days, with the S&P 500 down 5% in three weeks. The VIX index is above 20, and 10-year Treasury yields are near their highest level since 2011. Rising interest rates and diminishing earnings growth are contributing to the volatility, with Strategas Research Partners noting that this combination has historically generated negative quarterly returns in the S&P 500. Investors are struggling to discern signals, with some citing a "sheep-like" market behavior, and experts warn of more volatility ahead.

images.alt_text: There is more volatility ahead, but where the proper multiple lies is anyone's guess, says Morgan Stanley strategist Mike Wilson. Figuring this out is taking a toll on investors' nerves.

site_title: Venezuela teen's political cartoons sketch his country's downfall
summary: A 13-year-old Venezuelan boy, Gabriel Moncada, creates evocative political cartoons depicting his country's economic crisis, including hyperinflation, mass emigration, and food shortages. His mother, a radio journalist, shares his artwork on social media, where it has been published since 2016. Moncada's drawings, which include images of people fleeing the country and rats searching for food, reflect the harsh reality of Venezuela's economic meltdown, which has forced nearly 2 million people to flee since 2015.

site_title: LTC Corp gets in-principle approval from SGX for voluntary delisting
summary: LTC Corp, a steel trading and property company, has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for a voluntary delisting, subject to shareholder approval. The controlling shareholders have proposed a delisting at 92.5 cents per share, and the company will send a circular to shareholders with more information. The proposal requires at least 75% shareholder approval and must not be opposed by at least 10% of voting shares. LTC Corp advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing with their shares.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: China's real estate investment slows in September as caution sinks in
summary: China's real estate investment slowed in September, with home sales falling for the first time since April, as developers reduced expansion plans amid economic uncertainties. Investment growth rose 8.9% year-over-year, but property sales by floor area declined 3.6% from a year earlier. Despite caution, analysts believe investment levels remain relatively high, suggesting a hard landing is unlikely. The government continues to implement curbs on speculative investment and has methods to support the market if needed.

site_title: Singapore River Festival adopts e-payments
summary: Singapore River Festival has adopted e-payments, with EZ-Link being the only payment method at LAH Bazaar, a riverside e-payment driven outdoor market. The festival, running from Oct 16 to Nov 11, features locally themed performances and activities, including a trivia game and street party. EZ-Link's e-payment initiative aims to encourage the use of digital payments, offering rewards and promotions to festival-goers who link their EZ-Link and Plus! accounts.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund should stay in central bank, government says
summary: Norway's government proposes keeping its $1 trillion sovereign wealth fund within the central bank, rather than creating a separate entity. The proposal comes after a commission recommended the fund become a separate entity, citing specialized management expertise. Instead, the government suggests establishing a central bank committee for monetary policy and financial stability, allowing the central bank to focus on its core tasks and devote more time to managing the fund. This decision aims to alleviate pressure on the central bank and maintain its current management structure.

site_title: Fear of next crisis is stifling investment, Nobel winner Paul Romer says
summary: Nobel Prize-winning economist Paul Romer says fear of the next financial crisis is stifling investment, with investors prioritizing liquidity over growth. Romer believes this is due to the expectation of another crisis, which may lead to accumulation of liquid assets and a lack of investment in machines and infrastructure. Economists and investors are on the lookout for signs of the next crisis, with the International Monetary Fund warning that investors may underestimate the risk of a financial shock, which Romer predicts will happen again. This could have long-term implications for economic growth.

site_title: Creative fidelity: Does the Super X-Fi deliver?
summary: Creative Technology's Super X-Fi Headphone Amp aims to enhance music with a natural, expansive soundstage. The device, a small dongle, uses AI to personalize sound profiles based on user scans. In tests, the SXFI effect lifted music to a wider soundstage, making it sound less clinical and more open, but at the cost of detail in highs and muddying lows. While it's a good first step, the Super X-Fi doesn't quite deliver on marketing promises. It's a good value at $219, but its effectiveness may vary depending on personal taste and audio preferences.

site_title: US existing home sales fall for sixth straight month
summary: US existing home sales declined 3.4% in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.15 million units, marking the sixth consecutive month of falls. The decline is attributed to rising interest rates, constrained supply due to building material costs and labor shortages, and land shortages. The median house price increased 4.2% to $258,100. Economists attribute the decline to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, with a further rate increase expected in December.

site_title: EU top court orders Poland to immediately stop Supreme Court overhaul, reinstate judges
summary: The European Union's top court has ordered Poland to immediately stop a new law forcing Supreme Court judges into early retirement and reinstate those who have already left. The ruling, issued by the European Court of Justice, is a response to a request from the EU's executive European Commission. The court's decision aims to protect the independence of Poland's judiciary, which has been a point of contention between the EU and Poland's ruling nationalists. The order applies with retroactive effect to the affected judges.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust's Q4 DPU flat at 2.4 Singapore cents
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.4 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter, despite lower gross revenue and net property income. The increase in distribution income was driven by contributions from Farnborough Business Park, capital returns, and payment of management fees in units. Q4 income available for distribution rose 10.4% to S$21.4 million, exceeding expectations.

site_title: European politicians call for clampdown on tax trade trick
summary: European politicians are calling for a crackdown on dividend stripping, a tax trade scheme that cost taxpayers billions of euros. The scheme, known as "cum-ex," involved large banks trading stocks to secure illicit double tax rebates. Investigations in Germany, Denmark, Austria, and Belgium have uncovered widespread involvement by major banks, prompting calls for international cooperation to tackle the issue. Politicians and tax experts are urging stricter laws to prevent large-scale tax fraud, with some promising to be "ruthless" in their pursuit of those responsible.

site_title: SGX Q1 net profit stable at S$91m, declares interim dividend of 7.5 cents
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a stable Q1 net profit of S$91.1 million, comparable to the previous year. Revenue increased by 2% to S$208.9 million, driven by a 21% rise in derivatives revenue. However, the equities and fixed income business declined 13%. The company declared an interim dividend of 7.5 cents per share and plans to expand its product offerings and establish new offices in New York and San Francisco to cater to evolving investor needs.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Facebook hires ex UK deputy pm Clegg to lead lobbying effort
summary: Facebook has hired Nick Clegg, the former UK Deputy Prime Minister, to lead the company's global lobbying efforts as governments worldwide debate regulating the social media giant. Clegg, a former Liberal Democrat leader and European Parliament member, brings experience working with EU institutions and speaking multiple languages. His hiring comes as Facebook faces criticism over user privacy breaches, fake news, and hate speech on its platforms.

site_title: Date set for mega Hong Kong-China bridge opening
summary: Hong Kong's 55-kilometre sea bridge, connecting the city to Macau and the Chinese mainland, is set to open to traffic next Wednesday. The bridge, which includes a road bridge and underwater tunnel, has been delayed and marred by budget overruns and corruption prosecutions. Officials had announced a grand opening ceremony, possibly attended by China's President Xi Jinping, despite criticism over the project's secrecy. The bridge is seen as a costly engineering marvel, but also a symbol of Beijing's tightening grip on Hong Kong, a semi-autonomous city.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% down on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% to 3,062.51 on Friday, with 230 losers outnumbering 144 gainers. YZJ Shipbuilding led declines, down 13.87% to S$1.18, while DBS fell 0.37% to S$24.26. Singtel gained 0.96% to S$3.17. The Straits Times Index has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-based private equity firm Kendall Court invests $55 million in an Indonesian hospital expansion, tapping the country's growing healthcare sector. The Singapore dollar's average forecast for 2018 and 2019 is revised to $1.35 against the US dollar. CDL's Whistler Grand condo launches at an average price of $1,380 per square foot. Advanced Holdings cuts its acquisition of Agricore to a 12.25% stake. Singapore shares close 0.2% down on Friday following an overnight US stock sell-off.

site_title: Ryanair inks new deals with unions in Europe
summary: Ryanair has signed new deals with unions in Portugal, the UK, Italy, and Spain, aiming to avoid further strike action by pilots and cabin crew. The agreements, while progress, do not address the key demand of Ryanair staff outside Ireland to stop being employed under Irish legislation. The airline faces ongoing labor disputes and has already reported job losses in the Netherlands and Germany due to the pan-European strikes. Ryanair's earnings outlook update is set for Monday, following a profit forecast cut and a recent disruption of 100,000 travelers.

site_title: KS Energy disposes of distribution business, enters bond agreements with OCBC
summary: KS Energy announced an internal reorganisation, transferring its 55.35% stake in KS Distribution to its subsidiary KS Resources. The company entered a bond purchase agreement to buy $30 million in bonds from OCBC, to be repaid with $35 million in bonds issued by KS Resources. KS Energy also disposed of its 100% stake in KS Resources to ACH Distribution for $1.643 million, aiming to strengthen its financial position and focus on its core businesses.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Conference boycott over missing Saudi journalist may not have long lasting impact
summary: A Western boycott of the Future Investment Initiative in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, due to the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, may not have a long-lasting impact on the country's ambitions to attract foreign capital. Over 20 top officials and executives have cancelled plans to attend, but the event may proceed without its star power. Western companies are likely to put new business in Saudi Arabia on hold, but the freeze may ease within a few months. The Khashoggi affair may cast a shadow over foreign capital flows into Saudi Arabia, but the country's economic and social reforms have won support among many Saudis, potentially mitigating the impact.

site_title: EU's Barnier says 'yes', Irish border issue could sink Brexit deal
summary: EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier stated that the Irish border issue could sink the Brexit deal, saying "yes" when asked if it could cause negotiations to collapse. European leaders warned Britain they would offer no more concessions, but expressed confidence a deal can be done before the UK's exit from the EU in March. The issue of a legally-binding "backstop" arrangement remains a deadlock, with both sides disagreeing on its terms and holding up the rest of the Brexit talks.

site_title: AusGroup noteholders vote to extend maturity date again
summary: AusGroup's S$110 million medium-term notes were extended again, with noteholders voting 88.41% in favor of the move. The maturity date was initially set for 2016, but was later extended to October 20, 2018, with a 8.45% coupon rate. The notes were then extended another four years, with a new coupon rate of 5% for the first year, 6% for the second year, and 7% thereafter. A make-whole premium of S$7,680.96 per note was also approved, to be paid on October 22.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Soho House has 20b reasons to envy WeWork
summary: Soho House, a private members club, may envy WeWork's valuation of $20 billion after Softbank billionaire Masayoshi Son's investment. WeWork's valuation could reach $35 billion in the future. Soho House has 71,000 paying members, similar to WeWork, and is expanding its co-working spaces, but it also faces similar financial challenges, including large liabilities and negative cash flow. To achieve a multi-billion dollar valuation, Soho House may need to attract capital from investors willing to overlook its financial struggles.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks recover tracking China rebound
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed 0.37% higher on Friday, recovering from early falls, as Chinese equities rebounded following regulator pledges to calm markets. The Shanghai Composite index surged 2.5% after China's securities regulator unveiled measures to support the struggling stock market. The Korean won strengthened, while bond yields rose, and crude oil prices fell. The Kospi is down 12.9% so far this year.

site_title: Swiss banks court rich Americans a decade after tax drama
summary: Swiss banks are seeking to reestablish ties with American customers a decade after a tax drama led to billions of dollars in losses and the end of Swiss banking secrecy. To capitalize on the lucrative US market, Swiss money managers are targeting wealthy Americans looking to invest abroad, particularly those with a European background. Banks like Vontobel and UBS are expanding their North American presence, aiming to manage billions of Swiss francs in assets under management from US clients. The move comes as US regulations make offshore business with American customers more complex.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,064.29, down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday at 3,064.29, down 0.2% from the previous day's close. The Straits Times Index (STI) shed 5.38 points, with 814.5 million shares worth S$435.4 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 191 to 109, with key decliners including YZJ Shipbuilding and Asiatic. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China to allow bank wealth-management funds to be invested in stocks
summary: China's banking regulator has announced plans to allow funds from bank wealth-management products to be directly invested in stocks, a move aimed at boosting market confidence. The policy change, which is part of draft rules, allows banks to set up wealth management subsidiaries to strengthen risk management. Currently, only funds raised from privately sold bank wealth management products can be invested in China's stock market. The move could potentially see up to 20% of WMP funds invested in stocks, with some constraints limiting the amount.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as global investors retreat
summary: Global investors retreated from Asian markets on Friday, with most indexes down due to rising US interest rates, geopolitical tensions, and the China-US trade conflict. China's economy expanded 6.5% in the third quarter, the weakest rate since 2009, fueling concerns about the world's number two economy. Other Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul, also declined, while Shanghai briefly rebounded before closing 0.2% higher. The sell-off is seen as a warning that troubles in China could spread to other economies.

site_title: Australian, NZ shares dragged down by weak Chinese GDP data
summary: Australian shares edged lower on Friday, closing 0.05% down at 5,939.5, due to weak Chinese GDP data. China's economy grew 6.5% in the third quarter, missing expectations, and China's policymakers pledged more support to mitigate risks from a trade row with the US. This weighed on metals and mining stocks, with BHP and Fortescue Metals Group closing lower. New Zealand's benchmark index also slid 1.2% due to broad weakness among heavyweight stocks.

site_title: Watch luxury stocks after South Korean airline bag restriction
summary: Asiana Airlines' announcement to stop carrying commercial baggage on flights to mainland China and Hong Kong from October 22 has sparked concerns in the luxury goods sector. Shares in Kering, LVMH, and Hermes International may be active due to the potential impact on luxury items sold in South Korea and resold in China. This comes after recent setbacks for luxury stocks, including a slowdown in Swiss watch exports, and LVMH's comments on China cracking down on travelers returning home with luxury goods.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver at open
summary: European stock markets wavered in opening deals on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.2% to 7,039.37 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.1% to 11,578.85 points. In contrast, Paris' CAC 40 rose 0.1% to 5,119.64. The mixed performance comes ahead of US-EU trade talks and despite US stock indexes reaching fresh records.

site_title: Japan's KYB says products in 28 buildings failed to meet quality standards
summary: KYB Corp, a Japanese shock absorber maker, has announced that at least 70 buildings in Japan may have used its earthquake shock absorbers that failed to meet quality standards. The company has admitted to falsifying data on product quality since 2003. The affected buildings include government structures, such as the Ministry of Finance building in Tokyo, and several tourist sites. KYB officials have confirmed 28 buildings failed to meet standards, with nearly 1,000 potentially affected. The scandal follows a series of compliance issues in Japan's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Umno president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi arrested by anti-graft body
summary: Malaysian Umno president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi was arrested by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) on October 18, 2018, in connection with an investigation into the alleged misuse of RM800,000 from his charity foundation. The arrest was carried out after obtaining clearance from the Attorney-General's Chambers to charge him with abuse of power, criminal breach of trust, and money-laundering. Zahid, who is also a former deputy prime minister, rejected bail and indicated he would spend the night in the MACC lockup before being brought to court to face charges.

site_title: South-east Asia hails world's first multilateral air encounter code
summary: South-east Asian countries, including Singapore, agreed on guidelines for managing unexpected encounters between military aircraft, dubbed the world's first multilateral air encounter code. The voluntary, non-binding guidelines build on existing codes for sea encounters and include information exchange on terrorism threats. The agreement aims to address rising air and maritime traffic in the region, particularly in the disputed South China Sea. The 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) will encourage international partners to join the guidelines.

site_title: Germans enlist help to ease move of trillions in swaps from UK
summary: Deutsche Boerse AG is developing a service to transfer trillions of dollars in derivatives trades from LCH Ltd in London to its Eurex Clearing in Frankfurt. The company is working with four interdealer brokers - BGC Partners, Cie Financiere Tradition, TriOptima, and Quantile Technologies - to provide the technology. The goal is to ease the move of swaps and provide a seamless experience for clients, following the Brexit-related tensions. The service is expected to be ready soon, with the brokers selling it to their clients once it's available.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.96 points to 1,733.05 on Friday, with volume reaching 45.85 million lots worth RM18.03 million. The market saw 158 losers compared to 40 gainers.

site_title: Fitch Solutions forecasts Singdollar averaging S$1.35 against USD in 2018, S$1.38 against USD in 2019
summary: Fitch Solutions has revised its forecast for the Singapore dollar's average value against the US dollar for 2018 to S$1.35 per US dollar, down from S$1.36, due to US-China trade tensions and rising US interest rates. The forecast remains range-bound between S$1.36 and S$1.38 in the next three to six months. However, a strong external balance sheet and subdued inflationary pressure are expected to support the Singapore dollar's appreciation in the long term, with an average forecast of S$1.38 per US dollar in 2019.

images.alt_text: Fitch Solutions Macro Research has pared down slightly its average forecast for the Singapore dollar this year to S$1.35 per US dollar, down slightly from S$1.36, on the back of forces like the US-China trade tensions and rising US interest rates.

site_title: China's one-time richest woman becomes biggest loser in wealth rout
summary: Zhou Qunfei, China's former richest woman, has lost 66% of her fortune, or $6.6 billion, due to the US-China trade war. Her company, Lens Technology Co, saw its shares slump 62% this year as a result of US tariffs on Apple Inc suppliers and Elon Musk's resignation as Tesla chairman. This marks the largest percentage drop in wealth among Chinese billionaires in 2018, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: Thailand's richest man plans US$1.5b IPO
summary: Thailand's richest man, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, is planning a US$1.5 billion initial public offering (IPO) of his Asset World Corp. unit, TCC Group's property division. The IPO aims to list AWC in Bangkok next year, with the company developing shopping centers, office space, and hotels. The IPO comes as first-time share sales in Thailand have raised US$2 billion this year, following the country's biggest corporate IPO, Osotspa Pcl, which gained 9% on its trading debut.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai stocks tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks plummeted at the open on Friday, following a global sell-off due to concerns over higher US interest rates. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.11% to 25,172.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.06% to 2,460.08. Traders await the release of Chinese growth data, adding to the uncertainty.

site_title: NTU innovation unit partners startup accelerators to promote opportunities in India
summary: NTUitive, Nanyang Technological University's innovation arm, has partnered with Govin Academy and Startup Accelerator India to promote startup entrepreneurship opportunities between Singapore and India. The partnership aims to provide a launch pad for Singaporean startups to expand into the Indian market and vice versa through workshops, hackathons, and internships. Industry leaders and mentors from Govin and NTUitive will oversee these programs, providing insights into India's market. This collaboration seeks to foster innovation and growth between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: China's steel production hits new highs as winter curbs loom
summary: China's steel production reached new highs in October, with output of crude steel rising 7.5% year-over-year to 80.85 million tonnes, a daily rate of 2.695 million tonnes. This surpasses the previous record high of 2.673 million tonnes in June. The surge in production is driven by high prices and healthy profits, with rebar prices rallying to the highest this year and iron ore prices reaching a March high, ahead of winter production curbs. The record production is expected to continue, supporting China's steel markets.

site_title: Singapore PE firm Kendall Court investing US$55m in Indonesia company's hospital expansion
summary: Singapore-based private equity firm Kendall Court has invested US$55 million in Indonesia's Mandaya Medical International Pte Ltd (MMI), expanding its 420-bed hospital in Jakarta. MMI aims to cater to Indonesia's growing middle-class demand for quality healthcare. The hospital, which will start operations in 2019, focuses on cardio-vascular, neuroscience, and cancer specialties. Kendall Court will own a majority stake in MMI through its investment in preference shares, further solidifying its presence in Indonesia's healthcare sector.

site_title: Singapore ranked 9th in wealth per adult: Credit Suisse
summary: Singapore ranks 9th globally in wealth per adult, with a figure of over US$283,000, according to Credit Suisse's 2018 Global Wealth Report. The country's wealth has risen 5.3% since 2017, driven by high savings, asset price increases, and a rising exchange rate. Singapore's total wealth is forecast to grow to US$1.6 trillion by 2023, with the number of millionaires expected to reach 239,640, a 5.5% increase. The US remains the world's richest nation, with China emerging as the second-largest household wealth holder.

site_title: China's Sept property investment slows, sales fall
summary: China's real estate investment growth slowed in September, with sales falling for the first time since April, amid a cooling market. The country's real estate investment rose 8.9% in September from a year earlier, but property sales by floor area fell 3.6% from a year earlier. This decline is attributed to increased caution among developers following failed land auctions and tightening funding conditions. The market is expected to face additional regulatory tightening and slowing economic growth, posing downside risks to China's economy.

site_title: Korean Air very likely to order more Boeing 787 widebody jets, says its president
summary: Korean Air Lines Co Ltd's president, Walter Cho, suggests the airline is likely to order more Boeing 787 widebody jets, considering the 777X as a potential replacement for its current 777 generation. Cho notes that business to Europe and the US has improved, but the China route remains weak due to political issues.

site_title: Indonesia corruption crackdown adds to strains on junk bonds
summary: Indonesia's corruption crackdown on major developer PT Lippo Karawaci has raised concerns about broader corporate governance issues, potentially impacting junk bonds. The probe is part of the government's anti-corruption campaign, which may unearth other cases. This timing is problematic, as funding costs are rising ahead of maturing debt. Experts warn that Indonesian companies have poor corporate governance ratings, and the crackdown could lead to more cases being uncovered, further straining the nation's junk bonds.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall on global jitters
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Friday, following a global market rout due to diplomatic tensions and concerns over China's slowdown. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.56% to 22,532.08, and the Topix index declined 0.69% to 1,692.85. The losses were largely attributed to the disappearance of a Saudi journalist and fears of China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says 'hold' OCBC, 'buy' UOB for more attractive dividend play
summary: A DBS analyst recommends holding OCBC and buying UOB due to their attractive dividend yield play. UOB is expected to maintain a flattish net interest margin in the third quarter, while OCBC may see a net interest margin expansion as it reprices mortgages and phases out expensive deposits. The analyst prefers UOB due to its higher dividend yield, strong funding portfolio, and lower exposure to trade and wealth management income. Target prices for UOB and OCBC are set at S$31.70 and S$12.40, respectively.

site_title: China's economic growth slips to weakest since 2009, demand ebbs as trade war bites
summary: China's economic growth slowed to 6.5% in the third quarter, its weakest pace since 2009, due to a decline in factory output and weakening demand. The slowdown is attributed to the trade war with the US, which has sparked a selloff in domestic stock markets and a decline in the yuan's value. Regulators have pledged further policy support to tackle debt risks and stabilize the economy. Analysts expect China's full-year growth to slow further, potentially to 6.0-6.2% next year, amid increasing pressure from the trade dispute and dwindling exports.

images.alt_text: China's economic growth cooled to its weakest pace since the global financial crisis in the third quarter, with regulators pledging further policy support as a years-long campaign to tackle debt risks and the trade war with the United States began to bite.

site_title: Australian regulator says bigger stick needed to clean up financial sector
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, ASIC, says it needs a bigger stick to tackle widespread misconduct in the financial sector. ASIC Chair James Shipton told lawmakers that the regulator must pursue more meaningful penalties, but also acknowledged the need to balance expectations with reality. Shipton called for a review of ASIC's resources to meet community expectations and unique financial system challenges. This comes after a misconduct inquiry highlighted widespread issues in the sector.

site_title: China regulators deliver rare joint pep talk for worried markets
summary: China's top financial officials, including the central bank governor and regulators, delivered a joint statement to reassure markets and ease concerns over the country's economic prospects. They cited "abnormal" share price falls and economic slowdown, but noted that current stock market valuations are at historically low levels. The statement aimed to alleviate fears of a strengthening state hand on the economy and potential losses for private enterprises. The Shanghai Composite Index initially fell, but recovered after the officials' comments, with the index rising 0.65% and Shenzhen gaining 0.75%.

site_title: Curly Wurly
summary: Dyson has introduced the AirWrap, a curling iron alternative that uses a high-pressure motor to create curls without manual twisting. The device features various attachments for different curl sizes and can also straighten hair. The AirWrap will be available in Singapore starting October 20 for SGD 649, and can be purchased from Dyson's website and selected department stores.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: WhatsApp dirty tricks alleged in Brazil presidential race
summary: Brazil's presidential election campaign has been marred by allegations of WhatsApp dirty tricks, with leftist candidate Fernando Haddad accusing far-right frontrunner Jair Bolsonaro of using "illegal" tactics to sway public opinion. A report found companies were poised to send bulk WhatsApp messages attacking Haddad and his Workers Party, sparking concerns about social media manipulation. Bolsonaro denied the allegations, but ordinary Brazilians reported being exposed to misinformation, with some family members and friends receiving false messages. The issue highlights the growing concern about disinformation on social media in democracies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open sharply lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 1.32% or 298.41 points at 22,359.75 on Friday, following Wall Street's decline due to concerns over the disappearance of a Saudi journalist and global issues. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index also fell 1.11% and 1.11% respectively.

site_title: SIA prices S$600m notes issue; names Shell's Goh Swee Chen as board director
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) priced a S$600 million five-year note issue with a 3.16% interest rate, set to mature in 2023. The notes will be issued at face value and managed by DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and UOB Bank. SIA also announced the appointment of Shell Companies chairman Goh Swee Chen as an independent non-executive director, starting in 2019, to bring diversity and IT expertise to the board.

site_title: Asia: Shares extend slump as global sentiment sours
summary: Asia's stocks slumped on Friday as global sentiment soured due to trade worries, higher US interest rates, and concerns over China's slowing economy. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.11%, the Shanghai Composite Index shed 1.06%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index sank 1.35%. Investors await China's third-quarter GDP data, which is expected to show the weakest pace of growth since the global financial crisis. Analysts say markets are digesting the combination of higher US rates, ongoing trade tension, and Chinese growth concerns.

site_title: Australia's NAB cuts 300 staff over wrongdoing
summary: About 300 National Australia Bank staff have been fired or left the company following internal investigations into wrongdoing, chief executive Andrew Thorburn admitted. Over 1,200 staff were questioned about their adherence to the bank's code of conduct, with 700 found wanting. Thorburn expressed shame and apologized for the bank's behavior, stating that those committing "absolute clear misconduct" would be terminated immediately. The bank has set aside hundreds of millions of dollars for refunds and compliance charges, and shares edged 0.3% lower on the news.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.55% to 3,052.84
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.55% to 3,052.84 on Friday, following overnight declines in US markets. The decline was attributed to concerns over strained US-Saudi relations amid the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Losers outnumbered gainers 93 to 26, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings and United Overseas Bank being among the most heavily traded stocks to fall. The decline was seen as a result of increased selling in the market, with investors viewing any signs of trouble as a larger problem.

site_title: China's smog-prone north must guarantee winter heat: vice-premier
summary: Vice Premier Han Zheng warned northern Chinese officials that it's "absolutely forbidden" to leave households without heat this winter, amid a transition from coal to natural gas in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region. Last year, parts of the region were left without heating due to insufficient natural gas supplies. The region must guarantee residents have access to heating this winter to avoid a repeat of the issue.

images.alt_text: The smog-prone northern Chinese region of Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei must ensure residents have enough heating this winter, even as it switches thousands of households from coal to cleaner natural gas, Vice Premier Han Zheng said.

site_title: Malaysia's Umno president Zahid claims trial to 45 charges
summary: Malaysia's former Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi claimed trial to 45 charges of corruption, abuse of power, and money laundering, totaling RM114 million. He faces 10 charges under the Penal Code, 8 under the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission Act, and 27 under the Anti-Money Laundering Act. Zahid, 65, pleaded not guilty and was granted bail of RM2 million, with his passport also surrendered. This is the first time an Umno president has been charged in court, dealing a major blow to the party, which ruled Malaysia for 61 years.

site_title: China's Q3 GDP growth slowest since 2009, misses expectations
summary: China's third quarter GDP growth slowed to 6.5%, its weakest pace since the 2009 global financial crisis, missing expectations. The economy's domestic demand weakened, with factory activity, infrastructure investment, and consumer spending showing softness. Analysts expect full-year growth to meet the 6.5% government target, but next year's growth is forecast at 6.3%. The trade dispute with the US and China's efforts to tackle debt risks are contributing to the slowdown. Policymakers are shifting priorities to reducing growth risks, with interest rate and fiscal policy adjustments underway.

images.alt_text: China's third quarter economic growth slowed to its weakest pace since the global financial crisis, and missed expectations, as a years-long campaign to tackle debt risks and the trade war with the United States began to bite.

site_title: Sculptor Simone Leigh wins Guggenheim's Hugo Boss Prize
summary: Simone Leigh, a Brooklyn-based artist, has been awarded the Guggenheim Museum's prestigious Hugo Boss Prize for her achievement in contemporary art. The 50-year-old sculptor, known for exploring the experiences and social histories of black women through ceramics, received a $100,000 award and a solo exhibition at the Guggenheim in 2019. The jury praised Leigh's commitment to addressing the subject and audience of her work, recognizing her contributions to expanding the possibilities of ceramics in the mainstream art world.

site_title: Tesla launches new US$45,000 Model 3
summary: Tesla has introduced a new US$45,000 version of its Model 3 sedan, which features a mid-range battery and a 260-mile range. The car's delivery period is 6-10 weeks, and it is eligible for the current US$7,500 tax credit if delivered by the end of the year. This move is seen as a strategic effort to attract buyers who had been waiting for the lower-priced version, which Tesla had previously announced but would not manufacture this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Keppel Corp, IEV, Global Invacom, Debao
summary: Singapore Airlines is raising S$600 million to fund aircraft purchases and related payments through 5-year notes with a 3.16% interest rate. Keppel Corp posted a 15% drop in Q3 earnings due to lower contributions from investments and property divisions. IEV Holdings issued a clarification on its proposed disposal of a loss-making subsidiary, correcting a previous statement. Global Invacom Group is contemplating an acquisition that could constitute a reverse takeover. Debao Property Development has received an extension for its annual general meeting deadline until November 30.

site_title: Indonesian authorities raid home of Lippo Group deputy chairman in bribery probe
summary: Indonesian authorities raided 10 locations, including the home of Lippo Group deputy chairman James Riady, as part of a bribery investigation linked to the conglomerate's $21 billion Meikarta real estate project. The Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) arrested several Lippo Group employees and officials, accusing them of trying to bribe city officials to obtain property permits. Investigators seized financial documents and computers, and found $46,482 and $90,000 intended as bribe money. Lippo Group shares have plummeted since the investigation was made public.

site_title: The unseen side of the Singapore startup scene
summary: The Singapore startup scene is often portrayed as a path to success, but the reality is that many entrepreneurs face exhaustion, depression, betrayal, and bankruptcy. The media spotlight highlights only the success stories, while the stories of failure remain unreported. Experts warn of the dangers of chasing market frenzies, and the US economy is experiencing its longest expansion since the dot-com bubble in 2001.

site_title: US authorities reel in StarKist in canned tuna price fixing scandal
summary: US authorities have secured a plea from StarKist, a major canned tuna manufacturer, for conspiring with other companies to fix prices of canned tuna from 2011 to 2013. The company agreed to plead guilty and pay a fine of up to $100 million. This is the latest in a crackdown on price fixing, with Bumble Bee Foods also pleading guilty in 2017 for its role in the conspiracy. The Justice Department says the price fixing had direct effects on American consumers, and StarKist will cooperate with the investigation.

site_title: US stem cell researcher accused of faking results
summary: US stem cell researcher Piero Anversa has been accused of falsifying data in his studies, with over 30 articles retracted due to "falsified and/or fabricated data". Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston have advised journals to retract the articles, citing a lack of reproducibility in his lab results. Anversa's research on self-renewing human lung stem cells and cardiac stem cells was previously praised, but subsequent investigations revealed serious errors, leading to a retraction in 2014 and potentially dozens more. The incident has raised concerns about the integrity of scientific research.

images.alt_text: European leaders sought to build support from Asia on Thursday in defence of free trade and the fight against climate change, to counter the growing protectionism of President Donald Trump's America.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust Q4 DPU dips to 2.4 Singapore cents
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a DPU of 2.4 Singapore cents in Q4, down from 2.41 cents in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to a revenue slide, but contributions from Farnborough Business Park and capital returns offset the impact. The full-year DPU slipped to 9.6 cents from 9.82 cents in the previous year. The company's books will close on October 30, and payment will be made on November 29.

site_title: EU builds ties with Asia in face of US protectionism
summary: European leaders met in Brussels to build support from Asia against US protectionism, defending free trade and fighting climate change. The summit, attended by over 20 Asian leaders, aims to promote multilateralism and the global trading system. The EU seeks to counter the US's growing protectionism, while also addressing human rights concerns in Asian countries. The leaders will discuss trade deals, climate action, and non-proliferation, with a focus on strengthening the EU's role in international diplomacy.

site_title: Short sellers bet London home woes will spread
summary: Short sellers are betting that UK homebuilders will be negatively impacted by a proposed levy on overseas property buyers and slowing sales. Hedge funds have increased negative bets on companies like Crest Nicholson and Berkeley Group Holdings, citing high prices, Brexit uncertainty, and taxes. The proposed levy, if implemented, would increase the stamp duty sales tax on buyers outside the UK. This move is expected to affect homebuilders with the most exposure to London, such as Berkeley Group Holdings, which has seen its short interest decline.

site_title: Oil falls on concerns over escalating trade row
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday due to concerns over an escalating trade row between China and the US, which may impact oil demand growth. Global benchmark Brent crude fell nearly $8 per barrel, settling at $79.29 per barrel, amid lower forecasts for global economic growth and ample oil supplies. US crude was down 1.6% at $68.65 per barrel. The decline was also influenced by a US Energy Department report showing oil producers storing 22 million barrels, and the impending loss of Iran's crude exports after the US re-imposes sanctions in November.

site_title: Markets could see tactical rebound at end-2018
summary: Markets may experience a tactical rebound at the end of 2018 and start of 2019, driven by the US mid-term elections, despite weak market sentiment. JPMAM strategist Jasslyn Yeo believes the US economy can remain in a late-cycle phase, with emerging markets expected to bounce back, but warns of a full-scale trade war's potential to drag down US growth. Investors are advised to rotate into defensive plays, focusing on structural growth and quality companies with sustainable competitive advantages.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Quarles upbeat about economy; rate policy on steady course
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Randal Quarles expressed optimism about the US economy, citing positive signs in the labor market and business investment. Despite some unclear signals, Quarles believes the central bank can stay on a steady course with gradual interest rate increases. He pointed to a near 50-year low unemployment rate, inflation near the Fed's 2% target, and rising business investment, which suggests productivity will increase and sustain growth without fueling inflation. Quarles urged the Fed to maintain its course, only adjusting as needed, and defended the central bank's independence from the administration.

site_title: Pound falls after Britain's May says EU proposal on border unacceptable
summary: The British pound fell to intraday lows after Prime Minister Theresa May said European Union proposals for avoiding a hard Irish border were unacceptable. The pound dropped 0.4% to $1.3057 and 0.3% to 88.03 pence against the euro. May suggested extending the Brexit transition period could resolve the impasse, but the market remains skeptical, with analysts warning Brexit remains a major risk. Data also showed UK retail sales fell 0.8% in September, further weakening the pound.

site_title: FBI leaker jailed for four years
summary: A former FBI agent, Terry Albury, was sentenced to 48 months in prison for leaking internal documents revealing the agency's use of racial profiling in counter-terror investigations. Albury, a 17-year veteran, pleaded guilty after leaking the Domestic Investigations and Operations Guide to The Intercept in 2016. The guide showed how the agency used profiling to target investigations and spy on journalists. The sentence was handed down as part of the Trump administration's crackdown on media leaks, with Attorney General Jeff Sessions stating that such crimes will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

site_title: SPH puts up Singapore's largest sequential LED-lit billboard
summary: SPH, the outdoor media arm of Singapore Press Holdings, unveiled Singapore's largest sequential LED-lit billboard at Scotts Square, promoting Martell's Icons Grow Bold campaign. The 50m x 11m billboard features a 3D custom-built Martell VSOP Aged in Red Barrels bottle and vertical backlit LED panels that light up in a sequence at 7pm daily from September to November. This is the first installation of its scale in Singapore, targeting younger adult consumers aged 25-40.

site_title: EU slams Italy's 'unprecedented' deviation from budget rules
summary: The European Commission has formally warned Italy that its 2019 budget plans are a serious concern, citing an unprecedented deviation from EU rules. Italy's deficit is projected at 2.4% of GDP, far higher than the 0.8% estimate of the previous government. The commission demands "clarifications" from Rome and warns that Brussels may reject the entire budget, which would be a first within the European Union. Italy's populist government has defended its plans, saying they aim to fulfill electoral promises and boost spending.

site_title: Single-storey detached house in Serangoon Gardens on sale for S$11.5m
summary: A single-storey detached house in Serangoon Gardens, Singapore, is on sale for S$11.5 million, or S$1,085 per square foot, with the potential to be developed into two homes. The house spans 10,602 sq ft across two adjoining lots. The tender will close on November 15.

images.alt_text: "The site may also be attractive to multi-generational families who favour this location for its quaint surroundings as well as the abundance of amenities." - Suzie Mok, senior director of investment sales at Savills Singapore, on the 18/20 Berwick Drive house (above), that spans two adjoining lots.

site_title: Malaysia cuts growth target, sees budget still in deficit through 2020
summary: Malaysia has cut its economic growth target, now forecasting 4.5-5.5% annual growth for 2018-2020, down from the original 5-6% goal. The government has also revised its budget forecast, expecting a wider fiscal deficit and slower economic growth through 2020. To address this, the government plans to cut development spending and rely more on the private sector for growth. The revised forecasts may impact Malaysia's sovereign credit ratings, which could be affected if the government fails to narrow its budget deficit.

site_title: Turkey searches Saudi consulate again, as ministers cancel Riyadh trip
summary: Turkey searched the Saudi consulate in Istanbul for a second time as part of its probe into the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, with Turkish officials believing he was murdered at the consulate on October 2. The US, British, French, and Dutch ministers cancelled their attendance at a Riyadh investment summit amid global criticism of Saudi Arabia, with US President Donald Trump expressing concerns but also citing potential arms deals. Turkish investigators found an audio recording indicating Khashoggi's killing, while Saudi Arabia denies involvement.

site_title: India's richest brothers and how they grew US$40b apart
summary: India's richest brothers, Mukesh and Anil Ambani, have seen their fortunes diverge by over $40 billion in the past year. Mukesh's Reliance Industries, driven by its telecommunications revolution, has grown to $100 billion, while Anil's businesses have faced legal and liquidity challenges, cutting his personal fortune in half. The brothers' fortunes began to diverge 16 years ago, after their father's death, and a feud between them was eventually brokered by their mother. Mukesh's focus on the telecoms sector has paid off, while Anil's struggles have been fueled by debt and poor investment decisions. The brothers' fortunes may be set to continue to diverge, with Mukesh gearing up for an e-commerce expansion and Anil refocusing on real estate.

site_title: Airbus preparing for next wave of management shakeup: sources
summary: Airbus is preparing for another management shakeup, considering changes to key sales positions, despite having overhauled its senior executive lineup just two years ago. The move aims to inject fresh blood into the operation, but would also mean losing decades of experience, particularly against rival Boeing. The changes come as Airbus faces ongoing investigations and prepares for the departure of CEO Tom Enders and CFO Harald Wilhelm in April. The company's new commercial chief, Christian Scherer, is leading the shakeup, which would affect sales teams across Europe, the Middle East, and Asia.

site_title: Whizzpopping worlds collide at Dahl museum
summary: The Roald Dahl Museum in Great Missenden, UK, has reopened after a renovation following a flash flood. The museum features a recreation of Dahl's garden hut, where he wrote his beloved children's novels, including Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and Matilda. The exhibit showcases Dahl's life, writing process, and inspirations, including the village where he lived. The museum also includes artifacts from his life, such as his RAF flying helmet and annotated map of Egypt, and features a replica of his hut and a cartoon statue of Matilda facing Donald Trump.

site_title: Set Design
summary: Lawyer U Shaun Lim spent over a decade building his designer furniture collection, which inspired him to collaborate with architect Timothy Tan on a unique apartment set. After four years of searching for the perfect space, Lim finally found an apartment off Orchard Road in 2016, which he renovated with Tan's design expertise. The result is a "stage set" of a luxurious space showcasing Lim's iconic furniture pieces, featuring a mix of timber, stone, and steel. The apartment now serves as a backdrop for Lim's collection, and he hosts weekly parties for friends and family.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: UOB launches eLab to personalise digital services
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) launched an Engagement Lab (eLab) in Singapore to personalize digital services for its upcoming Digital Bank. The eLab aims to use technology and behavioral insights to encourage customers to save and spend wisely. With a focus on Asean customers, the eLab will design and test digital conversations in customers' native languages. The bank plans to set up eLabs in Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam, and is hiring 50 new staff for the Digital Bank team. The eLab will also focus on user experience and behavioral science.

site_title: The business case for getting Asia-Pacific's rail network on track
summary: Rail travel is experiencing a renaissance in the Asia-Pacific region, with rail becoming the third-largest travel segment and the fastest-growing online travel segment in 2017, up 23% year-on-year. Population growth and urbanization have created urgent demand for expanded rail infrastructure, and there is a strong economic and business case for developing better train links across the region. This growth is driven by Asia-Pacific's rapidly expanding economy and increasing population, presenting opportunities for rail networks to play a significant role in the region's future development.

site_title: Universal Sound
summary: A new festival, Universe of Sound (UoS), is being held in Singapore to promote sound healing and wellness through music and frequencies. The one-day event, led by sound therapy practitioner Amelia Kang, will feature talks, workshops, a concert, and a holistic wellness exhibition. The festival aims to dispel misconceptions about sound healing, which is believed to restore harmony to the body's cells by using instruments, voice, and direct frequency vibrations. The event is open to the public and will take place on October 20 at the Virgo Ballroom, Resorts World Sentosa.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US: Stocks fall on worries about Saudi Arabia, Italy
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.3%, the S&P 500 down 1.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 2.1%, due to rising worries over US-Saudi relations following Jamal Khashoggi's suspected murder and concerns over Italy's budget plans. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's withdrawal from a Saudi investment summit and European Central Bank Chief Mario Draghi's comments on EU budget rules also contributed to the decline. The market's uncertainty was fueled by heightened global tensions and the Trump administration's aggressive trade policies.

site_title: The Maverick
summary: Max Busser, founder of Swiss watch brand Max Busser & Friends, defies conventional watchmaking by rejecting the growth model adopted by most watch brands. In the past three years, the brand has cut back output after a period of over-production to meet demand. This approach sets the brand apart from others in the industry, which often prioritize mass production. By prioritizing quality and exclusivity, Max Busser & Friends aims to maintain its unique position in the world of haute horlogerie.

site_title: More COEs available for three months starting November
summary: The Land Transport Authority of Singapore announced an increase in certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the next three-month period, starting from November. The monthly supply will rise to 10,046, with 7,181 COEs available for cars, a 3.9% increase, and 2,207 COEs for motorcycles, a 34.7% increase. This growth is attributed to a surge in bike deregistrations and the premature scrapping of older cars due to low COE premiums.

site_title: For Muscadet, look beyond the obvious
summary: The article highlights the often-underestimated Muscadet grape, also known as melon de Bourgogne, used in French white wine. Unlike popular grapes like Sauvignon Blanc, Riesling, and Chardonnay, Muscadet's subtle qualities, such as texture, resonance, and minerality, are often overlooked. Despite a history of being banned in eastern France and relegated to cheap supermarket wine, dedicated producers have showcased Muscadet's potential through conscientious farming and production methods. Recent tastings have revealed the grape's ability to age and evolve, offering a rich and textured drinking experience.

images.alt_text: Muscadet is delicious when young, but can also age and evolve. It is especially enjoyable for consumers who can look beyond the obvious and tune in to its subtleties.

site_title: Thailand's richest man plans US$1.5b property IPO
summary: Thailand's richest man, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, plans an initial public offering (IPO) of his domestic property business, Asset World Corp., which could raise at least $1.5 billion.
