US Senator Lindsey Graham accused Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of ordering Jamal Khashoggi's murder, straining US-Saudi relations. The oil trade is now focusing on Iran and Saudi Arabia, according to Jim Ritterbusch.

site_title: Dollar stuck near three-week lows amid retail data
summary: The US dollar was near a three-week low on Tuesday due to tepid retail sales data, which contrasted with a strong economic run that pushed 10-year Treasury yields above 3.22% for over seven years. Despite this, Treasury yields remained firmer, preventing a sell-off. The data was a rare blemish in a series of strong economic indicators, highlighting mixed US economic performance.

site_title: US: Dow jumps more than 2% as stocks rebound on strong earnings
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 2.2% to 25,798.42, driven by strong earnings reports. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose 2.2% and 2.9%, respectively. The gains pushed aside concerns about the economy and trade tensions, with investors focusing on the positive earnings data. The rally extended the market's recovery from recent losses.

site_title: Temasek launches first bond for retail investors - at 2.7% fixed rate
summary: Temasek Holdings has launched its first public bond offer for retail investors, with a 5-year fixed interest rate of 2.7% per annum. Up to S$200 million is being offered, while institutional investors will receive a separate S$200 million. This marks Temasek's first foray into retail bond offerings, expanding access to investment opportunities for individual investors.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Surbana Jurong acquires two architecture firms
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based urban and infrastructure development consultancy, has acquired two major architecture firms, B+H and SAA Architects, in a move that nearly doubles its headcount of architects and boosts its capacity for ambitious projects. The acquisitions are aimed at deepening Surbana Jurong's urban capabilities, particularly in sectors such as healthcare and hospitality. With the two firms, Surbana Jurong will be able to take on "very complicated designs" and become a magnet for talents, with a focus on organic growth rather than just revenue contribution.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Uber boosts bond offering to US$2b
summary: Uber Technologies Inc has increased its debut bond offering to US$2 billion, up from an originally planned US$1 billion. The offering includes a US$1.5 billion portion of eight-year bonds and a US$500 million portion of five-year bonds. The move comes as the company prepares for a potential IPO next year, with some valuing Uber at US$120 billion.

images.alt_text: Ride-hailing firm Uber Technologies Inc increased the size of its debut bond offering to US$2 billion as orders for the private placement swelled, Bloomberg reported on Tuesday, citing people with knowledge of the sale.

site_title: Index fund investors' no-fuss approach may enrich returns
summary: Index fund investors tend to make fewer decisions, resulting in better performance due to a lower "return gap" between reported fund returns and actual investor returns. A Morningstar study found index funds outperformed actively managed funds by 2.48% annually, with the exception of the international equity category. To reduce the return gap, investors should adopt a humble and patient approach, avoiding market timing and focusing on long-term goals. Regular portfolio rebalancing, dollar-cost averaging, and diversification can also help minimize the gap, while actively managed funds may be more susceptible to poor market timing during prolonged bull or bear markets.

site_title: Entrepreneurship is the heart of all economies, says OSIM founder
summary: OSIM founder Ron Sim emphasizes that entrepreneurship is the heart of all economies, stating it's essential for growth and success. He attributes OSIM's success to expansion beyond Singapore, innovation, and long-term vision. Other panelists, including Razer's Tan Min Liang and Heliconia's Derek Lau, agree that entrepreneurship can be exercised in various forms, whether as an owner or worker. Despite market constraints in Singapore, entrepreneurs like Sim and Lau suggest that venturing overseas is crucial for local enterprises to grow big.

site_title: Asian stocks mixed amid uncertainties
summary: Asian stocks traded mixed on Tuesday as investors grappled with ongoing US-China trade rhetoric and geopolitical strains. The Singapore benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to close at 3,034.31, while Japan's Topix gained 0.74%. Banking stocks in Singapore closed mixed, with UOB gaining 0.6% and DBS losing 1%. The earnings season kicked in, with several companies, including Keppel Corp and Singapore Exchange, set to announce results.

site_title: US sets new trade talks with EU, Japan, Britain
summary: US officials announced negotiations for separate trade agreements with Britain, the European Union, and Japan as part of efforts to rebalance global commerce. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer stated the administration's intent to negotiate these agreements with timely and substantive results for American workers and businesses. This move comes as part of President Donald Trump's administration's efforts to renegotiate trade deals. The exact terms of the agreements have not been disclosed, but the goal is to promote fair trade practices and boost US economic interests.

site_title: DZ Privatbank halves clients while doubling assets under management
summary: DZ Privatbank, a German private banking arm, has reduced its customer base by almost half while nearly doubling its assets under management. The bank now manages over 18 billion euros (S$28.7 billion), a new record. CEO Stefan Schwab attributed this growth to efficient operations and a focus on serving a smaller, high-net-worth clientele.

site_title: London attracts global finance under Brexit cloud
summary: London secured 55 inbound foreign direct investment (FDI) projects in financial services in 2017, surpassing rival cities like Dublin and Paris. Top investors came from the US, Sweden, and China, creating 16,126 estimated jobs. Despite Brexit uncertainty, London remains a key financial hub, with 392 FDI projects between 2013 and 2017, and 4.23 billion pounds in capital investment. The City of London aims to secure a positive Brexit deal to maintain investor confidence.

site_title: Are ethics really the only way?
summary: Investors who focus solely on ethical investing may miss out on opportunities by excluding certain sectors or companies from their portfolios. The definition of "ethical" is subjective and can vary greatly, with some exclusions being more straightforward, such as tobacco, while others are more complex and nuanced. Historically, excluding certain companies has led to decreased returns, as sectors like tobacco have been driven by defensive dividend-generating nature rather than long-term fundamentals. A more effective approach may be to evaluate each company on its own merits, engaging with companies as owners and taking action to improve their management and long-term success, which can lead to wider benefits to society and investors.

site_title: CapitaLand said to be keen on massive Shanghai project on sale for 12.79b yuan
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property giant, is reportedly set to acquire the Star Harbour International Centre in Shanghai for 12.79 billion yuan (S$2.5 billion). The mixed-use development, launched for sale with a reserve price, features four towers, a six-level retail podium, and a rooftop garden. This comes as part of CapitaLand's efforts to expand its presence in China, where it already owns shopping malls and residential developments. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to further boost the company's footprint in the country.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: honestbee cross-pollinates supermart with dining - and sweetens it with tech
summary: Honestbee, a Singapore-based startup, has launched "Habitat" - the world's first tech-enabled, cashless, multi-sensory grocery and dining concept. Occupying 60,000 sq ft, Habitat features a full supermarket, restaurants, and a retail innovation lab, with integrated payment systems and automated retail experiences. The space aims to provide an experiential product, offering customers a multi-sensory shopping experience. Plans are underway to launch Habitat in seven other markets, with the goal of creating a scalable business model.

site_title: Temasek has held talks for stake in China's Anbang, sources say
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state investment firm, has held talks with Chinese authorities about acquiring a stake in Anbang Insurance Group Co, with potential discussions about acquiring some of its assets. This comes as China Insurance Investment Co, a body owned by major insurance firms, also considers investing in Anbang. The talks indicate Beijing's progress in finding strategic investors for Anbang, which was temporarily seized control of by officials in April.

site_title: Trump's USMCA renegotiation is just a charade
summary: US President Donald Trump's renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) with Canada and Mexico, now known as the USMCA, has been met with criticism. The agreement's 16-year sunset clause and retention of the dispute-settlement mechanism are seen as minor improvements, but its overall impact is expected to be negative, including increased costs for production, reduced competitiveness, and potentially fewer jobs. The deal's focus on the car industry and rules-of-origin requirements will likely stifle competition and innovation, and its long-term effects will be to reduce US employment and undermine America's credibility on international trade issues.

site_title: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen dies, aged 65
summary: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, 65, died from complications of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in Seattle. A philanthropist and key figure in transforming Seattle into a cultural center, Allen co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates in 1975. He played a crucial role in developing the company's early software, including MS-DOS and Windows. Allen donated over $2 billion to non-profit groups and invested in the Seattle Seahawks and Portland Trail Blazers. His legacy includes transforming Seattle's South Lake Union neighborhood into a hub for tech companies, including Amazon and Google.

images.alt_text: Mr Allen came up with the company's name Micro-Soft, for a company that made software for small computers. The term personal computer (PC) would become commonplace later.

site_title: As farmers set fire to fields, Delhi braces for choking smog
summary: Fires were set in fields in India's northern Haryana state to prepare for the next season's planting, releasing thick plumes of black smoke into the air. This trend is similar to previous weeks, suggesting authorities' efforts to mitigate pollution in nearby New Delhi may fail. The smoke is expected to contribute to Delhi's notorious smog, which is set to worsen in the coming weeks.

site_title: BP criticises price controls after India cuts retail fuel costs
summary: BP criticizes India's decision to cut fuel prices under price controls, warning it could hinder the sector's long-term growth. The company, which has a partnership with Reliance Industries, expressed concerns about the potential return to price controls. India has cut taxes on diesel and gasoline and asked state companies to reduce prices, but Finance Minister Arun Jaitley and Oil Minister Dharmendra Pradhan have stated the move is not a return to a regulated regime.

site_title: Vigorous exercise safe during pregnancy
summary: Two studies have found that female athletes can exercise safely and intensively during pregnancy without increasing the risk of birth-related complications. Researchers analyzed data from 130 elite female athletes and 118 non-athlete mothers, and found that athletes had healthy pregnancies and fewer delivery complications. One study examined the physiological effects of high-altitude exercise during pregnancy and found that a Sherpa runner, who was 7 months pregnant, was able to complete an 8-day trek with minimal distress. The findings suggest that moderate exercise is healthy for most pregnant women, and that strenuous exercise may not be as detrimental as previously thought.

site_title: First Reit Q3 DPU up 0.5% on boost from latest acquisitions
summary: First Reit's third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) increased 0.5% to 2.15 Singapore cents, boosted by its recent acquisitions of Siloam Hospitals Buton & Lippo Plaza Buton and Siloam Hospitals Yogyakarta. Gross revenue rose 5.1% to S$29.24 million, and net property income increased 5.4% to S$28.94 million. The distributable amount also rose 1.4% year-on-year to S$16.94 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Engineering consultancy, 3 public sector agencies win Excellence Awards
summary: Engineering consultancy Beca Carter Hollings & Ferner (S.E.Asia) and three public sector agencies, the Housing and Development Board (HDB), Institute of Technical Education (ITE), and National Library Board (NLB), have won Excellence Awards in Singapore. The Business Excellence Awards recognize organisations that uphold the country's brand of trust and quality, and are administered by Enterprise Singapore. The awards aim to give organisations a roadmap towards excellence, with the stronger economy being the ultimate goal. This year's winners have demonstrated excellent practices in various areas, including human resource management and data analytics.

images.alt_text: From left: Low Khah Gek, chief executive officer, Institute of Technical Education; Lee Ang Seng, managing director, Beca Carter Hollings & Ferner (S.E. Asia); Cheong Koon Hean, chief executive officer, Housing and Development Board; and Elaine Ng, chief executive officer, National Library Board; at the awards ceremony at Resorts World Sentosa. The awards are conferred by the Singapore Quality Award governing council and administered by Enterprise Singapore.
Janice Heng

site_title: Money flies across tarmac as business jet show gets ready for takeoff
summary: Business jet show in Orlando, Florida, kicked off with deals and announcements on new aircraft models, including Embraer's two new mid-sized jets and Cessna planes sold to NetJets. Supersonic jet developer Aerion Supersonic said it can operate without regulatory changes in the US. The industry expects 7,700 new business jet deliveries worth $251 billion from 2019 to 2028, driven by new aircraft entries and a positive US climate for business jets. However, analysts warn of the risk of weakening prices if production rates increase.

site_title: The aspirational RCEP and why it matters for Asean amid external risks
summary: Asean's Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is crucial amid mounting external risks, including a potential trade war and rising protectionism. The bloc needs to bolster domestic demand and strengthen intra-regional ties to mitigate the impact of external shocks. The disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi has also raised geopolitical tensions, potentially affecting global oil markets and economies. As RCEP talks near completion by year-end, experts emphasize the importance of building domestic defenses and seeking alternative trading partners to counter external risks.

site_title: China golfers backed despite rough year
summary: China golfers, despite a disappointing year, secured spots on the Web.com Tour, one step below the PGA Tour. No Chinese player made the top five, with Englishman Callum Tarren, American Charlie Saxon, and others receiving the opportunity. The PGA Tour China's executive director attributes the lack of Chinese success to injuries and a "culture shock" in the ultra-competitive US golf scene, while maintaining optimism about China's potential to produce future stars.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit DPU up 6.3% in Q3
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 6.3% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.85 Singapore cents, driven by higher rental top-ups and gross rental income. Gross revenue jumped 34% to S$47.6 million, with portfolio occupancy at 93.1% and weighted average lease expiry (WALE) at 8.5 years. The Reit manager expects strong demand for data centre space in European and Asian hubs, driven by hyperscale cloud players and digitalisation.

site_title: Momentum in the East: How Asia will lead the pack in blockchain integration
summary: Asian governments are leading the charge in blockchain integration, with a business-friendly approach that is driving mainstream applications. Despite regulatory uncertainty, projects in the region have pushed forward, developing private data management and P2P markets for gaming and social media. Examples include platforms allowing game licenses to be sold and purchased, and camera apps enabling users to develop and buy filters. Companies are now offering similar services that were once owned by giant industries at high prices, thanks to new blockchain applications. Asia is establishing itself as the leader in blockchain use cases for businesses.

site_title: Picking the right China nationals for the world stage
summary: China's choice of Meng Hongwei as president of Interpol in 2016 has raised concerns about the country's ability to select suitable candidates for global leadership positions. Meng's sudden disappearance and detention on corruption charges have tarnished China's reputation and undermined confidence in Chinese officials leading international institutions. China's growing global influence is partly due to its ability to appoint suitable leaders, as seen in the case of Margaret Chan, a Hong Kong doctor who led the World Health Organization with integrity and expertise. The Meng case highlights the need for China to carefully select candidates who can positively represent the country's interests.

site_title: Saudi Arabia has more to lose than US from an economic showdown
summary: Saudi Arabia is at a disadvantage in an economic showdown with the US, experts say, as the kingdom's reputation would be severely damaged if it uses its oil reserves as leverage. The US, Saudi Arabia's top trading partner, has threatened "severe punishment" for the kingdom's role in journalist Jamal Khashoggi's disappearance. The US may also block arms sales to Saudi Arabia and impose sanctions on the kingdom, putting pressure on the Saudi government to respond. Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is keen to attract international investors to support his economic reform drive, but the kingdom's reputation and economy could suffer if it escalates the crisis.

site_title: Restoration of Rembrandt's masterpiece The Night Watch to be live-streamed
summary: The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam plans to restore Rembrandt's masterpiece "The Night Watch" and live-stream the process online, starting in July 2019. The restoration, which will be open to the museum's 2 million annual visitors, aims to reveal the painting's original intent by showing the officers and militia in motion. The project will allow the public to see behind the scenes of the restoration, which will be carried out on a multi-million-euro budget, and is seen as a way to preserve the painting for future generations.

site_title: Now is the time for Asia-Pacific and Europe to cosy up
summary: The Asia-Europe summit is set to take place this week, bringing together over 50 heads of state and government to strengthen ties and address common interests. The EU aims to develop a European-centric alternative to China's Belt and Road project, while also promoting connectivity and stability in the region. The summit will focus on key areas such as international trade, climate change, and sustainable development, with a strong emphasis on cooperation and multilateralism. EU leaders see significant potential for economic growth and political ties with Asia-Pacific, particularly in the wake of US President Trump's challenges to the rules-based order.

site_title: As cheap as ships?
summary: Shipping costs have decreased for the third consecutive year, with a 1.3% drop in total operating costs in 2017, according to Moore Stephens. This decrease is attributed to lower insurance costs and store expenses. The trend is significant, with all categories of expenditure experiencing a decline compared to the previous year. This decrease is a welcome relief for shipowners and shippers, indicating that the industry is becoming more cost-efficient.

site_title: Closure of US newspapers leaves expanding news 'deserts'
summary: More than 1,800 US newspapers have closed since 2004, leaving thousands of communities with little or no local reporting. The University of North Carolina report found that half of US counties have only one newspaper, and nearly 200 have no newspaper at all. This has resulted in "news deserts" where the most vulnerable communities are often left without access to local news, making it harder to hold public officials accountable. The decline of local newspapers has also reduced coverage of key local issues, with most efforts to fill the gap being clustered around major metropolitan areas.

site_title: Japan's tourist numbers drop for first time in 5 years
summary: Japan's tourist numbers dropped 5.3% in September, the first year-on-year contraction in over five years, due to natural disasters including a typhoon and earthquake. Visitor numbers from China and South Korea also declined, with China's 3.8% drop partly attributed to the country's economic slowdown. The decline may weigh on Japan's tourism growth, which is crucial to the country's economic policy, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aiming to attract 40 million foreign tourists by 2020.

site_title: GIC makes two European investments
summary: GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, has made two European investments: a 465 million-euro office building in Paris, the Tour Ariane, and a significant minority stake in Nordic Aviation Capital (NAC), a Danish aircraft lessor. NAC is the world's largest regional aircraft lessor, with a fleet of 468 regional aircraft. GIC will partner with existing shareholders EQT VI and founder Martin Møller to support the company's growth. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2018.

site_title: Wells Fargo to shift European investment banking business to Paris as Brexit looms
summary: Wells Fargo has applied for an investment firm license in France to shift its European investment banking business to Paris as Brexit looms. The San Francisco-based bank will continue to serve UK and non-EU clients from London, while a new Paris-based subsidiary will provide services for European and international customers requiring access to the EU and the European Economic Area. This move aims to maintain business continuity and access to the EU market post-Brexit.

site_title: Sears bankruptcy gives landlords opportunity to refresh their malls
summary: Sears' bankruptcy has given landlords the opportunity to renovate and boost rent at malls where the retailer has anchor tenants. Most large US malls are controlled by real estate investment trusts (Reits) that have reduced their exposure to Sears Holdings. This shift allows Reits to refresh their properties, potentially straining some redevelopment plans due to increased costs. The move could lead to a renewed focus on mall renovations and rent increases, impacting the retail landscape.

site_title: Collaboration among partners crucial for Industry 4.0 to take off: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam of Singapore stated that Industry 4.0, or the fourth industrial revolution, poses a challenge as it may lead to fewer manufacturing jobs, but offers higher-quality jobs. Tharman emphasized that collaboration among partners is crucial for the industry to take off.

site_title: Global steel body hikes demand forecasts, but says risks remain
summary: The World Steel Association has doubled its 2018 and 2019 forecasts for global steel demand growth, predicting a 1.4% rise in 2019 to 1.681 billion tonnes. However, the association notes that trade tensions, particularly between the US and China, pose uncertainty and risk to the sector. Despite this, China's steel demand is expected to rise 6% this year and remain flat in 2019, driven by government stimulus measures to maintain economic growth.

site_title: India's cenbank lays out rules to make mobile wallet payments seamless
summary: India's central bank has laid out guidelines to make mobile wallet payments seamless, allowing users to send and receive money from different wallets. This move aims to boost digital payments in the country, with projections suggesting a five-fold growth to $1 trillion by 2023. The Reserve Bank of India's state-backed payments network will enable instant peer-to-peer transactions, creating more business opportunities and increasing the growth rate of digital payments.

images.alt_text: Mobile wallets such as the one run by SoftBank and Alibaba-backed Paytm have become popular in India after a ban on high-value currency in late 2016 pushed people to pay digitally.

site_title: The dirty truth about clean electric cars
summary: Manufacturers of electric vehicles are using lithium-ion batteries produced in places with high-polluting grids, contradicting the eco-friendly image of electric cars. By 2021, over 10 million batteries will be produced, mostly in China, Thailand, Germany, and Poland, which rely on coal for electricity. This highlights the contradiction between the environmental benefits of electric cars and the environmental impact of their production. The reliance on non-renewable energy sources for battery production raises concerns about the overall emissions reduction potential of electric vehicles.

site_title: TEE Int'l bags S$58m worth of engineering contracts
summary: TEE International has secured engineering contracts worth about S$58 million, bringing its order book to approximately S$304 million. The contracts include a replacement of a fixed gangway at Changi Airport and A&A works at Singapore Institute of Technology. TEE's subsidiary PBT Engineering also secured sub-contract work for electrical services at a light industrial development and a project term contract with Singtel Data Centres. The company's shares closed down 0.2 Singapore cent, or 1.042%, on the news.

site_title: US judge approves SEC settlement with Tesla, shares jump
summary: A US judge approved a settlement between Tesla and CEO Elon Musk over his tweets promising to take the company private, ending a tumultuous period for investors. Musk agreed to pay a $20 million fine and step aside as chairman for three years, while Tesla also paid a $20 million fine. The company must appoint an independent chairman and set controls over Musk's communications. Tesla shares rose 5.5% after the settlement, despite still being down over 20% since the initial tweets.

images.alt_text: A US judge on Tuesday approved a settlement between a federal regulator, Tesla Inc and its chief executive officer, Elon Musk, over his tweets promising to take the company private, signaling an end to a tumultuous period for investors.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Vard Holdings, Wheelock Properties, and Qian Hu Corporation are set to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange due to exit offers by Fincantieri Oil & Gas and parent Wheelock & Company. Qian Hu reported a 23.2% increase in net profit despite declining revenue. Blumont Group has revised its acquisition of Samadhi Retreats, and Jiutian Chemical Group expects to report a net loss for the third quarter. IEV Holdings is proposing to dispose of its stake in loss-making subsidiary PT IEV Gas for a total consideration of S$677,554. Trading in the shares of these companies will be suspended or delisted.

site_title: Helping Singapore overcome its limitation: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the potential of Industry 4.0 to help Singapore overcome its limitations in size and manpower, enabling the country to compete globally. However, changing the mindset of top and middle management is a major obstacle, according to panellists. To overcome this, the government can invest in learning and development programs, such as vocational training and digital education, and support companies in developing Industry 4.0-related talents. If successful, these efforts could lead to a transformative change in Singapore's manufacturing landscape within 5-10 years.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust reports flat DPU for Q3; confirms interest in Ixom
summary: Keppel Infra Trust reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents for Q3 2018, down 47.4% from the same period in 2017. Net profit was also down 47.4% to S$8.15 million. Lower contributions from City Gas and Basslink, as well as a higher fair-value loss of derivatives, contributed to the decline. The trust confirmed its interest in Australian chemical firm Ixom, but warned of no certainty in a potential transaction.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher led by tech stocks
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, led by technology stocks, as upbeat earnings from blue-chip companies eased concerns over the impact of the US-China trade war and global issues on corporate profits. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 100.98 points, or 0.40%, to 25,351.53, while the S&P 500 gained 16.26 points, or 0.59%, to 2,767.05.

site_title: Datapulse responds to SGX queries on full-year results
summary: Datapulse Technology responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its full-year financial results. The company attributed a significant rise in other operating expenses to increased legal and professional costs, lower exchange gains, and operating expenses from a newly-acquired subsidiary. Datapulse changed its accounting policy for measuring investment property to fair value, which did not impact the group's financial statements. The company also explained an impairment loss recognized on goodwill related to its investment in Wayco, citing a valuation exercise that showed no impairment on the properties.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: VCs to play significant role in age of innovation and disruption
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the significant role venture capitalists (VCs) will play in the age of innovation and disruption, connecting industry sectors and fostering an innovation-driven economy. VCs' greatest value-add lies in their networks, experience, and macro view. Heng also noted that Singapore should compete and cooperate with other digital economies, focusing on areas like artificial intelligence to distinguish itself.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust confirms participation in sale process for Australian chemical firm Ixom
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has confirmed its participation in the sale process for Australian chemical firm Ixom Holdco Pty Ltd, which is controlled by Blackstone Group. Ixom manufactures essential water treatment chemicals and owns an extensive infrastructure network. According to reports, a potential sale could fetch over US$1 billion. KIT advised unitholders to exercise caution and stated that further announcements would be made as necessary.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Fuelling returns with clean energy
summary: Global demand for renewable energy is surging, with investment in clean energy funds offering a chance to combine profit with environmental principles. The International Energy Agency reports that solar- and wind-powered electricity generation is outpacing coal- and natural-gas-fuelled generation. Billionaire Warren Buffett's MidAmerican Energy aims to obtain 100% of its electricity from wind power by 2020. Green energy funds, such as Fidelity's and New Alternatives, have returned an average of 6-9.75% over the past five years, outperforming the S&P 500 index. Investing in these funds can signal consumer interest and create a virtuous cycle, potentially pulling in more money and driving further investment.

site_title: PM Lee on visit to Austria and Belgium
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is on a visit to Austria and Belgium, meeting with European leaders and signing a landmark free trade agreement with the EU. The agreement, known as the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), covers areas such as digitalisation, electronic commerce, and emerging technologies. The visit also includes the 12th Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM) Summit, where leaders will discuss global challenges and deepen cooperation between Europe and South-east Asia. Lee will also sign a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in digitalisation and information and communications technology.

site_title: From disruptor to disrupted: Circles.Life has come full circle
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based virtual telco, is shifting its focus from the competitive consumer market to non-telco consumer services. The company is launching a top-up plan and developing an events app, marking a more aggressive expansion strategy. This move contrasts with its previous cross-promotions with partners like DBS Bank and oBike. Circles.Life's new direction aims to diversify its offerings and invest more heavily in its services.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: France preparing Channel Tunnel checks in case of 'no deal' Brexit
summary: France is preparing for a potential "no deal" Brexit by imposing checks at the Channel Tunnel, a senior minister warned. France's Europe minister Nathalie Loiseau said preparations are underway, including emergency legislation to deal with the chaos expected in the event of "no deal." The measures will include checks on the Channel Tunnel, which carries substantial numbers of passengers and freight, as well as those related to French and British citizens. The preparations come as Brexit talks are on a knife-edge, with a summit in Brussels set for Wednesday.

site_title: PACC Offshore recovers S$3.4m from Kensteel Engineering
summary: PACC Offshore Services recovered approximately S$3.4 million from Kensteel Engineering Pte Ltd, following a court ruling in its favor on a counterclaim for a failed property purchase. PACC Offshore had made a counterclaim for the return of a deposit and GST paid, as well as interest and costs. The High Court initially ruled in PACC Offshore's favor on August 2, with costs to be determined at a later hearing.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: US industrial output rises in September
summary: US industrial production rose 0.3% in September, following a 0.4% increase in August, as manufacturing and mining output grew. The 3.3% annualized rate in the third quarter was slower than the 5.3% pace in the second quarter. The Federal Reserve attributed the September increase to gains despite a "slight" impact from Hurricane Florence, estimated at less than 0.1 percentage point.

site_title: Stand together, Britain's May calls for unity on Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged her ministers to stand together in support of her Brexit strategy, aiming to secure a deal despite pressure to rethink it. May's Cabinet rejected any deal that would split the UK and might trap it in the Irish backstop indefinitely. The EU remains unwilling to compromise on the backstop, and a 'no deal' Brexit is increasingly possible, potentially disrupting trade and investment. May's spokesman said she is committed to delivering a Brexit that safeguards jobs and security, and preserves the union.

site_title: Temasek launches first 5-year bond for retail investors with fixed rate of 2.7%
summary: Temasek Holdings has launched its first 5-year bond for retail investors with a fixed interest rate of 2.7% per annum. Up to S$200 million is offered to retail investors, with another S$200 million for institutional investors. The bond, T2023-S$, has been rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by S&P, indicating minimal credit risk. The net proceeds will be used to fund the group's ordinary business activities. The bond offers a 38 basis point pick-up over the 5-year Singapore government bond, attracting retail investors seeking a relatively stable investment option.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: German prosecutors fine Audi 800m euros for diesel violations
summary: Audi, a division of Volkswagen, has been fined 800 million euros by German prosecutors for violating anti-pollution standards in its six- and eight-cylinder diesel engines. The company accepts the fine and will not appeal, admitting responsibility for the deviations. The fine is expected to significantly impact Audi's financial key performance indicators for the fiscal year 2018. Parent Volkswagen also warned that the fine will affect its earnings.

site_title: Uber proposals value company at US$120b in a possible IPO
summary: Uber Technologies Inc could be valued at US$120 billion when it goes public next year, according to recent proposals from US banks Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. This valuation is higher than Uber's previous valuation of US$76 billion after a US$500 million investment from Toyota Motor Corp in August. Uber is preparing for its IPO, but is behind smaller rival Lyft in its preparations. The company has hired a new chief financial officer and is working on its IPO plans, but declined to comment on the valuation report.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit Q3 DPU up 6.3%
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 6.3% increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.85 Singapore cents, driven by higher rental top-ups. Gross revenue jumped 34% to S$47.6 million, with gross rental income rising 30.2%. Net property income rose 33.4% to S$43 million, and portfolio occupancy stood at 93.1%. The Reit's net asset value per unit increased to S$1.02, and assets under management stood at S$1.95 billion. Demand for data centre space remains strong, driven by hyperscale cloud players and digitalisation.

site_title: Trump tears into 'Pocahontas' rival Democrat
summary: President Donald Trump has continued to mock Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren, calling her "Pocahontas" after she released a DNA test showing a small Native American heritage. Trump claims the test was "bogus" and that the Cherokee Nation has rejected her claim, despite the tribe's statement that a DNA test is not a reliable method for determining tribal citizenship. Warren's claim has sparked frustration in the indigenous community, with the Cherokee Nation Secretary of State stating that her claims are "dishonoring legitimate tribal governments and their citizens."

site_title: Google CEO says 'important to explore' China project
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai acknowledged the company's consideration of a search engine in China, citing the potential to offer "better information" to users. The project, codenamed Project Dragonfly, aims to understand what Google could offer if it resumed its search operations in China. Pichai emphasized the importance of exploring the market and taking a "long-term view" despite criticism over potential cooperation with Chinese censorship. He highlighted areas where Google could provide better information, such as medical treatments, and expressed a desire to serve China's large user base.

site_title: NUS commits up to S$2.5m to 50 startups
summary: NUS commits up to S$2.5 million to fund 50 startups through the Stephen Riady Young Entrepreneur Scholarship, which provides seed funding of up to S$50,000 to recipients who are keen to start a business venture after graduation. The scholarship covers tuition fees and living allowances for four years, and recipients will receive mentorship and guidance from NUS Enterprise. The university also plans to co-create up to 250 companies over the next five years with a commitment of S$25 million. The initiative aims to nurture entrepreneurial talent in Singapore and support the growth of startups.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Reit's 9M 2018 results came in broadly in line with expectations, with a 9-month DPU of 4.2 S cents/share, 72% of the full-year estimate. Third-quarter net property income declined 10.9% due to lower contributions from certain properties, but was partly mitigated by increased contributions from Bugis Junction Towers. The company's Singapore office portfolio remains firm, with high overall committed occupancy at 98%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.25% to 22,549.24, and the Topix index increasing 0.74% to 1,687.91. Investors took advantage of recent losses to bargain hunt, driving the gains.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% on Tuesday, closing at 3,034.31, with Allied Tech rising 10.5% as the most actively traded counter. Gainers beat losers 185-179, with about 1.8 billion shares changing hands. Other active stocks included Genting Singapore and DBS, which lost 1.6% and fell almost 1%, respectively.

site_title: China fines pharma firm US$1.3b in vaccine scandal
summary: Chinese authorities have fined pharmaceutical company Changchun Changsheng Biotechnology US$1.3 billion for a vaccine scandal that involved fabricating records of a rabies vaccine. The firm's chairwoman and 14 others were arrested in July, and officials have been sacked. The company was ordered to cease production after it was found that suspect vaccines did not enter the market, but the case sparked outrage among consumers. The fine includes the forfeiture of 1.89 billion yuan in revenue from the sale of the vaccine, as part of efforts to punish the company for the scandal.

images.alt_text: The massive fine is the latest move by authorities to punish Changchun Changsheng Biotechnology company, based in northeast Jilin province, over the faulty rabies vaccine.

site_title: EC World Reit gets right of first refusal on Bei Gang Logistics Stage 2 properties
summary: EC World Reit chose not to acquire Stage 2 properties of Bei Gang Logistics for 702.5 million yuan (S$140 million), exercising its right of first refusal instead. The Reit's manager cited the lack of accretion to distribution per unit as a reason for the decision. EC World Reit will continue to explore opportunities for yield-accretive assets, maintaining its exploration of third-party acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Trump's Saudi dilemma: Realpolitik vs liberal internationalism
summary: President Trump faces a dilemma with Saudi Arabia over the unresolved fate of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who disappeared after entering the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul. The Turkish government alleges that a Saudi hit team tortured and murdered Khashoggi, with evidence suggesting his body was dismembered and sent to Saudi Arabia. Trump has urged Saudi Arabia to explain the circumstances, saying "the whole world is watching." The incident has raised questions about Trump's approach to international relations, pitting his desire for realpolitik against liberal internationalism.

images.alt_text: A demonstrator dressed as Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman with "blood" on his hands outside the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Washington, DC.

site_title: Talks begin on disarming Korean border village
summary: Talks began in Seoul on disarming the Korean border village of Panmunjom, a 1 1/2-mile-wide buffer zone that has divided the peninsula since the 1953 Korean War armistice. Officials from North and South Korea and the UN will discuss erasing the demarcation line, disarming military guards, and moving sentry posts to the zone's perimeters. The move aims to create an unarmed neutral enclave where military guards and tourists can move freely. The agreement is part of a series of inter-Korean projects to improve relations and ease military tensions.

site_title: Blumont announces changes to proposed acquisition of Samadhi Retreats
summary: Blumont Group has revised its proposed acquisition of Samadhi Retreats Pte Ltd, excluding two entities initially included in the agreement. The revised aggregate consideration is S$35 million, with S$7 million paid in cash and S$28 million by issuing 9.2 billion shares at 0.3043 Singapore cents. The revised issue price represents a premium of 21% and 12% over the volume-weighted average prices for the one-month and three-month periods, respectively.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Jiutian Chemical Group expects net loss for Q3
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group, a Catalist-listed company, expects to report a net loss for the third quarter ended September 30, primarily due to increased raw material costs and low production levels. The losses are attributed to strict environmental controls and low product prices. Further details will be released on November 14. The company advises shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares, which closed unchanged at 3.1 Singapore cents on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q3 DPU stable at 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a stable DPU of 0.93 Singapore cents for Q3 2018, unchanged from the previous year. The trust's profit attributable to shareholders decreased 47.4% to S$8.15 million, due to lower contributions from City Gas and Basslink. Revenue was up 1.1% to S$162 million, with City Gas achieving 100% plant availability and higher revenue due to higher fuel prices. Distributions to unitholders and fair-value losses of financial derivative instruments contributed to the decline in net asset value per unit.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: First Reit Q3 DPU up 0.5%
summary: First Reit reported a 0.5% year-on-year increase in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.15 Singapore cents. Gross revenue rose 5.1% to S$29.24 million, driven by contributions from new acquisitions and existing properties. The trust's CEO, Victor Tan, expects the proposed acquisition of Bowsprit by OUE Lippo Healthcare to be a growth driver, allowing First Reit to access a more diversified pool of assets and expand its geographical reach in Asia.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Qian Hu Q3 net profit up 23% to S$175,000
summary: Qian Hu Corporation reported a 23.2% rise in net profit to S$175,000 for the third quarter, despite a 4.7% decline in revenue to S$21.4 million. The company attributed the decline to fewer orders during the World Cup season and intense price competition in the dragon fish business. Operating profits rose 9.3% in the fish segment and 21.5% in accessories, driven by higher sales of innovative products. The company remains optimistic about its export business and continues to focus on driving efficiency and boosting margins.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: IEV Holdings disposes of stake in Indonesian unit IEV Gas
summary: IEV Holdings proposes to dispose of its entire 95% stake in Indonesian unit IEV Gas for 960 million rupiah (S$87,000) due to the loss-making mobile natural gas business in Indonesia. The company aims to exit the business and stem losses. PT Digas Energi Semesta, led by Achwan Widiyanto, will acquire the remaining 5% stake. The disposal is expected to continue operating at a loss, draining the group's financial resources.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks gain in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.49% in early trade on Tuesday, recovering from recent losses due to concerns about global economic growth. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 25,568.84, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices remained flat. This rebound comes as traders brush off new US threats, focusing on extended stock rallies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Tuesday, rising 8.1 points to 1,736.84. The index saw a volume of 1.53 billion lots worth RM1.62 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 439 to 339.

site_title: Vard to delist on Nov 2; requests trading halt
summary: SHIPBUILDER Vard Holdings will be delisted from the market on November 2 due to the close of its exit offer by Fincantieri Oil & Gas, which acquired approximately 95.99% of its issued share capital. The exit offer closed at 5:30pm on Monday, with Fincantieri Oil & Gas paying S$26.97 million for tendered shares and S$22.1 million for acquired shares. Trading in Vard shares will be suspended on November 2.

site_title: Jurong Innovation District to house advanced manufacturing campus
summary: Singapore's Jurong Innovation District to house an advanced manufacturing campus with Industry 4.0 capabilities. The campus will provide access to research and development, capability developers, and technology enablers for firms to upgrade their manufacturing technologies. PBA Group, a robotics manufacturing firm, is set to commence operations in 2020, with a 260,000 sq ft facility featuring a training academy and technology incubator. This development aims to accelerate the adoption of smart manufacturing technologies in the district over the next two years.

site_title: Indonesia may suspend Australia trade deal over Jerusalem stance
summary: Indonesia is considering suspending a free trade deal with Australia due to Prime Minister Scott Morrison's support for moving the Australian embassy in Israel to Jerusalem. This move has upset Indonesia, which supports a Palestinian state and has been pressing for a positive relationship with Canberra. The deal, which was set to be signed before the end of the year, is now in doubt, and Indonesian Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi has been in contact with her Australian counterpart, expressing concerns.

site_title: Rembrandt masterpiece 'The Night Watch' to be restored - live
summary: The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam plans to restore Rembrandt's "The Night Watch" in a unique, public and livestreamed process starting in July 2019. The multi-million-euro restoration will be open to 2 million annual visitors and provide a rare glimpse into the restoration process. The project aims to return the 1642 tableau to its full glory, showcasing the Dutch master's work to a wider audience.

images.alt_text: Amsterdam's famous Rijksmuseum is to restore the Rembrandt masterpiece "The Night Watch" under the full gaze of the public, as well as livestreaming it online, the museum said on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Shares bounce from 22-month low as earnings flow in
summary: European shares rose 0.2% in early trading on Tuesday, bouncing from a 22-month low, as investors awaited earnings reports from companies. Defensive stocks like utilities and telecoms led gains, with Enel and Deutsche Telekom up 3.4% and 1.4%, respectively. Despite the rally, caution remained due to ongoing US-China trade tensions, Brexit talks, and geopolitical concerns. Some companies, like Merlin and Volvo, fell after downbeat trading updates. The pan-European STOXX 600 index is expected to deliver double-digit earnings growth for the third quarter.

images.alt_text: European shares rose in early trading on Tuesday helped by stronger defensive stocks, as the focus turned to the start of the reporting season which is expected to deliver double-digit earnings growth for the third quarter.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks steady; won edges up
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed flat on Tuesday, ending the day unchanged at 2,145.12. The won rose against the US dollar, while bond yields fell. Global uncertainties, including Brexit and US-China trade tensions, capped gains. The US dollar has risen 5.79% against the won this year, and South Korea's central bank is expected to keep its benchmark rate steady at 1.50% in its policy meeting on Thursday.

site_title: China's Q3 GDP growth seen hitting lowest since 2009 on trade war toll: Poll
summary: China's third-quarter GDP growth is expected to slow to 6.6% from 6.7% in the previous quarter, the weakest pace since 2009, due to the toll of the US-China trade war. Domestic demand has been faltering, with weakening infrastructure investment and consumer spending. Policymakers have unveiled measures to lower financing costs and cut taxes, but analysts believe more support is needed as risks to China's growth outlook have increased. The predicted growth rate is still higher than the government's full-year target of 6.5%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek Holdings plans to offer 5-year bonds for up to S$400m to retail investors, marking its first corporate bond issue with a public offer tranche. This move aims to provide more investment opportunities for retail investors. Meanwhile, Vietnam surprised by Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate, while the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Wheelock Properties to be delisted on Oct 18
summary: Wheelock Properties will be delisted on October 18, 9am, following a voluntary unconditional general offer by its parent company, Wheelock and Company, which acquired 90.1% of its shares. Trading of its shares on the Singapore Exchange has been suspended since the close of the offer.

site_title: China local governments' hidden debt could total 40 trillion yuan: S&P
summary: China's local governments may owe up to 40 trillion yuan in hidden debt, according to S&P Global Ratings. This debt, outside of the annual debt quota, could have reached 60% of the country's GDP in 2017. China has vowed to curb local government debt, but progress has been limited, and the country may take a decade or more to address the issue, which poses "titanic credit risks."

images.alt_text: Off-balance-sheet borrowings by Chinese local governments could be as high as 40 trillion yuan (S$7.95 trillion) and amount to "a debt iceberg with titanic credit risks", S&P Global Ratings said in a report on Tuesday.

site_title: Anwar pledges to let Dr M get on with governing for now
summary: Malaysia's leader-in-waiting Anwar Ibrahim returned to Parliament, vowing to give Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad space to govern. Anwar, who was released from jail after a shock election victory in May, pledged not to take a Cabinet position, instead focusing on supporting the government. He also stated that he would not contest for a leadership role, citing a desire for a more relaxed role. The two former foes formed an unlikely alliance, with Dr. Mahathir pledging to hand power to Anwar within two years.

site_title: Australian shares end up on bounce in financials, sentiment still fragile; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 5,868.9, supported by a bounce in domestic banks and a rebound in the metals and mining index. This followed a 1% decline on Monday, the lowest in six months. The country's biggest export market, China, saw factory-gate inflation cool for a third straight month. Meanwhile, tensions between Saudi Arabia and the West limited broader market gains. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4% for the 11th consecutive session.

site_title: This bank halved clients while doubling assets under management
summary: Germany's DZ Privatbank has nearly doubled assets under management to over $28.7 billion while halving the number of clients from 50,000 to 30,000 over the past eight years. CEO Stefan Schwab attributes the shift to larger, more efficient mandates. Assets under management per client have tripled to $600,000, and the bank aims to reach $20 billion within two years. Expansion into new branches and offices throughout Germany has improved the bank's presence, with eight branches now operating.

site_title: Ex-Malaysian PM Najib summoned by graft agency over new 1MDB-linked case
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak has been summoned by the anti-graft agency for questioning over a new case linked to 1MDB, a state fund he founded in 2009. This is the fifth time he has been summoned, and the case is believed to involve alleged abuse of power related to contract procurement matters. Najib faces 32 charges, including money laundering and abuse of power, which could lead to up to 15 years in jail and a fine of up to RM5 million.

site_title: Collaboration key for Industry 4.0 to take off: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for collaboration to unlock Industry 4.0's full potential. He highlighted three key areas: a common framework, such as the Singapore Smart Industry Readiness Index, and the Index Partners Network, which supports manufacturers through partnerships. Building a robust community, as seen at the inaugural Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific (ITAP) event, is also crucial. Furthermore, workers must be helped to benefit from Industry 4.0 transformation. Tharman stressed the importance of collaboration across geographical and industry boundaries to accelerate Industry 4.0 transformation in the region.

site_title: China's factory-gate inflation cools for 3rd month, points to slackening demand
summary: China's factory-gate inflation cooled for a third straight month in September, indicating a slackening in domestic demand amid the intensifying trade war with the US. Consumer inflation rose slightly, mainly driven by higher food prices, while the producer price index (PPI) rose 3.6% from a year earlier. The central bank governor sees room for interest rate adjustments due to significant downside risks from the trade row, and economic activity has been slowing down.

site_title: Singapore, Germany to boost startup collaboration
summary: Singapore and Germany have signed a memorandum of understanding to boost startup collaboration, with a two-year program for Singapore-based startups to enter Germany and Europe. The Scalerator program will support over 40 startups in areas like 3D printing, clean tech, and digital health. Additionally, 10 students from Singapore polytechnics have been awarded scholarships to study and gain work experience at German SMEs. This marks Germany's entry into the Global Innovation Alliance Network, strengthening ties between the two countries.

site_title: Temasek said to have held talks for stake in China's Anbang
summary: Singapore's state investment firm Temasek Holdings has held talks with Chinese authorities about acquiring a stake in Anbang Insurance Group Co and some of its assets. Temasek has been examining a potential deal for several months and is not currently in active negotiations. China Insurance Investment Co is also considering investing in Anbang, indicating Beijing's progress in finding strategic investors for the insurer. The talks come almost eight months after officials seized control of Anbang and put its chairman in jail, marking a step towards replacing an industry security fund that injected capital into the insurer.

site_title: Surbana Jurong acquires two architectural firms
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean group, has acquired Canadian firm B+H and Singapore firm SAA Architects, expanding its capabilities in sectors such as healthcare, hospitality, and urban development. The move aims to boost revenue and enhance its urban capabilities, particularly in architecture, civil structure, and project management. The acquisitions bring greater market access and talent, with B+H offering expertise in hospitality and healthcare, and SAA possessing capabilities in transport and healthcare. The group's CEO, Wong Heang Fine, stated that the acquisitions are more about talent than revenue contribution, but will help Surbana Jurong push the design envelope.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Pharma manufacturing in Singapore gets S$34m boost
summary: A consortium agreement valued at S$34 million, known as the Pharma Innovation Programme Singapore (PIPS), was signed to drive the transformation of Singapore's pharmaceutical manufacturing industry. PIPS is a partnership between A*Star, NUS, NTU, SIT, and pharma companies GlaxoSmithKline, MSD International, and Pfizer Asia Pacific. The program aims to increase productivity and operational efficiency through technology and data analytics, focusing on areas such as continuous manufacturing and digitalisation. The sector, which contributes 3% to Singapore's GDP, will benefit from the initiative, enabling more sustainable processes and quicker production of active pharmaceutical ingredients.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise as global uncertainties ease; won climbs
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.39% to 2,153.39 at 0234 GMT, driven by easing global uncertainties and a decrease in the rift between Saudi Arabia and the West. The won strengthened to 1,126.6 per US dollar, and Hyundai Motor shares gained over 3%. This marks a recovery from an eight-year low hit in the previous session. The Kospi has dropped 13.1% so far this year, but the recent gains may indicate a stabilization in the market.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower after volatile session
summary: US stocks ended lower Monday after a volatile session, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 0.9% to 7,430.74. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4% to 25,250.55, and the S&P 500 lost 0.6% to 2,750.79. Analysts attributed the market's uncertainty to rising US interest rates and trade wars, with some predicting further declines. Despite retail sales showing a 0.1% gain in September, IHS Markit trimmed its holiday shopping season forecast to 4.7% growth.

site_title: Hong Kong metro train signaling glitch sparks peak-hour chaos
summary: A signaling system fault in Hong Kong's metro network caused peak-hour chaos, delaying trains by 40 minutes and forcing thousands of commuters to wait for buses and taxis. The Island, Kwun Tong, and Tsuen Wan lines were affected, with trains running at slower speeds and limited services. At some stations, escalators were halted to manage crowds, with passengers waiting for over 30 minutes. An MTR press conference was held to address the issue, which is currently under investigation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.16 points to 1,728.17 on Tuesday, driven by a gain of 222 stocks over 162 losers. The market saw a higher opening with 227.36 million lots traded worth RM126.98 million.

site_title: Advanced Holdings requests trading halt
summary: Advanced Holdings has requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The supplier of proprietary process equipment and clean energy solutions reported a net profit of S$206,000 in the second quarter, compared to a net loss of S$1.1 million in the same quarter last year. Advanced Holdings proposed to acquire Agricore Global via a reverse takeover, with a long stop date extended to October 12.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading lower at 3,037.42, down 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed afternoon trading on Tuesday, down 0.3% to 3,037.42, following a 5-day rally. Allied Technology rose 5.3% and was the most actively traded counter, while DBS fell 1% and OCBC lost 0.6%. The Straits Times Index fell 8.55 points, with 862.2 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 152 to 142.

site_title: Temasek to debut tranche for retail investors with planned offer of 5-year bonds for up to S$400m
summary: Temasek Holdings plans to issue a 5-year bond with a public offer tranche for retail investors, offering up to S$400m in aggregate principal amount. The bond, expected to be rated "Aaa" by Moody's and "AAA" by S&P, will feature a 2.74% interest rate per annum. This is Temasek's first corporate bond issue with a public offer tranche for retail investors, following the establishment of a S$5 billion guaranteed medium term note programme in August 2018.

site_title: Trade show sees launch of Index Partners Network, standards mapping tool to aid Singapore manufacturers
summary: The Index Partners Network was launched at the Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific trade show to aid Singapore manufacturers in accelerating Industry 4.0 initiatives. The network will comprise four categories of partners to support manufacturers' transformation journey. Additionally, a standards mapping tool, SmS, was announced to map relevant national and international standards to the Index, providing good practices for interoperability, reliability, safety, and cybersecurity. The tool will be made available on the Singapore Manufacturing Federation's website from October 16.

site_title: Harvard admissions trial opens with university accused of bias against Asian Americans
summary: Harvard University is facing a federal trial over allegations of bias against Asian American applicants. Students for Fair Admissions claims the university penalizes Asian Americans for their race, particularly in subjective personal qualities, which can significantly impact the outcome. The trial centers on statistical analyses showing Harvard gives Asian Americans lower ratings for leadership and compassion compared to applicants from other racial groups. If proven, the case could set a precedent in the debate over affirmative action.

images.alt_text: Accusations that the Harvard University admissions process is rigged against Asian Americans were lobbed and parried on Monday as the trial opened in a case that could become another landmark in the long debate over affirmative action.

site_title: GIC makes two European investments in property, aircraft industry
summary: Sovereign wealth fund GIC has made two European investments. It acquired a 465 million euros Paris office building and a minority stake in Nordic Aviation Capital (NAC), the world's largest regional aircraft lessor. GIC will become a significant minority investor in NAC alongside existing shareholders EQT VI and founder Martin Møller. Separately, GIC also agreed to buy Tour Ariane, a 40-storey office tower in the La Défense business district, for about 465 million euros.

site_title: Asia: Stocks bounce modestly but Saudi tensions limit gains
summary: Asian stocks modestly rose on Tuesday, gaining ground after a week of losses, but tensions between Saudi Arabia and the West limited gains amid the disappearance of a Saudi journalist critical of Riyadh. US President Donald Trump sent Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to Saudi Arabia, straining the relationship between strategic allies. The Dow has lost 4.5% this month due to high US bond yields, while the yen and Swiss franc gained as perceived safe havens.

site_title: World's first tech-enabled grocery, dining concept 'habitat by honestbee' makes debut
summary: honestbee launches 'habitat by honestbee', a 60,000 sq. ft. tech-enabled grocery and dining destination in Singapore, featuring a supermarket, restaurant, and innovation lab. The concept includes AutoCheckout and RoboCollect, allowing for cashless checkout and automated bag collection. Orders can be processed in as little as five minutes. The innovation lab will partner with businesses to develop new retail solutions and enhance the customer experience. Honestbee aims to revolutionize the retail industry with its 'NewGen Retail' concept, harnessing technology for quality human interaction.

site_title: US judge tosses out Stormy Daniels defamation suit against Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump won his first major legal victory as a federal judge rejected Stormy Daniels' defamation suit against him. The judge, S James Otero, ruled that Trump's tweet claiming Daniels invented threats to silence her was "rhetorical hyperbole" protected by the First Amendment. This decision comes after Daniels filed a defamation suit in January, alleging Trump made false statements about her. A separate lawsuit against Trump remains, linked to $130,000 in hush money paid to Daniels before the 2016 presidential election. Daniels' lawyer plans to appeal the decision.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump scored his first major legal victory on Monday against porn star Stormy Daniels, as a federal US judge rejected her defamation suit against him.

site_title: Australia congratulates royal couple on news of first child
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison congratulated Prince Harry and Meghan on their pregnancy, the first child for the royal couple. The announcement was made by Kensington Palace, stating the child will be seventh in line to the throne. The royal couple is currently touring Australia, visiting iconic landmarks such as the Sydney Opera House and Taronga Zoo, before heading to New Zealand and the South Pacific islands.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.38% to 3,057.60
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.38% to 3,057.60 at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index gaining 11.63 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 60 to 37, driven by 26.8 million securities worth S$35.8 million changing hands. Key performers included DBS Group Holdings (up 0.4%) and Singtel (up 0.3%). The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally, with investors brushing off new Trump threats to extend their stock rally.

site_title: TEE International bags S$58m worth of engineering contracts
summary: TEE International secured engineering contracts worth about S$58 million, bringing its outstanding order book to S$304 million. The contracts include a replacement of fixed gangways at Changi Airport Terminal 1, 2, and 3, as well as A&A works at Singapore Institute of Technology's SIT@Dover campus and Singtel Data Centres. TEE International shares rose 2.67% on Monday to close at S$0.192, following the announcement.

site_title: Annual US budget deficit hits six-year high of US$779b
summary: The US budget deficit reached a six-year high of $779 billion in the 2018 fiscal year, exceeding $3.3 trillion in revenue and $4.1 trillion in spending. The deficit was attributed to the cost of last year's sweeping tax cuts, with corporate tax receipts dropping sharply. The Treasury Department warned that the growing debt burden would become increasingly costly to finance.

site_title: Bezos defends Amazon effort for Pentagon cloud project
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos defended the company's bid for a $10 billion Pentagon cloud computing contract, stating it's essential to support US defense efforts despite potential controversy. Bezos emphasized that the US is a great country that needs to be defended, and big tech companies should not turn their back on the Department of Defense. He also criticized Google for dropping its bid, saying it's a concern for the country's future. Bezos' comments come as Microsoft and Amazon remain in the running for the contract.

site_title: Oil steadies as Saudi tensions balance demand outlook
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday, supported by geopolitical tensions over the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, which raised concerns about supplies from Saudi Arabia. Brent crude futures rose 35 cents to $80.78 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 44 cents to $71.78 a barrel. Despite rising tensions, long-term demand outlook remains a concern, and some analysts predict a potential undersupplied market if Saudi Arabia does not increase production amid falling Iranian exports.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust said to near deal for Blackstone-owned chemical firm Ixom
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust is nearing a deal to acquire Ixom, the Australian chemical company controlled by Blackstone Group LP, for over US$1 billion. The acquisition would expand Keppel's presence beyond Singapore and provide access to new markets. Ixom's water treatment and chemical distribution business is centered on Australia, New Zealand, the Americas, and Asia. The deal, if announced, would be the latest in a string of large acquisitions of Australian companies this year, following Blackstone's purchase of Orica's chemical business for A$750 million in 2015.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands billionaire Adelson and wife give US$20m to Republican efforts to hold House
summary: Billionaire casino owner Sheldon Adelson and his wife Miriam donated $20 million to help Republicans try to hold the US House in the November 6 election, adding to their previous $55 million in campaign contributions. This donation went to the Congressional Leadership Fund, a super PAC aligned with House Speaker Paul Ryan. The Adelsons, who previously gave $82.5 million to conservative causes and candidates in the 2015-16 election cycle, are part of a larger spending effort by the two parties ahead of the election that will determine whether President Trump can push through his legislative agenda.

site_title: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen dies of cancer: family
summary: Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, died at 65 after battling cancer. He was remembered as a remarkable individual, a technologist, and philanthropist by his family and friends. Allen's sister described him as a "much loved brother and uncle, and an exceptional friend" who demonstrated "wit, warmth, generosity, and deep concern." Allen's passing was met with grief from many, including his family and the tech community.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Paul Allen, who founded US software giant Microsoft with Bill Gates in the 1970s, died on Monday at the age of 65 after his latest battle with cancer, his family said.

site_title: Australian share market steadies after selloff; NZ falls
summary: The Australian share market steadied after a 5.6% sell-off last week, advancing 0.4% to 5,860.3 points. Miners and bank stocks led the gain, with the banking index rising over 1% and the metals and mining index gaining 1.9%. Rio Tinto's shares rose 1.7% despite a 5% drop in iron ore shipments. In contrast, the New Zealand market fell 0.3% as financials were pressured, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group's shares hitting a 2-year low.

site_title: Harvard on trial over alleged discrimination against Asians
summary: Harvard University is on trial over allegations of discrimination against Asian students in its admissions process. A lawsuit claims the university uses race as a factor, boosting minority enrollments, despite denying any wrongdoing. Harvard defends its use of broader selection criteria, including personality, to form a diverse student body. The university argues that considering race is necessary to achieve its educational goals. The case, led by Students for Fair Admissions, has the potential to reach the US Supreme Court, which previously upheld the university's admissions policy in 2016.

site_title: Climate change? It comes and goes, Trump says
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that climate change is not permanent, saying "something" is happening but will "go back and forth." Trump acknowledged the impact of weather on the southern US, but downplayed the role of human activity in causing the rapid warming of the planet. He expressed skepticism about the findings of the Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change, citing a need to review the report's authors and sources. Trump claimed to be an "environmentalist" and wants "the cleanest water and air," but his stance on climate change remains unchanged.

site_title: China property market feels fresh chill as 'winter' looms
summary: China's property market is showing signs of slowing down, with home prices rising at their fastest pace in nearly two years in August but weak forward-looking indicators. Sales by floor area dropped 27% in China's Golden Week holiday, and property investment growth has been weakening. Developers are offering promotions and discounts, but sentiment is cautious, with buyer queues growing shorter. Experts warn of a "winter" in the market, with Nomura's chief China economist Ting Lu predicting a downtrend in home sales and prices.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings under construction in Quanzhou, Fujian province."There's downward pressure on home prices especially in third and fourth-tier cities," says Nomura chief China economist Ting Lu.

site_title: Condo flipping not prevalent in Toronto, Vancouver
summary: Vancouver and Toronto condo markets show low levels of flipping, with 3.4% and 1.7% of sales being resold within a year, respectively. Despite measures to curb speculation, such as a 15% tax on foreign buyers in Vancouver, prices in both cities have risen due to fundamental factors like weak housing supply and rising populations. The evidence of flipping is sparse, and experts attribute the low flipping rates to high transaction costs and the current housing slowdown, making it unattractive to try to flip condos in a down market.

site_title: Most firms still unaware of industry transformation maps
summary: A survey by the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) found that two in five firms in Singapore are unaware of Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs), sectoral roadmaps aimed at transforming industries. Only 62.5% of those aware of ITMs are unsure how to participate. The survey also highlighted rising business costs, stiff competition, and manpower shortages as major concerns for firms. The SCCCI recommends trade associations engage government agencies to implement ITMs and the government to enhance its Productivity Solutions Grant to maintain productivity momentum.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Taking the F&B route and sticking with it
summary: Tan Hock Soon, founder of Ramen Taisho, shares his challenges of running a food stall in Singapore. He highlights the long hours, repetitive tasks, and weather dependence that affect his business. Despite the difficulties, he is determined to scale up his business. Working with his wife, Kalene Chung, they have been operating a stall in Maxwell Food Centre for two years, serving ramen to customers. Tan emphasizes the importance of finding ways to overcome the tough conditions in the F&B industry.

images.alt_text: Tan Hock Soon and his wife Kalene Chung, who run Ramen Taisho at Maxwell Food Centre. Most of his customers used to be office workers but that has shifted to mainly tourists who make up the dinner crowd.

site_title: Central London holding up despite worst market since 2010
summary: Central London's housing market defied the UK's worst October market in eight years, with asking prices rising 2.4% to £625,064. The UK's overall home values rose 1% and London's decreased 1.1% on an annual basis. Despite a subdued market, tentative signs of a rebound in inner London's expensive districts suggest a seasonal pickup. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported significant caution among potential buyers, citing tax changes and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Dubai property prices sink in Q3, market equilibrium not expected soon: report
summary: Dubai property prices declined 6% in Q3, with off-plan sales volumes down 31% compared to 11% for completed units, according to Chestertons. The real estate downturn is expected to continue due to construction activity and pipeline units, with market equilibrium unlikely within the next 3-5 years. S&P Global Ratings cut its credit ratings for Dubai state-owned companies in September, predicting a 10-15% decline in property prices over the next two years.
