Sears, once a dominant force in US malls, has struggled in the age of internet shopping. The bankruptcy filing follows a series of attempts by billionaire CEO Eddie Lampert to turn the company around, but his efforts have been unsuccessful. The company's debt restructuring will aim to restore Sears to financial stability.

site_title: Swift winds down global tour with Reputation intact
summary: Taylor Swift's Reputation tour concluded with a successful run, despite initial predictions of a disaster. The tour, which kicked off in May, grossed nearly $200 million, making it the highest-grossing US tour by a female artist. Swift used the tour to address her past online backlash, embracing the "snake" moniker and sending a message to fans about not letting name-calling defeat them. The tour also featured surprise musical guests and long concert speeches, cementing Swift's reputation as a resilient and powerful performer.

site_title: Draghi asks Italy to 'calm down' and stop questioning the euro
summary: Italian officials must stop questioning the euro and calm down in their budget debate, European Central Bank (ECB) president Mario Draghi said. The comments follow Italy's government plans to triple the deficit next year, which has caused damage to firms and households, leading to higher interest rates on loans. Draghi stated that the ECB's plan to phase out asset purchases has not caused the increase in spreads, and markets reacted to local Italian issues rather than the ECB's policy change. Draghi urged the Italian government to focus on facts and calm down their tone.

site_title: China bemoans 'confusing' US signals but holds hope for a Trump-Xi meet
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping will "probably" meet at the G-20 summit in Buenos Aires, a US official said, as both sides seek answers for a strained relationship. Trade talks have been "unsatisfactory," with China expressing frustration over conflicting US signals. The two sides have also disagreed on issues beyond trade, including a recent US naval exercise in the South China Sea. Despite these tensions, Chinese officials hold out hope for the Buenos Aires meeting, citing previous successful encounters between the presidents.

site_title: New Istanbul airport to open fully only at end of year
summary: Istanbul's new airport, a 15-year construction project, will not fully open until the end of 2018, two months later than initially planned for October 29. The airport, with an initial capacity of 90 million passengers, will initially operate on domestic routes, including flights to Ankara, Izmir, and Antalya, with only one international route to Baku. The delay comes after protests over work conditions, which have since resumed with improved working conditions and living quarters.

site_title: Brexit talks provide stage for Barnier's second act
summary: EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Michel Barnier is impressing with his defense of the Union's core interests, earning the respect of British counterparts. Despite initial criticism, Barnier has proven to be a skilled negotiator, winning over pro-Europeans and British officials. His performance has revitalized his career, as he takes on a crucial role in the Brexit talks.

site_title: Dollar gains on stock bounce and China's upbeat data
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies as global equity prices rebounded from the week's rout, driven by robust Chinese export figures. China's data alleviated trade war concerns. In contrast, the euro and sterling snapped their three-day winning streak ahead of the European Union summit, where a Brexit deal may be struck.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says will retaliate against any sanctions over Khashoggi case
summary: Saudi Arabia has warned it will retaliate against any sanctions imposed over the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was last seen entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. The US and European allies, including Britain, France, and Germany, have called for a credible investigation into Khashoggi's disappearance. The US has threatened "severe punishment" if it is found that Khashoggi was killed in the consulate, while European countries have expressed concern over the potential for human rights violations. Saudi King Salman has stressed the strength of Saudi-Turkish ties, but the crisis has sparked anti-Saudi sentiment in the US Congress, with some senators calling for severe action, including ending support for Saudi military operations in Yemen.

site_title: BOE warns of 'weaponising' financial assets
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned against "weaponising" financial assets during a Group of 30 conference in Bali, Indonesia. He stressed the need for open investment flows to counter the impact of a trade war. Carney highlighted the US's use of secondary sanctions, which can force European firms to stop doing business with third-country parties. He praised the Trump administration for cooperating with the financial system to deliver reform, saying it has promoted the resilience of the system.

site_title: Buybacks rise and SLA plc adds to its AEM stake
summary: SLA plc increased its stake in AEM Holdings to 7.19298% after acquiring 1,864,900 shares. This is the second time SLA plc has increased its stake in AEM Holdings, with previous increases on Sept 28 and Oct 2. The company's buyback mandate has seen a total of S$34 million spent on buybacks, with DBS Group Holdings leading the way. Other significant transactions include United Engineers Limited's substantial shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong acquiring 466,000 shares of UEL, and Intelligent People Holdings Ltd acquiring 2,443,200 shares of Sinostar Pec Holdings.

site_title: Clarity on Fed hikes key outcome of Bali meeting
summary: Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that clarity on the gradual pace of US interest rate hikes was a key takeaway from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings in Bali. The US Federal Reserve officials' signals on policy normalization should ease pressure in financial markets, particularly in emerging economies, Warjiyo said. The governor expressed optimism that the Fed will communicate clearly about the future course of normalization, which he believes will reduce volatility in financial markets and exchange rates.

site_title: Re-inventing Asia-Pacific's industries
summary: Industry leaders in the Asia-Pacific region believe the Fourth Industrial Revolution is transforming manufacturing, with countries like China and Japan embracing digital solutions to leapfrog traditional industries. The region's diverse economies pose unique challenges, including varying connectivity and talent availability. Small and medium-sized manufacturers face obstacles in embracing Industry 4.0, including the need for continuous education, building digital ecosystems, and cultivating a collaborative mindset. Policymakers can catalyze adoption by adopting a cooperative mindset, signaling the importance of new technologies, and implementing initiatives like Singapore's Smart Nation agenda and China's Made in China 2025.

site_title: Two wheelers could rule electric transportation of the future
summary: A growing trend in electric transportation is expected to shift towards two-wheelers, solving traffic and pollution problems. Niu Technologies' upcoming IPO and advancements in electric mopeds, scooters, and motorcycles are poised to transform transportation, especially in emerging markets like India and South-east Asia. Despite initial costs and limited charging infrastructure, falling battery prices and decreasing costs of ownership make electric two-wheelers an attractive option. Governments are expected to play a crucial role in supporting the shift by installing charging stations and regulating transportation pollution.

site_title: Showcasing smart manufacturing innovations
summary: The Industrial Transformation ASIA-PACIFIC (ITAP) trade show, held in Singapore, showcased smart manufacturing innovations, including robotic vehicles, virtual power plants, and digital simulations of entire production chains. 265 exhibitors from 22 countries presented solutions for digital factories, additive manufacturing, industrial automation, and smart logistics. Key highlights included autonomous vehicles, digital factory innovations, and additive manufacturing technologies, as well as systems addressing data flow and management. The event aimed to demonstrate the future of manufacturing through digital twins and provide a platform for exhibitors to connect with customers and partners interested in Industry 4.0 concepts and technologies.

images.alt_text: Ashish Pujari of SAP.
Raimund Klein of Siemens PLM Software.

ST Engineering is launching Strobo, a new family of autonomous vehicles for material handling tasks. These are able to plan paths dynamically, navigate warehouse aisles, detect and avoid obstacles, and can also be remotely operated over wireless networks.

site_title: Island casino for Chinese high rollers sputters amid delays
summary: Imperial Pacific International Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong-based casino operator, is struggling to turn the remote US territory of Saipan into a high-stakes gambling hub. The company's first-half revenue declined 51% and earnings plummeted by over 90% due to uncollected debts from gamblers, exceeding Macau casinos' uncollected debts. Delays in building a 340-room hotel and issues with skilled labor have further impacted the project. The company's financial viability is unclear, and investors have reacted negatively to recent setbacks, with the company's shares declining 52% since 2017.

site_title: Call to stop companies using animals for cosmetic testing
summary: The Body Shop and Cruelty Free International launched a petition to stop companies using animals for cosmetic testing, collecting 8.3 million signatures within 15 months. The petition calls for countries to formalize an international framework to end cosmetic animal testing. Despite the European Union's ban in 2013, 80% of countries still allow animal testing, citing outdated methods. The petition aims to end decades of animal suffering and create a level playing field for companies worldwide.

images.alt_text: The petition signatures were collected from supporters globally in just 15 months and call on the countries of the UN to formalise an international framework to end cosmetic testing.
Vivien Ang

site_title: Tunisia fishermen cash in on blue crab menace
summary: Tunisian fishermen have capitalized on the blue crab infestation in their waters, four years after the crustaceans first appeared. Initially feared due to their ferocity, the blue crabs have become a valuable commodity, with fishermen selling them at a high price. The nickname "ISIS" given to the blue crabs has since been replaced, but the fishery has still seen significant economic benefits. The shift in perception has transformed the blue crabs from pests to a profitable resource for local fishermen.

site_title: From scores to skills
summary: A key factor in education is an open and questioning mind, essential for lifelong learning and adapting to tomorrow's world. This mindset change could influence how employers evaluate prospective hires. Experts emphasize the importance of developing skills beyond traditional academics, such as critical thinking and problem-solving. As a result, employers may prioritize these skills over traditional qualifications when selecting candidates. This shift could lead to a more skills-based approach in the job market.

site_title: Marching to the beat of Industry 4.0
summary: The first Asia-Pacific edition of Hannover Messe: ITAP 2018 opened in Singapore Expo, featuring over 10,000 participants and 260 exhibiting companies from 22 countries. The three-day event focuses on Industry 4.0 and the future of manufacturing, with a curated learning journey approach. The conference component features over 100 international speakers, including Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, and explores regional trends and ideas. The event aims to engage players along the manufacturing value-chain and catalyse partnerships, with the goal of supporting Singapore's vision to become a leading global advanced manufacturing hub.

site_title: A luxury rental in New York, from a low-key landlord
summary: Lloyd Goldman, president of BLDG Management, has completed his first ground-up rental building in New York, Summit New York, a 42-storey, 429-unit luxury rental at 222 East 44th St. The building, near the UN headquarters, offers market-rate and affordable apartments with amenities like a wine-locker-lined lounge, pool, and basketball court. Goldman, who has previously renovated thousands of units, designed the building to cater to the diplomatic corps, with prices starting at $4,500 for a one-bedroom apartment. The building's unique positioning and luxury features aim to attract high-end residents from the diplomatic community.

site_title: Japan to pledge 2019 tax hike to address debt mountain: reports
summary: Japan is set to announce a sales tax hike to 10% in 2019 to address its massive public debt, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe confident the move can be implemented without disrupting the economy. The tax increase is aimed at financing rising social security costs, particularly medical fees, in an ageing society. This move comes as the country's debt-to-GDP ratio is among the highest among rich nations, and critics warn that failure to address the issue could lead to a sharp drop in consumer spending and a loss of confidence in Tokyo's ability to pay its debts.

site_title: SGX-ST rejects most of Triyards' requests
summary: The Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) has rejected most of Triyards' requests, including an extension for its annual general meeting and quarterly results. The company had applied for more time to hold the meeting and release its financial results. However, SGX-ST has approved a request for an eight-month extension to submit a trading resumption proposal, subject to certain conditions. Triyards cited confidentiality reasons for its need for more time to prepare the resumption proposal.

site_title: Egypt seeks to weave cotton renaissance
summary: Egypt seeks to revive its cotton industry, which has faced challenges in recent years. Farmer Fatuh Khalifa harvests high-quality cotton in the Nile Delta, known for its durability and luxury. The country aims to capitalize on its reputation for producing the world's best cotton, but faces ongoing difficulties. Egyptian cotton has been in high demand, and the government is working to support farmers and increase production to meet global demand. The goal is to restore Egypt's position as a leading cotton producer and revitalize the industry.

site_title: US earnings, Chinese data in focus this week
summary: US markets will focus on the start of the earnings season, the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) September meeting minutes, and Chinese data releases, including producer and consumer price indices, retail sales, and GDP numbers. Despite a brief selloff, global markets recovered, with the Dow Jones advancing 1.15% and the S&P 500 rising 1.42%. Analysts warn that trade tensions and rising interest rates remain concerns, and earnings results may be impacted by the US-China dispute.

site_title: Uber-backed Lime crashes in court bid to disrupt scooter scene
summary: Lime, a US$1 billion electric scooter company backed by Uber and Alphabet, lost a court bid to temporarily halt San Francisco's plan to allow two smaller companies to operate in the city. The judge denied the request, but wants to investigate the city's permit process, allowing Lime to question officials. Lime accused the city of denying its permit as punishment for deploying scooters on sidewalks without approval. The company plans to take depositions of officials and has scheduled another hearing in November.

site_title: Connecting clients to Asean and BRI, the StanChart way
summary: Standard Chartered's regional head Judy Hsu discusses her role in strengthening key client and government relationships in Asean and South Asia. As regional chief executive, Asean and South Asia, Hsu aims to bring the bank's CEOs together to support clients and increase business. The bank has seen significant growth in the region, with 120 Singapore companies venturing into new markets in 2017 and plans to consolidate its local business in Singapore. Hsu emphasizes the importance of Singapore as a financial hub for Belt & Road investments and aims to groom future Singaporean leaders.

site_title: Dividend growth stocks trump Reits amid rate hike-driven volatility
summary: Dividend growth stocks are outperforming REITs (Real Estate Investment Trusts) amid rising interest rates and market volatility. Analysts say Singapore offers the highest dividend yield in Southeast Asia, but growth is expected to slow down next year. Instead of REITs, cyclical names with rising dividends are preferred, such as energy and materials sectors. Banks and insurance stocks are also favored for their "bottom-line resilience." The Singapore dollar's strength against emerging market currencies makes Singapore a top destination for yield seekers.

images.alt_text: Pundits generally agree that Singapore remains the most attractive market in the region to hunt for yield, once the relative strength of the Singdollar against emerging market currencies is taken into account.

site_title: Jared Kushner 'likely' paid little or no income taxes for years: NYTimes
summary: Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, likely paid little or no federal income taxes between 2009 and 2016, according to a New York Times report. Confidential financial documents show Kushner used depreciation to deduct part of his properties' costs from taxable income. Kushner's lawyer claims he properly filed and paid all taxes due under the law, despite the documents showing zero income taxes payable for most years, except for a $1.1 million payment in 2013. The White House did not immediately comment on the report.

site_title: Alstom lays down tracks for diversity and railway business
summary: Alstom appoints Ling Fang as regional head of its Asia-Pacific operations, making her the first Asian and first woman to hold the position. Fang, a 23-year veteran of the company, previously served as managing director for China and East Asia. She oversees 12 markets, including India, which is a key manufacturing base for the company. Alstom aims to increase the representation of women in its management team to 25% by 2020, and Fang's appointment demonstrates the company's commitment to internal mobility and promotion.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Fragile pipelines pose increasing risk in gas-hungry US
summary: US natural gas pipelines face increasing risk due to ageing infrastructure, particularly on the East Coast. The country has approximately 80,000 miles of unprotected pipes, many of which date back to the early 1900s. Despite efforts to replace old lines, concerns remain about the regulatory environment keeping pace with the shale-gas boom. The industry has seen a significant increase in pipeline-related fatalities in recent years, with the majority attributed to older cast-iron pipes. Utilities continue to invest billions in replacement projects, but the rapid expansion of new pipelines raises concerns about safety.

site_title: Go-Jek in head-to-head fight with Grab for S-E Asian dominance
summary: Go-Jek, a Jakarta-based ridehailing company, is set to expand into Singapore in November, aiming to become South-east Asia's most inclusive Super App with over 20 business verticals. The company currently operates 18 product lines, including transport, logistics, and beauty services, with 100 million orders monthly. Grab, its regional rival, has a significantly larger presence across South-east Asia but fewer product lines. Go-Jek's goal is to build a platform with multiple products, supported by partners like ThoughtWorks, and aims to become a Super App, offering more brand stickiness and engagement to users.

site_title: Deutsche Bank helps kids Dream Beyond
summary: Deutsche Bank partnered the Singapore Chinese Orchestra on October 6, 2018, to present their fifth "Dream Beyond" charity concert. The event featured visually impaired student Stephanie Ow and special needs students from the Rainbow Centre. The concert aimed to develop musical capabilities and social interaction among the students. Minister of State Sam Tan was the guest of honour. This initiative was part of Deutsche Bank's collaboration with the Rainbow Centre on a Music Talent Development Programme.

site_title: US-China trade row not a threat to world economy: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin contradicts the IMF's warning that the US-China trade confrontation would hobble global economic growth, stating that pushing Beijing to adopt fairer trade practices through tariffs would be beneficial for all. Mnuchin argues that the tariffs will encourage China to open up, rather than harming the world economy.

site_title: Five South Korean climbers among group of nine missing in Nepal Himalayas: officials
summary: A group of nine climbers, including five South Korean climbers and four Nepali climbers and porters, are missing after a storm hit their camp on Mount Gurja in the Nepal Himalayas. The storm destroyed the camp, and a rescue helicopter was unable to land due to poor visibility. The incident is the largest climbing accident in Nepal in two years, and authorities are continuing their search operation. The missing climbers were part of the autumn climbing season, which is a major source of revenue for the cash-strapped nation.

site_title: Air Canada's near miss last year almost 'worst accident in history'
summary: Air Canada's Airbus A320 nearly landed on a crowded taxiway at San Francisco International Airport on July 7, 2017, instead of the intended runway. The incident could have been the "worst aviation accident in history" due to only a few feet of separation between the plane and the waiting aircraft. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) report attributed the incident to the flight crew's misidentification of the taxiway, lack of awareness of parallel runway closure, and crew resource management issues. No injuries were reported, but the incident highlighted the importance of effective communication and crew training.

site_title: US dollar gains on stock bounce and China's upbeat data
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies as global equity prices rebounded from a rout and China's robust export figures eased trade war concerns. China's exports jumped 14.5% in September, beating expectations and suggesting the tariffs imposed by US President Donald Trump have yet to bite. The dollar index was up 0.23% at 95.234, reducing its weekly loss to 0.4%.

site_title: PBOC chief sees plenty of room for monetary adjustments
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang expressed concerns over the impact of trade tensions with the US, stating there is "plenty of room" for interest rate and reserve requirement ratio adjustments. Yi said China's economic growth is expected to reach 6.5% in 2018, with the possibility of overshooting, despite current inflation levels being manageable. Yi emphasized the need for a constructive solution to the trade dispute, while the PBOC remains neutral in its monetary stance, with liquidity levels seen as sufficient to stabilize leverage.

site_title: Hi-P expects lower revenue, profit for Q3; announces JV deal
summary: Hi-P International, a global contract manufacturer of consumer electronics, has revised its Q3 2018 financial guidance, expecting lower revenue and profit due to delays in sales and lower market demand. The company also announced a joint venture deal with Electric Connector Technology Co, which will invest 112.5 million yuan in Hi-Flex (Suzhou) Electronics Co Ltd, a subsidiary producing flexible printed circuit boards. The deal is expected to result in a positive impact on Hi-P's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Hi-P revises Q3 profit guidance
summary: Hi-P International has revised its Q3 profit guidance downward, citing lower revenue and profit compared to the same period last year. The company attributed the change to delays in sales, lower manufacturing yields, and decreased market demand for certain products. This is a departure from its previous guidance, which expected higher revenue but similar profit in Q3 2018. The group's shares closed 3.5 Singapore cents higher on Friday.

site_title: China won't use yuan as tool to deal with trade war, Yi says
summary: Chinese central bank Governor Yi Gang stated that China won't use its currency as a tool to deal with trade conflicts, amid a tariff war between the US and China. Yi emphasized the market will play a decisive role in the formation of the yuan exchange rate, and China won't engage in competitive devaluation. Despite the yuan's 9% decline against the US dollar in the past six months, pressure eased due to reports of a potential meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Yi said China's economy remains steady, with steady growth in 2018.

site_title: China speeds up small town redevelopment programme to support slowing economy
summary: China is accelerating its small town redevelopment program, which has pumped 3.2 trillion yuan (S$638 billion) into the economy by replacing substandard dwellings with new homes. The program, which aims to build 15 million new homes, has been slowed by concerns over debt and property bubbles. Analysts say the government is trying to boost stimulus while managing risks, with some cities experiencing rapid house price growth. The program has improved the lives of thousands of people, but also fueled debt in small cities with weak finances.

site_title: Winter is coming, finance chiefs warn as trade tensions deepen
summary: Global finance chiefs warn that rising trade tensions and interest rates threaten to derail the world economy as it reaches its peak growth. The IMF cut its global outlook for the first time in two years, citing plateaued growth, and urged the US and China to step back from the brink of a trade war. Economists warn that a trade dispute could have a significant impact on global growth, with export-reliant countries like New Zealand particularly vulnerable. The IMF calls for "cooler heads" to prevail to avoid a steeper downturn.

site_title: Trump takes centre stage in dispute over Jamal Khashoggi
summary: US President Donald Trump is under pressure to intervene in the Saudi Arabian dispute over the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, with Turkish officials seeking Washington's help to force Saudi Arabia to provide a more detailed accounting of the events. Turkey claims Khashoggi was killed inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, while Saudi officials insist he left freely. Trump has expressed willingness to speak with Saudi King Salman, but has not taken concrete action, instead deflecting questions about Saudi Arabia's human rights record. Analysts predict pressure from the US could force Saudi Arabia to offer a credible explanation for Khashoggi's fate.

site_title: He's 'trashing American values': Biden doesn't hold back on Trump
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden criticized President Donald Trump, calling him "trashing American values" and "amassing power." Biden made the comments while campaigning in rural Kentucky for a Democrat running in a House race, hinting at a potential 2020 campaign against Trump. Biden acknowledged Trump's appeal to the white working class but said his narrow value set and self-serving approach have limits, and that Democrats need to re-engage with this group to win the presidency.

site_title: European stocks fail to rebound in worst week since Feb
summary: European stocks closed down 0.2% and posted a 4.8% weekly loss, their worst week since February 2018, amid worries about protectionism and rising US interest rates. Despite initial gains, stocks ultimately fell as investors pulled out of European markets. The tech sector saw a modest recovery, while the autos sector also showed gains. Analysts believe the luxury sector's reliance on China is decreasing, which may help to stabilize European stocks.

site_title: Sears aims to close up to 150 stores in bankruptcy, say sources
summary: Sears Holdings plans to close up to 150 stores and keep at least 300 open as part of a restructuring plan under US bankruptcy protection. The company aims to sell assets, including its Kenmore appliances brand and home services business, through court-supervised auctions. Sears CEO Eddie Lampert, the company's largest shareholder and creditor, is exploring bidding on assets as a stalking horse, potentially keeping a slimmer Sears alive. The company has approximately 700 stores and 90,000 employees, and is seeking a $400 million bankruptcy loan to stay afloat through the holiday season.

site_title: USDJPY: Prices need to break below 110.36
summary: USDJPY is poised for a reversal to the downside, with prices expected to test the 107.95 and 104.55 levels. A recent reading above 80 on the Weekly Stochastics Oscillator suggests an overbought condition, increasing the likelihood of a price reversal. A shooting star pattern on the chart, with the candlestick closing below the key resistance level, further supports the impending reversal. To confirm the trend, USDJPY needs to break below 110.36, potentially capping the downward momentum.

site_title: France probes PSG v Red Star Belgrade match-fix claims
summary: French investigators are probing match-fixing allegations in Paris Saint-Germain's 6-1 win against Red Star Belgrade in the Champions League group stage on October 3. A senior Red Star official is suspected of betting on the match to lose by a five-goal margin, with a reported €5 million wager. The club and UEFA have denied any involvement, while PSG expressed concern over the investigation. The allegations come amid a week of corruption scandals in the Belgian league, with 19 suspects charged and nine detained in a match-fixing inquiry.

site_title: SGX-ST rejects most of Triyards' applications
summary: The Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) has rejected most of Triyards' applications, including an extension of time for its annual general meeting and quarterly results for the 2017-2018 financial year. The company had sought more time to prepare a trading resumption proposal, which was approved but subject to certain conditions. Triyards had applied for an extension to June 30, 2019, but the SGX-ST rejected this request. The company will need to announce the granted extension, reasons for seeking it, and conditions met, and will also have to make an update announcement if conditions are not met.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of October 7-13, 2018. Key points include:

- Charterers took a step back in the Middle East Gulf, with rates peaking at WS 85 for 270,000mt to China and then softening to low WS 80s.
- West Africa to China rates eased to WS 79, basis 260,000mt, while Suezmax rates gained 15 points to WS 107.5 for 130,000mt to UK/Cont.
- Aframax rates in the Mediterranean came under pressure, with Ceyhan fixed at WS 105 and the Black Sea paying WS 110/112.5 basis 80,000mt.
- Panamax rates remained steady, with limited tonnage availability seen in the ARA to the US Gulf market.
- Clean rates in the Middle East Gulf/Japan trade eased 2.5 points to WS 100, while rates for 55,000mt back to WS 120 after peaking at WS 125.
- The Capesize market experienced a sharp reversal of fortunes, with rates rising sharply and timecharter rates reaching over $20,000 daily for China delivery with West Australia rounds.
- The North Atlantic market saw sustained demand, with several charterers taking tonnage for two to three laden legs despite paying a premium.
- Supramax rates increased with period activity, while Handysize rates remained positive, with increased activity in the Atlantic basin.

site_title: Fed does consider impact of policy on emerging markets: Quarles
summary: The Federal Reserve considers the impact of its policies on emerging markets, according to Vice-Chairman for Supervision Randal Quarles. Quarles stated that the Fed aims to be predictable and gradual in its policy, acknowledging that its tightening has caused strains in emerging markets, particularly in Argentina, Turkey, and Indonesia. Officials from developing economies have called for awareness of these strains as the era of crisis-level monetary settings in the developed world comes to a close. The Fed's consideration of emerging markets' impact is a response to the concerns raised by developing economies during the IMF meetings.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve is taking into account the effects its policies have on emerging markets, Vice-Chairman for Supervision Randal Quarles said in Bali, Indonesia.

site_title: Healthy correction or sign of worse to come?
summary: US stocks surged on Friday after a massive selldown the previous week, amid concerns over rising Treasury yields and slowing global trade. Despite reassurances from investment strategists that rising yields are a sign of a brightening economic outlook, volatility is expected to persist. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1,300 points last week, with riskier small-cap and technology stocks suffering significant losses. Analysts warn that third-quarter earnings reports and forward-looking statements from major corporations could ease volatility, but the yield on the 10-year Treasury note remains a critical factor.

site_title: 3 nabbed for duping man of S$1.72m, largest amount lost in China officials impersonation scam this year
summary: Three Taiwanese men, aged 24-26, were arrested in Singapore for their suspected involvement in a China officials impersonation scam, resulting in a victim losing $1.72 million. The scam involved a call claiming the victim was implicated in a transnational fraud, leading him to hand over cash to a man claiming to be an Interpol officer. This is the largest amount lost in a single case of the scam this year, with almost $6 million lost in the first six months. The men could face fines and jail terms of up to five years if convicted.

site_title: Saudi delegation in Turkey for talks on missing journalist
summary: A Saudi delegation arrived in Turkey for talks on the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who vanished on October 2 after entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. Saudi Arabia denies accusations that Khashoggi was ordered murdered, calling them "lies and baseless allegations." Turkish officials claim to have recordings that show Khashoggi was tortured and killed at the consulate, while Saudi Arabia says it is committed to its principles and international laws. The case risks damaging Saudi Arabia's image and ties with the West, with major media and business figures canceling appearances at a major conference in Riyadh.

site_title: Oil steadies, settling up slightly after volatile session
summary: Crude oil futures steadied late in the session on Friday, rising slightly after earlier swinging lower due to a weakening oil demand outlook. The International Energy Agency trimmed its forecasts for world oil demand growth this year and next, citing a weaker economic outlook, trade concerns, and higher oil prices. Brent crude settled up 17 cents a barrel at US$80.43, while US crude futures rose 37 cents to US$71.34 a barrel. The US oil drilling rig count rose for the first time in four weeks, indicating rising production.

site_title: Companies eye Singapore for data centre storage, cloud leasing
summary: Singapore is becoming a key destination for data centre storage and cloud leasing, driven by the growing demand for cloud services in the Asia-Pacific region. Companies like Google and Facebook are setting up data centres, while others are leasing existing buildings or opting for Build-to-Suit arrangements. The city-state's stable geopolitical climate, supportive regulatory environment, and relatively cheaper land costs make it an attractive location. However, Singapore faces competition from emerging markets such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand, and must balance its relative scarcity of land and higher costs with the growing demand for data centres.

site_title: Hurricane death toll rises to 17 as search goes on in Florida
summary: Hurricane Michael's death toll rose to 17 across four states, with at least 8 fatalities in Florida, as search and rescue crews struggled to reach isolated communities due to communication failures. The storm, which made landfall as a Category 4 hurricane, caused widespread destruction and flooding, leaving 1.5 million homes and businesses without power. Rescuers used bulldozers and sniffer dogs to search for survivors and the deceased, with many residents returning to Mexico Beach, which was severely affected, with hopes of rebuilding to withstand future storms.

site_title: UN criticised over latest picks for rights council
summary: The United Nations Human Rights Council has faced criticism over its latest election, with Bahrain, Cameroon, and the Philippines being elected to the 47-member council despite having questionable human rights records. The US, which withdrew from the council in June, called the election "ridiculous" and said it undermines the council's credibility. Human Rights Watch described the election as "making a mockery of the word 'election.'" The UN General Assembly's president noted that member states are expected to abide by standards of behavior, but the US plans to continue pushing for reforms to make the council credible.

images.alt_text: Bahrain, Cameroon and the Philippines were among a number of nations controversially elected to the United Nations Human Rights Council on Friday, sparking sharp criticism from rights groups and the United States.

site_title: Clearing the air on tobacco investments
summary: Singapore, known for its tough stance on tobacco, has significant investments in the industry through its sovereign wealth fund, GIC, and central bank, MAS. The funds have stakes in major tobacco companies, including British American Tobacco and Japan Tobacco Inc, despite the country's strict laws and public health campaigns. This contradictory stance raises questions about the government's commitment to its anti-tobacco policies.

site_title: 'We are fine': Melania Trump dismisses gossip about marriage
summary: Melania Trump dismissed gossip about her marriage to President Donald Trump, saying she has "more important things to think about" and loves life in the US capital. In a lengthy ABC interview, she brushed off speculation about her husband's alleged affairs, stating "we are fine" and that the media's speculation is "gossip." The first lady emphasized her focus on her role as a mother and first lady, and expressed frustration with the constant scrutiny of her fashion choices.

site_title: Growing dividends from property developers
summary: Property developers offer decent dividend investments despite volatile profits, external risks, and challenging markets. The median net income margin for 22 Asian developers over the last 12 years was 20%, with returns on equity averaging 10% over the past decade. Current property developers look undervalued, with a median price-to-book ratio of 0.7 and a median price-to-earnings ratio of 16. Despite retaining 80% of profits, their dividend yields are still respectable at 3.2%.

site_title: Internet hacking is about to get much worse
summary: The future of internet security is at risk due to the increasing number of connected devices, known as the Internet of Things (IoT), which will make hacking more catastrophic. Computers embedded in physical devices will affect lives beyond data, and security cannot be solved by the market. Governments must step in and regulate this space with multifaceted approaches, including setting standards, penalizing bad security, and making liability a priority. The solution requires a policy-driven approach, with regulations that balance security with innovation, and penalties for companies with poor security.

site_title: New reporting standards sink SLB's Q1 results
summary: SLB Development, a Singapore property developer, reported a net loss of S$2.79 million in its first quarter, down from a net profit of S$3.65 million the previous year. The loss was attributed to the recognition of project contributions progressively and losses from joint ventures and associates. Revenue was S$23 million, down from S$220.7 million due to the completion of contracts method. The company cited challenges in the Singapore residential market and remains cautious about land-bank replenishment, but is optimistic about its diversified portfolio.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: MAS further tightens Singdollar policy
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has tightened the Singapore dollar's policy band, increasing its appreciation pace to maintain medium-term price stability. The policy band's width and center will remain unchanged. This is the second consecutive tightening at the half-yearly review, aiming to ensure steady expansion of the Singapore economy in the quarters ahead.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: The fickle IPO market and a warning from the listed plays
summary: The global IPO market has been experiencing a downturn, with recent poor performances of new entrants such as Funding Circle Holdings and Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings, indicating deeper malaise among investors. The two companies' stock prices plummeted 15% and 20% respectively, with Funding Circle's valuation exposed to an economic downturn and Aston's valuation relying on its luxury cachet. The poor performance of these IPOs has raised concerns about the market's resilience, with low trading volume and few buyers for Aston's shares.

site_title: Facebook now says data breach affected 29m users, details impact
summary: Facebook has disclosed a data breach that affected 29 million users, with attackers stealing profile details such as birth dates, employers, and location check-ins. The breach, which occurred between July 2017 and late last month, was carried out using an automated program that moved from one friend to the next. Facebook said it would message affected users to inform them of the breach and that the attackers did not access personal messages or financial data. The company's shares rose 0.25% on the news, but cybersecurity experts warned that the breach could deepen concerns about Facebook's data security practices.

site_title: Q3 growth better than expected; economists upgrade 2018 forecasts
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.6% in the third quarter, surpassing forecast of 2.4%, with the first 3 quarters' growth at 3.8%, the best 9-month performance since 2013. Despite trade tensions and emerging market uncertainties, economists upgraded their full-year growth forecasts. The steady but subdued growth is expected to continue for the rest of the year and 2019, with the economy on track for a more stable performance.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate hits 7-1/2 year peak after sell-off in bond market
summary: US 30-year mortgage rates reached a 7-1/2-year high of 4.9% after a sell-off in the bond market, driven by rising inflation concerns and expected interest rate hikes. This is the highest rate since April 2011. The 10-year Treasury yield also hit its highest level since May 2011, at 3.261%. Experts warn that the increase in mortgage rates, paired with high home prices, is putting downward pressure on purchase demand, particularly for first-time buyers.

site_title: China's September export growth tops forecasts
summary: China reported a 14.5% increase in exports in September, beating forecasts, and a record trade surplus of $34.13 billion with the US. The surplus widened despite US tariffs, possibly due to companies shipping before tariffs took effect. China's trade surplus with the US has now reached $225.79 billion for the first nine months of the year, prompting concerns about the ongoing trade dispute between Beijing and Washington.

site_title: Don't panic over the pullback in shares
summary: A recent share market correction, with a 7% decline from recent highs, is considered a normal and healthy pullback, limiting complacency and excessive risk-taking. Historically, such corrections have been followed by a short-term bounce, and the current pullback is likely a correction rather than a major bear market. Investors should avoid selling shares or switching to a conservative strategy, as this locks in losses. Instead, they should look for opportunities in the pullback, averaging in over time, and consider the attractive income flow from dividends.

site_title: One of two approved suitors puts in bid for Hyflux's Tuaspring
summary: Hyflux Group, a Singaporean water treatment firm, said that only one of two approved suitors has submitted a bid for its Tuaspring water and power project, which includes South-east Asia's largest desalination plant. The bid, submitted by Sembcorp Industries, is being assessed by regulatory authorities. Hyflux remains open to considering various opportunities and has not committed to any particular option. The sale of Tuaspring is key to Hyflux's debt restructuring plans, but Sembcorp's offer is reportedly below the project's book value and may not be enough to fully pay back loans.

site_title: US: Wall Street rebounds with technology stocks leading the way
summary: US stocks rebounded on Friday, led by technology stocks, as investors sought bargains ahead of the third quarter earnings reporting season. The S&P 500 index rose 1.42% to 2,767.13, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.15% to 25,339.99. Technology stocks, including Apple and Microsoft, rose more than 3%, while Netflix and Amazon also saw significant gains. Despite the rebound, investors remain cautious due to ongoing trade tensions, with earnings reports expected to reveal the impact of tariffs on corporate profits.

site_title: UOB reviewing insurance deal with Prudential
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is reviewing its insurance business, including its partnership with Prudential, amid a wave of lucrative distribution deals in South-east Asia. The bank has been consulting potential advisers to get more value from the operations, following similar reviews by other Singaporean banks. This move comes as the region experiences increased competition in the insurance market, prompting banks to re-evaluate their strategies to remain competitive.

site_title: Feel-good investing gaining ground: DBS
summary: DBS Bank has seen a growing interest in socially-responsible investing among millennials, with the bank boosting its offerings and seeing increased demand for ESG-compliant instruments. The bank's Women's Livelihood Bond, which supports micro loans for women in South-east Asia, has performed well financially and socially. DBS is now targeting a total of US$100 million for its second tranche of the bond program. The bank attributes the shift to millennials' approach towards philanthropy, with more than two-thirds of companies in the MSCI having ESG components.

site_title: Stay invested when the going gets tough
summary: Asian markets have experienced a downturn, with investors tempted to sell out due to uncertainties. However, history shows that missing the rebound after a sharp decline can lead to significant losses. According to a chart, an investor who stayed invested since 2003 has enjoyed a compounded annual return of 8.4%, while missing the best months can result in a return of only 4%. Experts recommend investors to stay invested, as short-term volatility is expected in the equities market, and it's the price to pay for higher returns over the longer-term period.

site_title: AIA taps humanoids for customer service
summary: AIA, a Singapore-based life insurer, has introduced humanoid robots, Pepper and Nadine, to its customer service centres. The robots can perceive emotions, adapt their behaviors, and acquire new knowledge to provide more personalized customer service. The robots will assist with general enquiries, policy loans, and transactions. AIA's group CEO Ng Keng Hooi emphasized the importance of the agency force, stating that digital channels cannot replace human agents in persuading customers to purchase insurance. The move marks AIA's use of robots in customer service, a first for the life insurance industry.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Just do it right
summary: Business ethics involves making conscious decisions to take the decent path, guiding personal and corporate behavior. It strengthens relationships, builds confidence, and establishes trust. Despite its importance for long-term success, many leaders make bad decisions. Building an ethical business culture is possible, but it depends on the industry. Personal standards can set a high benchmark, and industries with high standards, such as education, can inspire others. Establishing a corporate purpose is also crucial for creating a positive impact. By prioritizing ethics, businesses can drive long-term success and build trust with customers, employees, and the public.

site_title: The hours fly by on SQ22, the world's longest flight
summary: Singapore Airlines' SQ22, the world's longest flight, departed from Changi Airport on October 11, 2018, with 161 passengers on board. The 18-hour and 45-minute journey offers a comfortable experience with well-timed meals, subtle lighting adjustments, and superb service. Passengers in business class enjoy luxurious leather seats, 13.3-inch TV screens, and personalized reading lights. Premium economy passengers also receive extra leg room and adjustable headrests. The flight's unique formula, designed by wellness specialists Canyon Ranch, aims to minimize jet lag by adjusting cabin lighting and meal services to simulate a new time zone.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Memtech International's Q2 2018 gross margin fell short of expectations due to higher raw material costs. The company's target price was reduced to S$0.95 from S$0.9, and the 2018-20 net profit forecasts were cut by 4.6-5.0%. Meanwhile, RHB Research maintained an "overweight" stance on Singapore banks, citing expected net interest margin expansion in Q3 2018. The Monetary Authority of Singapore increased the slope of the S$NEER policy band, indicating a modest appreciation path for the Singapore dollar.

site_title: Oh no! Accidental Facebook post!
summary: A Facebook post by an Indian national working at DBS Bank sparked outrage in Singapore, highlighting the potential risks of social media on reputational damage. The incident demonstrated how social media can amplify and accelerate risks, including breach of confidentiality, conflicts of interest, and misuse of company resources. To mitigate these risks, organizations should consider how employees use social media, monitor social media conversations, and have a plan in place for addressing potential issues. A case study involving a CFO who accidentally posted confidential information on his personal Facebook page illustrates the importance of being mindful of social media usage.

site_title: Know-your-customer project hits speed bump
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has hit a snag with its proposed centralized know-your-customer (KYC) utility, which aims to streamline the verification process for financial institutions. The project, announced in 2017, faces cost issues and has hit a snag due to the complexity of verifying corporate customers' details. Despite setbacks, MAS managing director Ravi Menon believes that "setbacks are an inherent part of the innovation process" and that the utility will be "transformative" in reducing costs and processing time.

site_title: For Alvin Li, impact investing means taxing dad and becoming a vegan
summary: Alvin Li, a 28-year-old serial social entrepreneur, advocates for impact investing, which involves taking ownership of a company's environmental impact. He has divested from industries like fossil fuels, palm oil, and industrial farming and adopted a vegan lifestyle. Li also encourages his family to do the same, citing the need for "robust measures" to ensure companies' business activities are not harming the environment. He exemplifies this by not driving and relying on ride-hailing services, and by boycotting Uber due to its history of sexual misconduct.

site_title: ICP independent director barred from position in June, board discloses
summary: ICP Ltd, a Catalist-listed company, disclosed that independent director Winston Seow Han Chiang was barred from holding a director position for five years, starting June 4, 2018, under the Companies Act. Seow was appointed in 2012 but left the board four months prior to the decision being made public. The company will deliberate on a replacement for Seow, leaving the board with two independent directors. ICP's shares closed flat at S$0.009 after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US-China trade talks must cover currency, US Treasury chief says
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed concerns about the yuan's recent weakness during US-China trade talks. He emphasized the need for currency issues to be addressed in any further talks, stating that China needs to identify concrete action items to rebalance the two countries' trade relationship. Mnuchin's comments come after US-China trade talks were suspended due to disagreements over currency, trade, and other issues.

site_title: Midtown Manhattan office leasing at a high
summary: Midtown Manhattan office leasing reached its highest level since 2006, with 13.9 million square feet leased in the third quarter, according to CBRE Group. Financial companies led the way, accounting for 36% of leasing, followed by law firms and legal services. Key deals included Evercore's 343,606 sq ft renewal at 55 East 52nd Street and JPMorgan Chase's 270,536 sq ft renewal at 237 Park Avenue. The average asking rent in the district increased to $78.41 per sq ft, up 2% from the previous quarter.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees 8% home price hike in 2019 despite cooling measures
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts an 8% increase in private home prices in Singapore in 2019, despite cooling measures introduced in July. The bank forecasts a 2% price increase each quarter, contradicting other research houses' more conservative outlook. The prediction stands in stark contrast to the market's current trends, which are showing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Asiatic Group (Holdings) inks share subscription deal to issue new shares at 65% premium
summary: Asiatic Group (Holdings) has signed a conditional share subscription agreement with businessman Stephen Leong, who will subscribe to 232 million new shares at a 65% premium, giving him a 14.9% stake. The deal's net proceeds will be approximately S$3.77 million, primarily used for debt repayment and working capital. The agreement is subject to conditions and does not affect Asiatic's current financial position.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Calm does it in a calm way
summary: Calm, a mobile app that helps users relax, meditate, and sleep, has introduced Sleep Stories, a feature that guides users through soothing tales of train rides. The app boasts hundreds of podcasts, including fiction, non-fiction, and travel-themed stories, to help users unwind and fall asleep. Calm also offers meditation sessions, ranging from 2-35 minutes, and features ambient sounds to create a calming atmosphere. The app is free to download, but users must pay $60 per year after a 7-day free trial.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Raffles Medical Group announced that PNG Cheong Boon, CEO of Enterprise Singapore, will become an independent director on Oct 15. This move comes after Cheong Boon's current role as a statutory board member.

site_title: Prudential names Michael Falcon to lead North American business unit
summary: Prudential Plc has appointed Michael Falcon, a JP Morgan executive, to lead its North American business unit, effective January 7. Falcon, 55, takes over as chairman and CEO from Barry Stowe, who will retire at the end of the year. The North American business unit includes several subsidiaries, and Falcon will relocate from Hong Kong to the US, earning an annual salary of $800,000.

site_title: Sports Direct pays £95m for Glasgow building housing Frasers department store
summary: Sports Direct, controlled by billionaire Mike Ashley, has agreed to purchase the freehold of the Frasers department store in Glasgow for £95 million. The Glasgow building, which houses the first store opened by Hugh Fraser and James Arthur in 1849, will continue to operate as Frasers, with the deal saving 800 in-store jobs. The purchase is part of Ashley's plan to transform House of Fraser into the "Harrods of the high street" and create a similar luxury department store in Glasgow, dubbed the "Harrods of the North".

site_title: Turkey orders release of US Pastor Andrew Brunson
summary: A Turkish court ordered the release of US Pastor Andrew Brunson from house arrest, ending his 24-month imprisonment. Brunson, who was sentenced to three years in prison, was granted release due to good behavior and time served. The move signals a truce in the diplomatic dispute between Turkey and the US, which had raised tensions over Brunson's detention. The US had pressed for his release, while Turkey had sought to reduce penalties against a state-owned bank accused of violating US sanctions. Brunson's release allows him to fly home, marking a significant development in the dispute.

site_title: Reits
summary: Realtors and investors are bracing for a potential slump in Singapore's prime property market due to the upcoming Q3 wave of condo launches. Condo prices above S$3,000 psf are expected to face increased competition, posing a challenge to developers. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have risen after five weeks of declines, and Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with further increases anticipated. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a significant portfolio of hotel and retail assets in Seoul, while UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. WeWork has secured new tenants at its Singapore location.

site_title: Tencent Music delays US$2b IPO due to weak markets: sources
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment has delayed its planned US$2 billion initial public offering (IPO) until at least November due to weak global markets. The company, which owns popular music apps QQ Music, Kugou, and Kuwo, was initially set to launch its offering next week. The delay comes amid a slump in Wall Street, with the S&P 500 down 3.29% on Wednesday and 2.06% on Thursday. Tencent Music had planned to raise at least US$2 billion, making it one of the largest IPOs by a Chinese company in the US this year.

site_title: US FDA seeks details on new electronic cigarettes
summary: The US FDA sent letters to 21 electronic cigarette manufacturers seeking information on new products launched after August 2016, when the FDA banned the sale of new e-cigarette products without regulatory approval. The agency is concerned about the proliferation of high-nicotine e-cigarettes and sweet flavors that may attract youth. Companies that introduced products after the deadline could face fines or have their products seized. The FDA is also investigating Juul Labs Inc, which has seen its share of the e-cigarette market surge among US teenagers, and has taken steps to crack down on youth e-cigarette use.

site_title: McLaren 600LT review: Espresso shot
summary: The McLaren 600LT is a track-focused sports car that delivers exceptional performance and handling. With its 600 horsepower and lightweight design, it provides a thrilling driving experience. The car's aggressive styling and top-exit exhaust tailpipes add to its unique character. McLaren's approach to driving, emphasizing coaching and technical driver input, sets it apart from other brands. The 600LT is priced at S$819,000, making it a premium offering in the supercar market.

site_title: Trade bodies can do more to help local SMEs grow
summary: Trade associations and chambers in Singapore can play a greater role in helping local small and medium enterprises (SMEs) grow both domestically and overseas. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing suggested that trade associations can act as intermediaries, providing support such as sourcing, training, and sharing of experience. The government is also willing to help trade associations build their capabilities. Additionally, trade associations can help SMEs navigate foreign markets, share challenges and rules, and access government schemes.

site_title: Calm returns to Asian markets after rout, STI up 0.71%
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Friday, with the STI up 0.71%, following a steep selloff the previous day. The US markets, however, tumbled for a second straight session, with the Dow Jones dropping 545 points. Key indices in China, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul recovered, with the Hang Seng index surging 2.12% and Seoul's Kospi index gaining 1.51%. The rebound was driven by better-than-expected Chinese trade data and reports that the US had held back from labelling China a currency manipulator.

site_title: Economy strong, stock drop a 'natural correction' - Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the US economy remains strong despite a recent decline in the stock market, calling it a "natural correction." Mnuchin downplayed concerns over President Trump's attacks on the Federal Reserve, stating Trump "respects the independence of the Fed." Mnuchin also expressed confidence in Fed Chair Jerome Powell's performance and the fundamentals of the US economy, citing strong earnings and a resilient economy.

site_title: Magnus Energy replies to 37 queries by Singapore Exchange and Catalist sponsor
summary: Magnus Energy Group, a Catalist-listed company, has responded to 37 queries from its sponsor and the Singapore Exchange regarding issues raised by its former managing director, Charles Madhavan. The company addressed concerns over outstanding loans to an Indonesian contractor, PT Hanjungin, which owes S$6.9 million. Magnus stated that it is still in talks with PT Hanjungin and that the company is not in its interests to demand immediate payment. The company also clarified its involvement in a dispute over a plot of land in Timor.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: UK PM faces backlash over Brexit compromise
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces backlash over a proposed Brexit compromise that could involve a customs union with the EU. Her office denied plans would be "time-limited," sparking concerns among some ministers. Negotiations with the EU intensify ahead of a high-stakes summit next week, with May briefing her Cabinet on her approach. The UK's economy shrinks for the second month, adding to pressure on May's government.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Theresa May's office insisted Friday it would not "trap" Britain in an endless customs union with the EU after Brexit, amid reports some ministers could quit if this is the price of a divorce deal.

site_title: US: Wall Street gains at open as banks rise
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by strong earnings from the country's largest banks, including JPMorgan. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 354.80 points, or 1.42%, to 25,407.63, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The gains were despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, with President Trump making new threats. The market appears to be brushing off the uncertainty, with stocks continuing their rally.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened higher on Friday, as bumper results from the country's largest banks, including JPMorgan, set an upbeat tone for the earnings season.

site_title: Trade associations, chambers can do more to help local SMEs grow locally and abroad: Chan
summary: Trade associations and chambers can play a greater role in helping local SMEs grow both domestically and internationally. Minister Chan Chun Sing suggested they can act as intermediaries, providing sector-specific support and training. The Ministry of Trade and Industry will help build their capabilities. Additionally, trade associations and chambers can help SMEs navigate foreign markets, share knowledge of challenges and rules, and facilitate overseas ventures. New technologies can also provide opportunities for growth, but must be applied in each business's context.

site_title: G-20 panel urges reset of global financial system to better tackle challenges
summary: A G-20 panel of top economists and leaders urges a reset of the global financial system to better tackle challenges, citing the need for a new, cooperative international order for stronger, more inclusive, and sustainable growth. The proposed reforms include strengthening public finances, encouraging private investment, and tapping non-governmental organizations to help developing economies. The panel's chair, Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, emphasizes the need for bold and urgent reforms to address the challenges of a multi-polar world, particularly in Africa, where poverty, demographic, and environmental challenges are significant.

images.alt_text: Mr Tharman says current account deficits are needed for developing states.

site_title: US import prices increase 0.5 per cent on jump in fuel
summary: US import prices rose 0.5% in September, the largest increase since May, driven by a jump in fuel prices. Excluding fuels, import prices remained unchanged. The increase in fuel prices was the largest since May, while food prices rose 2%. Core import prices fell 0.1% and export prices were unchanged in September. The dollar's strength is expected to offset some of the price increase, amid the Trump administration's tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: Lian Beng Q1 net profit falls 39% on share of losses from SLB Development
summary: Lian Beng Group's first-quarter net profit fell 38.9% to S$6.97 million due to a 74.41%-owned property development arm, SLB Development, swinging into the red. Revenue rose 15.9% to S$83 million, but earnings per share fell to 1.39 Singapore cents. The group expects recurring income from investment properties and is "cautiously optimistic" on the construction industry, with a S$1.25 billion order book until FY2022.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: One final tennis hurrah
summary: The WTA's Melissa Pine is set to host the final edition of the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global, a tournament that has seen top players like Simona Halep and Naomi Osaka compete. The event, which takes place from October 21-28, will feature the world's top eight singles players and doubles teams, with a US$7 million prize purse at stake. Pine, a former NCAA tennis player, is determined to go out on a high note, having witnessed some of the greatest matches in women's professional tennis during her five-year stint in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Ms Pine (centre), with last year's WTA Finals winner Caroline Wozniacki (left) and runner-up Venus Williams.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: Qatar pledges US$3 billion to spur interest in new free zones
summary: Qatar plans to spend $3 billion to attract foreign companies to its new free zones, aiming to diversify its economy amid a boycott. The free zones, south of Doha, will focus on logistics, chemicals, plastics, and artificial intelligence, with a $3 billion development fund as an incentive. The country has already spent $10 billion developing the areas and plans to increase the fund to over $5 billion as the zones expand. Qatar aims to rival Dubai's financial center and attract companies such as Exxon Mobil and Volkswagen AG, seeking to boost investments and maximize the use of its wealth.

images.alt_text: Qatar plans to spend US$3 billion to attract foreign companies to its new free zones as the oil-rich country seeks to diversify its economy amid a boycott.

site_title: Japan PM Abe to make rare China visit
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will make a rare visit to China from October 25 to 27, marking the 40th anniversary of the Treaty of Peace and Friendship between the two nations. The visit aims to elevate bilateral ties and promote cooperation on multilateralism and free trade. Abe's previous visits were in 2011, and Chinese President Xi Jinping has met him several times on the sidelines of international events. Despite warming ties, sources of tension remain, including a territorial dispute over the East China Sea and military activities in the region.

site_title: Swissco signs agreement to transfer listing status by scheme of arrangement
summary: Swissco Holdings, a marine company under judicial management, has signed an agreement to transfer its listing status to Plus Renewable Technologies through a scheme of arrangement. Plus Renewable will pay S$6 million for the transfer through the issuing of shares. The move aims to provide some recovery to shareholders and creditors, offering better returns than a liquidation scenario. The agreement is subject to meeting conditions precedents and has a long-stop date of July 31, 2019.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust to divest from Shanghai chemical warehouse for 87m yuan
summary: Cache Logistics Trust is selling its Jinshan Chemical Warehouse in Shanghai to Zhejiang Yongtai Logistics for 87 million yuan, a 12.5% premium over valuation and 22.5% above the original purchase price of 71 million yuan. The sale is part of a portfolio rebalancing and growth strategy, with expected gains of 1.3 million yuan to be recognized by Dec 31.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Saudi faces business backlash over Khashoggi disappearance
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is facing a backlash from the business and media communities over the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Prominent figures, including Richard Branson and Dara Khosrowshahi, have suspended partnerships and cancelled appearances at the Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh. The conference has seen a wave of cancellations, with some major media organizations and investors pulling out as a result of the controversy. The US President Donald Trump has defended Saudi Arabia, saying there would be limits to any backlash, but the disappearance of Khashoggi has raised concerns about human rights and the legitimacy of the crown prince's reform drive.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase profits up; warns on geopolitical risk
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a 24.5% increase in third-quarter net income to $8.4 billion, driven by an improving global economy and higher interest rates. The bank's revenues rose 5.2% to $27.8 billion, beating analyst expectations. CEO Jamie Dimon attributed the results to a "smart regulatory policy" and lower taxes, but warned that geopolitical uncertainty could slow future growth. Dimon also criticized President Trump's trade policies, which led to a rebuke from the president last month.

site_title: China unveils rulebook for Shanghai-London stock connect
summary: China has published rules for a Shanghai-London stock connect, allowing companies to list on both exchanges. Companies must meet certain thresholds and limit the number of shares they can issue. Investors can swap London-listed depositary receipts for company stock 120 days after listing, down from six months. The link, which has been in the works since 2015, aims to connect China's capital markets with the world, amid President Xi Jinping's push for financial liberalization.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Friday after Thursday's sell-off
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 21.78 points, or 0.71%, to 3,069.17 on Friday, recovering from Thursday's steep sell-off. About 2.04 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 293 to 131. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with no significant news from the article provided to explain the movements.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up 2.1%
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose sharply on Friday, with the Hang Seng index jumping 2.12% to close at 25,801.49, despite a tariff war with Washington and better-than-expected Chinese trade data. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.91%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.19%. The gains followed a day of heavy losses in Hong Kong and a 5-day rally in Singapore.

site_title: South Korea crypto exchange Bithumb sold for US$354m to plastic surgeon-led group
summary: South Korea's major cryptocurrency exchange Bithumb was sold for US$354 million to a consortium led by plastic surgeon Kim Byung-gun, founder of BK Medical Group. The deal makes BK Global Consortium the largest stakeholder of Bithumb, following a hacking incident earlier this year that stole US$32 million.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end 8-session losing streak; won rises
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended an 8-session losing streak, gaining 1.51% on robust China exports data and positive US Treasury reports. The Korean won rose, and bond yields also increased. Shares of tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix led the gains, while the currency edged down 0.1% for the week.

site_title: Travelite Holdings to buy associate's assets for S$374,800
summary: Travelite Holdings has agreed to purchase the assets of its 35%-owned subsidiary Delsey Singapore (DSG) for S$374,800. The deal will help achieve economies of scale and allow Demarco to re-enter the Malaysian luggage market. DSG, which had been losing money since 2017, will supply products to Demarco on a wholesale basis, with Demarco receiving a 35% share of profits and annual dividends. The acquisition is expected to be funded internally.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 22.25 points to 1,730.74 on Friday, driven by a 2.2 billion lots worth RM2.5 billion in volume, with gainers outnumbering losers 578 to 334.

site_title: Saudi team arrives in Turkey for Khashoggi investigation - sources
summary: A Saudi delegation has arrived in Turkey for a joint investigation into the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who vanished after entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on October 2. Prince Khaled al-Faisal visited Turkey on Thursday for talks, and the two countries agreed to form a joint working group to investigate the case. This move comes after Turkish officials and Khashoggi's fiancee reported he never left the consulate. The joint investigation is at Riyadh's initiative, marking a significant development in the ongoing case.

images.alt_text: A delegation from Saudi Arabia has arrived in Turkey as part of a joint investigation into the disappearance of prominent Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, two Turkish sources said on Friday.

site_title: Australian shares inch up amid subdued investor interest; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Friday, closing at 5,895.70, but fell 4.7% for the week, amid a global sell-off. Gains in metals and mining stocks offset losses in energy and real estate. Mining behemoths BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto finished higher, while iron ore prices held up relatively well. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1.4% for the first time in 10 sessions, closing at 8,843.24.

site_title: Princess Eugenie weds in Peter Pilotto dress and queen's tiara
summary: Princess Eugenie married Jack Brooksbank at Windsor Castle's St George's Chapel in an elegant voluminous dress by Peter Pilotto. The 28-year-old bride wore a fitted corset and pleated skirt with a long train, designed to reveal scars from childhood surgery. The dress featured motifs meaningful to the couple, including thistle and shamrock, and was chosen after a close collaboration with the designers. Eugenie also wore Queen Elizabeth's Greville Emerald Kokoshnik tiara and satin peep-toe heels. The wedding took place at the same venue as Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's nuptials in May.

site_title: Tee International, Tee Land in red for Q1
summary: Tee International reported a net loss of S$3.8 million in its first quarter, up from a net loss of S$918,000 in the previous year, due to increased cost of sales and expenses. The company's topline grew 11.9% to S$78.5 million, driven by revenue from acquired subsidiaries. Loss per share worsened to 0.77 Singapore cent, from 0.18 Singapore cent in the previous year.

site_title: ASL Marine unveils informal steering committee, meeting for noteholders
summary: ASL Marine Holdings has set up an informal steering committee of noteholders to review its financing and capitalization structure. The committee will be facilitated by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) and will include holders of its series 006 and 007 notes. The company will provide an update on talks with its principal bankers and present a proposal for the notes. Noteholders are invited to join the committee and attend an informal meeting on October 29. This move follows previous informal meetings held in September and aims to improve communication with noteholders.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Delong to resume trading from Friday 1pm after privatisation plan scuppered
summary: Shares in Delong Holdings will resume trading on the Singapore bourse at 1pm on Friday after being suspended since Oct 5. The suspension followed the withdrawal of a S$7-a-share cash offer by Best Decade, an investment vehicle of Delong CEO Ding Liguo, amid a probe into potential breaches of Singapore's Take-over Code. The offer had been made to acquire 90% of Delong's shares, but Ding cited a requirement to hike the offer price to S$7.42 a share.

site_title: WhatsApp hits the road with skits to stamp out fake news in India
summary: WhatsApp has launched a 10-city roadshow in India to combat fake news, with skits and educational campaigns aimed at users. The effort, in partnership with Reliance Jio, follows intense government pressure to tackle misinformation that has led to over 30 deaths in 70 lynching attempts since 2017. WhatsApp has introduced a limit on forwarded messages, launched newspaper and radio campaigns, and developed a digital literacy curriculum with a non-profit organization. The company is also training police officials to use WhatsApp to combat misinformation, with the goal of driving public education on the issue.

images.alt_text: On a hot morning in India's tourist mecca of Jaipur, an open truck painted in the signature lime-green colours of Facebook's WhatsApp messaging service pulls into a dusty lane, where five men spill out and begin to perform a skit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks recover from global rout
summary: Tokyo stocks recovered from a global rout, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.46% to close at 22,694.66 on Friday, following a 4.58% drop over the week. The declines were linked to US interest rates and trade wars, with President Trump criticizing the Federal Reserve.
