A weak yen also encouraged investors to buy back shares, lifting the dollar to 112.39 yen in Asian afternoon trade. Individual stocks such as Nintendo and Toyota rose, while Sony lost 0.47%.

site_title: Thousands to march in Chicago against Trump's 'anti-woman agenda'
summary: Thousands of women in Chicago are expected to march against President Trump's "anti-woman agenda" ahead of the midterm elections, coinciding with the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh to the US Supreme Court. The protest, organized by Women's March Chicago, aims to mobilize women to vote against the Republican party. Similar marches are scheduled in other states, including Texas, Georgia, and South Carolina. The event is part of a nationwide movement fueled by anger over the Kavanaugh confirmation, with protesters to be directed to early voting locations to cast ballots.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is increasing the pace of the Singapore dollar's appreciation to ensure medium-term price stability. Singapore's Q3 GDP growth slowed to 2.6% year on year, while retail sales fell for the second month in August. The MAS is also reviewing a know-your-customer utility experiment and assessing a bid for Hyflux's Tuaspring project. Meanwhile, Singapore home prices are expected to rise 10% by the end of 2019 and double by 2030.

site_title: Europe: Stocks recover from 2016 low as miners, tech advance
summary: European equities rebounded 0.9% on Thursday, trimming the weekly drop to 3.6%, after all sectors advanced, led by tech and mining shares. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index reached a 2016 low on Wednesday due to rising interest rates and US-China trade concerns. Analysts say European equities are under-owned and look oversold, while the region may benefit from a value rotation if US growth slows. Despite this, Europe is unlikely to outperform if US equities continue to fall.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia move to deepen trade, investment links
summary: Singapore and Indonesia announced several initiatives to deepen trade and investment links, including a $10 billion local currency swap and a Bilateral Investment Treaty. The agreements aim to foster economic cooperation, protect investors, and promote financial technology and cultural exchange. The two countries also plan to develop a new RISING fellowship program and enhance tourism and defense collaborations. The initiatives are seen as a step towards strengthening their long-term relationship for the benefit of their people.

site_title: JV losses, new reporting standards send SLB Development into the red by S$2.8m in Q1
summary: SLB Development, a Catalist-listed property developer, reported a net loss of S$2.79 million in Q1 2018 due to swelling sales, marketing, and administrative expenses, lower operating income, and joint venture losses. The company's turnover decreased by 33.6% year-on-year to S$23 million, primarily from the recognition of units sold at the T-Space @ Tampines project. The company expects the residential market to remain challenging and will continue to monitor the market closely, focusing on opportunities in the resilient industrial sector.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: The yuan is Asia's weakest currency
summary: The yuan, Asia's weakest currency, fell 0.47% to 6.9215 per US dollar after the People's Bank of China set a daily reference rate weaker than expected. Chinese trade data beat estimates, with exports rising 14.5% and imports climbing 14.3%. Stocks rebounded, with the Hang Seng Index up 1.8%, as investors sought to buy dollars on the dip against the yuan. The yuan has fallen over 9% against the dollar in the past six months, with analysts attributing it to the trade war, economic slowdown, and monetary easing.

site_title: Singapore housing curbs won't cool prices, says Morgan Stanley
summary: Singapore home prices may rise 10% by end of 2019 and double by 2030, driven by faster income growth and demand from cash-rich buyers, according to Morgan Stanley. Despite recent property curbs, analysts say housing supply is below historical averages and set to fall, leading to a wave of capital inflows. The government's goal of price stability and sustainable growth is seen as achievable, with a toolkit to stimulate the market if needed. Faster economic growth and Singapore's status as a global hub also support the bullish outlook.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,058.65, up 0.37% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.37% to 3,058.65 on Friday, driven by a gain of 1.1% for Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Genting Singapore and Rex International were also among the top gainers. The Straits Times Index saw 214 gainers for every 137 losers, with 887.4 million securities changing hands.

site_title: Britain's RBS pays first dividend in decade
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) paid its first dividend in a decade, returning 2 pence per share to around 190,000 shareholders. The bank's CEO, Ross McEwan, said the dividend was a small return for years of patience, following a government bailout in 2008. The UK government, which holds a 62% stake in RBS, will receive around £240 million from the payout, while the bank has a healthy level of excess capital to return to investors. This milestone marks a significant step in RBS's turnaround process.

site_title: Asean leaders vow to uphold the multilateral trade and international cooperation
summary: ASEAN leaders reaffirmed their commitment to upholding the multilateral trade and international cooperation system, amid rising protectionism and global challenges. The 10-member grouping vowed to ensure no one is left behind in progress, with a focus on sustainable development and economic integration. Asean aims to achieve a "substantial conclusion" of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership by the end-of-year, with Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong calling for modernization, not dismantling, the global trade system.

site_title: Indonesia sees weakening currency as beneficial to spur reforms
summary: Indonesia's weakening currency is seen as a catalyst to spur economic reforms, according to Thomas Lembong, chairman of the Investment Coordinating Board. The government will soon announce measures to increase foreign investment and boost the economy, aiming to address the current-account deficit and currency slump. Lembong believes the current market turmoil will trigger fresh reforms, with the goal of achieving higher economic growth.

site_title: CSC Holdings recovers S$600,000 after amicable settlement in 2017 sub-contract dispute
summary: CSC Holdings has recovered S$600,000 after settling a dispute with UES Holdings, the main contractor for a stormwater storage tank project by PUB. The dispute involved payment claims and interim valuation certificates. As part of the settlement, the value of the performance bond will be recovered by L&M Foundation Specialist, along with the balance of outstanding claims. The settlement was reached amicably in 2017.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore and Indonesia plan bilateral US$10b stability package
summary: Singapore and Indonesia plan a $10 billion bilateral stability package, comprising a local currency swap and US dollar repurchase agreements, to boost confidence amid global liquidity risks and volatile markets. The package aims to support monetary and financial stability, particularly for Indonesia, which has seen the rupiah fall to a two-decade low due to the emerging market rout. The arrangement is seen as a positive development to mitigate global liquidity risks and market volatility, with economists welcoming Singapore's leadership role in regional financial cooperation.

site_title: IMF warns trade friction, market turmoil to hurt Asian growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that sustained trade tensions and market turmoil could slash Asia's economic growth by up to 0.9 percentage point over the next couple of years. The IMF urges policymakers in the region to liberalize markets to offset the impact of reduced export sales. The organization maintains its forecast that Asia's economy will expand by 5.6% this year but cuts its projection for next year to 5.4%, citing financial market stress and monetary tightening in some economies.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars proving resilient after rough week
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars ended a tough week on a positive note, with the Australian dollar rising 1% to US$0.7122 and holding a 1% weekly gain. Chinese data beat expectations, boosting risk appetite, and a lull in the equity rout also contributed to the dollar's resilience. The Australian dollar faces chart resistance ahead of a retracement target at US$0.7176.

site_title: Indonesia's president calls for vigilance over global economic risks
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged global central bankers and finance ministers to remain committed to cooperation and support the world's economy, citing risks similar to those in the popular series "Game of Thrones". He emphasized the need for vigilance, referencing the motto "Winter is Coming", as global economic troubles loom.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged global central bankers and finance ministers on Friday to remain committed to cooperation and to "nudge their leaders in the right direction" to support the world's economy.

site_title: Hyflux assessing bid by one of two pre-approved parties for Tuaspring
summary: Hyflux Group, a water treatment firm, said only one of two pre-approved parties, Sembcorp Industries, has submitted a bid for its Tuaspring water and power project. The bid is being assessed due to confidentiality requirements. Bloomberg reported Sembcorp's offer was below Tuaspring's book value and won't cover the project's main creditor's loans. Hyflux remains open to considering various opportunities and has not committed to any particular option. The sale of Tuaspring is a key component in the company's plan to restructure its debt and obtain capital.

site_title: BMW to buy control of China venture in 'new era' for foreign carmakers
summary: BMW will acquire 75% control of its Chinese joint venture, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd, in a deal worth 3.6 billion euros. The move, expected to close in 2022, marks a significant shift for foreign carmakers in China, where Beijing has relaxed ownership rules. The deal could spur BMW to shift more production to China, protecting profits amid the US-China trade war. Analysts predict other carmakers, such as Mercedes, may follow suit, and the deal could mark a new era for foreign carmakers in China.

site_title: Unlikely winners from Hong Kong's market crash: retail investors
summary: Hong Kong retail investors who traded callable bull/bear contracts (CBBCs) made a profit overall despite the market crash. According to UBS Group AG, CBBC investors made HK$480 million from bear contracts on the Hang Seng Index, exceeding the HK$200 million loss on bull contracts. They also generated a HK$61 million profit from bear contracts on Tencent Holdings Ltd, offsetting the HK$28 million lost on bullish contracts. CBBCs are structured products favored by retail investors, offering limited losses and unlimited upside.

site_title: China exports surge in September, creating record surplus with US despite tariffs
summary: China exported a record $34.13 billion more than the US in September, surpassing the August record due to strong export growth of 14.5% year-over-year. This growth may indicate US tariffs are not significantly impacting Chinese exports. Analysts, however, warn that this resilience is unlikely to be sustained as global growth cools and US tariffs become more punishing. The yuan's depreciation has also taken the sting out of US tariffs, but China's surplus with the US could prompt a reaction from US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Singapore's know-your-customer utility experiment hits snag: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has encountered an issue with its proposed centralized know-your-customer (KYC) utility, which aimed to streamline the identification and verification of potential customers' details. Introduced a year ago, the utility was intended to enhance the efficiency of checking against sanctions and blacklists to prevent money laundering and terrorism financing. The project has hit a snag, with no further updates provided on its current status.

site_title: Stock losses muted in Asia after global rout
summary: Asian stock markets opened with losses, but they were relatively muted after a global rout sparked by concerns over US interest rates and a trade war between the US and China. Japan's Nikkei-225 index fell 1% before rebounding, while Chinese stocks lost 0.36%. However, markets in South Korea and Hong Kong bucked the trend, with the Kospi and Hang Seng indices rising. The global sell-off was sparked by US President Trump's comments on the Federal Reserve, with the Dow Jones ending 2.1% down for the day.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.45% in early trade on Friday, following a US market recovery from a previous day's rout. The Hang Seng Index increased to 25,379.61, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.36%. This recovery comes as traders in Asia brush off new US threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: South Korea employment bounces back as jobless rate falls, more jobs created
summary: South Korea's job market rebounded in September with an unemployment rate of 4.0%, down from 4.2% in August. The country created 45,000 new jobs, exceeding August's 3,000. This marked the strongest month for job growth in nearly nine years. The improvement comes after August, the labor market's weakest month since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Boom underway in quiet corner of China's credit market
summary: China's credit market is experiencing a boom, driven by banks seeking to free up balance sheets to support economic growth. Structured debt sales in the interbank bond market surged to a record 300 billion yuan in the last quarter, with residential mortgage-backed securities accounting for 60% of issuance. This growth is seen as a positive development, as China's central bank has cut reserve requirements to boost lending. Despite concerns about the market's maturity and lack of data on crisis performance, experts expect the securitization market to continue growing.

site_title: Dr Doom v Mr Ethereum: crypto pits economists against engineers
summary: Economist Nouriel Roubini, known as Dr. Doom for predicting the 2008 financial crisis, clashed with Ethereum founder Vitalik Buterin over the merits of cryptocurrencies. Roubini criticized the industry for its lack of intrinsic value, high transaction costs, and energy consumption. He warned of a potential financial crisis and pointed to research showing that most initial coin offerings are scams. Buterin countered with a defense of his technology, citing its potential to decentralize financial transactions and its ongoing development. The debate highlights a fundamental difference in worldview between economists who view crypto as a hype-based bubble and engineers who see it as a problem worth solving.

site_title: China exports rise 14.5% in September despite US trade tensions
summary: China's exports rose 14.5% in September, exceeding forecasts, despite worsening relations with the US. Imports also increased 14.3%, resulting in a $32 billion trade surplus. However, economists warn that exports are likely to weaken in the coming quarters due to slowing global growth and US tariffs. The US and China continue to impose tariffs on each other, with no signs of backing down. China's trade growth may slow in the fourth quarter, and policymakers are rolling out measures to support the domestic economy.

site_title: China Sept aluminium, steel exports hold steady as trade row goes on
summary: China's aluminium exports decreased slightly in September to 507,000 tonnes, down 0.6% from August, as a narrowing price arbitrage reduced the incentive to ship metal overseas. Steel exports rose 1.4% to 5.95 million tonnes in September, driven by high production levels and an arbitrage of up to $30 a tonne between steel prices in Southeast Asia and China. The US trade row has not significantly impacted China's steel exports, with the country maintaining its top position as the world's largest steel producer.

site_title: South Korea unemployment inches down in September as fiscal spending boosts healthcare jobs
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate fell to 4.0% in September, the lowest in eight years, as fiscal spending boosted healthcare jobs. The number of employed rose by 45,000 people, the biggest increase since June. The healthcare sector saw a 133,000 job increase, while manufacturers shed 42,000 jobs and retailers cut 100,000 jobs. Analysts expect a slow job market recovery due to ongoing restructuring in the manufacturing sector. The government's efforts to improve healthcare and add social workers contributed to the job growth, but experts warn that the manufacturing sector's investment remains weak.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - How this local software developer battles the big boys
summary: Local software developer Titansoft, in a competitive industry dominated by tech giants, has managed to set itself apart by focusing on people operations and employee satisfaction. Joanna Zhan, Team Lead (People Operations), shares strategies to attract and retain talent, including investing in employee well-being and creating a positive company culture. With support from Enterprise Singapore, Titansoft has been able to navigate the challenges of competing with larger companies and establish a strong reputation in the industry.

images.alt_text: Patrick Lim (Director of Business & Service Excellence at Enterprise Singapore) and Joanna Zhan (Team Lead, People Operations, Titansoft)

site_title: China human resources ministry says National Energy Administration director removed from post
summary: China's Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security announced the removal of National Energy Administration director Nur Bekri from his position, effective immediately. Bekri, appointed in 2014, is under investigation for suspected serious disciplinary and legal violations. The move comes after the Communist Party's anti-corruption watchdog identified Bekri as a target for investigation last month. The exact reasons for Bekri's removal are not specified, but the incident highlights ongoing efforts to combat corruption within China's government.

site_title: Singapore retail sales fall for second month in August with 0.4% dip
summary: Singapore retail sales fell 0.4% in August for the second consecutive month, largely due to lower vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicles, the sector saw a 2.4% rise in sales. Online sales contributed 4.6% to the sector's haul, while petrol stations saw a 10.4% increase in sales. Conversely, jewellers and department stores registered stronger sales, with jewellers up 6.3% and department stores up 3.3%. Food and beverage services saw a 3.2% increase, led by fast food outlets and restaurants.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore Q3 GDP growth slows less than expected to 2.6% as manufacturing moderates
summary: Singapore's Q3 GDP growth slowed to 2.6% year-on-year, less than expected, as manufacturing moderated due to base effects, a fading electronics cycle, and trade war concerns. However, services-producing industries remained steady, and construction contracted by 3.1% year-on-year. The economy is expected to continue growing, albeit at a slow pace, with economists forecasting growth within the 2.5-3.5% range for 2018 and easing slightly in 2019.

site_title: Market selloff rattles IPO hopefuls with LeasePlan, Sonae dropping plans
summary: The US and European stock markets experienced a significant downturn, prompting several companies to shelve their initial public offerings (IPOs). LeasePlan Corp NV and Sonae SGPS SA cancelled their IPO plans due to market conditions, while Tencent Music Entertainment Group paused its US IPO. The S&P 500 reached a three-month low, and Europe's main equity index fell to its lowest since 2016. This trend is expected to continue, with at least eight IPOs withdrawn or postponed in the past 11 days, highlighting the challenges of executing IPOs in volatile markets.

site_title: New York judge dismisses one sex assault charge against Weinstein
summary: A New York judge dismissed one sex assault charge against Harvey Weinstein, allowing his defense to continue fighting the remaining five allegations. The decision came after prosecutors agreed to drop a forced act of oral sex charge due to witness inconsistencies, citing credibility issues and possible police misconduct. Defense lawyer Ben Brafman claimed the case against Weinstein is "not sustainable" and accused the district attorney of prosecuting him under pressure from the press. The next hearing is scheduled for December 20, and Weinstein remains charged with rape and other crimes.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday; STI at 3,046.85
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.54 points to 3,046.85. About 63 million shares worth S$85 million changed hands, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rising S$0.03 to S$1.26. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 72, while DBS and OCBC Bank shares fell 0.3% each. Globally, the Nikkei and Topix declined, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 fell 0.1%, and South Korea's Kospi rose 0.6%.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.56 points lower on Friday, closing at 1,706.93. The market saw 141 losers compared to 48 gainers, with a total volume of 41.38 million lots worth RM16.66 million.

site_title: Standard Life Aberdeen raises deemed interest in AEM Holdings to 7.2%
summary: Standard Life Aberdeen has increased its deemed interest in AEM Holdings to 7.2% following an open market purchase of about 1.86 million shares for S$1.53 million. The stake was raised from 6.5% previously. The move comes after AEM announced its test solution was selected by Huawei for its 5G network, although analyst William Tng downgraded the stock due to concerns. AEM shares finished down S$0.03 or 3.7% at S$0.79 on Thursday.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens down 1%, extending global rout
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index opened down 1% on Friday, extending losses in global bourses due to concerns over higher interest rates and trade wars. The benchmark index plummeted 3.89% the previous day, and the Topix index was down 0.66%. The losses come as investors await US-EU trade talks and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Virgin's Branson halts talks on US$1b Saudi investment in space ventures
summary: British billionaire Richard Branson suspended talks with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund over a planned $1 billion investment in Virgin Group's space ventures due to the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Branson cited concerns over the Saudi government's actions and the ability to do business with the government in the West. The decision affects two Saudi tourism projects and Virgin Galactic, The Spaceship Company, and Virgin Orbit.

site_title: MAS to strengthen Singdollar at faster pace; expects economic growth to moderate in 2019
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has increased the pace of the Singapore dollar's appreciation to ensure medium-term price stability, marking its second consecutive tightening. The MAS expects the economy to remain on a steady expansion path in 2019, with 2018 growth landing within the upper half of the official forecast range of 2.5 to 3.5 percent. Core inflation is expected to average 1.5 to 2.5 percent in 2019, and headline inflation is projected to be about 1 to 2 percent next year.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: UOB said to be reviewing insurance deal with Prudential
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is reviewing its insurance business, including its partnership with Prudential Plc, amid a surge in lucrative distribution deals in South-east Asia. The bank is soliciting ideas from potential advisers to get more value out of the operations, considering options such as renewing the 2010 agreement or looking for another partner. This move comes as bancassurance deals in Asia are fetching top dollar, with Standard Chartered expected to earn at least $1 billion over 15 years from its Asia agreement with Allianz SE.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank Ltd. is reviewing its insurance business, including an existing partnership with Prudential Plc, after South-east Asia witnessed a wave of lucrative distribution deals, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Facebook purges 251 accounts to thwart deception
summary: Facebook has purged 251 accounts and 559 pages for violating rules against spam and coordinated deceit, including ad farms posing as political forums. The move aims to prevent the spread of misinformation ahead of US elections in November. Facebook is also setting up a "war room" to quickly respond to election-related efforts to manipulate the platform. The company has recently thwarted foreign influence campaigns and blocked nearly 1.3 billion fake accounts using artificial intelligence software. This effort is part of Facebook's ongoing efforts to prevent voter manipulation and deception.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Delong, SingHaiyi, Chip Eng Seng, Yangzijiang, Sasseur Reit, AEM Holdings
summary: Delong Holdings' CEO Ding Liguo backed out of a privatization attempt due to revised offer price. SingHaiyi Group's Celine Tang became Chip Eng Seng Corp's new chairman. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding formed a joint-venture shipbuilder with Japan's Mitsui E&S Shipbuilding. Sasseur Reit's stake was cut to 1.36% after private equity firm L Catterton Asia sold part of its stake. AEM Holdings saw Standard Life Aberdeen increase its deemed interest to 7.2%. SPH Reit declared a 1.43 cents DPU, a 0.7% increase.

site_title: Step Up
summary: The Esplanade's da:ns festival features a quadruple bill by Nederlands Dans Theatre 1 on Oct 13-14, including Shoot The Moon, set to Philip Glass' music. Another highlight is Invisible Habitudes by Singapore choreographer Kuik Swee Boon, exploring identity in a world with too much information, staged on Oct 11-12. The festival showcases a range of contemporary and classical dance performances.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US curbs China nuclear exports as Trump warns Americans not 'stupid'
summary: The US will restrict civilian nuclear exports to China, increasing scrutiny and requiring a presumption of denial for new licenses, amid rising tensions over trade. President Trump warned China not to think Americans are "stupid" and imposed $250 billion in tariffs. China has responded with counter tariffs, and the IMF lowered its growth forecast for China and the global economy. The US has shipped $170 million in nuclear exports to China last year, and China's efforts to acquire nuclear technology are seen as a national security threat.

site_title: Europe: Shares sink to 21-month lows as global selloff deepens
summary: European shares plummeted to 21-month lows, sinking 1.7% and 2% respectively, as global investors sold off risky assets amid concerns over rising US Treasury yields and slowing global growth. Despite a partial recovery on Wall Street, European stocks remain under pressure, with the Stoxx 600 benchmark index down 4.5% for the week. Defensive sectors like healthcare and real estate outperformed, while tech stocks recovered some losses due to M&A hopes.

site_title: Sasseur Reit loses PE firm L Catterton Asia as substantial unitholder
summary: Sasseur Reit's substantial unitholder L Catterton Asia has sold part of its stake in the Reit's sponsor, Sasseur Cayman Holding, reducing its deemed stake from 58.86% to 1.36%. The sale was deemed a "normal course of action for the fund" and L Catterton Asia remains confident in Sasseur's growth prospects. Sasseur Reit's units closed at S$0.69, down 2.8% amid a broad market selldown.

site_title: A veto that heralds prolonged US-China strategic rivalry
summary: The USMCA's "veto" clause, allowing a US veto of trade agreements with non-market countries, sets a worrying precedent for the US-China strategic rivalry. This rivalry is driven by competition over innovation and technology, but also control of a global narrative and competing strategic visions for the world order. The US seeks to defend its global preeminence, while China's triumphalist rhetoric and expressed global ambitions are seen as threats. The label of "non-market economy" for China is a key factor in this rivalry, as it delegitimizes its economic rise and fuels a zero-sum game. Both sides must tread carefully to avoid false equivalences and escalating tensions.

site_title: US: Stocks end again with deep losses, Dow -2.1%
summary: US stocks plummeted for a second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.1% to 25,049.65, amid concerns over higher interest rates and trade wars. The S&P 500 dropped 2.1% to 2,728.26, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.2% to 7,330.26, bringing weekly losses to over 5%. This marks the second straight day of significant losses, as investors remain cautious about the impact of rising interest rates and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: World's longest flight departs Singapore for New York
summary: Singapore Airlines' world's longest commercial flight departed from Singapore for New York, marking 19 hours in the air, covering 16,700km. The Airbus A350-900ULR, configured for 161 passengers, features a "wellness" menu, over 1,200 hours of entertainment, and larger windows. The flight, which can take up to 18 hours and 45 minutes under normal conditions, aims to capitalize on a niche market as airlines compete for longest routes.

site_title: Melania Trump says she may be the world's 'most bullied' person
summary: Melania Trump stated in an ABC News interview that she may be the world's most bullied person, citing online criticism of her attire during her recent African trip. The former model, who has faced mockery over her fashion choices, believes her "Be Best" initiative is focusing on social media and online behavior. Despite online catty comments, she expressed her enjoyment of life in the White House and supported her husband's potential second term as US president. Her comments come after criticism of her fashion choices, including comparisons to colonial administrators and Michael Jackson.

site_title: Federal Reserve in Trump's line of fire but unlikely to change course
summary: US President Donald Trump has criticized the Federal Reserve, calling its interest rate hikes "out of control," but the central bank is unlikely to change course. Despite Trump's attacks, the Fed has explained the justification behind the rate increases, citing a strong economy and low inflation. Experts say Trump's criticism may damage the Fed's reputation and credibility, but Chairman Jerome Powell has emphasized the bank's focus on long-term economic goals. The Fed is expected to continue raising interest rates to prevent inflation, despite Trump's claims that the moves are causing a "correction" in the economy.

site_title: More budding than blossoming
summary: Blossom, a newly opened restaurant at Marina Bay Sands, offers a promising Cantonese cuisine experience despite some rough edges in service. Chefs Fok Kai Yee and Jason Lau bring impressive credentials to the kitchen. Standout dishes include Peking duck, tiger king prawn, and intense seafood broth, but some dishes, such as the double-boiled fish maw soup, need refinement. With some time to hit its stride, Blossom has the potential to "literally blossom" into a top dining destination.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia commit to deepen trade, investment links
summary: Singapore and Indonesia have strengthened their economic ties with several new initiatives, including a $10 billion local currency swap and a Bilateral Investment Treaty. The agreements aim to deepen cooperation in areas such as trade, investment, and financial technology. The two countries also plan to develop a new RISING fellowship program and enhance tourism and defense collaborations. The agreements were announced during a Leaders' Retreat in Bali, where Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President Joko Widodo discussed ways to promote long-term economic benefits for their people.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President Joko Widodo at their annual Leaders' Retreat. Mr Lee announced a project to develop a new fellowship programme that hopes to see more than a dozen leaders and officials, promising young people from Indonesia, visiting Singapore.

site_title: World's largest fish market reopens at new site in Tokyo
summary: The world's largest fish market, Tsukiji, has reopened at a new site in Tokyo's Toyosu district after a $5 billion renovation. The market's first auction took place on October 11, 2018, with a minor truck fire and early morning traffic jam marking the occasion. The new site, built on reclaimed land, is 1.5 miles from the original location and aims to improve sanitation and attract more tourists. Despite concerns from some traders about the move, Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike expressed her hope to develop the market into the core market of Tokyo and Japan.

site_title: Asean and India: Fundamentals shielding region from turmoil
summary: Emerging markets, particularly Asean and India, are shielded from global turmoil due to robust fundamentals. India's ample forex reserves and Asean's growth at a slower but steady pace allow them to withstand negative global events, including the US dollar's resurgence and the escalating US-China trade war. Both regions have made significant progress since past crises, with India liberalizing its economy in 1991 and Asean implementing reforms after the 1997-98 Asian Financial Crisis, positioning them for sustainable growth.

site_title: Delong CEO scraps takeover bid amid SIC probe into possible rule breach
summary: Delong Holdings' CEO Ding Liguo has scrapped his takeover bid for the Chinese steelmaker amid a probe by the Securities Industry Council (SIC) into possible rule breaches. The SIC is investigating if Ding's controlling shareholder, Best Decade, breached a rule requiring cash offers to be made at the same price as the offeror or any concert parties paid. Ding cited a requirement to hike the offer price to S$7.42 a share, which he claimed would exceed his ability to pay for the buyout.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: FamilyMart inks 212b yen Don Quijote deal in race for growth
summary: FamilyMart, Japan's second-largest convenience-store operator, has agreed to acquire a stake in Don Quijote Holdings Co for up to 212 billion yen (S$2.6 billion). The deal includes spending 28.2 billion yen to take full ownership of Don Quijote's Uny unit, a general merchandising store chain. The move aims to help FamilyMart grow in a saturated market and follows a partnership between the two companies, which also cooperated on product development and distribution.

site_title: A Good Space helps you help others
summary: A Good Space, a not-for-profit initiative, launched A Good Pitch to empower individuals to create solutions to social issues. The program provides seed funding, mentorship, and resources to community builders and changemakers. Since its inception, 43 individuals have come forward with ideas, including a social media campaign, a festival, and an inter-generational mentorship project. The initiative aims to demonstrate the power of individuals to create positive change, with the goal of inspiring businesses to support their employees' social impact endeavors.

site_title: Sommeliers finding room to mature
summary: Patrick Cappiello, a former New York sommelier, has transitioned to making wine with his new label, Monte Rio Cellars, producing about 2,700 cases in 2018. Cappiello's career trajectory is typical of modern sommeliers, who often start as restaurant staff and later capitalize on their reputation to pursue a more fulfilling niche in the wine industry. This shift reflects the changing nature of the sommelier role, which has evolved from a glamorous job to a more demanding and less glamorous career path.

images.alt_text: Patrick Cappiello, acclaimed New York City sommelier, sampling a Syrah he made at Pax Mahle Winery.

site_title: Telstra seeks to head off pay protest with apology to shareholders
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest telecom firm, has written an apology to shareholders to head off a vote against executive pay at its annual meeting. The company has struggled with profit falls and share price decline, and has cut executives' bonuses by nearly a third. A protest vote against pay packets could trigger a vote to spill the board under Australian law. Telstra CEO Andy Penn cited intense competition and changing customer expectations as factors weighing on the company's business, and outlined a new strategy to transform the business by 2022, including cost-cutting measures and a split of mobile and infrastructure divisions.

site_title: Asean leaders vow to uphold multilateralism, international cooperation
summary: Asean leaders reaffirmed their commitment to multilateralism and international cooperation, emphasizing the importance of free and open trade. The region aims to achieve a "substantial conclusion" on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, the world's largest free trade deal, by the year-end. Asean leaders also discussed sustainable development, acknowledging the need to reduce disparities and align economic objectives with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

site_title: Oil falls 3% as equity markets drop, inventories climb
summary: Oil prices fell to two-week lows on Thursday, with Brent crude futures dropping 3.41% to $80.26 a barrel and US WTI crude futures falling 3.01% to $70.97 a barrel. The decline was attributed to a bigger-than-expected build in US crude inventories and a global risk-off environment, with US equity markets tumbling. Refinery crude runs fell by 352,000 barrels per day due to maintenance, and the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) cut its forecast of global demand growth for oil next year.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slumped to more than two-week lows on Thursday as global stock markets fell, with investor sentiment made more bearish by a bigger-than-expected build in US crude inventories.

site_title: CPA Australia has new tech-focused courses for Singapore professionals
summary: CPA Australia has launched two technology-focused training programs in Singapore for accounting and finance professionals. The Graduate Certificate in Digital Finance and the Digital in Finance program aim to equip professionals with skills to harness new technologies and stay competitive in a digital transformation era. The programs, in partnership with Singapore Management University and NTUC, respectively, offer SkillsFuture funding and subsidize course fees for Singaporeans and permanent residents. Senior Minister Janil Puthucheary emphasized the growing demand for professional services in the region, driven by international trade, financial regulations, and corporate governance needs.

site_title: Singapore tops World Bank human capital study
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the top country in the World Bank's Human Capital Index, with children born in the country expected to reach 88% of their potential productivity due to a strong education system and good health. World Bank President Kim Jim Yong attributed the country's success to its leaders' investment in healthcare and education, despite spending only 4.6% of GDP on healthcare. Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for continued improvement, particularly in preschool education and step-down care for the elderly.

site_title: BP more optimistic as it plans investments at US$60-65 a barrel oil
summary: BP CEO Bob Dudley expressed optimism about the oil market, planning investments at $60-65 a barrel, up from $50-55 last year. Dudley said higher prices may ease spending "tightness," but the company will stick to its $15 billion investment budget. BP plans to approve new projects, including two in India, which will make money at less than $40 oil by 2021. Dudley attributed the improved outlook to balanced supply and demand, but noted the market remains volatile due to US sanctions on Iran's exports.

images.alt_text: "It's a very volatile crude world right now. It could spike up and it could go down now. There are decisions that could be made that drive it either way," says Mr Dudley.

site_title: Micron to invest US$100m in AI startups
summary: Micron Technology plans to invest up to $100 million in startup companies working on artificial intelligence technologies, focusing on self-driving vehicles, factory automation, and other growing fields. This marks a significant shift for the Idaho-based memory chip maker, as its previous investments had been "very sporadic" and close to its core business. The investment program is part of Micron's efforts to expand its presence in emerging technologies and drive innovation.

site_title: Pure Passion
summary: Sottes, a sustainable fashion brand, launched its debut collection "Surrender" in October 2018, showcasing its commitment to eco-friendliness. The brand, founded by Jeanne Guenat and Elliot Upton, produces handmade garments in a Swiss village, using local seamstresses and minimizing waste. The collection features upcycled materials, such as white cotton fabric waste from vintage stores, and a genderless aesthetic. Sottes aims to challenge the fast fashion industry's mentality, opting for a slower, more sustainable approach to fashion, while staying true to its passion for the art of fashion.

site_title: IMF to launch financial assistance talks with Pakistan: Lagarde
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde announced that the organization will launch financial assistance talks with Pakistan, following a request from the country's Finance Minister Asad Umar and central bank governor Tarik Bajwa. The talks aim to address Pakistan's economic challenges, including a mounting balance of payments crisis. A possible IMF-supported economic program is being discussed, which would be Pakistan's 13th IMF bailout since 1988, and would require a complete understanding and transparency about the country's debt.

site_title: Apple signs US$600m deal with Dialog Semiconductor for assets, staff
summary: Apple has signed a $600 million deal with Dialog Semiconductor to license its power management technology and acquire certain assets, including over 300 staff. Apple will pay $300 million upfront and an additional $300 million for product delivery. The deal helps Dialog reduce its reliance on Apple, which accounts for about 75% of its revenue, to 45% over the next few years. Dialog will focus on new businesses and launch a share buyback program after the agreement.

site_title: Massive selloff sends STI 2.7% lower
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a 2.7% decline, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching a 20-month low, following an overnight rout in US stocks. Despite a surge of US$3.5 billion in global equity investments, market analysts attributed the sharp sell-off to concerns over the US mid-term election, rising interest rates, and unrealistic expectations for the third quarter earnings season. The decline was echoed across regional markets, with key benchmarks in Japan, Hong Kong, and South Korea also falling.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: S$105.3m Nassim deal is highest for GCBs
summary: A two-storey bungalow in Nassim Road, Singapore, was sold for S$105.3 million, the highest price paid for a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in absolute terms. This works out to S$2,477 per square foot on a 42,515 sq ft freehold land area. The sale is believed to be the biggest in GCB history, surpassing previous records.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Champion Of Regional Art
summary: A new art platform, S.E.A. Focus, aims to rescue the struggling art market in South-east Asia. The annual event, launched by Singapore's STPI gallery, will provide unique opportunities for artists, gallerists, and collectors to connect. Initially, the 2019 event will be a subsidized boutique art fair, but future iterations may take on different formats. The platform seeks to counter the closure of small and mid-size galleries due to high booth rental fees and competition from popular art fairs.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Trump says Fed has 'gone crazy'; Lagarde disagrees
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve, calling it "crazy" after the stock market's worst losses in eight months. Chairman Jerome Powell's interest rate hikes have triggered global selling, with European stocks hitting an 18-month low. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde defended Powell, describing him as "extremely serious" and "keen to base decisions on actual information." Trump has been stepping up attacks on the Fed, but no action has been taken.

site_title: En bloc sales in Singapore cool after July property curbs
summary: Singapore's en bloc property sales cooled after the government imposed curbs in July, with only two redevelopment sales worth S$353m completed in Q3, down from S$3.8b in Q2. Total real estate investment sales dropped 42% to S$6.5b. Private home prices rose at the slowest pace in five quarters. Commercial and industrial properties helped prop up investment sales, with office sales rising 54% and industrial deals jumping 73%. The government's measures made it more expensive for developers to redevelop older properties.

site_title: #singaporetoo: How are our employers tackling the issue
summary: Singapore appears to be relatively quiet in addressing the #metoo movement, despite a 79% spike in calls to AWARE's Sexual Assault Care Centre in October 2018. The organization has seen a steady increase in calls, indicating that the issue is still being felt behind the scenes. This contrasts with the loud public reckoning of sexual harassment and assault perpetrators in other countries. The lack of public attention may be due to the country's more conservative culture, but AWARE's experience suggests that the issue is still being tackled internally.

site_title: High On Highballs
summary: The American bourbon brand Jim Beam has set up an alfresco pop-up bar at Clarke Quay, serving highballs from unique draught machines. The machines dispense perfect highballs with pressurized soda in the right proportions. Flavors include original, Kyoho grape and kiwifruit, strawberry and lychee, and mango and pomelo, with a DIY station available. The pop-up bar is open until October 13, from 6pm, and offers accompanying food options from Kushikatsu Tanaka and Hooters.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: 30 Christmas trees to light up Marina Bay for charity
summary: Singapore is set to light up Marina Bay with 30 Christmas trees, dubbed ChariTrees, in support of the less privileged and charity, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF). The trees, sponsored by Certis and Prudential Singapore, will be displayed from November 9 to December 26, with funds raised going to provide arts training and performing opportunities for over 16,000 disadvantaged children and youth. The event aims to celebrate community heroes and inspire others to give back to the community.

site_title: Dealing with data in a Smart Nation
summary: Singapore is rapidly moving towards a Smart Nation, relying heavily on artificial intelligence and vast amounts of data. However, concerns over data safety and ethics have arisen, with cybersecurity being a top priority. Experts emphasize the importance of making conscious decisions to take the "decent path" in business ethics, even in the face of mistakes. The article highlights the need for responsible data management and the importance of considering ethics in the use of collected data.

site_title: China border crackdown on luxury items spook big brand investors
summary: China's border crackdown on luxury items, including undeclared high-end merchandise, has sent shockwaves through the global luxury market. Shares of luxury brands such as Prada, Gucci, and Tiffany & Co. plummeted as Chinese officials scrutinize travelers returning from international destinations. The crackdown, which has been ongoing for two years, threatens to slow down China's luxury market, which accounts for two-thirds of the global luxury market's growth. Investors are concerned that the crackdown will hurt sales in countries of origin for branded goods, particularly in categories like cosmetics and bags.

site_title: Asia shares plunge to 19-month lows
summary: Asia shares plummeted to 19-month lows on Thursday, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan down 3.8%. The sell-off was triggered by Wall Street's worst losses in eight months, concerns over overvalued stock markets, and rising dollar yields. Japan's Nikkei ended down 3.9%, while Shanghai shares dropped 4.9%. The sell-off erased hundreds of billions of dollars of wealth in the region, with analysts warning of financial stability risks and continued trade tension.

site_title: US core inflation below estimates as used-car costs, housing rentals fall
summary: US core inflation was below estimates in September, rising 2.2% from a year earlier, as used-vehicle costs fell and housing rents cooled. The moderation in core inflation signals price gains may remain close to the Federal Reserve's 2% objective, potentially limiting future interest-rate hikes. The broader CPI slowed to a 2.3% annual gain, the least since February.

site_title: Surreal Sri Lanka
summary: Sri Lanka offers a unique blend of ancient culture and natural beauty, from the colonial past of Colombo to the stunning landscapes of the south. A journey through the country can be tailored to suit individual preferences, with options ranging from boutique accommodations and luxury resorts to eco-lodges and national parks. The Gal Oya Lodge, for example, is an off-the-grid retreat that offers a chance to disconnect from the modern world and reconnect with nature. Meanwhile, the southern coastline boasts emerald-hued forests, grass plains, and wetlands, with popular destinations like Udawalawe National Park and the historic Dutch fort of Galle. With its rich history, diverse wildlife, and warm hospitality, Sri Lanka is an ideal destination for travelers seeking an unforgettable experience.

site_title: Top Glove Q4 net profit up 7.5% to RM101.6m
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported a 7.5% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to RM101.6 million, driven by stronger demand for its products. Revenue rose 34.8% to RM1.22 billion and net profit jumped 32% to RM433.6 million for the full year. The company attributed its growth to better cost efficiencies and higher utilisation rates. Top Glove proposed a 10 sen dividend per share and shareholders approved a bonus issue and proposed guaranteed exchangeable bonds to raise funds. Despite potential challenges, the company remains optimistic about its growth prospects.

site_title: BMW plans to take control of China joint venture
summary: BMW plans to acquire a further 25% stake in its China joint-venture, Brilliance China Automotive, for 3.6 billion euros, bringing its stake to 75% by 2022. The move comes as Beijing relaxes ownership caps for foreign automakers, allowing them to hold up to 75% stake in their China operations. The decision is seen as a boon for BMW, but a setback for Brilliance China, whose shares have plummeted this year. The joint venture, which produces 650,000 cars annually, will see a 3 billion euro expansion plan.

site_title: ABB's new innovation centre co-develops solutions with clients
summary: ABB has launched a new Customer Innovation Center in Singapore, allowing clients to co-develop solutions with the industrial technology firm. The center features various technologies, including dashboards for real-time data, remote-guidance and robotics tech, and training facilities. It includes a showcase of ABB's digital offerings, such as smart power grids and e-mobility solutions, and a testing area for robotics trials. The center aims to enable customers to explore and develop tailored solutions, leveraging ABB's expertise and knowledge of the equipment.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Turkish billionaire seeks buyers for luxury hotels in southern Europe
summary: Turkish billionaire Ferit Sahenk's Dogus Holding is seeking buyers for luxury hotels in southern Europe, including the Capri Palace, Villa Dubrovnik, Hotel Villa Magna in Madrid, and Aldrovandi Villa Borghese Hotel in Rome. The hotels will be sold individually rather than as a portfolio. This move comes as the group looks to diversify its portfolio and potentially capitalize on the growing demand for luxury tourism in the region.

site_title: HK billionaire plans revamp of Goldman's London HQ
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Joseph Lau's Chinese Estates Holdings has invited companies to pitch to redevelop Goldman Sachs' London headquarters, River Court, after the bank vacates the building next year. The 430,000 square foot building, spanning seven football fields, is being considered for extensions and refurbishment work. Goldman will move into a new 8,000-worker building nearby, and the City of London Corporation's planning department prefers to keep River Court as an office rather than converting it to another use. The redevelopment plans are among the largest office developments in London.

site_title: Workers will earn more under new pay plan, says Amazon
summary: Amazon has announced a new pay plan that will increase hourly wages to $15, providing better compensation for its US workers. However, the company has simultaneously phased out bonuses and stock grants, sparking concerns that some workers may actually earn less under the new rules. Amazon claims that the increase in base pay will "more than compensate" for the loss of incentive pay, but some workers are still unsure how the changes will affect them. The company plans to provide more outreach to help employees understand the changes.

site_title: Indonesia sees stresses as beneficial to spur reforms
summary: Indonesia's weakening currency is seen as a catalyst for reforms to bolster the economy, according to Investment Coordinating Board chairman Thomas Lembong. The government will outline measures to open up the economy to more foreign investment ahead of the presidential election. Lembong believes the current market turmoil and currency pressure will trigger fresh reforms, as the country has a history of adopting policies during challenging times. The government has already taken steps to ensure financial stability, including raising interest rates and reducing imports.

site_title: Dollar extends losses to hit 2-week low
summary: The US dollar extended its losses to hit a 2-week low due to an overnight drop in US Treasury yields. Investors await September inflation data and potential interest rate increases to gauge the dollar's trajectory. The dollar index fell 0.4% to its lowest levels since October 1, with the euro rising 0.5% to $1.1577. The dollar's 2.5% gain since July is attributed to growing expectations of interest rate increases, but a stronger inflation rate could push yields higher, potentially reversing the dollar's decline.

site_title: MAS watching property market after curbs
summary: Singapore's central bank chief, Ravi Menon, says the city-state's property market will take at least two to three quarters to fully understand the implications of recent cooling measures. The measures, implemented in July, aim to curb the market's surge amid slowing economic growth and rising interest rates. Housing prices have slowed, with home prices growing at the slowest pace in five quarters, and bulk sales of condominium buildings have collapsed. Menon notes that the market warrants close watching, regardless of its direction, as Singapore has one of the world's highest rates of home ownership.

site_title: IMF warns against trade and currency wars; urges fix to global rules
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned countries against trade and currency wars, urging de-escalation of conflicts that hurt global growth and "innocent bystanders." The US and China have imposed tariffs on each other's goods, sparking global trade tensions and financial market volatility. Lagarde called for fixing global trading rules instead of abandoning them, and expressed support for China's efforts to maintain growth and stability amid the trade conflict. The IMF and World Bank meetings, attended by over 19,000 delegates, aimed to address the challenges posed by the trade tensions and promote global economic growth.

images.alt_text: Indonesia President Joko Widodo (second from right) greeting IMF MD Christine Lagarde. He is accompanied by President of the World Bank Group Jim Yong Kim (second from left) and Indonesian Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati during a seminar at the IMF and World Bank annual meetings in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, on Oct 11. The IMF and World Bank meetings were attended by more than 19,000 delegates.

site_title: China swoops in on Canada oil that's US$50 cheaper than US
summary: China is buying Canadian oil at a discount of over $50 per barrel due to its high bitumen content, which is in demand for infrastructure construction. The country's refiners are turning to alternative supplies as Venezuelan and Iranian oil exports decline. China's demand for bitumen is expected to increase as President Xi Jinping's government focuses on infrastructure construction, with the Asian nation's refiners chartering tankers to load oil from Vancouver in October. This trend is expected to boost prices of the material, benefiting refiners producing bitumen from relatively cheap Canadian oil.

site_title: Tesla closing in on 1b yuan plot for China factory
summary: Tesla is closing in on securing a 1 billion yuan plot of land in Shanghai, China, for its first factory outside the US. The sole bidder for the land, worth about $199.5 million, is expected to make a decision this month. The factory will produce 500,000 battery-powered vehicles annually, avoiding import duties and offering cheaper cars in the world's largest electric vehicle market. The move is a positive development for Tesla, which has been hit by market volatility and regulatory issues, and could be a key factor in its plans to augment existing production and expand globally.

site_title: Young Guns
summary: The Singapore Art Museum is hosting The President's Young Talents 2018 exhibition, a showcase of five emerging artists under 36, until January 27, 2019. The featured artists, Yanyun Chen, Weixin Quek Chong, Debbie Ding, Hilmi Johandi, and Zarina Muhammad, create distinctive artworks that challenge perspectives, drawing from personal and political themes. Hilmi's works, for example, evoke memories of Singapore's defunct amusement parks through sculptures and installations. The exhibition aims to champion bold young practitioners in contemporary art.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Power Play At SIFA 2019
summary: Legendary theatre guru Tadashi Suzuki directed a 2,400-year-old Greek play, "Dionysus vs Pentheus," at the Prambanan temples in Jogjakarta, Indonesia. The production, featuring actors from Indonesia, Japan, and China, presents a stylized and stately take on the classic myth, with slow and formal performances that convey emotion through intoned lines and dignified actions. The play's themes of power struggle, jealousy, and revenge are conveyed elegantly, with ornate costumes adding to the dramatic effect. Suzuki's interpretation of the ancient story simmers with emotion, offering a unique perspective on the classic tale.

images.alt_text: Classic Greek play Dionysus gets a Japanese-Indonesian update with stylised costumes and makeup.
Director Tadashi Suzuki (left) inspects the costumes.
Agave (played by Japanese actress Chieko Naito) mourns her son Pentheus.
Japanese composer Midori Takada collaborating with Indonesian musicians.
Helmi Yusof

site_title: Ganfeng Lithium down 29% on debut
summary: China's Ganfeng Lithium, the country's top lithium producer by capacity, sank 29% on its first day of trading in Hong Kong due to a disappointing share sale and a global market downturn. The decline follows a 50% drop in lithium prices in China this year, but the company's long-term outlook is brighter as Beijing promotes electric vehicles to combat air pollution. Despite this, Ganfeng's shares closed at HK$11.76, significantly below its offer price of HK$16.50, and raised only US$421 million in the initial public offering.

site_title: Climate catastrophe warnings greeted with global silence
summary: The International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) reported that a 1°C rise in global temperature since pre-industrial times is already being felt through extreme weather events, and the original 2°C limit by 2100 is no longer viable. The panel recommends aiming for a 1.5°C limit by 2030, which would require "unprecedented changes" to daily life, including land use, energy, industry, and transportation. World leaders, particularly US President Donald Trump, appear unmoved by these warnings, sparking criticism that the planet is experiencing a "climate catastrophe" with global silence.

site_title: Managing road congestion in age of autonomous cars, ride-hailing
summary: Uber's exit from Singapore following its merger with Grab has led to reduced road congestion, with some drivers stopping or switching to Grab. However, the rise of private-hire vehicles (PHVs) has raised concerns about the environmental and traffic management impact. Experts suggest PHVs should supplement public transport, not replace it, and fares should be adjusted to prevent a significant shift from buses and trains. The development of autonomous vehicles, which can work harder and reduce the need for personal cars, is seen as a promising solution to managing Singapore's vehicle population.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Coal sector analysts predict a slowdown in China's coal consumption reduction pace, citing potential surge in thermal power demand. Indonesian coal miners benefit from increased export targets, with expected Harga Batubara Acuan (HBA) averaging $100/tonne in Q4 2018. Meanwhile, ComfortDelGro Corp is seen as a buy with a target price of S$2.59, driven by earnings growth in 2019. NetLink NBN Trust is also recommended as a buy, with its defensive nature and potential to benefit from TPG Telecom's fibre network infrastructure.

site_title: Rentals for condominiums in Toronto reach new record
summary: Rentals for condominiums in Toronto reached a new record, with average monthly rent increasing 7.6% to C$2,385. The number of new condo rental leases signed grew slightly to 8,186, but the market remains tight due to high demand and limited supply. Average lease prices in purpose-built rental buildings surged 17% to C$3.09 per square foot. Urbanation president Shaun Hildebrand attributes the rapid rent growth to a shortage of supply, with 11,172 units under construction, the highest level in over 30 years.

site_title: Pop Opera
summary: Il Divo celebrates its 15th anniversary with a new album, Timeless, and world tour. The multi-platinum group, comprising Carlos Marin, Urs Buhler, Sebastien Izambard, and David Miller, has sold over 30 million records globally. Timeless marks the quartet's first solo effort, following their departure from Simon Cowell's record company. The album opens with a cover of Adele's 'Hello' in Spanish, retitled 'Hola'. Il Divo will perform in Singapore on October 13.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Mnuchin, Fed officials downplay risks of stock rout as sell-off spreads
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin downplays the risks of a stock rout, calling the decline a "correction" and citing the US economy's strong fundamentals. Global finance chiefs describe the sell-off as a long-awaited correction, despite concerns about the US economy. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: China brokerage slump may extend as retail investors flee
summary: China's five largest brokerages have seen shares drop 26% this year due to retail investors fleeing the nation's sinking stock market. Analysts have shaved off 2018 profit forecasts as brokerages posted worst first-half earnings since 2015. The volatility highlights the need for local brokerages to diversify their client base and boost resilience. Regulators' crackdown on risky lending has also contributed to the slump, with daily trading volumes dropping below 100 billion yuan. Brokerage revenue remains a significant driver for the sector, and a stock market recovery is needed before turning positive.

images.alt_text: The Shanghai Composite Index is the second worst performer among 95 global equity indexes tracked by Bloomberg, with daily volumes having dropped below 100 billion yuan four times since August.

site_title: SPH Reit Q4 DPU up 0.7%
summary: SPH Reit announced a 0.7% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, reaching 1.43 Singapore cents. The Reit's management highlighted plans to strengthen its positioning at The Rail Mall, a recently acquired property. This is the second consecutive quarterly DPU increase for SPH Reit, demonstrating its growth strategy.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Cyndi Lauper
summary: Cyndi Lauper, the petite redhead who rose to fame in 1983 with her hit song "Girls Just Want To Have Fun," became a new wave music and feminist icon. Her album "She's So Unusual" earned her the Best New Artist award at the 1985 Grammy Awards. However, her subsequent albums failed to match the success of her first two, and her music tackling difficult issues didn't resonate with listeners. Lauper's unique voice and style remained a defining feature of her career, cementing her status as a music legend.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US: Stocks open modestly lower
summary: US stocks opened modestly lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% at 25,537.72. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with the latter dipping 0.1%. The drop follows the previous session's largest decline since February, but benign US inflation data mitigated concerns about higher interest rates.

site_title: Microsoft CEO backs federal privacy law over state efforts
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella supports a federal privacy law over state efforts, joining tech giants like Apple and AT&T in calling for national consumer safeguards. Nadella characterizes privacy as a "human right" and notes that a national law would reduce transactional costs for companies. The comments come as tech companies face growing scrutiny over data privacy following European and California regulations. A national law is seen as a step towards addressing concerns raised by Senator John Thune and other industry leaders.

site_title: Rome's budget antics threaten to drag EU and euro into crisis
summary: Italy's populist government is threatening the euro and European Union with its reckless budget policies, sparking concerns of a sovereign debt crisis. With a public debt to GDP ratio over 130%, Italy's economy is vulnerable to a banking crisis and global economic ramifications. The government's refusal to commit to reform and its plans for increased spending and budget deficits are in direct violation of euro area rules. If Italy fails, the euro cannot survive, and the cost of saving it would be too high for European partners.

site_title: Spice Of Life
summary: Sri Lankan cuisine is known for its spiciness and variety, with dishes like maluwa (curry) and thel dala (stir-fried) being staples. According to chef Rishi Naleendra, the country's cuisine lacks a main dish, instead featuring a combination of vegetable curries, dhal, sambol, and chicken curry. Naleendra emphasizes the importance of spices and chilies in Sri Lankan cooking, describing it as "all about heaps of chilli in your face." This unique flavor profile sets Sri Lankan cuisine apart from other international cuisines.

site_title: Heritage For A Good Cause
summary: A limited edition Singapore-themed collection of lifestyle products, created by Sowing Room and fabric designer Mike Tay, is available exclusively at The Social Space. The collection, priced from S$13.50 to S$59, gives back to society by supporting at-risk foreign women who have been abused or exploited in Singapore. The products, made from upcycled fabrics and textiles, help these women learn sewing skills and earn a fair wage while waiting for their cases to be resolved. The collaboration aims to promote corporate social responsibility and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
A Peranakan inspired bag.
Toiletries bag with landmarks of Chinatown.
Table napkins that come with prints of shophouses in Little India.

site_title: Wall Street roils Asian markets but bears stay away for now
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Thursday following a brutal sell-off in the US overnight, with heavy losses of up to 5% in some bourses. Despite the steep decline, analysts do not see the start of a bear trend, citing the fundamentals of the US economy as strong and typical market swings at this stage of a bull market. Investors are advised to focus on defensive plays and stay engaged in the market, with some analysts predicting increased volatility and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Apollo funds commit US$700m in equity capital to Catalina
summary: Apollo Global Management has committed an additional $700 million in equity capital to Catalina Holdings Bermuda Ltd, an insurer that acquires old policies to wind down. This brings the total equity capital to majority ownership, with RenaissanceRe Holdings Ltd as a minority shareholder. The deal gives CEO Chris Fagan more funds to pursue deals, following the acquisition of German legacy medical malpractice liabilities from Zurich Insurance Group AG and a deal with Arch Reinsurance Ltd.

site_title: UK surveyors see weakest residential price outlook since Brexit vote
summary: British surveyors report the weakest residential price outlook since the Brexit vote in 2016, with a four-month low of -2 in September. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) cites uncertainty over Brexit negotiations as the top concern. Bank of England governor Mark Carney reportedly warned ministers of a possible house price crash if Britain leaves the EU with no deal, with prices potentially falling by 35% over three years. This marks the lowest outlook since June 2016, with prices continuing to rise outside London but slowing overall.

site_title: Room To Grow
summary: A Singaporean couple, Chris Chen and Tina Yeo, built a two-storey terrace house in Serangoon Gardens to accommodate their growing family. Their architect, Pan Yi Cheng, added a third floor and a dramatic inner courtyard with a skylight to maximize natural light. The home features child-friendly elements, such as a seamless connection between indoor and outdoor play areas, and clever storage solutions. The couple's desire for a home that meets their changing needs as a growing family is reflected in the design, which includes a flexible layout and private spaces for each family member.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Apple gets critical iPhone technology in US$600m Dialog deal
summary: Apple has acquired Dialog Semiconductor in a $600 million deal, securing control over the power-management technology used in its iPhones. The agreement, which includes licensing technology and hiring Dialog's 300-strong engineering team, is the largest of its kind by Apple. Dialog will continue to supply chips to other customers and expects to sell sub-PMICs to Apple, with the US tech giant accounting for 35-40% of Dialog's revenues in 2022. The deal is seen as a strategic move by Apple to control its main power-management chips, and Dialog's shares surged 34% following the announcement.

site_title: Trump says US close to finding out fate of Saudi journalist
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that authorities are "getting closer" to finding out the fate of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who disappeared in Turkey last week. Trump said it would be a "very sad thing" if Khashoggi was harmed, and he is urging the Saudi government to cooperate in the investigation. A bipartisan US Senate group is forcing an investigation, which could lead to sanctions against Saudi officials and entities. Trump previously stated he did not want to block arms sales to Saudi Arabia over the disappearance.

site_title: Harvey Weinstein wins dismissal of one criminal charge
summary: Harvey Weinstein had one of six criminal charges against him dismissed after prosecutors declined to oppose the dismissal due to new information. The dismissed charge involved an alleged 2004 sexual assault of aspiring actress Lucia Evans. Five remaining charges, involving two other women, remain in the case. Weinstein's lawyer plans to investigate "perjury" and the NYPD detective involved in the case. The producer has pleaded not guilty to all charges, and his company has been involved in the #MeToo movement, leading to his expulsion from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

site_title: Star Power
summary: TAG Heuer has long associated with celebrities from various fields, leveraging their star power to reach a wider audience. The brand, a pioneer in this direction, has partnered with influential figures such as Paul McCartney, Steve McQueen, Muhammad Ali, and Ayrton Senna. TAG Heuer supports motorsports and has official partnerships with teams like Aston Martin Red Bull Racing. The brand also collaborates with athletes, musicians, and artists, seeking ambassadors who embody innovation, creativity, and a strong presence on social media.

site_title: Walmart to invest US$250m in joint venture with content firm Eko -source
summary: Walmart has signed a joint venture with Eko, a developer of interactive video content, to boost customer engagement. The US$250 million investment will be used to develop interactive content, including toy catalogs and cooking shows. The venture, called W*E Interactive Ventures, will be led by Eko's CEO Yoni Bloch and will include strategic advisers Jane Rosenthal and Nancy Tellem. This move expands Walmart's entertainment offerings, including its video-on-demand service Vudu and ebooks platform. The partnership aims to attract shoppers and enhance customer engagement.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vividthree Holdings' wholly owned subsidiary, Vividthree Productions, has signed a memorandum of understanding with British video game company Slightly Mad Studios to set up a joint venture. The tie-up will focus on projects like a motor-sport racing simulation game, utilizing Slightly Mad Studios' game engine.

site_title: Thrill-seekers go to extreme haunts to get a good scare
summary: A growing underground industry of immersive horror experiences, known as extreme haunts, is offering participants intense physical and psychological situations, placing them inside their own real-life horror film. Led by Los Angeles-based company Heretic, these year-round events have gained popularity, with participants paying $150 for a 45-minute experience. The company's leader, Guy Michael, uses Hollywood stuntmen and actors to create realistic and terrifying scenarios, with some participants even reporting improved mood and increased distress tolerance after the experience. The industry has also attracted celebrities and wealthy individuals willing to pay $20,000 for private events.

site_title: Yale may consider exiting private funds in social investment shift
summary: Yale University may consider exiting private equity and hedge fund investments deemed socially irresponsible, such as those in gun manufacturers or companies profiting from private prisons. The Ivy League school has 60% of its $29.4 billion endowment in alternative assets, but has taken steps to address ethical concerns, including divesting from fossil-fuel companies and supporting shareholder resolutions on corporate social responsibility. Yale will work with outside managers to adhere to its standards, and as a last resort, could disassociate from the investment manager.

images.alt_text: Yale University, facing pressure to address ethical issues like gun violence, may consider exiting private equity and hedge fund investments that it deems socially irresponsible.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia plan US$10b stability package
summary: Singapore and Indonesia are working on a $10 billion bilateral financial arrangement to boost confidence amid global liquidity risks and volatile markets. The package includes a local currency swap and US dollar repurchase agreements, aimed at supporting monetary and financial stability. The move is seen as a positive development, with economists noting that it will provide a ready reserve of support for Bank Indonesia and instill confidence in the market. The rupiah, Indonesia's currency, has been under pressure, falling to a two-decade low, and the arrangement is expected to benefit both Indonesia and Singapore.

site_title: Passengers ready for world's longest flight
summary: Singapore Airlines is set to restart its 19-hour flight between Singapore and New York, the world's longest flight, after a 5-year hiatus. The 16,700km journey will feature two pilots, a "wellness" menu, and over seven weeks' worth of entertainment. The flight is expected to operate once a week, with passengers ready to board on Thursday.

site_title: Opec says oil market well supplied, wary of 2019 surplus
summary: Opec's Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo stated that the oil market is well supplied and wary of creating a surplus in 2019, despite expectations of US sanctions on Iran straining supplies. Opec's production rose to 32.76 million barrels per day in September, but the group is cautious about increasing output to meet a June agreement. The organization's report cut demand estimates for 2019 due to economic challenges and pointed to excess supply.

site_title: Soyuz emergency landing could result in major payout for insurer Soglasie - Interfax
summary: A Soyuz spacecraft made an emergency landing in central Kazakhstan after its booster rockets failed en route to the International Space Station. Russian insurance firm Soglasie is investigating whether it is liable for the incident, which could result in a major payout. The insurer has stated that the incident could be one of the biggest payouts in decades if it is deemed an insurance case. The cause of the failure is still unknown, with an investigation underway.
