Despite a protracted sector-wide downturn, dry bulk freight rates have increased, and some industry experts are cautiously optimistic about the market's recovery. To attract more investors, SGX needs to enhance its appeal as an IPO destination, while investor education and engagement efforts, such as the Maritime Capital Forum, can help increase retail investor participation and boost market liquidity.

site_title: Trade war bites China's ultra-wealthy
summary: China's ultra-wealthy saw their ranks thin by 237 individuals, falling to 1,893, due to the trade war with the US, which pummeled stocks and erased billions of dollars in paper wealth. The Hurun Report's annual ranking showed a decline in the number of Chinese magnates with a net worth of over 2 billion yuan. The trade war's impact on China's economy and wealth has raised concerns for policymakers.

site_title: Focus on improving energy efficiency
summary: Singapore is introducing a carbon tax to encourage businesses to improve energy efficiency, starting from 2019. The tax will be applied to facilities emitting 25,000 tonnes or more of greenhouse gas emissions annually, with a starting rate of S$5 per tonne and expected to increase to S$10-15 per tonne by 2030. To support companies, the government will set aside funds from 2019 to 2023 to help them improve energy efficiency. The Energy Conservation Act has also been enhanced to improve energy efficiency in the industrial sector.

site_title: Rising US-China tensions: Slouching towards Cold War II?
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence's recent speech heightened tensions with China, warning of a global struggle against Beijing and accusing it of interfering in American politics and stealing technology. The speech echoed a narrative in Washington portraying China as America's geo-strategic and geo-economic enemy, potentially escalating the Cold War. This aggressive stance may lead to a self-fulfilling prophecy, as it plays into the hands of Chinese military hawks and mercantilists, undermining efforts to rebalance the US-China relationship.

site_title: ICA achieves energy savings at Woodlands, Tuas checkpoints
summary: The Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) of Singapore has achieved significant energy savings at its Woodlands and Tuas checkpoints, with annual energy savings of 30% and 50% respectively. The checkpoints have implemented various energy-efficient measures, including retrofitting chiller plants, replacing non-LED lights with LED lights, and installing photovoltaic panels. These efforts have led to an annual energy savings of 14 million kWh. The ICA's energy efficiency improvement plan also includes educating officers and external stakeholders on energy conservation, and it has been recognized for its efforts with an award for best energy efficiency practices in the public sector category.

site_title: China taps brakes on outbound investment, betrays capital flow fears
summary: China has suspended approvals for the Qualified Domestic Limited Partnership (QDLP) scheme, a niche overseas investment product, amid renewed concerns over capital outflows due to the escalating Sino-US trade war. The move, which also urges licence holders to be "low profile" in marketing, signals Beijing's efforts to curb capital flight and stabilize the yuan currency. This policy reversal comes after China resumed the QDLP scheme in February, despite previously tightening controls on overseas investments.

images.alt_text: China is suspending approvals for a niche overseas investment product in Shanghai known as the Qualified Domestic Limited Partnership (QDLP) scheme and urging licence holders, such as JPMorgan Asset Management and Aberdeen Standard Investments, to be "low profile" in marketing it, sources said.

site_title: Duty Free International Q2 profit falls 12.6%
summary: Duty Free International (DFI) has reported a 12.6% decline in second-quarter net profit to RM12.3 million due to lower revenue, primarily caused by reduced product availability. The company expects its operating environment to remain challenging, with rising inflationary costs and weak consumer sentiment. DFI will closely monitor costs and intensify marketing efforts to remain competitive.

site_title: The digital journey ahead for finance professionals
summary: Finance professionals face disruption from emerging technologies and new business models, according to the State of Digital 2018 Report. Automation, real-time reporting and monitoring, enhanced data and analytics, and cloud-based systems will drive change. Financial professionals must be equipped to identify and manage innovation to create value. This includes upskilling employees with new skills and competencies to address associated risks and embracing new technology. Organisations must also appoint innovation champions to spearhead innovation and deploy new ideas.

site_title: Britain braces for 'the other' royal wedding
summary: Britain is set to witness a less-than-anticipated royal wedding between Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank, with the public showing limited interest. The wedding, taking place five months after Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's highly publicized nuptials, is expected to be met with criticism over its estimated £2 million security bill, which taxpayers will foot. The ceremony, held at Windsor Castle, will be attended by 850 guests, but the event is unlikely to generate the same level of excitement as the previous royal wedding.

site_title: Going all out to save energy
summary: G-Energy Global Pte Ltd, an energy services provider, has helped clients achieve significant annual energy savings through chilled water system retrofit projects. The company has built its credentials on over 600 successful projects and numerous prestigious awards since its incorporation in 2005. G-Energy is expanding its services to the industrial sector, with a focus on building internal capability to meet customer needs. The company has been recognized as the Outstanding Energy Services Provider of the Year.

site_title: Firms that are ISO 50001 certified will save more: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that companies implementing ISO 50001, a global energy management standard, can achieve annual energy and financial savings of over 10%. The number of ISO 50001 certifications grew to nearly 12,000 in 2015, with 85% in Europe. Companies like BASF South East Asia, GSK, and Globalfoundries Singapore Pte Ltd have achieved significant energy savings and reduced carbon emissions through structured energy management, demonstrating the benefits of adopting this standard.

site_title: World leaders need to fix broken economic models, says IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde urged world leaders to fix global trading systems instead of tearing them down, in response to nationalist politicians pushing tariffs and protectionism. The comments come as a trade spat between China and the US threatens global economic growth, with IMF experts warning of "new vulnerabilities" in the system. Lagarde's remarks also follow recent economic news, including China's slowing GDP growth, the UK economy shrinking for the second month, and Citigroup's mid-2026 target for the global equity index.

site_title: Brexit trade deal with Asia is not as outlandish as it may seem
summary: Brexit trade deal with Asia is not as outlandish as initially thought, with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe welcoming the UK into the 11-member trans-Pacific trade bloc, the TPP-11. While the UK may benefit from expanding ties with the region, its geography and existing trade agreements with the EU may hinder its ability to join the bloc. The UK would need to leave the EU customs union and navigate differences in food and product testing rules, potentially complicating its future trading relationship with Europe.

site_title: Imran Khan vows to steady Pakistan as new IMF bailout looms
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has vowed to steer the country out of a looming balance-of-payments crisis, seeking a fresh IMF bailout deal worth $10-12 billion. Khan dismissed the amount as "not a major issue" and announced the government will explore both IMF and friendly country financing options. This comes as the country faces its third economic crisis since 2013, with economists warning of urgent action. Khan also announced a massive low-cost housing scheme to build 5 million homes in five years, aiming to bring prosperity.

images.alt_text: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan on Wednesday vowed to steer the country out of a looming balance-of-payments crisis, days after his young government announced it would seek a fresh IMF bailout deal.

site_title: Oil price rally boosts electric car sales
summary: Oil price rally boosts electric car sales as legacy automakers and luxury brands prepare to launch a record number of battery electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids. Rising oil prices, leading to fuel prices at four-year highs, may turn consumers towards electric vehicles. Utilities and major oil firms are expanding charging infrastructure, particularly in Europe, addressing key concerns of consumers.

site_title: Facebook's WhatsApp says has fixed video call security bug
summary: Facebook's WhatsApp has fixed a security bug that allowed hackers to take over users' applications when answering an incoming video call. The vulnerability, discovered in late August, was fixed in early October by Facebook. The bug could have compromised WhatsApp, used by over 1.2 billion people, by allowing attackers to gain access to users' applications with just one call. This is the latest in a string of security-related problems for Facebook, following a breach affecting nearly 50 million accounts last week.

site_title: Helping SATS to achieve savings in energy costs
summary: Chen Jiayi, energy manager at SATS Ltd, has been named one of the two winners of the Outstanding Energy Manager of the Year award. Under his leadership, SATS has achieved significant energy savings through various projects, including the modernization of chiller plants and the installation of a 3.6 megawatt-peak solar array. These efforts have reduced the organization's overall electricity consumption by over 10% and have helped the company minimize its environmental impact. Chen emphasizes the importance of teamwork and long-term thinking in driving energy efficiency and reducing costs.

site_title: Societies need to work together in the fight against obesity
summary: World Obesity Day highlights the need for societies to work together to combat obesity, a leading cause of diabetes and other chronic diseases. The World Health Organisation has officially recognised obesity as a disease, and studies in Denmark show that social support is a key factor in treating obesity, rather than individual responsibility or economic factors. A people-centric approach is needed, focusing on understanding, respect, and recognition of obesity as a chronic disease, and addressing weight stigma through multi-disciplinary social services and public discourse. The economic burden of obesity is significant, with estimated costs of S$2.77 billion in Singapore alone, and the global burden is expected to rise.

site_title: Uber said to be pitching US$1.5b junk-bond offering
summary: Uber is planning a $1.5 billion junk-bond offering, which may come as soon as next week, to raise capital and disclose its financial information to a limited pool of institutional investors. The company has previously used this approach, including a self-led loan sale in March. Uber reported a loss of $891 million in the second quarter, with sales rising 63% to $2.8 billion. The bond sale may yield around 7.5% for five-year notes and 8% for eight-year bonds, with Morgan Stanley serving as the lead placement agent.

site_title: Game developer Zynga attracts takeover interest from rivals
summary: ZYNGA Inc, the creator of FarmVille and Words With Friends, has attracted takeover interest from rival game developers, with the company's shares jumping 12% to close at $4.36. This comes as dealmaking in the industry increases, with spending on entertainment software more than doubling in the last 12 months. Zynga operates in a competitive mobile gaming market, competing with firms like Ubisoft and Activision Blizzard, and has recently secured a licensing deal with Walt Disney to develop a Star Wars mobile game.

site_title: One small step for a man, and US$250,000 for Branson's Virgin group
summary: A reported two individuals paid around $250,000 each to join a dinner hosted by Richard Branson in Singapore, mirroring the price of a ticket on Virgin Galactic's spaceships. The dinner came as a 750-strong waiting list for astronauts on Virgin Galactic's spaceships remains unchanged, four years after it first closed. The high demand for space travel underscores the growing interest in space tourism.

images.alt_text: Mr Branson: "At least 2 out of 3 people I talk to say they would love to go to space one day. ... the market out there is enormous if we can ensure the product is safe and is affordable over time."
Lee U-Wen

site_title: Mini car built for young families in Japan attracts senior buyers instead
summary: Japan's mini car market, targeting young families with features like error-detecting pedals and automatic emergency braking, has seen a drastically different demographic - roughly half of the owners of the latest model are 50 or older. The N-Box, a pint-sized car, has become the country's best-selling passenger vehicle, with a price tag starting at around $7,500 and low ownership taxes. This shift reflects the rapidly growing ranks of Japanese elderly, with many downsizing from larger family cars to more compact ones, and automakers are now marketing mini cars to this demographic, citing safety features and ease of driving.

site_title: Justin Timberlake and Kobe Bryant are in talks to make shows for NewTV
summary: Justin Timberlake and Kobe Bryant are in talks to produce and appear in shows for NewTV, a startup aiming to bring HBO-like quality to short online videos. The company, backed by $1 billion, plans to release a paid service with high-end content, including original series and news clips, in late 2019. NewTV aims to compete with major video sites like Netflix, YouTube, and social media platforms by delivering quality programming for a fee, with pricing starting at $5/month.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as bond yields gain
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 down 6.44 points, or 0.22%, at 2,873.90, and the Nasdaq Composite down 43.94 points, or 0.57%. Treasury yields rose after data showed US producer prices climbed last month, suggesting no relief on inflation pressures.

site_title: Sears preparing to file for bankruptcy as early as Friday -sources
summary: Sears Holdings Corp is preparing to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as early as Friday, citing negotiations with CEO Eddie Lampert and the company's special board committee as the cause of the impasse. The committee is refusing to approve Lampert's rescue plan, fearing it could lead to litigation. Sears shares have fallen 27% to 43 cents, down from above $100 a decade ago.

site_title: Europe boosts counter-terror cooperation with SWAT deal
summary: Europe's law enforcement agencies have boosted counter-terror cooperation with a deal involving the EU's police agency and a network of SWAT teams. The agreement aims to increase safety for European citizens following a wave of terror incidents. Exercises were held across Europe, simulating responses to various terror scenarios, including a mock hijacked plane and a dirty bomb. The deal establishes a permanent coordination office at Europol HQ, set to bring added value to law enforcement preparedness and safety for all European citizens.

site_title: Dealing with digital disruption
summary: Companies in Singapore are investing in digital tools to cope with the transformative changes brought about by emerging technologies. A recent survey by CPA Australia and PwC found that 83% of respondents have undergone or are undergoing digital transformation, with plans to invest in data analytics, machine learning, and automation. The survey also highlighted the need for agile and effective leadership, with only 30% of organizations having appointed a Chief Digital Officer. To overcome roadblocks, companies are developing new tools to ease the transition to a digital-led organization, including platforms for idea-sharing and apps for employee control over work environments.

images.alt_text: Samuel Chong, group chief technology officer at Fullerton Health
Greg Unsworth, partner and digital leader, PwC Singapore

site_title: Ceremony for Japanese Imperial heir Prince Akishino set for April 2020
summary: A ceremony to proclaim Prince Akishino as the Imperial heir, "koshi," is expected to take place in April 2020, following the Emperor's abdication and the crown prince's accession in May 2019. The ceremony, known as "Rikkoshi no Rei," will be held as an act of state under the Constitution and will be conducted by a committee chaired by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The government aims to hold the ceremony in April 2020, about half a year after the crown prince's accession, to avoid holding it more than a year after the event.

site_title: Oil price rally sends shares of OSV operators surging
summary: Offshore supply vessel (OSV) operators have seen a significant recovery in their shares, with an average price rebound of 67.4% from 52-week lows. The 29 OSV stocks trading in Singapore have a combined market value of S$2.38 billion. Larger OSV companies have seen modest price improvements, while smaller-capitalized companies have experienced more dramatic surges. Analysts attribute the recovery to the recent oil price rally, which has boosted demand for rigs, platforms, and other equipment. However, challenges remain, including high interest expenses and the need for suppliers to consolidate or work together to drive up prices.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Mahathir's new car brand to be Asean effort to weather trade war
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is reviving his dream of developing a national car brand, aiming to source parts from neighboring countries to weather the US-China trade war. The Asean region is expected to benefit, with Toyota, Tata, and Ford already operating assembly plants in Thailand. The new brand will compete globally, not with existing Malaysian automakers Proton and Perodua. The private sector will drive and fund the project, with the government assisting in licensing and facilitation. A successful carmaker could boost exports, relying on commodities like crude oil and electronics.

site_title: LVMH falls after confirming China border crackdown on luxury items
summary: LVMH shares fell 8.4% after confirming Chinese customs authorities are stepping up border checks on luxury items, amid speculation on social media. The company reported a 10% organic sales growth in the quarter, but growth in Louis Vuitton's sales to Chinese customers slowed. The stepped-up checks aim to curb grey-market imports, where items are cheaper overseas and resold at a profit. LVMH has no plans to equalize prices in China and abroad, despite the risk of unauthorized arbitrage.

site_title: Falcon Energy board says company can continue as a going concern after auditors cite 'material uncertainties'
summary: Falcon Energy Group's board confirmed the company can continue as a going concern despite auditors citing "material uncertainties" in their financial statements. The decision was based on the company's ability to negotiate with lenders, finalize a debt restructuring plan, and generate positive cash flow. The board also believed Falcon Energy can secure new charter contracts and meet its debt obligations over the next 12 months. This decision came after a 18.42% decline in the company's share price.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: AmBank withdraws legal action against Nam Cheong unit
summary: Malaysian lender AmBank has withdrawn a legal action against a Nam Cheong subsidiary, the Nam Cheong Dockyard unit, following the successful conclusion of the group's debt restructuring exercise. The withdrawal was made with no order to costs and with liberty to file afresh. The claims have been fully restructured under the group's debt restructuring exercise, despite the withdrawal of the legal action.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Indonesia warns of 'spillover' effect of policies
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati has warned of a potential 'spillover' effect of global financial policies on emerging economies, particularly in the wake of the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes. Despite Indonesia's efforts to stabilize its currency and manage deficits, capital outflows are still affecting the country. Indrawati emphasized the need for better policy coordination among IMF members to shield emerging economies from the impact of global economic shifts.

site_title: London forex traders to go on trial on US price rigging charges
summary: Three former London-based traders, Chris Ashton, Rohan Ramchandani, and Richard Usher, are set to go on trial in federal court in Manhattan on charges of conspiring to rig prices in the US$5 trillion foreign exchange market. The traders, who worked at Barclays Plc, Citigroup Inc, and JPMorgan Chase & Co, respectively, have all pleaded not guilty. US prosecutors announced the charges in January 2017, and lawyers are expected to make opening statements once a jury has been chosen.

site_title: AirAsia India close to appointing new head - sources
summary: AirAsia India is close to appointing Sunil Bhaskaran, a Tata Steel executive, as its new head. This comes as Tata Sons, the local partner, seeks greater control of the company. Bhaskaran's appointment follows several high-profile exits and a nearly six-month search for a CEO. The airline is also under investigation for alleged corruption and rule-breaking, with the CBI accusing it of violating foreign direct investment rules and bribing officials. AirAsia India has denied wrongdoing, and the airline did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: US wholesale inventories rise slightly more than initially estimated
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 1.0% in August, slightly more than the initial 0.8% estimate, and 5.3% year-over-year. This increase is expected to boost production at factories and contribute to GDP growth in the third quarter. Wholesale auto inventories rose 3.5%, while machinery and farm products inventories also increased. Sales at wholesalers were up 0.8% in August, and it would take 1.26 months to clear shelves at the current sales pace.

site_title: Noble divests Indonesian subsidiary for nominal payment of US$1
summary: Noble Group sold its Indonesian subsidiary, Kaltim Bio Energi, for $1, including taking on outstanding payables and liabilities. The book value of the subsidiary was $10.4 million. The deal does not affect Noble's proposed debt restructuring. Wadash Enterprises, the buyer, also assumed environmental and mine closure liabilities. The sale was reached through arm's-length negotiations based on market and commercial considerations.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Britain expects 5,000 financial services jobs to leave by Brexit Day
summary: Britain's financial services minister, John Glen, stated that 5,000 financial services jobs are expected to leave the country by Brexit Day, March 2019. Despite this, Glen aims to ensure the City of London remains a major financial center. He believes a transition period will be agreed upon with the EU, avoiding a disorderly Brexit. However, a no-deal Brexit may not be as hostile as anticipated, according to Glen.

site_title: MAS prohibition orders against ex-Credit Suisse banker and ex-CEO of NRA Capital varied on appeal to minister
summary: A former Credit Suisse banker, Lim Fang Wee, and ex-CEO of NRA Capital, Kevin Scully, had their MAS prohibition orders varied by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. Lim's four-year ban was reduced to three years, while Scully was allowed to stay as a substantial shareholder of NRA Capital but must submit an undertaking to not influence the firm's management. The orders were initially imposed for Lim's role in hiding beneficial account owners and Scully's failure to ensure NRA's valuation services met required standards.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 35.12 points, or 1.11%, to 3,131.48 on Wednesday, with about 1.6 billion securities changing hands. The market saw more losers than gainers, with Nico Steel Holdings losing 14.3% to S$0.006. The decline was attributed to a decrease in trading activity.

site_title: US producer prices rebound in September
summary: US producer prices increased 0.2% in September, reversing an August decline and in line with expectations. The rise in services prices offset a 3.5% drop in gasoline prices, with the 12-month producer price index rising 2.6%. This slightly less than the expected 2.7% increase.

site_title: Sembcorp starts commercial operation of 225-MW Myanmar power plant
summary: Sembcorp Industries announced the successful commercial operation of its 225-MW gas-fired power plant in Mandalay, Myanmar, following its first phase operation in May. The $300 million plant, which uses advanced combined-cycle gas turbine technology, will generate 1,500 gigawatt hours of power for 5.3 million people, easing Myanmar's severe power deficit. The facility will be operated for 22 years, with the Myanmar government taking ownership after completion. The project received funding support from several international banks and institutions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's central bank chief Ravi Menon struck an upbeat tone amid global economic risks, cutting through gloom over escalating trade tensions. An accelerator program for medical device startups was launched at the Asia Pacific MedTech Forum. MindChamps PreSchool expanded into Malaysia with plans to launch 20 preschools by 2024. Hong Kong aims to add artificial islands to tackle its housing crisis. The Singapore stock market closed lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 1.11%.

site_title: New Silkroutes auditors issue qualified opinion on financial statements
summary: Independent auditors Foo Kon Tan LLP issued a qualified opinion on New Silkroutes Group's financial statements for the year to June 30, 2018. The audit was qualified due to insufficient evidence on the recoverability of pre-payments for iron ore fines and the valuation of New Silkroutes' stake in Thai General Nice Coal and Coke. The auditors noted that historical data and supporting materials were not available to evaluate the reliability of forecasts and assumptions used in the valuation. The rest of the statements were deemed properly drawn up, and the company's annual report will be sent to shareholders on October 16.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Nvidia aims to woo business analysts with new software
summary: Nvidia released new software tools called RAPIDS to target the business computing market, aiming to capture a larger share of the market for chips that perform basic data crunching, such as forecasting inventories. The software is designed to speed up business data analysis and is being used by companies like Walmart. Nvidia's strong position in artificial intelligence is expected to help it compete with Intel, but the company will need to find early customers who value the speed benefits over the cost of new chips.

site_title: Debao Property Development given third extension for AGM, with Nov 30 deadline
summary: Debao Property Development has been granted its third extension for its annual general meeting, with the new deadline set for November 30. The shareholder meeting for the 2017 financial year was initially due by April 30. The company needs an additional 4-6 weeks to review an independent reviewer's report, meeting the Singapore Exchange's conditions for waiving the deadline. This is the third extension granted to the company.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Duty Free International Q2 net profit falls 12.6% to RM12.3m
summary: Duty Free International reported a 12.6% decline in Q2 net profit to RM12.3 million due to a 21.8% drop in revenue. Earnings per share fell to 1.02 sen from 1.15 sen in the previous year. The group attributed the decline to lower product availability and a RM3 million donation. Revenue for the six months ended August 31 fell 25.6% to RM231.8 million.

site_title: GAM is in early stage talks with potential buyers
summary: GAM Holding AG, a Swiss asset manager, is in early-stage talks with potential buyers as it explores options to stabilize the firm after the suspension of a star fund manager, Tim Haywood. The talks may not lead to a sale of the company. GAM's shares surged 17% after the news, and the firm is under pressure to address the fallout from allegations of compliance breaches. A possible sale could draw interest from French and Italian managers, as well as asset management units of banks. GAM is also winding down nine bond funds and reviewing its profit targets.

site_title: Ikea plans to expand to a dozen new markets in coming years
summary: Ikea plans to expand to about a dozen new markets, including South America, by 2025, aiming to reach 3 billion potential customers. The company will open stores in Chile, Colombia, Peru, Mexico, Estonia, Ukraine, Puerto Rico, Oman, Luxembourg, Macau, and the Philippines through a new franchisee, Falabella. This expansion marks Ikea's shift towards emerging markets and alternative shopping experiences, with plans to introduce smaller store formats and online services.

images.alt_text: Ikea plans to expand to about a dozen new markets in the coming years, including branching into South America, as the Swedish furniture giant aims to reach a total of 3 billion potential customers by 2025.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at close
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed marginally higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.08% to 26,193.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.18%. However, the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.15%. Investors are cautious due to volatility in the US and a weak yuan.

site_title: Malaysia to abolish death penalty
summary: Malaysia's de facto law minister Liew Vui Keong announced the abolition of the death penalty, stating that all executions should not be carried out until a moratorium is implemented. The government will inform the Pardons Board to review applications for convicts on the death row, considering various factors such as the severity of the crime and the circumstances surrounding the offense. The necessary paperwork to abolish the death penalty has received approval from the Attorney General Chambers and is set to be tabled in the upcoming Parliament sitting, starting October 15.

site_title: Pine Capital board says group can continue as going concern, in reply to SGX queries
summary: Pine Capital Group, a Singapore-based investment firm, has confirmed it can continue as a going concern after responding to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on its share settlement and share placement plans. The group plans to raise S$326,721 through a share settlement and increase its available cash to S$596,000. It is confident its fund management business, Advance Capital Partners Asset Management, can stay competitive in the short to medium term. Pine Capital's executive chairman, Tan Choon Wee, is managing the group's businesses until a CEO is appointed.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: UK economy set for best quarter since 2016 despite flat August
summary: The UK economy is expected to have its best quarter since 2016, with a 0.7% growth in the third quarter, driven by a record heatwave that boosted retail sales and the services industry. Despite a weaker-than-expected August, annual growth was 1.5%, and the Bank of England may not raise interest rates again before the UK leaves the EU in March. However, the labor market remains tight, and business investment has fallen for two consecutive quarters, raising concerns about underlying momentum and potential inflation.

site_title: Asiatravel.com Holdings board says it will appeal against suspension of travel agent licences
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings received a notice from the Singapore Tourism Board to suspend its travel agent licenses due to the company's inability to fulfill outstanding obligations and a disclaimer of opinion from an independent auditor. The suspension will take effect on October 20 unless an appeal is made by October 19. The company has announced its intention to appeal, stating it will update shareholders on any material developments. The move was deemed in the public interest after the company suspended trading in its shares in July following a missed payment.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Deutsche Telekom to launch commercial 5G operations in 2020
summary: Deutsche Telekom plans to launch commercial 5G operations in Germany by 2020, provided sufficient commercial devices are available. CEO Tim Hoettges pledged to continue investing €5.5 billion annually in Germany's broadband network. He emphasized the need for cooperation in building out the country's fibre-optic network to support gigabit-speed internet connections and 5G services. This move aims to out-invest competitors as Germany prepares to auction 5G licenses in early 2019.

site_title: Singtel to buy Australian cyber security firm for A$23.3 million
summary: Singtel's Australian subsidiary has agreed to buy privately held cyber security firm Hivint for up to A$23.3 million (S$22.9 million), subject to earn-out targets and adjustments. The deal will integrate Hivint into Trustwave's cyber security arm, enhancing Optus' position as a leading cyber security service provider in Australia. The transaction, conditional on regulatory approvals, is expected to strengthen Optus' reputation as a trusted adviser to government and enterprise customers.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Huawei to sell servers with own chips in cloud computing push
summary: Huawei plans to sell servers powered by its own chips, doubling down on its cloud computing business. The move comes as the company seeks to gain a foothold in the public cloud market in China, currently dominated by Alibaba. Huawei's semiconductor arm, Hisilicon, will produce a 7-nanometer Ascend 910 chipset, which it claims is twice as powerful as Nvidia's v100, available from the second quarter of 2019. The company will not sell these chips to third parties, instead focusing on providing hardware and cloud computing services.

site_title: Photo Gallery: Cutting Edge with Howard Yu
summary: The inaugural Cutting Edge forum was held in Singapore, featuring expert Howard Yu, who discussed the biggest challenges facing today's companies. Yu, author of the business bestseller "Leap: How to Thrive in a World Where Everything Can Be Copied," shared his insights on innovation and corporate disruption.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares finished the day lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 38.97 points to 1,735.18, closing lower on Wednesday. The index saw 2.99 billion lots traded worth RM2.87 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 994 to 116. This follows a broader market trend in the region, where traders are brushing off US President Trump's new threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: MAS chief Menon strikes upbeat tone amid trade tensions
summary: Singapore's central bank chief Ravi Menon struck an upbeat tone amid rising global economic risks, saying "dark clouds" haven't yet materialized. Despite escalating trade tensions between the US and China, Menon believes the global economy remains resilient, with solid growth in Asia and a US economy "chugging along." The Monetary Authority of Singapore has already tightened monetary policy, and Menon warned that a possible slump in investment could have a stronger impact than a trade war.

site_title: India is considering tapping its citizens abroad to prop rupee
summary: India's government is considering a plan to tap non-resident Indians to attract foreign exchange flows and prop up the sagging rupee, which has declined over 14% against the dollar this year. The move aims to boost foreign exchange inflows to support the currency amid a widening current-account deficit. Officials are discussing a plan to raise money from overseas Indians, which could be announced as early as this month. The plan is seen as a potential solution to the rupee's decline, with experts stating it could change the currency's trajectory.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher after four-day losses
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, ending a four-day losing streak, as investors sought bargains. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% to 23,506.04, while the Topix index gained 0.16% to 1,763.86. The rally followed a similar trend in US stocks, which also reached fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Asia Pacific MedTech Forum sees startup accelerator programme unveiled
summary: The MedTech Innovator Asia non-profit programme was launched at the Asia Pacific MedTech Forum, unveiling an accelerator programme for medical device, digital health, and diagnostic startups. This Asia edition mirrors the US-based MedTech Innovator, which has reviewed over 2,500 companies and graduated 185 through its four-month accelerator, with startups going on to raise over US$700 million in follow-on funding.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: DBS launches programme to mentor 12 social enterprises in Singapore
summary: DBS has launched a programme to mentor 12 social enterprises in Singapore, providing access to mentoring sessions, banking and finance training, and better financing options. The programme, jointly administered by DBS SME Banking and DBS Foundation, aims to support social enterprises in their journey to create greater social impact. Participants will receive a relationship managed account and training courses, and will work closely with DBS to transform their businesses and achieve their goals. The programme was launched ahead of the DBS Foundation Social Enterprise Summit 2018.

site_title: Asia: Markets cautious after US volatility
summary: Asian markets began Wednesday mixed following a volatile US session, with US Treasury bond yields surging above 3.0% and the IMF sounding a cautious note on the global economy. Despite this, Japanese shares rose initially before dropping back into negative territory, while Hong Kong and Shanghai moved into positive territory. Global markets remained cautious due to fragile US-China relations and Brexit developments, with traders focusing on the Chinese yuan and Brexit talks.

site_title: Australia shares end slightly up amid investor caution; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6,049.80, rebounding from two sessions of losses, driven by gains in the healthcare sector. Investors remained cautious amid global economic growth concerns. Broader Asian shares barely moved, with traders awaiting clarity on US Treasuries and Chinese markets.

site_title: Credit Suisse gives loan to US$209m London homeowner
summary: Credit Suisse has given a £80 million mortgage to US$209 million London homeowner, Nick Candy, to refinance a penthouse at One Hyde Park. The purchase price of the luxury apartment was £160 million, with the loan used to restructure ownership for easier rental. This sale marks a resurgence in luxury property sales in London, driven by a weaker pound and falling values. The transaction is part of a trend of decreasing apartment values, despite house price increases.

site_title: Real cash cow in mining isn't metals but coal
summary: Coal is outperforming metals in the mining industry, with strong demand from China driving up prices and profits. Coal is trading near its highest level in over six years, with Glencore on track to surpass copper earnings this year. Analysts attribute the disparity to coal's susceptibility to price swings and China's increasing reliance on imported coal due to domestic production shortages. Despite being seen as a less desirable commodity, coal is expected to contribute 43% of Anglo American's profits this year, with some producers making significant profits.

site_title: Luxury shoppers in China are still buying bags, but not BMWs
summary: China's luxury shoppers continue to support high-end retail, with handbags and champagne sales remaining strong despite the ongoing trade war. LVMH's luxury retailer DFS performed well at Hong Kong and Macau, while the company's wines and spirits business saw rapid growth. Luxury brands such as Louis Vuitton and Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group Ltd reported double-digit sales growth. In contrast, BMW and Mercedes sales in China slumped 46% and Jaguar Land Rover sales plummeted 46% due to uncertainty over import duty changes and trade tensions.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.1% to 7,231.69 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices were flat and unchanged, respectively. The markets were influenced by mining and healthcare stocks, with traders also keeping an eye on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: China's ultra wealthy buffeted as trade war bites
summary: China's ultra-wealthy saw their ranks decline by 237 individuals this year due to the trade war with the US, resulting in a 20% drop in stock exchange values. The number of billionaires fell to 620, with only 28.7% being women, a 20-year high. Alibaba's Jack Ma regained the top spot with a net worth of $39 billion, while the US-China trade war had a significant impact on the manufacturing sector, with 456 individuals dropped from the rankings.

site_title: China Airbnb rival Xiaozhu.com raises nearly US$300m from Jack Ma fund
summary: China's short-term rental firm Xiaozhu.com has raised nearly US$300 million in a funding round led by Jack Ma's Yunfeng Capital, amid fierce competition from Airbnb and local rival Tujia.com. Xiaozhu, valued at over US$1 billion, will launch a smart service and security system backed by Alibaba Group technology. The company currently has over 500,000 active listings and has expanded into full-service options with value-added services. This funding round comes as China's domestic tourism market continues to expand rapidly.

site_title: Hong Kong to add artificial islands to tackle housing crisis
summary: Hong Kong will add 688 hectares of artificial islands to counter its housing crisis. The plan, announced by Chief Executive Carrie Lam, includes 1.1 million people living on the islands, about 15% of the city's population. The reclaimed land will be used for subsidized housing, with 70% allocated to public housing. The first phase of reclamation work will start in 2025, with people able to move in by 2032. The move aims to address the city's shortage of affordable housing, following a 15-year price boom.

site_title: Singapore condo rents slip 0.4% in September; HDB rents drop 0.5%: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents dropped 0.4% in September, while HDB rents fell 0.5% from August, according to SRX flash data. Private rentals have been stagnant, with a 0.1% decrease from September 2017, while HDB rents are down 1% year-over-year. Rental volumes for condos and HDB flats also declined, with a 14.8% drop in condo leases and a 3.8% decrease in HDB leases. Experts attribute the decline to a slowdown in foreign employment and increased buyer's stamp duty for foreign buyers.

site_title: Sears hires advisers for bankruptcy filing ahead of debt payment: report
summary: Sears Holdings Corp hires advisers to prepare for potential bankruptcy filing ahead of a $134 million debt payment due next week. The company, which has been losing money for years, is weighing a deal to acquire its Kenmore appliances brand and home services business for $480 million. CEO Eddie Lampert, who owns 50% of the company, wants to restructure debt without filing for bankruptcy, citing it as risky for retailers. Sears has been struggling due to declining foot traffic and online shopping, with plans to shut 72 locations and nearly 400 stores since last year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit over 17-month closing low on growth worries; won down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed at its lowest point in 17 months, falling 1.12% to 2,228.62, amid concerns over the country's growth forecast cut by the IMF and US President Donald Trump's criticism of the Federal Reserve. The South Korean won also declined, and shares of Hyundai Elevator and Hyundai Rotem plummeted due to North Korea uncertainties. This marks the seventh straight session of decline for the Kospi index, the longest since September 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.83% to 26,389.55. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, at 0.10% and 0.15% respectively. The gains were attributed to cautious traders monitoring the Chinese yuan.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM Holdings gains 5% on news of Huawei contract
summary: AEM Holdings shares rose 5% on Wednesday, October 10, 2018, after the company announced its test solution had been selected by Huawei for its 5G network. The tech solutions provider developed the solution in collaboration with a Chinese research institute. AEM's executive chairman attributed the selection to the company's advanced test technology and customization capabilities. The stock's active trading led to a 4-cent gain, bringing its share price to S$0.83.

site_title: MindChamps expands into Malaysia, targets 20 preschool centres by 2024
summary: MindChamps, a Singapore-based early-education group, has signed a master franchisee deal with Victoria Education in Malaysia to expand into the country. The plan is to launch 20 international preschools in Malaysia by 2024, with a focus on a learning village concept. This marks MindChamps' first expansion across the Causeway. The company already operates preschools in Australia and has international franchises in the UAE, Vietnam, the Philippines, and Myanmar.

site_title: T-MEC? TEUMECA? Mexico seeks name for new Nafta
summary: Mexican President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador has launched an online poll to choose a Spanish-language name for the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, replacing the name "USMCA" due to US President Donald Trump's insistence on a new name. Options include "TEUMECA" and "T-MEC", with Trump previously referring to Lopez Obrador as "Juan Trump". The poll aims to find a name pronounceable in Spanish, as the USMCA acronym is in English.

site_title: Malaysia's former deputy PM Zahid Hamidi arrives at anti-graft agency for questioning
summary: Former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Zahid Hamidi arrived at the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) for questioning on Wednesday, October 10, 2018, regarding alleged misappropriation of funds from his family-owned welfare foundation, Yayasan Akalbudi. He was summoned for the third time since the May 9 polls, facing allegations of RM800,000 in credit card bills paid by the foundation. Zahid claimed the payment was an error made by an aide, but the MACC is investigating the matter.

site_title: Self-driving cars may hit US roads in pilot programme: NHTSA
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is considering a pilot program to allow fully self-driving cars on US roads. The program would require self-driving cars to have technology disabling the vehicle if a sensor fails and to be limited to safe speeds. NHTSA is seeking public input on data disclosure, including near misses, and is working to revise safety rules for fully autonomous vehicles. The program aims to foster safe introduction of self-driving cars and validate their safety performance.

site_title: Singapore restaurant solutions startup TabSquare raises S$10m in Series B funding
summary: Singapore-based restaurant solutions startup TabSquare has raised S$10 million in Series B funding led by Kakaku.com, a Tokyo-listed comparison shopping website. The round is supported by Coca-Cola Amatil, Resorts World, and existing investor Walden International. This funding marks a significant milestone for TabSquare, expanding its capabilities in the restaurant industry.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Australia's CBA hit with lawsuit over pension investments
summary: Australia's Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has been hit with a class-action lawsuit by law firm Slater & Gordon Ltd over alleged investments of thousands of customers' retirement savings into low-interest products. The lawsuit seeks over A$100 million in damages, claiming CBA's pension arm, Colonial First State, prioritized its parent company's interests over those of its members. This is the seventh class-action lawsuit against a major financial firm stemming from the Royal Commission misconduct inquiry.

images.alt_text: Law firm Slater & Gordon Ltd has filed a class-action suit against Commonwealth Bank of Australia seeking damages of more than A$100 million (S$98.3 million) after the bank allegedly invested the retirement savings of thousands of customers into low, uncompetitive interest-returning products.

site_title: Singapore startup making biodegradable straws snags US$13m funding
summary: Singapore-based startup RWDC Industries has secured US$13 million in Series A2 funding led by Vickers Venture Partners and WI Harper Group. The funding will be used to expand the company's production capacity of biodegradable bioplastic in the US to 2,000 tonnes per year. RWDC develops biodegradable bioplastics for various applications, including drinking straws, and aims to make them commercially affordable for the global market. The funding is seen as a step towards solving the plastic pollution problem, with the company's expansion expected to make it one of the world's largest PHA producers by early 2019.

site_title: Activist investor Ackman bets China's coffee drinkers will be next fast-food win
summary: Bill Ackman, a prominent activist investor, has revealed a 1.1% stake in Starbucks Corp, citing China as the company's "single-largest unit growth opportunity". Ackman expects China to drive Starbucks' earnings growth, with nearly twice as fast growth as the company's overall earnings. He predicts the company's shares could double in the next three years. Ackman's stake is valued at approximately $878 million, and his investment in Pershing Square has seen significant gains, with shares up over 70% since 2014.

site_title: Uber said to be pitching US$1.5b junk-bond offering
summary: Uber is reportedly pitching a $1.5 billion junk-bond offering, which would be its second major debt sale in less than a year. The company may offer $500 million of 5-year notes and $1 billion of 8-year bonds, yielding around 7.5% and 8% respectively. This follows other tech companies, including WeWork and Tesla, that have successfully tapped the leveraged loan market. Uber's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, has stated that the company is targeting an initial public offering in the second half of 2019.

site_title: Italy's Benettons sell 20% of their Cellnex stake to GIC
summary: Italy's Benetton family sold 20% of their Cellnex stake to Singapore's GIC, following a similar 20% sale by Abu Dhabi's ADIA. The deal was made at the same economic terms as when Edizione acquired the stake from Abertis in July for 1.5 billion euros. All ConnecT shareholders have committed to spending an additional 1.5 billion euros to support Cellnex' growth plans.

site_title: Philippines' trade deficit stays above US$3b, imports up 11%
summary: The Philippines' trade deficit stayed above $3 billion for the fifth consecutive month in August, with imports growing 11% and exports increasing 3.1% year-over-year. The trade deficit reached $3.513 billion, compared to $3.546 billion in July. This large trade gap has added pressure on the peso, which has been near 13-year lows against the US dollar, and has widened the country's current account deficit.

site_title: Australian state leader wants to slash immigration to Sydney region
summary: Australian state leader Gladys Berejiklian calls for a 50% reduction in immigration to the Sydney region to counter worsening congestion. The region's population has grown by 25% since 2011, with immigration accounting for more than half of the total flow of people into Australia. The current number of foreigners arriving in New South Wales annually is nearly 100,000, which the premier says is unsustainable. Berejiklian's call comes as the federal government considers plans to require foreign migrants to temporarily settle in rural areas to ease congestion in big cities.

images.alt_text: Sydney and its surrounds need to slash immigration by half to counter worsening congestion in Australia's most populous state, politicians said Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,145.21, down 0.68% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.68% on Wednesday, closing at 3,145.21. Losers outnumbered gainers 215 to 106, with 963.7 million securities changing hands. Active stocks included OCBC and DBS Group Holdings, which fell 0.8% and 1.2% respectively. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and comes as traders brush off new Trump threats.

site_title: Trump questions UN global warming report
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed skepticism about a UN report warning of global warming-caused chaos, stating he has not yet read the landmark report. The Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC) had declared high confidence in its predictions, warning that time is running out to avert climate-induced disasters.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.21% to 23,519.34 and the Topix index up 0.36% to 1,767.49. The gains were driven by bargain-hunting purchases, offsetting the negative impact from a stronger yen.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.17 points to 1,779.32 on Wednesday, driven by a 129-56 gainers-to-losers ratio. Volume was 77.41 million lots worth RM45.95 million.

site_title: US private equity firm KKR to invest in office property in southern Seoul
summary: US private equity firm KKR is investing in an office property project in southern Seoul, South Korea, with a total cost of approximately 2.1 trillion won (US$1.9 billion). The project, located in the affluent Gangnam district, will feature office space, retail, and a five-star hotel. This is KKR's largest real estate investment in South Korea, and it joins other investors including South Korea's National Pension Service and IGIS Asset Management. The investment is part of Seoul's rapidly growing commercial property market, which saw 7.8% year-over-year price growth in the second quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.2% to 3,160.93
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.2% to 3,160.93. About 73 million shares worth S$78 million changed hands, with an average unit price of S$1.08 per share. The market was evenly matched, with 55 gainers and 55 losers.

site_title: Federal Reserve policymaker says clarity key to avoiding global disruptions
summary: Federal Reserve policymaker John Williams emphasized the importance of transparency and open communication in avoiding global disruptions and market volatility. As the US economy remains strong, Williams expects continued gradual rate hikes to maintain a "very strong" labor market with low inflation. The global interconnectedness of economies plays a crucial role in shaping monetary policy decisions.

site_title: UK Brexit minister Raab confident of Brexit deal in autumn
summary: UK Brexit minister Dominic Raab expressed confidence in reaching a Brexit deal by autumn, despite the negotiations being "tough in the final stretch." Raab urged the government to hold its nerve and remain resolute, saying he remains confident a deal will be reached.

site_title: Indonesia tells Fed chief to be more aware of impact on emerging markets
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati urged US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell and other global financial leaders to consider the impact of their policies on emerging economies, particularly Indonesia. Despite the country's efforts to stabilize its currency and manage deficits, capital outflows triggered by Fed rate hikes continue to affect Indonesia. Indrawati emphasized the need for better policy coordination among IMF members to shield emerging economies, warning that the effects of global policies are "very real" and must be taken into consideration.

site_title: Japan's August core machinery orders point to more capex gains
summary: Japan's core machinery orders increased 6.8% in August, beating the median estimate of a 4.0% decline. This marks the second consecutive month of gains, following a 11.0% increase in July, the fastest since January 2016. The data suggests that capital spending is expected to grow, driven by companies investing in automation and labour-saving technologies to address labour shortages. Japanese companies' capital expenditure plans remain strong for the current fiscal year, according to a Bank of Japan tankan survey.

site_title: Noble flags objection from Yancoal over terms of restructuring plan
summary: NOBLE Group stated that Yancoal Australia Ltd and its affiliates will object to the terms of Noble's restructuring plan, which involves handing over 70% of equity to senior creditors. Yancoal also plans to challenge the English courts' jurisdiction. Noble's board believes the restructuring is in the best interest of all stakeholders, and the company expects to issue an explanatory statement to scheme creditors on October 16. Noble has scheduled scheme meetings in London and Bermuda, with hearings on October 12 and 15, respectively.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Lafe Corp, Addvalue Tech, Q&M
summary: Noble Group faces potential objections from Yancoal Australia Ltd over its restructuring plan. Lafe Corp has backed out of a condominium deal, expecting a loss of S$8.5 million. Addvalue Technologies secured a contract for its inter-satellite data relay system. Q&M Dental Group's associate was voted to be delisted from a Chinese stock exchange. Falcon Energy's auditors flagged material uncertainties casting doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern. Ipco International's independent auditors issued a disclaimer of opinion on its financial statements.

site_title: Tulip Garden sale proceeding, says marketing agent Colliers
summary: Colliers International, marketing agent for Tulip Garden, has denied speculation that the S$906 million en bloc sale of the Farrer Road project has hit a snag. The sale is proceeding and is expected to be completed by 2023. The project, which includes 162 apartments and two shop units, was won by Asia Radiant in April with a winning bid of S$906.9 million, a 20% premium to the reserve price.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia's biggest bond house sees end to post-election doldrums
summary: Malaysia's biggest bond underwriter, CIMB Group Holdings, sees an end to post-election doldrums in capital markets. The nation's second-largest lender expects more activity in treasury markets as companies return to raising funds, driven by the new administration's plans to address fiscal challenges. CIMB aims to book a record profit this year and turn around its shares, which have underperformed its peers. The bank's CEO, Zafrul Abdul Aziz, is targeting 6% loan growth this year, after a 3.4% increase in the first six months.

site_title: Louis Vuitton propels LVMH growth in boost for luxury sector
summary: LVMH's fashion and handbags division saw a 14% rise in comparable sales in the third quarter, beating expectations, driven by strong demand from Chinese customers. The division's sales reached 11.4 billion euros, up 10% on a comparable basis. The luxury goods sector is seeing an encouraging sign despite concerns over a slowdown in China, with LVMH's rival Kering also benefiting from rebounding demand. The company's wine and spirits division saw accelerated revenue growth, while perfumes and cosmetics sales slowed.

site_title: China's yuan slump puts 7 in sight as traders boost bearish bets
summary: China's yuan currency is expected to reach a 12-year low of seven per dollar within six months, according to market bets. The notional value of options betting on the yuan's decline has surged, with new options put bets reaching $12.5 billion. China's central bank has cut the reserve requirement ratio, but the currency continues to slide due to trade tensions and diverging monetary policies with the US. The People's Bank of China still has tools to arrest the yuan's decline, but a break below seven could trigger faster drops in the currency and hurt stocks.

site_title: Europe: Stock market enjoy late rebound
summary: European stock markets closed higher, recovering from earlier losses, as tensions in bond markets and tech stocks eased. Italy's bond yields eased, with Finance Minister Giovanni Tria saying the country's financial situation was misrepresented. The Dow index showed little change, while US-China trade tensions continued to simmer. The International Monetary Fund lowered its forecast for China's economic growth, citing escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Lyft asks banks for pitches to underwrite 2019 IPO
summary: Lyft has asked banks to submit formal pitches to underwrite its initial public offering (IPO) next year, targeting March or April. The move could be the first of several listings by ride-hailing businesses, with Uber also aiming to list in 2019. Lyft's IPO could give it an edge in hiring bankers, as firms that underwrite one company can't underwrite its competitors due to conflicts of interest. A successful IPO could also set expectations for other ride-hailing companies and provide a competitive advantage for Lyft.

images.alt_text: Lyft, the second-largest US ride-hailing company, has asked banks to submit formal pitches to underwrite an initial public offering next year, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Google unveils new Pixel phone, adds tablet in Apple challenge
summary: Google unveiled its third Pixel smartphone, priced at $799 for the Pixel 3 and $899 for the larger Pixel 3 XL. The company also introduced its first tablet, the Pixel Slate, priced at $599, running Chrome OS. Despite limited adoption of the Pixel phone in its first two years, Google aims to expand its hardware business, with new distribution channels and a smart speaker, the Google Home Hub, priced at $149. The company's hardware push follows its success in the Android software market and a bid to compete with Apple's iPhone.

site_title: Instagram ramps up battle against bullying
summary: Instagram has introduced artificial intelligence to scan photos for abusive content and automatically flag it for review by staff. The move aims to combat cyberbullying, following a survey showing young victims feel social media firms aren't doing enough. Instagram also extended a filter to detect and hide bullying remarks on live videos and added a camera effect promoting kindness. The network also allows users to report bullying on behalf of friends. This comes after Facebook increased anti-harassment measures, following a survey that highlighted the need for more action against online abuse.

site_title: Nikki Haley unexpectedly resigns as Trump's UN ambassador
summary: Nikki Haley unexpectedly resigned as US Ambassador to the United Nations on October 9, 2018, amid speculation about her future in politics. Despite President Trump's praise, Haley cited "importance to understand when it's time to stand aside" without specifying reasons. Her departure was seen as a surprise, even to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Haley had been a vocal advocate for the Trump administration's policies, including a hard line on Iran and cuts to foreign assistance. Her resignation marked the latest departure from Trump's national security team, with a successor expected to be named within weeks.

site_title: Indonesian firms set to sign pacts on US$13.6b of projects
summary: Indonesian state-owned companies are set to sign deals worth over $13.6 billion in infrastructure projects, aiming to diversify funding sources and reduce leverage. Over 20 deals will be signed by 12 state companies, including Pertamina and Taiwan's CPC Corporation, during the infrastructure forum in Bali. Partnerships will help reduce leverage and provide more equity-based financing, as state companies have borrowed extensively to fund President Joko Widodo's ambitious infrastructure push. This move is seen as helping deepen Indonesia's shallow capital market.

site_title: Paltrow's wellness brand Goop accused of peddling pseudoscience
summary: Gwyneth Paltrow's wellness brand Goop has faced criticism for promoting pseudoscientific products, including energy stickers and vaginal steaming, despite a $145,000 civil penalty from California prosecutors over unsubstantiated medical claims. Paltrow claims the products are based on ancient healing modalities and asserts the power of the human body to heal itself, but acknowledges it has been a learning experience for the company, which now has a science and research team to vet products.

site_title: Google appeals record 4.3b euro EU fine over Android: spokesman
summary: Google has appealed the 4.34 billion euro EU fine for allegedly abusing the dominance of its Android operating system, which was imposed in July. The tech giant filed its appeal at the General Court of the European Union, claiming that the fine was "unlawful" and "unjustified". The EU had accused Google of promoting its search engine and shutting out rivals on Android devices. This marks the biggest anti-trust fine imposed by the EU on a US company.

site_title: Oil prices rise as Iranian crude exports fall
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as Iranian crude exports fell further in the first week of October, amid US sanctions taking effect on November 4. Benchmark Brent crude rose 55 cents to $84.46 a barrel, while US light crude increased 45 cents to $74.74. Iran's crude exports declined to 1.1 million barrels per day, down from 2.5 million bpd in April. Saudi Arabia promised to increase crude output to 10.7 million bpd, but analysts questioned its ability to replace Iran's exports.

site_title: Facebook seeing growth in business network Workplace
summary: Facebook's Workplace platform, a private social network for businesses, has seen significant growth with user ranks doubling in 8-10 months. The platform, launched in 2016, is used by 30,000 companies, including Walmart, Starbucks, and Virgin Atlantic, and costs $3 monthly per active user. Workplace's "democratic" nature, connecting all employees regardless of role, resonates with millennials, and it has introduced new features such as a disaster response system and group voice/video chats. The platform has become a rival to collaboration services like Slack and Salesforce.

site_title: Trillions in US net worth vulnerable to recession: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund warns that a severe US recession could slash the country's public wealth by approximately $5 trillion, causing significant damage to Washington's finances. The fund's report highlights the vulnerability of trillions in US net worth to economic risks, including trade tensions and rising interest rates. The IMF also notes that the net worth of many advanced economies, including the US, has deteriorated due to the global financial crisis, with some countries facing negative net worth due to state and local government retirement pension shortfalls and off-budget borrowing.

images.alt_text: A severe recession would slash US public wealth by about US$5 trillion, causing vastly more damage to Washington's finances than just an increase in debt and deficits, the IMF warned Tuesday.

site_title: SoftBank in talks to take majority stake in shared office space provider WeWork: report
summary: SoftBank is in talks to acquire a majority stake in WeWork, a shared office space provider, for between $15 billion and $20 billion, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. The investment is likely to come from SoftBank's Vision Fund. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at its 21 Collyer Quay location in Singapore after emerging from bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: Japan's SoftBank Group Corp is in talks to take a majority stake in shared office space provider WeWork Cos, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday, citing people familiar with the talks.

site_title: Tariff weapons in trade war bear risk of backfiring
summary: US President Donald Trump's imposition of import tariffs could push the world into a full-blown trade war, undoing progress in global trade liberalization since World War II. Critics argue that tariffs disproportionately harm poor countries, locking them into producing goods with little room for productivity growth. The World Trade Organization (WTO) provides a framework for resolving trade disputes, but Trump's unilateral approach threatens its multilateralism, which is essential for impartial global governance. The WTO's dispute-settlement mechanism is a key feature, but its effectiveness could be undermined by Trump's policies.

site_title: Dyson targets hair beauty market with US$500 styling tool
summary: Dyson launches the Airwrap Styler, a $500 hair styling tool that uses the Coanda effect to create curls, waves, and smooth blow dries without extreme heat. This is the company's second foray into the beauty market, following the success of its Supersonic dryer. The tool took six years and $24 million to develop and will be available in two variations, priced at £399.99 in Britain and $499.99 in the US. Dyson, which has an annual profit of over £801 million, aims to harness airflow to prevent heat damage when styling hair.

site_title: Planned Kim summit narrowed down to 'three or four' locations: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that planning for his next summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is advanced, with "three or four" potential locations shortlisted. The meeting aims to discuss ending North Korea's nuclear weapons program and hostilities. Trump expressed optimism, citing "incredible progress" since the absence of missile or nuclear tests this year. A second summit is likely, with Pompeo stating that a path to verified denuclearization of North Korea is being pursued. Timing is not specified, but Trump hinted that it won't be too far away.

site_title: Britain's summer spending cools in September: surveys
summary: Britain's summer spending slowed in September, with total spending rising 0.7% annually, the slowest rise since October last year, according to two surveys. Consumer spending accounts for 60% of Britain's economy, which has been supported by household consumption despite pay growth lagging inflation. A Barclaycard survey found 46% of consumers plan to spend less on Christmas this year, while retail sales fell 0.2% in September, the first non-Easter decline since October last year, suggesting the economy can no longer rely on consumer spending to soften the Brexit slowdown.

site_title: British Airways loses New York crown to low-cost rival Norwegian
summary: British Airways has lost its position as the largest non-US airline serving the New York area, overtaken by Norwegian Air Shuttle. Norwegian carried 1.67 million passengers to or from New York airports in the 12 months to July, surpassing British Airways' 1.63 million passengers. This marks a shift in the low-cost carrier's expansion into British Airways' territory.

site_title: Consumers' fears, complacency are the weak link in cyber hygiene
summary: A recent survey by the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore found that one in three respondents store their passwords in their computer and use the same password for work and personal accounts, with 50-70% not changing their passwords or using unique passwords. The survey also showed that 9% of Singaporeans prefer using banking apps, lower than the global average. Consumers' fear of financial apps may contribute to their lack of awareness about cyber risks and illusory superiority, leading to a lack of public education on cybersecurity.

site_title: Microsoft investing in Grab to collaborate on AI, big data and tech projects
summary: Microsoft is investing in Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing firm, to collaborate on technology projects such as AI, big data, and tech initiatives. The deal value was not disclosed. This partnership aims to leverage both companies' expertise to drive innovation and growth. Microsoft and Grab will work together to develop technology solutions that can benefit the region and the world. The companies will focus on AI, big data, and tech projects, with no specific deal value mentioned.

site_title: Oil prices gain as Iranian crude exports fall, Hurricane Michael nears
summary: Oil prices rose about 1% on Tuesday due to falling Iranian crude exports and a partial production shutdown in the Gulf of Mexico. Iranian crude exports fell to 1.1 million barrels per day, down from 2.5 million bpd in April, ahead of US sanctions set to take effect on November 4. Meanwhile, a hurricane in the Gulf of Mexico led to a 40% production cut by US oil producers. Brent crude futures rose to $85.00 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $74.96 a barrel.

site_title: US: Airlines, chemical shares fall as stocks stagnate
summary: US stocks ended little changed on Tuesday, with the Dow shedding 0.2% to 26,430.57, as investors remain cautious over higher interest rates. Airlines, such as American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and United Continental, fell 2-6.6% due to Hurricane Florence cancellations. Chemical companies, including PPG and DowDuPont, also declined 2.9-10.1% due to higher raw materials and logistics costs. The yield on 10-year US Treasury bonds retreated slightly to 3.21%, but analysts expect the Federal Reserve to accelerate interest rate hikes due to inflation concerns.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Editors' Choice
summary: London's Heathrow airport is considering increasing fees for its £10 billion upgrade project, aiming to generate additional revenue. Meanwhile, Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai, and the company plans to expand its robotaxi services in California and Arizona. FedEx partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas, and Delta Air Lines offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, lifting its shares. Japan's carmakers reduced export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs, while BYD and other EV battery makers face pressure to cut emissions.

site_title: Toys R Us mascot's return hits a raw nerve
summary: Toys R Us is reviving its brand with the return of mascot Geoffrey the Giraffe, sparking controversy among former employees who were laid off when the company closed hundreds of stores. The hedge fund that owns Toys R Us has opted to hold onto the brand name, assets, and other intellectual property, including Geoffrey. Former workers, who are still awaiting severance pay, view Geoffrey's return as a "PR stunt" meant to boost the tarnished brand name, while a potential comeback is uncertain and lacks details on store reopenings and employee rehiring.

site_title: China central bank shifts focus to growth; more easing expected
summary: China's central bank has shifted focus to supporting economic growth, with a move to cut banks' reserve requirements by 250 basis points, freeing up $152.6 billion. The move aims to lower financing costs and spur growth amid a slowdown in exports and investment. Analysts expect further easing measures, including interest rate cuts and tax rebates, as the trade war with the US intensifies. The Chinese government is increasingly worried about the economic impact of the trade tensions, with downward pressures expected to persist and a further depreciation of the yuan.

site_title: Comcast becomes majority shareholder of Sky
summary: Comcast has become the majority shareholder of Sky after purchasing 21st Century Fox's 39% holding in the group. This follows a long-running battle to take control of Sky, with Comcast emerging victorious over Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox. The deal marked a significant milestone for Comcast, which saw its shares close up 0.7% at $35.44. The acquisition has raised questions about whether Comcast overpaid for the company, with some analysts criticizing the deal.

site_title: Banksy's art stunt is economic genius
summary: Banksy's latest art stunt, which saw a self-shredding stencil sell for $1.4 million at auction, has been hailed as an economic genius. By embedding a shredder in the frame and activating it remotely, Banksy tested the value of high-end art and proved that the stunt will likely increase the artwork's value. This stunt is part of Banksy's empirical study of the value of art, which he has been conducting for years. The artist's unique approach to art and economics has led to a clear, separate market value being placed on the story behind the object, a rare achievement in the art world.

site_title: Climate-change battle can still be won if Paris treaty is ratcheted up
summary: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) warns that the world may have only a dozen years to prevent the worst impacts of global warming, with a 1.5°C rise above pre-industrial levels being the key target. The report, set to be delivered to governments in December, urges urgent action to avoid worsening droughts, extreme heat, and floods. While pessimism may grow, collective action by governments, businesses, and individuals can still be taken under the Paris treaty, which can be ratcheted up to achieve the 1.5°C target.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has completed the acquisition of a portfolio of five modern ramp-up logistics properties in Singapore from CWT Pte Ltd, contributing an initial net property income yield of 6.2%. The acquisition is expected to increase MLT's gross revenue by 9.5%. OCBC Investment Research raises its fair value estimate to S$1.37, citing the acquisition's potential to boost MLT's revenue. Meanwhile, Sembcorp Industries is expected to break even or turn a profit in 2018, driven by elevated spot electricity prices in India.

site_title: HK's outlook bleak as China calls the tune
summary: Hong Kong's reputation as a bastion of rule of law and free press is under threat after the government rejected a journalist's visa renewal application on unclear political grounds.
