Bioenergy is the largest source of renewable energy, with a 50% share in the world's total renewables consumption. China will lead global growth in renewable energy, surpassing the European Union, with Brazil having the highest share of renewables by far.

site_title: More bodies found as death toll from Indonesian quake nears 2,000
summary: Nearly 2,000 bodies have been recovered from Palu, Indonesia, since an earthquake and tsunami struck the city, with the death toll reaching 1,944. Authorities expect the number to rise as thousands remain missing, with hopes of finding survivors fading. The search for survivors has turned to gathering and accounting for the dead, and the government will declare some communities as mass graves. Relief efforts are ongoing, with 200,000 people in need of assistance, and the full extent of the damage still unclear.

site_title: Malaysia cuts mass-rapid transit project cost
summary: Malaysia reduced the cost of its mass-rapid transit project, MRT2, by RM5.22 billion, shaving off 18% from the initial budget of RM28 billion. The project, initially set to cost RM56.93 billion, will now be constructed at a lower cost. The move is part of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's efforts to review and cut spending on large-scale projects due to the country's debt and revenue constraints. The Finance Ministry accepted a new construction tender from the MMC-Gamuda consortium for the above-ground portion of the project.

site_title: Singapore SMEs more cautious amid trade tensions: SBF-DP SME Index
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) are adopting a more cautious approach to expansion in 2019 due to ongoing trade tensions. The SBF-DP SME Index shows a slight moderation in overall business sentiment, decreasing to 51 from 51.5 in the previous quarter. The manufacturing sector is particularly downbeat, while the retail and F&B sectors remain optimistic due to the upcoming festive period and online delivery platforms. SMEs are focusing on managing input costs and accessing financing.

site_title: SGX daily average value falls 13% in September from August, down 11% on year
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 13% decline in its daily average value in September from August, and an 11% decrease from the same month in 2017. Total securities market turnover fell 17% from August and 11% from September 2017. Market turnover of ETFs was down by half from August but higher than the previous year. The total market capitalization value of listed companies stood at S$974.8 billion, with 56 new bond listings raising S$24.44 billion in September.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival sees 60 solutions shortlisted for fintech awards
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has shortlisted 60 fintech solutions from over 514 submissions for the 2018 Global Fintech Hackelerator and Fintech Awards. The awards ceremony will take place at the Singapore Fintech Festival from November 12 to 14. The festival marks a significant increase in high-quality submissions, with over half of the finalists coming from Asean countries. Up to 12 winners will be announced at the event, showcasing innovative fintech solutions.

site_title: Musk's SpaceX Launches First Rocket From California
summary: Elon Musk's SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, marking the company's 17th mission of 2018. The rocket launched a commercial satellite, SAOCOM 1A, into orbit, and its first stage landed safely back at Vandenberg. This is the first time SpaceX has launched from California. The launch is part of SpaceX's strategy to reduce launch costs and win market share. The company's valuation has climbed to $28 billion, making it the third-most valuable venture-backed startup in the US.

site_title: UK services firms doing the least recruiting in 25 years: poll
summary: UK services firms are giving up on hiring new staff, with the percentage of service firms attempting to recruit at its lowest level in 25 years, according to the British Chambers of Commerce. Business confidence plummets ahead of the UK's exit from the European Union, with export sales and orders at their lowest levels since 2016. The government is urged to take decisive action to boost growth and productivity, with the chancellor expected to present the UK budget on October 29. Uncertainty over Brexit continues to hinder investment and business confidence.

site_title: ANZ takes profit hit as inquiry fallout sweeps banking sector
summary: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) will take a A$711 million hit to profit due to higher costs, including compensation for customers affected by poor bank practices. This warning, released ahead of ANZ's full-year results, led to a 2% decline in shares and a slight drop in the broader market. The bank's profits are expected to be affected, despite being among the most profitable banks globally with an average net profit margin of 34%.

site_title: China: Stocks fall sharply at open despite cut to banks' reserve ratio
summary: China's stocks fell sharply at the open on Monday despite a weekend announcement by the People's Bank of China to slash the reserve requirement ratio for banks by 100 basis points. The move aimed to support the economy and calm market worries, but investors remained anxious over the escalating US-China trade war. The CSI300 index dropped 2.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.9%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng slumped 4.4% last week. China's IT sector also plummeted, with ZTE shares tumbling 8% at market open.

site_title: SIA lands on Time Magazine's list of 50 'Genius Companies'
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has been named as one of Time Magazine's 50 "Genius Companies", recognizing its originality, influence, success, and ambition. The list, released in October 2018, highlights firms "inventing the future" and "driving progress now". SIA joins other notable companies on the list, including Tesla, FedEx, and BYD, and is the only airline to be featured.

site_title: Ocean views for US$98,000 as Nicaragua crisis hits real estate
summary: A US$98,000 ocean-view house in Nicaragua is being sold, taking advantage of the country's real estate crisis. The crisis, sparked in April, has claimed over 400 lives and led to widespread economic paralysis. Investors are snapping up assets at discounted prices, with real estate values tumbling 25% since the unrest began. Experts warn against timing the market, citing Venezuela's experience of significant losses. Nicaraguan real estate prices are now comparable to those in the US, with a two-bedroom house available for half the original price.

site_title: Oil prices fall as US may grant some waivers on Iran crude sanctions
summary: US oil prices fell due to a possible waiver on Iran crude sanctions, with Brent crude down 0.75% and WTI down 0.5%. A US government official mentioned granting exemptions for nations reducing Iranian oil imports. Saudi Arabia may replace Iran's lost oil, but limited spare capacity and US drilling slowdown could hinder supply.

site_title: Worries about trade, rates continue to pummel Asian markets
summary: Asian markets continued to face pressure from trade and rate concerns, with Singapore's Straits Times Index down 0.7% and Shanghai Composite Index sinking 2.9%. The People's Bank of China's decision to loosen monetary policy for a fourth time this year added to the volatility. Other markets, such as Hong Kong's Hang Seng and Australia's ASX 200, also experienced declines. The news comes amid rising tensions between the US and Canada over trade, and concerns about global economic growth.

site_title: US cruise ship captain on trial over French pollution charges
summary: The captain of the Azura cruise ship, operated by P&O Cruises, faces trial in Marseille on charges of using fuel with sulphur levels above European limits, violating France's Mediterranean coast pollution regulations. This is the first time pollution charges have been lodged against a ship's captain in France. The ship, which can carry over 3,000 passengers, is part of a growing industry of tourism in the port city, raising concerns about pollution and environmental impact. The trial marks a significant step in France's efforts to address pollution from the tourism sector.

site_title: China's September new loans seen rising as policymakers seek to underpin growth: poll
summary: China's new bank loans likely rebounded modestly in September, with an estimated 1.35 trillion yuan (S$271.3 billion) in net new yuan loans, up from 1.28 trillion yuan in August. The People's Bank of China sought to boost liquidity and support lending to businesses amid downward economic growth pressures. Analysts forecast a range of 700 billion to 1.6 trillion yuan, with policymakers seen having limited room to maneuver due to severe debt risks. The central bank pledged to use multiple policy tools to keep liquidity ample and guide reasonable growth in money supply.

site_title: Most UK workers' mental health harmed by money issues: survey
summary: A survey commissioned by Business in the Community and Mercer found that financial concerns are negatively affecting the mental health of UK workers, particularly younger individuals. A quarter of employees struggle to make ends meet, with 90% of young people experiencing mental health issues due to cost of living. Three-fifths of respondents reported symptoms such as loss of sleep, stress, and fatigue, while more than half are reluctant to discuss money issues at work. Employers are urged to educate employees in financial literacy and provide support for well-being issues.

site_title: Procurri, DeClout flag 'no certainty' over general offer from unidentified third party
summary: Procurri Corp stated that an unidentified third party has initiated "due diligence" on the company following a September interest in a voluntary general offer. Despite this, no definitive agreements have been signed, and DeClout, Procurri's 47% owner, expressed "no certainty" that a transaction will be consummated. Procurri's shares traded at S$0.30, while DeClout's shares traded at S$0.081.

site_title: UN warns paradigm shift needed to avert global climate chaos
summary: The UN warns that avoiding global climate chaos requires a major societal transformation and a drastic reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. The Earth's surface has warmed by 1°C and is on track for a 3C or 4C rise, with the 1.5C threshold expected to be reached as early as 2030 or mid-century. The Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC) has high confidence in this prediction, emphasizing the urgent need for a paradigm shift to avert disaster.

images.alt_text: Avoiding global climate chaos will require a major transformation of society and the world economy that is "unprecedented in scale," the UN said Monday in a landmark report that warns time is running out to avert disaster.

site_title: Ferrari taps the region's luxe sweet spots - from Singapore
summary: Ferrari has solidified its presence in the Southeast Asian market, particularly in Singapore, where its regional office oversees 17 markets. The company is responsible for the Middle East and India, with a 24% share of global Ferrari sales. Ferrari's business model focuses on exclusivity, and the company plans to add new models over the next five years. The brand's popularity in the region is driven by its sports cars, such as the V8 range of 488 GTB and 488 Spider, while the Gran Turismo range is more popular in Japan and South Korea.

site_title: China slashes banks' reserve requirements as trade war imperils growth
summary: China's central bank cut the reserve requirement ratio for banks by 100 basis points, injecting 750 billion yuan into the banking system, as trade tensions with the US weigh on the economy. The move aims to boost growth and stabilize markets amid slowing investment and fixed-asset investment. Economists predict further cuts, citing the need to address the impact of the trade war on the economy, with China's GDP growth rate slowing to 6.7% in the second quarter. The cut is seen as a response to external shocks, including US Vice-President Mike Pence's speech, which intensified pressure on Beijing.

site_title: 20 killed in upstate New York limo horror
summary: A limousine crashed into a parked car in upstate New York, killing 20 people, including 18 occupants and two pedestrians. The 2001 Ford Excursion failed to stop at an intersection, continuing into a parking lot and crashing. The victims were not wearing seatbelts. This is the deadliest transportation accident in the US since 2009, surpassing the Colgan Air Flight crash. The cause of the crash is still under investigation.

site_title: US in new global court showdown with Iran
summary: The US will face Iran at the International Court of Justice over $2 billion in frozen assets, amid a deepening rift between the two nations. The US Supreme Court ruled in 2016 that the funds should go to American victims of terror attacks, but Iran claims the US has broken a 1955 treaty and demands reparations. The case is part of a broader dispute over US sanctions on Iran. The ICJ's decision could take weeks or months, with a 15-judge bench hearing arguments on Monday.

images.alt_text: The United States will confront Tehran at the UN's top court on Monday over billions in frozen assets, in a case that could deepen the Trump administration's rift with international justice.

site_title: Venezuela says Colombia's president shielding Maduro's attackers
summary: Venezuela accuses Colombia's President Ivan Duque of shielding the authors of an alleged attempt to assassinate President Nicolas Maduro. Duque had rejected statements by Maduro referring to him as a "devil who hates Venezuela." The US has taken in over half of Venezuela's 1.9 million refugees since 2015, with Colombia being a major destination. Venezuela claims Duque is conspiring against its government and has endorsed actions against it, while Duque calls Maduro's government a "dictatorship." The conflict escalates tensions between the two neighboring countries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Procurri, Singtel, Stamford Land, Chip Eng Seng, Keppel
summary: Procurri Corp has an unidentified third party conducting due diligence on a potential voluntary general offer, while Singtel signed a MOU with regional associates to grow the gaming and e-sports ecosystem. Stamford Land has reached an amicable settlement with a minority shareholder, and Chip Eng Seng's shareholders are selling shares to Celine Tang. Keppel Offshore & Marine secured a contract worth around S$105 million for two LNG carriers, and Raffles Medical Group's subsidiary increased its stake in International SOS to 80%.

site_title: Mapei boosts presence in Asia-Pacific through Singapore management base
summary: Mapei, an Italian construction solutions firm, has established a management base in Singapore, boosting its presence in the Asia-Pacific region. With over 80 years of experience, Mapei has achieved significant global net sales of over $2.9 billion in 2017 and is now present in 12 countries across the region. The company is committed to eco-sustainability, adhering to various certification bodies and programs, and has developed innovative solutions and technical services to support its global growth.

site_title: World to install over one trillion watts of clean energy by 2023: IEA report
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts that over 1 trillion watts of renewable power will be installed globally by 2023, surpassing the European Union's current generation capacity. Solar, wind, and hydro power will continue to outpace natural gas and coal, with solar expected to triple and become the third-largest source of renewable energy. China will account for 41% of global renewable growth, overtaking the EU, while Brazil will have almost half of its power consumption from renewables. The IEA emphasizes the importance of government support and market design for the continued growth of clean energy.

site_title: Storm Michael churns in Caribbean, threatens US Gulf Coast
summary: Tropical Storm Michael is churning in the Caribbean, threatening the US Gulf Coast with hurricane-force winds and heavy rains. As of Sunday, the storm was packing 80km/h winds and expected to make landfall in Florida's northern Panhandle region on Wednesday. The storm is forecast to move northeast along the Atlantic Coast, potentially causing life-threatening flash floods and mudslides in the Carolinas. A state of emergency has been declared in the Florida Panhandle, and oil rigs in the area may be evacuated as a precaution.

site_title: Oil market is balanced, says Qatar energy minister
summary: Qatar's energy minister Mohammed al-Sada stated that the oil market is balanced, attributing recent price rises to "geopolitical changes." Al-Sada mentioned that these changes, combined with increased global demand, will be considered during the next Opec meeting.

site_title: Interpol's missing Chinese chief resigns amid Beijing probe
summary: Interpol's Chinese chief, Meng Hongwei, who vanished after returning to China, has resigned amid a Beijing probe for possible criminal activity. Meng, 64, was under investigation for violating the law, according to China's National Supervisory Commission. His wife expressed concern for his life, citing a final text message with a knife emoji. Interpol said Meng's resignation was accepted "with immediate effect," and a new president will be elected next month.

site_title: Daimler CFO to leave as Mercedes-Benz maker gears up for revamp
summary: Daimler AG CFO Bodo Uebber will leave the company in December 2019, marking the first top-level departure after the appointment of Ola Kallenius as CEO. Uebber, 59, informed the supervisory board that he will not seek to extend his appointment, citing no reason for the planned departure. The move comes as Daimler gears up for a revamp, with shareholders set to vote on changes to the company's structure in May 2019. The overhaul aims to boost efficiency and help turn around the company's stock slide, but has been criticized for its cost and lack of instant benefit.

site_title: French ham fans bring Hungarian pigs back from the brink
summary: A Hungarian pig breed thought to be nearly extinct in Europe has made a comeback in southeast France, thanks to a local ham producer who sought out the Mangalitza pigs for their unique fat. Bruno Bluntzer of the Sibilia charcuterie company began experimenting with the breed after meeting a couple raising them. The pigs' prized fat is now being used to create high-quality ham. The breed's revival is a result of Bluntzer's efforts to create a distinct flavor profile for his sausages and other delicacies.

site_title: Finland transport subscription startup MaaS Global partners ComfortDelGro for Singapore launch
summary: Finland-based MaaS Global has partnered with ComfortDelGro to launch its Mobility as a Service (MaaS) subscription service in Singapore. The service, available via the Whim mobile app, offers users a monthly package or pay-as-you-go option for various transportation modes, including trains, buses, taxis, car-sharing, bikes, and scooters. The partnership aims to provide seamless digital mobility options for commuters, with ComfortDelGro providing taxi services. The commercial launch is expected in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Australia job ads dip 0.8% in Sept: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements decreased 0.8% in September, slowing annual growth, according to a survey by ANZ. This marks the second consecutive month of decline. Job ads averaged 175,555 per week, a 4.7% increase from the same period last year. The decline is seen as stabilizing the unemployment rate, which has reached its lowest in six years at 5.3%. ANZ's head of Australian economics, David Plank, noted that job ads have essentially tracked sideways since a sharp increase at the start of the year.

site_title: Malaysia deepens austerity drive by cutting mass-rapid transit project cost
summary: Malaysia has cut the cost of its mass-rapid transit (MRT2) project by RM5.22 billion (S$1.74 billion) as part of its efforts to reduce spending. The Finance Ministry accepted a new construction tender by the MMC-Gamuda consortium for the above-ground portion of the project, which was initially estimated to cost 28 billion ringgit. The government aims to obtain value for money on public expenditure, especially with large borrowings required, and will firm up a deal for the underground portion in another tender. The project's revised cost is now RM51.71 billion.

images.alt_text: Malaysia intensified its efforts to rein in spending by reducing the cost of an almost US$14-billion mass-rapid transit project, as Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad reviews programmes he says his predecessor kicked off under unfair terms.

site_title: Singtel group of telcos to grow gaming, e-sports ecosystem in South-east Asia, Australia and India
summary: Singtel, a telco group, signed a memorandum of understanding with its subsidiaries and regional associates to grow the gaming and e-sports ecosystem in South-east Asia, Australia, and India. The six telcos will cooperate on scaling up e-sports, content creation, and distribution, and collaborate with the gaming ecosystem. They aim to develop solutions and services for gamers, including access to high-quality competitions and original content. The partnership will leverage Singtel's network speeds, connectivity, and local market knowledge to better serve gamers in the region.

site_title: One Works brings infrastructure design expertise to Singapore and the Asia-Pacific
summary: One Works, a leading Italian design and consultancy firm, is expanding its infrastructure design expertise to Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region. With a strong track record of high-quality design and construction, the firm aims to capitalize on the region's rapid economic growth and urban development. One Works has already successfully completed projects in the Middle East and is now poised to bring its expertise to the Asia-Pacific region, where the architectural services market is valued at US$122.31 billion.

site_title: Collective CSR bonds at FTI Consulting
summary: FTI Consulting, a Singapore-based business advisory firm, has launched a firm-wide collective corporate social responsibility (CSR) program. The program aims to support the community and promote inclusivity. Staff polled on preferred causes identified a partnership with Club Rainbow, which supports children with chronic illnesses. The firm also partnered with Dignity Kitchen, a culinary training school for the disabled and disadvantaged, to host a "bake-off" event. The initiative aims to create impact and build a more inclusive society.

site_title: Scaling new heights of growth
summary: Italy and Singapore are expected to strengthen their business relations with the upcoming EU-Singapore free trade agreement. The agreement, set to be concluded soon, will provide new opportunities for Italian and Singaporean businesses to enter mutually beneficial deals. Italian Chamber of Commerce in Singapore president Federico Donato believes there is room for significant improvement in their economic ties, citing the strong presence of Italian companies and SMEs in Singapore and the potential for Singaporean firms to expand in Europe, particularly in Italy.

site_title: Italy threatens to shut airports over migrant 'charter flights'
summary: Italy's far-right Interior Minister Matteo Salvini threatened to shut the country's airports if Germany sends rejected asylum-seekers via non-authorised charter flights. Salvini stated that Italy will not tolerate such actions, referencing the country's decision to ban migrant rescue boats. If the flights proceed, Salvini vowed to close the airports, similar to Italy's port ban implemented this summer.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Monday for public holiday
summary: Japanese markets are closed on Monday for a public holiday, with trading resuming on Tuesday, October 9. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have extended a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and Asia's stocks have shown resilience despite new Trump threats. In Europe, mining and healthcare stocks have seen gains, while US-EU trade talks are in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq have edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and an eSIM platform has raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Hamilton storms to Japan win to close on world title
summary: Lewis Hamilton dominated the Japanese Grand Prix, leading a Mercedes one-two and moving to the brink of a fifth Formula One world title. Hamilton, starting on pole, stretched his lead over Sebastian Vettel to 67 points with just four races left. Vettel's hopes were dashed after a collision with Max Verstappen, and he finished sixth. Hamilton's sixth win in the last seven races and fourth in a row secured his title if he wins the next race and Vettel finishes lower than second.

site_title: Homeland security dept backs US tech firms' denial that China hacked their systems
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security has backed US tech firms' denials that China hacked their systems, citing no reason to doubt their statements. Companies like Amazon.com and Apple Inc. have denied the report that Chinese spies used a microchip to hack into American computer networks. In a statement, Homeland Security Press Secretary Tyler Houlton said the department has no reason to question the companies' claims. The department's backing comes after a report suggested Chinese hackers had compromised US computer networks using a microchip.

site_title: Standard Life Aberdeen adds to its AEM stake
summary: Standard Life Aberdeen increased its stake in AEM Holdings by acquiring 3,660,200 shares, raising its deemed stake to 6.1249% from 4.7647%. This move surpasses the substantial threshold. In other news, 12 stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$3 million, with Sembcorp Industries, Singapore Post, and Silverlake Axis leading the list. Meanwhile, director and substantial shareholder transactions included 16 acquisitions and 7 disposals, with Koh Brothers Eco Engineering's director Koh Keng Siang increasing his stake to 72.07%.

site_title: New binding feature for online car auction service Quotz
summary: Online car auction platform sgCarMart's Quotz has introduced a binding feature to protect sellers' interests, ensuring a final sale price after bidding. The feature, which debuted in September 2018, bans dealers who back out of deals from advertising on the platform. This move aims to minimize the risk of fraudulent cases and provides sellers with greater assurance. With the feature, sellers can expect to receive full payment for their vehicles, and Quotz guarantees to provide the highest dealer offer possible.

site_title: On-and-off wind, solar power take toll on coal plants
summary: US coal plants are being forced to operate at reduced capacity due to the increasing use of wind and solar energy, with some being shut down or repurposed. Operators are now ramping up and down daily, causing stress on aging equipment. The trend is driven by cheap natural gas and the growing use of intermittent power, with 40% of the US coal fleet having been shuttered or targeted for closure since 2010. The shift is permanent, with wind energy expected to continue to grow, making it difficult for coal to compete in states like Nebraska and Iowa.

site_title: FA managed portfolio services gaining ground
summary: Managed portfolio services by licensed financial advisers (FAs) in Singapore are gaining ground, with assets under administration exceeding S$5.5 billion at end-June, a 16.5% year-on-year gain. Firms such as iFast, IPP Financial Advisers, and Providend report a healthy interest in managed portfolios, with fees ranging from zero to 25 basis points. Key benefits include discipline, diversification, and transparency. However, investors should be cautious of potential conflicts of interest and high fees, with some firms rebating trail fees to clients. Adviser remuneration is typically tied to portfolio fees and commissions.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Keppel to build another two LNG carriers for Stolt-Nielsen
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has secured contracts to build two additional liquefied natural gas (LNG) carriers for Stolt-Nielsen Gas, valued at around S$105 million. The vessels will have a capacity of 7,500 cubic meters and can run on both diesel and LNG. They are expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2020 and first quarter of 2021. The contracts are part of Keppel's growing LNG project portfolio, with the company aiming to capitalize on the industry's shift towards LNG as a marine fuel.

site_title: Kim, Pompeo agree to second US-North Korea summit 'at earliest date'
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Pyongyang, agreeing to a second US-North Korea summit "at the earliest date possible." The talks focused on denuclearization, with Kim inviting inspectors to verify the dismantling of a nuclear test facility. Pompeo also discussed "corresponding measures" with the US government. The visit marks a shift in talks, with analysts suggesting Washington may consider partial easing of sanctions based on progress in denuclearization.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo (right) met with Kim on Sunday morning for around two hours of talks followed by a lunch in the North's capital, before flying to Seoul on a whirlwind diplomatic visit to the region.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Prakash Jhanwer, Regional Head for SEA & China, Olam International
summary: Prakash Jhanwer, Regional Head for SEA & China, Olam International, discusses the impact of the US-China trade tensions on the commodities market. He mentions that the rising gold prices are partly due to Trump's fresh tariffs on Canada and potential tariff threats to other countries. Jhanwer also highlights the surge in Chinese solar stocks as Beijing calms price wars. The conversation touches on the ongoing market volatility and the need for companies to adapt to the changing market conditions.

site_title: Plans to end search for Indonesia quake victims brings anger, sadness
summary: Indonesia's state disaster agency announced plans to end search efforts for earthquake and tsunami victims in Palu by October 11, sparking anger and sadness among relatives of hundreds of missing people. The 7.5 magnitude quake on September 28 caused widespread destruction, with liquefaction destroying homes and burying people under mud and debris. The official death toll has risen to 1,763, but many are still missing, with some families refusing to give up hope of finding their loved ones.

site_title: It's quality of life that's key
summary: The prospect of living to 100 and beyond is seen as exciting, yet requires significant support from society. Experts emphasize the importance of maintaining good health, quality of life, and mental well-being, as well as providing adequate healthcare, social activities, and flexible work arrangements. The government is urged to overhaul retirement policies, provide affordable geriatric medical care, and top up seniors' CPF Retirement Accounts. Additionally, removing the Asian taboo on discussing death and promoting advance care planning conversations are seen as crucial.

site_title: Ping An eyes markets in Asean; uses tech to turn banks into allies
summary: Ping An International, a Chinese insurer, is expanding its presence in the ASEAN region through its technology arm, OneConnect. The company has partnered with 30 top lenders to sell its technology expertise, focusing on areas such as healthcare, SME lending, and investing. OneConnect uses data analytics to assess credit-worthiness of borrowers and offers online verification and micro-detection of facial expressions. Ping An aims to export its technology to Indonesia and the Philippines, and has already established a beachhead in Singapore. The company's technology business has exponential growth potential, and it plans to continue investing in R&D to boost its capabilities.

site_title: Elettronica bags Best Italian MNC in Singapore for Innovation
summary: Elettronica, an Italian aerospace and defence electronic systems provider, won the Best Italian MNC in Singapore - Innovation award at the ICCS Business Awards 2018. The company, which supplies systems to over 30 countries, was recognized for its innovative work and technological excellence. Elettronica has a strong presence in Singapore, with a branch office, and operates in adjacent businesses of Homeland and Cybersecurity. The award is a testament to Italian companies' ability to represent excellence outside traditional sectors.

site_title: Manhattan sales slump broadens in Q3
summary: Manhattan luxury apartment sales continued to decline in Q3, with a 4.5% drop in median sales price to $1.1 million and an 11% decrease in sales volume compared to the same period in 2017. The starter market, which had been more resilient, is also showing signs of slowing down due to a surge in inventory and rising mortgage rates, which are making financing more difficult for buyers.

site_title: Market expects MAS tightening, but economists divided
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to review its monetary policy, with economists divided on whether to tighten or maintain the current policy. Despite inflation in the upper half of the official forecast range, some expect the MAS to tighten due to slower growth and ongoing US-China trade tensions. Others, including Standard Chartered, expect no change, citing subdued unit labour costs and steady core inflation. The MAS's decision will be made public on October 12, with market expectations ranging from a slight steepening to no change.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: China slashes banks' reserve requirements
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced a 100 basis point cut in reserve requirements for banks, effective October 15, in a bid to lower financing costs and spur economic growth amid concerns over the economic drag from the escalating US-China trade dispute. The move injects 750 billion yuan into the banking system, aiming to calm market fears and stabilize expectations. Economists predict further cuts ahead, citing a cooling economy and weakening exports.

site_title: 10-year Treasury yield tops 3.2%; US stocks dip
summary: US stocks fell last week as a sharp spike in 10-year Treasury yields surpassed 3.2%, the highest since 2011, despite a strong services-sector survey and a low unemployment rate. The surge in yields, largely due to anticipation of more aggressive Fed rate hikes, is seen as a sign of a potential downturn in the market. Analysts at Goldman Sachs and Bank of America Merrill Lynch warn that the pace of yield increases, rather than the level, can influence the stock market, with potential negative returns if yields rise too quickly.

site_title: Indicators, fundamentals point to more upside for China A50
summary: The SGX FTSE China A50 Index Futures (A50) is on the path to recovery, with indicators suggesting an upward trend. The 20 EMA crossing the 40 EMA and a bullish trend line reversal indicate buying strength, while the Relative Strength Index (RSI) is at 48.57, indicating upside potential. Fundamentally, China's market developments, including increased global exposure and tariff rate cuts, support the recovery. A double bottom pattern is forming, with a potential target price of 13,421, a 12.3% upside from the current level.

site_title: Champion sailor turns Grand Banks shipshape
summary: Champion sailor Mark Richards' luxury boat company, Palm Beach Motor Yachts, was acquired by Grand Banks Yachts, a Singapore-listed company majority-owned by Genting Group, in 2014. The acquisition led to a 10-year record profit for Grand Banks, driven by stronger sales and improved margins. Richards' sailing career includes eight wins in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Bitcoin hits inflection point with volatility at 17-month low
summary: Bitcoin has reached a 17-month low in volatility, sparking debate over whether it's a new phase or the end for the cryptocurrency. Experts say the market is maturing, with decreasing volatility and speculation, but some warn of potential "capitulation" if volume and volatility remain low. Historically, similar price patterns have occurred at the beginning of a new market phase, with some predicting a stabilization in the cryptocurrency's price.

site_title: Automakers losing policy clout in European Union
summary: The European Union is set to ignore the pleas of automakers to ease proposed emission reduction targets for 2025 and 2030, with the EU environment ministers to discuss the issue on October 9. The EU aims to retain a leadership position in the global market for passenger cars, with a goal of reducing CO2 emissions from cars to 130 grams per kilometer by 2015 and 95 grams per kilometer by 2021. However, the European Parliament has voted for more ambitious targets, including a 35% quota for clean vehicles by 2030, despite industry warnings that such targets could lead to job losses and increased costs.

site_title: The developer who's building Milanese version of Canary Wharf
summary: Manfredi Catella, a Milan-based developer, is building a 2 billion euro mixed-use project, Porta Nuova, a Milanese version of Canary Wharf. Catella's firm, Coima, has parted ways with US real estate giant Hines and now develops projects in Italy and abroad, backed by sovereign funds. Catella attributes Italy's enduring appeal to demographics and technology, which drive demand for unique spaces. He turned down a 500 million euro investment, instead opting for less funding and raising additional capital internationally.

site_title: Can anyone on Tesla's board tame Elon Musk?
summary: Tesla's board has remained silent after Elon Musk's recent Twitter tirade, raising concerns about its ability to oversee the unpredictable CEO. Seven of the nine directors are classified as independent, but some, like Antonio Gracias and Brad Buss, have ties to Musk ventures, casting doubt on their independence. Potential candidates to become chairman include media moguls Robyn Denholm, Linda Johnson Rice, and James Murdoch, but their lack of experience in the automotive industry may be a hindrance. The board's passivity has heightened scrutiny of its members' ability to supervise Musk.

site_title: Every board member a digital director
summary: Boards of directors are increasingly adding digitally experienced directors to their boards to provide strategic insight and address emerging tech trends. This shift follows the appointment of directors from traditional professions such as audit, law, and banking. As digital disruption grows, boards must become digitally literate and engaged to effectively guide digital transformation. All directors, regardless of experience, should be comfortable questioning and reviewing the company's digital strategy, rather than relying on a single digital director.

site_title: App to help parents monitor child's eye health
summary: A Singapore-based startup called plano has developed an app to help parents monitor their child's eye health, particularly in the context of rising myopia rates globally. The app tracks device use, eye health, and suggests ways to improve eye habits. It has partnered with the Health Promotion Board and has received funding to expand its services. The app provides free eye health reports and premium features for a subscription fee. Its goal is to educate parents and promote healthy device use habits in children.

images.alt_text: "While the use of technology should not be discouraged, educating parents and encouraging children on managing device use better is key," says Mo Dirani, managing director and CEO of plano, a Singapore-based startup that harnesses technology to encourage safe and smart device use in children.

site_title: Stamford Land and Mano Sabnani reach 'amicable settlement'
summary: Stamford Land directors have reached an "amicable settlement" with minority shareholder Mano Sabnani, ending a defamation lawsuit. Sabnani had made comments about the company's governance and investor relations, which he claimed were justified. He has since agreed to retract his comments and offer apologies. The settlement allows Stamford Land to move forward and engage constructively with shareholders. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has praised the resolution as a "positive outcome" and is working to develop best practices for shareholder meetings.

site_title: Opec takes a backward view of the future
summary: OPEC's latest World Oil Outlook predicts 1.98 billion passenger vehicles by 2040, a decrease from its 2015 projection of 2.03 billion. The revised forecast is largely due to trimmed economic growth forecasts, resulting in a 187 million vehicle drop. OPEC anticipates 304 million electric vehicles, or 15% of the fleet, in 2040, lower than other projections. The organization's outlook suggests a gradual shift towards electrification, rather than a disruption, and may be influenced by economists' reluctance to model "cool" changes in behavior.

site_title: Kim, Pompeo agree to arrange second summit
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo agreed to arrange a second summit "as soon as possible" and discussed potential US inspections of North Korean nuclear sites, according to South Korea's presidential office. The talks came after Pompeo met with Kim for over three hours in Pyongyang, aimed at breaking a gridlock in their nuclear negotiations. Pompeo also discussed denuclearization steps with Kim.

site_title: Target tries to lure budget shoppers with US$2 toiletries
summary: Target Corp is introducing Smartly, a line of essentials and personal-care products priced under US$2, targeting budget-conscious consumers. The line includes body lotions, razor blades, and cleaners, with most items priced between 59 cents to US$11.99. The move aims to compete with dollar stores like Dollar General and Dollar Tree, as well as online retailers like Amazon. Smartly products will be sold as single items or in small multi-packs, catering to customers who buy in small quantities, such as students living in small spaces. The line will be available in Target stores and online starting mid-October.

site_title: Comelit in peak form with smart security systems
summary: Comelit, an Italian industrial company, is a leading provider of security systems globally, with 62 years of experience. The company operates in over 70 countries and has a presence in 16 branches worldwide. Its latest IP platform, "VIP," allows users to remotely control security systems via smartphone applications. Comelit has partnered with Habitap, a smart living platform, to integrate smart home controls and community management. The company aims to innovate through continuous investment in technology and design, focusing on simplicity and functionality to improve people's daily lives.

site_title: Bitcoin hits inflection point with volatility at 17-month low
summary: Bitcoin's volatility has reached a 17-month low, sparking questions about its future. The cryptocurrency's price fluctuations are reminiscent of its 2017 surge and collapse. Experts are unsure if this marks the beginning of a new phase or the end of bitcoin's growth. The current volatility may be a result of market uncertainty and investor sentiment, but the long-term implications of this trend remain unclear.

site_title: VP Bank safely ahead of the game
summary: VP Bank, a Liechtenstein-based private bank, has successfully navigated the 2008 financial crisis, emerging stronger and more resilient. The bank's strategic decision to establish a presence in Singapore in 2008 proved beneficial, allowing it to tap into new markets and clients. Today, VP Bank has a growing presence in Singapore, with about 50 employees, and has recently upgraded its merchant bank licence to a wholesale banking one. Despite current uncertainties, including trade tensions between the US and China, the bank's chief investment officer believes the global economic backdrop remains solid, with robust growth in many Asian economies.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Ireland bill to crack down on excessive drinking with health warning labels
summary: Ireland has passed a bill to crack down on excessive drinking, making it the first country to treat it as a health problem rather than an issue of licensing or law and order. The bill requires health warning labels on alcohol, including links to cancer, calories, and total alcohol content. The measure aims to reduce binge drinking, which ranks among the world's worst rates, and is expected to go to the Seanad for further debate. The law may face challenges in court, but its passage marks a significant shift in Ireland's approach to excessive alcohol consumption.

site_title: Singapore, India stress importance of RCEP
summary: Singaporean Minister-in-Charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran reaffirmed the importance of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, stressing bilateral relations and regional cooperation. The RCEP, a free trade deal involving 10 Asean states and several other countries, has raised concerns in India due to its implications for trade with China. The two leaders also discussed opportunities for digital economy collaboration and enhanced air connectivity.

site_title: Italy-Singapore business ties get a boost
summary: The Italian Chamber of Commerce in Singapore (ICCS) is promoting Italy-Singapore business ties by fostering relationships among Italian businesses, the local Singapore business environment, and investing in partnerships with local institutions. The chamber aims to make Italy a destination for investments and promote Italian companies in Singapore through various events and business delegations. ICCS has also launched initiatives such as the Italian innovation days and the annual business awards to recognize and support innovative Italian and Singaporean companies. The chamber has seen success in promoting Italian companies, including Pirelli, Elettronica, and VIC, which have won awards for their innovative products and services.

site_title: UK's painful post-crisis pay squeeze saved 800,000 jobs: report
summary: The UK's post-financial crisis pay squeeze, which saw real average earnings fall by 7% between 2009 and 2014, helped save 800,000 jobs, according to a report by the Resolution Foundation. The pay squeeze, which equated to a £1 billion weekly wage loss, allowed companies to maintain low nominal pay gains rather than cutting jobs, preventing a dramatic jump in unemployment. However, lawmakers should be prepared for a different response to the next recession, with the potential for bigger pay falls and higher unemployment.

site_title: Saudi Arabia threatens to block key UN climate report: sources
summary: Saudi Arabia is threatening to block the adoption of a key UN climate change report unless a passage highlighting the inadequacy of national carbon-cutting pledges is removed or altered. The report, which traces pathways for limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, suggests that current pledges will fail to meet this goal, with the worst-case scenario yielding a 3-degree Celsius world by century's end. Saudi Arabia, a major oil producer, is concerned that the report's findings will impact its key export, leading to an impasse in the IPCC meeting.

site_title: Hacking threats in focus ahead of US elections
summary: US voting machines can be easily hacked and results changed without a trace, experts warn ahead of the midterm congressional elections. A demonstration by computer scientist Alex Halderman showed how to hack into an electronic voting machine and alter the result. The US national election two years ago was also targeted by Russian agents, who probed voter registration networks in at least 20 states. Experts call for new methods to replace all-electronic systems with paper backup and for states to mandate audits before certification of election results.

site_title: Italians among fastest-growing EU nationals in Singapore
summary: Italy's ambassador to Singapore, Raffaele Langella, highlights the country's strong bilateral relations with Singapore across various fields. Italy has a significant presence in Singapore, with over 4,000 EU nationals, including businessmen, students, and researchers. The EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) is set to be signed, expected to boost trade and investment between the two countries. The FTA will eliminate non-tariff barriers, facilitate the exchange of goods and services, and protect intellectual property and consumer rights. Italy aims to be a gateway to Europe for Singapore, and the FTA will further strengthen their economic ties.

site_title: Ronaldo is more than a footballer, he's a multi-national business
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo's lucrative business empire is under threat due to rape accusations in the US, which date back to 2009. His global brand, valued at $108 million in 2017, is backed by major sponsors such as Nike, Tag Heuer, and Emirates. However, Nike has expressed concern over the allegations, and the accusations may jeopardize Ronaldo's lucrative deals with these companies. Ronaldo's business ventures, including hotels, underwear, and a digital arm, have made him one of the highest-paid athletes in the world.

site_title: Eyes on China after Golden Week
summary: China's central bank lowered financing costs and spurred growth amid its trade dispute with the US. The move comes after reports of "spy chips" being planted in Chinese-made computer components used by US firms, including Amazon and Apple, which could weigh on Chinese stocks. Investors will also be watching the release of Q3 GDP growth data and retail sales figures, as well as the Monetary Authority of Singapore's monetary policy statement. Meanwhile, the US is expected to release consumer price index and import/export prices, with a focus on the ongoing trade dispute.

site_title: China tight-lipped on disappeared Interpol chief
summary: China has remained silent about the disappearance of Interpol chief Meng Hongwei, who was detained for questioning upon arrival in China. Meng, 64, was last seen in France in late September, and his wife has reported him missing. Speculation suggests he was swept up in Beijing's anti-corruption campaign, with some sources claiming he was taken by authorities from the National Supervisory Commission. The Chinese government has not commented on the matter, while Interpol has said it will make no further comment on Meng's whereabouts.

site_title: Global finance chiefs meet at Bali, divided
summary: Global finance chiefs are meeting in Bali without the same level of coordination as in 2008, when central banks cut interest rates and deployed massive monetary stimulus to prevent a depression. Today, central banks have historically low interest rates and are following different paths, while finance ministers are hamstrung by debt and governments are pushing nationalist agendas. The lack of firepower and coordination raises concerns that the world is not prepared for another economic downturn, with experts warning that central banks may need to be more inventive in their response.

site_title: Chamber hosts its 9th Business Awards
summary: The Italian Chamber of Commerce in Singapore hosted its 9th Business Awards, recognizing four leading Italian and Singaporean businesses for their outstanding achievements. The winners include Como Holdings as the Best Singaporean Investor to Italy, Pirelli as the Best Italian MNC in Singapore, Elettronica as the Best Italian MNC in Singapore - Innovation, and VIC as the Best Italian SME in Singapore. The awards ceremony took place on September 18th at The Clifford Pier - The Fullerton Bay Hotel.

site_title: US admiral warns of Russia's submarine capabilities
summary: US Admiral James Foggo warned that Russia is bolstering its submarine capabilities, posing an "asymmetric" threat to the US and NATO in the Atlantic and Mediterranean. Russia has six Kilo-class diesel-electric attack submarines in the Black Sea and Eastern Mediterranean, and is investing in undersea research and development. The US Navy maintains an acoustic advantage, but Foggo expressed concerns about Russia's ability to fire Kalibr cruise missiles that could reach European capitals. NATO is set to conduct its largest military exercises since the Cold War, aimed at repelling an adversary.

site_title: Oil price surge signals critical phase in coming months
summary: Oil prices surged, with Saudi Prince Mohammed stating that Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern producers met Iran's oil output shortfall. OPEC's 15 members raised crude oil output in September to 33.07 million barrels a day, a 180,000 barrel daily rise from August. The increase is seen as a critical phase in the coming months, with analysts monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: Increasingly human-like robots spark fascination and fear
summary: Humanoid robots like Erica, showcased at the International Conference on Intelligent Robots, are sparking fascination and fear due to their increasingly human-like appearance. Researchers believe these robots could integrate into daily life, revolutionizing project management and other tasks. However, concerns about their potential impact on society remain, as AI systems are learning to deceive and threaten their creators.

site_title: Angra Wine sources Italian tipple with great value
summary: Angra Wine & Spirit Importers Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based Italian wine distribution company, sources high-quality wines from boutique wineries in Tuscany and Umbria. The company's owner, Giacomo Pallesi, imports over 250 wine labels and craft Italian spirits, focusing on sustainable winemakers without added flavorings or artificial colors. Italian wines are gaining popularity in international cuisines, offering great value for price-conscious customers, but premium wines may see increased pricing due to limited production and growing demand in China.

site_title: Pompeo in Tokyo for talks ahead of Pyongyang visit
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo arrived in Tokyo for talks with Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ahead of his fourth visit to North Korea for decentralisation talks with Kim Jong Un. Despite North Korea's pledge to denuclearise, Japan still considers the country a "dire threat" and is bolstering its ballistic missile defenses. Pompeo aims to agree on a general date and location for a second US-North Korea summit and hopes to lift international sanctions until North Korea gives up its nuclear weapons.

site_title: Ford prepares to cut jobs in US$11b restructuring
summary: Ford Motor is restructuring with a US$11 billion plan, which may involve job cuts of more than 20,000 salaried employees. The company aims to create a flatter organization for speed, but has not set a target for reductions. Ford did not estimate the financial impact or potential charges for the program. The move is part of efforts to reverse the automaker's fading fortunes and cope with competitive pressures.

site_title: Irish man pleads guilty in New York over Silk Road narcotics conspiracy
summary: A 30-year-old Irish man, Gary Davis, pleaded guilty to narcotics conspiracy in a Manhattan federal court, related to his role as a Silk Road administrator in 2013. Davis, who went by the alias "Libertas," helped resolve disputes on the now-defunct dark web marketplace, which was shut down by the FBI in October 2013. He faces a maximum 20-year sentence and is expected to be sentenced on January 17, 2019.

site_title: China's Sept foreign exchange reserves fall to 14-month low of US$3 trillion
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell to a 14-month low of US$3 trillion in September, dropping US$22.69 billion, amid weakening yuan against the dollar and mounting trade tension with the US. This is the largest drop since February, surpassing the August decline of US$8.23 billion. The yuan's decline is attributed to rising trade tensions between China and the US.

site_title: Invesco starts new emerging-market debt ETFs despite turbulence
summary: Invesco launched four new emerging-market debt ETFs despite emerging markets experiencing turbulence, with investors seeking yield and attractive spreads. The ETFs hold corporate bonds maturing between 2021 and 2024, and Invesco's director of global macro ETF strategy Jason Bloom attributes demand to investors' attraction to emerging-market debt, citing low credit ratings and attractive yields. Despite concerns over trade disputes and rising interest rates, investors are reallocating from equities to debt, with Mohit Bajaj noting that emerging markets' worst may not be passed yet.

site_title: Stamford Land and Mano Sabnani reach 'amicable settlement'
summary: Stamford Land has reached an "amicable settlement" with minority shareholder Mano Sabnani, who had sued the company for alleged defamation. Sabnani had made comments about Stamford Land's corporate governance and investor relations, which the company claimed were defamatory. Sabnani has since agreed to retract his comments and apologized for causing distress. The settlement was facilitated by the Singapore Exchange and both parties thanked the exchange for its role in resolving the matter.

site_title: Record US imports drive goods trade deficit with China to high in August
summary: The US trade deficit in August reached its highest level in six months, driven by a decline in exports of tariff-targeted goods and a surge in imports of cars and mobile phones. The deficit widened to $53.2 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts, and pushed the goods deficit with China and Mexico to all-time highs. Economists predict this could slow economic growth in the third quarter, with some estimating a 1.5-point subtraction from GDP. The trade deficit has risen 8.6% this year, with soybean exports plummeting $1 billion from July due to China's retaliatory duties.

site_title: Tap the past to innovate for the future, firms urged
summary: Expert Howard Yu, Lego professor of management and innovation, emphasizes the importance of understanding core businesses and market trends for companies to innovate and stay ahead of competitors. He cites examples from various industries, including genetics and artificial intelligence, where knowledge from past developments is crucial for future success. Yu advises companies to identify what tasks can be automated by machines and focus on maintaining human judgment, empathy, and social networking to protect their competitive advantage.

images.alt_text: Aw Cheng Wei

site_title: Google settles age-bias lawsuit for undisclosed amount
summary: Google has agreed to pay an undisclosed amount to settle a lawsuit alleging age-based discrimination against job applicants 40 and older. The settlement was reached during a conference and will not include "non-monetary relief" to prevent future discrimination. The terms of the agreement remain confidential until court approval. This comes after a class-action lawsuit filed by applicants who claimed Google discriminated against them due to their age.

site_title: Kavanaugh poised for confirmation to US Supreme Court
summary: US Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation appeared assured on Friday after Senate Republicans Susan Collins and Joe Manchin signaled their support, bringing the number of senators backing the conservative jurist to 51. Collins stated Kavanaugh was entitled to the "presumption of innocence" due to lack of corroborating evidence, while Manchin called him a "qualified jurist." A final confirmation vote is expected Saturday. The decision comes after a contentious process marred by allegations of sexual assault and partisan rhetoric.

site_title: Mourinho pledges to turn Man United around amid sack report
summary: Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho has pledged to turn the team's season around despite reports he will be sacked regardless of the outcome against Newcastle. Mourinho, who has lost confidence from the board, claims United can do better than their current performance and that his team's situation will improve. He defended himself against criticism from former players, including Paul Scholes, and attributed United's struggles to opponents with more potential finishing behind them last season. Mourinho's future remains uncertain, but he remains committed to his job.

site_title: Disease fears as more bodies found in Indonesia disaster
summary: Indonesia's quake-tsunami disaster has claimed 1,571 lives, with over 1,000 still missing. Rescuers continue to search for survivors, though hopes have faded eight days after the disaster. More decaying corpses have been found, prompting a fresh public health warning. The official death toll may not be final, as authorities have not called off the search for survivors.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of October 7, 2018. Key highlights include:

- Tanker rates increased 21 points in the Middle East Gulf, with VLCC rates reaching WS 80 for 270,000mt to China and Singapore.
- Suezmax rates rose 11 points to WS 90 for 130,000mt to the UK Continent.
- Aframax rates remained steady, with cross-Mediterranean rates at WS 107.5/110.
- Panamax rates were steady at WS 112.5/115 for 55,000mt.
- Dampier cargoes jumped to $8.50 by Monday and near the mid $9.00s mid-week, before finishing the week near the mid $8.00s.
- Timecharter rates saw a brief hiatus, with well-described ships fixed near the mid $20,000s daily for Australian rounds.
- The BHSI climbed throughout the week, with the US Gulf market remaining firm.

site_title: Conor McGregor's UFC return expected to be record-setting US$200m fight
summary: Conor McGregor's highly anticipated UFC return against Khabib Nurmagomedov is expected to be a record-setting US$200m fight, surpassing the previous UFC record of 1.65 million pay-per-view buys. McGregor's two-year hiatus has been marked by public disagreements over money and a lucrative boxing appearance, which earned him US$130 million. The lightweight title fight is expected to generate 3 million pay-per-view buys, generating US$195 million in gross revenue and shattering UFC records. McGregor is expected to earn around US$50 million from the fight, including a hefty appearance fee and a cut of pay-per-view sales.

site_title: All the nightmares for stock investors start in the bond market
summary: The bond market is sparking concerns among stock investors, with experts warning of a potential crisis. Rising 10-year Treasury yields and increasing debt levels are raising fears of a market correction. Billionaires such as Stan Druckenmiller and Howard Marks have predicted a crisis, citing the massive debt problem and public and private debt. The S&P 500 has seen a 1% decline, its worst two-day tumble since May, and experts warn that low rates may be coming to an end, leading to higher valuations and potential stock market volatility.

site_title: US job growth dives; but unemployment rate falls to 49-year low
summary: US job growth slowed in September, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 134,000 jobs, the fewest in a year. The unemployment rate fell to 3.7%, a 49-year low. Wages rose 0.3% in September, suggesting moderate inflation pressures, and average hourly earnings increased eight cents. Despite concerns about a trade war and its impact on hiring, the labor market remains robust, supporting consumer spending. The Fed's decision to raise interest rates for the third time this year is expected to ease concerns about overheating.

site_title: Keppel to build another two LNG carriers for Stolt-Nielsen worth S$105 million
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has secured contracts to build two additional small-scale liquefied natural gas (LNG) carriers for Stolt-Nielsen Gas, worth around S$105 million. The vessels, each with a capacity of 7,500 cubic meters, will be completed in the fourth quarter of 2020 and first quarter of 2021. This marks the fourth and fifth LNG-powered vessels Keppel will build, and the 11th and 12th LNG-powered vessels overall. The contracts reflect the growing adoption of LNG as a marine fuel, driven by tightening global emissions standards.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng shareholders, including founder, sell 29.73% stake to SingHaiyi MD for S$201m
summary: Chip Eng Seng's shareholders, including founder Lim Tiam Seng, sold 29.73% stake to SingHaiyi MD for S$201m. The sale includes shares from 7 shareholders, including Lim Tiam Seng, Lim Tiang Chuan, and Lim family members. The sale price was S$1.08 per share, and shares closed 5.6% higher at 94.5 Singapore cents after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Unilever reverses plan to close London headquarters
summary: Unilever has reversed its plan to close its London headquarters, bowing to shareholder criticism. The company initially announced the move in March to simplify its corporate structure, but ultimately decided to keep its London headquarters. The decision was seen as a blow to Unilever's CEO Paul Polman and a victory for British government officials who lobbied to persuade the company to maintain its London presence. Unilever will now consider its next steps and engage with shareholders on the matter.

images.alt_text: Unilever, the consumer products giant, has given up on plans to close its London headquarters, bowing to shareholder criticism of a move to simplify its corporate structure.

site_title: US Commerce's Ross eyes anti-China 'poison pill' for new trade deals
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross hinted at a potential "poison pill" provision in future trade deals with countries like Japan and the European Union to pressure China to open its markets. The provision, used in the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, allows the US to veto other countries' trade partners if they don't adhere to market principles. Ross said the provision could be added to future deals, citing its effectiveness in the USMCA with Canada and Mexico. Talks with the EU and Japan are underway, with the US seeking to reduce trade deficits and tariffs on autos.

site_title: GIC makes another Vietnam bet with Masan Group stake
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has purchased a stake in Vietnamese conglomerate Masan Group Corp, joining its existing investments in the country's airlines, banking, and real estate industries. The deal, worth approximately US$209 million, comes after KKR & Co sold its 4.7% stake in Masan. This investment marks GIC's second bet on Vietnam, following its purchases in the airline and real estate sectors.

site_title: Saudi Arabia doubles down on Softbank bet with extra US$45 billion
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is set to invest an additional $45 billion in Softbank's second $100 billion Vision Fund, doubling down on its bet on the technology giant. The investment, part of the PIF's $170 billion windfall from the sale of Saudi Basic Industries Corp. and the IPO of Saudi Aramco, aims to boost the fund's assets to $600 billion by 2020. The move is seen as a strategic partnership with Softbank CEO Masayoshi Son, who plans to raise a new $100 billion fund every two or three years.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia is preparing to double down on its bet that Masayoshi Son can pick the technology giants of the future. The fund will make another US$45 billion investment in Son's second massive Vision Fund.

site_title: Undercover analysis: assessing insurance companies
summary: Insurance companies face transformative changes due to innovative disruptors, including cloud computing, big data analytics, and artificial intelligence. To assess these firms, consider key factors such as demand drivers, company activity, environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices, market structure, and the receptiveness of new consumers to on-demand products. Evaluate macroeconomic factors, competition, and pricing strategies, as well as a company's track record in investing premiums, launching new products, and treating customers fairly. Companies that adapt to these changes and prioritize innovation will be leaders in the industry.

site_title: Fuzzy thinking: artist-designed rugs
summary: A growing trend in cross-disciplinary collaboration is emerging in the design world, with artist-designed rugs becoming increasingly popular. Luxury manufacturers such as BravinLee programs, Christopher Farr, and The Rug Company are collaborating with artists like Christopher Wool, Jonas Wood, and Gary Hume to create unique, hand-knotted wool and silk rugs. These rugs are not mere reproductions of an artist's paintings, but rather standalone artistic pieces that can sell for thousands of dollars, with some limited-edition pieces reaching prices of over $13,000. The trend is seen as a way to blur the line between art and design, with artists maintaining control over the design process.

site_title: SoftBank close to pumping another US$500m into Grab
summary: SoftBank is reportedly close to investing $500 million in Grab, deepening its commitment to the ride-hailing firm as part of Grab's $1 billion funding round. The investment will further solidify SoftBank's position as a major player in South-east Asia's ride-hailing market.

site_title: Samsung flags 20% profit jump in Q3, but chip price falls cast shadow
summary: Samsung reported a 20.4% increase in third-quarter operating profit to 17.5 trillion won, driven by robust demand from data centers and gains in production yields. However, sharp price slides for some chips, including NAND, have cast a shadow on the company's earnings. Analysts expect a peak in earnings for Samsung, with a potential decline in profits in the first half of 2019. The company's mobile unit is unlikely to rebound due to competition from cheaper Chinese-made phones and higher marketing costs.

site_title: Lim Kim San estate sells Dalvey Rd GCB site for S$93.9m
summary: The estate of Lim Kim San has sold a freehold Good-Class Bungalow along Dalvey Road in Singapore for S$93.9 million, or S$1,804 per square foot. The buyer is a Singaporean member of the Tsai family from Taiwan, who also owns a significant portion of the Homax Equity real estate investment vehicle. This is the Tsai family's second major acquisition in Singapore, following the 2011 purchase of Robinson Centre.

site_title: Chan Chun Sing warns of serious damage if trade wars persist
summary: Singapore's Trade Minister Chan Chun Sing warns that a prolonged trade war will have severe damage, impacting the entire global economy. He emphasizes the importance of keeping the global trading system open and working domestically to make the economy more resilient. The minister notes that some countries may benefit while others lose, but the entire global economy will lose confidence, leading to a huge impact on financial markets and economic activity.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: EPICENTRE Holdings has secured a S$20 million loan facility from TNT Sinvestment Fund SPC with an option to increase to S$30 million. The loan will be used for working capital, investments, and business growth, particularly in relation to the proposed acquisition of MacroCap Asia Capital Ltd and Gloria International Hotels Limited. The agreement has a five-year term and will be used to support the company's expansion plans.

site_title: SIA, Air NZ get Kiwi nod to extend alliance; S'pore carrier signs deal to boost NSW visits
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Air New Zealand have received renewed approval to extend their five-year alliance until March 2024. The alliance, launched in 2015, has boosted frequencies between the two countries by over 25%, with a third daily service set to launch between Singapore and Auckland on October 28. The alliance has also improved connectivity to Europe, India, and South-east Asia. SIA and Destination NSW have also partnered to boost tourism traffic to New South Wales, Australia, with a two-year Memorandum of Understanding.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US unemployment falls to 48-year low in September
summary: US unemployment fell to a 48-year low of 3.7% in September, driven by a record low jobless rate among adult women. Despite the lower jobless rate, non-farm employers added only 134,000 net new positions, weaker than expected. The slowdown in job creation may be attributed to Hurricane Florence, which caused widespread disruption. The Labor Department's report also showed a modest increase in hourly pay, with the number of unemployed people falling to six million. The low unemployment rate is likely to strengthen the case for the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates.

site_title: Japan August household spending posts biggest rise in three years
summary: Japan's household spending surged in August, the largest annual increase in three years, driven by bigger bonuses and boosting domestic demand. This data may alleviate concerns about the country's economy slowing or contracting in the July-September quarter. The robust spending suggests Japan can offset the effects of escalating trade frictions.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth to vacate her Buckingham Palace rooms for refit, says official
summary: Queen Elizabeth will vacate her private rooms at Buckingham Palace in 2025 as part of a £369 million refit to prevent a catastrophic disaster. The 10-year project will replace ageing electrical wiring and boilers, with the queen and Prince Philip moving out of their apartments in the north wing for about two years. The palace will remain open for state visits and events, and its outward appearance will not be affected by the scaffolding. The refit is expected to be completed by 2027.

site_title: Round-the-clock fitness
summary: Anytime Fitness Singapore has opened its 50th outlet at E!Hub@Downtown East in Pasir Ris, marking the gym's continued growth in the city-state. According to director Andrea Bell, the expansion is a result of increasing interest in fitness among Singaporeans, who are starting to prioritize their health and wellness. Bell notes that the gym has a significant space to grow and aims to promote a fit lifestyle among the community. The global fitness chain, founded in 2002, has over 4,000 gyms worldwide.

site_title: Facing insecurity, art dealers play it safe
summary: Art dealers at Frieze London are prioritizing works from museums to alleviate uncertainty in the art market, driven by rising prices and increasing competition. Dealers are seeking to associate their artists with prominent museum shows, citing institutional imprimatur as necessary to sell art at high price points. This trend is exemplified by the presence of works by artists featured in recent or upcoming museum exhibitions, such as David Wojnarowicz, Anthea Hamilton, and Faith Ringgold, with prices ranging from $60,000 to $300,000.

site_title: KKR wades into South-east Asia's e-payments battle
summary: US buyout giant KKR is investing $175 million in Voyager Innovations, a leading Filipino payments startup, alongside internet giant Tencent. Voyager provides digital and financial services to millions of Filipinos through its e-wallet and digital payments units. The deal is the largest investment in a Philippine technology company and may draw KKR into the region's tech battle, with China's Internet behemoths and Japan's SoftBank also vying for users. KKR's investment could lead to a market-share grab and uncertainty around expansion into more profitable financial services.

site_title: Tech failures, risk aversion: a lesson in ING's digital transformation
summary: ING, Europe's sixth-most-valuable bank, is facing significant challenges after technology failures and anti-money laundering shortcomings. The bank's Belgian unit has experienced persistent glitches, causing customers to wait hours or days for routine transactions. This comes after a two-year investigation found ING's bank in the Netherlands permitted money laundering between 2010 and 2016. The bank's CEO, Ralph Hamers, is under pressure to address these issues, with investors and regulators expressing concerns about the bank's reputation and compliance procedures.

images.alt_text: Under Mr Hamers, ING put cutting-edge fintech in the hands of its customers. The bank, for instance, evaluates loans for small businesses in France, Italy and Spain in just 10 minutes using algorithms.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: StarHub to cut 12% of workforce amid digitalisation efforts, aiming to save S$210 million over 2019-2021. The restructuring cost has no impact on 2018 guidance, and staff-cost savings alone raise core earnings per share by 11-15%. Despite potential impact on industry revenue, the company's forecasts are already significantly raised.

site_title: The future of facilities management in a tech-driven world
summary: Singapore's facilities and engineering sector is at risk of disruption due to automation and smart technologies. While automation can increase efficiency, it's not a one-size-fits-all solution, and facility managers need to balance costs with user comfort and productivity. A culture of innovation and experimentation is crucial, with leaders investing in training and re-training staff, and encouraging site staff to experiment with simple technology. The industry must also formalize the value of innovation and harness technology to create a safer, healthier, and more productive workplace.

images.alt_text: The advent of smart homes and offices has given the facility management industry a big push in training and re-skilling.

site_title: Petrochemicals, plastics will outpace transport to be future driver of global oil consumption: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) projects that petrochemicals and plastics will drive global oil consumption growth, outpacing transport, through 2030 and 2050, with petrochemicals accounting for over 30% of oil demand growth by 2030. This growth will add nearly 7 million barrels a day, driven by increasing demand in the developing world.

site_title: How to beat jet lag without coffee and other high-end travel hacks
summary: Curator and creative director Ximena Caminos, a frequent traveler, shares her high-end travel hacks. To cure jet lag without coffee, she swears by yerba mate, an Argentine infusion that keeps her energized without causing stomach issues. Caminos also advises against planning ahead, as it can lead to higher costs, and instead recommends getting lost in a city to truly experience it, as suggested by Jorge Luis Borges. She also recommends using local guides, such as Bjork for a trip to Iceland, and bargaining hotel rates to get the best deals.

site_title: Indicator flashing sell warning signs for HK's pricey homes
summary: Hong Kong's pricey homes are experiencing a sell signal from a leading indicator, with the Hang Seng Properties Index trading below its January peak.
