The warning signs come as loan costs rise, the US-China trade war heats up, and investors doubt the sustainability of home values, which cost nearly 20 times the median household income. Experts predict a 20% drop in home prices, the largest slump since the 2008 global financial crisis, posing risks to economic growth and Hong Kong's banking system.

site_title: Asian shares end week lower on rising Treasury yields, tech rout
summary: Asian shares ended the week lower due to rising US Treasury yields and a report on China's infiltration of US companies with a microchip. The Nikkei and Hang Seng indices declined, with tech stocks also taking a hit. The revelation of a tiny microchip in servers worldwide raised concerns over national security and company secrets. In Singapore, the Straits Times Index fell 0.7% to close at 3,209.79, marking a 1.65% decline for the week.

site_title: Era of bank secrecy ends as Swiss start sharing account data
summary: Switzerland has begun sharing financial account data with dozens of countries, marking the end of the era of bank secrecy. The move, under global standards, aims to crack down on tax cheats and follows years of international pressure. The initial data exchange includes 19 countries and involves around 2 million accounts, with the number set to expand to 80 countries next year. The Federal Tax Administration will continue to collect and share data on millions of accounts, allowing authorities to check whether taxpayers have correctly declared their foreign financial accounts.

site_title: Unilever's about-face on London base leaves CEO in limbo as shareholders revolt
summary: Unilever has abandoned its plan to relocate its London base to the Netherlands, following opposition from shareholders who would have had to sell their shares if the company dropped out of UK stock indexes. The decision, announced in March, was intended to give the company more flexibility to undertake major mergers and acquisitions. However, investors representing 10% or more of the company's shares pledged to vote it down, leading to a reversal of the plan. The move is seen as a blow to CEO Paul Polman and Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, who had pushed for the relocation.

site_title: Bottles of rare Scotch from same cask vie for million-$ record
summary: A rare 60-year-old Macallan whisky from the same cask as a previously sold million-dollar bottle is set to be auctioned off in November. The 194-year-old distillery has only produced about 40 bottles, with none appearing at auction in over a decade. The sale is expected to crack the one million pound mark, following a recent surge in prices for rare single malts from Scotland and Japan, with whisky appreciation rates outpacing fine wine.

site_title: Lenovo, ZTE shares tumble as investors fret over impact of China hack report
summary: Lenovo and ZTE shares plummeted on Friday due to concerns over the impact of a report stating that US companies, including Apple and Amazon, had been infiltrated by malicious computer chips inserted by Chinese spies. The report, citing 17 unidentified sources, did not involve Chinese tech firms. Lenovo shares fell 15% and ZTE's Hong Kong-listed shares dropped 11%. Investors fear that the hacking concern may harm Chinese tech goods sales, particularly as the US-China trade war intensifies, potentially shifting the electronics supply chain out of China.

site_title: Oil rises, but Singapore industry watchers doubt prices will stay up
summary: Brent crude oil rose above $86 a barrel on Wednesday, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude hitting $76 a barrel, a four-year high. US oil traders predict prices could reach $100 a barrel by next year, but industry watchers in Singapore are more cautious, citing global oil production remaining flush despite OPEC's pledge to pump more oil. Analysts forecast prices to decline after reaching $81 a barrel in 4Q18, with some expecting volatility in November when sanctions on Iran come into force.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Turnaround queen with Midas touch helps transform ailing Thai drinks company
summary: Kannikar Chalitaporn, a 70-year-old Thai businesswoman, has transformed energy-drink maker Osotspa Pcl, helping it become the nation's largest corporate listing of 2018. The company raised 15.1 billion baht in an initial public offering, valuing CEO Petch Osathanugrah's family at $1.5 billion. Osotspa, established in 1891, sold or closed less profitable divisions and focused on its strengths, including beverage and personal-care products, to ensure a successful listing. The company plans to use the proceeds to fund domestic and overseas expansion, including a factory in Myanmar.

site_title: Asset management in Asia in 'hyper-growth' mode
summary: Asset management in Asia is experiencing "hyper-growth" with nearly 90% of total financial assets in the region, around $110 trillion, outside the industry. The sector is expected to see an 11% growth in assets under management to a record $16 trillion in 2017, with profits reaching record levels of $29 billion. Key drivers of growth include pension reforms, the "great wall" of Chinese capital, and burgeoning affluence. The industry is expected to double its revenue pools to $112 billion by 2022, with opportunities in institutional retirement, China's growing investment market, and the burgeoning high net worth individual segment.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Reits
summary: Realty investment trusts (REITs) and property markets worldwide are experiencing fluctuations. US mortgage rates have risen after five consecutive weeks of decline, affecting the housing market. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches may test demand for projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark. Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with further increases anticipated. Other markets, including the UK and China, also saw notable developments, such as Goldman's acquisition of hotel and retail assets in Seoul and New World's sale of Chinese property assets. REITs and WeWork also reported significant updates.

site_title: Asia's health protection gap widens to US$1.8 trillion: Swiss Re
summary: Asia's health protection gap, estimated at $1.8 trillion, represents 40 million households that forgo medical treatment due to financial stress. The gap is highest in emerging Asia, where 18% of net household income is spent on healthcare, causing financial stress for many. The largest gaps are seen in China ($805 billion) and India ($369 billion), while Thailand has the lowest gap ($6 billion). The study emphasizes the need for stakeholders to work together to find solutions to improve access to quality and affordable healthcare in the region.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Singapore's Insignia, tryb among co-leads in US$26m fund raising by Philippine fintech First Circle
summary: Philippine fintech startup First Circle has raised US$26 million in Series A funding led by Singapore's Insignia Ventures Partners and tryb Group. The funding will be used to expand in the Philippines and increase its capital base to over US$100 million in 2019. This round of funding brings the company's total funding to US$28.5 million. First Circle's platform targets small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the region, providing financing solutions.

site_title: Europe: Persistent rising yield fears dent European shares
summary: European shares posted their biggest weekly loss in a month due to persistent fears of US interest rates rising to combat an overheating economy. US Treasury bond yields reached a seven-year high, making equities less attractive, particularly in Europe. Analysts attribute the rise to strong job creation, putting pressure on equities.

site_title: Hyflux still in talks on possible Tuaspring sale, strategic investments
summary: Hyflux remains in talks with potential investors for its Tuaspring water and power project, but has not committed to any particular option. The company is considering divestment or strategic investments, with discussions ongoing in parallel. Sembcorp Industries is reportedly the only party to submit a final bid for Tuaspring, but Hyflux has not confirmed this. The company is also exploring overseas investment options, but regulatory approval may pose a hurdle. Trading in Hyflux shares is currently suspended.

site_title: The life skill that your boss won't teach you
summary: Managing one's manager is a crucial life skill that can benefit workers beyond their careers. Despite its importance, the art of "managing up" is often overlooked in business school and not taught to employees. According to Sam Neo, founder of People Mentality Inc., the key to effective engagement lies in creating a safe space and trust with one's supervisor, and being authentic in building relationships. Workers must position their message at their supervisor's level, set boundaries, and frame the situation effectively to achieve success. Authenticity and building rapport are essential in "managing up," but beware of crossing the line into sycophancy.

images.alt_text: The importance of building rapport cannot be emphasised enough when it comes to "managing up". To get a supervisor's buy-in, it's not just about producing the best quality work. Having a good relationship and being likeable are almost as important.

site_title: French police investigating after Interpol president reported missing in China
summary: French police are investigating the disappearance of Interpol president Meng Hongwei, a Chinese national, who went missing on September 29, 2018. His wife alerted French authorities, leading to a probe opened by Lyon's prosecutor's office. No one at Interpol has commented on the situation, and the agency's Secretary General, Juergen Stock, oversees the operation. The investigation's status is confidential, and Meng's family has not received any news from him since his disappearance.

site_title: Kraft Heinz starts food technology VC fund with US$100m
summary: Kraft Heinz has launched a US$100 million venture capital fund called Evolv Ventures to invest in food technology startups, focusing on supply chain technology, e-commerce, and direct-to-consumer projects. The fund aims to boost the company's flagging sales by investing in fast-growing food startups. This move follows similar efforts by other big food peers, such as Kellogg and General Mills, to adapt to the changing food industry. Evolv Ventures will be led by Bill Pescatello, a founding member of Peacock Equity.

site_title: Singapore takes another shot at growing Islamic finance industry
summary: Singapore has launched a new Shariah-compliant index to serve as a benchmark for Shariah-compliant funds investing in the city-state. This move aims to support the growth of the global Islamic banking and finance industry, which has struggled to gain traction in the past. The launch follows Singapore's efforts to increase its presence in the Islamic finance sector, and the index is expected to pave the way for more Shariah-compliant products to be created.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines chairman plans departure by year-end
summary: Malaysia Airlines Chairman Mohammed Nor Md Yusof plans to leave the airline by the end of this year, shifting focus to his new role as chairman of Malaysian pilgrims fund Lembaga Tabung Haji. He joined Malaysia Airlines in 2011 and has been working to transform the carrier since it was taken private in 2014 following two tragic incidents. Despite rising revenues, the airline faces challenges such as a pilot shortage, fuel price volatility, and foreign-exchange fluctuations. Nor's departure comes amid efforts to address these issues.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group unit increasing shareholding in MC Holdings by 25%
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group's subsidiary, Raffles Surgicentre, has agreed to increase its 25% stake in MC Holdings by 25% to 80%, for a total of US$1.77 million. MC Holdings provides clinical care and is a subsidiary of AEA International Holdings. This deal marks Raffles Surgicentre's significant investment in the healthcare sector, solidifying its presence in the market.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Asia's private-bank party is rocking - while it lasts
summary: Asia's private banking industry is experiencing a boom, with cash pouring in from China's growing ranks of millionaires. However, this trend is expected to end as emerging markets turn south, forcing private banks to address structural problems such as high salaries, technology, and compliance costs. With revenue growth slowing, smaller players may retreat, while bigger banks like UBS and Credit Suisse may continue to thrive. A prolonged market downturn could lead to a "day of reckoning" for some of the industry's smaller players, potentially triggering outflows and lower returns.

images.alt_text: Singapore and Hong Kong could beat Switzerland as the world's top banking destination for the rich in the next few years, say Bloomberg Intelligence analysts.

site_title: Shareholders of Chip Eng Seng selling 29.73% of total issued shares to SingHaiyi MD
summary: Chip Eng Seng's shareholders, including founder Lim Tiam Seng and executive deputy chairman Lim Tiang Chuan, are selling 29.73% of the company's total issued shares to SingHaiyi MD Celine Tang. The shares amount to 186,105,000 at S$1.08 per share. Lim Tiam Seng will sell 77.87% of his shares, while Lim Tiang Chuan will sell all 44,177,000 shares. The sale is part of a sale and purchase agreement.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Wanted: Fashion designers who really understand women
summary: The fashion industry is re-examining its values after the Celine brand's transformation under a new male designer sparked controversy. The brand's shift from sophisticated to puerile and ostentatious designs highlighted long-standing industry issues, including ageism, white privilege, and body negativity. The debate centers on women's power and agency versus male designers' influence, with women's fury illuminating these issues. As the industry grapples with these challenges, designers are being asked to create clothes that cater to women's diverse lives, work, and lifestyles, rather than just their physical appearance.

site_title: Tesla shares fall after Musk mocks SEC on Twitter
summary: Tesla shares plummeted 4% on Friday after CEO Elon Musk mocked the US Securities and Exchange Commission on Twitter, stirring concerns about a settlement in his securities fraud lawsuit. Musk's tweets criticized the SEC, which had ordered him and Tesla to justify a settlement allowing him to remain CEO. The settlement, announced earlier, requires Tesla to pay $20 million and Musk to step down as chairman but remain CEO. The move comes after Musk's tweets were deemed "false and misleading" by the SEC, threatening to undermine Tesla's operations and ability to raise capital.

site_title: Chernobyl begins new life as solar power park
summary: Ukraine has launched a 1-megawatt solar power park at the former Chernobyl nuclear power plant, marking a new initiative to harness renewable energy in the area. The €1.59-million facility, located 100 meters from the damaged plant, can power a medium-sized village and is expected to eventually produce 100 megawatts of electricity. The site, contaminated by radiation, is not suitable for farming, but its proximity to the power grid and affordable land make it an attractive location for solar panel installation, with Ukraine offering investors nearly 2,500 hectares of land at a cheap price.

site_title: Asia tech stocks hit 15-month low on US-China tension
summary: Asia's tech stocks plummeted to a 15-month low due to escalating US-China tension. The MSCI AC Asia Pacific Infotech Index fell on Friday, with Chinese computer maker Lenovo Group Ltd experiencing its biggest loss in almost a decade. The decline was attributed to a Bloomberg report on a 2015 hacking chip investigation involving Super Micro Computer Inc, which supplied servers to clients with altered chips. The news raised concerns about the safety of electronics produced in China, affecting tech shares and leading to losses across Asia, including Taiwan's Taiex index and ZTE Corp.

site_title: Oil prices mark weekly gain ahead of Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices rose ahead of US sanctions on Iranian oil exports, with US WTI crude futures gaining 1.3% and global benchmark Brent crude futures rising 1.4%. Prices hit four-year highs earlier this week, with Brent reaching $86.74 per barrel. Saudi Arabia and Russia plan to increase output to offset expected disruptions from Iran, but analysts expect Iranian exports to drop by 1 million barrels per day. Oil prices are up 15-20% since mid-August, with some predicting prices will weaken in the first two quarters of 2019 before strengthening later in the year.

site_title: As a San Francisco skyscraper leans, a call for stricter building codes
summary: A panel of experts in San Francisco has called for stricter building codes to address the city's inadequate infrastructure following a recent earthquake. The report, commissioned by former Mayor Edwin M Lee, recommends the inspection and retrofitting of existing tall buildings and stronger regulations for new ones. Experts believe the current codes are insufficient to handle the city's seismic activity, emphasizing the need for improved safety measures to protect residents and property. The report's findings aim to inform the city's building code revisions and ensure the long-term structural integrity of its skyscrapers.

site_title: Singapore shares close down on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.7% on Friday, closing at 3,209.79, with 1.55 billion shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 243 to 125, and the Straits Times Index ended the day with a 21.8-point drop. DBS inched up 0.04% and Thomson Medical rose 4.82%, while OCBC Bank dipped 0.89%.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again as bond yields surge
summary: US stocks fell for a second consecutive session on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.7% to 26,447.05, the S&P 500 down 0.6% to 2,885.57, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 1.2% to 7,778.45. The decline was attributed to worries about runaway inflation spurred by the sudden jump in US Treasury bond yields.

site_title: UK, Germany consider fresh Russian sanctions after hacking charges
summary: The UK and Germany are considering new sanctions against Russia amid hacking charges, following US accusations of seven Russian nationals' involvement in hacking attempts. British officials have also accused Russia of deploying a nerve agent in the UK. Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel's government believes with near certainty that Russian military intelligence is behind the attacks. The move may bring US and EU allies together in taking more action against the Kremlin, with the UK's Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt discussing further sanctions with partners.

site_title: October opportunities for the brave
summary: October is often associated with market crashes, but recent trends in September suggest a potential long-term uptrend in the market. This month's correction could be an opportunity for traders to enter a favorable position. However, the historical trend of October closing higher than it opened is also a consideration. The article notes that October's reputation as a "mythical monster" of the market has some truth, but also exaggeration, and that most Octobers end on a positive note.

site_title: Malaysia shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 12.96 points lower on Friday at 1,777.15, with volume reaching 20.5 million lots worth RM1.9 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 639 to 265.

site_title: Bruised euro zone bond markets take fresh beating, Italy yields soar
summary: Eurozone bond markets are experiencing a fresh beating, with Italian bond yields soaring as much as 20 basis points due to concerns over the new government's budget deficit plans and a war of words between Rome and the EU. The US economy created fewer jobs than forecast in September, but the unemployment rate fell to a 49-year low, sparking a rally in US Treasuries and pushing yields up. The European Central Bank's stimulus unwinding and hawkish comments from the Federal Reserve have added to the selling pressure, with German and Spanish bond yields also rising to new highs.

site_title: Hyflux says still in talks on possible Tuaspring sale, strategic investment; no details given
summary: Hyflux is engaged in discussions with potential investors for its Tuaspring water and power project and the company as a whole. The company has not committed to any particular option and is considering various opportunities, including divestment and strategic investments. Hyflux is seeking to restructure its debts through the Singapore courts and has parallel processes to consider. The company is not commenting on specific details of discussions due to confidentiality requirements. Trading in Hyflux shares is currently suspended.

site_title: Gold little changed, US non-farm payroll data in focus
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Friday amid cautious investor sentiment, following multi-year peak US Treasury yields and expectations of a tighter monetary policy. Investors are awaiting the US September payroll report, which is expected to show a rise of 185,000 jobs, potentially bolstering the Federal Reserve's case for a policy change. The report, scheduled for release on Friday, is expected to provide insight into wage growth and its impact on the Fed's decision-making.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as yields bite ahead of US job data
summary: European stocks declined, with the STOXX 600 benchmark index down 0.3% as rising US Treasury bond yields continued to impact the market. Investors await US job data for guidance on potential interest rate hikes. Danske Bank shares fell 8.7% after a rating cut, while Intu Properties soared 25% after a potential bid from a consortium. The market is also watching US-EU trade talks and the impact of new Trump threats on stocks.

images.alt_text: David Mackerness, Director, Kaer##########mtesgkaer##########Yen Meng Jiin

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, citing an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will become OCBC's new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: China financial markets closed for holiday
summary: China's financial markets will close from October 1-5 for the National Day holiday and resume trading on October 8.

site_title: GIC makes another Vietnam bet with Masan Group stake
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC purchases roughly half of KKR's 4.7% stake in Masan Group Corp, a Vietnamese conglomerate, in a $209 million deal. This investment joins GIC's previous stakes in Vietnam's airlines, banking, and real estate industries. The sale price represents a 5% discount to Masan's Thursday close, following a 109% gain in shares since KKR's initial investment. GIC's CEO Lim Chow Kiat sees potential opportunities in emerging markets experiencing "idiosyncratic" challenges.

site_title: End of an era for Japan's famous Tsukiji fish market
summary: Japan's historic Tsukiji fish market is set to close its current location on October 6 and relocate to a new site near Tokyo Bay. The move, which began in 2001, is expected to be completed on October 11. The new market will replace the site of a former gasworks and will feature a 1.6 billion yen seafood market, with 480 types of seafood and 270 types of other produce. The relocation is due to safety concerns and the high cost of the move, estimated at 392.6 billion yen.

site_title: Many SMEs fail to plan more than a year ahead: ACCA survey
summary: A global survey by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) found that 27% of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) lack a company vision spanning more than a year. Additionally, 45% of SMEs do not have a strategy or one that covers only the next 12 months. The owner-manager or CEO plays a major role in strategy setting, but senior management becomes more significant in larger firms. The top critical factors for long-term prosperity among SMEs include attracting and retaining employees, having a robust strategy, and business resilience.

site_title: Oil prices rise on Iran sanctions, outlook uncertain
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday due to anticipated US sanctions on Iran's crude exports, tightening the market. Benchmark Brent crude oil rose 30 US cents to $84.88 a barrel, while US light crude rose 40 US cents to $74.73 a barrel. Analysts expect Iranian exports to drop by 1 million barrels per day, and global spare capacity is dwindling, making it difficult for the market to manage further supply disruptions. Speculators have accumulated bullish positions, but Goldman Sachs predicts the uptrend may not last, with fundamentals expected to gradually become binding by early 2019.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hyflux is in talks with potential investors for its Tuaspring water and power project, but has not committed to any option. The company remains open to considering various opportunities. Meanwhile, global economic trends are unfolding, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. Asian markets are also reacting to US tariffs on garments and the ongoing trade war, with Vietnam expressing surprise and seeking a lower rate.

site_title: Singapore's tryb, Insignia among co-leads as Philippines fintech First Circle raises US$26m
summary: Singapore's Insignia Ventures Partners and tryb Group are among the investors backing Philippines fintech startup First Circle's US$26 million Series A funding round. The funding, led by Venturra Capital and Silverhorn Investment Advisors, will be used to expand First Circle's platform targeting small and medium enterprises in the Philippines. The startup aims to increase its capital base to over US$100 million in 2019 to meet growing demand for SME financing in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei drops to 2-week lows as US bond yields soar
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell to a 2-week low, closing 0.8% lower at 23,783.72, due to rising US Treasury yields. The banking sector surged 1.1%, led by regional banks, after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's advisers presented a draft on policy ideas including bank consolidation. Analysts said the market was overbought and vulnerable to profit-taking, with shares unlikely to rise unless a positive factor specific to Japan emerges.

site_title: Australian shares gain, but in red for week despite modest relief for financials; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Friday, closing at 6,185.5, despite a weekly loss of 0.4%. Financial stocks gained 0.4% for the second session, but the S&P/ASX 200 index remains down 1.4% for the week due to pressure from a months-long inquiry into misconduct.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,201.60, down 0.93%
summary: Singapore stocks closed down 0.93% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,201.60, as 857.7 million shares worth S$500.6 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 226 to 98, with Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Venture Corp among the biggest decliners. Despite a 5-day rally, investors seemed cautious ahead of GDP data, with the market influenced by US trade tensions and the split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Lenovo, ZTE plunge amid Asian tech wreck on report China planted spy chips in US computers
summary: Asian technology shares plummeted amid a report that China planted spy chips in US computers, escalating tensions between the world's two largest economies. Benchmark stock indexes fell across Asia, with Lenovo Group, ZTE Corp, and other Chinese tech companies suffering significant losses. The news raised concerns about the safety of electronics produced in China and the broader implications for the global supply chain. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index is heading for its worst week since March, with investors digesting the implications of the US-China trade confrontation and the potential impact on tech shares.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble on US yields, China row worries
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, driven by concerns over the US interest rate hike and strained China-US relations. The 10-year US Treasury yield hit a seven-year high, fueling fears of higher borrowing costs. Chinese PC maker Lenovo plummeted 20% and telecoms equipment maker ZTE lost 10% after a report revealed China's use of stolen US technology secrets. The US jobs data release later Friday is expected to further boost Treasury yields, exacerbating market volatility.

site_title: Seoul: Korean stocks fall on rising US Treasury yields
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 1% on Friday due to fears of foreign fund outflows after US Treasury yields surged to a seven-year high. The index recovered partially on Samsung's bullish third-quarter profit forecast. The KOSPI closed 0.31% lower at 2,267.52, extending a five-session decline. The Korean won also edged lower, while bond yields rose, as investors feared faster-than-expected interest rate hikes.

site_title: SoftBank nearing another US$500m investment in ride-hailing firm Grab: sources
summary: SoftBank is nearing a deal to invest approximately US$500 million in ride-hailing firm Grab, part of a US$1 billion funding round. Grab, valued at around US$11 billion, has received over US$6 billion in total funding, led by SoftBank and Didi Chuxing. The investment will support Grab's expansion into consumer technology services, including food delivery, electronic money transfers, and mobile payments, in the rapidly growing South-east Asian market.

site_title: SIMTech launching new digital transformation and innovation programme
summary: SIMTech, a Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology, is launching a digital transformation and innovation programme to train key personnel in local enterprises on being champions for digitalisation. The programme, developed with SkillsFuture Singapore, aims to speed up business model transformation in sectors such as manufacturing, food, retail, and hospitality. Senior Minister Dr Koh Poh Koon emphasized the need for companies to equip their workforce with necessary skills to thrive in an evolving technological environment, warning that resistance to change will be the biggest stumbling block.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Lotte chairman freed as court suspends corruption sentence
summary: Seoul's Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong-bin was released from jail after a court suspended a 30-month bribery and embezzlement sentence for four years. The suspension was made following a similar court decision to release Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y Lee. The move aims to address the leadership vacuum at the conglomerates, which have faced government pressure to weed out corruption. The decision is part of a broader effort to support minority shareholder rights in South Korea's family-run conglomerates.

site_title: Singapore happy to be 'Goldilocks' for energy usage experiments
summary: Singapore is being considered as a "Goldilocks" testing ground for reducing energy usage through data-driven approaches and urban design. The city-state is using data to optimize its electricity system and experimenting with building designs to reduce energy consumption. A carbon tax of S$5 a ton will be imposed in 2020, affecting large industrial facilities, with revenue to be used for more efficient energy production and company energy efficiency improvements. Singapore's small size allows for system-level changes to be made, making it a suitable testing ground for innovative solutions.

site_title: Singapore companies take on a more aggressive stance amid trade tensions
summary: Singapore companies are increasingly taking on a more aggressive stance in the global market, with a total of US$91 billion of overseas deals announced through September this year, more than double the US$41.9 billion in the same period of 2017. This surge in M&A activity is driven by companies looking to expand globally amid an escalating trade war and a forecasted slow economic expansion in Singapore. Key players such as Temasek Holdings and GIC are leading the charge, with Singapore firms also targeting Chinese companies, including a US$14 billion investment in Ant Financial.

site_title: Damage from prolonged trade war will be severe: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing warns that a prolonged trade war will have severe damage to the global economy, with the entire economy losing confidence. The damage will impact financial markets, slow down economic activity, and negatively affect countries like Singapore, which is heavily dependent on exports. With global economic growth already at risk, Chan emphasizes the need to maintain the global trading system open and work domestically to make the economy more resilient.

site_title: HK stocks at 3-week low amid fresh trade war fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell to a 3-week low, closing at 26,572.57, amid renewed fears of a US-China trade war's impact on technology shares. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.19% for the day and 4.4% for the week, its steepest weekly fall since February. Chinese H-shares listed in Hong Kong fell 0.16% as traders awaited cues from the Mainland A-share market's movements on Monday.

site_title: Short sellers feast on Hong Kong stocks as China investors brace
summary: Hong Kong's stock market has reached a bearish level, with short-selling turnover at nearly 18% of total shares traded. This is the highest since 2016, contributing to a 1.7% decline in the Hang Seng Index. A trade war and economic slowdown concerns are weighing on the market, and a currency peg with the US limits the city's ability to follow its own economic path. The Hang Seng Index is on track for its worst year since 2011, with at least 14% of shares sold short, including Great Wall Motor Co and BYD Co.

site_title: Toyota issues second Prius recall in a month on crash risk
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is recalling over 2 million hybrid cars, including the Prius, due to a software malfunction that could lead to a crash. The affected vehicles include approximately 1.25 million in Japan and 830,000 in North America. This is the second recall for Priuses in a month, following a previous recall due to a fire risk. The recall, which began on Friday, is the second in 2018, following a 2014-2015 recall for a related issue.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.55 points to 1,786.56 on Friday, with losers outnumbering gainers 163 to 53. The market saw 84.1 million lots traded worth RM32.8 million.

site_title: Strong quake hits Japan's northern island, no tsunami danger
summary: A 5.3-magnitude earthquake struck Japan's northernmost island of Hokkaido on October 5, 2018, with no tsunami danger reported. The quake, 42 kilometers deep, was centered on Hokkaido's southern coast. It occurred in the same area as a magnitude 6.7 quake on September 6 that paralyzed the island, killing dozens and knocking power to its 5.3 million residents.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks poised for fifth losing session, won steady
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell for the fifth consecutive session due to rising US bond yields, while the won remained steady against the dollar. The KOSPI dropped 0.31% to 2,267.41 points, with Samsung Electronics shares rising 0.45% after reporting a potential record high operating profit. The won was quoted at 1,129.7 per US dollar, and foreigners sold 83,480 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Dollar treads water before US jobs data, Aussie dips
summary: The US dollar paused its rally ahead of Friday's US jobs data, trading flat at 113.93 yen, after a two-day global government bond rout lifted US Treasury yields to seven-year highs. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note hit its highest levels since May 2011, boosting expectations of stronger-than-expected jobs data and a potential tightening cycle by the Federal Reserve. The Australian dollar slipped 0.2% to a 32-month low, while the euro edged down 0.05% to US$1.1507, amid a rise in euro zone government bond yields and a strengthening US dollar.

site_title: Last-ditch search for survivors as Indonesia disaster toll tops 1,500
summary: Indonesia's death toll from a devastating 7.5 magnitude earthquake and tsunami on Sulawesi island has risen to 1,558, with over 100 people still unaccounted for. Search teams made last-ditch efforts to find survivors, but chances of pulling survivors alive from the rubble are almost zero. International aid has finally started to arrive, with over 100 planes carrying supplies en route. The disaster has left the city of Palu in ruins, with roads impassable and detritus scattered everywhere. Recovery efforts are expected to take years, with aid groups and governments pledging support to help the country recover.

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer biggest fall in a month after bond yield surge
summary: European shares plummeted 1.1-1.5% on Thursday, their largest decline in a month, as bond yields surged due to rising US interest rates. The surge boosted euro zone government bond yields and made steady dividend streams less appealing for defensive companies. Luxury goods companies, such as Kering and LVMH, were among the worst performers, while financials like Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank rose as they benefit from rising rates.

site_title: Investors pull most cash from US Treasury funds since March 2016: Lipper
summary: Investors pulled nearly $1.7 billion from US Treasury funds in the latest week, the largest outflow since March 2016, amid growing concerns about inflation and interest rate hikes. The move exacerbates a bond selloff, with US benchmark 10-year Treasury note yields reaching their highest since May 2011. Investors are shifting to lower-grade corporate credit and other sectors, such as real estate and healthcare, as they seek to protect against rising rates.

images.alt_text: Investors dumped US government debt funds during the latest week, Lipper data showed on Thursday, pulling the most cash from those funds since March 2016 and exacerbating a bond selloff that spooked markets.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.18% to 3,225.85
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.18% to 3,225.85 at open on Friday, following overnight US market declines. Losers outnumbered gainers 74 to 22, with 49.4 million securities worth S$63.5 million changing hands. Key stocks including Rex International Holding and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust were among the most traded.

site_title: Home For The Holidays
summary: In Singapore, staycations have become increasingly popular, with six in 10 locals taking a staycation in the past year, and seven in 10 planning one in the next year. The trend is attributed to the growing appeal of exploring the city-state as a tourist in its own backyard, with luxury hotels like The Capitol Kempinski Hotel and Orchard Rendezvous Hotel offering unique experiences. Budget-friendly options like the CUBE Boutique Capsule Hotel also cater to digitally-inclined travelers. With new hotels and bars opening, staycations are poised to become the next national pastime.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US: Wall Street stumbles as bond yield climb continues
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with the Dow falling 0.75% to 26,627.48, as Treasury yields reached seven-year highs. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rising to 3.232%. Strong economic data, including jobless claims and factory orders, fueled concerns about accelerating inflation. Financials were a bright spot, with banks rising 0.81%, but tech stocks, including Alphabet and Netflix, fell due to concerns over global supply chain security.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, Pacific Star Development, Chip Eng Seng
summary: Ascendas Reit completed its £253.25 million (S$451.67 million) acquisition of 26 UK logistics properties. Chip Eng Seng Corp halted trading after a late Thursday rally, and Pacific Star Development revised its total liabilities to S$146.2 million after an audit.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil falls from 4-year highs; Wall Street weighs
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with Brent crude futures dropping $1.71 to $84.58 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling $2.08 to $74.33 a barrel. The decline came after futures hit four-year highs on Wednesday due to imminent US sanctions on Iran. Market participants took profits after Brent reached a technically overbought level, and crude inventories at the US hub of Cushing rose. The decline weighed on oil prices, which have risen amid concerns about sanctions on Iran and global trade worries.

site_title: Australian shares up, financials attempt to steady after selloff; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by a tentative recovery in the financial sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,196.4, despite a small weekly loss. Investors are taking advantage of relatively cheaper levels to buy shares with juicy dividends. The sector's recovery comes amid concerns over the absence of Chinese investors, who have been taking profits in the current environment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, influenced by the decline in US Treasury bond yields. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.79% to 23,786.10, while the Topix index decreased 0.49% to 1,792.32. The negative lead from New York, where stocks sank due to US Treasury bond yield concerns, contributed to the Tokyo market's decline.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.45% on Friday, closing at 26,503.75, amid concerns over US interest rate hikes. The losses follow a 4% decline this week, with traders worried about an extended period of rate hikes. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed due to a public holiday.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng halts trading after late Thursday rally draws query
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp halted trading of its shares on Friday after a late Thursday rally drew a trading query from the Singapore Exchange. The company's stock rose 5.6% or 5 Singapore cents to close at 94.5 cents, with a record 8.9 million shares changing hands. The halt is pending an announcement and follows a surge in trading activity after 4pm on Thursday.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q3 operating profit likely climbed by a fifth to record
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a likely 20.4% increase in third-quarter operating profit to a record high of 17.5 trillion won, exceeding market expectations. The company attributed the surge to strong demand from data centers and improved production yields. However, this quarter is expected to mark the end of a two-year supply and demand cycle, leading to lower prices and earnings in the future.

site_title: Apple, Amazon deny Bloomberg report on Chinese hardware attack
summary: Apple and Amazon have denied a Bloomberg Businessweek report claiming that Chinese intelligence agents inserted malicious computer chips into their systems, giving Beijing secret access to internal networks. The report cited 17 unidentified sources, but the companies strongly disputed the claims, stating there is no truth to the allegations. Security experts expressed doubts about the attacks, citing the stark discrepancy between the claims and the companies' denials. Bloomberg defended its reporting, but the companies' denials have raised concerns about the potential for malicious cyber activity in global supply chains.

site_title: Shariah-compliant index tracking SGX-listed companies launched
summary: A new Shariah-compliant index, the FTSE ST Singapore Shariah Index, has been launched by FTSE Russell, tracking SGX-listed companies that adhere to Shariah principles. The index, starting with 48 constituents, includes top companies like Singtel, Keppel, and Singapore Airlines. This launch comes as the global Islamic banking and finance industry reaches $2 trillion in assets, highlighting the need for Shariah-compliant asset management tools.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan August real wages fall as rising gasoline prices threaten consumption
summary: Japan's real wages fell 0.6% in August, the first decline in four months, as inflation-adjusted wages lost momentum due to rising gasoline and kerosene costs. This decline suggests consumers may cut back on spending to afford fuel and heating, impacting economic growth. The decrease follows a revised 0.5% annual increase in July.

site_title: For Performance Motors' new boss, motorcycles sharpen the BMW brand
summary: BMW's new managing director of Performance Motors Limited, Arnt Bayer, is an avid motorcyclist who has revived his hobby after a 20-year break. Bayer rode a motorcycle with customers at the Pure & Crafted music-and-motorcycles festival, promoting BMW's two-wheelers and highlighting the brand's adventure motorcycle, the F 850 GS. He believes motorcycles help sharpen the BMW brand, similar to the high-performance M division, and sees the bike business as important for BMW's overall image. Bayer's passion for motorcycles may also influence his family, including his three-year-old son.

site_title: CapitaLand's joint venture acquires co-working business
summary: CapitaLand's joint venture, The Work Project Kingdom, has acquired Collective Works' co-working business for an undisclosed amount. Collective Works, founded in 2012, operates 30,000 sq ft across two locations with over 90% occupancy. The joint venture plans to preserve space at Collective Works Capital Tower, rebranding it next year, while ceasing operations at Cecil Street. Collective Works' founder, Jonathan O'Byrne, will manage the business for six months. This acquisition follows CapitaLand's recent investment in The Work Project and securing a sustainability-linked loan.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - Recourse when you encounter ICO fraud
summary: Danny Ong, a partner at Rajah & Tann Singapore LLP, discusses the risks of Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs) and asset recovery in this area. He shares his experience managing disputes and advises potential investors to be cautious of ICO fraud. Ong highlights the importance of due diligence and understanding the risks involved in investing in ICOs. The podcast aims to provide guidance on recourse when encountering ICO fraud, emphasizing the need for investors to be informed and vigilant when investing in these emerging markets.

site_title: US plans to rewrite rules that impede self-driving cars
summary: The US Department of Transportation is revising safety rules for self-driving cars, aiming to make it easier for fully autonomous vehicles to be deployed without human controls. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) plans to reconsider its current safety standards, which require features like steering wheels and pedals. The move comes as companies like General Motors and Waymo prepare to launch self-driving services, despite concerns about safety and security. The revised rules are expected to be proposed in the coming months, with a focus on modernizing procedures for reviewing exemption petitions.

site_title: US agency saw sharp rise in sexual harassment complaints after #MeToo
summary: The US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) reported a 12% increase in sexual harassment complaints filed with the agency over the past year, attributed to the #MeToo movement. The number of complaints rose to about 7,600, with the EEOC filing 41 lawsuits, including sexual harassment claims, and recovering nearly $70 million for victims. The increase marks the first rise in nearly a decade, with many experts predicting the #MeToo movement would spur an uptick in harassment claims.

site_title: Every board member a digital director
summary: Boards of directors are increasingly appointing digitally experienced directors to provide strategic insight and oversight on emerging tech trends and threats. This trend, known as "going digital," aims to make all directors digitally literate and engaged to drive digital transformation. According to a study, boards will evolve to include members who fit four categories of digital board roles, including thought leadership, strategy formulation, and strategy execution. As digital disruptions continue, boards will play a crucial role in stimulating and triggering management action to respond to digital trends and threats.

site_title: Rising use of plastics to drive oil demand to 2050: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts that global oil demand will continue to grow until 2050, driven by the increasing use of plastics and petrochemical products. Despite efforts to reduce oil consumption, emerging economies like India and China will propel demand for petrochemicals. By 2050, petrochemicals are expected to account for nearly half of global oil demand growth, offsetting slower consumption of motor fuel. Oil companies are investing in new petrochemical plants, betting on rising demand for plastics, while recycling efforts are expected to have a minor impact.

images.alt_text: Plastics and other petrochemical products will drive global oil demand to 2050, offsetting slower consumption of motor fuel, the International Energy Agency (IEA) said on Friday.

site_title: HP gives upbeat 2019 profit forecast on strong demand
summary: HP Inc has issued an upbeat profit forecast for fiscal 2019, citing strong demand for its products. The company expects a profit of $2.12 to $2.22 per share, beating analyst projections of $2.15. PC shipments rose 1.4% in the second quarter, and HP plans to increase its quarterly dividend by 15% and maintain free cash flow of at least $3.7 billion. The company also targets an operating margin of at least 16% for its printer division, which includes the Samsung printer unit acquired last year.

site_title: Tsukiji: It's not all about the fish, says Michelin chef
summary: Michelin chef Lionel Beccat reminisces about Tsukiji fish market, saying it's not just about the fish, but about human relationships. He spent 12 years establishing relationships with fishmongers, who choose clients, and finds inspiration in the market's sights, smells, and expertise. The market's closure on October 6 marks the end of an 83-year era, with a new site at Toyosu planned, which may impact suppliers' relationships with customers. Despite improved sanitation, the atmosphere will be different, with Beccat acknowledging that Tsukiji is addictive and has taught him much in his life.

site_title: Watch and Learn
summary: A Canadian lifestyle channel, Makeful HD, has launched on StarHub TV Channel 436, focusing on DIY projects and home improvement shows. The channel features celebrity-led programs, including "Brojects," where brothers renovate their weekend getaway home. Makeful is also partnering with Singaporean makers, such as food artist Little Miss Bento, to create new content.

images.alt_text: Brojects.
Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Three Morgons from 2016 Beaujolais vintage are drastically different
summary: Three Morgon wines from the 2016 Beaujolais vintage exhibit drastic differences, defying simplistic descriptions. The wines, produced by Jean Paul Brun, M&C Lapierre, and Jean Foillard, showcase distinct characteristics due to varying grape plots, soil composition, and winemaking techniques. Brun's wine comes from sandy decomposed granite, while Lapierre's grapes are grown in light granite soils. Foillard's wine is from a schist-based plot, contributing to its intense and powerful flavor profile. The wines' differences highlight the complexity of Beaujolais and challenge the notion that the region's wines can be easily categorized.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascendas Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, had an active quarter of acquisitions and fund raising, including S$425.8 million of acquisitions in Australia and Britain. The post-acquisition weighted average lease expiry is stable at 4 years. The outlook is stable, with a target price of S$2.82 set by Phillip Securities Research.

site_title: Irate SBI Offshore investors grill Mirzan Mahathir at EGM
summary: At SBI Offshore's extraordinary general meeting, around 20 shareholders criticized the three-member board, led by executive chairman Mirzan Mahathir, for the company's poor performance. Shareholders expressed concerns about the executive chairman's time commitment to the firm, raising questions about its viability. The relatively low turnout underscored shareholder fatigue, highlighting the need for better performance and governance.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Pressure on India lenders as easy money ends
summary: Pressure on Indian lenders is mounting as the era of easy money ends, causing strain on the country's fastest-growing economy. Rising global interest rates and central bank tightening policies are affecting debt-focused mutual funds and infrastructure financiers, such as Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Ltd, which recently defaulted on debt. This is the latest example of the economic challenges India is facing as the country's economic growth slows.

site_title: Making way for mod-Italian cuisine
summary: Italian chefs in Singapore are breaking away from traditional Italian cuisine, which is often associated with pizza and pasta, to showcase modern and innovative dishes. Chefs like Massimo Bottura, who topped the World's 50 Best Restaurants list, are pushing boundaries and challenging the notion that Italian food is limited to grandma's recipes. Native Italian chefs in Singapore are now experimenting with new flavors and techniques to redefine the country's culinary scene.

site_title: Parkway Pantai gives S$2m to establish scholarship
summary: Parkway Pantai Limited has contributed S$2 million to establish a Mount Elizabeth-Gleneagles Graduate Scholarship fund for financially needy Duke-NUS medical students. The scholarship is valued at S$10,000 each and aims to support aspiring doctors regardless of their financial background. This addition brings the cumulative amount of scholarship contribution to S$8.5 million, as announced by Tan See Leng, Group CEO of Parkway Pantai. The company aims to nurture the next generation of medical leaders and support medical education in Singapore.

site_title: OCBC aiming for encore performance by gem of a PE fund
summary: OCBC Bank's private equity fund, Lion-OCBC Capital Asia Fund I, is on track to achieve its 20% internal rate of return by the end of its 10-year term. The S$550-million fund, launched in 2015, has made 10 investments, including in tech unicorns Grab and a Chinese tech hardware startup. OCBC plans to start a second, larger fund next year, which will be funded by third parties and have a "totally independent" structure. The bank's approach is unique in providing financial solutions and advisory services to its investees, while maintaining a conflict-free relationship.

site_title: SIA, Air New Zealand alliance gets nod for 5 more years
summary: SIA and Air New Zealand's joint venture alliance has been renewed for five more years until March 2024. The alliance, launched in 2015, has increased frequencies between Singapore and New Zealand by 25% and added 40% more capacity on the Singapore-Auckland route. This includes three daily services between Singapore and Auckland, starting October 28, and increased services during peak season to Christchurch. The two airlines will operate 35 return services a week between Singapore and New Zealand during peak months.

images.alt_text: Sinagpore Airlines (SIA) and Air New Zealand's joint venture alliance has received renewed approval from the New Zealand Ministry of Transport, the final step in enabling the two flag carriers to extend their alliance for a further five years until March 2024.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Drink And Stay The Night
summary: The Mandarin Oriental Singapore's MO BAR is a popular spot, open from 11am to 1am (Sun-Thu) and 11am to 2am (Fri-Sat). The bar offers a unique experience for hotel guests who want to enjoy a night out without worrying about getting home. This trend of hotels enhancing their bar offerings is becoming increasingly popular, providing guests with a convenient and luxurious option.

site_title: Travel Insider
summary: Porter & Sail, a travel app, has expanded to Bali, Phuket, Sydney, and Singapore, partnering with boutique hotels for a seamless booking process. The app allows on-the-go check-in, keyless room entry, and insider travel knowledge, including restaurant reservations and city guides. Even if not staying at partner hotels, users can access expert travel advice and recommendations, such as Parisian baker Eric Kayser's favorite shops. The app is available for download, offering users a convenient and personalized travel experience.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Vibrant seeks noteholder approval for waiver of notes' terms
summary: Vibrant Group, a Singaporean logistics provider, is seeking noteholders' approval to waive certain obligations for its S$66 million series of 7.50% notes due 2020. The waiver would allow the company to sell shares in Sabana Investment Partners for cash to redeem the notes. This comes after accounting irregularities at its coal production subsidiary Blackgold International Holdings led to litigation with Chinese banks. Vibrant has called a bondholders' meeting on Oct 26 to vote on the proposal, with eligible bondholders eligible for a 0.25-0.35% consent fee.

site_title: Exploring the controversial effects of the Japanese Occupation on localities
summary: The Japanese Occupation in Asia from 1895 to 1945 had a profound impact on the region. The Sook Ching massacre in Singapore, where thousands were executed, is one of the many atrocities committed by the Japanese secret police. Historian Prasenjit K Basu's book, Asia Reborn, defends Japan's imperial record, arguing that Japanese rule led to rapid industrialization and economic growth in its territories. Basu credits Japan's centralized bureaucratic practices and investment in health and education for Taiwan's success. However, critics argue that Basu glosses over Japan's atrocities and ignores the role of institutions in the former colonies.

site_title: IT infrastructure is key to successful adoption of AI
summary: A study by Seagate found that one in five IT decision-makers in the Asia-Pacific region are not prepared to handle the growing volume and velocity of data required for Artificial Intelligence (AI) adoption. The study revealed that 95% of respondents require more robust data storage solutions to support AI applications. A clear strategy and a sufficiently robust IT infrastructure are key to successful AI implementation, with data centers playing a critical role in storing and processing massive amounts of data.

site_title: Maybank to ring-fence Singapore retail, SME and commercial banking businesses
summary: Maybank has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to locally incorporate its community financial services business in Singapore. The move, part of a ring-fencing strategy, will transfer the retail, SME, and commercial banking businesses to Maybank Singapore Limited (MSL) on November 5, 2018. The bank aims to deepen its commitment to customers and communities in Singapore as part of its growth strategy. Maybank has operated in Singapore since 1960, with retail customers banking through 27 service locations, including 20 retail branches.

site_title: Macron pushes on with with business-friendly moves as popularity dips
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron continues to push for business-friendly reforms, despite a decline in popularity. Macron's economic measures, including a revamped labor code and budget cuts, aim to stimulate growth but have alienated many working-class voters. Consumer confidence has fallen, and unemployment remains above 9%. Macron's government is trying to shore up support with tax breaks for the working class, but critics argue the policies favor big business. Macron remains committed to his vision of a "new French prosperity," but his approval ratings continue to slide.

site_title: The comeback kid
summary: Sushi chef Kenjiro "Hatch" Hashida has returned to Singapore with his new venture, Hashida Sushi, in Mohamed Sultan Road. The restaurant, inspired by an old sake brewery, features a main sushi counter, Japanese bar, and private rooms. Hashida's comeback was not planned, but was encouraged by friends and team members who asked him to re-open. He is currently overseeing the San Francisco restaurant, which is set to open in July 2019, and his father's Tokyo restaurant, which is expected to open in July 2019 as well. Hashida aims to bring back the passion and creativity that defined his early days in Singapore.

site_title: World Bank trims East Asia's 2019 GDP forecast on trade frictions
summary: The World Bank has lowered its 2019 GDP forecast for East Asia and the Pacific to 6% due to trade tensions and volatile capital flows. This is slower than the 6.1% estimate in April and reflects a slowdown in China, which is expected to slow to 6.5% this year and 6.2% next year. The region's developing economies are advised to use available macroeconomic policies to cushion external shocks, according to the World Bank's chief economist. The 2019 forecast also marks a slight decrease from the 6.3% estimate for this year.

site_title: New BMW X5 review: An SUV with more X factor
summary: BMW's new X5 SUV boasts luxurious features, rivaling its flagship 7 Series. The fourth-generation X5 arrives in Singapore early 2019 with a starting price of S$350,000. It features the latest iDrive 7.0 infotainment system, adaptive air suspension, and a 3.0-litre six-cylinder engine producing 340hp. The X5 also offers advanced safety features, including a parking system, massage function, and lane-keeping assistance. With its refined interior and refined performance, the X5 is poised to be a top contender in the luxury SUV market.

site_title: Digital technologies finally making possible financial inclusion in India
summary: India has made significant strides in financial inclusion thanks to digital technologies, specifically the "JAM" trinity of Jan Dhan Yojna (no-frills bank accounts), Aadhar (biometric ID system), and mobile phones. Since its launch in 2014, the Jan Dhan Yojna has led to a surge in bank account openings, with millions of people accessing government subsidies and entitlement payments. Aadhar has empowered poor people with easy identity verification, while mobile penetration has enabled online payments through the United Payment Interface (UPI). This has dramatically altered the banking experience for the poor, with services now accessible in remote villages and migrant labor can remit money more quickly and securely.

images.alt_text: An Indian visitor meeting a talking robot at a digital banking branch in New Delhi.

site_title: Amara to launch Newton boutique project at upwards of S$2,400 psf
summary: Amara Holdings will launch its 56-unit freehold development, 10 Evelyn, off Newton Road in Singapore at an estimated S$2,400 psf. The boutique project, set to be completed in early 2020, will feature one-bedroom and two-bedroom units, as well as four three-bedroom penthouses. The development aims to cater to millennials seeking luxury living, with smart home features and "little touches" such as labelled switches in the kitchen. Previews start next weekend, marking the group's return to residential development after a hiatus.

site_title: Diversity quotas on corporate boards can work
summary: California Governor Jerry Brown signed a bill requiring companies with main executive offices in the state to have at least one woman on their boards by the end of 2019, and two or three women directors by 2021. This quota aims to increase the already low 20% representation of women on corporate boards nationwide. Other countries with similar quotas have seen improvements in diversity, and the US could learn from their examples, rather than focusing on voluntary efforts that have been ineffective.

site_title: HDB resale prices drop 0.7% in Sept; volume falls 3.9%
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dropped 0.7% in September from August and 2.1% compared to a year ago, according to SRX Property. This is the second consecutive month of decline. The drop in volume was 3.9% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Leave passports out of ECB race
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to undergo two significant changes in the next year, with Daniele Nouy stepping down as head of the supervisory board and Mario Draghi leaving his presidency. Three candidates have been shortlisted to replace Nouy: Andrea Enria, Sharon Donnery, and Robert Ophele. Meanwhile, contenders for the presidency include Jens Weidmann and Benoit Coeure, despite Germany's criticism of Draghi's radical measures. The ECB's suitability of candidates should be evaluated based on their ideas and qualifications, not their nationality.

site_title: StarHub cost-cutting brings out the bulls, but are dividends safe?
summary: StarHub's cost-cutting measures, driven by new CEO Peter Kaliaropoulos, have boosted shares by 4.28% to S$1.95. Analysts are divided on the impact of the plan, with some predicting a sharp cut in dividends to more sustainable levels. DBS analyst Sachin Mittal upgraded StarHub to a "buy" with a target price of S$2.45, citing potential earnings stabilization and growth from 2021. However, Nomura analysts remain cautious, citing concerns over revenue growth and competition pressure.

site_title: Irish data authority probes Facebook over breach
summary: Ireland's data protection authority has launched an investigation into Facebook over a security breach that exposed 50 million accounts. The breach, which occurred in September, exploited a vulnerability in Facebook's code, potentially allowing attackers to access people's accounts. The investigation will examine Facebook's compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and its obligation to implement technical and organisational security measures. Facebook faces a theoretical fine of up to 1.4 billion euros if it fails to adhere to GDPR rules.

site_title: Transition to cloud will improve govt service delivery
summary: Singapore's government plans to move its services and data to the cloud, despite initial concerns about security, and aims to attract top IT talent to create better services and technology. The move is expected to bring down costs and improve quality of services, but will require revamping existing IT infrastructure and creating a more startup-like culture within the public sector. The government will need to balance security with the benefits of cloud computing, and offer competitive incentives and work environment to attract the best talent.

site_title: IBF launches microsite to help finance professionals upgrade skills
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) launched a microsite called FutureMeNow to help finance professionals upgrade their skills, plan their careers, and mentor others. The microsite aims to encourage professionals to learn, discuss their career plans, and share their experiences. This initiative is part of the IBF's campaign to support the development of finance professionals in Singapore.

site_title: Brexit bill could go up as new data shows rise in EU budget liabilities
summary: Britain may need to pay more than initially estimated to fulfill EU budget liabilities due to rising pension costs and financial guarantees. The European Court of Auditors reported a 73.1 billion euro increase in EU pension liabilities in 2017. Britain has committed to paying 6.3 billion euros into the EU budget by 2020, but has only disbursed 1 billion euros so far. The total Brexit bill is estimated to be £39 billion, but the final figure could be higher due to contingent liabilities and outstanding commitments.

site_title: Ahead of holidays, FedEx dangles bonuses to keep pilots from retiring
summary: FedEx is offering retirement-age pilots bonuses of up to $110,000 to keep them flying into next year, amid a global pilot shortage and peak holiday shipping season. The company aims to retain around 150-200 pilots this year, which is expected to strain its capacity and disrupt supply chains. FedEx has about 5,000 pilots on its payroll, and rival UPS is also facing similar challenges. The bonuses are part of a larger effort to manage the timing of retirements and maintain capacity during the holiday season, which is critical for the company's global supply chain operations.

site_title: The 5G frontier, in BT Weekend
summary: 5G mobile networks are expected to revolutionize virtual reality and autonomous vehicles, but experts say the actual implementation will be challenging due to various limiting factors. A separate article discusses the monetization of personal data and the role of advertising in the digital age. Meanwhile, the article also touches on other topics, including market analysis, managing one's manager, and the expansion of the 24/7 gym chain Anytime Fitness in Singapore.

site_title: Recommending directors have complied with all requirements
summary: The Recommending Directors of Wheelock Properties Limited have responded to an article criticizing their independence, stating that they have complied with the Singapore Code on Takeovers and Mergers. The directors argue that their acceptance of the offer, as disclosed in the offeree circular, is consistent with the Code and their intentions. They claim that any insinuation of their lack of independence is unfounded and without proper basis. The directors assert that they have acted in accordance with the requirements of the Code and relevant legislation.

site_title: Wilmar unit leads US$50m funding in pharma firm Accera
summary: Wilmar International's unit, Wilmar Ventures, led a US$50 million investment round in brain health-focused pharmaceutical firm Accera (now Cerecin), with non-dilutive grants also included. The funds will be used for global drug development and the Asia-Pacific launch of Axona, a treatment for Alzheimer's disease. Cerecin will relocate its global headquarters from the US to Singapore, citing the country's infrastructure, science, and workforce. This investment is seen as a strategic opportunity for Wilmar, with potential synergies in manufacturing, R&D, and commercialization.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Maybank gets regulatory nod to locally incorporate retail business and SME banking in Singapore
summary: Maybank has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to locally incorporate its community financial services business in Singapore. The business, which includes retail, private wealth, SME banking, and commercial banking, will be transferred to Maybank Singapore Limited (MSL) via a scheme of transfer on November 5, 2018. The local incorporation signifies Maybank's commitment to its customers and communities in Singapore, and is part of its strategy to accelerate growth and business presence in the country.

site_title: Mercedes E 350 e review: A plug-in hybrid star
summary: The Mercedes-Benz E 350 e, the brand's first Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicle, is a low-profile, eco-friendly option that can travel 33km on battery power with zero tailpipe emissions. This marks a significant step for the company in its sustainability efforts.

site_title: Cairnhill Mansions en bloc: It's a 'go'
summary: The S$362 million collective sale of Cairnhill Mansions in Singapore will proceed after a settlement. The penthouse owner who objected to the sale received an extra S$867,004.79, which will be equally borne by the other unit owners. The High Court ordered the settlement, allowing the sale to proceed.

site_title: Best Foot Forward
summary: Kinky Boots, a Tony Award-winning musical, is set to run at Marina Bay Sands' Sands Theatre from October 5 to 14. The show is based on a true story about a man reviving his family's shoe business with the help of a drag queen. The musical features music and lyrics by Cyndi Lauper and a script by Harvey Fierstein, with direction and choreography by Jerry Mitchell.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Kinky Boots.

site_title: Stately Palace
summary: The Istana, Singapore's official residence, was built in 1869 on 43 hectares of prime Orchard property. Constructed by convict labourers, it was the first Government House and housed 21 governors during colonial rule. The building has undergone 21 terms of governorship, two terms of Yang di-Pertuan Negara occupation, and six terms of presidential occupation. Although it is the President's residence, no presidents or ministers have lived there since the third president, Devan Nair. The Istana is open to visitors on public holidays, offering a glimpse into Singapore's history and colonial past.

site_title: HK banks, developers offer sweeteners after rate increase
summary: Hong Kong banks and developers are offering cash rebates and discounts to attract homebuyers amid a cooling housing market. BOC Hong Kong and CMB Wing Lung Bank are offering up to 2% loan rebates, while Citigroup lowered its mortgage rate cap by 10 basis points. Developers such as Lai Sun Development and Vanke Property are also providing perks, including price cuts and furniture vouchers. The moves come after lenders raised mortgage rates for the first time in over 12 years, and ahead of a vacancy tax that will penalize firms for holding onto empty apartments.

site_title: US steelworkers wonder where the windfall will land
summary: US steelworkers are uncertain about the long-term benefits of President Trump's tariffs, which have led to a surge in domestic steel production and profits. Despite initial excitement and anticipation, many workers now question whether the tariffs will translate into higher wages and better benefits. The industry's renewal is being tested as labor contracts governing 31,000 steelworkers at US Steel and ArcelorMittal expired, with workers voting to authorize a strike due to the lack of progress in negotiations. Analysts warn that the tariff boon may not last forever, and the industry's long-term trends may affect steelworkers' livelihoods.

site_title: A Meta of taste
summary: Meta, a restaurant in Singapore, has revamped its menu to feature a mix of international flavors, including French and Indian cuisine. The chef's nationality is not a determining factor in the quality of the food, according to the article. The restaurant, located on Keong Saik Road, offers dinner and lunch options, with varying hours of operation. Meta aims to push the boundaries of its culinary offerings, showcasing the versatility of its chef's skills.

images.alt_text: Grilled squid, springy yet tender, on a bed of sunchoke purée darkened with squid ink and draped with leaves of raw kangkong.
Dark chocolate ice cream with pistachio sponge, crispy tuiles and gochujang jam.
Aged pigeon, grilled and glazed with a shiny reduction, whipped carrot purée and confit baby carrot.

site_title: Italy bond turmoil far from over: HSBC
summary: HSBC predicts Italy's bond turmoil will worsen before improving, with a forecasted yield spread of 300 basis points by year-end, up from 230 basis points previously predicted. The yield spread is expected to shrink to 200 basis points by 2019 if Italy's sovereign debt remains undervalued. The European Union commission is likely to reject the government's budget proposal, with Moody's Investors Service downgrading the debt by one level in October, according to BNP Paribas economists.

site_title: Elevating the Cantonese table
summary: Shang Palace, a renowned Cantonese fine dining restaurant in Singapore, has launched "The Chef's Table," a monthly dinner event featuring six-course meals crafted by Executive Chinese Chef Mok Kit Keung. The menu showcases seasonal produce, premium ingredients, and traditional Cantonese flavors, with dishes such as barbecued pork belly, Teochew marinated foie gras, and sautéed Boston lobster. The event, held in the restaurant's private dining room, also features personal stories and inspirations behind the cooking. Tickets are available for S$150++ per person, with limited seats available.

images.alt_text: Sauteed Boston Lobster with two kinds of rice vermicelli.
Deep-fried Soon Hock in two ways.
Braised Luffa and Scallop with Hairy Crab Roe and Sakura Ebi.

site_title: US dollar near six-week highs
summary: The US dollar reached a six-week high due to a surge in US Treasury yields, prompting investors to buy the greenback ahead of Friday's jobs data, which may show a robust US economy. The Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing activity index jumped to 61.6, the highest reading since 1997, and private payrolls rose by 230,000 jobs in September, the largest gain since February.

site_title: A day of giving by children, for children
summary: A charity event called Children for Children raised over S$300,000 for the Business Times Budding Artists Fund, supporting financially disadvantaged children and youth in arts training and performing opportunities. 1,000 children attended a day of activities, including a live musical performance and excursion to The Maritime Experiential Museum and S.E.A Aquarium. The event marked the 10th year of the initiative, which has brought over 10,000 children under the Ministry of Education's financial assistance scheme since 2008.

site_title: Asian markets falter on greenback, bond rally
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, with Hong Kong losing 1.73% and Tokyo falling 0.56%. Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1.1%, led by a fall in three local banks, amid concerns over the strengthening US dollar and higher Treasury yields. DBS Group Holdings was one of the few winners, with analysts predicting a widening net interest margin, while others, such as CapitaLand and real estate agencies APAC Realty, fell. Despite this, analysts expect loan growth to remain unaffected by higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Code Appeal
summary: Chanel has unveiled its latest Code Coco watch, a stainless steel timepiece with a steel and black ceramic case and bracelet, paying homage to the brand's iconic 2.55 bag. The watch features a lacquer dial with a princess-cut diamond and is water-resistant to 30 meters.
