The Code Coco name refers to the codes deciphered before the timepiece is fully appreciated, a theme common in Chanel's luxury label. The watch joins Chanel's growing list of watch collections, including J12, Boy Friend, and Monsieur, and marks the brand's continued expansion in the watch business.

site_title: Rosmah charged with money laundering
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's wife, Rosmah Mansor, has been charged with 17 money laundering offenses, pleading not guilty to the charges. The charges relate to about RM7.1 million (S$2.4 million) from unlawful activities, and failing to declare the amount for tax purposes. Rosmah was granted a bail of RM2 million. The charges come as part of a wide-ranging graft probe launched after Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's election victory, which has implicated Najib in billions of dollars missing from state coffers.

site_title: Big-ticket property deals fall 42% in Q3 after cooling measures
summary: Singapore's big-ticket property transactions fell 42% to S$6.5 billion in Q3, mainly due to cooling measures that halted the residential collective sales market. However, commercial and industrial property segments saw a pick-up, with office sales rising 54% and industrial property sales increasing 73% quarter-over-quarter. The property consultancy Cushman & Wakefield attributes the decline to the new stamp duty rates and increased penalties for developers failing to sell out projects within five years.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Carmakers throwing money at the future of driving
summary: Carmakers are investing heavily in the future of driving, with Honda Motor Co announcing a $2.75 billion investment in General Motors' self-driving subsidiary Cruise, valuing it at nearly $15 billion. SoftBank Group Corp also made a $2.25 billion investment, and Toyota Motor Corp and SoftBank unveiled a joint venture, MONET Technologies Corp, to develop mobility offerings including ride-hailing and autonomous driving. These investments aim to address the global race towards autonomy, but it remains to be seen if Japan's carmakers can successfully develop and implement these technologies.

site_title: Singapore companies on a global acquisition spree amid trade tensions
summary: Singapore companies are on a global acquisition spree amid escalating trade tensions, with total overseas deals reaching $91 billion through September, more than double the $41.9 billion in 2017. Companies such as SPH, CapitaLand, and Singapore Technologies Engineering are making big-ticket acquisitions, with a focus on China and the US. The trend is driven by a desire to adopt a more aggressive stance and achieve organic growth in a relatively small market, with companies looking to acquire new technologies and sources of growth.

site_title: Screen Debut
summary: Renowned Singapore lensman John Clang's debut feature film, Their Remaining Journey, premiered at the International Film Festival Rotterdam, earning a Bright Future Award nomination. The film interweaves three stories of individuals struggling with life transitions. Clang's unerring eye for line and composition creates a stark and intimate portrait. The film will play at the National Gallery Singapore's Ngee Ann Kongsi Auditorium on October 5 and 13.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Traders eye US$100 oil as Iran sanctions loom
summary: US crude oil prices are expected to surge to $100 a barrel by next year due to looming US sanctions on Iran and transportation bottlenecks. Despite record US production growth and flat global demand, hedge funds and speculators are betting on a market rally. Open positions on US$100 December 2019 WTI call options have risen by 30% in the last week, with estimates suggesting 500,000-2 million barrels per day of Iranian exports could be affected by sanctions. Opec and Russia are expected to make up supply shortfalls, but price risks are tilted to the upside, with some analysts predicting a spike in oil prices to $100 a barrel.

site_title: Bichup Line - Healing from Within
summary: The History of Whoo celebrates its 10th anniversary of the Bichup Self-Generating Anti-Aging Ja Saeng Essence, a regenerative beauty elixir inspired by the Korean Empresses. The 2018 Special Edition features artisanal craftwork and contains the signature Gongjinbidan Complex, CHO JAHABIDAN, GYEONGOAKBIDAN, and CHEONGSIMBIDAN formulas to balance Qi, self-diagnose, and self-generate skin. The essence has received positive reviews from customers, including those with uneven skin tone, blemish marks, and mature skin concerns.

site_title: Future Reality
summary: The Red Dot Award: Design Concept has announced its winners, recognizing innovative ideas and designs in various categories. The Motoroid, an electric motorcycle with AI technology, won the Luminary top prize. Other winners include a table designed for cats, a cooktop that allows pots of any size, a charity-based wearable bracelet, and a pair of resistance training shoes. The awards celebrate designs in electric and autonomous driving cars, smart technologies, and robotics. A record 5,640 entries were received from 55 countries, with 265 concepts awarded the Red Dot and 40 more recognized as the Red Dot: Best of the Best.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.19 points to 1,790.11. Losers outnumbered gainers 528 to 317, and volume was 2 billion lots worth RM2.5 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Apple logo is seen on the Apple store at The Marche Saint Germain in Paris, France July 15, 2020.  REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo##########apple##########

site_title: Where is Hyflux now?
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment firm, is facing financial difficulties and a potential winding-up action. The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) has appealed to the company to provide a full and frank appraisal on October 8 of its reorganisation process and chances of securing funding to preserve its going concern status. SIAS believes Hyflux is worth saving due to its brand value, demand for its services, and the spillover effects of its collapse on employees, investors, and smaller businesses. The company's board is expected to focus on the sale of its main asset, Tuaspring plant, with maximum transparency and engagement with stakeholders crucial to alleviate anxiety and secure the highest possible price.

images.alt_text: Maximum transparency must be practised so as to provide stakeholders with comfort that the price discovery process for Tuaspring is rigorous and competitive.

site_title: No picnic for Country Garden as shares tumble despite buybacks
summary: Country Garden Holdings Co, China's largest developer by sales, has seen its shares tumble 46% from its January peak despite spending over $125 million on share buybacks. The company's earnings growth has slowed due to a Chinese real estate market crackdown and concerns over a sales slowdown. Analysts believe the stock's valuation is cheap, but delivery of sales remains uncertain, making buybacks ineffective in reversing the decline.

site_title: Tokyo stocks down on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Thursday, falling 0.56% to 23,975.62, amid profit-taking after reaching a 27-year high earlier in the week. The drop was also influenced by a decline in Hong Kong shares. The broader Topix index fell 0.09%.

site_title: More sporty Kias are on the way
summary: Kia has unveiled a GT-Line version of its popular Ceed hatchback, a rival to the Volkswagen Golf, at the Paris motor show. The GT-Line package adds sporty upgrades such as red brake calipers, larger wheels, and glossy black body parts. This is part of Kia's efforts to introduce more sporty models, following the success of its Stinger fastback. However, high-performance Kias are ruled out by the company, with a focus on improving driving dynamics through design and engineering. A GT-Line version of the Cerato is also planned for 2019, marking the beginning of Kia's expansion into sporty models.

site_title: Ascendas Reit completes £253.25m acquisition of 26 logistics properties in the UK
summary: Ascendas Reit has completed its £253.25 million acquisition of 26 logistics properties in the UK, with Ascendas Management (UK) Ltd serving as the asset manager for four years. The acquisition was funded by a combination of debt and equity, with professional fees totaling £4.23 million.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Singapore shares close down by 1.1% on Thursday; STI ends at 3,231.59
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% to 3,231.59, led by local lenders DBS Group Holdings and Singtel. The index drop was largely due to regional decline, with losers beating gainers 281 to 136. Other notable stocks include PSC, which saw a mandatory offer, and eSIM platform Airalo, which raised US$220 million in funding.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Applying for F&B licences to become simpler, faster, cheaper
summary: Singapore is simplifying the process of applying for food and beverage (F&B) licences, reducing the number of data fields from 845 to 200, and lowering licensing fees by more than S$500. The application process will now take 28 days, down from 42 days, and businesses will only need to upload supporting documents once. The changes are part of a review and streamlining effort by the Ministry of Trade and Industry to make the process simpler, faster, and cheaper for F&B businesses. The new system will be tested with the Restaurant Association of Singapore before being rolled out next year.

images.alt_text: Mr Chee said the government will be working with the Restaurant Association of Singapore to test and refine the new system.

site_title: Shamans broaden their services
summary: Shamans are increasingly being hired by spas to oversee 'healing' treatments, including 'soul cleansings', which are listed alongside massages and facials. In a hotel wellness spa, 20 people lay on the floor with crystals on their foreheads as a shaman, Deborah Hanekamp, performed a healing ritual. This trend is part of a growing demand for alternative therapies and spiritual experiences in the wellness industry.

images.alt_text: Deborah Hanekamp, the shaman-trained owner of Mama Medicine, performs what she calls a medicine reading for visitors to Washington's Eaton Workshop hotel.

site_title: Russia's latest billionaire minted on cheap booze
summary: Russian billionaire Sergei Studennikov, owner of discount liquor retailer Krasnoe & Beloe, has become the country's fastest-growing major retailer, with 6,700 outlets in 57 regions. His no-frills business model, focusing on cheap booze and minimal food items, has disrupted the market and turned him into a billionaire. With a sales jump of 50% in 2017 and 40% this year, Studennikov plans to continue expanding, aiming to challenge market leaders X5 and Magnit. His model is seen as a response to Russia's strict anti-alcohol laws, which have led to a decline in consumption.

site_title: Metro Holdings establishes S$1b multicurrency debt issuance programme
summary: Metro Holdings establishes a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, allowing for the issue of notes and perpetual securities for general corporate purposes, including financing investments and refinancing existing borrowings. DBS Bank has been appointed as the sole arranger and dealer of the programme. The net proceeds will be used for various corporate activities, with no specific allocation mentioned.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Pacific Star Development's liabilities rise S$S11.5m after audit of financial statements
summary: Pacific Star Development's total liabilities increased by S$11.5 million to S$146.2 million following an audit of its financial statements for 18 months ending June 30, 2018. The increase was mainly due to a S$10.7 million jump in other payables, with S$11.5 million related to a purchase consideration for a reverse takeover. The firm classified the consideration as equity previously, but it should have been recorded as a liability.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: US Fed rate hikes set to lift Asean banks, but are unlikely to cool regional property markets: DBS
summary: US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes are expected to benefit Asean banks, with minimal impact on loan growth, according to a DBS report. However, the analysts warn that Indonesian banks will face a hit to their bottom line due to slower deposit rate re-pricing. The impact of higher interest rates on property demand is also limited, with affordability and loan-to-value ratios being more pressing issues. The report notes that Malaysia's property sector faces structural problems, while Indonesia and the Philippines are expected to see strong demand from foreign investors.

site_title: Pharma firm Accera secures US$50m in funding led by Wilmar unit; global HQ moves to S'pore
summary: Pharmaceutical firm Accera (now Cerecin) secures US$50 million in funding led by Wilmar Ventures, a subsidiary of agribusiness group Wilmar International. The investment will be used for global drug development and the Asia-Pacific launch of Axona, a medical food for Alzheimer's disease management. Cerecin will also relocate its global headquarters from Colorado, USA to Singapore, where it will establish its global clinical operations, manufacturing, and commercial teams.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Want to prosper in the digital age? Move to Singapore
summary: Senior vice-president Hildegard Wortmann of BMW Group says Singapore is the ideal location for companies to prosper in the digital age. She notes that half of the world's population under 30 lives in Asia, and expects them to drive consumer trends. Companies must deliver fast, top-notch service and keep up with the latest technology. Wortmann praises Singapore's digital society, where everything is mobile-first, and highlights the importance of understanding local market needs. She advises multinational companies not to underestimate the scale of the Asian market, saying it is the centre of Asia and drives future technologies.

site_title: What keeps Fed chief Powell up at night? Everything
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell admitted that a multitude of economic concerns keep him awake at night, including the potential rise of inflation, interest rates, and economic risks. Despite being optimistic about the US economy's future, Powell stated that "basically, everything" weighs on his mind. His concerns come as global economic indicators, such as China's slowing GDP growth and the UK's shrinking economy, raise pressure on policymakers to make informed decisions.

site_title: Oil price rally could be fiscal threat for Indonesia: Citi analysts
summary: Indonesia is vulnerable to fiscal risks due to a recent surge in oil prices, according to Citi analysts. The analysts estimate that oil-led direct subsidy cost over-runs in Indonesia's budget stand at 0.7% of GDP. This may have concealed the impact of inflation in the country, similar to Malaysia. The report warns that the oil price rally could pose a threat to Indonesia's fiscal stability, particularly given the country's dependence on fuel subsidies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dropped 0.7% in September from August, and by 2.1% compared to a year ago. Meanwhile, global news highlights Vietnam's surprise over Trump's tariff announcement, Malaysia's plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth expected to slow. The Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs, while Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. In politics, Thailand's Thaksin is confident his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case will be cleared.

site_title: Australian shares up as financials staunch losses; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by strong gains in the material sector, as financials snapped a three-day losing streak following a Royal Commission inquiry's interim report. The S&P/ASX 200 index advanced to 6,176.3, with material stocks up 1.2% and financials up 0.8%. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4%, with a2 Milk Company and Auckland International Airport falling 3.4% and 1.9%, respectively.

site_title: China slams "irresponsible" United States over shelved security talks
summary: China criticized the US for suggesting it was behind the cancellation of planned security talks, calling the accusations "irresponsible" and "extremely distorted." China had postponed the talks at Washington's request, citing tensions in relations. The US-China Diplomatic and Security Dialogue was set to be held with US Secretary of Defence Jim Mattis and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. The cancellation highlights the escalating trade tensions between the world's two largest economies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall most in 2 months as US Treasury yields soar; won falls nearly 1%
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 1.52% on Thursday, its largest decline in two months, as US Treasury yields hit multi-year highs and the Korean won lost nearly 1% against the US dollar. The decline was exacerbated by escalating China-US trade tensions and a report that China stopped US crude oil shipments. The won's value is now at its weakest in over two weeks.

site_title: Hot stock: Shares in StarHub up 4.8% as telco cuts 300 jobs
summary: StarHub shares rose 4.8% to S$1.92 after the telco confirmed it was cutting 300 jobs, or over 10% of its staff, to reap S$210 million in cost-savings over three years. Analysts upgraded their target prices, with DBS Group Research predicting earnings may stabilise and resume growth from 2021, while OCBC Investment Research maintained a "hold" rating. The move comes as Australia's TPG Telecom is poised to enter the market as the fourth telco operator in Singapore, intensifying competition in the industry.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore plans to tighten controls in maritime fuel industry
summary: Singapore plans to implement stricter controls on the maritime fuel industry, extending the use of mass flow meters to fuel transfers from oil terminals to bunker barges. The move aims to boost transparency and accountability in the sector, following recent scandals and contaminated fuel incidents. The proposed measures, set to take effect July 1, 2019, will ensure fair trade and prevent fuel theft, with the goal of enhancing transparency and accountability in the bunkering ecosystem.

site_title: Bank of America Merrill Lynch cuts Singapore, Malaysia GDP forecasts for 2019 on trade war concerns
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has cut its economic forecasts for Singapore and Malaysia in 2019 due to escalating trade tensions between the US and China. The analysts cited lower exports to China and prevailing caution as key factors. Singapore's GDP forecast was trimmed to 2.8%, while Malaysia's was reduced to 4.5%. The downgrade was attributed to the region's reliance on Chinese final demand and the potential for disrupted trade channels. The analysts also noted that the US growth could offset some of the adverse effects, but domestic headwinds would compound external risks.

site_title: HDB resale prices drop 0.7% in September from August; volume falls 3.9%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices dropped 0.7% in September from August, with a 2.1% decline compared to the same period last year, according to SRX Property. The number of flats sold also fell 3.9% from August. Prices for four-room flats increased 0.6% while those for three-roomers, five-roomers, and executives decreased by 1.3%, 1.3%, and 1.9% respectively. The median transaction-over-x-value (TOX) was negative, indicating buyers may be underpaying.

site_title: Peru annuls ex-president Fujimori's pardon, orders arrest
summary: Peru's Supreme Court annulled ex-president Alberto Fujimori's pardon for crimes against humanity, ordering his immediate arrest at 80 years old. The pardon, granted by then-president Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, was seen as a quid-pro-quo for Kuczynski's son's role in avoiding impeachment. Fujimori was pardoned on humanitarian grounds due to his ill-health, but critics argued the move was unjust and inhumane. The decision comes after Fujimori's lawyer said it is subject to appeal, and the ex-president was hospitalized after his arrest.

site_title: 'Holy Grail' of whisky sold for US$1.1m
summary: A rare 750ml bottle of single-malt whisky, referred to as "the Holy Grail" of whisky, was sold for a record-breaking $1.1 million in London. The sale price surpasses the price of a 16th-century castle in Scotland, which was sold for over $1 million. The exact details of the sale are not specified, but the whisky's rarity and value make it a significant and highly sought-after item in the world of whisky connoisseurs.

site_title: CapitaLand joint venture acquires Collective Works' co-working business
summary: CapitaLand has acquired Collective Works' co-working business through a joint venture, The Work Project Kingdom, for an undisclosed amount. Collective Works, founded in 2012, operates two locations in Singapore. The acquisition is part of CapitaLand's expansion into the premium co-working space market. Jonathan O'Byrne, founder of Collective Works, will continue to manage the business for a six-month transition period. The deal marks CapitaLand's investment in the co-working platform and its enhanced network of amenities for members.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Pacific International Lines, IBM tie up for blockchain initiative
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) and IBM have partnered to create an electronic bill of lading, a digital document used in international shipping to reinforce contract sanctity. The electronic bill of lading aims to reduce paperwork and increase efficiency in the shipping industry. This initiative is part of PIL's blockchain efforts, which also focus on contract sanctity and digitalization. The partnership seeks to create a secure and transparent electronic bill of lading, benefiting the shipping industry and trade financing.

site_title: Asia: Most stock markets decline; Indonesia plunges to near 4-week low
summary: Southeast Asian stock markets declined on Thursday, with Indonesia's benchmark index plummeting 1.6% and Singapore's falling 1.2%. The decline followed positive US economic data, which raised expectations of a December interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Higher US yields are unfavorable for emerging markets, drawing away foreign funds and pressuring local currencies. The decline also weighed on real estate stocks, with Ayala Land and SM Prime Holdings losing 2.6% and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: Indonesia weighs tax cut for bond investors to prop up currency
summary: Indonesia is considering tax cuts for bond investors and extending tax breaks to exporters who park their dollar earnings in local banks to prop up the weakening rupiah. The proposals aim to attract more inflows and deepen domestic financial markets. The country has been hit hard by the emerging-market selloff, with the currency losing about 10% and foreign inflows into its bonds at a paltry $832 million. Officials are tweaking rules to grant exporters a tax break on foreign-exchange deposits beyond six months, and the government is also raising interest rates to reduce capital outflows.

site_title: Leave passports out of the ECB race
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to undergo two significant changes in the next year, with Daniele Nouy stepping down as head of the Supervisory Board and Mario Draghi leaving his presidency. Three candidates have been shortlisted to replace Nouy: Andrea Enria, Sharon Donnery, and Robert Ophele. In contrast, the ECB presidency race is less urgent, with contenders including Jens Weidmann and Benoit Coeure. The selection process highlights the importance of a candidate's ideas over their nationality, with Enria's support for a bad bank and Weidmann's opposition to the ECB's quantitative easing policies drawing attention.

site_title: Advent Access secures global manufacturing, commercialisation rights to Vwing vascular needle guide
summary: Advent Access, a Singapore medtech startup, has acquired global manufacturing and commercialization rights to Vital Access's Vwing Vascular Needle Guide product line for an undisclosed cost. The deal aims to establish Advent as a leading vascular access solutions provider, targeting the US market, the world's largest for haemodialysis. This acquisition opens up new opportunities for Advent and expands its portfolio to address gaps in enabling haemodialysis in alternative care environments.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Nissan warns no-deal Brexit will damage British industry
summary: Japanese carmaker Nissan warns that a no-deal Brexit will have "serious implications" for British industry, citing potential port and motorway hold-ups that could slow component and finished model movement, crippling output and adding costs. The company urges Britain and the EU to reach a deal on their future trading relationship, expressing concerns over the impact on mutually beneficial trade. Nissan's statement comes as the UK is set to leave the EU on March 29, 2019.

site_title: Toyota, Softbank to announce partnership in self-driving, other technologies: source
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and SoftBank Group Corp are set to announce partnerships on automated driving and other technologies. The high-profile companies will develop self-driving vehicles and new mobility technologies, aiming to survive the shift to autonomous driving, ride-sharing, and electric vehicles. The partnership comes as cooperation between automakers and technology companies grows. Details of the announcement remain confidential, with the two companies scheduled to hold a joint news conference.

site_title: Gaylin gets shareholders' nod to acquire Amos
summary: Gaylin Holdings has received shareholders' approval to acquire Amos International Holdings for S$48.6 million in an all-shares deal. Amos will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Gaylin, expanding the company's marine transportation sector operations in Singapore, Shanghai, and Hong Kong. CEO Perry Kennedy stated that the merged entity will benefit from economies of scale, allowing for improved efficiency and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.23% in the opening minutes on Thursday, October 4, 2018, due to rising US Treasury yields and expectations of further Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index fell to 27,029.40. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,238.22, down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Thursday with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,238.22, down 0.9% from the previous day. Losers outnumbered gainers 244 to 114, with 904.7 million securities worth S$656.3 million changing hands. Despite the decline, the market maintained its 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with some stocks such as Rex International Holding and Thomson Medical Group experiencing gains.

site_title: Ayondo, Huanying International to cooperate on trading opportunities in China
summary: AYondo and Huanying International have established a collaboration through a white label agreement to grow trading opportunities in China. Ayondo will provide Huanying's clients with a full suite of products, including equities, indices, and forex, through its CFD TradeHub platform. The duo will also offer execution and risk management services. The collaboration is expected to expand Ayondo's presence in the Asian market, particularly in China, without affecting its financial performance.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Grab, Fave form strategic partnership to boost growth across Singapore and Malaysia
summary: Grab and Fave, a deals platform, have formed a strategic partnership to boost growth across Singapore and Malaysia. Fave will onboard merchants for GrabFood and GrabPay in the region starting this week. Later in October, Fave will integrate GrabPay into its platform, allowing customers to spend GrabPay credits at Fave merchants and on Fave deals. This partnership aims to accelerate growth across the Asean region.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree, StarHub, Datapulse, Vibrant Group
summary: Mapletree Investments acquired a 16.5 million square foot logistics portfolio for US$1.1 billion from Prologis, Inc. StarHub is cutting 300 full-time employees amid strategic transformation. Datapulse Technology entered into a non-binding letter of intent for the acquisition of a hotel in Seoul. Vibrant Group is seeking noteholders' approval to waive certain obligations for its S$66 million, 7.50% notes due 2020.

site_title: Logistics sector gearing up to accelerate technology adoption
summary: Singapore's logistics sector is accelerating technology adoption with a three-year plan. Developed by the Singapore Logistics Association, the industry-led roadmap aims to digitalize processes and facilitate collaboration among stakeholders, benefiting over 700 companies. The plan outlines platforms for innovative technologies, aiming to improve efficiency and competitiveness in the sector.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: PIL, IBM in blockchain trial to create electronic bill of lading
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) and IBM have partnered to conduct a blockchain trial to create an electronic bill of lading. The digital document aims to reduce fraud, loss, and handling costs associated with traditional paper-based bills of lading. The partnership seeks to improve supply chain management and provide a secure, efficient, and cost-effective alternative to traditional methods.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 1% to 3,233.58
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% to 3,233.58, with 75.8 million shares worth S$181.8 million changing hands. Local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS dropped 1.75%, 1.41%, and 1.35%, respectively. The decline was influenced by a weak yen in Tokyo, where stocks rose. US markets opened higher, with the Dow and S&P 500 reaching new records.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 1 per cent, or 33.82 points, to 3,233.58 as at 9.04am.

site_title: Barnes & Noble opts for strategic review after takeover interest
summary: Barnes & Noble Inc. announced a strategic review after receiving takeover interest from founder-chairman Leonard Riggio and investor Richard Schottenfeld. The company will explore options to thwart any hostile bid, including a plan to prevent parties from accumulating 20% or more of its shares. Shares rose 24% in extended trading. The review comes as the US book store chain struggles with declining sales due to online competition.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.80 points to 1,797.10 at 9am on Thursday, with gains outnumbering losses 118 to 46. The index saw a high volume of 45.82 million lots worth RM18.14 million.

site_title: New standards for ICOs needed
summary: Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs) have raised over $6.3 billion in the first quarter of 2018, with experts calling for new accounting standards to address the digital phenomenon. Current accounting approaches are inadequate, creating a risk of a bubble for companies issuing tokens. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) is testing the resilience of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) standards in the digital world. Publicly-listed companies in Singapore must disclose additional information to ensure transparency when using ICOs to raise funds. As the ICO market continues to evolve, experts predict greater clarity on token classification and treatment will emerge, creating new employment opportunities in auditing smart contracts.

site_title: Singapore companies are on a global acquisition spree, Bloomberg data show
summary: Singapore companies are on a global acquisition spree, with US$91 billion of overseas deals announced through September 2018, more than double the US$41.9 billion of transactions for the same period in 2017. Temasek Holdings and GIC are driving the trend, with Temasek investing in Bayer AG's Monsanto takeover and GIC acquiring a stake in Thomson Reuters Corp's financial unit. The surge in M&A activity is attributed to the escalating trade war between China and the US, as well as the need for Singapore companies to adopt a more aggressive stance to achieve growth in a slow-expanding economy.

site_title: US dollar rally moves to Asia after US data but stocks suffer
summary: The US dollar surged to an 11-month high against the yen following a strong private jobs report and a surge in Treasury yields, as the US economy continues to boom. This move came despite a sell-off in safe-haven Treasuries, a sign of confidence in the US economy. Asian equities, however, sank due to concerns over further Federal Reserve rate hikes. The dollar's rally also helped drive stocks to suffer, despite the Dow reaching a record close for the second day in a row.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen drops
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on October 4, 2018, with the Nikkei 225 rising 0.51% to 24,234.27, driven by a weak yen and a record close on Wall Street. The broader Topix also increased 0.81% to 1,817.25. This follows a rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Italy cuts deficit targets in concession after EU pressure
summary: Italy's populist government has revised its budget deficit targets, aiming for 2.1% in 2020 and 1.8% in 2021, following EU pressure and concerns over its high debt. The move is part of efforts to reassure investors and reduce its public debt, which is at 131% of GDP. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte's concession comes after Finance Minister Giovanni Tria stated the deficit would be squeezed after 2019. The revised targets aim to ease investor concerns and stabilize the Italian economy.

site_title: Irish data authority probes Facebook over breach of 50m accounts
summary: Ireland's data protection authority launched an investigation into Facebook over a security breach exposing 50 million accounts, amid strict European privacy laws. The breach, which occurred in September, was exploited by attackers who could have accessed people's accounts. The investigation will examine Facebook's compliance with GDPR, which allows for fines up to 4% of annual global turnover, potentially totaling $2.2 billion. Facebook claims it has adhered to breach notification rules, but EU officials say sanctions are unlikely to be the maximum.

site_title: Waiting out Trump era as America's global standing wanes
summary: The global image of the US has worsened for the second consecutive year under Donald Trump, with a median of 43% of respondents from 25 traditional American allies holding an unfavorable view of the US. This is according to a Pew Research Center survey of over 26,000 people between May and August. The decline in US global standing coincides with sustained poor ratings for the president.

site_title: Europe: FTSE rises; Tesco falls
summary: The FTSE 100 index rose 0.5% to 7,510.28 points, driven by easing concerns over Italy's budget targets. Tesco fell 8.6% after missing first-half profit forecasts, while other retailers, banks, and miners gained. Aston Martin fell 4.7% on its stock market debut, while ITV rose 3.7% after dismissing reports of a potential bid. The pound held steady despite Prime Minister Theresa May's appeal for party unity on Brexit.

site_title: Brent crude hits new four-year high on Iran supply worries
summary: Brent crude oil reached a four-year high due to concerns over US sanctions on Iran, set to take effect on November 4. Despite a large 8 million barrel increase in US crude inventories, the market rallied, with analysts citing the looming sanctions as the primary factor. Saudi Arabian and Russian production also rose, further contributing to the price increase. The market is expected to remain volatile until the sanctions take effect.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as financials and resources jump; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,184.3, driven by gains in financials, materials, and energy sectors. Aluminium prices surged to a three-month high after Norsk Hydro halted output, boosting stocks like South32 and BHP. Financials, led by Westpac Banking Corp, rose 1.1% after a Federal Reserve rate hike in December was seen as likely. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.3% for a fourth consecutive session.

images.alt_text: sclecorb15##########pic##########Arron Teo

site_title: Indonesia weighs tax cut for bond investors to help prop currency
summary: Indonesia is considering tax cuts for bond investors and exporters to boost its currency, which is weakening. The proposed measures include reducing the levy on sovereign bond gains and extending tax breaks to exporters who park dollar earnings in local banks for a longer period. The goal is to deepen domestic financial markets and attract more inflows, according to Robert Pakpahan, director general of taxes.

site_title: UK accuses Russian spies of global cyber attacks campaign
summary: British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt accused Russian military intelligence of conducting a global cyber attacks campaign targeting various institutions worldwide. The National Cyber Security Centre identified operatives from Russia's GRU arm behind high-profile computer attacks, including the 2017 "BadRabbit" ransomware targeting a Ukrainian international airport and Russian media outlets. The UK claims the attacks are "indiscriminate and reckless" and linked to Moscow.

site_title: Turning an old Manhattan freight terminal into a sleek office tower
summary: Oxford Properties Group is investing approximately US$2 billion to transform a 120,773 sq m freight terminal in Manhattan's Hudson Square into a 12-storey office building, dubbed St John's Terminal. The project, set to be completed by 2022, aims to create a modern workplace with open spaces, natural light, and stunning views of Hudson River Park. The building will retain its historical facade and feature a greenscaped rooftop and wraparound terrace. The development is part of Oxford's US$10 billion portfolio and is expected to attract large tenants in sectors such as technology and financial services.

site_title: Vibrant dangles 25-to-35 bps fee for waivers on S$66m of 7.5% bonds due 2020
summary: Vibrant Group, a logistics provider, is seeking noteholders' approval to waive certain obligations for its S$66 million 7.5% bonds due 2020. The company, facing accounting irregularities at its coal production subsidiary, is requesting waivers of terms related to the "Blackgold Events" and a mandatory redemption provision. If approved, the waivers will allow the company to sell its shares in Sabana Investment Partners and use the proceeds to redeem the notes. The proposal requires a bondholders' meeting on Oct 26, 2018, with an early-consent deadline of Oct 17.

site_title: CapitaLand secures S$300m sustainability-linked loan from DBS
summary: CapitaLand secured a S$300 million, five-year sustainability-linked loan from DBS Bank, the first and largest in Asia's real estate sector. The loan is linked to the developer's ESG efforts, with interest rates to be reduced on a tiered basis if performance targets are met. The funds can be used for general corporate purposes, unlike traditional green loans. This move is seen as a significant step towards sustainability in the region's real estate sector.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: DC Council votes to restrict Airbnb in Washington
summary: The DC Council voted unanimously to restrict Airbnb in Washington, making the city one of the most tightly regulated in the US. The legislation aims to regulate thousands of property owners and visitors who rely on homesharing services. The restrictions are a victory for the hotel industry, community groups, and other critics of Airbnb. The measure is expected to impact the city's lodging market and could pave the way for further regulations.

site_title: Boards face major shifts with new governance code
summary: Singapore's 700+ listed companies must comply with a new governance code by 2022, requiring independent directors to comprise a majority of the board. The code change, which takes effect in January 2022, will impact 516 companies, with 174 already compliant and 342 needing to restructure their boards. The report also highlights a growing number of independent directors, but notes challenges in gender diversity and low disclosure of directors' remuneration. The changes aim to enhance board effectiveness and promote constructive discussions among directors and shareholders.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Manhattan home sales tumble in a market clogged with listings
summary: Manhattan home sales declined 11% in the three months leading up to September, with 2,987 purchases, the fourth consecutive quarter of decline. Listings increased 13% to 6,925 homes, the most since 2011. Buyers are pushing for bargains, refusing to overpay due to market concerns and federal tax changes. The median price of completed purchases dropped 4.5% to $1.12 million, with buyers paying less than the asking price in 54% of sales.

site_title: Spain court confirms 4.5-year jail term for ex-IMF chief Rato
summary: Spain's Supreme Court confirmed a 4.5-year jail term for former IMF chief Rodrigo Rato for misusing €12 million in personal expenses while heading Caja Madrid and Bankia during Spain's economic crisis. Rato, 69, had been free on bail pending an appeal. The case, which involved 64 other executives, sparked outrage in Spain, where the banks were nationalized. One executive, Miguel Blesa, was sentenced to six years in jail and later found dead under mysterious circumstances. Rato's sentence is expected to be carried out soon.

site_title: Bottle of whisky sells for record US$1.1m
summary: A 60-year-old bottle of Macallan Valerio Adami 1926 single malt whisky, one of the rarest and most desirable bottles ever produced, sold for a record US$1.1 million at Bonhams auction house in Scotland. The bottle, with only 24 produced, features a label designed by pop artist Valerio Adami and is considered a "Holy Grail" of whisky. The buyer, from Asia, paid £700,000 plus a £148,000 sales premium. The sale marks the second time this year a bottle of whisky has fetched a record amount, with another bottle selling for HK$8.6 million in May.

site_title: Amazon wage hike aims to secure holiday help in tight job market
summary: Amazon has announced a $15-an-hour minimum wage for its workers, aiming to attract temporary warehouse staff amid a tight job market. The move is expected to pressure other retailers, including Walmart and Target, to raise their own wages. With the US unemployment rate at historic lows, Amazon's wage hike is seen as a competitive incentive to secure holiday help. The company plans to hire 100,000 temporary workers and is also advocating for a federal minimum wage increase.

site_title: Indonesia's pragmatic policies giving it resilience amid market turbulence
summary: Indonesia's pragmatic policies and favorable economic fundamentals have enabled the country to weather the turbulence in global financial markets. The government has implemented a comprehensive strategy to ensure economic resilience, including solid coordination between the government and central bank, measures to curb import growth, and efforts to boost tourism revenues. With a low government debt, contained current account deficit, and rising infrastructure investment, Indonesia is well-positioned to sustain economic growth at reasonably good levels despite potential global market challenges. The country's credible policies and favorable economic fundamentals are expected to help it prevail.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence - Singapore's new ride-hailing platform Tada
summary: Singapore's new ride-hailing platform Tada, founded by Kay Woo, has introduced a blockchain ecosystem to benefit drivers and passengers. The platform aims to provide a more secure and transparent ride-hailing experience. With Tada's blockchain technology, drivers can track their earnings and passengers can verify the authenticity of their ride. The platform is part of Singapore's growing transportation industry, which is expected to continue its growth in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Tada founder Kay Woo

site_title: US: Dow ends at second straight record after strong US data
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2% to a record 26,828.39, following strong US economic data on hiring and consumer sentiment. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also reached fresh records, with the Nasdaq advancing 0.3%. Strong private-sector hiring and a record services sector activity, as well as a positive outlook for holiday shopping, contributed to the surge. Despite concerns over a trade war, economists remain optimistic about the pace of economic activity.

site_title: Tech giants allied against proposed Australia law seeking access to private data
summary: Tech giants Facebook, Apple, Alphabet, and Amazon have joined forces to oppose an Australian law requiring access to private encrypted data linked to suspected illegal activities. The proposed law, which includes fines of up to $10 million and prison terms, aims to combat terror attacks. The four companies will lobby lawmakers to amend the bill ahead of a parliamentary vote. The Alliance for a Safe and Secure Internet says any attempt to weaken encryption poses a huge risk to digital security, as seen in the Five Eyes nations' efforts to demand access to encrypted emails and messages.

site_title: Rosmah arrested, to face charges on Thursday
summary: Malaysian former first lady Rosmah Mansor, 66, was arrested on Wednesday and will face money-laundering charges in court on Thursday. She was questioned for nearly 13 hours over state fund 1MDB, from which US authorities said over $4.5 billion was misappropriated. Rosmah's arrest follows her husband Najib Razak's election defeat in May, with authorities banning them from leaving the country and seizing $275 million worth of cash and goods.

site_title: COEs end mixed as demand for new cars continues to be dampened
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) ended mixed in the latest tender, with COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing slightly higher at S$28,457. Commercial vehicle COE rose to S$28,501, while motorcycle premiums fell to S$4,109. Despite the mixed results, motor traders expect no significant price deviation for the rest of the year due to the plentiful supply of used cars dampening demand.

images.alt_text: Certificates of entitlement (COE) ended mixed in the latest tender on Wednesday , as demand for new cars continued to be dampened by plentiful supply of used cars.

site_title: Aston Martin skids on market debut
summary: Aston Martin's shares fell as much as 6.5% on their London market debut, pricing at £19 each, amid concerns over its ability to deliver ambitious new model rollout plans. The luxury carmaker aims to launch a new model every year from 2016 to 2022 and has invested all its cashflow to achieve this. Despite a turnaround plan led by CEO Andy Palmer, investors raised concerns over execution risk, Brexit impact, and a lack of earnings track record.

images.alt_text: Aston Martin expects to produce around 7,100 to 7,300 cars in 2019, and 9,600 to 9,800 cars in 2020.

site_title: Swiber pursues equity deal with NY-listed Seaspan
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, is pursuing a US$200 million equity deal with NY-listed Seaspan Corp to rescue its power generation business. Seaspan will invest US$20 million for an 80% stake in Swiber and US$180 million for preference shares in a subsidiary. The deal is conditional on Swiber's successful restructuring of its billions of US dollars in debt. A meeting with creditors is expected, and the deal may only proceed with their backing.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ) shares were downgraded to "Hold" by OCBC Investment Research, citing diminishing upside potential after a 38% rise since their August 8 "Buy" call. The stock is trading close to the research firm's fair value estimate of S$1.32, and the upward momentum may continue in the near term.

site_title: Looming large: Shell's LNG Canada seen as tip of megaproject iceberg
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has approved a C$40 billion project to export liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Canada by 2025, with an initial production capacity of 14 million tonnes per year. This move is seen as a sign that the industry is regaining confidence and preparing to invest in new projects. Several other LNG projects are expected to follow, including those in the US, Africa, and Asia, which could help ease a supply shortage expected in the next decade. The projects are expected to boost global LNG supply, which is expected to jump to 360-450 million tonnes by 2023.

site_title: 60 migrants feared drowned in Guinea-Bissau capsize
summary: A small wooden boat carrying migrants capsized off Guinea-Bissau, leaving at least 60 people feared drowned. The pirogue, which was overloaded, sank on Monday night in the impoverished West African country with no patrol ships to assist. A local official reported that fishermen have been asked to search for bodies or survivors, but a rescue operation was hindered by a lack of fuel and financial resources. The incident occurred in a country plagued by a power struggle and poverty, with legislative elections scheduled for November.

site_title: End divisions or put Brexit at risk, Theresa May tells party
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged her Conservative Party to unite behind her Chequers plan for Brexit, warning critics that their arguments could put the UK's exit from the EU at risk. In a speech at her party's conference, May called on party members to put aside their differences and work towards a deal that delivers for Britain, amid growing pressure from eurosceptic lawmakers and critics. With just six months to go before the UK's Brexit deadline, May's speech aimed to reassure her party that she has a plan to deliver a good trading and security relationship with the EU.

site_title: Study finds more than 250 'selfie deaths' in the last six years
summary: A new study found that over 250 people have died taking selfies worldwide in the last six years. The leading causes of death were drowning, transportation incidents, and falling from heights. Researchers, including Dr. Agam Bansal, warn that the simple act of taking a selfie isn't deadly, but the risks associated with it can be. They urge people to be aware of the dangers and consider "no selfie zones" in areas prone to accidents. The study's findings highlight the need for prevention and awareness to reduce the number of selfie-related fatalities, particularly among young people.

site_title: Hilton plans to double hotels in Africa in next five years
summary: Hilton plans to double its hotels in Africa over the next five years by converting existing hotels into its brand. The company will mainly focus on deals with local hotels in countries such as Botswana and Rwanda. Hilton's CEO, Chris Nassetta, announced the plan at a hotel industry meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, citing strong demand for its brands across the continent. The company will introduce its upscale Curio Collection brand in Nigeria and expects to open eight hotels in Africa this year. This expansion is part of Hilton's $50 million Africa growth initiative launched last year.

site_title: Turkey inflation surges to nearly 25% in September, highest in 15 years
summary: Turkey's inflation surged to nearly 25% in September, the highest in 15 years, with prices jumping 6.3% from a month earlier. The lira has lost nearly 40% of its value this year due to concerns over President Erdogan's influence on the central bank and a rift with Washington. The central bank is expected to hike interest rates again to combat inflation, with economists warning that the economy and consumers are deeply impacted by the currency crisis.

site_title: Bay in The Beach shut indefinitely
summary: Thailand's Maya Bay, made famous by the movie "The Beach," has been closed indefinitely due to severe pollution and beach erosion caused by thousands of daily tourists. The bay, ringed by cliffs on Ko Phi Phi Ley island, was initially closed for four months but a survey revealed the damage was worse than thought. The National Parks office has announced that the restrictions on tourism will not be lifted until the ecosystem fully recovers, a process expected to take at least four years.

site_title: Apple guards data privacy even in China, says Tim Cook
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook stated that the company prioritizes data privacy, with encrypted data stored on servers even in China, where Chinese law requires it to be kept. Cook emphasized the importance of privacy, saying it is one of the most significant issues of this century. Despite this, Apple ensures that user data is protected, even when required by Chinese law to be stored locally.

site_title: Wave of worries takes shine off Paris Motor Show
summary: Industry executives at the Paris Motor Show are expressing concerns over Brexit, trade tensions, and the challenges posed by China and electric vehicles. Despite the show's focus on cutting-edge concept cars and self-driving technology, executives see numerous reasons for worry, including the impact of these global issues on the automotive industry.

images.alt_text: Faced with the reluctance of some industry giants to spend millions of euros on marketing, organisers have responded by cutting back the Paris Motor Show's length to 11 days from 16.

site_title: Deutsche Bank faces more senior departures in Japan
summary: Deutsche Bank faces another wave of senior departures in Japan, with top dealmaker Keisuke Sueyoshi and COO Bret Dandoy leaving the company. Sueyoshi, 46, will join a competitor, while Dandoy, 54, retired at the end of August. This follows the departure of Japan chairman Norimichi Kanari, country head Makoto Kuwahara, and local asset management chief Daisuke Toki. The exits come as CEO Christian Sewing seeks to restore profitability by cutting costs and focusing on the home market. The departures have further eroded Deutsche Bank's presence in Japan, ranking 12th among advisers on mergers and acquisitions this year.

site_title: Bowsprit deal benefits buyers more than seller
summary: Lippo Karawaci sold its stake in Bowsprit Capital and First Reit to OUE and OUE Lippo Healthcare (OUELH) for S$202 million, providing a liquidity boost but potentially harming Lippo's operating cash flows. Moody's downgraded Lippo's corporate family rating, citing weakening cash flows and foreign-denominated debt. The transaction benefits buyers, particularly OUE, which aims to grow its assets under management to over S$10 billion by 2019. OUELH will benefit from a vehicle to expand its healthcare assets in Japan, China, and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Quest to cut sulphur in bunker fuels estimated to cost CMA group US$1.5b
summary: The French shipping group CMA CGM is estimated to incur a cost of $1.5 billion in complying with the rule limiting sulphur content in bunker fuels to 0.5% from 2020. The company's Singapore-based subsidiary APL has already informed clients of potential rate hikes to prepare for the change.

site_title: Visitors flooding into Macau raise Golden Week hopes for casinos
summary: Macau's casinos experienced a boost in visitor numbers during Golden Week, with Chinese arrivals on Oct 1-2 jumping 27% from last year, according to the Macau Government Tourist Office. This marked the best two-day start to Golden Week in at least six years. The Bloomberg Intelligence gauge of Macau casino stocks rebounded 2.5% on Wednesday, providing hope for the industry's resiliency despite a slowdown in gaming revenue growth. Analysts expect Macau's gaming revenue for October to surpass 28 billion patacas for the first time since 2014.

site_title: City officials develop plan to keep Amsterdam homes affordable
summary: Amsterdam's left-leaning government has developed a plan to keep the city's homes affordable amidst rising house prices and investor interest. The plan includes adding 7,500 new homes per year through 2025, with 30% of new construction earmarked for social housing at affordable rents of €711 per month. This aims to address the shortage of middle-income housing and prevent the city from becoming unaffordable for locals. The city official, Laurens Ivens, believes the plan will maintain social cohesion and prevent a property bubble, but critics argue it will limit investor interest and drive up prices.

site_title: US dollar strengthens after Fed comments
summary: The US dollar strengthened against other major currencies on Wednesday after Federal Reserve policymaker Charles Evans expressed comfort with a potential December interest rate hike, citing the strong US economy and inflation rate. The euro, which had gained earlier, fell to a six-week low due to uncertainty surrounding Italy's debt and fiscal plans. The euro eventually regained some ground, but analysts remain skeptical about the single currency's prospects. The dollar edged 0.05% higher at 95.56 against its rivals.

site_title: AI could well devastate the developing world
summary: Emerging economies, particularly those following the China and India models, are vulnerable to devastating effects from artificial intelligence (AI) due to its ability to automate repetitive, non-social, and largely uncreative work. As AI accelerates automation, it will lead to job displacement, exacerbating poverty and inequality in developing countries. To mitigate this, emerging economies must shift focus towards education, unique human-centred service industries, and carving out their own niches within the AI landscape. Governments should invest in AI education, supporting local companies that employ AI, and collaborate with AI superpowers to share benefits and avoid a global burden.

site_title: Disruption, technology and opportunity
summary: Disruption and innovation are accelerating in the Asia-Pacific region, driven by technology. Industry 4.0 is transforming businesses with Artificial Intelligence, Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality, and 3D Printing. These technologies are enabling products to be created on-demand, personalized, and locally produced, without geographical constraints. As a result, companies are adopting new strategies and creating opportunities to disrupt incumbents, ultimately changing the way products are designed, manufactured, and delivered.

site_title: A$ delivers stimulus where the central bank fails to
summary: The Australian dollar is expected to fall further due to the RBA's cash rate being 75 basis points below the US Fed target, the widest gap in 35 years. The RBA has been reluctant to provide stimulus, but the declining Aussie dollar is seen as beneficial for economic growth, hiring, and wages. Economists predict the currency will fall from near 72 US cents to 68 cents by the middle of next year, equivalent to 25 basis points of loosening on the cash rate.

site_title: Global growth positive but under a bit of pressure: Jerome Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the global economic outlook remains positive, with some emerging markets experiencing instability, but slightly less positive than a few months ago. The US economy is expected to continue growing, despite a slight slowdown in advanced economies, with the Fed maintaining a reasonably positive picture. Powell downplayed concerns over rising asset prices, citing strong bank reserves and households' increased savings rate.

site_title: China tech, financials represent 'window of opportunity': DBS investment chief
summary: DBS Bank's chief investment officer Hou Wey Fook recommends re-engaging Asian equities, particularly financials and tech plays in China, due to emerging value and stimulus policies. DBS has upgraded Asia ex-Japan equities to "overweight" and is bullish on Hong Kong and China equities, citing near-lows in valuations and a relatively insulated domestic revenue generation. The bank also favors Chinese tech stocks due to the country's large smartphone user base and growing e-commerce market.

site_title: Asian patients finally have medicines designed for them
summary: Asian patients are finally receiving medicines tailored to their bodies and lifestyles, a departure from the traditional West-to-East approach in medical innovation. Companies like AstraZeneca and Roche are developing drugs targeting specific mutations and conditions common in Asian populations, such as lung cancer and breast cancer. This shift is driven by Asia's booming economies and rising healthcare spending, with total revenue predicted to jump 11% to $517 billion this year. The focus on precision medicine acknowledges diversity in disease treatment and ethnicity, aiming to provide effective treatments to patients where they are needed.

site_title: Serving up the First Bank of Starbucks with coffee
summary: Starbucks has partnered with Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) to launch Bakkt, a new financial system that will enable the use of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies for retail payments. The system aims to disrupt the traditional banking industry by providing a decentralized, peer-to-peer monetary system. Bakkt will allow consumers to buy and sell cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin futures contracts, and will be backed by Microsoft's cloud services. While the future of finance is uncertain, the partnership is expected to bring positive spillover effects, including lower fees and increased convenience for consumers, potentially leading to a shift away from traditional banking models.

site_title: Trade pact clause seen deterring China trade deal with Canada, Mexico
summary: US President Donald Trump's new trade agreement with Mexico and Canada includes a clause that allows either country to quit the agreement if they enter a free trade deal with a "non-market" country, such as China. This provision effectively vetoes any China trade deal by Canada or Mexico, potentially isolating Beijing in the global trading system. The clause has sparked controversy in Canada, with some lawmakers calling it "astonishing" and a "severe restriction on Canadian independence."

site_title: Shophouse at 21 Boon Tat Street fetches record price in District 1
summary: A 999-year leasehold shophouse at 21 Boon Tat Street in Singapore's Telok Ayer Conservation Area has been sold for S$16.5 million, or S$4,259 per square foot. This sets a new high for a conservation shophouse in District 1. The estimated built-up area is 3,874 sq ft.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US car sales slump but Fiat Chrysler surges
summary: US car sales declined 10% or more in September compared to the same period last year, with major auto makers including Ford, Toyota, and Nissan reporting declines. However, Fiat Chrysler's North American subsidiary FCA US saw a 15% sales growth, driven by refreshed Jeep SUV and Ram truck models. Analysts attribute the decline to higher gas prices, rising interest rates, and tariffs, with some predicting a slowing market and total industry sales below 17 million units by the end of 2018.

site_title: Home is where the holiday is
summary: A recent travel study by Expedia found that 6 in 10 Singaporeans have taken a staycation in the last 12 months, with 7 in 10 planning to do so in the next year. This trend is good news for local hotels, which already have high occupancy rates. Meanwhile, Italian restaurants in Singapore are struggling to break away from stereotypes, with chefs trying to balance traditional and modern flavors. Additionally, sushi chef 'Hatch' Hashida has re-opened a new restaurant in Singapore after breaking away from his original restaurant.

site_title: Turkey's Dogus Reit sets rates for foreign currency rent
summary: Turkey's Dogus Reit sets exchange rates for foreign currency rents at four commercial properties in October, following the government's ban on foreign currency rents. The rates are fixed at 5.90 euros to the lira and 4.9 dollars to the lira. The decision aims to address the negative effects of exchange rates on tenants with "narrowed business volumes." An announcement from the Treasury and Finance Ministry regarding exceptions to the new rent regulations is expected.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cityneon Holdings has appointed Mark Kemper as its new group chief corporate and financial officer, replacing Aw Hui Mien. Serial System has proposed a special dividend of one Singapore cent per share after selling its Australian laundry business for A$40.2 million. Heeton, KSH, and Lian Beng Group have acquired Hotel Indigo Glasgow in Scotland. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Japan to order Suruga Bank to halt new property loans after scandal: sources
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency will order Suruga Bank to halt new property loans following a lending scandal that found the bank falsified documents on loans to retail investors who built "share houses." The scandal led to the resignation of the bank's top executives and a surge in the bank's shares as some market participants expected lighter measures. The FSA determined that the improper lending was widespread and governance functions had failed, and the bank will need to improve its governance and stop extending new loans for property investment.

site_title: GE downgrade will lift its costs in a debt market it once ruled
summary: General Electric (GE) has lost its near-top credit ratings on its short-term debt, resulting in a downgrade from S&P Global Ratings to A-2. This downgrade is likely to force GE to pay more to borrow in the commercial paper market, a key funding source for the company. The downgrade adds pressure to GE, which is already facing sluggish demand for its gas turbines, flagging cash flow, and probes from the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

site_title: Trump's cyber security strategy is reckless
summary: The Trump administration's new National Cyber Strategy is criticized for being reckless and shift towards an offense-first approach, aiming to deter adversaries through pre-emptive cyber attacks. This strategy may lead to escalation of cyber conflicts, deterring deterrence and encouraging reckless actions. The plan to "defend forward" by launching cyber attacks before threats reach their targets and disrupting malicious activity at its source is seen as a sharp change from the cautious approach of the past decade. Experts warn that this approach may lead to more attacks, not deterring them, and could destabilize online infrastructure.

site_title: StarHub axing 10% of staff amid telco industry woes
summary: StarHub, Singapore's second-largest telco, is laying off about 10% of its staff, or around 300 full-time employees, due to industry pressures. The company will cut costs by S$25 million, but expects to save S$210 million over three years. StarHub will focus on investments in areas like cyber security, digital customer service, and enterprise solutions. The layoffs come as the telco industry faces challenges, including intense competition, new players, and high content costs.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore to embrace greener alternatives to LNG in marine-fuel mix
summary: Singapore is setting aside S$5 million to research and develop alternative marine fuels, including biofuels and methanol, to meet the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) goal of halving carbon emissions by 2050. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has already invested S$26 million in liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering, but recognizes the need for greener alternatives. The IMO's global sulphur cap will be implemented in 2020, and the MPA will publish a list of suppliers for low-sulphur marine fuels by mid-2020 to help the industry comply.

site_title: Malaysia nudges Islamic banks towards sustainable finance
summary: Malaysia's central bank has issued guidelines to encourage Islamic banks to adopt sustainable finance practices, aiming to boost growth rates and align with the sector's fundamental premise of sharia. The guidelines, which are not compulsory, encourage Islamic banks to engage in socially and environmentally-themed activities, such as microcredit and financing affordable housing projects. The move follows a debate over whether Islamic banks are fully aligned with religious teachings that shun gambling and speculation. Only nine out of 27 Islamic finance bodies in Malaysia have adopted the system, and the central bank seeks public feedback on related documents.

site_title: BreadTalk adds tea to growth brew; eyes deeper regional expansion
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singaporean bakery chain, plans to invest S$100 million to achieve its growth targets, including an 8% net margin by 2022. The company aims to deepen regional expansion and improve processes. CEO Henry Chu stated that the investment will be used to boost offerings and enhance operations. This move follows the company's consolidation strategy, as it continues to grow and meet its financial goals.

site_title: US: Dow opens at record high on boost from financials
summary: US stocks opened at a record high on Wednesday, driven by gains in financial stocks following a rebound in European markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 59.53 points, or 0.22%, to 26,833.47. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, reaching fresh records. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Nanshan family in S$40m GCB purchase
summary: The Song family, owners of Nanshan Group Singapore, are reportedly buying a freehold bungalow in the Camden Park Good Class Bungalow Area for S$40 million, with a price of S$1,373 per square foot on land.

images.alt_text: The Song family is expected to redevelop the property, which is on a 29,143 sq ft elevated freehold site.

site_title: Navigating South-east Asia's offshore market
summary: South-east Asia's offshore oil and gas market is experiencing a notable uptick in new project sanctioning after a three-year decline following the 2014 oil price fall. The region's gas demand, driven by China's pollution reduction goals, is fueling offshore production. Key projects, such as those in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, are expected to contribute 197,000 barrels of oil per day and 8,219 million cubic feet of gas per day to global production. However, complex commercial terms and a lack of significant improvement in the near term may hinder future activity, requiring a steady, robust rate of growth to thaw the industry's negative mindset.

site_title: Baker Hughes to bid for Petrobras production-sharing deal
summary: Baker Hughes is preparing to bid for a production-sharing deal with Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil company, to boost output from mature fields. The deal would allow Petrobras to partner with one of the world's largest oil service providers without losing control or risking capital. The tender includes a 15-year contract, and the winner would be responsible for investment and operation costs. This move aims to help Petrobras squeeze better returns from aging fields, focusing on developing the country's prolific pre-salt fields.

site_title: Logistics sector rolls out plan to accelerate technology adoption
summary: Singapore's logistics sector has unveiled a three-year plan to accelerate technology adoption, benefiting over 700 companies. The industry-led roadmap, developed by the Singapore Logistics Association, aims to digitalize processes and foster collaboration among stakeholders. The plan was announced at the Singapore Logistics Forum 2018 by Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon, marking a significant step forward for the country's logistics sector.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Tencent Music files for US IPO, H1 revenue surges
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment, the largest online music platform in China, has filed for a US IPO, seeking to raise $1 billion. The company, which owns popular music apps QQ Music, Kugou, and WeSing, reported a 92% revenue jump to $1.3 billion in the first half of 2018, with profits after tax climbing fourfold to $263 million. The IPO comes as the global music industry sees a resurgence in streaming, with Tencent Music boasting over 800 million monthly active users.

site_title: Asia markets mixed on EU-Italy spat
summary: Asian markets ended the day mixed on Wednesday due to a growing spat between Italy and the European Union, sparking fears of another eurozone crisis. Italy's budget plan drew criticism from Brussels, prompting Italian Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini to threaten to seek damages for scaring off investors. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) closed 24.75 points higher at 3,267.40, its highest level in over a month and a half, with gainers outnumbering losers 229 to 155.

site_title: Companies in US add most jobs in 7 months, ADP data shows
summary: US businesses added the most workers in seven months in September, with 271,000 jobs created, according to ADP data. This sign suggests hiring remains resilient despite a tight job market. Demand for workers was strongest in construction, administrative and support services, and health care and social assistance. The data points to the economic expansion continuing through year-end, with consumer spending expected to fuel growth. However, manufacturing jobs saw the smallest gain in over a year due to the intensifying trade war with China.

site_title: Japan's first inter-regional transfer of excess solar power
summary: Japan has successfully transferred excess solar power from the island of Kyushu to Honshu for the first time, marking a significant increase in flexibility in the country's electricity grid. The transfer, approved by the grid monitor OCCTO, was facilitated by Kyushu Electric Power and involved up to 1.125 gigawatts of renewable energy. This move signals the country's progress in opening up its power sector to competition, following the 2015 reforms aimed at boosting renewable energy supplies after the Fukushima disaster.

site_title: Singapore has worst cyber hygiene in the region: poll
summary: Singapore consumers have the worst cyber hygiene in the region, according to a VMware Inc survey. 45% of respondents in Singapore do not use secure measures to protect financial data, including using the same passwords across multiple services and apps. Only 14% of Singapore consumers use different passwords for all their accounts, making Singapore the country with the least cyber hygiene in the region, with a regional average of 24%.

site_title: Vietnam Communist Party general secretary nominated president
summary: Vietnam's Communist Party general secretary Nguyen Phu Trong was unanimously nominated as the country's president, marking his ascension to the most powerful position in the country. The nomination follows the death of President Tran Dai Quang last month. Trong, a 74-year-old conservative leader, will hold the top posts of president and party leader simultaneously, a role not seen since Ho Chi Minh in the 1960s. The National Assembly is expected to approve the nomination, solidifying Trong's position as the head of state and chief of the Communist Party.

site_title: Datapulse Technology to seek shareholders' approval to expand into hotel business
summary: Datapulse Technology has entered into a non-binding letter of intent to acquire a hotel in Seoul, South Korea, with the goal of expanding its business into the hotel industry. The company plans to seek shareholders' approval for this move and will focus on acquiring or investing in hotels or hospitality assets. Datapulse will not provide hotel management services itself, instead engaging third-party providers. The proposed acquisition is subject to due diligence and will be evaluated by the company's board.

site_title: Mapletree acquires Prologis logistics portfolio for US$1.1 billion
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired a 16.5 million square foot logistics portfolio from Prologis, Inc. for US$1.1 billion. The assets are located in key distribution centers in the US, France, Germany, and Poland. This acquisition aligns with Mapletree's strategy to expand globally and capitalize on the growing demand for modern logistics facilities and the e-commerce sector. The deal marks a significant move for Mapletree as an active capital manager, with plans to syndicate the assets to institutional and high net worth investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.85 points to 1,796.30. The index saw a trading volume of 2.3 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 472 to 336.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.8% to close at 3,267.4. About 1.55 billion shares changed hands, with SinoCloud Group being the most actively traded stock. Gainers outnumbered losers 229 to 155, and the average unit price was S$0.58 per share.

site_title: Rehn chimes in on ECB rate debate as officials map slow liftoff
summary: Finland's Olli Rehn, a potential ECB successor, emphasized the need for flexibility in communicating interest rate hikes, warning against detailing an exact path. Rehn prefers a data-dependent approach, stressing policy makers' ability to react to economic conditions. This echoes ECB officials Benoit Coeure and Peter Praet, who advocate for clearer communication on rate increases to avoid market volatility. The comments come as officials begin to map out the path of interest rates after liftoff, anticipated for after 2019.

site_title: Swiber seeks revival from US$200m equity deal with Seaspan
summary: Swiber Holdings has secured a US$200 million equity deal with Seaspan Corp, with Seaspan investing US$20 million in cash and US$180 million in new shares for an 80% stake in Swiber's subsidiary Equatoriale Energy Pte Ltd. The deal is conditional on Swiber restructuring its debts and meeting certain milestones for a US$1 billion liquefied natural gas-to-power project in Vietnam. The proposal involves converting debts into new shares and issuing redeemable convertible bonds for secured creditors.

site_title: Mapletree acquires logistics assets in the US, Europe
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired a 16.5 million sq ft logistics portfolio in the US and Europe for US$1.1 billion.
