The assets, located in key distribution hubs such as Chicago, Dallas, and Seattle, as well as France, Germany, and Poland, align with Mapletree's strategy to expand its global logistics presence. This acquisition aims to capitalize on the growing demand for modern logistics facilities and the thriving e-commerce sector globally.

site_title: Mark Kemper named as Cityneon's new group chief corporate and financial officer
summary: Cityneon Holdings has named Mark Kemper, 47, as its new group chief corporate and financial officer, replacing Aw Hui Mien who resigned to pursue other career opportunities. Kemper previously held roles at KPMG Netherlands and KPMG Hong Kong. The company has also partnered with Blizzard Entertainment for the Singapore stop of the Hearthstone Championship Tour. Cityneon shares fell 1.6% on the news.

site_title: Heeton, KSH, Lian Beng consortium acquires hotel in Glasgow
summary: Heeton Holdings, KSH Holdings, and Lian Beng Group have acquired Hotel Indigo Glasgow in Scotland for an undisclosed sum. The consortium, led by Heeton with a 60% effective interest, has joined forces to acquire the five-storey hotel with 94 rooms, which operates under a franchise agreement with InterContinental Hotels Group and will be managed by Interstate. This marks Heeton's second hospitality asset and the consortium's first in Scotland.

site_title: OCBC extends digital instant account opening service to SMEs from November
summary: OCBC Bank has announced that it will extend its digital instant account opening service to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) from November. The service, which currently takes one day to open a business account, will allow SME owners to instantly open accounts online through the bank's digital platform, leveraging Singapore's national data repository, MyInfo. This is part of OCBC's efforts to improve its service offerings, following similar initiatives by DBS and UOB, and is expected to benefit 70% of SMEs in Singapore with a one or two-man structure.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: First Nintendo built-from-scratch mobile game off to weak start
summary: Nintendo's first built-from-scratch mobile game, Dragalia Lost, has started weakly, generating US$3 million in revenue over its first five days in the US and Japan, less than its previous mobile titles. The game, featuring original characters, ranks 71st in revenue among iPhone apps in the US and 8th in Japan. This underwhelming start is disappointing to investors, who had expected a stronger showing after years of limited mobile gaming success. Nintendo shares remained unchanged in Tokyo trading.

site_title: SGX RegCo working with SIAS and SID to issue best practices guide at AGMs
summary: The Singapore Exchange RegCo, SIAS, and SID are collaborating to create a best practices guide for directors and investors at annual general meetings (AGMs). The guide aims to present a holistic view of each party's role and responsibilities, promoting constructive discussions and fruitful engagement. This effort comes after Stamford Land Corporation filed a defamation suit against a shareholder over comments made at the 2016 and 2018 AGMs. The guide will not be "one-sided" and aims to improve relationships between management and shareholders.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Is sleepy Thai town's MotoGP makeover preparing it for Formula Ones next?
summary: A sleepy Thai town, Buriram, is hosting its first MotoGP event, a milestone in its bid to become a global sports hub. The event, which starts with practice sessions on Friday and culminates on Sunday, represents a step into the international limelight for the rural town. With a population of 30,000, Buriram has invested heavily in sports infrastructure, including a certified F1 track, and is now eyeing Formula One as its next target. The event has generated significant interest, with tickets sold out, and the Thai government is optimistic about the economic benefits, with millions of dollars at stake.

site_title: Brexit risks take their toll on Britain's high-yield bond market
summary: UK companies with speculative-grade ratings are increasingly avoiding sterling bonds due to investor unease over Brexit, leading to a 60% drop in bond sales to £5.04 billion so far this year. The sterling high-yield bond market has lost 18% of its market value since January, with some issuers opting for euro-denominated bonds or leveraging loan markets instead. Investors are demanding higher yields and stronger creditor protection, making it a tougher market for borrowers with natural sterling needs.

site_title: Australian shares propped up by resource stocks; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,146.1, driven by gains in resource-related stocks, including BHP and Rio Tinto. Gold prices reached a one-week high, lifting mining stocks. Financials, however, fell for a third consecutive session, weighed by scathing interim findings from a Royal Commission inquiry and the departure of Freedom Insurance's CEO and CFO. New Zealand's benchmark index dropped 0.4% to 9,293.95.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end down on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.66% to 24,110.96, following a profit-taking session after reaching a 27-year high earlier in the week. The broader Topix index also fell 1.17%. The decline came as investors locked in profits after the recent surge.

site_title: UK services firms see steady growth, Brexit concerns weigh
summary: Britain's services sector maintained steady growth in September, with the IHS Markit/CIPS UK Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 53.9, slightly below August's 54.3. The economy is expected to have grown at a quarterly rate of 0.4% during the July-September period. Despite steady growth, Brexit uncertainty remains high, with business optimism anchored at levels that would normally indicate an imminent slowdown. Cost pressures are also intensifying due to rising oil prices, leading some to expect another interest rate hike from the Bank of England.

site_title: Deliveroo Singapore unveils subscription service Plus for unlimited free delivery
summary: Deliveroo Singapore has launched Deliveroo Plus, a subscription service offering unlimited free delivery and exclusive discounts for S$10.90 monthly. This move aims to expand the customer base and make food delivery more affordable. Customers can save the usual S$3 delivery fee on every order and access exclusive promotions from partner restaurants. The service is available in Singapore and has been successful in other markets, including the UK and Ireland. Deliveroo plans to enhance the service with additional promotions and rewards.

site_title: YTL PowerSeraya rolls out integrated brand for business and consumer energy
summary: YTL PowerSeraya launches integrated brand Geneco for business and consumer energy, ahead of Singapore's open electricity market rollout. The company aims to be the preferred energy provider, focusing on innovation, cost-effectiveness, and sustainability. Geneco will roll out an electric vehicle charging network with 1,000 points by 2025, targeting commercial fleets and building owners. The move signals YTLPS's intent to expand its energy portfolio and position itself as a leader in the industry.

site_title: Serial System announces S$0.01 special dividend after selling laundry business
summary: Serial System, a Singapore-based electronic components distributor, announced a special dividend of one Singapore cent per share after selling its Australian laundry business for S$39.6 million. The company's shares fell 25.56% to S$0.099 prior to the announcement. The sale proceeds will be distributed as a special dividend, following an earlier promise to do so.

site_title: US must lift 'humanitarian' sanctions on Iran: UN court
summary: The UN's International Court of Justice ordered the US to lift sanctions on "humanitarian" goods to Iran, including medicines, food, and airplane parts. The US had re-imposed these sanctions after pulling out of the nuclear deal. The court's ruling, made unanimously, instructs the US to remove any impediments to the free exportation of these goods. This decision comes after President Trump reimposed the sanctions in May.

site_title: Singtel launches network for roaming mobile payment in Asia
summary: Singtel, Singapore's largest telco, has launched VIA, a cross-border mobile payment alliance, with AIS and Kasikornbank in Thailand, aiming to unify mobile wallets for cross-border use. VIA enables consumers to use their local mobile wallets when traveling, with Singtel Dash users able to pay in Thai baht through a forex conversion. The alliance has the potential to drive mobile payments adoption and support financial inclusion in the region, with Singtel planning to expand the service in India, the Philippines, and Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore to launch electronic arrival card for visitors to country
summary: Singapore's Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) will launch an electronic arrival card for foreign visitors, replacing the current paper-based disembarkation/embarkation card. A trial period will run for three months to ensure a smooth implementation. The new system will not affect Singaporeans, permanent residents, or long-term pass holders.

site_title: Mary Chia unit sets up direct selling branch in Taiwan
summary: Mary Chia Holdings' wholly owned unit, Organica International Holdings, has established a Taiwan branch for direct selling skincare and health supplements. The branch was set up with an initial operating capital of NT$1 million and plans to increase this to NT$15 million. The establishment is in line with the group's plan to enter the Taiwanese direct selling market and is funded through internal resources, with no expected material financial impact on the group for the current financial year.

site_title: Super-car maker Bugatti considering broader range of models
summary: Bugatti, the luxury super-car brand, is considering a broader range of models to cater to its affluent target audience. The brand is exploring chassis and engine variants, as well as a sport utility vehicle or crossover, to expand its product lineup. Bugatti's CEO, Stephan Winkelmann, stated that the brand is ready for more and is looking to justify investment with a convincing pitch to shareholders. A hybrid engine could be part of the future, but social acceptance of emissions is a key consideration. The move aims to tap into the demand for exclusive, high-value vehicles.

site_title: Philippine inflation climbs closer to 7% in September: poll
summary: The Philippine inflation rate is expected to climb closer to 7% in September, according to a Reuters poll of 12 economists, surpassing the 6.4% increase in August. Rising global oil prices and crop losses after a super typhoon are driving the inflation increase. The central bank has maintained its forecast that inflation will peak in September and ease back to its 2-4% target next year. The central bank has raised its benchmark rates for the fourth time in five months, with some economists predicting at least one more rate hike before the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,266.95, up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.7% to 3,266.95 at 1:03pm. Advancers outnumbered decliners 176 to 115, with shares worth S$482.4 million changing hands. Key gainers included Keppel Corp, UOB, and ThaiBev, while SinoCloud fell 50%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with stocks extending a 5-day rally.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower, slipping 0.13% or 35.12 points to 27,091.26, amid investor concerns over a budget row between Italy and the EU, sparking fears of another eurozone financial crisis. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed for a public holiday.

site_title: PODCAST: How to start a wine collection and invest in it (Money Hacks, Ep 23)
summary: In a podcast episode titled "How to start a wine collection and invest in it," Money Hacks co-host Chris Lim shares tips for newcomers to wine investing, including picking wines on sale, attending tasting events, and "gamifying" investments by monitoring prices online. Lim, a certified specialist of wine and French wine scholar, advises listeners to focus on "off vintages" that cost less upfront but appreciate rapidly. The episode aims to educate listeners on wine investing, but notes that any financial or investment decisions should be made after consulting a qualified financial adviser.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's logistics sector launches a 3-year plan to accelerate technology adoption, while the country's shares closed 0.8% higher on Wednesday. OCBC Bank extends its digital instant account opening service to SMEs, and Deliveroo Singapore launches a subscription service offering unlimited free delivery. Serial System's subsidiary, Serial Microelectronics, will lose its distribution deal with Texas Instruments on December 31, 2018. Globally, Vietnam reacts to the US tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Apple chief says firm guards data privacy in China
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook emphasized data privacy, stating the company encrypts and stores data on servers in various countries, making it difficult for local authorities to access. Despite China's tight internet controls, Cook assured that Apple safeguards data stored in the country. He also stressed that Apple's business model does not involve gathering user data for targeted ads, and he supports legislation to protect people's privacy. Cook believes technology itself doesn't have a moral compass, and it's up to creators to ensure responsible use.

images.alt_text: Apple chief executive Tim Cook on Tuesday said the company is devoted to protecting people's privacy, with data encrypted and locked away on servers even in China.

site_title: StarHub to let 300 full-time employees go, CEO cites 'industry pressures'
summary: StarHub, Singapore's second-largest telco, is laying off 300 full-time employees as part of its "operational efficiency programme" due to industry pressures, including intense competition and declining voice revenues. The company cited "ongoing natural attrition" and a tightening of contractor positions. The layoffs will primarily affect non-customer-facing functions, but the telco will hire more employees in areas such as cyber security and customer care. The restructuring cost is estimated at S$25 million, with expected savings of S$210 million from 2019 to 2021.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: For wine auctions, it's been another very good year
summary: Wine auctions have experienced significant growth in recent years, with a shift towards the US and Asia. The market has expanded globally, with live auctions now held in multiple locations, including Beverly Hills, London, New York, Paris, and Hong Kong. In 2017, French wines accounted for 40% of Sotheby's sales, while Burgundies dominated Asian sales. The market is driven by collectors seeking rare and high-value wines, with spirits, particularly Scotch whisky, gaining popularity. The industry reflects market trends, with sales of Bordeaux and Burgundies increasing in value over time.

site_title: 2 editors disciplined after SPH internal inquiry investigates allegations of improper relation
summary: Two editors at The Straits Times, a Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) publication, have been disciplined after an internal inquiry found they had breached SPH's code of conduct. The editors will face disciplinary action, with one being removed from their post, demoted, and redeployed, while the other will receive a written warning, have their salary docked, and also be redeployed. The incident led to a staff member being hospitalized, and SPH prioritized their recovery and support for their family. The company takes a serious view of code of conduct breaches and will take appropriate measures following a full inquiry process.

site_title: Malaysia again questions former PM Najib and wife Rosmah in 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysian authorities have summoned former Prime Minister Najib Razak and his wife Rosmah Mansor for questioning in connection with the 1MDB probe. Najib faces 32 charges, while Rosmah was questioned for the second time in as many weeks. The couple's world has been turned upside down since Najib's election loss in May, with corruption accusations dogging him for years. Last week, investigators recorded Rosmah's statement as part of their inquiry into 1MDB, with nearly $700 million in funds allegedly diverted to Najib's personal bank account.

site_title: Indonesia rocked by volcanic eruption after devastating quake
summary: Indonesia was hit by a volcanic eruption at Mount Soputan in North Sulawesi province, days after a 7.4-magnitude earthquake and tsunami that killed over 1,200 people. The eruption threw ash 4,000 meters into the sky, with authorities ordering a 4-kilometer radius evacuation. The disaster comes as the country struggles with a slump in the currency and a potential impact on the tourism industry, which was previously disrupted by volcanic eruptions on nearby islands.

images.alt_text: This handout picture taken on Oct 3, 2018, by Indonesia's National Agency for Disaster Management shows Mount Soputan erupting ash up to 4,000 metres above the crater, as seen from Pinabetengan in Southeast Minahasa, North Sulawesi Province.

site_title: Looming large: Shell's LNG Canada seen as tip of megaproject iceberg
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has approved a C$40 billion (S$42.9 billion) liquefied natural gas (LNG) export project in Canada, which could fire the start of a wave of approvals globally, easing a supply shortage expected in the next decade. The project, LNG Canada, is expected to produce 14 million tonnes of LNG per year by 2025, boosting global supply and helping to meet surging demand from countries like China and Asia. Other LNG projects are in the pipeline, with analysts expecting 175 million tonnes of capacity to be approved by the end of 2019, helping to curb the supply shortage.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index unchanged at 1797.90. A total of 67.1 million lots were traded, worth RM19.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 104 to 58.

site_title: After losses in Europe, Nomura seeks to resuscitate business
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. is seeking to revitalize its struggling European business after years of losses and internal turmoil. The Japanese brokerage has struggled to compete with US investment banks in Europe, with its European division losing nearly $9 billion since taking over Lehman Brothers' assets in 2008. To address the issues, Nomura's CEO has implemented a leadership overhaul, hired new talent, and focused on complex financing deals and technology. Despite these efforts, analysts warn that Nomura faces significant challenges, including a decline in fixed-income trading and increasing competition from US banks.

site_title: Dunkin' Donuts fires worker dumping water on homeless man in viral video
summary: A Dunkin' Donuts employee in Syracuse, New York, was fired after a viral video showed him pouring water on a homeless man, Jeremy Dufresne, who was sleeping in the store. The incident occurred after Dufresne entered the store to charge his phone and was not asleep, but resting his head. The employee's behavior was widely condemned, with Dunkin' Donuts stating that it goes against the brand's core values. A crowdfunding campaign raised over $13,000 for Dufresne, who struggles with mental illness.

site_title: Japan to order Suruga Bank to halt new property loans after scandal: sources
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) will order Suruga Bank to halt new property loans following a lending scandal that found the bank falsified documents on loans made to retail investors. The scandal led to the resignation of top executives and a surge in the bank's shares as market participants anticipated lighter measures. The FSA determined that the improper lending was widespread and governance functions had failed. Suruga Bank will stop extending new loans for property investment and improve its governance.

site_title: Euro crawls up from 6-week lows on Italy budget speculation
summary: The euro rose 0.35% to US$1.1585 after Italy reported plans to reduce its budget deficit to 2% of GDP by 2021, alleviating concerns about the country's finances. This move provided relief to the battered currency, which had hit a six-week low. The dollar index, however, remained steady, and the yen dipped against other currencies. US data due later in the day may impact the dollar's performance, but analysts attribute the greenback's recent advance to fundamental factors, including the Federal Reserve's rate hike.

site_title: China, South Korea: Markets closed for holiday on Wednesday
summary: China and South Korea's financial markets are closed on Wednesday for public holidays. Meanwhile, in Singapore, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positive outlook despite ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Man fined S$4,500 for bomb scare on Scoot flight to Hat Yai
summary: A 41-year-old man, Hsu Chun Meng, was fined S$4,500 for making a bomb threat on a Scoot flight to Hat Yai, Thailand. He claimed he had a bomb in his carry-on bag after being told to check it in, leading the plane to be turned back to Singapore and fighter jets to escort it back. The incident caused a four-hour delay and resulted in vouchers totaling S$13,757.60 for affected passengers. Hsu's behavior was deemed unacceptable and a threat to public safety, with the court ruling that his actions needed to be deterred.

site_title: UK's May seeks to rally party as Brexit pressures mount
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will address her party's divisions over Brexit, six months before the UK's departure from the European Union. May's Chequers proposal has been rejected by EU leaders, who demand revised proposals by October 18. The Conservative Party's annual conference in Birmingham has exposed ongoing splits, with eurosceptic MPs led by Boris Johnson arguing against May's plan. The DUP, crucial to May's majority, has rejected the idea of checks on goods passing between Northern Ireland and Britain. May's hold on power remains fragile, with speculation of a plot against her.

site_title: Sharp makes long-awaited OLED foray, wary of big spending
summary: Sharp Corp, a Japan-based electronics maker, has unveiled its entry into the OLED market with plans to offer OLED panels in its new smartphones later this year. The company has invested 57.4 billion yen (S$690 million) to produce OLED panels and will initially sell them in Japan. Sharp's cautious approach is due to the slower acceptance of pricier OLED panels, which has offered relief to other LCD screen suppliers. The company aims to sell OLED panels to other manufacturers, but has not yet reached any deals.

site_title: Box ship giant CMA CGM may incur about US$1.5b to comply with green shipping rule
summary: CMA CGM, a box ship giant, may incur around $1.5 billion to comply with the International Maritime Organization's 2020 global sulphur cap, which limits marine fuel sulphur content. The estimated exposure is based on CMA CGM's 10% market share in the container shipping sector, estimated at $15 billion. The company acquired APL in 2016 and holds significant market share, making it a substantial player in the industry. The implementation of the sulphur cap is expected to have a significant impact on the shipping sector.

site_title: China fines movie star Fan Bingbing 479m yuan for tax evasion
summary: China's taxation authorities fined A-list movie star Fan Bingbing 479 million yuan (S$95.8 million) for tax evasion, ordering her to pay back 255 million yuan in taxes. The fine was related to alleged tax evasion in the film industry, with reports suggesting Fan had used "yin-yang" contracts to evade taxes. Fan had dropped off the radar in June amid the investigation, sparking speculation about her fate. The Jiangsu provincial tax bureau delivered its judgments to Fan on Sunday, but there was no immediate comment from her or a representative.

site_title: Singapore logistics sector rolls out 3-year plan to accelerate tech adoption
summary: Singapore's logistics sector has launched a 3-year plan to accelerate technology adoption. The industry-led roadmap aims to digitalize processes and enhance collaboration among stakeholders. The plan includes establishing platforms to showcase innovative technology and digital applications in logistics. The initiative was announced by Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon at the Singapore Logistics Forum 2018.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks reopen with sharp losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 1% in the first few minutes of trading, extending losses from the previous day. The Hang Seng Index dropped 286.18 points to 26,840.20, amid concerns over a brewing crisis in the eurozone. Investors were tracking the clash between EU and Italian leaders, which fueled uncertainty. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed for a public holiday.

site_title: First Hyperloop passenger capsule unveiled
summary: Hyperloop Transportation Technologies Inc unveiled its first full-scale passenger capsule, the Quintero One, in Spain. The 105-foot capsule, weighing five tonnes, is made of composite material and will be used on one of the first commercial tracks in California. Hyperloop technology, popularized by Elon Musk in 2013, aims to transport passengers at speeds over 750 miles per hour through low-pressure tubes, reducing friction. The Los Angeles area is emerging as a hyperloop hub, with competitors Arrivo and Virgin Hyperloop One also operating in the region.

site_title: Facebook says no sign recent hack spread to other apps
summary: Facebook says no sign recent hack spread to other apps, after hackers stole digital keys to tens of millions of accounts. The breach affected up to 50 million accounts, but no third-party applications linked to Facebook were tampered with, according to an investigation by Facebook engineers. Hackers exploited three software flaws to steal "access tokens" that enabled automatic login, but no accounts were actually misused. Facebook reset the affected accounts and took down a "view as" feature to prevent further exploitation.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.5% to 3,260
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.5% to 3,260. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 47, with ThaiBev rising 2.99% to 69 Singapore cents. Active index stocks like DBS and Singtel also inched up. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: US retail vacancies flat at 10.2% in third quarter: Reis
summary: US retail vacancies remained flat at 10.2% in the third quarter, according to a report by Reis Inc. Mall vacancy rates jumped to 9.1% due to Sears and Bon-Ton store closures, while the retail sector continues to correct itself due to e-commerce growth. Net absorption was 2.3 million square feet, with a 2% increase in national average asking rents and effective rent. New construction dropped 27.9% to 2.3 million square feet. The retail sector is adapting to e-commerce by adopting omni-channel approaches.

site_title: Canadian Nobel physics laureate hails womens' progress
summary: Canadian Nobel physics laureate Donna Strickland praised women's progress in science, citing her predecessor Maria Goeppert Mayer. Strickland said women have "come a long way" despite Mayer's pioneering work in 1939. Strickland was awarded the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physics for her work on creating short, intense laser pulses. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau commended Strickland for inspiring women to pursue careers in science, noting her work's potential impact on cancer therapy and other physics research. Strickland expressed equality in pay and treatment, reflecting the progress made since Mayer's time.

site_title: Brokers' take: OCBC Investment Research downgrades Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to 'hold'
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to a "hold" due to diminishing upside potential. The analyst cited a pause in share repurchases and concerns over higher steel prices affecting margins. Despite this, the group is expected to meet its full-year target of US$1.8 billion, with a strong outstanding order book of US$4.1 billion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.18% to 24,226.50, following a fresh 27-year high earlier in the week. Investors took profits, contributing to the decline. The broader Topix index also fell 0.15%.

site_title: Say goodbye to Nafta, and say hello to, umm, what's it called again?
summary: US President Donald Trump has renamed the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), in an effort to distance himself from the original deal. Despite his claims that the new name will be used 99% of the time, officials and critics have struggled to verbalize it, with some referring to it as "Nafta" or "USMCA" interchangeably. The name change has sparked debate over whether it will take hold, with some experts suggesting it may be easier to use the original name due to its phonetic similarity.

site_title: Thai bay made famous in 'The Beach' shut indefinitely
summary: Thai bay made famous in 'The Beach' will be closed indefinitely due to the impact of hordes of tourists, causing beach erosion and pollution. The bay, known as Maya Bay, was initially shut for four months but a survey revealed the damage was worse than thought, with the ecological system destroyed by up to 5,000 daily tourists. The National Parks office has announced the indefinite closure, stating it's impossible for recovery to occur in the allotted time, and restrictions on tourism will remain until the ecosystem fully recovers.

images.alt_text: The glittering Thai bay immortalised in the movie "The Beach" will be closed indefinitely to allow it to recover from the impact of hordes of tourists, an official said Wednesday, as a temporary ban on visitors expired.

site_title: Australian dollar delivers rate cut central bank can't provide
summary: The Australian dollar is expected to continue its downward trend, falling to 68 cents by mid-2024, driven by a 75 basis point gap with the US Federal Reserve target and a potential drop in key commodity prices due to a slowing Chinese economy. The Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) cash rate remains at a record low 1.5%, and economists predict further stimulus from the currency, equivalent to 25 basis points of loosening on the cash rate. This has been welcomed by the RBA, which has been seeking to stimulate the economy.

images.alt_text: Australia's currency is set to head even lower as local interest rates fall further behind US levels, delivering a dose of stimulus the central bank has long sought but been reluctant to provide itself.

site_title: UN warns Indonesia quake needs 'vast' as toll nears 1,400
summary: Indonesia's Sulawesi island is facing a devastating humanitarian crisis after a 7.5-magnitude earthquake and tsunami, killing nearly 1,400 people and leaving almost 200,000 in urgent need of aid. Survivors are struggling with thirst, hunger, and lack of clean water, while hospitals are overwhelmed by the number of injured. The UN has warned of "vast" needs for both survivors and rescue teams, and international aid offers have increased, with the UN releasing $15 million and Australia providing an additional $5 million.

site_title: Mazda picks up the pace in electric vehicles
summary: Mazda Motor Corp has announced plans to revamp its product lineup, aiming to have all its vehicles powered by electric motors by 2030. Five percent of the cars will be fully battery-powered, while 95 percent will combine electric and internal combustion engines. The company plans to introduce its first electric vehicle by 2020, a year later than originally planned, with two models in development, including one powered solely by battery. Mazda's goal is more aggressive than that of partner Toyota Motor Corp, which aims for half of its cars to be electrified by 2030.

site_title: OCBC to extend digital instant account opening service to SMEs from November
summary: OCBC Bank plans to launch a digital instant account opening service for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore from November. The service will leverage Singapore's national data repository, MyInfo, allowing SME owners to instantly open accounts with minimal required documentation. This move aims to simplify the account opening process, reducing the typical one-day wait. With the SME owner's consent, OCBC can access their MyInfo profile to streamline the application process.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Philippine inflation seen moving closer to 7% in September: poll
summary: The Philippine inflation rate is expected to reach 6.8% in September, the highest since 2009, according to a Reuters poll of economists. Rising global oil prices and crop losses after a super typhoon contributed to the forecast. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the central bank, has maintained that inflation will peak in September and ease back to its target range of 2-4% next year. The central bank has already raised interest rates four times in five months, with some economists predicting at least one more hike before the end of the year.

site_title: Comcast sells US$27b of bonds in year's second-biggest deal
summary: Comcast sold $27 billion of bonds to finance its $39 billion acquisition of Sky Plc, one of the largest corporate debt sales in the US. The bonds, sold in 12 parts, yield 1.75 percentage points above Treasuries, with investors placing orders for $88 billion of debt. The deal is the second-largest of the year, behind CVS Health's $40 billion issuance. Comcast's debt could nearly double to $114 billion, but the company aims to maintain its current rating and reduce debt to return to 2.2 times earnings.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Aspial, Serial System, Sembcorp, Stamford Land
summary: Aspial is launching S$20.75 million in additional notes with a 6.25% coupon, adding to an earlier S$29.25 million tranche. Serial System's distribution agreement with Texas Instruments will terminate on Dec 31, 2018, and the company is considering a potential sale. Sembcorp Industries was the only bidder for Hyflux's Tuaspring project, but its offer was below book value. Minority shareholder Mano Sabnani has denied allegations against Stamford Land, and Wheelock Properties is requesting a trading suspension due to a loss of public float.

site_title: Canadian CEO pleads guilty in US to helping drug cartels
summary: Canadian CEO Vincent Ramos pleaded guilty to facilitating international narcotics traffic by supplying encrypted communications devices to drug cartels. The devices, supplied by his company Phantom Secure, helped distribute cocaine, heroin, and methamphetamine in multiple countries. Ramos agreed to forfeit $80 million and face up to 20 years in prison. The co-conspirators remain at large, and Ramos is scheduled to be sentenced on December 17.

site_title: French interior minister quits in latest blow to Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron accepted the resignation of his interior minister, Gerard Collomb, on Wednesday, amid pressure to step down amid a scandal surrounding Macron's former security aide Alexandre Benalla. Collomb had initially attempted to resign two weeks ago but was rebuffed by Macron, who accepted his fresh bid to quit. The move is the latest blow to Macron's approval ratings, which are languishing at around 34%. Collomb will remain in the position until the announcement of a successor, with Prime Minister Edouard Philippe stepping in to act in his place.

site_title: Tesla must defend lawsuit alleging abuse of foreign workers: judge
summary: US federal judge Lucy Koh has ruled that Tesla must defend itself in a lawsuit alleging the company knew foreign workers at its Fremont, California facility were threatened with deportation if they reported injuries or worked long shifts violating forced labor laws. The lawsuit, filed by Slovenian national Gregor Lesnik and Croatian national Stjepan Papes, claims Tesla and subcontractor ISM Vuzem forced workers to work long hours for low pay and threatened deportation if they reported injuries. Tesla faces intense pressure to turn a profit amid recent CEO Elon Musk's settlement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

site_title: MPA gives S$5m boost to research and development on greener marine fuels
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has allocated S$5 million to support research and development of greener marine fuels, aiming to meet the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) target of halving carbon emissions by 2050. This initiative builds on the MPA's existing investment of S$26 million in liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering. The goal is to develop alternatives such as biofuel and methanol to achieve a 50% reduction in carbon emissions, surpassing the 25% cut offered by LNG.

site_title: Parcels sent to Pentagon suspected to contain ricin: official
summary: Two or more packages delivered to the Pentagon on Monday were suspected to contain ricin, a deadly poison. The packages were intercepted at a nearby screening centre, and authorities are still waiting for confirmation. Pentagon police referred the matter to the FBI for investigation. Defence officials said the packages were addressed to Defence Secretary Jim Mattis and Navy head Admiral John Richardson, and are undergoing further testing. The Pentagon's mail screening facility processes around 500,000 items per year, with Defence Department workers wearing protective suits to screen the mail.

site_title: Trump helped his parents dodge millions in taxes: report
summary: Donald Trump allegedly helped his parents dodge millions in taxes and received far more money from his father's real estate empire than claimed. The New York Times reported that Trump received the equivalent of $413 million from his father's activities, earning him a millionaire by age 8 and $5 million annually in his 40s and 50s. Trump and his siblings set up a sham corporation to disguise gifts from their parents and helped his father take improper tax deductions. The Trumps paid a total of $52.2 million in taxes on a potential $1 billion in wealth, with Trump's lawyers calling the allegations "100% false" and "highly defamatory".

site_title: Asian markets mixed, euro weak on brewing Italy risk
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday as the euro struggled to recover from recent selling pressure due to a brewing Italy-EU crisis. Italy's populist government passed a budget that drew rebukes from Brussels, prompting investors to seek damages and fueling concerns of another eurozone crisis. The yield on Italian government bonds surged, making it more expensive for the country to borrow on international markets. The euro extended losses, while equity investors shifted warily, with Tokyo down 0.1% and Hong Kong adding 0.4%.

site_title: Aspial offers additional notes on investor interest
summary: ASPIAL Corp is issuing S$20.75 million in additional notes under its S$700 million debt issuance programme at a 6.25% coupon, following investor interest. The notes, due 2021, add to an earlier tranche and bring the total under the Series 006 notes to S$50 million. This reduces outstanding debt by S$3.5 million and will be used for general funding, working capital, and capital expenditure. DBS Bank is the sole lead manager and bookrunner for the issue.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Europe: Stocks retreat on Italy budget worries
summary: Europe's stock markets declined on Tuesday due to concerns over Italy's budgetary spending, easing the euro against the US dollar and falling oil prices. US markets rose despite lingering trade war concerns. Analyst David Madden attributed the European market downturn to renewed fears about the US-China trade dispute and Italian politics.

site_title: Pompeo to meet Kim Jong Un in fresh visit
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will visit North Korea on Sunday to meet with leader Kim Jong Un, as the administration seeks a denuclearization deal. Pompeo's fourth trip to North Korea aims to build momentum for a second summit between Kim and US President Donald Trump. North Korea has refused to give up nuclear weapons in exchange for a peace treaty, citing the need for trust-building measures. Pompeo will also meet with officials in Japan, South Korea, and China, where the US is engaged in trade and diplomatic disputes.

site_title: Indonesia weighs tax cut for bond investors after rupiah falls to 20-year low
summary: Indonesia is considering tax cuts for bond investors and exporters to boost the weakening rupiah currency. The proposed measures include reducing the 20% tax on foreign investors' bond gains and extending tax breaks to exporters who park their dollar earnings in local banks for longer periods. The goal is to attract more inflows and deepen domestic financial markets, which have been crucial in bolstering the currency amid a 10% decline in the rupiah this year.

site_title: Global growth positive but under pressure: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the global economic outlook remains positive but is under pressure, citing instability in emerging markets. He emphasized the importance of monitoring developments overseas and in emerging markets, such as Vietnam and China, where GDP growth is expected to slow. Powell's comments come as the global economy faces various challenges, including trade tensions and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Oil prices ease below 4-year highs; US inventory rise expected
summary: Oil prices eased to near four-year highs on Tuesday, falling 18 cents to US$84.80 per barrel for Brent and 7 cents to US$75.23 per barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude futures. Despite global demand remaining strong despite trade tensions, US inventory rises are expected, with analysts forecasting a 2 million barrel increase last week. The US sanctions on Iran's oil industry, set to take effect on November 4, are also a concern, with some analysts predicting prices could reach US$100 per barrel.

site_title: US restricts visas to unmarried gay diplomats
summary: The US is denying visas to the partners of over 100 gay diplomats unless they get married, affecting around 105 families, including 55 posted at US-based international organisations. The decision, implemented by the Trump administration, is claimed to be based on legal reciprocity, but critics, including former US ambassador Samantha Power and the Human Rights Campaign, describe it as "needlessly cruel & bigoted" and "unnecessary, mean-spirited and unacceptable". The policy change reflects the administration's hostility towards the LGBTQ community, following moves to chip away at protections for the community.

site_title: Asian markets continue to trade mixed
summary: Asian markets closed mixed, with the Nikkei 225 reaching a 27-year high, while the Hang Seng and ASX 200 indices fell. Despite the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) deal, investors remained cautious, fearing a focus on China by US President Trump. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dropped 2.4%, while the ASX 200 and Kospi closed in the red. The Nikkei's surge was attributed to upbeat earnings forecasts and a weaker yen.

site_title: The era of 5G technology is officially here
summary: Verizon launches the world's first commercial 5G network for home internet service, offering download speeds of approximately 300 Mbps in select cities. The service, 5G Home, costs $70/month or $50/month with a Verizon cellphone plan, and works by sending web content over a mobile data connection to a wireless router. This marks the first commercial use of a 5G network worldwide, with potential benefits including faster mobile data downloads and support for emerging technologies like self-driving cars and remote medicine.

site_title: Serial System says unit to lose distribution deal with Texas Instruments; may sell that business
summary: Serial System's subsidiary, Serial Microelectronics, will lose its distribution deal with Texas Instruments on December 31, 2018. The company is in discussions with TI to end the business relationship and is also considering selling its TI distribution business, which generated US$442.5 million in revenue in the previous half year. This move is part of Serial System's efforts to restructure its business and focus on core operations.

site_title: Australia's competition watchdog opens inquiry into forex services
summary: Australia's competition watchdog, the ACCC, has opened an inquiry into foreign currency conversion services, examining price competition among suppliers and the mark-up from wholesale rates. The inquiry will investigate why major companies, including the Big Four banks, consistently charge high prices. A 2017 study found that Australian consumers and businesses paid A$3.9 billion in foreign currency fees in 2016, with A$3.1 billion attributed to exchange rate mark-ups and card spending charges. The ACCC will submit its final report to the Treasurer by May 2019.

site_title: Exxon explores sale of US Gulf of Mexico assets: sources
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is exploring the sale of its US Gulf of Mexico assets, driven by higher prices and a focus on concentrating development operations in key areas like Guyana and the Permian basin. The company has asked a few parties to gauge interest in its Gulf assets, which produce about 50,000 barrels of oil per day, and is considering selling these assets next year. A potential buyer, Qatar Petroleum, has partnerships with Exxon in Brazil and Argentina, and could be well-positioned to make an offer.

site_title: Tokyo fishmongers mourn and protest closure of famous Tsukiji fish market
summary: Tokyo's famous Tsukiji fish market is closing, with hundreds of fish traders, including 45-year-old Takako Arai, packing up to relocate to a new $5 billion market on reclaimed land. Arai feels "torn" about leaving the historic market where she grew up and now runs her family's seafood stall. The relocation marks the end of an era for Tsukiji, which has been a Tokyo staple for decades, and raises concerns about the loss of history and tradition. The new market is expected to be completed in the near future, but the exact date has not been announced.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us lenders plan brand revival
summary: Toys 'R' Us lenders plan to revive the brand by creating a new company that maintains current license agreements and invests in new retail operations. The new entity will own the Toys 'R' Us and Babies 'R' Us names, as well as intellectual property, including the iconic Geoffrey the Giraffe mascot. However, the timing of the move may be challenging, missing the critical holiday season and requiring significant marketing and management resources to succeed.

site_title: Toyota sees hard Brexit disrupting £60 million in weekly revenue
summary: Toyota's European operations head, Johan van Zyl, warns that a hard Brexit could disrupt £60 million in weekly revenue, equivalent to 600 cars produced daily, due to logistics interruptions. The UK's potential exit from the EU without a trade agreement would force a temporary stoppage at Toyota's plant in Burnaston, England, and the company seeks tariff-free trading after Brexit. Toyota has invested £240 million in Burnaston and relies on the EU for 87% of its vehicle exports.

site_title: Singapore and India: A shared vision for a clean future
summary: Singapore and India have made significant progress in achieving a clean future, with India building over 86 million toilets and declaring nearly 470,000 villages free of open defecation. Both countries value international cooperation and have learned from each other's experiences in sanitation and water management. India's Swachh Bharat Mission, launched in 2014, aims to transform the way people think, live, and work, while Singapore has implemented a Sewerage Master Plan to separate sewerage and drainage networks and recycle used water. The two countries share a vision of a clean and sustainable future, and will continue to cooperate to achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goal of clean water and sanitation for all.

site_title: Facebook adds new tools to stem online bullying
summary: Facebook has introduced new tools to combat online bullying and harassment. The platform will allow users to hide or delete groups of comments, report bullying on behalf of friends, and search for or block words considered offensive. The new features are part of an initiative to make the social network a safer space for users. The move comes after a survey found that 59% of US teenagers reported being bullied or harassed online.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Tuesday stepped up ways to battle bullying and harassment at the leading social network.

site_title: Kuehne + Nagel rolls out first EVs for SEA
summary: Kuehne + Nagel, a leading logistics player, has rolled out its first electric vehicles (EVs) for island-wide delivery in Singapore. The EVs are part of the company's plans to grow its EV fleet in the South-east Asia region by 2022. The logistics player has partnered with Hub Distributor to offer distribution services using the EVs, with charging stations set up at its Singapore Logistics Hub. This move marks a significant step towards reducing the company's carbon footprint in the region.

site_title: Slow payments on the rise in Q3, retail sector sees highest jump in over six years
summary: Singapore's retail sector saw the largest jump in slow payments in over six years, with a 14.27 percentage point increase in Q3 2018, reaching 44.11%. This was attributed to weaker sales in the previous quarter due to muted consumer sentiments. However, overall payment performance showed slight improvements across other sectors, with slow payments falling in construction, manufacturing, services, and wholesale. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau reported prompt payments at 48.31% and slow payments at 38.94% in Q3.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Risk of hard Brexit has these Asian companies on edge
summary: Asian companies invested in the UK are concerned about the risk of a hard Brexit, which could lead to higher tariffs and costs. Major Japanese companies, including Toyota, Sony, Panasonic, and Hitachi Construction, are monitoring the negotiations and considering potential impacts on their operations. Some, such as Panasonic, have already shifted their European head office to Amsterdam, while others, like Toyota, may need to temporarily halt production in the UK. The uncertainty is causing concern among Japanese corporations, with some considering leaving the UK or adjusting their supply chains.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars - Eco-friendly cars
summary: Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars - Eco-friendly Cars" discusses the pros and cons of electric and hybrid cars with Julian Kho from sgcarmart and Claressa. They share their favorite eco-friendly options, but no specific models are mentioned. The conversation highlights the benefits of eco-friendly cars, including reduced emissions and lower operating costs. The podcast is part of Prime Time on MoneyFM 89.3, and listeners can download or stream the episode on various platforms.

site_title: Shell, partners take on a bold strategy in Canada
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and its partners have announced an investment in a C$40 billion liquefied natural gas project in western Canada, set to be the nation's largest infrastructure project. The project, LNG Canada, will enable faster routes to Asia, reducing transit times from 8 to 20 days. Construction will start immediately, with expected first LNG production by the middle of the next decade. The project aims to export 26 million tonnes per year, with potential for expansion, and is seen as a turning point for Canada and the global gas industry.

site_title: IMF-World Bank meetings in Bali look set to be Indonesia's Olympian moment
summary: Indonesia is set to host the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank in Bali, marking a significant moment for the country's economy and democracy. The event comes 20 years after the Asian financial crisis, which left Indonesia's political and economic fabric in tatters. Since then, the country has made significant strides in embedding democracy and decentralization, and its economy has shown stability and growth. President Joko Widodo will use the opportunity to shape the narrative about Indonesia's future, addressing concerns over infrastructure, foreign investment, and nationalism.

site_title: Shaping the best of all possible futures amid insecurity
summary: The world is experiencing an era of insecurity, driven by repudiation of liberal democracy, liberal economies, and a rules-based international system. This has led to growing support for nationalist and illiberal politicians, declining social mobility, and worsening prospects for future generations. Experts argue that addressing inequality is key to a happier future, and that austerity has exacerbated this issue. To shape a better future, policymakers must adopt a multi-dimensional approach, including progressive taxation, a living wage, and a new approach to work and economic progress.

site_title: Tennis and corporate hospitality a perfect match
summary: The WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global has sold 90% of its Racquet Club VIP tickets, with 9,108 tickets sold to date. The event, which includes world No 1 Simona Halep and US Open champion Naomi Osaka, will feature a premium hospitality experience with gourmet buffets, wine, and beer. The tournament, worth US$7 million, will take place in Singapore from October 25-28, with five more spots still available.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Yale's endowment grows by 12.3%, against Harvard's 10%
summary: Yale University's endowment, the world's second-largest, grew 12.3% in the fiscal year to $29.4 billion, surpassing the 10% gain of Harvard's $39.2 billion endowment. Yale's performance trailed MIT's 13.5% and Penn's 12.9% gains. The university's endowment strategy, led by David F. Swensen, has drawn criticism for relying on alternative investments, but Swensen notes that Yale's approach has added $33.3 billion in value over 30 years, exceeding a 60-40 stock-and-bond portfolio.

site_title: Going beyond an economic relationship
summary: Germany's Ambassador to Singapore, Ulrich Sante, emphasizes the importance of preserving a multilateral world order, citing the EU's goal of a trade deal with Asean. The upcoming EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) is a key milestone towards this goal. Sante sees the FTA as a message of support for multilateralism and against protectionism, and as a benchmark for other trade deals with Asean. Germany and Singapore have a strong, balanced economic relationship, with bilateral trade growing 8.3% in 2017. Sante advocates for a strategic relationship between the EU and Asean, with people-to-people relations, cultural exchange, and vocational training playing a crucial role in strengthening ties.

site_title: Singapore a hub and bridge to the region
summary: Singapore has become a hub and bridge to the region for German businesses, with over 1,700 German companies operating in the city-state, more than tripling in the last decade. The presence of German firms like Siemens, which has been in Singapore since 1908, has been complemented by the arrival of startups under the German Accelerator program. This growth is driven by Singapore's favorable business environment and strategic location, making it an attractive destination for German companies seeking to expand into the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Katong Park Towers gets Court's nod for en bloc sale to proceed
summary: The High Court has given approval for the en bloc sale of Katong Park Towers to proceed, following a successful hearing after several failed rounds of mediation. The sale, initially valued at S$345 million, was met with objections from some owners, including a shop unit owner who argued the method of apportionment was unfair. The court ultimately agreed that the 90-5-5 method was acceptable, as long as premiums were fair across all units. The sale now has the green light to proceed.

site_title: Challenging her critics, British PM May embraces Brexit "opportunity"
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to address her Conservative Party conference, assuring them that the UK's departure from the European Union is an "opportunity" for a bright future. In a speech, May will criticize critics who say she has failed to embrace Brexit, promising to act in the national interest and address domestic policy concerns. With only six months before the UK's departure, May faces pressure from Brussels and within her own party, but will attempt to reset her agenda and counter opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn's leftist policies.

site_title: Singapore Q3 bond market stuns with quadrupling of issue value
summary: Singapore's dollar bond market made a strong recovery in Q3, with SGD issuance rising 73% to S$8.8 billion, driven by declining yields and favorable swap rates. Banks and government entities issued billions in perpetual bonds, which were lapped up by investors. However, experts doubt if Q3's performance will be repeated in the final quarter of 2018, citing rising interest rates and increasing supply. Despite this, infrastructure bonds and ESG-linked bonds are expected to be major themes in the market.

site_title: CapitaLand invests S$27m in co-working operator in push to build offices of the future
summary: CapitaLand invests S$27 million in co-working operator, The Work Project Kingdom (TWPK), to build offices of the future integrating conventional and flexible spaces. The investment includes S$13.5 million in shares and S$13.5 million in loans, with plans to add over 500,000 sq ft of flexible spaces by 2021. This strategy aims to provide dynamic workspaces and customer-centric solutions, differentiating CapitaLand from other office landlords.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: A good starter platform
summary: Singapore and Germany are strengthening their startup ecosystems through a series of initiatives. Startup Autobahn Singapore, a Mercedes-Benz corporate accelerator, has supported 14 startups, while the German Accelerator, a government-backed program, has brought in eight German startups in Singapore. The German Accelerator Southeast Asia aims to help German tech startups break into the South-east Asian market, with Singapore seen as a key platform. A two-way partnership between the German Accelerator and Enterprise Singapore will support Singapore startups' entry into Germany, with up to 60 startups expected to benefit over the next two years.

images.alt_text: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean meeting the staff of accelerator Startup Autobahn during his tour of Techventure X Slush Singapore event in September 2016.

site_title: Trump clears deck for China trade war with new Nafta deal
summary: President Trump has cleared the decks for a potential trade war with China by signing a new North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) deal with Canada and Mexico. The agreement includes provisions aimed at keeping Chinese products out of the region. Trump has also struck deals with South Korea and Japan, signaling his intention to take on China in a prolonged economic conflict. This move may lead to higher tariffs on Chinese goods, potentially escalating tensions between the two nations.

site_title: There's no fish in London's first vegan fish and chips shop
summary: London's first dedicated vegan fish and chips shop, "Vegan Fish & Co," has opened in east London, offering a full menu of plant-based versions of classic fish and chips dishes. The "vegan fish" is made from banana blossom marinated in seaweed and deep-fried, while vegan "prawns" are made from Japanese potato starch. The shop has seen high demand for its vegan options, with prices starting at £5.50 per serving. The shop aims to capitalize on the growing demand for vegan food, despite some critics arguing that it may not be as healthy as traditional options.

site_title: Credit Suisse to add Apple business chat for rich Asian clients
summary: Credit Suisse is integrating Apple Business Chat into its digital platform for wealthy clients in Singapore and Hong Kong. The service allows clients to access account information, portfolio details, and transaction status. This integration aims to enhance the banking experience for high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: Investors clamour for crumbs in hot loan market
summary: Credit Suisse increased the size of a $5.05 billion corporate loan by $400 million after investors clamored for the deal, with yields averaging 6.81% as borrowing costs rise. The hot loan market signals issuers are regaining control, with loan yields expected to fall and investor protections weakening. The Federal Reserve's rate hikes have driven demand for loans, which pay floating rates and allow investors to earn higher yields. Despite low supply, loan sales are expected to reach $80 billion in the third quarter, down from $99.5 billion in the second quarter.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SinoCloud Group has terminated a letter of intent for the acquisition of an internet data center in Lianyungang, China, after both parties failed to reach an agreement on terms. Maybank has made two new senior appointments in its investment banking arm, with Ami Moris as CEO of Maybank Kim Eng Group and Fad'l Mohamed as CEO of Maybank Investment Bank. Olive Tree Estates has signed a non-binding MOU for four property development projects in Vietnam with the National Housing Organization Joint Stock Company.

site_title: New Nafta is not the huge win that Trump claims
summary: US President Donald Trump has celebrated the new US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), but critics argue it's not as significant as he claims. The deal includes limited wins for the US, such as opening Canada's dairy markets, but also includes concessions, such as preserving a trade dispute settlement mechanism and protecting Canada's car industry. The agreement does not meet Trump's expectations, and he has faced criticism for his handling of the negotiations, which damaged goodwill with Canada and Mexico. The deal is seen as a step forward for multilateralism, but its impact remains uncertain.

site_title: Wheelock Properties hits 90% delisting threshold
summary: Wheelock Properties (Singapore) is set to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after a takeover offer crossed the 90% threshold. As of October 2, 2018, parent firm Wheelock and Company's stake in the company reached 90.1%. This marks the end of Wheelock Properties' time on the SGX.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: The Frieze Art Fair is going Hollywood
summary: The Frieze Art Fair is set to debut in Los Angeles next February, marking a significant expansion of the British fair into the US market. The inaugural edition will feature a diverse range of galleries, including major American and international players, and will be curated by local art impresario Bettina Korek. The event aims to establish Los Angeles as a major hub for contemporary art, building on the city's existing reputation for producing iconic artists. With the support of influential figures such as Ari Emanuel and Serena Williams, Frieze Los Angeles is poised to become a key player in the US art scene.

site_title: Facebook, IMDA start accelerator for data startups
summary: Facebook has launched its first accelerator programme, Startup Station, Singapore, in partnership with the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA). The programme is designed for data startups in Singapore and South-east Asia, offering non-funding support such as coworking space, access to the Regulatory Sandbox, and mentorship. The programme aims to empower startups to refine and scale their business models, while maintaining data trust and transparency. The initiative is part of Facebook's expansion in Singapore, with its new office occupying 260,000 sq ft of space.

images.alt_text: Facebook's latest Singapore office occupies some 260,000 sq ft across four floors in Marina One. It houses more than 1,000 employees from Facebook's Singapore and regional teams.

site_title: Oil shock has already started in emerging markets
summary: Oil prices have surged to near-record levels in emerging markets, with Brent crude reaching over $85 a barrel. This is exacerbating inflation and fueling populist movements, such as in Brazil and Mexico, where governments are struggling to cope with the economic impact. The rising cost of fuel is also affecting India, where prices have reached record levels. Governments are providing subsidies to mitigate the effects, but these measures can damage government budgets and create a vicious cycle. The oil market's tightness is largely driven by emerging-market consumers, which could have a significant impact on global oil prices.

site_title: 2019 will be a hopeful year for emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets are expected to rally in 2019 as protectionism between the US and China eases. A trade breakthrough by the US, Canada, and Mexico has generated optimism over a truce between the two largest economies, potentially alleviating the impact of tariffs on emerging markets such as Argentina, Turkey, and Brazil. Economists predict US economic expansion will slow to 2.5% and China's to 6.3% next year, which could hasten a trade deal and provide relief for emerging markets.

site_title: Resources Prima to acquire Chinese developer in RTO
summary: Resources Prima Group, an Indonesian coal miner, has entered into a binding MOU to acquire ChongQing HuangYang Property Development for S$33 million. This will result in a reverse takeover of Resources Prima. The acquisition is aimed at resolving the company's financial and business challenges, which include severe cash flow constraints and a significant doubt about its ability to remain a going concern, according to its independent auditor. The deal will be satisfied by issuing new shares in Resources Prima at S$0.20 per share.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Half of women at risk of dementia, Parkinson's, stroke: study
summary: A study published in the Journal of Neurology Neurosurgery and Psychiatry found that nearly half of women and one in three men are at risk of developing stroke, dementia, or Parkinson's disease during their lifetime. Researchers tracked over 12,000 people aged 45 and above from 1990 to 2016, finding that women aged 45 or older were 48% at risk, while men were 36%. A healthy lifestyle, including a good diet and not smoking, can reduce the risk of these diseases. The cost of these diseases is estimated to be over 2% of global economic productivity.

site_title: Cyber panel flags concentration risk in cloud technology for banks, insurers
summary: The Cyber Security Advisory Panel in Singapore has raised concerns about concentration risks in cloud technology for banks and insurers, citing the reliance on a limited pool of cloud service providers. The panel advised financial institutions to secure data on the cloud and network connections, while cloud providers should be more transparent about their security measures. This comes as the trend of using open plugged-in code from third-party partners continues to grow.

site_title: Pay in Singapore tipped to rise 4.0% in 2019
summary: Singapore's average salary increase for 2019 is projected to remain unchanged at 4.0%, according to a survey by Willis Towers Watson. This is consistent with 2018's rate. The pharmaceutical and health sciences industry is expected to see the highest salary increases, while banks will offer the lowest. Top performers will receive 16.8% of the salary hike budget, with incentives averaging 1.5 months' base salary. The sector's growth is attributed to biotech developments and policy reforms in China and Japan.

images.alt_text: While pay for the Asia-Pacific region as a whole is tipped to continue on a gentle upward trend in 2019, rising 5.9 per cent on average, the increase in Singapore is likely to stay the same as in 2018.

site_title: DBS, POSB to provide instant approvals for credit cards, credit line
summary: DBS Bank and POSB have launched an online application service that allows customers to receive instant approval for credit card and credit line applications, eliminating the need for physical documents. The service utilizes the national platform MyInfo, which is used by 3.3 million SingPass holders in Singapore. This change is expected to reduce processing times for new-to-bank customers, who can now receive their credit card or access Cashline immediately, rather than waiting up to a week.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan PM Abe keeps allies in key posts, just one woman in cabinet
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe maintained key cabinet positions in a recent reshuffle, including finance, trade, and foreign affairs. However, he appointed only one woman, Satsuki Katayama, to the new lineup, which also includes a former finance official, to promote female empowerment. Despite Abe's emphasis on female empowerment, the majority of his cabinet remains unchanged, raising concerns about the country's progress in this area.

site_title: On patrol with India's anti-plastic 'blue squad'
summary: India's "blue squad" of 311 inspectors is enforcing a ban on single-use plastics in Maharashtra state, with fines of up to 25,000 rupees or three months in jail for repeat offenders. The ban, introduced in June, has already collected 11.6 million rupees in fines and seized over 21 tonnes of plastic. While some traders have switched to cloth bags and paper straws, others continue to violate the ban, and retailers associations claim confusion and lack of cheap alternatives have hurt businesses. The goal of the blue squad is to raise awareness and protect the environment.

site_title: Google ad chief exits; search, AI veteran replaces him
summary: Google is replacing its top advertising executive, Sridhar Ramaswamy, with Prabhakar Raghavan, a veteran of search technology and artificial intelligence research. Raghavan will oversee product and engineering for Google's digital-ad business, which is expected to generate over $100 billion in sales this year. He aims to maintain the company's growth while preventing commercial goals from influencing consumer services, amid rising regulatory pressure and scrutiny. Raghavan, 58, joins from Greylock Partners after 15 years at Google, where he led the ads business and developed new ad formats.

site_title: Shaping Singapore
summary: In Singapore, two women are shaping the country's physical and digital environment. Cheong Koon Hean, CEO of the Housing & Development Board, has played a key role in transforming the physical environment through her tenure as head of the Urban Redevelopment Authority. Her work has contributed to the country's urban planning, with a focus on creating a livable and sustainable environment for its citizens.

site_title: Minority shareholder responds to Stamford Land's defamation claims
summary: Minority shareholder Mano Sabnani has denied defamation claims by Stamford Land and its directors in a Singapore court. Sabnani maintained that remarks made at the company's AGM were justified and not defamatory, citing the importance of minority shareholders' rights to raise issues and promote transparency and accountability. He rebutted the plaintiff's allegations point-by-point and is being represented by Providence Law Asia. The defamation suit has been closely followed by the Singapore investing community, highlighting the growing trend of such cases in corporate Singapore.

site_title: Wheelock Properties to delist following buyout
summary: Wheelock Properties (Singapore) is going private after crossing the 90% stake threshold for delisting. The company's parent firm, Wheelock and Company, acquired 90.1% of its shares, exceeding the SGX's listing rules requirement of a 10% public float. Shareholders who have not accepted the offer can sell their shares at S$2.10 in cash per share within three months. The company's delisting follows a voluntary unconditional general offer.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Faber Garden tries again for en bloc - at unchanged S$1.18b price
summary: Faber Garden, a freehold site in Singapore, is relaunching its en bloc sale at the unchanged reserve price of S$1.18 billion. Marketing agent CBRE is encouraged by recent strong take-up for nearby Jadescape project, citing the site's location near Singapore's Central Nature Reserve and the upcoming Bright Hill MRT Station. The site can support 900 units, and the authorities have approved the development. The public tender will close on October 31, adding to the growing disquiet in the collective sale market.

site_title: Software suite to speed up development of apps for govt e-services
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the introduction of the Singapore Government Technology Stack, a suite of common software tools to develop apps for government e-services, aiming to speed up development and reduce costs. The government will also move systems to the cloud over the next few years, benefiting from economies of scale. The move is part of Singapore's sixth strategic Smart Nation project, Codex, to improve IT infrastructure and cybersecurity.

site_title: Asean's diversity creates cyber security hurdles
summary: Southeast Asia's diverse countries face challenges in adopting a unified cyber security approach due to varying policies and regulations. Member states, such as Indonesia, Vietnam, and Thailand, are establishing legal frameworks to protect data from cyber attacks. Singapore's efforts to strengthen cyber security policies, including its Cybersecurity Act and Asean Cybersecurity Centre of Excellence, aim to foster cooperation among stakeholders. However, effective implementation and long-term repercussions must be considered to ensure economic growth and job security.

site_title: If the Tories don't pull together, Labour can gain power
summary: The UK's Conservative Party faces a potential threat of losing power if they fail to unite on Brexit. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn hopes to exploit divisions within the party, while Prime Minister Theresa May lacks a majority government. An Ipsos Mori poll shows 60% of voters dislike the Conservative party, while 60% prefer Labour. If the Tories fail to compromise, Labour may form a coalition with the Scottish National Party and Liberal Democrats, potentially gaining power in the next three years.

site_title: SGC paving the way for S'pore, German companies
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to serve as a hub for German investment in South-east Asia, according to the Singaporean-German Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SGC). The city-state's focus on the digital economy, smart cities, and high-end manufacturing presents opportunities for German companies to develop further in Industry 4.0 and startups. Despite challenges such as non-tariff barriers to trade and a shortage of qualified labor, the SGC advocates for German companies to tap into Singapore's competitive advantages and offers services to both German and Singaporean companies.

site_title: TransferWise to ride open-payment rails to quicken transactions
summary: TransferWise, a fintech firm, will start using Singapore's instant, round-the-clock payment rails, aiming to reduce downtime and lower costs. The move follows the startup's successful use of the Bank of England's payment rails earlier this year. TransferWise will not have a direct settlement account with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, instead opting for a settlement account from its banking partner. This change could add to overall costs, but the company expects to reduce fees for customers as it scales. Singapore's move to open up its payment rails to fintech firms is seen as a competitive advantage in building financial infrastructure.

site_title: SoftBank helps China's Bytedance sing a US$75b tune; firm could muscle in on the empire of US$400b Tencent
summary: SoftBank is set to invest $3 billion in Chinese startup Bytedance, valuing the company at $75 billion. Bytedance's popular apps, including Jinri Toutiao and TikTok, have attracted global attention and half a billion monthly active users worldwide. This investment will help Bytedance surpass Uber as the world's most valuable privately-held technology company, and potentially challenge Tencent's $400 billion empire. Bytedance's unique approach to short-videos and lack of subsidies make it an attractive option for advertisers and investors.

site_title: Singapore's new fund structure a step in right direction
summary: Singapore's new Variable Capital Company (VCC) fund structure aims to lure funds away from established domicile centers like the Cayman Islands, Dublin, and Luxembourg. Industry players welcome the move, citing flexibility and potential tax savings, but acknowledge that "very compelling" incentives are needed to break inertia. The VCC's ability to accommodate closed-end funds and offer greater flexibility in capital distribution may also be a draw. However, experts note that funds will need to weigh the costs and benefits of re-domiciling, with Singapore's reputation as a reputable financial center and existing structures in Hong Kong and Australia also being considerations.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Becoming lean, mean and agile
summary: Companies are shifting from traditional hierarchical structures to small, self-managing teams, adopting agile philosophy and toolsets. This trend is seen across industries, including IT, media, and manufacturing. Agile methodology, originally used in software development, is now being applied to various areas, such as creating new radio programs and human-resources procedures. This shift is driven by the need for flexibility and adaptability in a rapidly changing business landscape.

site_title: US: Dow closes at record but Facebook drags on S&P, Nasdaq
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at a record high on Tuesday, but the S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell due to a decline in Facebook shares. Dividend-paying sectors, such as utilities and consumer staples, rose, while the FANG group of stocks, including Facebook, Netflix, and Amazon, dragged down the Nasdaq. The Dow was boosted by trade-sensitive companies, including Boeing and Caterpillar, following the US-Mexico-Canada trade deal.
