Facebook fell 1.91% for the third straight session, and investors expressed concerns about the company's online security.

site_title: Shell says approves huge gas project in Canada
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has approved a huge liquefied natural gas project in Canada, LNG Canada, to meet growing Asian demand. The project, a joint venture between Shell and other companies, has a 40-year export license and all major environmental permits. Funding will come from Shell's annual capital investment guidance of $25-30 billion. The project is seen as critical for the world's transition to a lower carbon energy system, with global LNG demand expected to double by 2035, mainly driven by Asian growth.

site_title: Beyond the rhetoric, Britain, EU prepare to move forward on Brexit
summary: Britain and the EU are preparing concessions as part of a constructive dialogue to move forward on Brexit. The EU plans to put in writing its offer for future trade ties, while Britain has promised to bring a new proposal to unlock a stand-off over the Northern Ireland border. Both sides aim to avoid a no-deal Brexit, with the EU hoping to woo Britain into more compromises. Negotiations between the EU and British Brexit Minister Dominic Raab are expected to take place in Brussels next week, with a preliminary Brexit deal possible by the EU leaders' summit on October 18.

site_title: Next on BT: homes of the future
summary: Singapore is exploring ways to make homes more sustainable, liveable, and safer using smart technology. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) is using software to simulate urban interactions, design open spaces, and optimize building layout. Smart features in the upcoming Punggol Northshore Residences include smart lighting and a waste conveyance system, reducing energy usage by 40% and carbon footprints through clean energy. The initiative is part of Singapore's Smart Nation program, which aims to transform the country into a global city through technology and digital innovation.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens slightly lower on Italian concerns
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, October 2, 2018, due to turmoil in European markets following Italian lawmaker comments on the euro. Bank stocks were the biggest drags, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.01% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opening lower by 0.03% and 0.16% respectively.

site_title: Sembcorp is only bidder for Hyflux's Tuaspring plant: sources
summary: Sembcorp Industries Ltd is the sole bidder for Hyflux Ltd's Tuaspring plant, with an offer below the asset's book value of S$1.47 billion. The bid is insufficient to fully repay the project's main creditor, Malayan Banking Bhd. Hyflux, which is struggling with S$2.95 billion of liabilities, had granted approval to only two companies to study the asset before the Oct 1 deadline. The sale is seen as crucial for Hyflux to trim its debt load, with the company considering negotiating with Maybank or exploring other options with overseas investors.

site_title: Rex now plans to retain large stake in Oman concession
summary: REX International Holding plans to maintain a high equity stake in its Block 50 Oman licence after a feasibility study on the discovery well GA South#1 showed encouraging results. The company had previously considered farming out a substantial interest to reduce risks and obtain financing. Instead, Rex will aim for production in the second-half of 2019 and explore non-dilutive financing options. The company holds a 92.65% stake in Masirah Oil, which holds a 100% interest in the concession occupying 17,000 sq km of territory.

site_title: In mutual pursuit of innovation
summary: Singapore and Germany are strengthening their partnership in Industry 4.0 solutions, with a focus on innovation and co-innovation. The two countries have established a range of partnerships, including public and private sector collaborations, education, and research initiatives. The Singapore Smart Industry Readiness Index (SSRI) was developed in collaboration with German testing company TÜV SÜD to help companies assess their readiness for Industry 4.0 technologies. Germany's Heliatek and Singapore's vTrium have also collaborated on a large-scale organic photovoltaic power generation installation. The partnership aims to accelerate industrial transformation and foster new solutions, with over 10,000 visitors expected at the upcoming Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific (ITAP) trade show.

site_title: Faber Garden relaunching en bloc sale at same S$1.18b price
summary: Faber Garden, a 34-year-old freehold site in Angklong Lane, is relaunching its collective sale bid at S$1.18 billion. The site, zoned residential with a plot ratio of 1.6, has a maximum allowable GFA of 871,581 sq ft. The development charge for intensifying the GFA is approximately S$106.7 million. The new tender will close on Oct 31, and the upcoming Bright Hill MRT Station slated for 2021 is expected to support the proposed new development.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil trades near 4-year high as Iran export drop stokes concerns
summary: Oil prices rose 0.2% near a four-year high as investors worry about Iran's reduced exports due to impending US sanctions. The US-Mexico-Canada Agreement eased concerns about global commerce, but the market remains uncertain about Saudi Arabia and Russia's ability to replace Iranian barrels. Crude futures rose 16% since mid-August as supply losses from Iran and Venezuela continue to impact global markets.

site_title: Euro slips after Italian lawmaker's talk of lira return
summary: The euro plummeted to a six-week low on Tuesday after Italian lawmaker Claudio Borghi suggested that a national currency would resolve Italy's problems, sparking a market sell-off. The euro fell to $1.1505, its weakest since August 21, and dropped against the yen and Swiss franc. Investors are wary of Italian political developments, which have raised concerns about the country's debt and budget. The US dollar surged to a one-month high, while equities were sold. Despite a retraction by Borghi, the euro's weakness persists, raising concerns about the European Central Bank's stimulus plans.

site_title: GE's credit is under review for downgrade by Moody's
summary: General Electric's credit rating is under review for a potential downgrade by Moody's due to its disappointing 2018 earnings forecast, primarily caused by struggles in its power-equipment business. Moody's stated it would examine the deterioration and dim prospects of GE's power business, which may lead to a possible ratings cut, potentially affecting its A2 rating. New CEO Larry Culp faces significant challenges ahead, including a $23 billion charge related to the power unit.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Venture Corporation, a maker of the IQOS smokeless tobacco device, reported 1.8 million IQOS kits sold in Q2, with total users reaching 8.6 million as of August. The company's market share declined to 15.2% in Japan, but saw gains in European countries. In contrast, Sembcorp Industries faces a potential fine of up to S$100 million related to environmental claims, which could reduce its FY2018 profit forecast by 20%. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Singtel launches network for roaming mobile wallets in Asia
summary: Singtel launches VIA, a cross-border mobile payment alliance with AIS and Kasikornbank, allowing users to make payments in multiple currencies across Singapore and Thailand. The alliance enables consumers to use their local mobile wallets while traveling, and Singtel plans to expand the service to India, the Philippines, and Indonesia. The move aims to unify Asia's fragmented payments scene, with Singtel CEO Arthur Lang calling it a "game changer." The partnership also marks a step towards financial inclusion, with the goal of reaching 42 million Line chat users in Thailand.

site_title: German government reaches deal to clean up dirty diesel cars
summary: Germany's ruling coalition reached a deal with Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW to clean up emissions from older diesel vehicles to avoid driving bans in polluted urban areas. The plan, agreed upon by Chancellor Angela Merkel's government, aims to improve air quality in cities like Frankfurt and Stuttgart. This marks the second attempt to address the country's diesel crisis, following software upgrades last year that proved insufficient. The deal's details will be announced at a press conference.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks reopen with sharp losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.38% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 27,126.38. The decline was attributed to data showing Chinese manufacturing activity slowed in the previous month. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed due to a public holiday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.69 points to 1,798.15 on Tuesday, closing higher. The index saw a volume of 3 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 554 to 376.

site_title: Danske in historic management shift after six top people leave
summary: Danske Bank is undergoing an historic shift in its upper ranks after six top people left, including CEO Thomas Borgen, amid a money laundering scandal. The bank's chairman has signaled he might be next. The rapid turnover is new for the bank, which has only seen 12 other men hold the top job over 142 years. The bank's executive team is largely composed of people hired in the past five years. The bank's market value has plunged 30% this year, and analysts are uncertain about penalties ahead, with Danish authorities warning of a possible fine of up to $630 million.

site_title: Italy contagion fears bubbling beneath surface of apparent calm
summary: Italian bond yields surged to multi-year highs, fueling concerns of a potential contagion effect on European markets. The euro slumped to a six-week low, while the Swiss franc and German bunds rallied as investors sought safe-haven assets. Goldman Sachs warned of increased risk of a wider impact, despite Spain and Portugal showing little anxiety. Italian officials denied plans to leave the euro, but euroskeptic comments reignited fears of a potential breakup of the eurozone, with the cost of credit default protection rising and investors seeking to hedge against potential losses.

site_title: EU removes Palau from tax havens blacklist
summary: The European Union has removed Palau from its list of tax havens, moving it from the blacklist to a grey list of jurisdictions with low tax transparency standards. The decision follows Palau's commitment to changes in its tax rules and practices, which align with EU standards. Six other jurisdictions remain on the blacklist, including Namibia, Samoa, and US territories. The move is seen as a step towards greater transparency and cooperation in tax matters, although critics argue that renowned tax avoidance countries are not listed.

site_title: Tesla model 3 deliveries surge in move past Musk's controversies
summary: Tesla delivered 83,500 vehicles in the third quarter, doubling the total from the prior three months, with 55,840 being Model 3 sedans. This marks a significant milestone for the company, overcoming distractions from CEO Elon Musk's controversies. Musk had recently settled fraud charges and stepped down as chairman after agreeing to pay $20 million. The surge in deliveries could be pivotal to Tesla earning its first profit, with Musk acknowledging the company has left manufacturing "production hell" and is now facing "delivery logistics hell."

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.4% to 3,242.65, after 2.2 billion shares worth S$944 million changed hands. The market saw more losers than gainers, with 236 stocks falling and 149 rising. Nico Steel was the most actively traded stock, rising S$0.001 to S$0.007.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing outlook cools in September
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector saw a slight cooling in optimism in September, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling 0.2 points to 52.4, its 25th consecutive month of expansion. New orders, exports, and factory activity declined, while inventories hit a one-year low. The electronics sector, a linchpin of the economy, also saw a slight slowdown. Experts attribute the dip to a "popped bubble of hope" in August, with growth expected to moderate for the remaining months of 2018.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Hong Kong freezes chairman assets, alleges US$1.3b con
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) froze chairman assets totaling HK$4.64 billion (US$812.3 million) on suspicion of US$1.3 billion fraud. The person may be abroad or under investigation in China, and the company, Kingston Securities, has lost contact with the chairman. This is the largest asset freeze in Hong Kong history. The SFC ordered three brokerages to stop dealings with the person's accounts, amid a trend of missing chairmen from Hong Kong-listed Chinese firms and sudden share price plunges.

site_title: ECB supervisor sees no room for lowering capital demand on banks
summary: European Central Bank supervisor Pentti Hakkarainen stated there is no room to lower capital requirements for euro zone banks, citing a 2010 study that suggests an ideal Tier 1 capital ratio of 16-19% of risk-weighted assets. Currently, euro zone banks have an average Tier 1 capital ratio of 15.4%. Hakkarainen warned against "straight-jacketing" bankers and stifling innovation, emphasizing the need for flexibility in capital requirements to allow for business strategies and customer interests to be prioritized.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei inches up to new 27-year high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose to a 27-year high, closing at 24,270.62, driven by a cheap yen and advances on Wall Street. The key Nikkei 225 index added 0.10% for the third consecutive session, while the broader Topix index gained 0.33%. This marks the highest level since November 1991.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks see worst day in 7 weeks on US-China tension; won falls
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 1.25% to its lowest point in seven weeks, tracking Asian peers lower due to US-China tension. The won weakened, and bond yields also dropped. The finance minister warned of potential employment losses in September, despite a small jobs gain in August. Chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix closed lower, with analysts expecting Samsung to mark a peak in earnings. The Kospi has fallen 5.2% this year.

site_title: Parliament of Singapore approves new Variable Capital Companies (VCC) Bill
summary: Singapore's Parliament has approved the Variable Capital Companies (VCC) Bill, which aims to boost the country's fund management industry by allowing funds to both manage from and domicile in Singapore. The new entity will create new business opportunities for service providers, such as lawyers and accountants, and is expected to generate over 1,000 new jobs. The bill is seen as a game-changer for Singapore's fund management industry, which is already recognized as a leading Asian hub, with assets under management growing at an average 15% per annum.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Danske's crisis and the populist fallout the bank risks igniting
summary: Danske Bank faces a major money laundering scandal, with an estimated $235 billion potentially laundered through a tiny Estonian unit. The scandal has sparked concerns about Denmark's welfare state and voter confidence in institutions, echoing the populist wave of 2008. The bank's former CEO, Thomas Borgen, will leave with 12 months' pay, and investors are souring on the bank. Danish lawmakers have agreed to raise money laundering fines by 700% and may face fines of up to $630 million. The government is considering joining the European banking union to tackle the scandal.

site_title: Citigroup's investor guide for No-Deal Brexit, or a Corbyn upset
summary: Citigroup analysts have outlined two high-impact scenarios for the UK post-Brexit: a cliff-edge EU exit and the advent of a Labour government led by Jeremy Corbyn. A no-deal Brexit could trigger a large shock to UK output, inflation, and a 5-10% depreciation of the pound. A Corbyn government could lead to "maverick" economic ideas, but a softer Brexit could offset investment concerns. The pound could reach a new low under both scenarios, while UK stocks could be threatened by a no-deal or change in government.

site_title: Armenians pay last tribute to beloved singer Charles Aznavour
summary: Thousands of people in Yerevan, Armenia gathered to pay last respects to French singer Charles Aznavour, who died at 94 on Monday. Aznavour, of Armenian origin, was a national hero in Armenia and regarded as one of the most famous Armenians in the world. He will be remembered for his contributions to music and his heritage. A condolence book was signed by mourners, paying tribute to the beloved singer.

site_title: Parent's stake in Wheelock Properties clocks 88.17% ahead of close for general offer
summary: Wheelock Properties, a Singapore-listed company, has reached 88.17% stake ownership following a general offer of S$2.10 per share. The offeror aims to privatize the company and needs to control at least 90% stake to secure delisting. Analysts advise investors to consider alternatives like CapitaLand and UOL, citing potential for a second, better offer. Shareholders who haven't accepted the offer will have the right to require the offeror to purchase their shares at the offer price. The offer ends at 5:30pm on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SMRT's mobilityX raises Series A round led by Toyota Tsusho; deal size undisclosed
summary: MobilityX, backed by Singapore's SMRT Corp, has raised an undisclosed Series A round led by Toyota Tsusho Corp. The funding will be used to expand the company's integrated mobility-as-a-service solution in Singapore and the region. MobilityX is beta testing a subscription service combining public transport and first-and-last-mile services from various providers. A master collaboration agreement has also been signed with Toyota Tsusho to focus on technology development and regional expansion.

site_title: Mazda CEO welcomes new US, Canada, Mexico trade pact
summary: Mazda CEO Akira Marumoto welcomed the new US-Canada-Mexico trade pact, calling it a "big step forward." The deal maintains the auto industry's current footprint in North America, sparing Canada and Mexico from US national security tariffs. Mazda plans to work to meet new rules on components used in Mexico-made vehicles, with the goal of increasing regional value content to 75% from 62.5%. The updated pact effectively maintains the status quo for automakers operating in the region.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Faber Garden en bloc sale to relaunch with same S$1.18b price. Facebook unveils Startup Station, a startup accelerator programme for data-driven startups in South-east Asia. DBS Bank launches an online application service for instant credit card and credit line approvals. CapitaLand invests S$13.5m in co-working operator, while Ahmad Magad is appointed secretary-general of the Singapore Manufacturing Federation. Indonesian coal miner Resources Prima enters a MOU to acquire a Chinese property developer in a reverse takeover.

site_title: Australian shares close at 3-month low as financials extend losses; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares closed at a 3-month low, falling 0.8% to 6,126.2 points, as financial stocks extended losses following a Royal Commission report. The Big Four banks led the decline, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia dropping 1.2%. The central bank held interest rates steady for a 26th month, citing rising global borrowing costs and overseas funding for banks. New Zealand's benchmark index closed flat, while a private survey showed a 9-year low in business confidence.

site_title: Amazon raises minimum wage to US$15, urges rivals to follow
summary: Amazon raises its minimum wage to US$15 per hour for US employees, benefiting over 250,000 employees. The move aims to address criticism of working conditions and follows the "Fight for Fifteen" movement. Amazon will also lobby for a federal minimum wage increase and urges competitors to follow suit.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com said on Tuesday it would raise its minimum wage to US$15 per hour for US employees from next month, seeking to head off criticism of working conditions at the world's second most valuable company.

site_title: Rex now plans to retain large stake in Oman concession after positive feasibility study
summary: Rex International Holding plans to maintain a high equity stake in its Oman concession after a positive feasibility study for its discovery well, GA South#1. The study found the well to be a valuable asset, and Rex is now considering retaining its 92.65% stake in Masirah Oil, which holds the 100% interest in the Block 50 Oman concession. The company aims to achieve production in the second half of 2019, with the possibility of non-dilutive financing options to fund oil production costs.

site_title: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen battles cancer anew
summary: Billionaire Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, has announced a new battle with cancer, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, which has returned after he went into remission nine years ago. Allen, 65, plans to fight the disease aggressively and remains active in his business and charitable endeavors, including managing his wealth estimated at over $20 billion. His doctors are optimistic about the latest therapies and their effectiveness.

site_title: Singtel launches mobile payment alliance for cross-border travel
summary: Singtel launched VIA, a cross-border mobile payment alliance, with regional associate AIS and Kasikornbank, Thailand's largest digital bank. The alliance enables QR code-based mobile payments across Singapore and Thailand, with plans to expand to India, the Philippines, and Indonesia. VIA aims to unify Asia's fragmented payments scene, supporting financial inclusion and a single digital market. The partnership allows customers to use their local mobile wallets abroad, and Singtel is open to working with China's Ping An eWallet.

site_title: Opec output edges higher as Iran losses offset by other members
summary: Opec's 15 nations increased production to 32.83 million barrels per day in September, offsetting Iran's 140,000 barrel decline. Saudi Arabia, Angola, and Libya contributed to the increase, while Iran's shipments fell 1.1 million barrels per day. US sanctions on Iran, combined with Venezuela's economic crisis, have driven crude prices to a three-year high. Despite President Trump's demand for increased production, Opec members have been cautious, with Saudi Arabia raising output by 80,000 barrels per day.

site_title: The Frieze Art Fair is going Hollywood
summary: The Frieze Art Fair is set to debut in Los Angeles next year, with Frieze co-founder Amanda Sharp stating a desire to build on the city's existing contemporary art foundation. The event, scheduled for February 14-17, will be led by local art impresario Bettina Korek as executive director. This move aims to bring together desire, fantasy, and commerce, marking a shift in the city's emerging status as an important contemporary art hub.

site_title: Singapore Manufacturing Federation names Ahmad Magad as new secretary-general
summary: The Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) has appointed Ahmad Magad as its new secretary-general, effective October 16, 2018. Magad, who was previously vice-president, replaces Andy Yun, who left the position about a month ago to pursue his own interests. SMF president Douglas Foo expressed confidence in Magad's ability to strengthen the tripartite relationship between the government, SMF, and companies, ultimately benefiting the manufacturing sector and SMF members.

site_title: Australia's competition watchdog opens inquiry into forex services
summary: Australia's competition watchdog, the ACCC, has opened an inquiry into foreign currency conversion services, examining price competition and mark-ups from wholesale currency rates. The inquiry aims to investigate why major banks, including the Big Four, consistently charge high prices for currency conversions. The ACCC will also look into why the exchange rate offered by banks differs from the rate found online. The inquiry's final report is due by May 2019, with the goal of improving price transparency and competition in the foreign currency market.

site_title: Owner asks S$41m for Three Buckley duplexes near Newton
summary: The owner of the Three Buckley duplexes in Newton, Singapore, has put the S$41 million freehold residential project up for sale by expression of interest. The development comprises 11 strata duplex units, with most tenanted and owned by a single company. Located in prime District 11, the property offers investors flexibility in leasing to different resident profiles, including young families, expatriates, and working adults. Interested parties can bid for single or multiple units, with the exercise closing on November 8, 2018.

site_title: Australia holds key interest rate as housing downturn threatens consumers
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank kept interest rates at a record low of 1.5% amid a housing downturn, with house prices down 6.1% in Sydney and nationally over the past year. Governor Philip Lowe cited the need for a cooling effect on the property market to safeguard financial stability, while the economy remains strong with growth over 3% and unemployment at 5.3%. The decision aims to prevent consumption from being impacted by declining relative wealth, and Lowe expects gradual progress in reducing unemployment and inflation.

images.alt_text: Australia kept interest rates at a record low Tuesday as it gauges the impact of falling property prices on an economy that's otherwise showing strong growth and hiring.

site_title: Dozens of students found dead as Indonesia rescue ramps up
summary: Dozens of students were found dead in a landslide-swamped church in Sulawesi, Indonesia, as rescue efforts continue. At least 844 people have been confirmed dead, but officials predict the death toll could rise into the thousands. The discovery comes after a powerful earthquake triggered a tsunami that hit the city of Palu on Friday, leaving nearly 200,000 people displaced. The international response is ramping up, with rescue efforts focusing on isolated communities.

site_title: DBS, POSB to provide instant approvals for credit cards, credit line
summary: DBS Bank and POSB have launched an online application service that allows customers to receive instant approval for credit cards and credit lines. The service, which uses the national platform MyInfo, enables customers to submit online applications without providing physical documents. This is part of a broader trend in Singapore's banking industry, with UOB and OCBC Bank also integrating MyInfo into their digital application and approval processes. The move aims to streamline customer onboarding and reduce wait times, with DBS expecting to increase MyInfo adoption and roll out more services by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: New Zealand business confidence sinks to 9-year low, puts central bank on alert
summary: New Zealand business confidence has plummeted to a nine-year low, with 30% of firms expecting general business conditions to deteriorate, according to a survey. This has led to a possible rate cut in coming quarters and sent the local dollar to a two-week low. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is on high alert, with concerns about the potential drag on the economy amid international trade tensions and gloomy business sentiment.

site_title: Germany to present plan for polluting diesel cars
summary: Germany's government will present a plan to address the crisis caused by polluting diesel cars, aiming to reduce city air pollutants while minimizing costs for car owners. The compromise, reached after late-night discussions between Chancellor Angela Merkel and her coalition partners, is expected to be presented on Tuesday. Manufacturers may face a significant bill for the emissions cheating scandal. The plan seeks to secure mobility in cities while achieving clean air, with details to be revealed on Tuesday.

site_title: Neither rich nor crazy: film noir sheds light on Singapore's migrant labourers
summary: A Singaporean film noir, A Land Imagined, sheds light on the lives of the city-state's 280,000 migrant workers, who build its affluent structures. The story follows a Chinese labourer who goes missing on a building site, prompting a detective's search. The film highlights the precarious existence of these workers, often overlooked in discussions of Singapore's opulence. By exploring the lives of migrant workers, the film noir humanizes this often-marginalized group, revealing a more nuanced side of Singapore's affluent city-state.

site_title: Indian national charged with trying to extort S$500,000 from StanChart in Singapore
summary: A 35-year-old Indian national, Nagarajan Balajee, was charged in court for attempting to extort S$500,000 from Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore. He allegedly threatened to publish defamatory libel against the bank's global head of digital banking unless paid. Balajee used fictitious email accounts and masked his identity with VPN services. He faces a jail term of 2-5 years and caning if found guilty.

images.alt_text: A 35-year-old man who tried to extort half a million dollars from Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore was charged in court on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened down on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.26% to 27,716.16. The decline occurred as investors returned from a long weekend and mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday.

site_title: Emirates executive says M&A isn't in DNA of long-haul carrier
summary: Emirates, the largest long-haul airline, remains opposed to acquiring other airlines through mergers and acquisitions, according to Hubert Frach, its head of commercial operations. The airline prioritizes organic growth, citing its success formula as speed, independence, and agility. Frach denied reports of talks to combine Emirates and Etihad, its rival airline, and emphasized that while cooperation is possible, a merger is not in its DNA. The airline's focus on organic growth is driven by its desire for independence and agility in the competitive aviation market.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip as Nafta lift fades; oil near 4-year highs
summary: Asian stocks declined on Tuesday, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan falling 1% as cautious views on the global economy curbed risk sentiment. The US and Canada forged a deal to salvage the North American free trade deal, Nafta, which had boosted the S&P 500 earlier in the day. The euro zone's manufacturing growth slowed to a two-year low, and the US dollar rose to an 11-month high against the yen. Oil prices edged up, with US crude futures rising 0.25% to $75.48 a barrel.

site_title: PwC says more tech is solution for higher audit standards
summary: PwC's global chairman Bob Moritz says the Big Four accounting firms can raise audit standards through technology investments, countering UK lawmakers' calls to break up the firms. PwC will invest $1 billion in "Cloud" computing by 2019, allowing for more data harvesting and tougher checks on company accounts. Moritz defends the firms, stating that any market intervention must be well-thought out and noting that the industry has already offered temporary, voluntary limits on audit services to help smaller rivals expand.

site_title: Manhattan home sales tumble in a market clogged with listings
summary: Manhattan home sales declined 11% in the third quarter, with 2,987 purchases, the fourth straight quarter of decline, according to a report by Miller Samuel Inc. and Douglas Elliman Real Estate. Listings increased 13% to 6,925 homes, the most since 2011. Buyers are seeking bargains, pushing for discounts, and the median price of completed purchases fell 4.5% to $1.12 million. Sellers are expected to adjust prices, with average co-op prices falling for all apartment sizes, including a 17% decline for three-bedroom homes.

site_title: Axiata's Asia dream fades as rivals bid for its overseas units
summary: Axiata Group Bhd's expansion plans in southern Asia are fading as it risks losing its overseas units to rivals. The Malaysian carrier received an offer from Singapore Press Holdings and Keppel Corp to buy out its stake in M1, a challenge to its regional presence. Despite its presence in 11 countries and expansion into tower infrastructure, Axiata faces higher competition and regulatory hurdles, leading analysts to predict it will focus on growth at home and in Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,215.09, down 0.13%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Tuesday afternoon at 3,215.09, down 0.13% due to a weak morning. Gainers and losers were evenly matched, with 162 securities down and 152 up after 1.1 billion securities worth S$419.4 million changed hands. Nico Steel Holdings and Rex International Holding led the gains, with shares rising 33.3% and 1.8% respectively.

site_title: Record sale of US$65 million Zao painting yields 2,735 per cent return
summary: A Chinese-French abstract oil painting by Zao Wou-Ki sold for HK$510.4 million (US$65 million) at Sotheby's, setting a new record for an Asian oil painting sold at auction. The buyer, Taiwanese businessman Chang Qiu Dun, paid US$2.3 million in 2005 for the 10-meter triptych, yielding a 2,735% return on investment. The sale demonstrates the growing importance of Asian artists and the region's increasing presence in the global art market, with Sotheby's achieving a record HK$1.56 billion in sales from its Modern and Contemporary auctions.

site_title: Google teams with Ubisoft to test video game streaming
summary: Google has partnered with Ubisoft to test its video game streaming platform, Project Stream, with the release of "Assassin's Creed Odyssey" on October 5, 2018. The test will be limited to the US and will allow a select number of people to play the game streamed to Chrome browsers on desktop or laptop computers. The goal of the test is to push the limits of Project Stream technology and provide a seamless gaming experience. The test will also be available on PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and personal computers via disk or download.

site_title: Toyota says hard Brexit would temporarily halt UK factory
summary: Toyota's European operations head, Johan van Zyl, stated that a hard Brexit would require the temporary halt of UK factory production. This would be due to logistics disruptions, forcing a stoppage. Toyota wants tariff-free trading after Brexit. The company's Burnaston factory, which produces vehicles for the European market, would be affected, with about 87% of its vehicles exported to EU customers. A production halt would be difficult to estimate, but would likely be temporary due to Toyota's just-in-time production system.

site_title: Former Malaysia PM's wife Rosmah stands to give evidence over RM60m in unpaid jewellery
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's wife Rosmah Mansor may be required to give evidence in a lawsuit over RM60 million in unpaid jewelry. A Lebanese jeweller, Samer Halimeh, claims Rosmah owes him the money for 44 pieces of jewelry seized in government raids. Rosmah has applied to strike out the case, citing anti-money laundering laws, but Halimeh's lawyer says she will have to give evidence if her application is rejected. A decision on Rosmah's application is expected soon.

site_title: Coffee industry could act to raise prices: Brazil association ABIC
summary: Brazil's coffee industry may take joint action to combat low global prices, such as restricting supply, after the country's election on October 7. The industry is concerned about the impact of a weak real currency and widespread shortselling of coffee futures, which has pushed prices in New York to a 12-year low. Industry representatives acknowledge that a decision can only be made after the election, but say that once the elections pass, the dollar will establish an equilibrium, and prices will improve.

site_title: Doors open to London's latest vegan venture: fish and chips
summary: London's latest vegan venture, a fish and chips restaurant, has opened its doors with a unique menu featuring "vegan fish" alternatives. The restaurant, owned by Daniel Sutton, initially tested the concept with high demand and has since introduced a full menu of scampi, prawn cocktail, and other traditional fish and chips dishes. Sutton's innovative approach has been met with success, offering a plant-based twist on a classic British dish.

site_title: Are we wired to sit?
summary: A new neurological study suggests that people may be wired to be physically lazy, despite knowing the benefits of exercise. The study found that certain electrical signals in the brain can override intentions to work out, even when people plan to exercise. The authors hope that understanding this phenomenon can help motivate individuals to move more, potentially leading to improved physical health and well-being.

site_title: Government e-services to be created more quickly, cheaply with common suite of software tools: PM Lee
summary: Singapore is transforming its government software development with the introduction of a common suite of software tools, the Singapore Government Technology Stack (SGTS), to create e-services more quickly and cheaply. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the move at the Stack 2018 Developer Conference, aiming to reduce costs and improve efficiency. The government plans to migrate some systems to the cloud over the next few years to benefit from economies of scale, while others will have to design and build their own government cloud to share resources and enhance security.

site_title: Singaporean oil trader gets 12 years in Chinese prison over tariff evasion
summary: A former Singaporean oil trader, Yin Dikun, was sentenced to 12 years in Chinese prison for evading Chinese tariffs on oil imports. Yin, a managing director for Gunvor Group Ltd, was found guilty of evading 378 million yuan (S$75 million) in tariff payments on 1.3 million tons of oil products. Gunvor, the company, denies any liability, stating that the relevant tariffs were conducted properly in the Philippines. This is not the first time a former Gunvor employee has faced legal trouble, with another employee recently receiving an 18-month suspended sentence for bribery.

site_title: Australia: Financials drag shares to near 3-week lows; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to a near three-week low, with financials dragging down the S&P/ASX 200 index. The Royal Commission report's interim findings on the financial sector led to losses, with National Australia Bank and Westpac Banking Corp dropping 1% each. Energy stocks rose, led by Origin Energy's 2.6% gain, while New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1%. Business confidence in New Zealand sank to a nine-year low, citing concerns over government policy and labor costs.

site_title: China, India: Markets closed for holiday on Tuesday
summary: Financial markets in China and India were closed on October 2, 2018, for public holidays. This article is unrelated to the provided content, which discusses various stock market news and trends in Singapore, Asia, Europe, the US, and other regions, including new funding rounds and market performances.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.05% to 1792.73 on Tuesday, with 151 gainers outweighing 56 losers. Volume reached 146.4 million lots worth RM50.38 million.

site_title: Facebook, IMDA's startup accelerator to kick off in February 2019 in Singapore
summary: Facebook has launched Startup Station, a startup accelerator programme in partnership with the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) in Singapore. The programme, set to start in February 2019, aims to empower data-driven startups in South-east Asia to accelerate their businesses while maintaining user trust and data control. The initiative is designed to foster innovation and collaboration between startups and corporations, ultimately driving the development of cutting-edge technologies in the region.

site_title: Britain will stop favouring EU workers after Brexit: PM
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May announced that the country will end preferential access for European Union workers after Brexit, aiming to attract high-skilled immigrants from anywhere. This decision comes ahead of plans for a single system for EU and non-EU countries, set to be published later this year and a bill in 2019.

site_title: Twin quakes hit off Indonesian island of Sumba: USGS
summary: Two earthquakes struck off Indonesia's Sumba island on October 2, 2018, with a 5.9-magnitude quake followed by a 6.0-magnitude quake 15 minutes later. The quakes occurred 40km off the island's coast and 30km below the surface. Sumba, home to 750,000 people, is 1,600km from Sulawesi, which was hit by a devastating quake and tsunami on Friday, killing over 800 people.

site_title: Katrina acquires first Japanese restaurants for S$952,767
summary: Katrina Group has agreed to acquire Tomo Izakaya, a two-restaurant Japanese establishment in Singapore, for S$952,767 in cash. The purchase price includes S$575,000 as an initial payment plus the estimated net tangible asset value of S$377,767. The acquisition is expected to expand Katrina's brand offerings and serve a new type of cuisine. The deal will not impact the company's existing earnings per share and net tangible asset per share.

site_title: Japan PM Abe to keep key ministers in posts in cabinet reshuffle
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a cabinet reshuffle, retaining key ministers including Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso, Chief Cabinet Minister Yoshihide Suga, and Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi. Abe aims to maintain stability ahead of his attempt to revise Japan's post-war constitution. The reshuffle also includes Takeshi Iwaya as new Defense Minister and Akira Amari as LDP executive for election strategy. The move comes amid challenges, including trade tensions with the US and economic concerns, including a decline in business confidence.

site_title: Slow payments up for second straight quarter in Q3: Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau
summary: Singapore's payment performance declined for the second consecutive quarter in Q3 2018, with slow payments rising to over a third of transactions. Prompt payments fell to 48.31% and partial payments remained steady at 12.74%. The retail sector saw a sharp increase in slow payments, largely due to weaker sales in food and beverage and automobiles. Despite this, overall payment performance has not deteriorated significantly, with slight improvements seen across most sectors.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Giant Brazil farms look to close tech divide
summary: Brazil's vast farms are seeking to close the tech divide by implementing high-tech solutions to automate agriculture. Illinois-based Deere & Co. launched a program to connect Brazil's farm fields to a data network, while AGCO Corp. is exploring linking its gear to the cloud via satellite. This will enable farmers to monitor field work remotely, analyze data, and make timely decisions about planting and harvesting schedules. The goal is to boost yields and increase efficiency, with projected annual growth of 14% to $10 billion by 2025.

site_title: Even in new trade deal, US plays hardball with China
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a new trade deal with Canada and Mexico, but maintained pressure on China, stating it's "too early to talk" about a truce. The US has imposed tariffs on $250 billion in Chinese annual exports, and Trump has threatened to target the remaining half, worsening relations. The new US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) includes a provision that allows any partner to terminate the agreement if a trade deal with a "non-market economy" (China) is not reached, signaling a strategy to counter China.

site_title: Australia's competition regulator opens inquiry into forex services
summary: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has launched an inquiry into foreign currency conversion services, focusing on price competition among suppliers, particularly among the Big Four banks. The ACCC aims to investigate why major companies can charge high prices and will examine how easily new entrants can compete. The inquiry will also look at how currency prices are presented to customers. A final report will be submitted to the Treasurer by May 2019.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Thakral, Oxley, Q&M, Katrina
summary: Thakral Corp invested in a hotel and two office buildings in Osaka, Japan, for S$66 million. Oxley Holdings sold 40% of its Mayfair Gardens condominium project, while Q&M Dental Group aborted a HK$4 million acquisition deal. Katrina Group acquired its first Japanese restaurant, Tomo Izakaya, for S$952,767. Delong Holdings halted trading pending an announcement.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.2% to 3,248.85
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.2% to 3,248.85 at Tuesday's open, down 6.61 points. A mix of gains and losses in US markets overnight led to the decline. Notable movers included AEM Holdings, KrisEnergy, OCBC Bank, and DBS Group Holdings. Despite a 5-day rally, investors appear cautious ahead of GDP data, with no major economic announcements scheduled for Tuesday.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens up after passing 27-year high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index opened higher on Tuesday, reaching a 27-year high, driven by a cheap yen and US market advances. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.5% to 24,367, while the Topix index gained 0.6% to 1,828.85. The benchmark closed at its best level since November 1991 on Monday. The gains were attributed to a positive market sentiment despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Macron blocks interior minister resignation bid
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron refused to accept the resignation of Interior Minister Gerard Collomb, who had announced his intention to step down to run for mayor of Lyon in 2020. This decision comes amidst uncertainty at the government, following the resignations of Environment Minister Nicolas Hulot and Sports Minister Laura Flessel. Macron's approval ratings have been declining, and the French public is starting to sour on his energetic centrist policies.

site_title: Trump clears deck for China trade war by striking new Nafta deal
summary: US President Donald Trump has cleared the decks of disputes with other trading competitors, setting the stage for a potential trade war with China. Trump has recently signed trade agreements with Canada, Mexico, South Korea, and Japan, including provisions aimed at limiting Chinese exports. Analysts believe the US can now focus on China, which is expected to slow its GDP growth, increasing pressure on policymakers.

site_title: CapitaLand takes 50% stake in co-working operator
summary: CapitaLand has invested S$13.5 million for a 50% stake in co-working operator The Work Project Kingdom (TWPK) and extended another S$13.5 million in shareholder loans. The move is part of CapitaLand's "core-flex" model to build offices of the future with flexible space. TWPK will lease space at CapitaLand's Capital Tower and Asia Square Tower, increasing the occupancy rate at AST 2 to 97%. The total rent payable for the leased space is estimated at S$43.4 million over five years.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Carmakers brace for shocks as electrified future looms
summary: Carmakers are bracing for the electrified future of the automotive industry, with premium brands like Mercedes and Audi showcasing electric vehicles at the Paris Motor Show. The promise of self-driving cars is also on display, with dozens of startups attending the event. According to Luc Chatel, head of the French auto industry association, electric vehicles require 100 million lines of code, five to six times more than a Boeing. The shift towards electrification and autonomous vehicles poses significant challenges for carmakers, but also presents opportunities for growth and innovation.

site_title: Europe: Trade pact lifts European shares while Italy extends slide
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Monday, boosted by a US-Mexico-Canada trade pact, while Italian stocks slid 0.6% amid concerns over the government's budget plans. Ryanair plummeted 7.5% after a profit warning, while Fresenius gained 8.3% after a Delaware judge ruled it could back out of a deal. Linde rose 6.2% after receiving Chinese antitrust approval for its Praxair merger. The European Commission warned Italy's budget plans may break EU rules.

site_title: With renewed Nafta deal, Trump opens door to metal tariff accord
summary: US and Canadian negotiators have secured a new Nafta deal, replacing the 24-year-old agreement, but steel and aluminum tariffs imposed by US President Donald Trump remain in place. The tariffs, imposed under the USMCA deal, will be dealt with separately over the next two months. Canada is pushing to resolve the metal tariffs before the USMCA is signed, with a 60-day negotiation period allowed under the agreement. The US has opened the door to an agreement on quotas, but no resolution has been reached yet.

site_title: Former classmate says Trump court nominee downplayed his drinking
summary: A former classmate of Brett Kavanaugh, Chad Ludington, has claimed that the Supreme Court nominee was a heavy drinker and downplayed his drinking in Senate testimony. Ludington stated that Kavanaugh was "belligerent and aggressive" when he drank, contradicting Kavanaugh's previous statements. Ludington, a professor at North Carolina State University, contacted the FBI with his information, challenging Kavanaugh's credibility. This new information raises questions about Kavanaugh's character and potential impact on his confirmation process.

site_title: Coal miner Resources Prima enters MOU to buy China property developer in reverse takeover
summary: Resources Prima Group, an Indonesian coal miner, has entered into a binding MOU to acquire ChongQing HuangYang Property Development in a reverse takeover for S$33 million. The deal will see Resources Prima issue new shares to satisfy the payment. The company is facing financial and business viability issues, including severe cash flow constraints, and has been suspended from trading. Resources Prima plans to write to the Singapore Exchange to seek a further extension of time to complete the acquisition and submit a proposal to address its issues.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Top iron ore shipper warns China is at 'peak steel'
summary: China's steel production is forecast to peak in 2018 and decline in 2019 and 2020, according to the Australian government, driven by stricter environmental regulations and government policies. The expected drop in production will add to headwinds for iron ore, with prices expected to drop to US$51.90/ton in 2019 and US$50.70/ton in 2020. Global output is expected to hold steady, aided by expansions outside China. This contrasts with some miners' outlooks, including BHP Billiton, which believes Chinese steel production will peak in the middle of the next decade.

images.alt_text: The world's largest steel market is about to go into reverse.

site_title: Night School aces exams at US box office
summary: Kevin Hart's comedy film Night School topped the US box office with an estimated US$28 million, nearly paying off its production costs. It was followed by Warner Bros' family animation Smallfoot, which earned US$23 million. The House With a Clock in Its Walls and A Simple Favor rounded out the top three. Overall, the September month brought strong box office numbers, with the second-best September ever, according to BoxOfficeMojo.

site_title: Trump administration says trade pact will bring auto jobs back to US
summary: The Trump administration claims the new US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) will bring tens of thousands of auto jobs back to the US, particularly among suppliers. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross cites higher regional content and wages as key requirements, which he believes will lead to a shift of production back to the US. However, industry executives and analysts are less optimistic, warning that higher costs could hurt sales and production. The deal's impact on employment remains unclear, and some experts predict potential job losses if tariffs are imposed on non-Nafta trading partners.

site_title: Why Trump may look abroad after mid-terms
summary: US President Donald Trump is planning to travel abroad after the mid-term elections, potentially running for re-election in 2020 against a hostile Democratic Congress. History suggests that the president's party loses House seats in mid-terms, and Trump may be stymied in his domestic agenda. Instead, he may focus on foreign policy, particularly if Democrats make significant gains, including de-escalating tensions with North Korea and managing trade disputes with China. This shift could be a strategic move to establish a legacy if he fails to be re-elected.

site_title: Eurozone battles Italy as EU budget row deepens
summary: Eurozone finance ministers warned Italy to abide by EU rules on public spending, amid a budget row that has spooked markets and raised concerns of a debt crisis. Italy recently announced a big spending boost, prompting Rome to accuse Brussels of economic "terrorism." The meeting between eurozone ministers left Dutch Finance Minister Wopke Hoekstra "somewhat less optimistic" about the situation, highlighting the growing tensions between Rome and Brussels.

site_title: Euro chiefs dismayed by Italy's budget as Juncker evokes Greece
summary: Italian finance minister Giovanni Tria's budget proposal was met with dismay by eurozone chiefs, with Commissioner Pierre Moscovici warning of a potential Greek-style crisis. The yield on Italian 10-year bonds reached its highest level in four years, and the spread over German bunds increased. EU President Jean-Claude Juncker expressed concerns, saying "one crisis was enough" and urging Italy to avoid a repeat of the Greece crisis. The Italian government's budget targets, including a 2.4% deficit, are at odds with eurozone rules, and negotiations are ongoing.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us lenders plan brand revival as they cancel IP auction
summary: Toys 'R' Us lenders plan to revive the brand by reorganizing its assets into a new company, maintaining current license agreements and investing in new retail businesses. The decision comes after canceling a plan to auction off the company's intellectual property. Maintaining the brand under a new independent US business was deemed the best option for the recovery of the Toys 'R' Us estate and its stakeholders. The court authorized the cancellation of the auction, allowing the lenders to control the rights to the company's name, including Solus Alternative Asset Management and Angelo Gordon.

site_title: Nordea moves HQ to Finland, becomes 8th 'too big to fail' bank to join the eurozone
summary: Nordea Bank Abp is moving its headquarters to Helsinki, Finland, becoming the 8th 'too big to fail' bank to join the eurozone. The bank, with US$670 billion in assets, aims to be part of the European banking union and has sold off assets outside the Nordic region. CEO Casper von Koskull stated that the bank will not focus on size and instead adopt automated and digitized services to stay competitive. The move is expected to significantly change Finland's financial industry, with finance assets swelling to 400% of its GDP.

site_title: Half of women at risk of dementia, Parkinson's, stroke: study
summary: A study published in the Journal of Neurology Neurosurgery and Psychiatry found that nearly half of women and one in three men are at risk of developing stroke or degenerative neurological diseases such as dementia and Parkinson's during their lifetime. Researchers tracked over 12,000 healthy people from 1990 to 2016 and found that women aged 45 or older had a 48% risk, while men had a 36% risk. The study suggests that a healthy lifestyle can reduce the risk of these diseases by 20-50%.

site_title: Selfie culture has made art museums cave on strict 'no photo' policies
summary: Selfie culture has led some art museums to reconsider their strict "no photo" policies. The shift is seen as a way for museums to tap into the potential of social media as publicists. Some museums have already dropped the rule, while others are reevaluating it. By allowing visitors to take photos, museums hope to increase engagement and reach a broader audience. This change reflects the evolving way people consume and interact with art, with social media playing a significant role.

site_title: General Electric replaces CEO with outsider; shares soar
summary: General Electric (GE) ousted CEO John Flannery with outsider Larry Culp, who will tackle the company's problems aggressively. GE will take a $23 billion charge to write off goodwill in its power division, primarily from a large 2015 acquisition. The company also fell short of its forecast for free cash flow and earnings per share for 2018. GE shares jumped 7% to close at $12.09, with analysts expecting Culp to make difficult decisions on cost to transform the company's portfolio.

site_title: Trudeau sets out to sell Canadians on trade pact
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau hailed a new trade pact with the US and Mexico as "profoundly beneficial" for Canadians, replacing a 24-year-old pact. The deal was reached after over a year of negotiations. However, Canadian dairy farmers and steel workers expressed skepticism due to market protections and US tariffs on steel and aluminum. Trudeau must now sell the deal to these groups and the public.

site_title: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen treated again for cancer
summary: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen has started treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the same type of cancer he overcame nine years ago in 2009. In a statement, Allen expressed optimism about the latest therapies and his ability to fight the disease aggressively while staying involved in philanthropy and business. This marks the second time Allen has treated for the cancer, and he remains committed to his philanthropic and business endeavors.

site_title: Paris names its first street after fashion designer Sonia Rykiel
summary: Paris has named its first street after fashion designer Sonia Rykiel, in recognition of her contributions to the city's fashion scene. The "Allee Sonya Rykiel" was declared open by Mayor Anne Hidalgo, who praised Rykiel for giving Parisians a taste of freedom. This marks the first time a French capital street has been named after a fashion designer, with no plans to name streets after Coco Chanel due to her wartime collaboration with the Nazis.

site_title: Danske names interim CEO as Borgen is relieved of his duties
summary: Danske Bank A/S has appointed Jesper Nielsen as interim CEO, replacing Thomas Borgen, following his role in a European money laundering scandal. The bank admitted to laundering 200 billion euros, sparking criminal investigations and a European probe into local regulators. Nielsen, who has been with the bank since 1996, will start immediately as interim CEO, while a permanent replacement is sought. The move aims to restore confidence in the bank's management amid a plunge in its market value and investors' concerns.

site_title: US factory activity slows in Sept; construction spending edges up
summary: US factory activity slowed in September, with the Institute for Supply Management's index dropping 1.5 points to 59.8, the lowest since May 2004. Despite this, demand remained "robust" and employment increased, with factories hiring more workers. The slowdown was attributed to a moderation in new orders, while export orders rose. Construction spending edged up 0.1% in August, with public construction projects rising 2.0% to a 10-month high.

site_title: Roberto Cavalli branches into hotel interior design with DAMAC deal
summary: Italian fashion house Roberto Cavalli has partnered with DAMAC Properties to provide interior design for at least five luxury hotels, starting with a 2023 project in Dubai. The deal aims to expand the luxury brand into lifestyle categories and boost revenue. The company is on track to break even this year and return to a net profit in 2019, with management focusing on executing a growth strategy supported by shareholder Clessidra.

site_title: Twitter ramps up fight against fake profiles before US midterm elections
summary: Twitter is intensifying its efforts to combat fake profiles and spam ahead of the US midterm elections. The company removed 50 fake accounts in August, and is now expanding its methods to identify fake accounts, including scrutinizing those with stock or stolen avatar photos. Twitter has also improved its algorithms to identify spam and automated accounts, and is suspending 30,000 developer applications per month. The company's efforts come as other tech platforms, including Facebook and YouTube, also ramp up their efforts to combat foreign influence campaigns and election interference.

images.alt_text: Twitter Inc is ramping up the fight against fake profiles and spam in an effort to clean up its platform ahead of the US November midterm elections.

site_title: Discretionary portfolios a growth area for private banks
summary: Asian private clients are increasingly shifting towards discretionary portfolios, with growth rates exceeding 20% annually. Banks such as Bank of Singapore, UBS, and Credit Suisse are expanding their discretionary portfolio management (DPM) services to generate recurring fee income. DPM assets under management have grown significantly, with Bank of Singapore's assets reaching $8 billion and UBS's assets accounting for 65% of total AUM in Asia. Risk control measures include asset allocation, diversification, and tactical asset allocation. Private banks remain positive on equities and emerging markets, with some predicting a buffer against trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Tesla's SEC deal provides ammunition for US probe and investor lawsuits
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk and the company agreed to pay $20 million each to settle SEC charges that Musk misled investors by tweeting about a go-private deal. Musk will step down as board chairman, and two independent directors will be added to the board. The settlement may provide relief for investors but could bolster claims of stock market losses, potentially leading to further lawsuits and a Justice Department probe.

site_title: Tech can amplify great teaching - but it can't replace bad teaching
summary: OECD official Andreas Schleicher emphasizes that technology can amplify great teaching but not replace bad teaching. He highlights the benefits of technical and vocational education and training (TVET), citing its effectiveness in easing school-to-work transitions and serving the economy. Schleicher stresses the importance of collaboration, adaptation, and precision in digital learning systems to suit individual learners' needs. He also notes that TVET can only succeed if it is attractive to both learners and employers, and that fair competition is essential to maintain its relative attractiveness.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Bottoms up!
summary: Cognac's popularity is experiencing a significant surge, driven by its luxury appeal and complex flavor profile. The brand has seen a 10.8% growth in exports to over $3 billion in 2017, with top destinations including the US, Singapore, and China. Luxury cognac makers, such as Hennessy, are expanding production to meet the demand, with the company opening a new plant in France to meet US and Asian demand. The brand's image is evolving, with rappers and celebrities investing in cognac, and the industry is exploring new ways to drink cognac, including neat or with mixers.

site_title: Abstract Zao Wou-Ki painting fetches US$65m
summary: A 10-meter-long triptych by Chinese painter Zao Wou-Ki, titled Juin-Octobre 1985, sold for US$65 million at Sotheby's Hong Kong, setting a world auction record for the artist. The painting, commissioned by architect I M Pei, represents a fusion of Eastern and Western techniques and philosophy. Zao Wou-Ki's largest work, it surpassed the previous record held by 29.01.64, also sold by Christie's for US$26 million last year.

site_title: 'Don't bully us': Britain takes new combative tone to Brexit talks
summary: Britain's Brexit Minister Dominìc Raab has taken a combative tone in Brexit talks with the EU, warning that the bloc cannot bully the UK into a deal. Raab criticized the EU for its approach, saying it was "one-sided" and "unconstructive." He called on the EU to match Britain's "ambition and pragmatism" in negotiations, following a tense summit in Salzburg. The UK is set to leave the EU in March 2019, and a "no-deal Brexit" is increasingly possible, with businesses preparing for the worst-case scenario.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa - NTUC Income goes viral
summary: NTUC Income's "Best Gift for Your Child" advertisement has garnered over 20 million views on its Money FM podcast, "Coffee with Claressa". The team behind the ad, including Marcus Chew, Janson Choo, and Khairul Mondzi, discussed its conception and creation in an episode of the podcast. The ad's success highlights the effectiveness of NTUC Income's marketing strategies.

site_title: Oil rises to 2014 highs on Iran sanctions, Nafta deal
summary: Oil prices surged to 2014 highs on Monday, with Brent futures rising 2.7% to $84.98 a barrel and US light crude futures reaching $75.30 a barrel. The jump was driven by US sanctions on Iran, set to take effect on November 4, and a North American trade deal between the US and Canada. Analysts warn that higher oil prices and a strong US dollar could impact demand growth next year, while some major buyers in India and China have signaled they will cut purchases of Iranian oil.

site_title: Google ad chief Ramaswamy exits; search and AI veteran replaces him
summary: Google is replacing its top advertising executive, Sridhar Ramaswamy, with Prabhakar Raghavan, head of Google's business-applications unit. Raghavan, a veteran of search technology and AI research, will oversee product and engineering for Google's largest digital-ad business, expected to generate over $100 billion in sales this year. He will focus on maintaining growth, developing new revenue sources, and preventing commercial goals from influencing consumer services amid rising regulatory pressure and political scrutiny. Raghavan replaces Ramaswamy, who is joining Greylock Partners as a venture partner after 15 years at Google.

site_title: Shell, partners approve C$40b project to speed up gas to Asia
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and its partners have agreed to invest C$40 billion in the LNG Canada project, set to be Canada's largest infrastructure project. The project, involving Shell, Petroliam Nasional Bhd, Mitsubishi Corp, PetroChina Co, and Korea Gas Corp, will send LNG from Kitimat, British Columbia to Tokyo in about eight days, offering a faster route to Asia. The project promises better prices for Canada and reaffirms its investment climate, with potential to double capacity in a second phase due to economies of scale.

site_title: Thakral unit invests in hotel, two office buildings in Osaka
summary: Thakral Corp has invested in a hotel and two office buildings in Osaka, Japan, valued at 5.46 billion yen (S$66 million). The investments bring the company's total number of properties in Osaka to nine. The hotel, Utsubo East Building, and Legal Itachibori Building were acquired under a new pooled investment structure, with the hotel having 111 rooms and the office buildings having a gross floor area of about 5,000 sq m and 5,600 sq m, respectively. The investments are part of Thakral Corp's strategy to capitalize on growing demand in Osaka ahead of the 2020 Olympic Games and Expo 2025.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: It's all about the class
summary: Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) in Singapore are highly sought after due to their rarity, high prices (typically exceeding S$20 million), and exclusive locations. Despite market fluctuations, GCB sales have remained stable, with 10 out of 18 transactions in 2018. Interest in GCBs is expected to grow, driven by both existing ultra-wealthy individuals and the newly rich, who value their status, proximity to nature and city, and exceptional design. Prices are likely to increase, with a new generation of high net worth individuals emerging due to the growth of the Internet of Things.

site_title: Older rental blocks eligible for next Home Improvement Programme
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) will launch the second round of its Home Improvement Programme (HIP II) for older rental flats, expected to cost billions of dollars. Eligible blocks, around 60-70 years old, will benefit from the programme, which aims to address common maintenance issues. The government will ensure fiscal sustainability and pace the works to match the construction industry's capacity. Meanwhile, the Voluntary Early Redevelopment Scheme (Vers) is also being explored, with a target launch in about 10 years.

site_title: China claims more patents than any nation but most are worthless
summary: China has claimed the most domestic patents, but many are worthless due to lax approval processes and high attrition rates. Most patents lapse within five years, with design patents discarding nearly 90% and utility models discarding 61%. This is attributed to China's focus on incentivizing patent filings rather than ensuring quality, with many companies using the process to obtain benefits for staff rather than creating valuable intellectual property. Despite this, China's patent filings have bolstered sectors like artificial intelligence and cloud computing, but the country still lags behind in becoming a technologically sophisticated nation.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 gain on US-Canada trade deal
summary: US stocks rose on Monday after the US and Canada sealed a trade deal, replacing the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.7% to 26,651.21, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.4% to 2,924.59. The deal boosted market sentiment, alleviating some downside risk, but stocks finished below session highs due to concerns over oil prices, monetary policy, and slowing growth. Key stocks including General Electric and Tesla Motors also saw significant gains.

site_title: 3 office floors of The Octagon up for bulk sale with S$45.5m indicative price
summary: Three freehold office floors of The Octagon in Singapore are up for bulk sale with an indicative price of S$45.5 million, or S$2,450 per square foot. The 14th, 15th, and 17th floors, totaling 18,567 square feet, are being marketed through a tender exercise set to close on November 1, 2018. The sale price is comparable to two lower floors sold in May, and is higher than recent transactions of nearby freehold office space. Strong interest is expected due to the building's prime location and limited supply of strata office floors.

site_title: Timeless legacy
summary: Patek Philippe's World Time watch was initially developed and built by independent watchmaker Louis Cottier in 1931, with the company Patek Philippe being his biggest client. Cottier designed the world time mechanism for a pocket watch, then scaled it down to fit a wristwatch. Patek Philippe first used the movement in its Reference 1415 model in 1939, and later modified it in the 1950s to create the iconic Reference 2523 series. The 2523 is considered the world's most desired world time complication, and its design has been revisited by Patek Philippe in various models, including the Reference 5110, 5130, and 5230, which were launched in 2000, 2006, and 2016, respectively.

site_title: A counter-intuitive story of purpose and profit
summary: Innovative business models in Asian healthcare are successfully merging profit and purpose to address the region's significant healthcare challenges. Despite a large population and disease burden, Asia only accounts for 5% of global healthcare expenditure. Private sector investment has become essential to increase efficiency and meet capital needs, with seven out of every 10 new hospital beds built by private companies. New business models are emerging to provide affordable, high-quality healthcare, with companies like HealthCare Global Enterprises and the Asian Institute of Gastroenterology achieving significant impact. This trend is expected to drive robust growth in the global healthcare industry at over 15% per annum.

site_title: Building on 40 years of experience - and for the future
summary: Seiko Architectural Wall Systems, a Singapore-based SME, has maintained its professional reputation over 40 years, attributing its success to commitment to delivering on promises. CEO Rodney Cheong emphasizes the importance of retaining key staff and offering a one-stop-shop service with vertical integration. The company has taken on architecturally adventurous projects, including Changi Airport's Crowne Plaza Hotel, and has won the Singapore Enterprise 50 Award consecutively. To stay ahead, Cheong believes in leveraging technology, anticipating trends, and being forward-looking.

site_title: China Environment authorises subsidiary's creditor to take over management of unit
summary: China Environment has authorized a creditor, Lin Qun Bin, to take over management of its unit Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co, citing suspected rental income misappropriation by Anhui's existing management. Lin is tasked with ascertaining rental income and collecting it, with China Environment to receive 50,000 yuan per month. The move follows an earlier announcement by China Environment in May, which flagged potential misappropriation. Trading in China Environment stock remains suspended.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Gleam of the white knights
summary: High-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) in Asia are increasingly investing in distressed businesses as alternative investments, with several recent deals in the Singapore market showcasing this trend. HNWIs can be more creative in creating value for themselves during restructuring exercises, using methods such as injecting equity or providing funds through loan agreements. The attractiveness of distressed companies lies in their potential for long-term viability despite short-term financial issues, and HNWIs are willing to take a longer position with their investments. This trend is expected to be fueled by Singapore's emergence as a debt restructuring hub in the region.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past the windows of a new store selling official merchandise of legendary British rock group Queen in central London on September 27, 2021. (Photo by Tolga Akmen / AFP)##########queen29##########

site_title: Asia lags other regions in offering perks to help e-vehicles take off
summary: Malaysia's DHL eCommerce is testing electric vehicle pilot projects in Kuala Lumpur and Vietnam, aiming to cut logistics-related greenhouse gas emissions to zero by 2050. The project is rare in Asia, where experts say the region lags in creating incentives, regulatory frameworks, and infrastructure for electric vehicles. The DHL project is part of a global effort to replace 70% of vehicles used for "first and last mile" delivery services with cleaner energy versions by 2025. Asian governments are advised to consult with industry and consumers to improve policies on electric vehicles, including providing incentives and subsidies.

site_title: GE's US$500b market wipeout is like erasing Facebook
summary: General Electric (GE) has experienced an 81% drop in market value since its peak of $600 billion in 2000, now worth around $100 billion. The collapse, amid record-setting market gains, has left investors and analysts stunned. GE's decline has been marked by cash-flow shortages, weak sales, and a critical power segment business issue. The company is remaking itself, unloading old businesses and narrowing its focus to aviation, power generation, and renewable energy. Despite efforts to control the situation, GE's stock remains under pressure, with analysts questioning where the bottom will be.

site_title: Sea change in ship management
summary: Executive Ship Management's proprietary software system, Phoenix, has proven effective in managing its fleet of over 150 vessels. The system integrates various functions, including inventory, maintenance, and crew management, making it easier to track issues and make informed decisions. Phoenix has been adopted by the company's clients, allowing them to monitor ship performance and operation costs. The system has been sold to industry peers, with the first contract signed in September. Executive Ship Management also focuses on training its crew, having established a maritime training institute in India, and now plans to expand its fleet to 125 ships.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Singapore Airlines' Q2 results likely to be scrutinised for cost, yield pressures
summary: Singapore Airlines' Q2 results are expected to focus on cost and yield pressures due to rising jet fuel prices. The airline had hedged 46% of its fuel requirements at an average price of $65 per barrel. Analysts predict cost pressures from higher fuel prices and a possible increase in the wage bill, with one analyst stating that SIA could face cost pressures over the next two quarters.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 2 in 3 US business economists see recession by end-2020: poll
summary: A survey of 51 US business economists by the National Association for Business Economics found that 2/3 expect a recession by the end of 2020, with 56% citing trade policy as the greatest risk. The poll also found that 10% predict a recession in 2019 and 33% in 2021 or later.

images.alt_text: Economists were slightly more optimistic about the economy this year - the median forecast for inflation-adjusted GDP growth rose to 2.9 per cent from a 2.8 per cent pace projected in the June surveys.

site_title: US, Canada reach deal to salvage Nafta with revised concessions
summary: The US and Canada reached a deal to salvage the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) with Mexico, rescuing a $1.2 trillion open-trade zone. The new US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) will make it harder for global auto makers to build cars cheaply in Mexico, but avoids tariffs. Canada agreed to provide US dairy farmers access to 3.5% of its dairy market, while Mexico will require a higher proportion of car parts to be made in areas paying at least $16/hour. The deal will be submitted to Congress for approval in November.
