summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.07% to 25,462.26, as investors exercised caution amid global economic headwinds. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.85% to 2,546.33. The caution was also reflected in other Chinese bourses, which continued to experience losses.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended flat Tuesday as investors opted for caution in response to global economic headwinds, while other Chinese bourses continued their run of losses.

site_title: Stocks to watch: TEE International, Asian Healthcare Specialists, 8Telecom, HMI, C&G
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies announced new developments on Tuesday that may impact their shares. TEE International secured S$58 million engineering contracts, bringing its order book to S$304 million. Asian Healthcare Specialists entered an investment agreement with Vanda 1 Investments. 8Telecom terminated its subscription agreement with Tai Yang Technology. HMI bought additional units in Farrer Square for S$36.7 million. C&G Environmental Protection Holdings was granted an extension to finalise its reverse takeover of Param Mitra Coal Resources. ST Engineering secured new aerospace contracts worth S$590 million. Singapore Press Holdings reported a 19.7% fall in net profit for the year ended Aug 31.

site_title: Indonesia sees market stress as good thing for reforms
summary: Indonesia's weakening currency is seen as a positive catalyst for economic reforms, according to Investment Coordinating Board chairman Thomas Lembong. The government will unveil measures to increase foreign investment and open up the economy, with President Jokowi's team already discussing reforms for the second term. The currency has slumped 11% against the US dollar this year, but Lembong believes this market stress will spur reforms and potentially lead to a "fresh way of reforms." The government aims to boost economic growth and address the current-account deficit.

site_title: Asian markets hit by rout on financial conditions squeeze
summary: Asian markets, including Singapore, plummeted on Thursday due to a sharp selloff in US stocks and bonds, with the S&P 500 falling over 3% and the Nasdaq losing 4%. The decline was attributed to rising interest rates, tightening labor markets, and escalating trade tensions between the US and China. Regional markets, such as Shanghai and Hong Kong, also suffered significant losses, with the Shanghai Composite Index sinking 4.4% and the Hang Seng tumbling 3.8%.

site_title: USD expected to continue rising against Singdollar
summary: The Singapore dollar is expected to continue its "modest and gradual appreciation" against a basket of currencies, but analysts predict it will weaken against the US dollar in coming months. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) slightly steepened the slope of the Singdollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band, with forecasters expecting a USD/SGD spot rate of 1.39 by the end of 2018 and 1.41 by mid-2019. The weakening of the Singdollar is attributed to ongoing Fed rate hikes, higher USD yields, and further weakness in the Chinese yuan.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: UK businessman posts defiant anti-Brexit war cry
summary: UK businessman Charlie Mullins, CEO of Pimlico Plumbers, has posted a defiant "Bollocks to Brexit" sign at his London office, opposing the UK's planned exit from the European Union. Mullins, a self-made entrepreneur, believes the move will be a "disaster" for the British economy and is funding the Liberal Democrats' campaign for a second referendum. He estimates the UK will lose £500 million a week and will lose skilled migrants, citing Prime Minister Theresa May's ineffective negotiations. Mullins has refused to take down the sign, citing freedom of speech.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore CEO to join board of Raffles Medical Group
summary: Enterprise Singapore CEO Png Cheong Boon, 48, is joining Raffles Medical Group as an independent director, effective Oct 15. He has no prior experience as a director of a listed company but plans to take training courses. Png previously led Enterprise Singapore, CEO of JTC Corp, and Spring Singapore. The appointment follows a 0.94% increase in Raffles Medical Group's stock price to S$1.07.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Passengers ready for world's longest flight between Singapore and New York
summary: Singapore Airlines is set to launch the world's longest flight, a 19-hour journey from Singapore to New York, on Thursday. The 16,700-kilometer flight will be operated by the Airbus A350-900ULR, with 161 passengers and a crew of 21. The flight features a special "wellness" menu, over 1,200 hours of entertainment, and a modified fuel-efficient system. The airline aims to capitalize on the growing demand for non-stop services to the US, following the successful launch of similar routes by Qatar Airways.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Basslink unit is involved in arbitration with a business owned by the Australian state of Tasmania, despite a warning of potential project financing default. The dispute has no material financial impact on the trust's net tangible assets and distribution. Compact Metal Industries is no longer pursuing a 51% stake in a Mozambican cement plant after a term sheet lapsed. YuuZoo Networks Group Corp reported narrower second-quarter losses, while Jackspeed Corp's earnings rose 27.2% due to real estate associate contributions.

site_title: Rewriting the rules
summary: Workday CEO Mike Stankey believes that without innovation, a company can't survive for more than a decade. The company has disrupted the enterprise software industry by moving to the cloud, offering a premium pricing model and delivering better value to customers. Stankey attributes Workday's success to its cloud-native approach, which optimizes software code for the cloud and allows customers to access the latest version of the software easily. He also emphasizes the importance of innovation, collaboration, and employee engagement in creating a successful business model.

site_title: Melania Trump carves solo path in Africa visit
summary: Melania Trump embarked on her first solo international trip, a four-country tour of Africa, visiting Ghana, Malawi, Kenya, and Egypt. The trip, focused on her "Be Best" campaign for children's well-being, aims to carve her own diplomatic path. Unlike her predecessor Michelle Obama, Melania has kept a low profile, and this trip seeks to showcase her initiative and humanitarian efforts. The trip comes at a time when the US government is reducing global aid, with Melania set to highlight the work of the US Agency for International Development.

site_title: Increased US dollar dependence sets world up for 'liquidity crunch': analysts
summary: The US dollar's rise poses a significant risk of a global liquidity crunch, according to analysts. The increased dependence on the US dollar, which has doubled to 14% of global GDP since 2007, makes the financial system more vulnerable to a shortage of dollars. This, combined with rising US Treasury yields, could lead to a perfect storm of a liquidity crisis, as seen in the 2008 global financial crisis. Experts warn that a stronger US dollar and rising global capital costs could increase tail risks for emerging market assets and fund managers.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO after Helen Wong's retirement. The announcement comes as Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Musk's Tesla has marked its formal entry into the Indian market with a launch event in Mumbai.

site_title: Facebook, IMDA to launch startup accelerator in Singapore in February
summary: Facebook and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) of Singapore are launching a startup accelerator program, Startup Station, in February 2019. The program aims to empower data-driven startups in South-east Asia, providing co-working space, mentorship, and access to investors and the Regulatory Sandbox. This is Facebook's first data innovation startup program in Asia and its second globally. The program is designed to support startups in their growth stage with established business models and data sets.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Tuesday unveiled Startup Station, Singapore, a startup accelerator programme for data-driven startups based in South-east Asia.

site_title: Going digital on the seas and on shore
summary: Executive Ship Management has seen significant changes in the last decade as more processes go digital. The firm implemented its own web-based software system, Phoenix, in 2012, which replaced manual checklists, paper-based accounts, and radio communications. Phoenix allows for real-time data access, streamlines communication, and provides greater transparency. The system is now being upgraded to an Internet-of-Things approach, where data flows from ship sensors directly into the system, reducing the need for manual data entry.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: How to build and scale an online marketplace
summary: A study of hundreds of marketplaces running on Stripe found that revenue increased by nearly 300% year-over-year. To keep sellers and buyers coming, marketplaces should focus on seller retention, offering superior revenue-generating opportunities and valued platform services. A mobile-first model is also crucial, with integrated mobile payment options and optimized checkout flows. Building security and trust is paramount, with tokenization and anonymous communication tools being effective solutions. Finally, implementing a seamless international payment solution is key to attracting global sellers and buyers.

site_title: Mazda CEO welcomes new US, Canada, Mexico trade pact
summary: Mazda CEO Akira Marumoto welcomed a new trade deal between the US, Canada, and Mexico, which aims to increase regional value content in cars to 75% by 2025. Mazda plans to work towards meeting the agreement's requirements, particularly for vehicles made in Mexico. The deal follows separate trade agreements between the US and Mexico, and affects major Japanese carmakers operating plants in the region.

site_title: Kuwait oil to US stops for first time since 1990-91 Gulf War
summary: Kuwait has stopped shipping crude oil to the US for the first time since 1990-91 Gulf War, with US imports of Kuwaiti crude falling to zero over four weeks through late September. The halt is due to higher prices in the Asian market, where Kuwaiti oil fetches around $80 a barrel, compared to around $79 in the US. Kuwait is diverting its barrels to Asia, where prices are more lucrative, and faces production limits due to a dispute with Saudi Arabia over shared oil fields.

site_title: Industry split by scrap over ship-breaking
summary: The European Union is implementing a new ship recycling regulation that only allows European yards to be approved for recycling EU-flagged ships. The regulation, set to take effect on January 1, 2019, is expected to boost the number of ships flagged outside the EU. Environmental campaign groups support the EU-only approach, citing concerns over low-cost, non-EU ship-breaking yards with poor environmental standards. However, the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) argues that the EU List is inadequate and may discourage improvement by third-party yards, potentially harming global regulation efforts.

site_title: The 5G Frontier
summary: Singapore's telcos are weighing the advent and extent of 5G networks, with some experts predicting a long road to widespread coverage due to existing infrastructure limitations. Industry players, including Singtel, M1, and StarHub, are conducting trials and building infrastructure for 5G, but some question the viability of holding trials and investing in a system not yet fully developed. Benefits of 5G include faster and more reliable connections, enabling applications like driverless cars, drones, and virtual reality. Telcos are focusing on enterprise solutions, such as process automation and cybersecurity, with some predicting a niche market for 5G in the early stages.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Global mergers and acquisitions appetite wanes amid geopolitical concerns: EY poll
summary: Global mergers and acquisitions activity is expected to slow amid rising geopolitical concerns, according to a survey by Ernst & Young. Corporate takeover appetite has dropped to a four-year low, with only 46% of executives planning to make purchases in the next 12 months. However, the consultancy forecasts that activity will pick up in the second half of 2019. The slowdown is attributed to trade wars, regulation, and Brexit uncertainty, with companies taking more time to review their portfolios and divest assets.

site_title: Coffee industry should emulate wine, not soda: illycaffe chair
summary: Illycaffe's chairman, Andrea Illy, warns that persistently low coffee prices threaten the industry, citing a possible glut and eventual price spike. He advises the industry to focus on premium bean production, rather than mass, cheap production. Illy expects global coffee production to rise, but supply could fall in 2019/20 as low prices force farmers to abandon coffee. He criticizes the coffee industry for emulating the soft drink industry's approach, which drives down prices and eventually forces farmers out of business.

site_title: SGD bond market in Q3 is both hot and tepid
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) bond market experienced a mixed Q3, with investors snapping up fresh issues but showing limited follow-through in the secondary market. Perpetual bonds from banks like OCBC and DBS, which received strong demand, are now trading below par. HSBC's perpetual bond, with a 5% coupon, is performing well, while lesser-known issuers like Perennial Real Estate and Soilbuild Business Space REIT have seen tepid responses to their new issues. The market remains risk-averse, with investors preferring high-quality names and avoiding high-yield issuers.

site_title: Ex-Malaysian PM Najib's wife Rosmah pleads not guilty to 17 counts of money laundering and tax evasion
summary: Rosmah Mansor, the wife of former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, pleaded not guilty to 17 charges of money laundering and tax evasion, totaling over RM7 million, in Kuala Lumpur's Sessions Court. The charges stem from alleged funds obtained from money-laundering activities, with prosecutors seeking bail of RM10 million. Rosmah, who faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted, was granted bail of RM2 million with conditions, including surrendering her passports and refraining from contacting witnesses. The case marks the first time a former prime minister's spouse has been charged in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Datin Seri Rosmah Mansor, the wife of disgraced former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak, is expected to face up to 17 charges on Thursday for allegedly receiving funds obtained from money-laundering activities.

site_title: Catching your clicks
summary: Criteo, a French digital advertising software company, is repositioning itself from an ad platform of choice to a strategic partner for the open Internet. Founded by JB Rudelle in 2005, the company has built a centralized platform for retailers to buy digital ad inventory programmatically to retarget online shoppers. Criteo's revenue accounted for 7.4% of the worldwide market for digital advertising software in 2017, but the company faced growth challenges and was restructured. Rudelle returned as CEO in April 2018 to accelerate product innovation and adapt to changing consumer behavior, including the impact of Apple's Intelligent Tracking Prevention (ITP) feature and the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Criteo is now focusing on app retargeting and other technologies, and is positioning itself as a pure tech partner with no hidden agendas, to help small and medium-size enterprises maintain control of their data and relationships with users.

images.alt_text: "New discovery - that's what we're trying to do. We have no interest in showing a banner ad to someone if we don't think there's a reasonable likelihood that they're going to click on the ad. We get paid only if there are true engagements." - JB Rudelle.

site_title: An app that knows when you've been in an accident - and then calls emergency services for you
summary: A new app called Noonlight, which connects people with rescue services, has introduced a feature called "automatic crash detection and response." The app uses smartphone sensors to detect changes in motion and force, alerting 911 in the event of an accident. If emergency services are not needed, the app sends a virtual alarm with the user's location and medical information, and dispatchers contact the user for confirmation. The service costs $10 a month and aims to help vulnerable populations, such as teenagers and the elderly.

site_title: Indonesian rescuers hold hope for survivors as scale of disaster emerges
summary: Rescuers in Indonesia's Sulawesi island are searching for survivors of a devastating earthquake and tsunami that struck on Friday, with the death toll rising to 844, mostly in Palu city. Officials fear the toll will rise into the thousands, and international aid is being accepted. Power remains out, and access to remote areas is disrupted, with liquefaction causing widespread destruction. Aftershocks have caused concern, and nearly 60,000 people have been displaced. The government is working to meet survivors' immediate needs and is preparing for international assistance.

images.alt_text: The extent of the devastation caused by an earthquake and tsunami on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi should become clearer on Tuesday, as rescuers push into remote areas that have been out of contact for more than three days.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Monday, following China's central bank decision to cut reserve requirements to support the economy. The Hang Seng Index rose, despite mainland markets sinking due to a week-long holiday and global sell-off. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.88%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index tumbled 2.10%.

images.alt_text:
Bundles of 100 yuan (14.6 USD) notes are pictured at a bank in Shanghai on August 8, 2018.
A rally in Asian markets stuttered on August 8, with early gains pared as the US-China trade row erodes investor confidence. But the yuan got some support after a news report said the Chinese central bank had emphasised the need for currency stability to the country's lenders as it looks to halt a slide in recent months. / AFP PHOTO / Johannes EISELE##########cfyuan##########

site_title: 10 years of bringing joy to children
summary: CHILDREN for Children (CFC) celebrated 10 years of fundraising for disadvantaged children in Singapore, marking over 10,000 children's trips to iconic attractions since 2008. The initiative, jointly organized with The Business Times, CHIJ (Kellock), and The RICE Company Ltd, has raised funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, which has provided over 16,000 children with arts training and performing opportunities since 2004.

images.alt_text: Students from CHIJ (Kellock) performing rhythmic gymnastics as part of the musical titled Journey to Your Dreams.

Children for Children 2018: (L-R) Colin Goh (The RICE Company), Tong Ka-Pin, (Perennial Real Estate Holdings), Yong Shu Ying (ING Bank); Gary Lau, (ERA Realty Network Singapore), Kenneth Kam (Kenn Foundation), Belinda Yew (Resorts World Sentosa), Magdalene Chin (CHIJ Kellock), Alvin Tay (The Business Times Budding Artists Fund), Jennie Chua (The RICE Company), Desmond Lee (Minister for Social and Family Development), Wong Wei Kong (The Business Times), Jack Chua (ERA Realty Network Singapore), Kwek Eik Sheng (Hong Leong Foundation and City Developments Ltd), Jonathan Kek (Hong Leong Holdings), Yet Pek Yeen (Hong Leong Finance), Cheong Hai Poh (Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel, Millennium Hotels and Resorts), and Sherilyn Chua (Singapore Pools).
Students from CHIJ (Kellock) performing rhythmic gymnastics as part of the musical titled Journey to Your Dreams.

site_title: What keeps US Federal Reserve's Powell up at night? Everything
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed concerns about getting monetary policy right, citing risks from inflation, interest rates, and economic instability. Despite positive economic indicators, including low unemployment and moderate inflation, he noted that the US economy faces global risks, such as rising protectionism and a slowing China. Powell also warned about potential crises, including cyber-attacks and global events, and expressed optimism about the impact of lower tariffs on trade with China. He emphasized the need for careful consideration of these risks, stating "basically everything" keeps him up at night.

images.alt_text: Is inflation about to rise? Are interest rates too high? Or too low? Are economic risks lurking? These are the fears that keep US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell from getting a good night's sleep.

site_title: Stark differences in US life expectancy: demographic trends
summary: US life expectancy varies significantly across different neighborhoods, with some areas experiencing life expectancies of over 96 years and others under 60 years. A study by the National Center for Health Statistics found stark differences in life expectancy within 5 miles of the White House, with Friendship Heights, Maryland averaging 96.1 years and Anacostia's Barry Farm averaging 63.2 years. Factors such as income, access to healthcare, and environmental conditions influence life expectancy, with states like Maryland, New York, and Oklahoma exhibiting the greatest differences.

images.alt_text: Maryland, New York and Oklahoma are the states with the greatest differences. One neighborhood in Albany, the state capital of New York, has an average life expectancy of 60.4 years, while the average in Harrison, about 150 miles to the south, is just shy of 93 years.

site_title: Ellen Bettridge
summary: Uniworld, a luxury river cruise company, has seen significant growth in Asia, with sales in Singapore jumping 25% year-on-year and in Malaysia increasing 10 times. CEO Ellen Bettridge attributes this success to the relaxing and pampering experience offered by river cruises, which appeal to mature travelers seeking a unique and leisurely experience. Asian clients, particularly in their 50s and 60s, tend to book late and enjoy socializing with fellow passengers, with many opting for European itineraries such as the Danube and Rhine. Uniworld has also introduced a new brand, U by Uniworld, catering to a younger demographic with a more modern and vibrant atmosphere.

images.alt_text: "It is an opportunity to really take it easy. It's about getting on board your beautiful floating hotel, unpacking just once, and having everything taken care of for you for the next seven, 10 or 25 days." - Ellen Bettridge
Helmi Yusof

site_title: Army of tiny Tigers driving China's young golf boom
summary: China's young golfers are driving the country's growing interest in the sport, with thousands of children taking up the game despite its previously elite image. The China Golf Association reports a 35,000-fold increase in junior golfers since 2013, with 100,000 expected within five years. Child golfers like six-year-old Lai Runci are competing in tournaments and practicing daily, with some parents pushing their children to play as early as six years old. The sport's increasing popularity is seen as a way for Chinese children to gain a competitive edge in the country's highly competitive education system.

images.alt_text: Lai Runci practises every day and looks very much the golfer as she pings the ball effortlessly off the tee. She is aged six.

site_title: JetBlue plans to grow by adding more flights, selling travel services
summary: JetBlue Airways plans to expand its operations by adding more flights to Boston and Fort Lauderdale, increasing its presence at New York's John F Kennedy International Airport, and selling more travel services such as car rentals and hotels. The airline aims to boost earnings by as much as $3 per share in 2020, topping analysts' estimates. To achieve this, JetBlue will focus on improving on-time performance, reducing costs through a renegotiated maintenance contract, and increasing seats on some planes.

images.alt_text: JetBlue's plans represent a new push to broaden revenue sources while trying to contain rising costs from pricier fuel and new and pending labour contracts.

site_title: Independent auditors include disclaimer of opinion on Ipco International's financial statements; material differences reported in bottom-line numbers
summary: Ipco International's independent auditors have issued a disclaimer of opinion on the company's financial statements for the year to April 30, citing material differences in bottom-line numbers. The auditors were unable to obtain sufficient evidence to support an audit opinion due to issues such as the validity of the going-concern basis and potential misstatements in the carrying value of land held for sale. The company has reported a net loss of S$43.44 million, which was later revised to S$20.49 million after overstating expenses by almost S$22.95 million.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: I See You: Is our data safe, and are we safe from our data?
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation initiative relies heavily on vast amounts of data collection, raising concerns over cybersecurity and ethics. The government has implemented measures to protect data, but experts warn that proper public education and ethical protocols are crucial to prevent social divide and potential harm from AI. Companies must balance data protection with responsible use, while regulations and guidelines are still being formulated. Efforts to educate Singaporeans on AI and its implementation are underway, but a lack of awareness and understanding can lead to mistrust and fear, ultimately hindering the benefits of Smart Nation initiatives.

images.alt_text: I SEE YOU: As we build our Smart Nation, is our data safe, and are we safe from our data?

"AI is like fire. After fire was discovered, it took a while for humans to realise that we need not only the fire, but also all kinds of things to make it useful, including regulations, safety measures, and people like firefighters." - Chen Tsuhan, deputy president of research and technology at NUS, and chief scientist at AI Singapore.

"We need to regulate this (AI) the same way we've regulated every other industry where there was a benefit and a significant risk both to the public as well as to trusted public institutions." - Janil Puthucheary, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Transport and Ministry of Communication and Information.

"It's a challenge to keep your information private. But the question is, what information should remain private?" - Subodh Mhaisalkar, executive director of the Energy Research Institute @ NTU (ERI@N)
